Must have!! The cover texture is amazing.: [[VIDEOID:d2864aa427104384ac5f0d2727c9dbf6]] This book is AN ABSOLUTE MUST!! It was the quickest impulse decision of 2022. I didn’t realize there was a book, so I was already excited to get it. 2 days later when it arrived I was ecstatic after opening the box. Once I touched the book, I was in love!! Total SG fan & this is absolutely phenomenal.

Great read! Especially recommend for cyclists.: I’m an avid cyclist & was particularly fond of the storyline, clicked buy. After reading I can honestly say this was a good read. It takes place in the past & present. Without spoiling it, each chapter alternates. You’ll read current, next chapter will be from the past & she seamlessly pulls the story together. I enjoyed reading about a cycling journey & the accuracy measure was spot on. The author has done cross country rides of her own, so you could tell it was thought out & believable. I’m not into ultra endurance cycling, but this book sure made me have thoughts of doing one someday. I bought used because I like to support book stores. Cheers to your next ride & next book, may they both be enjoyable!

Inviting & very pretty journal! Do not need to have read the book.: I’m so in love with the design & cheetah. I adore the matching book & journal set. I recommend the journal even if you’re not interested in reading the book. The journal can be used as a stand alone interactive journal. Very pretty design & hardcover is heavyweight. Great purchase & will look good on the book shelf for years to come.
A gifted storyteller: Gogol was a natural storyteller. Unpredictable plots, wild imagination and a gorgeous style. Four stars only because of the unavoidable recurrent antisemitism.

Seminole Hamlet: This is a beautiful written novel and deeply poignant. Tony Tiger futility tries to fight against being steamrolled by “progress”. Whether he fights against it or accepts it he looses. The unfairness and absurdity is real and he knows it but it doesn’t matter because the odds are impossible. Toby Tiger is like Hamlet in his inability to accept the evil in the world. Smith draws sensitive portraits of the non Seminoles who were sympathetic and tried to help, and graphic pictures of the ignorant people who have always existed. The father-in-law is a survivor to adapts rather than perishes but at a price, and the Medicine Man who lost his purpose and has reduced his knowledge to a sales pitch. Sad and beautiful novel.

Gifted Writer: I am fascinated by Apocalyptic Novels and this is the best I’ve read. Heller is a gifted writer and his descriptions are wonderful but there’s more to this novel than good writing. There’s compassion here and kindness and a man who is in the midst of chaos and violence and he manages to maintain his humanity. There is insight into others character and an assessment of people that is deep and his relationship and love of his dog. Hig is strong, tough and brave but never macho. I don’t usually read a book twice but I will with this one.

Fascinating, Somewhat Political: Before this book came out there were reports of people living in RV or vans for economic reasons. 2008 knocked some people, mostly older, out of the middle class. Most  jobs loss was due to workers who were replaced by a younger person, or had a financially devastating divorce, or were marginal to begin with. Apparently some of the people lived this way by choice. Despite the fascinating details, the author’s political views intruded on an otherwise interesting documentary. It’s inaccurate to say Amazon just produced junk that ended up in a landfill 6 months later. In many ways Bezos is a modern-day Henry Ford. It was simplistic to assumed the reason the Nomads were largely white was because of police stops of black drivers. The movie version of this book was one of the few  films that I’ve seen that was better than the book. The brilliant Chinese-American director of that film managed to tell the story in all its complexity minus the politics and it made all the difference.

Great adaptation with illustrations that help reinforce the text. The concepts are SOLID!: If you're looking for a book that's easy to read as a typical book, get the original version. It's PHENOMENAL, as is this, but for different reasons, but both have the GOLDEN content of wisdom from Snyder.  I had the audio version and when this came out, I decided to buy the paperback version in this form so I could have something to easily reference when I needed to. And we ALL should be referencing this book, DAILY. It should be required reading for all high schoolers, if we truly cared about our nation and preserving it.

Like all other Disney recipe books, this one is severely disappointing.: I had hoped this book would be different from past Disney Parks recipe books, but in many ways, it was worse.
Let’s start with the hard binding isn’t at all conducive to a cookbook which is what this is supposed to be. They only added “stories” to the title because the publisher simply didn’t have enough to fill the page count they needed to make their price-point. I worked in publishing for over a decade, I know a stretch when I see one.

Next, let’s address that a sizable portion of the recipe contained in this book are well over 3 decades old in that they haven’t been made on property for at least that long. I couldn’t care less about that many recipes few have ever heard of let alone tried.

Getting back to the filling a book w fluff issue. There is simply WAY too much story text in here. Honestly, there are dozens of books w that info in it. I would buy them if that’s what I wanted. But no, they needed to fill a book very weak on content, so we got a lot of big photos w stories taking up valuable real estate that would have been better served on recipes. Of the recipes they did include, I haven’t heard of or tasted most of them! That’s coming from someone who has been visiting Disney parks as an adult for 30 years. That’s exceptionally disappointing.

I haven’t tried to make any of the recipes yet, but if this book is like past books, they’re going to be nothing like their namesake either. Calling something “Dole Whip inspired “ is NOT a Dole Whip recipe. Anything can be inspired by anything else. That’s weak sauce (pun intended).

In the end, I’d return this is Amazon didn’t make returns so cumbersome now. Save your money. Skip this.

Garbage: I’ve read probably 100 books on leadership and this might be the worst. These concepts are dated and sometimes evil. You can easily succeed by doing the exact opposite of what he suggests. Not much practical application here. The most overrated book of all time.

Sheer torture: The headline says it all. Sheer torture.

I read novels for escape and enjoyment. Any of which can show up in the form of sticky character development, compelling plot lines, lyrical writing, creative use of language. This tiresome chronicle of progressive descent into madness provided not so much as a whiff of any of these. Had I not been reading it for a book club, I would not have gotten past a quarter of it.

Enjoyable distraction: But…it’s one of those murder mysteries where the author gives very little leading up to the plot reveal. So that, when the resolution does come, it isn’t foreshadowed, which makes it unsatisfying. I prefer to be given bits and pieces so when the reveal does come there’s an “aha” moment. But I enjoyed the historical aspects.

Riveting, vivid and haunting: I was so deeply affected by this magnificent book that I am writing this review several months after I finished reading it. Its grip on me hasn't relaxed during all that time.

The book's subtitle references "race, fate and sisterhood;" I certainly don't mean to deny the relevance of race to the story. A great part of Ms. Turner's apparent purpose in writing the book is to dramatize the razor-thin margin for error with which she, her sister, her best friend, and her surrounding family and friends had to operate in the south Chicago development where they lived. Any unlucky event, any bad decision, could have lasting adverse consequences. She looks at her sister's and her best friend's lives and how differently they turned out from her own, despite similarities in talent and intelligence, and seems genuinely shaken by the thought, "There but for the grace of God go I." She is haunted by how little forks in the road can lead some people up, but others way down, even the best and closest of friends who initially seem to be on the same road.

But I would suggest that what makes this book outstanding are not the aspects specific to the author's situation, but the aspects that are universal. Because anyone who has passed through childhood has no doubt noticed many of the phenomena that Ms. Turner documents so sensitively, even if we lack her eloquence in translating them into words.

Turner is such a skilled writer that she is able to transport the reader back to the playgrounds of elementary school recess, and how other kids appeared to us there. She conveys the truly salient details that place the reader in these scenes almost as effectively as a time machine could -- the belch of a bubble of water in a cooler, the scent of copier ink, the girl who sticks her tongue out at you if she catches you advertently looking too long in her direction, and so forth.

The writing is precise and vivid, sophisticated but always accessible and brisk. There were multiple scenes where my heart was in my mouth, feeling the tension or emotion of a moment. The author never expends many words or much space creating these emotional effects. She simply describes them so well that you feel as though you are there, experiencing them with her. No doubt her task is aided by the fact that many of the events recounted pack a heavy emotional wallop. But few writers could have captured these moments so well.

Ms. Turner's book deals with a topic I find inherently fascinating -- how it is that children who bond so closely in preadolescence go on to live such different lives and experience such different fates? Again, this is a universal phenomenon. Who among us hasn't noticed it at some level? We can all think of kids we were close to way back in elementary school, and note how when adolescence hit later, we started to gravitate in different directions. Looking back, one can detect the early signs of these differences at younger ages. But in those early childhood years, kids are focused on their common ground, not their differences, and so they don't see them.

Similarly, you can detect these differences distinguishing Dawn Turner from her sister Kim and from her best friend Debra. Dawn is more cautious, more studious, someone who observes and reflects first, and acts later. Both Kim and Debra are more creatures of instinct, people who act first and then reflect later. This is not to suggest that they are any less intelligent or gifted than the author, but only that the temperamental differences between people can be glimpsed in early youth before becoming more pronounced and consequential later in life.

Another interesting aspect of this book (for me) is how Ms. Turner is harder on herself than on anyone else. She doesn't shy away from recording episodes in which one might find fault with her conduct; there is no self-justification in this book, even though it seems apparent that her achievements and skills would justify more than a little bit of pride in her journey. In particular I was struck by how she never portrays her eventual-ex-husband in an uncharitable way, even though as we all know, the end of a marriage can be very difficult and no doubt there are resentments and grievances on both sides. She doesn't permit herself to portray any situation at his expense, even though she is sometimes critical of herself. For me this added to the integrity and perceived credibility of her account.

In sum, while there are aspects of this story that arise from the particular circumstances and background of the people who move through it, the author weaves a tale I believe is universally resonant and thought-provoking: why do we end up in such different places from seemingly similar beginnings? The answers aren't in this book, but it's a very fine place to start framing these questions.

My three year old is learning how to talk quietly and cover his mouth vs yelling. He is gradually improving and wants to read this book often. I’m so pleased with this book I’m planning to buy the rest of the toddler tools books and these behavior books too.

By the way, where was Charlie Parker? He seemed to make a cameo appearance in his own storyline...

Beautifully written wonderful story: This is the kind of book you savour, you don't want to read it too fast as the story is massive and the writing is perfect. I'm quite sad that I finished the book but oh so happy I read it.
The early parts about the Spanish Civil War were difficult for me, such brutality and sadness for so many years, yet they helped to remind me that such political conflicts can turn ugly if allowed. The family journeys and the constant love and support through difficulty and hardships is an inspiring story.
If you are hesitating to read this book don't, just start and you will enjoy and epic tale.

If you like Hallmark movies you may like this book: There are so many better books about WWII heroes I cannot recommend reading this one. The writing is mediocre and some of the characters are merely cliché personae. The dialogue, and there is a fair amount, is tedious.
Based on true stories of forgers who saved lives but otherwise nothing redemptive here.
To be fair most of my book club friends liked it so you may too. Hallmark channel bound.
Fantastic Book: I purchased several cookie decorating books when I began this journey and this book by far exceeds all the others put together. I refer to it all the time

Good Book!: In my opinion, this is a good book, but not a great book. Something seems to be missing; it is the usual interaction between characters that usually keeps me reading. I read the book in one sitting but had difficulty is staying as interested as these books usually keep me.
I will continue to purchase any books in this series though; they can't all be great!

Enjoyed the plot of the story: Yes yes I did enjoy this book. It has a plot over all and it is interesting how it ends. I don’t want to give out too much but i consider to be a romance/suspense/thriller. Great for young audience. Middle school and up.

history: B07K1MTH2Z B0775X2BM8 B07FNDHJ1T B07QHXDQ17 B07Y61LC6V B083H39WJ6 B07HNRW3C1 B07Z2ZHHCM
review: Can a girls dreams come true?: A chance for HEA, Ariel Number style!  This was a very anticipated read for me, I was not disappointed.  This author has woven this universe in a unique and entertaining journey.  Ariel is my kind of girl!  Not afraid to go after what she wants.  We got a little more insight on the personalities and lots and lots of steam. You are missing out if you haven't read this series!  Very glad to hear its not over.  Keep writing, Mary, and I will continue to read and buy your books!
Very Informative.: Very informative for beginners.
Love it!: Very detailed. Packed with interesting information. Grandson loves it.
Very classy: Recipes a little complicated for a beginner, but I love the stories.

Great insight: This book tells the story of the money that changes hands between the young basketball players. The prospects of life changing monetary gain held at arms length away. It also tells of how once certain groups start to gain access to too much money it is time to change the game instructions. This is the old rule of this game is for white folks only all others beware.
As described, timely delivery: Her books are all good.
Interesting reading: The variety and to read of course.
Wonderful True Spy Book: A great book about the CIA, spy craft and incredible patriots who served honorably in our clandestine operations to keep our country safe.
I have all these cooking books: I have all volume of these books but not once captured me to bake from the recipes. I like the looks of the book but the urge to bake is not there.

I’m hooked: I made the No Butter No Chicken (page 191) using the cashew cream (page 115) tonight. Very easy recipe, took no time to put together. Let it simmer while my rice cooked and enjoyed an absolutely delicious meal! Highly recommend! Looking forward to more good eating from this beautifully laid out cook book.

Excellent read: Growing up I wanted to be Hayley Mills. Or at least pretty much all of the characters she played. I loved her Disney films and Tiger Bay and Whistle Down the Wind were 2 favorite non-Disney movies. I know I’ve seen both countless times. I was excited when I heard she’d written a memoir and it is totally worth reading. She’s had an interesting life. And she comes across as honest and likable. Definitely 5 stars.
It’s All About Mel: A great fun read. Lots of behind the scenes stories about the greatest comedies that make me laugh no matter how many times I’ve seen them. Mel is a wonder!
Good and informative: Perfect for my needs
Great book: My grandson loved it.  He’s totally into fire engines.
Granddaughter loved it.: It seems like a lot of chapter books today are about dragons & fantasy.  I bought this book to expand my 8-yr-old granddaughter’s interests.  And she loved it!

Changing my review from four stars to two stars: Original review: **** Cute pictures, nice story.
Revised review: ** I think the cute pictures over-influenced me when writing my original review. The “story” is pretty thin and I abhor the use of the word “hate”.

Helen Tunsten rules!: A great novella featuring the wily Maud, a spirited senior citizen who solves problems in her own way - permanently. Maud prevails with the Swedish police, but comes up against suspicious South African police.
Great premise but ended up confusing: Excellent prose but too many by moving parts led to confusion at the end. Plot was difficult to follow in the closing chapters.
Dave Barry is hilarious.: More of Dave Barry’s offbeat humor - perfect gift for Florida resident.
It’s Selena: Who doesn’t love Selena? She was amazing and her life was taken way too early. This book makes you believe in love. They are truly inspirational.
5 stars: Beautiful book and message.
Great: Perfect
Amazing: Love how each book has a mini lesson with each sight word
An excellent read: I learned a lot. This is an excellent book, very easy to read and enormously informative. I wish the author the best after his ongoing ordeal.

Wow!: Just finished this. Totally a page turner. Plot includes a blend of family life and that of  a working attorney. Totally excellent. My only criticism related to the number of characters. I had to ask myself a few times. "Now, who is this, again?"  Otherwise, quite a story that I highly recommend.

Noticeably contrived plot: First of all, who is the author writing for? I think it's for men in their 80s because who really cares about Frank Sinatra and the Rat Pack now, especially if you are a woman, what with all the carousing and slut-shaming going on in this book and the apparent female sex trafficking going on along with it? And if he wanted to write about Robert Kennedy and Peter Lawford,  why didn't he write about the time a few months after this story takes place that involves how these two were apparently at Marilyn Monroe's house looking for a red diary on the day/night before she died? And apparently she had partied at Frank Sinatra's house a week or two before that time, with several of Sinatra's associates in attendance, who may have raped her there? That would be a far more interesting storyline than the one depicted in this book. As for plot development, it seemed contrived in a similar way that daytime soap opera storylines are contrived. I think the author could have done better. I give this book four stars for some information provided otherwise unknown to me and important but, come on, really? ( PS ... My information on Marilyn Monroe was from two books by the late Richard Belzer. "Hit List" and "Dead Wrong."

Where's the drama?: A Kindle read for me. Thought it sounded interesting but there's no drama at 28% through it. I'm totally bored and feel I'm wasting my time with it. Totally disappointed. I recommend buying a different book for a better reading experience.

Enjoyable, but too many travel details.: I liked that Ms. Andres recapped her first book at the start, telling about her harsh growing up years. This book covers her quick rise to stardom and much of her Hollywood career. She is a charming person and it shows in her writing. She rarely has harsh words for anyone.  That said, there was an overabundance of small details as she traveled from one home or job to the other.  You would find which of her children made it for a holiday at the chalet, and which didn't, and why, complete with their boyfriend or girlfriend problems. That said, there were lots of intimate details of her life and her husband Blake Edwards' life, including mental health issues. I prefer when stars talk more about the intricacies of their work. Yes, she does discuss a lot of the filming details, but too often the flow is interrupted by more recountings about who missed a plane or who had the flu. But I still adore her and her talents.

Pale horsesh*t: I love love love a good conspiracy theory.  I’ve been very sure for my entire life that reality, history, etc. are not exactly as presented to the majority.  However, to believe this book, there have to be plot holes in reality.  If the elite secret societies are that powerful, why not just end us all and take our stuff? Do we exist just to be the butt of their jokes?  Why educate us, allow us technology and social mobility if they think we’re all such stupid animals?  Also, the author gives so many backhanded compliments to Lucifer I almost started liking the devil(jk).  Ultimately, when I read stuff like this, I wonder why they haven’t just carried their plans out already? According to this, they answer to nobody but themselves(or do they?!)  I live in a house, not a pod, I don’t eat bugs, and I teach Yoga, not nothing.  What beautiful, benevolent force is stopping them from taking over? Is it god? An opposing secret society? Aliens? And why does nobody in all the  conspiracy theory books I read ever talk about them?

Ehhh…: I don’t really like the tone this book is written in.  Author assumes you will be absolutely bewildered by any and all yoga concepts and talks down to the reader. At other places it’s just a bit cringey…at one point it says “Enlightenment, baby!” or something like that. Yikes. It’s not my preference but some may like it or think it makes difficult concepts more accessible. I’m also not sure who the intended audience for this book is:  I certainly need something more in depth as a seasoned practitioner, but newbies in the reviews are saying it’s not descriptive enough for them. Kinda just a miss.

A little-known but very important feature of the US Civil War (1861-65): This was a gift given to a Civil War buff who is very knowledgeable, but never really explored this fascinating economic facet of America's civil war.  He is enjoying it and says he's picking up a lot of new information he never knew prior to reading the book.  Highly recommended.
The book arrived on time and in good condition: This was a gift, but it looks very interesting and gets good reviews for covering aspects of the War of 1812 that are more than just military tactics.

Enough with the personal politics!: So we have to cancel ancient Egypt now? Yes lets cancel people and their decisions made over 3,000 years ago. Of course men ruled Egypt, just like every other civilization since the beginning of time.  Wokeism is trash and this "professor" will of course make money off hating and badmouthing the very civilization she's dedicated her life to. Ridiculous....

Not good: I frequently see Ms. Ratajkowski complain about how she has always been sexualized. She doesnt like being known for only her body, ok fine, then why are you always naked and posed in a sexual manner? Almost all her social media photos are of her scantily clad. She willing appeared topless in a music video but "dont you dare sexualize" her. Dumb.....

Cover is not classic per discription: I order the classic version of this book. The classic does not have a green grinch and is to be consistent with the original version. Too my surprise it arrives with a metallic shine on the cover. Not classic! This is important as the bible study I am doing is specific to the original class version. May need to buy used version.
Disappointed

Purrfect: This calendar exceeds my expectations. I need one large enough to include multiple appointments each day written with a Bic Mark it which is dark and thick enough for me to see from a distance. Each daily box meets my needs!
The monthly cat photos and comments are fun. The price can't be beat. I highly recommend this calendar

Gift - parents thrilled: This was a gift for a toddler. His parents are thrilled with book and had put it on the little ones list.  Little one is set on favorites at the moment. However, at some point a more variety will be welcome and this will be available.

Great exposure but hard to read: Good memoir, because this is how life was for Roberta, but yikes, it's hard to read. Very few characters are in the book for longer than a chapter and so many folks go in and out that it's hard to keep track.

I had a hard time landing with the author's birth privilege but it's authentic so I think that's actually a good thing.

It's not "Once Upon a Car" but no one else wrote about this the same way: Want an American take on the DCX mess? Read Vlassic. Thanks, Bill. I'm too young to have watched this play out in the news but I interned for DCX the summer of 2007 during the divorce and I always had unresolved feelings about "what did I just experience??". This book helped me.

Wonderfully narrative account of what could have just been a series of newspaper clippings, but I appreciated meeting Schrempp, if he wasn't himself this wouldn't have happened.

The first half is immersive and intense, second half is... American: I loved Nina's stories of Siberia and Piloting, I loved the Euro hunt for Lorelei, but continental story didn't land with me. Jordan has some alienating privilege and the chain of events during the pursuit are increasingly unlikely. None of the romance seemed authentic (and not creepy) to me.

Vivid and real characters wrap you up in heart squeezing adventure: This story made me feel like a kid again. At 13 years old, having no experience in life but plenty of intelligence, the author uses Odie to create the kind of romanticism that makes me nostalgic for my own youth. Odie and his family of kids trust each other and love ferociously while trying to figure it out in the big world.

I was distracted from my normal life by this book and its absence from my hand until I finished it, and what an ending! I can't think of any possible ending with more poetic justice and perfect resolve. My only regret is that I wish for more Maybeth in the story.
A charming book about obsolescence: I liked the text and illustration layout and the timeless story, and so does my toddler.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2
review:
A good science-based series.: This is not the first Body Farm novel I've read and I've totally enjoyed them all. I always learn something about forensic science by reading these books, plus I get the added benefit of a great story. In this book, Dr. Bill Brockton is tasked with identifying the remains of hundreds of bodies dumped by an unscrupulous crematorium operator. At the same time, a former colleague who has threatened to kill him has escaped and is prepared to stop at nothing to eliminate the one person he blames for his downfall - Dr. Brockton. All in all, a recipe for high drama.
I like the way the authors play the characters off each other. There is plenty of snark, both on the part of Brockton and his students.
This is a good series for those who enjoy medical thrillers, crime fiction and science based fiction. You won't be disappointed with Jefferson Bass.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2 B0010SEP20
review:
Strange but compelling.: Bloodless has arguably the strangest conclusion of any Pendergast books to date. It reminded me of some of the old sci-fi novels from the dawn of the atomic age. Like all Pendergast books, this one contained the same mysterious personas that grace the pages all through this series. We do get to learn more about Constance Greene here. I learned enough to never get on her bad side if I ever chance to meet her.
There are plenty of hints that lead you to believe there will be at least one sequel in the future and to that I give a heart felt Hurrah. I've loved all the books in this series and I hope they don't stop anytime soon.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2 B0010SEP20 B08PV5J8BT
review:
America as perhaps it truly is.: When I began this novel, I suppose I was expecting The Godfather. At first I was a bit disappointed but as I got deeper into the story, the more I came to appreciate the richness of the story and the depth of the characters. This is a saga of power brokers in the movie and gambling industries and the sacrifices that need to be made in order to remain at the top. As with the Corleones , family is foremost with the families in this novel.
I like the subtlety with which Puzo presented the scenes of violence. There is violence, to be sure, but little gratuitous gore. Puzo makes his points but doesn't gut punch the reader while doing it. This is a story that draws the reader in slowly and deliciously.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2 B0010SEP20 B08PV5J8BT B000FC29JI
review:
A hauntingly strange tale: Okay, pigs can be a bit creepy. They eat anything, even people. I was on a farm once many years ago for some work I was doing and had to cross a small fenced in area to get to where I needed to be. A pig, A big one came around the corner and had this look on its face that told me that if I took one more step, I'd be his own private smorgasbord. This book, and the character Pearl, brought that memory back to me.
Okay two. Josh Malerman is decidedly weird. I've read several of his books and he definitely flies in a different stratosphere from most of us. Pearl is horror, no two ways around it. It has a Steven King flavor to it (think "Cujo") that kept me reading. I'll never turn my back on a pig again.
The only thing that kept me from giving this book five stars is that I thought the ending could have been better. It felt like the author wasn't sure how to conclude the story. It's not a bad ending, mind you, just not as good as I thought I'd could have been.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2 B0010SEP20 B08PV5J8BT B000FC29JI 0593237838
review:
Disturbing glimpse into the mind of a psychopath.: This book is disturbing on many levels. It is basically a loosely defined journal written by the protagonist, Russell, outlining his descent into mental illness and serial murder. His life is a series of rejection and pain, beginning as a child with his parents, through high school with classmates he thought were friends, into the working world in a series of dead end jobs and climaxing with being thrown out of his sister's home. All this has a decidedly negative effect on Russell. He kills and skins cats and then moves to women. The descriptions of some of Russell's acts were disturbing, to be sure, but what I found most disturbing of all was the fact that real life Russells walk among us.
This book does provide an authentic view of the mindset of a true psychopath. It has some violent scenes and crude language and some readers may find it too rough for their tastes, but it isn't the kind of read that one soon forgets.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2 B0010SEP20 B08PV5J8BT B000FC29JI 0593237838 B07NSG5XTS
review:
A mystery wrapped in an expose.: This book has a number of themes - retribution, mystery and, probably most compelling of all, an examination of the financial and moral excesses of megacorporations, in this case Silicone Valley. Lou McCarthy is a disenfranchised journalist who takes it upon herself to take on the Raum Corporation, the richest and most powerful company ever created, because of their almost criminal disregard for the lives of those they trample on their quest for an ever larger share of the information world. As one might suspect, this is far easier said than done. Along the way, Lou teams up with some unlikely allies.
The characterizations of corporations in this book are reminiscent of the muckraking tomes from the early Twentieth Century, highlighting as it does all the ugliness and smarm that is too often found in these megafirms. If I have anything negative to say about the book it is that it is decidedly anti-male. I suppose this is the norm for the current sociopolitical atmosphere but it still disturbed me.
On the whole, 1414° is a good, solid mystery. Some of the scenes may be a bit beyond the realm of belief but that just adds to the fun.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2 B0010SEP20 B08PV5J8BT B000FC29JI 0593237838 B07NSG5XTS B09DF2VGVH
review:
I couldn't put it down.: It took me to almost the last third of this delicious book before I figured out it was fiction, albeit fiction with a healthy dose of reality. It is written in the style of a true crime chronicle and the author places himself into the role of main character and narrator. However one might feel about this style, it works. This book grabbed me from the get-go and never let go. The only negative I could find was that I felt the ending could have been more detailed, such as more on the fate of the Boogeyman.
The story is based in a small town in Maryland. This makes it doubly frightening because it could actually happen and it could happen anywhere. Reading this book reminded me of books written about Ted Bundy. The killing and mutilation of the Boogeyman's victims was similar to Bundy. If you enjoy true crime or crime fiction, you won't be disappointed with this one.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2 B0010SEP20 B08PV5J8BT B000FC29JI 0593237838 B07NSG5XTS B09DF2VGVH B08LDY63RX
review:
A fun, well written mystery.: This is the fourth book in th Chronicles of Cyric series set in the same realm as the Heir to the Crown series. While it helps, it is not necessary to have read any or all of the Crown series to enjoy these wonderful mysteries. In this story, poorer townspeople begin dying from what is feared to be a mysterious plague. Brother Cyric is tasked with investigating the cause of the malady and becomes embroiled in a much deeper mystery.
I liked this book. It was easy to read and the action flowed smoothly. If I have any criticism at all, it would be the fact that I found the mystery easy to figure out. Still, the conclusion of the book was satisfying.
Paul Bennett is a good writer. He builds a fantasy world that is believable and populates it with relatable characters.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2 B0010SEP20 B08PV5J8BT B000FC29JI 0593237838 B07NSG5XTS B09DF2VGVH B08LDY63RX B09P46BTRH
review:
An interesting twist: I don't read a lot of science fiction. So much of the genre is space-operish. Mickey7 is different. Yes, there are alien life forms and interstellar travel, but the book doesn't make these aspects the main theme. Mickey7 is an Expendable, a person whose main function is to perform the most dangerous and deadly jobs in the colony. When, not if, he dies, he is regenerated with all the memories and quirks of his just dead predecessor. Mickey7 is the 7th such iteration. The fun begins when he is dropped into a chasm and presumed dead. When he works his way back, he has already been replaced.
I liked the pace and writing of this book. The author provided a nice mix of science and alternate history as Mickey7 struggles with his role. I think even readers who don't like Sci-Fi would enjoy this one.
As about the closest thing to a real life Expendable, I felt a true connection with Mickey7. He kept on keepin' on in spite of the disdain felt toward him by most of the other colonists.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2 B0010SEP20 B08PV5J8BT B000FC29JI 0593237838 B07NSG5XTS B09DF2VGVH B08LDY63RX B09P46BTRH 1250275032
review:
Lots of twists.: Lots of twists and turns here and the ending wasn't what I expected. I've read books with similar themes before and they all have been compelling enough to keep me turning pages. This one was no exception. What I really liked was the author's ability to make the reader think she was using one character when in fact it was another one.
This is a fairly quick read but worth your time.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2 B0010SEP20 B08PV5J8BT B000FC29JI 0593237838 B07NSG5XTS B09DF2VGVH B08LDY63RX B09P46BTRH 1250275032 1739689909
review:
A well researched and compelling historical novel.: One of my favorite genres is medieval history and this book does it very well. The authors did their homework here. The locations are real world places and much of the action is compelling.
I especially enjoyed the tournament portion of the book. The authors painted a very accurate picture of jousting and melees. It kept my interest throughout.
I hope there will be more books in this series. I want more of Fox and Willa.

history: 0743203984 0985703024 1940161452 B00XIDJ02A B01BCEPOYY 1455525871 B01K7T52NI B01INMZL00 1501138065 B07B2MYC89 B00CDQZCRK B079LXSLNX B07BPKC8LS B01FD96JIE B07D73M3DC 1476795924 B078LTW9QM B07F668MBT 1796643882 B00F9H59Z0 B07RNDN5CQ B00GVQZR3C B00P1W6RDQ B07N7G4CHZ B0823WYP4F 1679267507 B07GNTW4X5 B075X2GCLB B084M1TVDJ B0876MF3KH B087LB9GKQ B07TD6GRX5 B08BDZ5MV7 B08286GQ5P B08272L5MQ B0853767GV B005KB0VSU B07ZNW4NVN B000SEGB3S B08CTGLM9D B08HY29VM2 B0010SEP20 B08PV5J8BT B000FC29JI 0593237838 B07NSG5XTS B09DF2VGVH B08LDY63RX B09P46BTRH 1250275032 1739689909 1801108633
review:
A wild ride.: This book is quite a ride. I did not see the ending coming. The author was very skillful at weaving the story so that the reader was kept guessing and begged for more. This is a terrific thriller.
I liked how the author used flashbacks and flash forwards to deepen the mysteries. As a reader, I found my interest piqued by this method.
Not to give away the ending, the story revolves around three teenagers raised in a mysterious institution. They begin to question their pasts and in so doing uncover more questions than answers. Things get stranger from there. Suffice it to say that you will not put this book down.
Great pictures: I got this for my mom for Christmas. She loved it. She said it was one of the best decorating books she’d seen in a while.

Self-Absorbed Navel Gazing: I had a difficult time choosing a title for this review as so many seemed apt. 'Boring', Torture', 'Huge Waste of 'Time'. Finally I settled on 'Self-Absorbed Navel Gazing'. This is just about the worst piece of literary fiction I have ever read. Its 250 pages seemed like 950 pages. I was drawn to it by its setting in Athens. Big mistake. Our narrator, a British writing teacher, has taken a brief job in Athens teaching creative writing. On the plane from London to Athens her seat mate, a sixtyish Greek man who has grown up in England launches into a monologue about his life, his marriages, his children. Is there a conversation with our narrator? No. Just a boring monolgue. It's a good thing the flight wasn't from London to Hong Kong. Next we see our narrator having lunch with a colleague in Athens. Another boring monologue with no interaction. More complaints about his wife and children. Next up our narrator's friend brings along a woman writer. More monologue about her gender oppression. I guess you get the point. One boring monologue after another. No plot just self-absorbed navel gazing. Avoid this novel at all costs. Spare your eye-sight.

Avoid. Read a Thomas Mann Novel Instead: As a huge admirer of Thomas Mann, one of the greatest writers of the 20th century, I looked forward to reading this fictionalized homage to Mann. What a complete disappointment. Yes, extensive research went into writing it, but it is tedious spending far too much time obsessing over Mann's deeply repressed homosexuality and the antics of his six children. As for his seminal oeuvre there is virtually nothing. A brief mention of Buddenbrooks, Death in Venice and The Magic Mountain. For a highly regarded writer like Toibin to gloss over these works is criminal. Death in Venice is not merely a story of a homosexual obsession, nor is The Magic Mountain merely a story of a trip to a Swiss sanitorium, but that is what one would think after reading this book. Don't waste your time on Toibin's 500 page misstep. Instead spend your time more wisely reading one of Mann's brilliant novels.

Bad Teen Drama - Avoid: If you are over the age of fourteen avoid this piece of trite trash. Pedestrian writing, cardboard characters. The Richardsons are a perfect white privileged family in progressive Shaker Heights, Ohio. Except their daughter Izzy burns down their house on page one. Izzy would be a perfect recruit for Antifa. To find out why she does this deed you must  read 300 plus excruciatingly bad pages about teen pregnancy, transracial adoption and surrogacy. I wish I could get back the hours I spent reading this awful book.
Its good!: It would have been better if it was written well after the Saudi dust up

Great Series!  Huge Font so Easy to Read: I have now purchased the entire series of these books! 7mo old grand daughter loves the pictures and has us reading them over and over to her. Sturdy board books and well made.  Big font will help baby learn to read too.

Cutest Book for a 1st Birthday: This is a great little touch and feel book specifically for a ONE YEAR 1st Birthday. Well packaged with protective covers on the mirror and sticky cake. Nice group of Disney characters. Seems to be written more for princess lovers with Cinderella's dress as the dress up part but perfect for my little granddaughter.
GREAT Board book for Little Ones who Love Cats!: We had this as a Kindle book and granddaughter loved Pete so much we bought the boardbook too. It is a hit! She loves Pete the Kitty!

Spoiler Alert....: There are quite a few descriptions of sexual abuse...which did happen... and homosexuality. If this offends you, you may not want to read. I loved learning about these women, however, the story didn't need to have referenced the above so much. A reader could have caught the gist of it with less.

So fascinating hearing about what women used to deal with to bring a more equal footing to all races and genders. I learned a lot.

Nice summer read: On a Summer Tide was the August pick for the Page-turners Book Club at the Kewaunee Public Library. We had a nice lunch time meeting last week to discuss this book.

On the Summer Tide is the story of the Grayson family. Father Paul Grayson has recently lost his voice and career as a sports broadcaster. He also lost his wife, Corinna, years before. He decides to buy an island that is the location of the summer camp where he and his beloved wife met. He hopes that putting the camp together will bring his three daughters back together. The oldest Camden is focused on her career, but her son Cooper is dealing with a lot of issues. Middle child Maddie is almost finished with her degree and is engaged, but not thrilled about it. Youngest Blaine strives to be taken seriously as she can’t seem to settle down on a career or pathway. What happened to Corinna that set them all down this path? Will they be able to get the camp ready to be opened for the season?

I enjoyed this novel. It was a nice mellow novel that is perfect for the summer. I thought the story was engaging. I also liked that it was about all three sisters and their father. The book club did discuss that switching to different viewpoints within the chapter was confusing at first until you got used to it. Our favorite character was Peg, the owner of a combined hardware story/eatery in town that gives out indispensable advise. This novel is the first in a trilogy. I only read this first novel, but other ladies in my book club read on and loved the future books as well. This was a nice clean read and had a nice discussion of faith. There was a major plot point that seemed too convenient to me, but it did go along with the overall arc of the story. I loved the family drama, the Maine island setting, and the fixing up of the old camp.

Favorite Quotes:

“Even as a girl, Cam had a hard time just being a part of something without finding a way to improve it.” - I can relate to this.

“So many times, he had chosen work over family, always assuming there’d be plenty of time to catch up. Boy, was that a dumb idea. Time had no mercy.”

“You can’t live other people’s lives for them, even if you love them. Sometimes love means trusting people to make their own decisions.”

“Planning doesn’t make the wedding. And the wedding doesn’t make the marriage. The marriage is what we live with, day in and day out.”

“How’d you like to be defined by your nineteen-year-old self for the rest of your life.” – This was our book club’s favorite quote.

Overall, On a Summer Tide was a nice summer read on families, love, and forgiveness.

Book Source: Kewaunee Public Library

Great Characters and Story!: The Dread Penny Society helps the plight of the poor in Victorian London. They also raise funds by writing penny dreadfuls (stories written and sold in installments) to amuse the masses. Brogan Donnelly is an Irishmen that writes penny dreadfuls on the side while he goes undercover to try to investigate a criminal enterprise. Vera Sorokina is a Russian immigrant that helps her father run a book and print shop. She loves penny dreadfuls and helping out the poor when she can. She hires Brogan to help with delivers. Will these two be able to solve the mystery plaguing their community and the growing attraction between themselves?

This is the third book in the Dread Penny Society series, but it can be read as a stand alone novel. There is an overarching theme with an evil mastermind that is discussed in the previous books, and it looks like will continue in future books. I loved the two strong leads, Brogan and Vera. They were both interesting on their own, but I loved the chemistry between them. Eden has written a vivid Victorian world like Dickens that shows that good and the bad side of that world. The poor, downtrodden, good, and evil are all exposed.

My favorite part of this series is that there are alternating chapters of two penny dreadfuls that run throughout the course of the book. I love these extra stories.

Favorite Quote:
“People are more than their labels, is what you’re saying.”

Overall, The Merchant and the Rogue is a delightful addition to the Dread Penney Society series with great characters and story.

Book Source: Review Copy from Shadow Mountain Publishing for being a part of the Book Tour. Thank-you.

An Impossible Choice . . .: What would Jane Austen choose, love in the future or becoming a successful writer in her own time?
Jane in Love tells us the story behind this choice. In 1803 Bath England, Jane Austen is 28 years old and becoming a spinster. She longs to be able to have her own independence without everyone trying to push her into marriage. After a visit to a mysterious woman, she finds herself in present day Bath. She meets Sophia Wentworth. Sophia is an actress playing Mrs. Allen in a new film version of Northanger Abbey. She was once a major Hollywood star married to a famous director, but as she nears the end of her thirties, her career and marriage are in shambles. As Sophia helps Jane find her way in modern England, will she also be able to find herself?

I always love time travel novels. I thought it was an interesting concept to bring Jane Austen to the future and to see if she would choose love over her career. I enjoyed her meeting Fred and their romance, but I never really felt the love connection between the two as I feel that I should have. Part of it may be that I didn’t feel the character of Jane fit with the Jane Austen I know and love. Persuasion is my favorite Austen novel and I loved how it worked with this novel.

My favorite part of this novel was actually Sophia. I loved the details of her rise to fame, her marriage, and her trials of being an actress nearing forty in Hollywood. The making of the movie was fascinating as well. I would love a spin off novel on Sophia and her future adventures in film and love.
I kind of hope future versions of this book will change the year to 2019 or 2021. The story didn’t fit in the 2020 setting as there weren’t movies being made that year. It’s hard to have a story set in 2020 without mentioning COVID.

This is our August selection for the JASNA Northwoods Book Club and I can’t wait to discuss it with our group this weekend.

Favorite Quote:
“She was too old to act so childishly, gripped by juvenile longing, but then love never aged. She’d feel the same at eighty.”

Overall, Jane in Love is an interesting time travel novel that looks at the impact of Jane Austen on our time.

Book Source: Review Copy from William Morrow. Thank-you!

A thriller you won't be able to put down!: My friend Jen loaned me this book and told me I would be up all night to finish it. I’ve been holding off reading it until I had that kind of time. She was right and I couldn’t put this book down once I picked it up.

I didn’t know anything about this novel when I started to read it and honestly, I think that is a great way to go into it. It tells the story of two different people. Beth is a ten-year-old girl with an alcoholic mother. One terrible day, she is kidnapped and locked in a strange basement. She uses her skills to survive and tries to figure out a way to escape. Seven years in the future, Imogene is getting ready to attend the funeral of her Klan leader father. Her mother enlists her help to figure out some of the secrets he left behind. Will Imogene find all of her father’s ghosts and figure out a way for herself to move on? Will Beth make it out of the basement?

Gone Too Long was action packed with a swift moving plot. It was very interesting, and I enjoyed reading it. I will admit though that I wasn’t totally happy with the ending. I really want to talk to someone about it! I thought the look into the history of the Klan and how it has impacted the members, community, family, and victims of its hate was very interesting. History of the Klan was told between chapters. It was sad to see that it seemed to have had its day, but it’s risen back up again today and is as full of hate as ever. Knowing that people filled with such hate can surround you in your community is a horror novel of its own.

Overall, Gone Too Long is a thriller that you won’t be able to put down!

Book Source: Borrowed from my friend Jen.

Okay Romantic Suspense Read: What is your favorite book set in a small town?

Adrian Rizzo was seven when she met her father for the first time, and he nearly killed her and her mother. Her mother has an exercise video empire, and Adrian sets up her own exercise online video empire when she hits her teen years. Her safe place has always been her grandparent’s house. When her grandpa leaves her his home, she decides to move to her favorite small town, Traveler's Creek. While there she rekindles her childhood infatuation with a good-looking friend Raylan. Adrian has been receiving threatening letters from a mysterious person for years, but they start to escalate. Who is stalking her and why?

I love Nora Roberts and this novel started off with a bang. I was reading quickly at first, but the story really seemed to drag in the middle. It was filled with making fitness videos and running errands. It seemed to go abruptly from scene to scene. I enjoyed the characters, but they weren’t as well developed as I am used to in a Roberts novel. Adrian herself I just didn’t connect with, which is troublesome when she is the main character. I also wasn’t feeling the romance as I usually do in her novels. I usually really love second chance romance and friends to lovers. The suspense seemed to come rather abruptly to the front of the story at the end of the book. Legacy felt like a mediocre Roberts novel, it was definitely not one of my favorites. It pains me to say this.

Favorite Quotes:
“The first time Adrian Rizzo met her father, he tried to kill her.”

“If her childhood had taught her anything, it was to make time for her passion, her responsibilities. And for the ones she loved.”

Overall, Legacy was an okay romantic suspense novel.

Book Source. Review Copy from Netgalley and St. Martin’s Press. Thank-you!

Fascinating Novel: Three young women meet in 1965 at a maternity home hospital. All three are from different backgrounds, but they all share one thing, babies that must remain hidden. As the years go by and their lives move on, will they ever be able to really put behind the secrets from their past?

I found No Names to be Given to be a riveting novel. Sandra, Faith, and Becca all led fascinating lives. The novel was told from their three points of views, with later points of views of their children added into the novel. The story started with their young adult lives, how they became pregnant, life at the maternity home hospital, and then their lives afterwards. I enjoyed it all, although I wish there would have been more on the stay at the hospital and how the three became friends. There was also intrigue in the novel when the three women start to receive mysterious letters and their secrets are threatened to be exposed. I enjoyed it and this novel was a real page turner.

I was also intrigued to learn at the end of the novel that the author, Julia Brewer Daily, was herself born in a maternity hospital in New Orleans. She had pictures of her life growing up as well and it stated that she searched and was able to find her birth parents. I was fascinated.

Favorite Quotes:

“Although we are from different walks of life, we have bonded in a way we might never have in the outside world.”

“They had no mothers to hold them, no names to be given.”

“Adoption is a two-sided coin – heartbreak and loss for the birth mother, joy and elation for the adoptive mother.”

Overall, No Names to be Given is a captivating look into maternity hospitals in the 1960s and how they impacted the lives of mothers and children for decades.

Book Source: Review Copy from Admission Press as a part of the TLC Book Tour.

Slow Burn Mystery and a Masterful Portrait of Small Town Life: Deer season has opened in Gunthrum, Nebraska in 1985 and a girl has gone missing. Peggy was a typical high school girl that snuck out from home for a party on Saturday night, but failed to turn up for her brother’s confirmation Sunday morning. As the family starts to look for her, more mysteries abound. Alma Costagan’s intellectually disabled farm hand, Hal, is like a son to her. Hal shows up early from a weekend of deer hunting with blood in his truck and a dent in his truck. His story doesn’t add up, and soon the small town turns against him. Is Hal guilty and where is Peggy?

I enjoyed this story for the slow burn mystery and more for the masterful portrait of small-town rural life and people. I loved the small-town farm community setting. It reminded me of where I live now in Wisconsin and where I grew up in Michigan. I also loved the characters. They were all interesting in their unique ways. The novel is told from Alma and Peggy’s 12-year-old brother Milo’s point of view. The two viewpoints kept the action moving in the novel. I also loved that this novel really explored families and relationships. Most of all I loved Alma Costagan. She’s a woman of a certain age who tells it like it is to everyone she meets. She has suffered through great heart ache in her life, but she’s also found happiness with her husband Clyle and Hal. I would love to read more about Alma. Milo’s coming of age story was riveting as well as he grapples with guilt for knowing that his sister was sneaking out and wondering what happened to her. What does Milo want from life?

Favorite Quote:
“He wondered if for the rest of his life he’d think about the time his sister went missing while he watched it snow.”

Overall, Deer Season is a wonderful literary mystery with great characters.

Book Source: Review Copy from University of Nebraska Press for being a part of the TLC Book Tour. Thank-you!

Perfect Mystery to take along on your next holiday . . .: I read Evil Under the Sun at the end of August for the #ReadChristie2021 challenge. The prompt was a story on a seaside. Poor Hercule Poirot never gets a break, even when he is on a seaside vacation. He goes to visit the Jolly Roger Hotel, Smuggler’s Island, Leathercombe Bay on a promontory that is cut off from England at each high tide. He meets a motley crew of characters and soon enough, one is found dead on the beach. Who committed this murder during a seaside vacation and why?

I enjoyed this Christie as I’ve been enjoying each one as I read them for the first time. Christie tricked me again, but I loved going along for the ride and seeing how this mystery turned out. This novel did not have a narrator and I liked how chapter one set up the seaside location including a map. I loved how once again Poirot uses his little grey cells to understand people’s characters and to really look at how much they are saying or not saying. He shows the reader and the characters of the novel that sometimes or own biases are what make it so that a murderer can be hiding in plain sight.

Favorite Quotes:

“It is romantic, yes. It is peaceful. The sun shines. The sea is blue. But you forget, Miss Brewster, there is evil everywhere under the sun.”

“One can’t go back, can one? That – never. But I’d like to have gone on - a different way.”

Overall, Evil Under the Sun is the perfect mystery to take along on your next holiday.

Book Source: Purchased from Amazon.com

Truly Inspiring Story!: What is the last inspiring book you read that restored your faith in humanity?

The Day the World Came to Town is the story of what happened to the planes that were forced to land elsewhere when the United States closed its airspace on 9/11. Thirty-eight planes were diverted to Gander, Newfoundland which had an extra-long landing from its early days in aviation. 6,595 passengers were deposited on a town of barely 10,000 people. The community came together to help out these passengers from all over the world.

The Day the World came to town is the stories of individuals that were flying to the United States for various reasons. It is also the story of the individuals in Gander and how they helped. I was amazed at how the town was able to mobilize and help out the people including stripping their beds of sheets and beddings and bringing all of their towels. I loved the individuals and the pictures included. Some of the individuals including the parents of a NYC firefighter, a couple trying to fly home with their adopted daughter, a US general trying to get back to her command, etc. I was riveted. This was a truly human story of perseverance. It reminded me that just like Mr. Rogers said, you should focus on the helpers on not on those that are evil in the world. When you get down to it, most people are good people that just want to help each other out. I think this story applies to today more than ever.

Favorite Quotes:
“We realized we are part of a global village, as my children used to say: What is happening in one part of the globe is affecting us all.”

“Their willingness to help others is arguably the single most important trait that defines them as Newfoundlanders.”

“They affirmed the basic goodness of man at a time when it was easy to doubt such humanity still existed. If the terrorists had hoped their attacks would reveal the weaknesses in western society, the events in Gander proved its strength.”

“We’re all Americans tonight.”

“There was no hatred. No anger. No fear in Gander. Only the spirit of community. Here, everyone was equal, everyone was treated the same. Here, the basic humanity of man wasn’t just surviving, but thriving.”

“Nevertheless, given all of those human frailties, what happened in Gander is still remarkable. And perhaps the lesson learned isn’t that these acts of kindness occurred because Gander is a magical place, but rather these people came together in a time of crisis regardless of their own personal shortcoming. And if that’s the case, then it offers us hope that all of us have that ability within us.”

Overall, The Day the World Came to Town is a truly inspiring story that will restore your faith in humanity.

Book Source: Review Copy from William Morrow. Thank-you!

Entertaining Victorian romance and mystery: Have you ever gone on a blind date?

Amelie is an independent woman in Victorian England working for her Aunt at the Marriage Gazette. She decides to match together two lonely heart letters at the Gazette. She knows she is not supposed to, but she spies on the date to see how it is going. She is surprised to see Mr. Radcliffe is one of the people meeting. He is a member of her book club and a recent widower. She has developed a tendre for him. She runs into Michael Baker who is trailing Mr. Radcliffe. He believes that Mr. Radcliffe’s first wife did not die by accident and is determined to figure out what happened. What happened to Mr. Radcliffe’s wife? Will Amelie find her own happy ending?

I greatly enjoyed this novel. I loved the witty banter between Detective Baker and Amelie. I also enjoyed the other characters such as Amelie’s cousins Charlotte and Eva. I hope they get their own novels. The Victorian setting was perfect. This story had it all, romance, mystery, suspense and adventure. It does take a dark turn, but I really enjoyed the ending.

I loved the quotes at the start of each chapter from different publications. They not only set a great backdrop to the times, but they made me chuckle sometimes when the characters acted in direct opposition of the quotes.

Favorite Quote:
“I do not know that absence of emotion holds any sway in a debate on human evolution. I should think Darwin’s observations prove the opposite, in fact. The more man evolves, the higher his plane of morality, the greater this depth of compassion, wouldn’t you say?”

Overall, The Matchmaker’s Lonely Heart is an entertaining Victorian romance and mystery.

Book Source: Shadow Mountain Publishing as part of the Austenprose Book Tour.

Nice Comfort Read!: What are your favorite comfort reads?

Jenny Colgan is one of my favorite authors and one that I turn to when I’m looking for comfort reads. I love her characters and really like the Little Beach Street, Summer Seaside Kitchen, and Scottish Bookshop series. I always can’t wait what is in store for the characters next.

Sunrise by the Sea is a new book in the Little Beach Street Bakery series. Marisa Rosso has moved to the village of Mount Polbearne to try to start over. Marisa’s beloved grandfather has passed away and she can’t get over her death and move on. She realizes she has anxiety and tries to figure out how to deal with it. Unfortunately, the peace and quiet she craves, quickly vanishes when a piano teacher, Alex, moves in next door. Will she be able to get over her fears and work with him to find peace and quiet? Will she be able to get to know her community and Alex?

While there is a new character, old favorites Polly, Huckle, and there twins also are part of the story. The story moves between Polly and Marisa. Polly’s family is having a hard time with finances and making their businesses work in these trying times. How can they make it all work and what is the most important thing to them?

I really liked having a new character while still enjoying old characters. I really liked the exploration of anxiety and grief in this novel and how Marisa was able to get the help she needed. I also loved Marisa’s relationship with her grandmother over Skype. She didn’t know here that well as she had always spent time with her Grandfather. I love that they cooked together, watched TV together, and talked. They were two lonely people who found comfort with each other over the distance.

Favorite Quote:
“But being an introvert meant that often she hadn’t quite managed to pluck up the courage to tell people she didn’t like them that much, and things could bumble along, or she would lack the courage to make it clear to people she did like that she liked them, and they’d pass her by.”

Overall, Sunrise by the Sea was a nice comfort read that continues as one of my favorite stories.

Book Source: Review Copy from William Morrow. Thank-you!

Unique and Fascinating WWII Historical Fiction Novel!: At the age of two, Inge is kidnapped from her German parents. Rechristened Yona, she is raised in the wilderness by Jerusza, an elderly mystical Jewish woman. She tells Yona her parents were evil, and she teaches her about how to live in the wild. She is convinced that Yona needs to learn these things for a reason. Jerusza dies after World War II starts and Yona discovers groups of Jewish people living in the forest. She realizes her purpose in life is to help them survive. Will they be discovered by the Germans?

This was a fascinating historical fiction novel. It felt like a mystical or magical realism book at times. I looked it up as it seemed more like a fairy tale than a real story. What I found online and what is included in a great afterword to the book is that this was indeed a true historical event. Jewish people did flee into the forest and did have a large-scale settlement that was able to hide from the Germans until the end of the war, the Bielski Partisans. The Bielski Partisans are mentioned in this novel. There is also a 2008 movie called Defiance about the Bielski Partisans starring Daniel Craig. I need to watch this.

I loved Yona as a character. She felt called to help people, but she also felt a deep loneliness in life from her strange upbringing. I’ve always enjoyed survival novels and did like how her she is able to use her knowledge of the forest to survive herself and to help others. I like how she had to learn to live with people as well and I also enjoyed when she fell in love. It was also interesting that Jerusza implied that Yona was predestined for her role in helping others. Do you believe in predestination?

Favorite Quotes:
“We’ve all lost so much. When we find happiness, especially where we didn’t expect to, we must hold it close with all our might, don’t you think?”

“Every time a good soul dies, I think the world gets a little darker.”

“Whoever saves a life, it is considered as if he saved an entire world.”

“I’m broken, too. But sometimes it’s the jagged edges that allow us to fit together. Sometimes it’s the breaks that make us strong.”

“You have to remember one thing for the rest of your life: hardship teaches a person life.”

Overall, The Forest of Vanishing Stars is a unique and fascinating World War II historical fiction novel. There is a lot out there in this genre lately and it’s great to find new aspects of it.

Book Source: Review Copy from Netgalley and Gallery Books. Thank-you!

This book greatly moved me - excellent novel!: Have you ever read a book that captures your mood perfectly?

I LOVED The Unlikely Yarn of the Dragon Lady. Once I started this cozy read, I couldn’t put it down. The Heavenly Hugs Prayer Shawl Ministry knits together at the church prayer chapel each Wednesday. They are shocked one Wednesday to discover that the chapel is closed down for painting and their pastor tells them that he wants them to take their ministry out into the world. How are they supposed to pray at a shopping mall? Margaret, Rose, Jane, and Fran pack their knitting bags and try it out. The new people they encounter have problems of their own that could use some prayer. Will these ladies be able to spread their ministry and also solve their own issues?

I loved that each character was fully fleshed and had a compelling story of their own. I loved that the overall message was that making human connections with people and caring for them, makes the world a better place. We all need that human connection and caring for the greater good. I also loved the theme of mother and child relationships and being able to take the time to forgive and say goodbye. There was also a good theme of not judging others as you don’t know their full story. The story was very well written and engaging. I need to read more from Sharon J. Mondragon.

I also really liked that this is a Christian book that is actually a Christian book. Many Christian books are labeled Christian as they have a chaste romance, but do not actually have any discussion of Christianity. This book actual has prayer, a church, church services, and trying to evangelize in the community to bring in new members. It also applied Christian teachings such as forgiveness. I especially loved the description of the Christmas Eve service and the lighting of the candles. Jane has a moment where she realized that instead of blowing out the candles, you could be the candle that stays lit and brings the message out to your home and community. I loved this.

Favorite Quotes:
“Apparently, like most women of a certain age, they were virtually invisible.”

“Luck is random. Blessing is from God.”

Overall, The Unlikely Yarn of the Dragon Lady is a truly wonderful novel with great characters and message that will stick with me.

Book Source: Review copy from Kregel Publications for being a part of the Book Tour.

Unique Action Adventure Story!: The Water Keeper was the September selection for the Rogue (FLICKS) Book Club after we won the book from the TLC Book club giveaway. We had our meeting the last week of September.

Murphy Shepherd has recently lost his mentor and has a quest to bring his ashes to where they met. He is a secretive man that helps those in peril. He meets a mother that has lost her daughter to a shadowy crew that traffics young girls on yachts around Florida. Summer wants to find her daughter April and Murphy is determined to help her. He also meets a faithful Labrador Retriever, an ex-con named Clay, and a mysterious girl named Ellie. Will Murphy be able to reunite mother and daughter? What is Murphy’s past?

We all agreed that this book was hard to get into as the beginning was confusing. Once you got into the story it was engaging. The one complaint was that there were too many threads of the story going on – it could have just focused on the main story. For myself once I realized it was an action-adventure story, I could suspend my disbelieve and enjoy the ride. I enjoyed the book and do want to see how the story continues in book two. It was also distressing to learn more about human trafficking and to think about this happening to young girls.

Overall, The Water Keeper is an action-adventure story with unique twists.

Book Source: Thomas Nelson Publishing as part of the TLC Book club Giveaway.

Engaging Legal Thriller and Historical Fiction Novel!: Are you looking for an intriguing legal thriller mixed with a historical fiction novel? Look no further than Defending Britta Stein by Ronald H. Balson. I read Defending Britta Stein at the end of September for the Brenda Novak Book Group. Author Brenda Novak had a great interview with author Ronald H. Balson that can still be found on her Facebook page.

Ole Henryks is a popular restaurant owner in Chicago is being honored for being a Danish war hero. This does not sit well with ninety-two-year-old Britta Stein who starts a one-woman campaign to discredit Ole by graffitiing his restaurant. After charges are pressed against Britta, can her legal team defend her by showing it’s not defamation, but true statements about Ole Henryks? Britta narrates her past to her legal team and granddaughter and long buried secrets are unearthed. Was Ole Henryks a Nazi collaborator? How did his life intersect Britta’s life?

I found out when I started reading this novel that it is part of a series. It stood up well as a stand alone novel, although I am intrigued about the series now. I had no idea about the Danish history during World War II and I loved learning about it. It was particularly wonderful to read about how an entire country was able to pull together for the greater good and help people out to save almost their entire Jewish population. I am amazed I had never learned about this before. This would make a wonderful movie. I loved Britta’s story, but I’m not sure why she waited until this very late stage of her life to share it with her granddaughter.

Overall, Defending Britta Stein is an engaging legal thriller and historical fiction novel that is not to be missed!

Book Source: Review copy from Netgalley. Thank-you!

Not to be Missed!: Daunis Fontaine is an eighteen-year-old girl living in Sault St. Marie Michigan trying to determine her next steps in life. Daunis is half Ojibwe and is trying to find where she belongs in her two worlds. She was a powerful high school hockey player and is set to go to the University of Michigan to major in premed. After her uncle’s death and grandmother’s hospitalization, Daunis decides to stay near her family and friends and attend Lake Superior State University in town. After a mysterious death, Daunis uses her knowledge of both science and Native American medicine to try to solve the mystery that is plaguing her community.

I love, love, loved this novel. It straddles many different genres and is hard to describe succinctly. It is a great thriller story with trying to figure out the mystery. It is a great coming of age story as Daunis tries to figure out what she wants in life and how decisions of her family in the past affect her in the present. It is a great young adult novel as she tries to figure out what is important in life, love, and family.

Firekeeper’s Daughter is an #OwnVoices tale and is written by Angeline Boulley who is an enrolled member of the Sault Ste. Marie Tribe of Chippewa Indians. I loved the immersion in the Ojibwe community, its language, history, traditions, troubles, etc. There are so many tribes around the United States and their stories are hard to find. I loved that this novel had a very strong Ojibwe woman that is part of her modern tribe.

I loved the setting in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. The hockey, pasties, locations, etc. were wonderful. I last visited Sault Ste. Marie in 2001, just a few years before this story was set in 2004. I attended Michigan Tech in the U.P. and now live in Northeastern Wisconsin. The culture captured in this novel represents a large part of northern Michigan and Wisconsin. I love finally having a book that shows that cleaning the snow off of a girl’s car is a declaration of love.
