After his younger sister Cora states that she believe he had been murdered, she is abruptly murdered. “’It’s all very odd, isn’t it?’ she said. ‘There was Cora, after the funeral, suddenly coming out with “He was murdered!” and then, the very next day, she goes and gets herself murdered?’” Richard Abernethie’s solicitor Mr. Entwhistle is on the case at first, but then brings in Hercule Poirot to solve the mystery.

I enjoyed this one. There were a lot of different paths the story could have taken for the ultimate resolution. I didn’t quite have it figured out as I suspected everyone. I liked Mr. Entwhistle and thought he was making a fine detective. Poirot didn’t enter the scene until well into the book. I always find it interesting when a rich person in murdered and there are so many people in his family who could have committed the crime for one reason or another. I liked the characters.

Favorite Quotes:
“On a foundation of Coral Cornplasters there had arisen this neo-Gothic palace, its acres of gardens, and the money that had paid out an income to seven sons and daughters and had allowed Richard Abernethie to die three days ago a very rich man.”

“The value of money is always relative,” said Mr. Entwhistle. “It is the need that counts.”

“What any woman saw in some particular man was beyond the comprehension of the average intelligent male. It just was so. A woman who could be intelligent about everything else in the world could be a complete fool when it came to some particular man.”

“Should murder make sense? Mr. Entwhistle wondered. Academically the answer was yes. But many pointless crimes were on record. It depended, Mr. Entwhistle reflected, on the mentality of the murderer.”

Overall, After the Funeral was another enjoyable Agatha Christie mystery.

Book Source: Purchased as a Kindle book from Amazon.com.

Riveting Historical Fiction Novel!: Marion Davies was a chorus girl in New York City when she met the older, wealthy, and famous William Randolph Hearst. Hearst was already a newspaper media tycoon and a married father of five. He is struck by the teenage Davies and soon the two have started a relationship. Marion Davies hopes that it will lead to marriage, but she soon finds that she will always be the mistress while Hearst keeps his family life. With the help of Hearst, Davies embarks on a movie career and ends up in Hollywood. As Hearst works on his famous castle, Davies befriends Hollywood royalty and becomes one of the top stars of the 1920s. As times change, Davies and Hearst stick together through sickness and health, times of financial and social ruin.

I didn’t know much about Marion Davies going into this novel besides the fact that she was William Randolph Hearst’s mistress and the role that I thought was her in Citizen Kane, Susan Alexander Kane. I learned from this novel that Davies was actually a very talented actress that had to work through her childhood stutter to succeed. Her career was helped by Hearst’s publicity but was also hindered by him controlling her parts.

I am usually not a fan of books about cheating, but William Randolph Hearst’s affair with Marion Davies spanned most of her life until his death. When his business was about to be ruined, she pulled together her money to help him out. After he gave up on his political career, they lived openly together.

I loved the look into old Hollywood and Davies being friends with so many big names in the 1920’s and 1930’s. She also had a very passionate affair with Charlie Chaplin that I did not know about. I have never watched a Marion Davies movie before, but now I really want to find one, especially some of her silent movies.

Favorite Quotes:
“Being with WR was like being on a ship far from land on a voyage to some imagined exotic destination that was our perfect life together, and no matter how awful the journey got, there was no way to get off the ship. The ship was either in good weather or bad weather, it didn’t matter. I took comfort in that I would always be on the ship with him.”

“Don’t take too much of the insults once they come. Ignore them. You and I know the truth of our lives. Let’s embrace the truth and ignore the rest.”

Overall, The Blue Butterfly was a riveting historical fiction novel about Marion Davies.

Book Source: A Review Copy from Spark Point Studio and She Writes Press. Thank-you! I received a complimentary copy of this book. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

I can't stop thinking about this book!!: The Sea of Tranquility was a beautiful and unique book that I couldn’t put down. My husband, Ben, and I are currently watching Station Eleven, but Sea of Tranquility was my first novel by Emily St. John Mandel. It takes place during four different time frames and involves time travel. I loved it.

The novel starts with the younger son from an aristocratic family being shipped to Canada in 1912 because he has “radical” opinions that embarrass the family. He has a strange experience in the woods on Vancouver Island. In 2020, a concert is taking place where footage is displayed that was taped in the same woods in 1994 and a strange event occurred. In 2203, Olive Llewellyn is on a book tour on Earth. She is a resident of the second moon colony. While at an airport, she has a moment where she hears music, sees trees, and has a strange experience. Is this a glitch? In 2401, Gaspery-Jacques Roberts is a security guard at a hotel on the first moon colony. His sister and old friend work for the Time Institute. He gets a job there and is soon an operative traveling through time to try to solve the question of these strange disturbances. What are these glitches?

The writing of this novel was beautiful. It started somewhat slow with different pieces of the story that seemed unrelated. Then the pieces finally started to come together. I was fascinated. There were some deep thoughts about life and reality. It is a short book and I read it quickly.

Favorite Quotes:
“Illness frightens us because it’s chaotic. There’s an awful randomness about it.”

“I’ve been thinking a great deal about time and motion lately, about being a still point in a ceaseless rush.”

Overall, Sea of Tranquility is a book I can’t stop thinking about. It’s a beautiful novel with an intriguing story.

Great Cozy Mystery!: What is your favorite type of book to cozy up with?

Nora Pennington is enjoying the winter weather and creating new book displays at her shop, Miracle Books. She is excited when Deputy Jasper Andrews asks for her help in creating a Little Women themed proposal for her friend Hester. Mysteriously, right before the planned event, Nora discovers that all of her copies of The Scarlet Letter have had the name Hester cut out of them. Nora knows that Hester gave up a baby for adoption in the past and hasn’t even told Andrews her secret. Her family treated her like she had the scarlet letter embroidered on her and shamed her. When a dead hiker shows up with ties to Hester’s past, will Hester’s secret come out?

This is the fifth book in the Secret, Book, and Scone Society Novel series. I was able to read it as a stand alone novel, but I do want to go back and read the rest of the books in the series. I greatly enjoyed it. It’s been pretty stressful at work and with life lately and a cozy mystery was just what I needed. I loved all of the characters, and really enjoyed the literary references and love for books. I loved how the mystery was intricately tied to books as well. The end of the novel had a list of all of the books referenced which I thought was great! There were also book club discussion questions as well. I wanted to live in Miracle Springs and help Nora and Sheldon with their book displays.

Overall, The Vanishing Type is great cozy mystery filled with wonderfully developed characters, great food, and books galore.

Book Source: Review Copy from Kensington Cozies as part of the TLC Book Tour.

Entertaining Coming of Age Novel: What do you miss from summers in your teen years? What do you not miss?

Belly spends her summer at Cousin’s Beach each year with her mother, brother, mother’s best friend Susannah and Susannah’s two sons, Conrad and Jeremiah. This novel goes back and forth through Belly’s life in the summer as she grows up into a teenager that is love with Conrad and sometimes Jeremiah. Will Belly end the summer finally noticed by Conrad?

The Summer I Turned Pretty is a coming-of-age story and is a light read. Belly is a teenager in this young adult novel, and as a teenager, she is sometimes annoying as she tries to figure out what she wants in life. It made me remember teenage years. Having more time to have fun in the summer was great, although I started working summers at the age of 12 so I didn’t have long summers on the beach like this. It’s complicated being a teenager and trying to figure out the social scene. Belly has problems when she invites her best friend, and also when she starts seeing a boy named Cam. I like books set in the summer and coming of age novels. I’m interested to see what happens next in this trilogy and I will be reading onward. I’m also looking forward to the Amazon Prime series. It looks like it came out while I was on vacation the past week and a half. My daughter Penelope and I will be watching it!

Overall, The Summer I Turned Pretty is an entertaining coming of age novel.

Book Source: Thank you to Simon & Schuster for the free copy for review.

Intriguing Regency Romance: Do you consider yourself to be a “wallflower” or are you more the life of the party?

Midnight’s Budding Morrow is the second book in the Regency Wallflowers series. I read and enjoyed the first book as well. This book can be read as a standalone.

Sarah Drayton is invited by her friend Beatrice to visit her family estate, the run-down castle of Langley which is located by the sea. Sarah hopes they do not run into Beatrice’s brother, James, who is a drunken rake that had forced a kiss on her at a dance. Sarah finds things not happy at the castle as it fallen into disrepair and the servants don’t seem to be doing much work. Beatrice is unhappy as she is in love with a man that her father does not approve. Sarah soon finds herself in a marriage of convenience with the dreaded James. Will Sarah be able to find happiness?

I enjoyed this novel. I love marriage of convenience stories. I really liked how this book delved into whether a person can really change or not. James has what would now be PTSD from his service for the crown in the Napoleonic Wars. He finds God and works through his demons while recovering and wants to start afresh with Sarah. It’s hard to make true changes and start over with a spouse that you barely know.

Sarah is an orphan and looking for family and a place to belong. Old Mr. Langley enjoys her skills running a household, but neighbors look at Sarah more as a servant than the lady of the house. Will she find her place in the household, neighborhood, and with her husband?

The novel has some slight Gothic elements. Nothing scary, but it did have a treasure hunt, shut up rooms, a falling down castle, and the mysterious death of old Mrs. Langley years before.

Overall, Midnight’s Budding Morrow is an intriguing regency romance.

Book Source: Review Copy from Kregel Publications as part of the Audra Jennings PR Book Tour.

Interesting Read, but Analysis went off the rails at times: Jane Austen, the Secret Radical was one of the May selections for the JASNA Northwoods Book Club. Author Helena Kelly analyzes each of Austen’s novels for signs of the “secret radical” that she believes Austen was.

The introduction is an analysis of Jane Austen. Each chapter started with a narrative on Austen’s life and then followed by an analysis of each of her novels. “”I would suggest that when dealing with someone like Jane Austen, we could add another, and more dangerous, class of knowledge; what might be termed the unknown knowns – things we don’t actually know but think we do.”

I thought the writing was engaging and not written like a dry academia book. Sadly though, detailed notes were lacking in the book that could have explained why Kelly seemed to not agree with many items that seem to be established ideas from other scholars.

I did like how the author brought out interesting thoughts and ideas about the characters and the novels. In particular the Mansfield Park section had an interesting discussing about slavery. I learned that Maria Edgeworth had to rewrite Belinda to remove a marriage between a white character and a black character after being ravaged by critics. The links of Mansfield Park to slavery were detailed.

I was not happy about the analysis of Sense and Sensibility which heavily implied that both Edward Ferris and Colonel Brandon had strange sexual proclivities. I was not amused and not feel like I can never look at these characters in the same way. The analysis seemed to stretch way to far with these characters.

Favorite Quotes:
“She loves her family – truly, she does – but the days seem to slip through her fingers. There is always some demand on her time: someone needing to be nursed or entertained a letter of condolence to be written, paper boats to be sailed on the river, yet another new niece or nephew to sew caps for.”

“In a society where unmarried men and women were largely kept separate, and permitted to socialize only when properly chaperoned, how could a woman arrive at any sort of knowledge of a man’s character, and how could a man hope to understand the nature of the woman he married?”

Overall, Jane Austen, the Secret Radical, was an interesting read, but the analysis seemed off the rails at times.

Interesting look into turn of the century fashion and the woman who designed it: Lucy Wallace is in a pickle. Her husband has been abusive, unfaithful and has finally left her for a dancer. She realizes this is the chance she needs to fulfill her dream of becoming a dress designer. She scandalously divorces her husband in the 1890s and starts her business. Her unique designs catch on with the upper crust and rich Americans. She is able to fulfill her dreams while also supporting her mother and her young daughter, Esme. When Sir Cosmo Duff-Gordon starts to court her, will Lucy have a second chance at love?

I enjoyed this novel. I love historical fashion and the descriptions of the dresses and clients were wonderful. Lucy Wallace was a real person and I loved looking her up and seeing what the dresses she designed looked like. I had never heard of her before, and I loved learning her story. The book was told in alternating perspectives between Lucy and her employee, Celia. Celia is a great character too. She comes to Lucy as a teen from the workhouse. Lucy sees something in her and together they are able to build Lucy’s company. I liked the romance between Lucy and Cosmo. I am a fan of second chance romance. I liked that Cosmo loved her for who she was and realized that she was always going to be a designer.

I love Titanic stories and was surprised to discover in this book that Cosmo, Lucy, and Celia were on the Titanic. It was a fascinating part of the story for what happened and the aftereffects. There was a great author’s note on the end that gave details on each of the real-life characters.

Overall, A Dress of Violet Taffeta is an interesting look into turn of the century fashion and an independent woman.

Book Source: A Review Copy from Berkley and Netgalley. Thank-you! I received a complimentary copy of this book. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

Riveting and Moving Memoir!: Have you ever made a bad decision? I think everyone has a decision they regretted making at some point in their life. For some people, those decisions are so major that they upend their lives. This is true in the case of Toby Dorr. Toby was a successful middle-aged mother and wife. She had started a dog training program in a local prison and became national news when she fell in love with a convict (John Maynard), used a dog crate to help him escape, and ended up on the run. This book is Toby’s story.

Living with Conviction is a powerful memoir that I could not put down. Toby’s story was riveting. She told the story starting from the moment her and John crashed and were arrested by police. She finds herself in jail and grappling with the fact that she will be there for some time, and that her relationships with her family have been altered forever. In flashbacks, Toby tells the story of the budding relationship of her and John and also the story of her life up to the point. She was a woman who had accomplished a lot in life and had a husband and two sons. During her time in prison she started to understand that she had used being busy to hide the emptiness she felt inside. She was put in charge of her siblings at five years old after her father was in a horrific accident. Since that time, she always thought she had to take care of everyone and not worry about her own happiness. While in jail, Toby was able to think through her life and put everything in perspective.

Toby’s story made me realize again how our prison/jail system is broken. It was odd how they kept transferring her all over. The most disturbing part to me was that the prison and jails seemed to be mostly filled with people who had mental problems and needed help. The system has just abandoned them to be imprisoned without help. I was also disturbed that when there were serious medical issues with the prisoners, they were just ignored. There has to be a better way to do things.

I’d like to think I would be a forgiving person if my friend or relative was in the same situation as Toby. I was disturbed on how her sisters treated her, and my heart broke for her as a mother when her sons no longer wanted to see her while she was in jail or afterwards. What was amazing is that her cellmates and friends she made in jail treated her better than many in her own family. She was able to make real connections with different ladies and form a real sisterhood. One friend was Lisa Montgomery, the woman who killed another woman to steal the baby still in her womb. Reading this made Lisa seem a real person to me, someone who was wounded, and not someone just from a headline. These relationships helped to put Toby back on track with her life.

Favorite Quotes:
“But she is also a daily reminder that none of us is as bad as our worst mistake.”

“My husband didn’t notice ow much Dad’s cancer affected me, but John Maynard did. He saw right into my soul. I’d been waiting all my life for someone to see me, to notice me, to love me; John did.”

“Perhaps from a different perspective, Senorita’s story did mimic my own. It only took one act of desperation to spur the wheels of fate.”

“I learned that grief is neither good nor bad, it just is. What mattered was how I dealt with it.”

Overall, Living with Conviction is a riveting and moving memoir that I highly recommend.

Jaw-dropping: I read two to three books a month. I usually listen to the audiobook when I’m working and read the print version when I’m at home relaxing. I use my audio book app A LOT and before this book, I never understood why there was an option to increase the speed of the narration.

At 72% of the way through, I was just dying… banging my head against the wall wishing for this inane drivel to finish. I finally put the book in hyperspeed and I still couldn’t get through it fast enough.

The writing is incredibly dull and wordy. There’s so much repetition. There’s so much repetition in every paragraph (see what I did there?) The characters are, without exception, flat and unlikeable. Everyone behaves in a confusing and unrealistic manner. Gah. I could go on and on. The “climax” was the most painfully boring and stupid part of the book. Make it make sense!

How is this a best seller?!?! Wish I could give it a negative star for the time it stole from me.

Good read: As I read this book which is the sequel to "I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings" by Maya Angelou. I felt a variety of things as a whole. Maya talks about her later life, her journey to find her self, her quest to find love etc. I really feel that she was misguided and was not taught self love as that is something all mother's should teach their kids. She parented the way her mother did her, as far as not really being there the way mother's should be for their kids. She had really low self esteem and it shows with her relationships with men. It was a very entertaining read. 4/5 stars

Good read: In this book, which is part 3 from the last book of "Gather Together In My Name'. In this book Maya talks about how she started writing and how she started acting in a play. She got married to a African guy whom she moved with to Africa. He was a revolutionist for Africa and trying to get them their rights and she was right alongside him helping him. Her son Guy was also there for the ride and it talks about the things that he went through as a teenager how he was also in a horrible accident to Africa and also how Maya ended up leaving and divorcing her husband. She talked about dealing with his indefinitely which definitely lead to her getting the divorce. This was a very great read as it gave you more insight into her life and the things that she went through as a mother wife and also as a friend. It showed her growth as far as her writing and as far as her branding herself. This was a really great book 5 out of 5 stars 🌻🌻🌻

Loved it: As I read this book I was immediately engrossed. I feel that this was a great insight into the early life of the great poet Maya Angelou. After reading about her being raped, learning about herself, her love and discovery for books and poems and also her giving birth to a baby boy, it's was an eye opener. Maya lived with her grandmother at one point and then transitioned to live with her mother and it seemed that all the tragic things that happened to her did so while she was with her mom and dad. So many things transpired in her life that will leave anyone who reads this book mouth hanging wide open. This was definitely a great read and I'm upset with myself that it took me so long to read this book. 5/5 stars 🌻🌻🌻

Great read: After reading this book I gained insight to a person and a group to which I had legit never even heard of before. This book tells the story of Raekwon which was a member of a group called The Wu-Tang clan. Beats on his struggles growing up as a fatherless child and the overall struggles as a black child growing up in the ghettos of America. He started off as a drug dealer  but ended up turning to music as his outlet. He spoke of how the group Wu-Tang clan was formed by RZA and how the group spiraled downhill when certain members were given solo albums and other members were not. RZA had  to have all creative control over the group and really make all the decisions and it did not sit well with the group and especially raekwon who was really vocal about his concerns. Raekwon was also upset that the group would not be able to have any input as far as the beats for the songs were concerned and the overall mismanagement that was handled by the group by the founder RZA. RZA also had a brother Divine who was literally mishandling the monies of the group and that also did not sit well with them. I do not want to give this book away because it was really really good and it's really at the top of my list of autobiographies that I have read I will literally definitely recommend this book because it will expose younger readers to the sounds of original Hip Hop and also tell of all the things that were relevant then there are still relevant now. 5/5 stars a definite good book to read

Amazing read: If I never recommend that u read anything I recommend this book. This book speaks of how black and brown people are held back first slavery, Jim crow and now mass incarceration. There was a point of time when poor whites voted with blacks because it made sense, we all were being oppressed by the same issues. Whites then noticed how blacks where becoming entrepreneurs and making more money and living better than them. Elite whites them convinced poor whites to vote their way because why should blacks do better and live better than them. Mass incarceration came about a means to keep us from being where we once were. Images depicted on tv screens show black people and the crack/cocaine time period and showed us as being drug dealers, users and of being over all aggressive. Laws were made to stop and halt the War on Drugs. Even though white people use and sell drugs at a much higher rate than we do, the camera was on us. This book was nothing short of amazing. I don't wanna give too much of this book away but the main focus is that there are incentives given to police departments to arrest back people on trumped up drug charges and ultimately get them to plead guilty on felony charges and thus ruins their life by not being able to get jobs or even government assistance when they get out of jail. The goal is to understand that we don't hold us back but the laws and goals of the government to keep us down as a people so. I do however not like the part of the book at the end where they speak of how affirmative action negatively affected white people, I was like really 🤔 how sway? Ur white in America and the odds are in ur favor. Over all very good book.
🌻🌻🌻🌻

Will update once I've tested out some of the recipes, but 2.5 cups of sugar in a brownie recipe??: This book looks like it has a lot of helpful tips and instructions for making your own condensed milk, buttermilk, etc. The recipes also look intriguing, even though some of them are so rich that you'd definitely want to reserve them for special occasions. The "Fudgiest Giant Brownies" for example have 2.5 cups of sugar, 1 cup of chocolate chips and one cup of vegetable oil for 9 to 12 brownies. There's far more sugar than flour in this brownie recipe! If sugar and fat content are a non-issue, then that's fine, but for many of us, this is just too much of unhealthy ingredients. Let's do the math: 2.5 cups of sugar plus 1 cup of semi dark chocolate chips amounts to no less than 143 teaspoons of sugar. Divided by 9 that means that each large brownie has almost 16 teaspoons of sugar in it. Divided by 12, one smaller brownie has almost 12 teaspoons of sugar in it. The 1/12 size brownie has the same amount of sugar as a can of Coca Cola. Now let's look at the oil. The fat content of one 1/9 size brownie is 218 gm/9 = 24 gm per brownie or 214 calories from just the oil. The fat content of one of the 1/12 size brownies is 218/12 = 18 gm of fat and the calories just from the oil is 1928/12 = 161 calories.
It looks like the other recipes are a little less sugary. Here's hoping!

Lots of ground covered: This book covers a number of supply chain concepts—all good but very few represent what we might call radical thinking. Most of the concepts have been around for decades; the newer one’s presented do not go far enough to make a huge difference. However, as I said, the book covers a lot of ground so is worth a read.

Lessons Learned: The author does a good job of presenting mistakes made in land purchasing and I am fairly convinced they are true stories; in addition, you get a bonus—a checklist to use if you plan to buy land. I’m not sure that any author can give you all the tricks you need to manage scams. So, the book serves as a good warning but may not by itself ensure that you don’t have a bad buying experience.

Well done, Mr. Roberts!: After a long time, I found a book that was hard to put down. Yeah, I mean Bar Maid.  Everything — the writing style, the characters, the milieu, all well packaged in an interesting story. And, I really liked that the author gets close to the main character without writing in the first person. Enjoy.

Interesting fantasy: This fantasy is written well, with interesting characters and a quick pace. However, it is written in script format which I found somewhat disconcerting. Besides this format does not lend itself well to world-creation which should be an essential element of any fantasy.

Another outstanding Ryder Creed mystery: I am an Alex Kava fan of all her books. I can always look forward to jumping right into one of the character's lives. Then others are introduced. Throughout the book, various situations come into play that connect the characters in some fashion. Alex always weaves a tale of mystery that keeps my attention. Mysteries unfold, revealing unexpected discoveries, twists and turns in events. And, I am always surprised at the ending, thinking that I might be on the right track, but not necessarily. I appreciate the surprises, the closure to the mystery.

I also have to acknowledge: the extensive research into forensic science, legal aspects, criminology: the K9 acute abilities, training, responsiveness when assisting to resolve crime scene searches. The acknowledgements at the end of each book is appreciated and interesting, to know those involved, some of the real life crimes and the people and places represented.

I'm hooked and highly recommend Alex Kava's books to any crime, mystery reader. Don't miss out.

Tasty Story and Tasty Recipes: Written with humor, fond remembrances, and great warmth (as well as tasty recipes).  Purchased as a selection for my book club discussion; I'm enjoying it!
Witty Book with Great Insights: Purchased as a book club selection.  Enjoying this read thoroughly!
Creative Folk Art and Beyond:  Just Right for Crafting Projects: Purchased as a gift for my granddaughters who love to craft and who really loved these craft designs!
Thoughtful Coming of Age Story: My book club selection, and a thoroughly good read!

I should have read this long ago: Wow.....I am not a learned critic but I saved this book way too long before deciding I needed something meaningful to read.  Once the reader understands the meaning of the Nightingale an unforgettable adventure awaits. Beauty abounds in this literary novel.

Too Easy But Beautiful Artwork: Here’s a big spoiler: on most illustrations in this book, the wookie is somewhere in the top right area.

There you go. Saved you a couple hours.

The art work is absolutely beautiful but you can tell the artists got extremely lazy in hiding the wookie. The wookie is literally in the top right corner of most of these illustrations. After the third one I realized it wasn’t a mistake it was a pattern and it completely ruins the mystery of the entire book. Still worth buying in my opinion, because children ten and under will most likely not notice this pattern.

Photos printed on regular paper, stapled together to look like a "book": Have you ever attempted to make your own book at home with a color printer? That's what this is. A soft, floppy "book" that looks and feels handmade. So low quality. I bought this as gift and was so embarrassed when I opened it...I could just hear the choruses of "how cute, you made this at home?!". $13...should be more like $2.

A Family Favorite, Purchased as a Gift: This book was out of print for years so it was great to see it back. It was popular years ago and it still is now. Purchased to add to a baby shower gift. I got the hardback. It has a sleeve cover like hardcovers do now. I’d recommend this book for preschoolers old enough to eat popcorn.
Great Book: Very exciting never know what’s gonna happen around the corner
Good reading.: Kept my attention.
Good story for kids: It was a good story for my kids but I was bored with the plot- I like the other book we ordered more

Worth having: I used this in a pre-college writing workshop over the summer (through an Ivy League university) and found it to be an excellent text. I could have wished for actual exercises at the end of each chapter but you don't get everything.

May not be for everyone (if anyone has ever called you stodgy it's not for you) but I loved it: Years ago on a multi-hour drive to a wedding w new & trusted friends (who are now old & trusted friends) someone asked, "So how did you two get together?" and we each talked intimately and honestly about our relationships for hours. That's the only analogy I can think of to reading this book. The book is funnier than the conversation was (full of laugh out loud one-liners) but just as delightfully honest and real. Havrilesky has a great combination of wisdom and humility that I always appreciate. Not saying the book is the most brilliantly written or edited work I've ever read, but if you are married I think it is worth your time. We rarely share so honestly about what real intimacy means, and given the way others have responded to the book I can see why others are unwilling to tackle it. Kudos to Havrilesky for sharing herself and her marriage so frankly.

Good, quick read: I know this is not a novel, but a novella and yes it is a quick read. As others have mentioned, it does not hold back on being horrific, the author has done a good job of not holding back when it comes to the gory details. I very much enjoyed it, but my biggest problem with it, is that with as involved as it was, it really needed to be a novel. Characters needed to be fleshed out, there is very little character development, which left me feeling nothing for the characters. As involved and descriptive as it was at times, some scenes were cut short when I wanted them to go on. I wanted more detail and to get to know these characters. As enjoyable as it was, overall I felt the story did not work as a novella. It ends with too many questions unanswered and in fact when it ended abruptly I was kind of shocked that it was already over.
Good reading: Good story
Good story: Great story
Loved it: Bought for my son he loved the book

Book is overrated, in my opinion: Was really good and addictive until it got almost to the middle/end. The story really didn’t go much of anywhere, and the ending was just a cheap cop out. The “twist” was really disappointing. I don’t respect Kya as the heroine. Her transformation is not at all believable. I feel like a lot of time was spent on meaningless wordy tangents, and not enough on the nitty-gritty. Could have had SUCH a better ending that would have made all the difference in the book overall. I really do think it’s overrated, and have read so many better books. There were some good quotes I tagged, so I will keep it, but it’s not worth a reread.

The book I didn’t know I needed in my life!: Ew, David!… Have watched the show twice all the way through so far, and always want to start it again when I finish. This book gives so much insight and detail into the making of the show. Loved every minute of it, just like the show!

Fantasy - not the real story of how people succeed: The most accurate predictor of succeeding is affluence - primarily where you are born and how wealthy your parents are. At the age of five, poorly educated children will not catch up to affluent educated children. Being "gritty" is a nice feel-good story, but will not make up for the limitations of poverty.

I knew a woman who told me when she was in junior and high school, her family bought her extra copies of her textbooks so she would haven't have to carry them home and worry about forgetting them. Most families don't have either the money or insight to buy extra copies of textbooks for children. That is not grit, it is affluence.

Another "feel-good" faux psychology book that justifies wealth inequality in the country. Using "grit" while trapped in a minimum wage job is not going to make you a millionaire hedge fund manager. It's who you know and who your parents know.

Well written and an ambitious approach: This is actually two mysteries, one set in the 1950s and the other contemporary. You have to keep track of two stories and two sets of people. It is very well written and more complex and more ambitious than a typical mystery. I recommend it.

Well written but needlessly convoluted: The book is very well written, but the storyline is confusing and convoluted. The original premise for the murders is not convincing. Poirot and his sidekick are entertaining, but it doesn’t compensate for the disjointed storyline.
good book: I knew several of the questions ....

Disappointing.: I thought this would be better than it is.  I usually finish a book quickly, but this one has languished on my side table.  I just can't seem to get into it.  The illustrations are great, but the story seems uninspired and the writing is odd.  I honestly can't recommend this.  There is nothing unique about the story.  It is just a rehash of many other fantasy novels.

Terrific personal calendar: Cute personal calendar! There's plenty of space for noting appointments, b'days, etc. Nice size, easy to read and use; it's well laid out. Slides easily into a purse. Not flimsy.
Fantastic Animal Book: Quality is great. Pictures of all kinds of animals are excellent! Great price. Our grandson loves this book! Learning and having fun at the same time!
First Learning activity book: Quality is there nice learning book for young kids ages 3 and up! I donated several of these this yr for kids for Christmas!
Enjoying this a lot!: Great novel about Shakespeare's son.

This is the book I was looking for!: I'm tasked with teaching a high school creative writing class next year.  I've studied the usual high school masters and searched TPT, but wasn't able to put together the meaningful ideas I wanted to share until this book.  It is huge, as others have noted, but reads easily and includes activities and mentor texts as examples.  It's an easy read in 50 page chunks of mixed story and explanation.

pretty useful: lots of good illustrations on shelter, traps, knots, plants, tracks etc. great info on lots of stuff but some of the written parts seem obvious but ive been woodsy for a long time now, if your interested in getting into bushcrafting, this book is a great start.

great guide! buy it if you spend a lot of time outdoors: LOTS of great info! color pics with detailed description of the plant and how to process. Shows where in the country it is found. even gives recipes. the only thing i dont like about this book is the fact that the poisonous plants section is just pics with no descriptions or locations doesnt specify how its poisonous (touch or ingested) and how to treat it
nice: good little pocket guide with good info, i really like how its laminated, can take it on the trail with you
nice: good little pocket guide with good info, i really like how its laminated, can take it on the trail with you
A GREAT REFERENCE FOR THE 20TH CENTURY: This is a kind of reference book that does not have to be read in sequence.  You can begin reading anywhere!  Great pictures, great format.

Message: "Meanness Equals Love": I couldn't believe my eyes reading this book when I unpacked it.
Brother bunny ruins sister's food, messes up her clothes, ruins her paints, destroys her dolls, "smashes" food on her head, jumps out and frightens her, paints her face when she's asleep... She finally complains to parents (who were apparently oblivious.) Brother is sent to room and told he's "a bad bunny." He now ignores sister, who becomes miserable, thinking her brother doesn't love her anymore. Sister bunny tells mother this. Mom bunny SMILES and lifts the little bunny up to look in the mirror at her face, which brother painted blue during the night.
"PJ loves me! she cried. Honey Bunny Funny bunny was VERY HAPPY."
"PJ... You are the best brother a bunny could ever have!" And she gave him a great big fuzzy bunny hug.
The End.
This is such garbage. It's being returned.
Great book: I have some more of his books and I think he is a great writer! Some of the books have been made in to TV movies!
Great author: I really love Debbie Macomber’s books! I have a lot of her books!
Mary is great!: Really like the show on PBS! Paul and Mary are great!
It's an OK book: I don't regret reading it.  It's well written. I wouldn't reread it cause I was kind of glad when I finished it.  Wasn't as great as the hype.

Perfectly wonderful cookbook and more: [[VIDEOID:c0d9ef80926f076dcbddbe1ad8d24a46]] My first recipe used was Golden Cornbread.  Delicious!  I plan on trying to cook everything in the book.  It's so much more than a cookbook!  Next I will cook The Garden of Eden Salad.  It's a meal in itself.  Grains, fruit, mushrooms, lemon, figs, raisins, onions.  What's not to like!

Review for paperback edition: This is a perfectly decent copy of John Ciardi's translation of the Divine Comedy. The explanatory notes are extremely helpful, as they explain many of the obscure political, religious, and mythological references that Dante makes throughout his work. The pages are really thin. Personally I like it, but you do have to be careful, the entire book is pretty delicate.

Great: There are no words to describe how much I liked this book.  It grabbed me from the first page and didn’t let go until the end.  I could not put it down and read it in one sitting.  I found the book to be atmospheric, it gave me goose bumps at some parts.  I think that it is relevant to what is going on in society today.  I recommend this book to anyone that enjoys horror and main characters that learn to find their voice in a world that wants to keep them silent.

I loved it!!: I received an advanced copy of The Lost Dreamer by Lizz Huerta for my honest review.
I really enjoyed this book. The story telling was rich with vibrant imagery. I loved reading the two different view point of the two main characters, Indir and Saya. They were both strong in their own ways. I enjoyed reading about the Dreamers and what it was like in The Dream for them.
There were moments were I was slightly confused about the time line. I also felt that the ending was a bit rushed. The ending is good if there is going to be another book in the series, however if not then it leaves too many unanswered questions.
I fully intend to buy a physical copy of this book when it comes out and I am excited to read more from this author!

Amazing: I received an advanced reader copy of A Thousand Steps into Night by Traci Chee for my honest review.
Let me begin by saying that this is an amazing book. The story kept me gripped until the very end. I finished the book within a couple of hours, I just could not put it down. The storytelling is superb and very imaginative. I really liked the character of Miuko. You could see her character development throughout the story. I was sorry to have the story end and felt like I was missing dear friends. I will be buying a physical copy when it comes out!

Magical!: I first would like to thank the publisher for giving me a copy of this book to review.
This book was amazing. It was magical. It had the same feel as watching a favorite C-drama. Ning is such a strong character. Her love for her sister and her guilt over her mother’s death were heart wrenching to read. I am looking forward to seeing more of Ning, Zhen, Ruyi, Kang, Lian and Shu in the next book.
Judy I. Lin is a wonderful storyteller. The way she wrote made me feel completely absorbed in the story. I was grabbed from the first line and not let go even after the last chapter. I really enjoyed how the magic of the shènnóng-shī was described, so vivid. I will be waiting with bated breath for the next book.
I also would like to say that the book cover art is stunning. It lends to the story’s magical and surreal feel. This a book that is beautiful both inside and out.
Bought as a gift: I bought this as a gift for me son.  He loves this manga.  I have not read it so I can only go by what he says.

Historical romance.: I have read almost every Kristin Hannah book as she is one of my favorite authors. I just adore her writing style which is truly magical. I’m usually hooked before finishing the first chapter. However, “Waiting for the Moon” was much different. It didn’t hold my interest until halfway through. It was obviously written when the author wasn’t as experienced as a writer. The plot was good…it was a tender story about love and loss.

You won’t be disappointed.: This is a great cookbook, full of everyday recipes I will use over and over again. You will find a great selection of all types of recipes: entrées, desserts, side dishes, breads, appetizers and the like. Such beauty to each page… pictures, content, and style. Joanna Gaines really brought to life her words, “Food is the musical soundtrack of our lives.”
Super cute!: This collection of sticky notes is ever so cute! I bought it for my granddaughter and she’s enjoying it! Would definitely recommend!

adorable illustrations, well-made, highly recommend: I bought this for my granddaughter and she couldn’t be happier as she loves anything sloth related. I love that it’s hardcover and heavy-duty spiral bound so it’s extremely durable. Love the layout of the floral sketches which appear randomly.

Beautifully Printed Series: Great series well printed and vendor totally reliable. The paper supply chain issue delayed the printing deadline for sending the books but the vendor bent over backwards to explain and sent the available printed editions with the last edition to come soon. A wonderful series and beautiful books. Very pleased and nice size paperback editions to read and shelve. The vendor is fabulous!
Update: Received the one book that was delayed as promised and highly recommend Reading Spa as a source for purchases with excellent customer service!

Illuminating and Accessible!: Excellent writing and synthesis of our senses.
Like Eric Kandel, Mlodinow gives credit to others in his homage to those who labored to know what informs us to act and feel. This is an outstanding book. Highly recommend!

Transitions: Just when I wondered if the series could be winding down, more pathways are opened up. I see at least 7 more stories based on characters from this one. I wish we had learned more about the Bed and Breakfast owners. Maybe in future stories we will.

Ranger, Morelli, Diesel on my!!!: Another Plum winner!  I really loved the storyline.  I love Diesel and I love Ranger!  I also love Lula and Grandma!  However I only got one and a half laugh on loud moments!  I'm always a little sad when the book ends.  It's Silk long before the next installment!
Fun stuff: An incredibly fun read!!  Dakota Cassidy never fails to entertain!  I love the worlds she creates. Waiting for more!  Thanks Dakota!

Good clean fun: Since this is part of a series, it's impossible not to compare "My Plain Jane" with "My Lady Jane." I found "Plain Jane" to be less funny and the plot to be a whole lot less...plotty? I was enjoying the characters and their shenanigans, but no actual story emerged until halfway through the book. I haven't read the source material, Jane Eyre, and maybe that's just the way it is, but I was beginning to worry if anything was ever actually going to happen. But then suddenly a lot happened and I began liking it much better.

As usual, the characters are charming and the audiobook narrators for this series are first class. The story started knitting together at the halfway point, but some of it confused me. By the end I was having a hard time remembering exactly what Mr. Mason's purpose was in the story, and felt pretty disconnected from certain characters, as it felt they were just written off the page once they'd served their purpose. I did enjoy the book, but it didn't feel as tight and satisfying as "Lady Jane."

Dubious consent; otherwise this would be perfect!: A pretty decent erotic romance manga. I enjoyed the plot of the fireman rescuing his long-time friend from an arson attack. The love scenes were very creative. I just wish there weren't such dubious consent in this first volume, even if the two leads do have genuine feelings for one another.

Consider me officially creeped out!: I went into this book not knowing what to expect and was totally blown away. I could never tell where the story would go next, and I never knew whom to trust.

This is the story of three sisters who vanished into thin air on New Year's Day. While their parents frantically searched for them and even became suspects in their disappearance, they suddenly returned, their hair gone white, their eyes black, and their memories wiped clean.

Fast forward to adulthood. Eldest sister Grey is a world-famous model and fashion designer; Vivi is a rock band of some renown in Europe; and youngest sister, the story's narrator, Iris, just wants to be left alone by the high school bullies so she can go to college like a normal girl. But there's nothing normal about her or her sisters. They have powers over others and their own mother is afraid of them.

I really love the celebrity aspect of two of the sisters. There's a mock Vogue interview in the book and it reads just like a real fashion article. All the characters felt like real people and I felt invested in each of their lives and especially in the mystery surrounding their disappearance. The relationship between the sisters is a bit weird, but it suited the weirdness of the rest of the story. There's so much gore and mystery and horror. The book felt otherworldly but so real at the same time. There were some plot twists I saw coming, and some I didn't, but I loved how the entire story played out. It ended in such a way that there could even be more to come... I would love to delve back into this world because it's hard to let go of it, even if it terrifies me.

Repetitive and open-ended: I didn't like the first half of this book. I felt it was very repetitive and dull. The main character has a set pattern of getting angry with her stepsister, getting scared of things that go bump in the night, desperately craving weed, and getting freaked out by thinking of bed bugs. It was the same four things happening in every single chapter.

The chapters were broken up strangely. Some might only be 5 pages long, then the next would be 30. I like short chapters with easy stopping points, but here I had to stop mid-chapter a lot of the time.

I disliked a lot of characters in this book. Step-dad Alec and his daughter Piper were the worst. Piper kept doing awful things to the main character, Marigold, who was always just minding her own business, then acting innocent when Mari got mad, so everyone treated Mari like she was crazy. I found that situation very frustrating. And Alec clearly favored his own daughter and spoiled her so badly, right in front of his step kids like they were less than dirt. They were both just rotten to the core until they each showed a little humanity right in the last couple of chapters.

After the first half of the book, the story got better. I tore through the last 150 pages and absolutely loved the patented Tiffany D. Jackson plot twist. I enjoyed the second half of the book a lot, but I think this book was trying to be too many things, so in the end there are so many loose ends that are left untied. Is this a book about a haunted house, a new family failing to blend, drug addiction, phobias, friendships, romance, gentrification, the Russian mob, or a religious cult? Cause this book has all of that, and it's kind of a lot. And the pieces don't all fit together. They fit like they were forced. I just let some of the details go over my head because if I thought too hard about them, it just sounded like a mess.

I've loved the other books I've read by this author and I very nearly loved this one. The last quarter in particular was so good. But I am really disappointed by all the unanswered questions left in the end.

Very predictable but cute: I enjoyed this book well enough, but I did find it to be entirely too predictable. I knew every single plot twist that was coming by chapter 3 out of 30-some chapters. There were some mature elements, like a pirate captain who collects skulls and whose ship cabin is so saturated with the blood of his victims that the floor is permanently stained red; but on the whole I thought it read very young young-adult, more like a middle grade book. Maybe because of its predictability? It's like every cartoon adventure you've seen before in your childhood: you know from the onset who the villain is, you know who the love interest is intended to be, and you anticipate a happy ending because it's just that kind of book.

Beautiful and brilliant!: This book is brilliant! The author has me convinced she's an expert in the fields of astronomy, botany, British societal history, and...embroidery?! The setting feels alive, the characters are real, their backstories are rich, the relationships are swoonworthy. The plot is complex and still manages to fit in plenty of steamy love scenes. The plot twist at the end was amazing and had me clapping and cackling with glee! Loved this book and absolutely want to read more from this author.

Gorgeous writing and genuine scares abound!: I had no idea what this book was about but the cover made me want to read it! So I borrowed it from the library. By chapter three I'd decided I needed a copy of my own, I was enjoying it so much, and the feeling never changed.

This is the story of a house that possesses people, rather than the other way around. It's like a living thing, granting corrupted wishes to the most beautiful girls it knows throughout the years. But you always have to be careful what you wish for...because you just might get it.

There was a creepy atmosphere throughout the book and some legit scares that made me gasp out loud. I enjoyed all the characters. This book could have been twice as long and I'd still want to read about them and their adventures in the haunted house that even GPS won't acknowledge exists.

The writing was beautiful. But if I had any critique at all, it's that maybe the author's knowledge was bleeding too far onto the page. The teenagers in this book frequently throw around words like sfumato. They understand what "pre-Raphaelite" and "Louis XV-style" mean. They can operate gas lamps (a thing I only know how to do because I lived frequently without electricity in the 1980s) and they know the composition of Edwardian makeup products, for crying out loud! If they were college students studying a specific field I'd believe it, but they're kids in public school.

That aside, the writing drew me in immediately. I loved reading this book and it's going to leave a void now that it's over.

Gorgeous romcom!: I gotta admit, I'm over the crossdressing trope when it comes to cisgender characters. It's just kind of tired at this point. It was a fad over a decade ago and the synopsis of this manga feels a bit overdone. I don't even understand why the main character in this manga is disguising herself as a boy. The only purpose it serves is for her to get a job among other male staff at an all-boys café. But! Everything else about this manga, I loved.

The vampires of this manga aren't the typical. There's no mention that they can't go out in the sun (which, to me, is half the point of the character being a vampire), but they don't eat human food, at least. To them, though, human blood changes flavor depending on how much love the person has felt in their life. As a general rule, girls taste better than boys. Blood from someone who is deeply loved will taste like strawberry juice, but an unloved person will still taste disgusting. That's where main character, Mito, comes in.

Mito is a girl but dresses like a boy. Girls flock to her because they think she's a very attractive boy. (Creepy old men also flock to her, thinking she's an attractive boy...) Her family never loved her and kicked her out. She has no family anymore, and no friends. And when the manga begins, she's just lost her job because the restaurant where she works was tailored for old men to gather and eat but young girls keep coming in to flirt with her. I don't understand why (a customer is a customer, right?) but the restaurant owner is angry about the change in clientele and fires Mito.

Mito ends up at a café where a vampire named Ruka works, and they come to an arrangement. Her blood is disgusting, but she's willing to let the vampire feed from her in exchange for room and board and a job at the café. She doesn't seem disturbed or scared by the vampire at all. (Well, I mean, he is gorgeous...) And he has a secret of his own, a reason why he can't feed from girls, so to him drinking the disgusting blood of a "boy" is still better than feeding from a girl. And he vows to love Mito until his blood tastes good.

The other guys at the café don't know Ruka is a vampire, but there's someone else who does: Ren, a boy who hates vampires, because a vampire stole his mother away and turned her into one of them. Ren warns Mito about Ruka and vows to protect her from becoming a vampire, even if he has to drag her away.

The art in this manga is absolutely stunning. I love male characters with beautiful faces (all of the guys in this manga are pretty!) and especially with long hair like Ruka's. The characters have depth and complexity to them, but for the most part this manga reads like a romcom and it's very lighthearted and comical. I like the worldbuilding, but the story did feel a little bit rushed. At least it's going to have several more volumes! I like the relationships between them all. There's a pretty boy who seems infatuated with the vampire, Ruka. Ruka has a manservant who changes into a bat, and he's also gorgeous. Slayer-wannabe Ren keeps trying to stand in Ruka's way. And a love triangle seems to be developing, with both Ruka and Ren crushing no Mito, whom they think is a boy.

The author also did some cute side-panel comics about unrelated topics, like their cat. lol I enjoyed this manga a lot and look forward to more!

Prettier on the inside than the cover suggests!: This book made me laugh out loud! It reads like a romcom but it does have its serious moments. The art is gorgeous and the characters are likable. Plus it's really hot! I can already tell I'm going to enjoy this series.

Dull and rambly: This was a really long and very little happened. I stayed bored throughout the entire book but it seemed to get more boring as it went. The story jumped around a lot and it felt basically like an excuse to put Greek gods in modern-day bars and watch the fallout. There are a lot of characters but they're all rather bland. I honestly didn't like the art at all. I'm sorry I spent my money on this, but my copy is signed so I can probably make back what I spent, at least.

I'm an adult but I liked it!: Kendare Blake referenced this graphic novel in her recent book, In Every Generation, so I decided to check it out.

I found this to be sort of a mix between Locke & Key and Howl's Moving Castle, both of which are things I like. The art wasn't my favorite; everyone's heads seem to be odd shapes and almost flat in some panels. The colors were very nice, though. (At the end of the book, the author said his wife did the coloring.) I liked the characters quite a bit, especially robot-bunny Miskit and the main character's little brother, Navin. Miskit's character design is just cute, and he tries to be take-charge even though he proves to be a bit incompetent, and Navin feels like a real little brother, arguing with his big sister and wanting to be older than he is.

One plot hole in the story bothered me. The kids are trying to find their mom, and the only way is through a super dangerous tunnel full of man-eating tentacles that attack from all sides. Their only means of getting through the tunnel was by flying a little airplane and shooting the tentacles with a laser gun. But they lost the laser gun and then crashed the airplane as soon as they got through the tunnel, and the story never explained how they went back through the tunnel again and returned to the house, after they barely made it the first time and lost all their supplies. They were just suddenly safe back at their headquarters, and that bugged me.

This was a quick, entertaining read. The author definitely has me interested in the elven prince and in the possibility of time travel in a future volume. I'm curious to read more for sure.

If you don't know Buffy, you might be bored: I bought this book because I love the author. When it was first announced, for the first time I started binging Buffy the Vampire Slayer, the TV show. I was hoping I'd have time to watch it all by the time the book was released. Then Kendare said you don't have to have watched the show to enjoy the book, so I slowed my viewing and watched other things... I was partway through season 2 when I picked this book up. And it spoiled EVERYTHING about the show, all the way to the end. So if you have any interest at all in the TV series, WATCH IT FIRST. I was really enjoying the show and now I'm sad. I really wish I'd binged it all before picking up In Every Generation.

This book has a huge cast, a mash-up between canon and original characters, and they all have vital roles in the story. But I don't think someone unfamiliar with Buffy will care about them because they're all clearly preexisting characters with preestablished relationships. You really feel like you're thrown into the middle of things and if you haven't watched the show, you may really not like this book. There were times I didn't even like it, but mostly when they were spoiling things I hadn't found out in the show yet.

The new characters were good. The overall plot was awesome! The main villain was the perfect nemesis to bring to life...er...unlife. I loved the ending. And it left me curious to see how the mystery concludes. I'm definitely going to continue this series. But I do not have the happy, nostalgic feelings that other readers who grew up with Buffy have. When I was a teen, I saw the Buffy movie. I never watched the TV show, though. It was probably on cable and I didn't have access to that, growing up. We had 3 channels and no internet back then. lol

My second biggest complaint, after the way the book kind of ruined the show for me, is that the romance was not interesting. Everybody in this book gets into some kind of relationship or wants to be in one or is pining over a former one. And I couldn't really picture any of the characters together that way so it was just weird to me. I wasn't rooting for any of the couples.

Lastly, I listened to the audiobook and I did not like the narrator. So my plan is to finish binging Buffy (the show) over the next year, then to reread this book (with my eyes), and continue on with the second. I'm always going to support Kendare but I do not think this book would be very appealing to non-Buffy fans because all the worldbuilding and half the cast is from a show you would know nothing about.

Rushed but addicting: I loved this manga, but it does have some problems. The pacing is atrocious, which causes the story to be unrealistic. The overall plot is amazing but it took me until the last chapter to appreciate it because the writing itself just isn't good. The story is rushed and jumps around so much you feel like you have to be missing scenes. If the chapters were drawn out for longer this would have been so much better, but even as it is, I love it and can't wait to get my hands on more. The art is some of the prettiest I've ever seen. It's just hard to believe the main character can be as unobservant and gullible as she is portrayed. The vampires in this manga are of a very unique variety and that, combined with a little romance, is what's holding my interest.

Problematic content but a satisfying story: On the whole I liked this, but for some reason it was taking me forever to plod through, so I switched to the audiobook halfway through to finish it up quickly.

So...Richelle Mead. I read a couple of her Vampire Academy books years ago, then recently read some of her Glittering Court series. And I enjoyed them to varying degrees, but...listen...she's always writing something problematic (student/teacher sex in VA and women literally auctioning themselves off to men in GC), but this book takes the cake so far. The problem this time is the racism. The main character meets her love interest for the first time at a bar and keeps staring at him because he looks "exotic." So he turns to her and says, "I bet you're wondering what race I am, aren't you?" So...that happened. Then there is a character in this book who is white but "looks Native American." So...he pretends to be Native American to pick up girls. He wears a fringe vest, says "how" - yes, really - and talks about the "Great Spirit" to impress women. And that is literally all he does. This character has no purpose in the book's plot whatsoever and you forget he's there until he pops up to be flamboyantly racist again. If he weren't in the book, the book would be unchanged. So...maybe someone like an editor should have suggested scrapping him...one would think.

ANYWAY. This book is more than a decade old and that's no excuse, but there was more to the story, fortunately!

The main character is a shaman. She has exceptional abilities when it comes to banishing otherworldly creatures from the plane of Earth, so that is her profession. I thought that was pretty cool. She comically exorcises a demon from a shoe first thing. She has magical tattoos that can help her contact Hecate and Persephone from Greek mythology, and those help her banish fae back to the fairy realm or send demons back to hell, whichever she wants to do. She also has three magical creatures assisting her, two of them bound to her service and one of them volunteering. She has a magic ring, daggers, guns, and athames. Fae cannot bear iron or anything made of a similar alloy, and other creatures cannot stand against silver, so she has some things made of each. And she has the very unique ability to travel between all three worlds (Earth, the fae realm, and the land of the dead). No shaman before her has possessed such unique capabilities. Gee, I wonder why.

A lot of predictable things occurred in the book, from the main character Eugenie's mysterious past to other major plot points. There were obvious hints along the way and nothing really surprised me, at least until the end. Then everything went crazy and some really clever plot twists came to light, that made me give this book 4 stars instead of 3.

Eugenie has two love interests and there are plenty of romance and spicy love scenes in the story for paranormal romance fans. One is the hot guy she met at the bar early in the story, and one is the fae King of the Autumn Court. Both of these relationships have some really interesting complexities. I liked them both but hot-guy-at-the-bar was Best Boy. For me, once a love interest is first introduced, I tend to pick him because he was first in line. lol Seriously, you can't make me like a character and then throw in some competition because my loyalties have already been aligned.

The fae in this book are referred to as the "gentry," and I loved that. It made them sound formal and fancy. lol

There were some really interesting plot elements. The main story kicks off when a guy contacts Eugenie for her usual services, dealing with otherworldly creatures, and tells her his sister was kidnapped by a fae king (who is awesome and was my favorite character). Okay, there were SO many twists involved in that plotline and I did not see any of them coming! That storyline runs up till the end of the book. It was ingenious. I think I would have enjoyed the story more if the focus had been more on that, maybe. It's not that I didn't like all the flirting going on, but sometimes it bogged down the story for me, even though romance is my favorite factor in any media.

What I really didn't like was the fact that, for reasons, all the otherworldly characters (even the "good guys") are trying to rape Eugenie. Every male character in the book wants a piece of her, and it was gross. And, adding to the problematic material, the girl that was kidnapped by the fae king is only 14 and he is also having sex with her. No. Just...no. At least it isn't graphically depicted but the story wouldn't have changed at all if that character had been at least 18 years of age. So...why do this...to a child...

There is a lot of focus on the magic system in this book, though I never really figured out why the gentry want to use bondage as a method of training magical skills. It's never really explained but there is a lot of tying-up, if you're into that. lol

The worldbuilding was interesting. I liked who could travel between worlds and how. There are a lot of interesting rules about that. And it was very interesting that the fae were originally from Earth, until anyone with magical abilities was banished to another realm. Part of the main plot revolves around a fae faction that wants to return to Earth and conquer, or at least make things the way they were with humans and the gentry coexisting once more. The gentry are fascinated with all things human, from pop culture references to food. That was a really interesting element.

This book on the whole was a mixed bag for me. The problematic material was REALLY problematic. But the plot worked out in ways that by the end of it that I have to say I can appreciate the complexity of the thing. I'm just not sure if I would read this again... I will continue the series. I bought all four books at a used book store and they might go right back there eventually, but that remains to be seen. I'm probably going to stick with the audiobooks from the library because things went so much faster that way for me.
God Bless those that served here on HIll 488: 17 really brave men, all wounded , against long odds

Amazing Work of Art: I purchased this book for my husband. The book itself is a work of art. Stunning. My husband,, who has a musical background and is a longtime admirer of the genius of Paul McCartney and the Beatles, couldn’t put it down. This is a project of Paul’s, so he was personally invested in the making of the book-not just someone doing it all for him. The book allows you to see through Paul’s eyes. Beautiful.

Marvelous!!!: I purchased this book as a gift for a friend. After it arrived, I began leafing through the book and absolutely fell in love with it!  The book is fascinating and laid out to be incredibly readable. It's so different from any other book I've purchased about birds, which usually end up being dry and hard to navigate. This book opens up a far greater understanding, providing information bird by bird that includes beautiful illustrations. It's a larger format book and so very organized. I can't imagine the work that went into creating this book.  I highly recommend it as a great gift–even for young readers. But, like me, you'll probably end up ordering a copy for yourself.
Fantastic insights!: Incredible real-life journey...

For Beginners???: This book is packed with information and the author knows his stuff.  However, there is some repeated information here, as well as things that don't make sense.  I know something about solar and electricity, but I quickly got bogged down in all the technical stuff here.  NO WAY is this for beginners.  This book has shown me that the best thing for me would be to hire a pro to do the work.

Nice sounding music: The tunes are perfect for learning Christmas songs. The music is pleasing, not tinny.
My four year old charge easily picked out the songs for each page by matching the pictures on the page.

REQUIRED READING 4 EVERYONE: This should be REQUIRED READING for everyone in the world. This is the only document that explains the meaning of FREEDOM and how to ALLOW GOVERNMENT to Serve The People in a way that DOES NOT INFRINGE on the God Given Rights of The People.
De Ja Vue: Pretty much follows  the same route as Lonesome Dove...

And the human comedy continues....: This book is an attempt by the author to put the future under indictment by looking backward and asking the question 'Just how bad can things get?'. The kernel idea of the book --or, the Archimedean point for you tech/engineering types-- is that things, in America, are moving in a very, VERY, dangerous direction and that we, as Americans seem blithely unaware of this trend and, furthermore, that our society's elites are purposely leading us astray.
Another interesting wrinkle comes from a recent episode of TC's TV show; it was his last, in Hungry, with PM Viktor Orban where he asks the question noted above....'Just how bad can things get?'. But here, he refers to bullet holes in buildings that note what level of violence can erupt in civil society.
TC's analysis focuses on the media world where he lives and works. He --rightfully in my view-- laments the corrosive degradation of respect for the tenets of free speech, free inquiry, and robust, unrestrained debate. He properly skewers Simon and Schuster (Jonathan Karp and, Dana Canedy particularly) as a once blazing beacon promoting these intellectual values which are the hallmark of the 'open mind'.
He brings to light how far this institution has strayed from it's gigantic past as a champion of free thinking. He notes that a free society must protect and nurture this mind set if it, meaning us the USA, is to survive.
As to the book itself.....all one need do is read the introduction, where this analysis/review/argument is presented. Everything else is material drawn from work product from his earlier career except for a one page closing which is the expected lamentation, summing up, that reduces to 'we ain't in Kansas anymore'. If one is a devotee of W Somerset Maugham, or William Saroyan all this is no surprise given they too, like TC, looked back with angst as mankind --OOPS, HUMANkind-- stumbled forward.
But, having said all that....BUY THE BOOK. There are wonderful vignettes of days gone by.....like listening to Al Sharpton when he was very pro academic proficiency for the next generation of black students in public schools. Plus, the book is an easy, flowing, read and is easily digestible for any reader. TC's text show how powerful his linguistic skills are, and vault him to a very prominent position in America's current public forum.

A pleasing, but rather ordinary, SH mystery....: This story is good if one does not have much else at hand for diversion and relaxation. Really, this book's audience is deep Sherlock Holmes fans only.

Very tedious, but insightful nonetheless: Far, that's FAR, too much Hollywood movie minutia. The biographical dimension only gets interesting when the author focuses on Eastwood's long, LONG, LONG, love life. The author vividly shows the difference between a man like Harvey Weinstein and Clint Eastwood; to wit, Eastwood ATTRACTED women and Weinstein did not. There will always be a fundamental difference between seduction and coercion. Eastwood has many notches on his gun; but they all came to him gladly
Eastwood --like other legendary Hollywood womanizers: John Derek, Roger Vadim as examples-- drew women to themselves because they were SUCCESSFUL men with money, power, and influence in an industry addicted to such things, plus, they all were just personally attractive (as themselves) with their physicality, personality, and lavish lifestyle. While Weinstein was equally successful in the industry, he was a fat, sloppy, lethargic, ill kempt slob no matter how often he appeared in an ultra expensive tuxedo at Hollywood affairs and parties.
In the end, this very human component is the driving force in all these human interactions. Simply, bottom line, Eastwood's life proves that for all eternity men go out to conquer the world and acquire wealth.....to spend it on women. And there will always be legions of women willing to play such a game.
A coffee table book.....: Lots of pictures with a few compelling passages here and there. Movie historians will gain very little from this book.

A love letter....: Understandably, this book is a love letter to Rush by someone who was a loyal employee for many years. The author gives a gentle review of RL's life and contribution to the broadcast industry. Not much else of note to consider here....

Insightful, worth the effort: The author gives a serious, searing review of Bill DeBlasio and his long destructive administration of NYC. There is one chapter, deep into the book, that vividly records how literally billions of taxpayer dollars get wasted every year by a cadre of political operatives who flow between campaigns, city offices, consulting groups, law firms, and lobbyists. These people have no interest in solving problems when they can 'manage solutions' forever....those who do well under the guise of doing good. All they need is puppets like Bill DeBlasio to front for them.

Far too much tedium: Frankly, just not enough humanity that focuses on the title character. Far too much trivia surrounding the making of this, or that, particular picture. Plus, the author has a habit of interjecting details (usually salty/judgmental comments from other personalities) without warning into a timeline for an event that occurred years later. This habit severely complicates a reader's ability to follow the flow of Lancaster's story.

Just an excellent read....: The author writes smooth, flowing --indeed fast moving-- events into a great narrative. Short chapters that are readily digestible and give a more languid reader lots of opportunity to pause and reflect. Plus, the current/present tense presentation of the facts pulls in the reader from student to witness. There's everything here.....battle, intrigue, sex, conspiracy, politics.
One short coming is the author's penchant to jump around the landscape of events rather than following a more concise narration, and this may disconcert more focused readers, or students, of history. This pithy style may well be a legacy of the author's association with BOR.

A good read; informative and entertaining: This author tells a smooth, easily digestible --but substantial-- story from history about a family and their travails during very tumultuous times. Unfortunately, he does drift into the weeds occasionally which is likely due (in my mind) to his respect for a full accounting that may occasionally weigh against telling a startling, moving, tale.
Plus, it's very nice to see that old truth come shining through yet again: There's nothing new under the sun. If we were to place a fine bottle of Madeira, a prime roast with all the trimmings, and a lovely woman in front of Benjamin Franklin, he would not be confused as to what to do with all three succulents. So take THAT, Bill and Monica!!!
Utter crap!!!: Garbage. This book is the kind of excrement one reads when there is just nothing else available and one needs to deflect the mind.

A detailed view in the mentality of the Kennedy patriach.: The Kennedys....self-centered, arrogant men, and very smart. compliant women. That's the family that the author brings forward while examining Joe Sr.'s years as an ambassador. The author throws more light on the simple adage that resonated all through Joe Sr.'s life: Wives are for children and women are for fun.
Inadvertently, almost as a casual happenstance, the author uncovers the simple --almost boyish-- disposition that developed in JFK's attitude towards women. And it was this odd charm JFK radiated, while still maintaining a colossal ego and self assurance, which would explain all his many romantic conquests who, despite being horribly abused, still held warm regards for him until the end.
As for the book itself....as a read, it can be ponderous occasionally. But, in her quest for vivid detail, which she provides, the author rewards the reader's strain with a colorful view of these years in the Kennedy clan's life story.
