The lady writes the way she talks......forever.: A long journey to God knows where; but while on the trek she does settle some scores.
a sweet story: I enjoyed this story. It flows fast and tells a nice tale. It does your heart good.  A really good weekend snowstorm read.
The edge of the lost: I just started reading it and its very interesting. I finished the book and it was so good to read.

The story is sweet, but the binding is very poor. Several pages separated from binding.: Having just gotten into the book, I can't comment on the story just yet. It looks promising though. However, I was saddened that as I turned to page 10/11, the binding cracked and split up the middle. It did so for a few pages. It seems to only be in the beginning pages and not any further along, but we'll see. I can repair the book, but it's just disappointing.

UPDATE: Just finished the story, and it's a very sweet Christmas love story. The characters are likeable, and I loved the push and pull of the story and the very cool plot twists.

UPDATE ON THE BINDING: I've fixed loose pages before in books, but this one was really bad. The first 30 pages were completely coming away from the spine, rather than just being loose. So it was hard to fix, the result being pages that were no longer even because they kept slipping. Sad. Probably won't keep the book at this point.

An important outlook on the gospel, especially these days: Great book, full of Miller's trademark humor, at least in the beginning. His point of looking at the Gospel and each others from a relational standpoint should be obvious, but in this day and age is still profound. Tearing down the fundamental view of scripture (and specifically using it to push anyone not like us out of the lifeboat - a big metaphor throughout) and pointing people back to building relationship with God is such an important message, especially these days.

Great practical guide for beginners in comedy: Great book, practical application exercises, excellent lessons and discussions on comedy, and the book itself is pretty hilarious in its own right. If you want a good beginner's guide to comedy this is it.
Books have a very cheap feel: I do not like the illustrations and the pages seem of poor quality

Creepy and surprisingly short for a Stephen King: This was definitely the length of a full book, but somehow still felt like a novella. Stephen King writes in such a way that even when it's nearly 300 pages, it feels too short. 

This was a great story about a kid (later teenager)--Jamie--who is able to see dead people. At first that's useful to help find a missing item, or complete a task left undone before an untimely death. But soon Jamie realizes all the ways this power of his can go wrong. 

It's nice to be able to read a Stephen King book in an afternoon instead of dedicating weeks :) 

I liked how this covered the horrors associated with both the supernatural aspect of seeing dead people, but also at how living people can manipulate this power, both bringing terrible consequences. 

I just would have liked a bit more, the ending felt a tad rushed. But any fans of Stephen King or horror would definitely enjoy!

Not great: Synopsis: 20 years ago, Rachel accidentally shot and killed her brother Luke with what she thought was an air pellet gun but ended up being a real gun. Or so she thought. Now, other people who were there that night are getting murdered, and she's worried she and her family are next. 

This was just ok. It had an interesting premise, but was so incredibly repetitive, I found myself skimming through large chunks. I also thought one major twist wasn't explained particularly well, so it felt like it was largely for shock value but not fully thought out. 

It wasn't terrible, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend.

Just ok for me: So this was basically The Chicken Sisters set during WWII. Don't read this if you're hungry!

Very quick synopsis: During WWII in a small village, four women enter a cooking contest, each with something to prove.

This one didn't do it for me. I think the premise would have been interesting if I hadn't read The Chicken Sisters, but the writing and character development fell flat. Every character seemed really one-dimensional. I also thought it was really predictable.

It was a quick read though, and I liked the alternating POVs. And I enjoyed having the recipes interspersed throughout. It wasn't terrible, it just didn't really stand out for me.

So exciting!: This was so good! Highly recommend for thriller fans. 

Synopsis: A woman disappears when she's out for a late night jog. Just a couple weeks later, another woman and her 6-year-old daughter go missing. 11 years later, the missing daughter returns, answering some questions but raising even more. 

This was such an entertaining read and had me completely hooked throughout. It's told in alternating perspectives, and alternating between present time and 11 years prior -- both after the second woman goes missing and before. Despite all the jumping around it was really easy to follow, and it does such a great job of building suspense. 

A couple twists were on my radar, but the way it all came together was still completely unexpected. 

I also thought it does a really good job of being exciting but also making you think about the emotional impact on the characters, it was more than just a whodunnit. 

The Good Girl is still my favorite by Mary Kubica, but this is up there!

Exciting, surprising ending: I've seen a lot of lackluster reviews, so I wasn't really sure what to expect, but I actually really liked this! 

Synopsis: Struggling writer Jake Bonner is teaching a creative writing class when one of his students tells him he has an idea for a plot that is sure to be a hit. Years later, Jake is wondering whatever happened to the student's book and after some searches, finds out that he died without ever publishing it. Jake decides to write the book himself, and gets every success the student had predicted, but soon he starts getting notes that reveals someone knows he stole the plot. 

My only negative on this was that the can't-fail plot wasn't really all THAT amazing. Definitely interesting, but I wouldn't say enough to guarantee bestseller, Oprah's book club, and movie rights. 

Otherwise, I thought this had an intriguing premise with the ethical dilemmas it portrayed And I did NOT see the ending coming at all. I listened to it on audio book and thought it was really enjoyable!

Exciting read, really enjoyed the end: This was a great book to read in front of the fire with a glass of wine! (hot chocolate would definitely work too)  

Synopsis: A company retreat at a ski chalet in France goes horribly wrong, with an avalanche trapping them and people start dying.

This felt like a revamp of The Hunting Party, where you start off knowing that people die from the very beginning, but you don't know who, or how, or why. (The fact that we know exactly how many die at the beginning is why i'm not comparing it to And Then There Were None, although the locked door mystery aspect was definitely reminiscent of that.) 

This was nothing revolutionary, and the twists weren't all that shocking, but I very much enjoyed reading this and flew through it in two days. The atmosphere is great, and it's super creepy even without the murders, getting snowed into the chalet after an avalanche. I liked how the big reveal of who the killer was came earlier than I expected, and was handled so matter-of-factly, that it wasn't really a big reveal at all. It was a really unique approach.  And it meant the final 100 pages or so were just pure adrenaline. 

(I'll add that I did grow up skiing, so that helped. I've heard that people that weren't familiar with ski terms were put off by this)

Enjoyed it but found it problematic: Third in The Hollows series (although easily read as a standalone), this has been my favorite one so far. I really liked the mystery at first, and I liked Lana as a twisty, flawed character. Some parts were problematic though, which I'll get to but will involve spoilers!  

Synopsis: College senior Lana Granger gets a job babysitting for a troubled, manipulative young boy. After arguing over the job with her roommate Beck, Beck disappears. Although Beck has run off in the past, this feels different, and police and friends are quick to point out that previous friends of Lana's have disappeared before, is this a pattern? 

I don't know how to talk about this without spoilers, so be warned! 

I really liked that this had a transgender main character, and at first how she seemed to find herself as a female in a way she never felt as male. However, I didn't like that as soon as Beck revealed she knew about Lana's background, her gender was all of a sudden a disguise and not who she truly was. It felt superficial, and as other characters realized her past, Lana started referring to "Lane" as her "real name" instead of her deadname. 

I think it ultimately took away a lot from the diverse angle I thought this was going to present, as it seems Lane became Lana only to hide from the press, not because of actual self-discovery.

I did like the mystery and thought it was a quick read, but the trans representation is problematic at best, and I wish it had been handled differently.

Exciting read: I got an early copy of this from @bookishfirst and @syracuseupress, I thought this was really interesting with a really exciting ending! 

Synopsis: A friendship between Galan, a Cuban emigrant in Puerto Rico, and Pat, a Coast Guard officer, comes to a head when Galan desperately needs to get his sister to join him in Puerto Rico.
 
I wasn't sure about this at first. The beginning was fine, but nothing amazing, and I thought a lot of it was rather predictable. I also thought the way the flashbacks (which came up frequently in the first half or so) were handled in a kind of clunky way. 

But the last 100 pages are really exciting, and I got so much more into it! There were some side stories that seemed unnecessary at first, but ended up mattering so much by the end. The whole book ended up having some strong messages on family, loyalty, and honor. 

I plan to look for thoughts by Cuban reviewers. The author is a former Coastie, so obviously has good background for Pat's perspective, but I'm very curious about how #ownvoice reviewers interpreted Galan's perspective. But I definitely enjoyed this!

Such an exciting book: This was my first @ladyhawkins book, and I am definitely going to go back and read more by her! Thank you to @netgalley and @stmartinspress for an early copy of this! 
*
Synopsis: Lux and her boyfriend Nico are hired to sail two women to a deserted island a couple days from Hawaii. The island is gorgeous and remote, and they quickly bond with the other couple they find there. But the longer they stay on the island, the more cracks begin to form among the friends and couples, and the island's creepy history makes everything more ominous.
 *
This was so fun, and while objectively not much happens plot-wise for a good chunk of the book, it never felt slow. The background of the island provides the perfect eerie backdrop, and I loved the flashback chapters giving the history of the island as well as insight into each of the women on the island. 
*
I really liked Lux, the main character, and in particular her friendships with the other women. Even though she was kind of a moron about Nico, it was really easy to root for her. 
*
The ending was nuts. Very fast, but didn't feel rushed, and had several twists that I did not see coming. 
*
 If you like this book and true crime, I would definitely recommend And The Sea Will Tell. I got major vibes of that throughout this book, which made sense at the author's note, where she says that was part of her inspiration. 
*
Overall I would definitely recommend, this is a great book to kick off 2022 reading!  (Although I wish I was reading it on a tropical beach somewhere)

Great writing, slow story: Epic, and over really enjoyable, with really great writing. 
*
Synopsis: Marian Graves from a young age really wants to be a pilot, although as a woman in the early-to-mid 20th century, she has to struggle to get opportunities, including smuggling alcohol from Canada during Prohibition and shuttling planes during WWII. After the war, she decides to fly a "great circle" around the globe, but sadly goes missing during the flight, assumed to have died in a crash over the ocean. In 2014, Hadley Baxter is cast as Marian in the movie about her life, adapted from a journal found in Antarctica, but which leaves many questions about her life and those in it. 
*
Overall I liked this. It's really long but doesn't (always) feel that way. I liked the parallels between Marian and Hadley, and the process of Hadley discovering herself through discovering Marian. I also really liked how the movie very clearly gets it wrong -- I feel like most books with alternating timelines end up miraculously coming together, so this felt more realistic. 
*
I especially loved all the side characters (especially from Marian's storyline) and thought it was impressive how well they were developed and the story arcs that brought them together. 
*
One part of the ending I thought was very predictable, but another was really surprising and emotional. 
*
In general, while I enjoyed it while reading it, I didn't really feel compelled to pick it up. There were great sections, and then other parts that were sort of a slog to get through. I'm glad I read it, but I wouldn't recommend to everyone

Fine but nothing amazing: I thought this was fine. Not bad, but nothing particularly amazing either.
*
Synopsis: Daisy Wilder is a bit of a loner, dresses in trousers when all other girls are in skirts, and is desperately trying to care of her mom since she'd fallen into a depression after her father died years earlier. She gets the chance to be trained on radar to support WWII efforts, while also ending up falling for someone unexpected and possibly off-limits.
*
I read this in a day. Not because it was amazing, but because it was simplistic enough to fly through. There was one twist I didn't expect (although I don't think it was actually possible to predict since there wasn't enough information) but the rest of it was completely predictable.
*
I did like the setting in Hawaii, and the descriptions of the island, and the use of Hawaiian words sprinkled in. This was an aspect of WWII that I wasn't familiar with, although the storyline of women proving themselves during the war is not new.
*
Overall it was fine, but with all the amazing WWII fiction out there, I wouldn't necessarily recommend this.

Wonderful, such a beautiful story: In short, I loved this. Thank you to @bookishfirst and @penguinteen for an early copy! 
*
Synopsis: In 1989, Romanians are struggling to live in a brutal communist dictatorship, hearing by illegal radios that other communist regimes are falling and wondering when they will also be free. 17-year-old Cristian gets bribed by the secret police to be an informer, and has to balance the safety of his family with his desire to really affect change in his country. 
*
This was pretty short, and very quick to get through, but so incredibly powerful. Everyone is suspicious of everyone, including family members, especially when some people are informing on others out of a sense of duty, whereas others like Cristian feel they have no choice so they can protect their loved ones. For a YA novel, it was really heavy, teens were certainly not immune from the horrors of the regime. 
*
I didn't know much about the Romanian communist regime, and what conditions were like there at that time, so it was fascinating to read this perspective. This book is eye-opening, thrilling, and heartbreaking all at the same time.

3.5 stars - the ending redeemed it: This was a psychological thriller that I really wasn't sure about for about half the book but I'm glad I stuck with it because the ending was really exciting! Thank you to @netgalley and @oceanviewpub for a copy of this.
*
Synopsis: Susan Lentigo is heading across the country to witness the execution of the man who raped and killed her 7-year-old daughter Amy 20 years earlier. But on the way, she discovers something that makes her question if the man about to be executed is actually guilty.
*
I started off not really liking this. I wasn't really impressed with the writing, and a lot of it felt really unrealistic (Amy's friends "weeping" over her death 20 years later...come on, they were 7 when it happened.) I also really didn't like Susan. I've seen a lot of reviews talk about her strength, which is true I guess, but I was really turned off by her immediate wish to (or actually) use violence. As an example, in one scene a woman is rude to her, and she "had an urge to slap this woman's face." This reaction happens a lot, and for me it took away from her.
*
But the ending really was exciting, and I liked how it all came together. I'm not sure if that was particularly realistic either, but there was enough rationale behind it to make it plausible, and I really enjoyed it. I also loved Kyra, a teenager Susan meets along the way. She was so fun, and I wish there was more of her.
*
I hovered around 2 or 3 stars for most of this, but the ending bumped it up to 3.5 for me!

Loved this: Oh I love this series so much!
*
Synopsis: Lincoln Rhyme is in NC for spinal surgery when the local sheriff asks for his help finding a teen who killed one person and kidnapped two others. Lincoln and Amelia do what they do but things get nuts along the way.
*
This starts a bit slow, but is just packed with twists so it gets exciting really quickly. It ends up pitting Lincoln against Amelia at one point, and that was really fun to see how they managed that. There ended up being a lot more to it than just the initial investigation, and I was looking forward to continuing the book the whole time I was reading it.
*
Definitely recommend this series, and can't wait for the next one!

Beautiful and powerful: This book is pretty short, under 300 pages, and it can be ready really quickly (I finished in a day), but don't let that fool you about just how powerful this is.
*
Synopsis: Hadi and Sama are living in Boston in 2017, both Syrian refugees. Hadi travels to Jordan when his father dies, and upon his return he finds out that he is no longer allowed to enter the country. Sama goes into early labor, and their family feels like it's been torn apart forever.
*
I remember the outcry surrounding the travel ban in 2017, but this puts a human face to it. The helplessness they both feel, the frustration, finding out that Hadi was lied to about what form he needed to fill out and how that will change his life forever. The decisions they each have to make -- for their marriage, for themselves, for their newborn son who is unquestioningly American.
*
I loved the flashbacks that reveal some hints into how Hadi and Sama met and their relationship developed, as well as their backgrounds in Syria and why they chose to leave.
*
This had a ton of really beautiful moments that seemed small while reading through it but had so much weight behind them. This was truly a wonderful read.

Strong continuation to the series: I've really liked this series so I was excited to get an early copy of this. Out of three so far published, this is my second favorite and I'm excited to see where the rest of the series goes. Thanks to @netgalley and @harlequinbooks for a copy!
*
Synopsis: A bomb goes off on a charter sunset cruise off a Washington state island, killing all nine on board. Quinn, Costa, and the FBI mobile response unit are desperately trying to figure out who was responsible--was it the local environmental group that was protesting the cruise company, the woman who didn't board at the last second but let her much older and richer husband go, or was someone worried the retired FBI agent got too close to the truth investigating a cold case?
*
I really like this series - it's exciting, the characters are fun, and at least this one didn't leave me lost in financial terms :) I like the team environment for this type of mystery, that there's not one person who's the superstar, but they all work together, they all make mistakes, they don't always get along, and that makes it feel real.
*
I will say that I'm not a fan of the romance between Quinn and Costa, I don't think it adds anything and just gets annoying the constant debate about its appropriateness. I also thought the last 50 pages or so dragged a bit, and there were a few implausible twists.
*
But overall, I really liked it and can't wait for the next one!

Interesting, sweet story: This was cute, overall a really story of love and loss. It was really interesting reading about how Denver handled the Spanish flu and thinking about how that compares to the recent treatment of COVID (the mayor says it's ok to go to the parade today! You can't get the flu if you vote Republican!) 
*
In general I liked the characters, although they were largely one-dimensional. The characters you were supposed to like were sweet and kind-hearted, while the characters you weren't supposed to like were almost caricatures of evil. I also thought the secrets and twists that were revealed over time were a bit jarring how they were brought up, they didn't seem to come up naturally. 
*
This didn't necessarily blow me away, but it was interesting and easy to read.

Good premise but ending fall apart: Cults and mysterious pasts? Yes please! Thanks to @netgalley and @harlequinbooks for an early copy of this.
*
Synopsis: Rainy Ives reluctantly agrees to go on a girls' weekend to Vegas with some women she met when she moved to Washington for her boyfriend. But it quickly becomes apparent that there may be some ulterior motives to the trip, and then one woman disappears and Rainy receives a text message from that woman's phone indicating that she is in trouble and whoever has her phone knows Rainy's real background.
*
I really liked this at first. Rainy is a fun, likeable character, and her interactions with some of the women are really entertaining. The flashbacks to her childhood are also fascinating and horrifying, and keep the book moving quickly.
*
Unfortunately the last 75 pages or so completely fell apart for me. Rainy makes some really stupid choices that have no logic behind them, there were a lot of plotholes, and red herrings brought up that didn't end up making any sense in retrospect.
*
I'm disappointed because I think it had a lot of potential, and I really enjoyed the characters and some of the twists, but it just didn't hold up.

Really enjoyed: If you enjoy Tudor-era historical fiction, then Alison Weir is the undisputed master, and this book completely lived up to my expectations!
*
This tells the full story of Elizabeth of York, daughter of Edward IV and wife of Henry VII. This is long and detailed and you will feel like you know Elizabeth inside and out by the end, and all that she had to endure in varying stages of her life. I love that, knowing that this was written by Alison Weir, that I can trust there is thought and a ton of research behind everything presented. Even though it is historical fiction, it is still as true to fact as possible.
*
I especially liked the alternative perspectives considered for the events following Edwards IV's death. It is easy to ascribe intent to actions when looking back in time, but I appreciated that she set up several characters who essentially played "Devil's advocate" roles against the accepted norm. That was a unique set-up that was interesting to think about.
*
My biggest negative is that I thought the early chapters were a bit clunky with scene-setting (a lot of "let me sit you down and explain the history of these people and their families...which was helpful as a reader but made it a bit slow to get into the actual narrative.)
*
Overall I really enjoyed this, but I LOVE reading this era. I wouldn't necessarily recommend it for a casual historical fiction fan, as it is very long and very detailed and I think without some level of passion it could be boring. But it was perfect for me!

3.5 stars - dramatic ending but slow start: This took me a while to get into. I liked Ronke but the others just seemed terrible. On their own and to each other, so it made it hard to root for them. And it was frustrating to read at times because it seemed SO obvious how terrible Isobel was, but no one (except Ronke) seemed to notice. 
*
The ending redeemed it for me. It turned dark FAST. I like dark, and this still caught me off guard. So overall I liked it, I just wish it had moved a bit faster. (I also wish a bit more had come out of the stalker storyline...that was intriguing!)

Really exciting but confusing ending: This is the 21st book in the Temperance Brennan series (inspiration for the show Bones), and it was among my favorites right up until the very end, which lost me a bit. Thanks to @netgalley and @scribnerbooks for the early copy!
*
Synopsis: A series of murders, some recent and some recently discovered, remind Tempe of murders she had previously assisted on the investigations. Is there a copycat killer, who is trying to target Tempe?
*
I really liked this. It was quick moving and exciting, and I really enjoyed the references to previous books, at least at first. There was also one twist that caught me completely off guard.
*
I thought the side stories were also well done, addressing issues with veteran mental health and homelessness.
*
My biggest issue is that this ultimately requires knowledge, and memory, of previous books. I actually read about 13 of the series in the past few months to catch up to this one, and I didn't remember a key case. It left me a bit confused about the ultimate motivation for the murders.
*
If you skipped previous books, or read them years ago, there's a really good chance this won't make sense. I really did enjoy this, but fair warning!
Excellent book helped for home turtoring: This book as well known so my feedback means nothing. It did help me a lot to tutor my daughters at home.
Great book: Great book and value
Great book: Great book and value
Wonderful book: Love all the pictures and explanations/travel suggestions
A must read for everyone: Great value and book.
Good book: Good book for the value.  Easy beach read
Raunchy white trash noir: I'm a Stephen Hunter fan. This is rated M for Mature. It's violent, raunchy and doesn't pull punches.
Dispelled my confusion about these creatures.: Visually detailed photos, accompanied by in depth descriptions of each family, helped me understand the depth and complexity of spiderhood.
Part of a series: Bought for Grandson he loves this series
Part of a series: Bought for Grandson he loves this series
Part of a series: Bought for Grandson he loves this series
Part of a series: Bought for Grandson he loves this series

An amazing story: I was highly impressed by the book. Not only about the way it reflects the very complicated political history of the country, but also by the way the characters are developed and described.  It made me feel very profoundly their moments of happiness, sadness, loses  and above all, the resignation.  The children are less defined, until they are presented as adults.  I found the book and what the house represents, to be very moving. Life go on. People adjust, pull themselves together and move on

surprised by the negative reviews: While this one grabbed me from the start and held me rapt throughout, I found myself distracted trying to figure out who "Judy" really was, and where Fern was in the present-day part of the story. Also, how Trent Sr. originally got involved in the whole thing (although that might have been explained and I missed it).

Wonderfully told, and horrifying that the story comes from real-life events.
Lost Light: Best Bosch yet. This one is written in the first person so we are able to get into Harry's head -- to know what makes him tick.

short who-dunnit: Short but took the long way around to get to the point. This one is set in Canada's Northwest Territories, so there wasn't so much of the French names that trip up my enjoyment.

The story starts with the macabre discovery of murdered newborns -- which was upsetting -- but then veers off into something totally different. I kept wondering what one story line had to do with the other, but Ms. Reichs brought it all together and tied it up with a neat little bow at the end. Four stars.

based on true events: I hesitated between 3 and 4 stars for this one -- 4 stars because it was a good story, 3 because the inconsistencies drove me crazy.

Possible spoilers:

This book needs another pass with an editor. For example, on page 142, she states that Moshe, Leon et al are living in the largest zemlianka, but on the previous page, it says that the larder is in the largest zemlianka. On page 129, where they are building the underground shelters, the smallest is for food storage.

Jerusza would steal books to use in Yona's education, yet they traveled light, with only what they could carry. What happened to those books? To Jerusza's menorah?

Perhaps the worst was the passage of time and marking it. Living outside of society, there would be no calendars. A passing of one day to the next, yes. And the change of seasons. But to know that today would have been someone's birthday? No. I suppose Hanukkah is celebrated based on a phase of the moon, but so are the holidays of the new year and atonement, which are not mentioned.

At the top of page 37, the paragraph reads: "For two months, Yona wandered the forest alone, setting up camp in a different spot for a few months, just as Jerusza had taught her ..." Months? Weeks?

The story itself was heartbreaking, especially given that it was based on true events. There were also some beautiful philosophical quotes, including one from the Talmud, that I would have highlighted had I been reading on my kindle.

My first by this author: "Summer Rental" started a little cliche, almost boring, until Maryn's character appeared. I wanted more of that story line. Ellis and Ty were the centerpiece, but I thought the other three women were more interesting.

Still, it held my attention and I wanted to know where each of the women's stories were going.

wasted time: Review for audio CD of Fly Away

In addition to being depressing, this was awful! I enjoyed the tv series / movie for the first book, so understood the background, but Fly Away was hours and hours of rehashing the same events over and over from different characters' points of view. And the ending -- so very sappy.

I wasn't impressed with the narrator, either. All characters spoke in the same voice, so when I picked the story back up (next time I got in the car), I really have to think about who was talking. This was especially challenging when Kate and Tully were talking, or when the author was revisiting an event from a different perspective.

Bosch and Rider, together again: Connelly has gone back to writing in the third person. And he's taken Bosch back to LAPD. I liked the first person POV in book #9, Lost Light, better. With the third person, the author has to step back on occasion and explain why a character did what they did.

The Closers is a quick read, all the clues -- and a few red herrings -- are there. I did catch "the thing in the bedroom" right away though.

I don't understand the hype: Capital Crimes Book #3 has absolutely nothing to do with the first two in the series, other than geography.

This was drawn out, filled with run-on sentences and preaching. I forced myself to keep going until I reached the 70% mark, where it suddenly got very interesting and started to tie together. So many tangents.

NOT Mickey Haller: Reading the book's synopsis, I thought it would be a rip-off of "The Lincoln Lawyer". Oh, no.

The first half reads like a series of short stories, or perhaps tv episodes like "Law and Order" -- different trials with a common cast of core characters. But midway, it starts to pull together in to a related climax.

Only two stars because the subject/trial matter was too dark and violent for my tastes.

(parenthetically speaking): I almost quit reading prior to the 100-page mark (I give any book that long to grab my attention or I move on). So many run-on sentences and parentheses! Very difficult to get in to the story. But then I became accustomed to the writing style.

Next, I wondered if we were ever going to be enlightened about Evan's actual plot. By the 50% mark, I was deeply in to the story and enjoying it. I did guess the ending (the villain) ahead of time, which was a bummer.

five stars: Starts with a bang and the action never stops. Plausible plot, likeable characters (even the one bad guy), no noticeable grammar or punctuation errors. Winner all around, one of my rare five stars!

Not as described: When I read the synopsis, I envisioned four stuffy old men in a room with wood paneled walls and overstuffed chairs debating esoteric problems.

That's not the Camel Club at all -- in fact those four gents are MINOR characters in this story. The real hero/lead is Secret Service agent Alex Ford. (With a little help from his friends.) In fact, other than witnessing the murder early on, the Camel Club disappears from the story line until about page 250.

I spent a good portion of the book trying to decide if Tom Hemingway and Carter Gray were good guys or bad guys...

The terrorist activities were so well orchestrated as to be implausible, but once the action starts in Pennsylvania, I see a bit of the old Baldacci -- the one who wrote "Total Control" and "Absolute Power". That part of the story was an edge-of-your-seat ride. And <sigh> then we slip back into the impractical again with the action on Murder Mountain and the White House.

Who do you love?: Review for Audible version
I liked the two alternating female voices reading the story.

Who do you love? That question gets asked a lot in this story. And an underlining theme that applies to both women is "how far will a mother go for her child?"

I wish that the title line did not tell us that this was the first in a new series with Tessa at the center -- kind of eliminated a lot of possible endings for me as I listened along and tried to guess where the story was going next.

Before It's Too Late: Loved the Civil War history/trivia woven into the story as place settings. Had to suspend belief that there were "enough" Black-Irish-looking women in the DC metro area with ties to those Civil War landmarks to keep the action/pattern flowing.

This is the second book in a series, and while it stands alone, it is probably best to read the first on (STORM RISING) to get the background.

I'm giving this one a rare 5-star rating. I'd love to see it made in to a movie.

far-fetched: Very slow, almost boring until about page 150. Once Harry lands in Hong Kong, things get interesting, albeit far-fetched. Enjoyed the surprise "visit" from Mickey Haller near the end, and great final two twists.

From hurricane to whirlwind: I really, really like this series, but they do have to be read in order to understand who all the players are and the settings.

STORM RISING starts with a hurricane (best part), works it's way through storm-damaged and flooded Norfolk and ends up in a courtroom. My 20+ years in animal rescue make me really agree with the authors' philosophy that our animal friends give back so much more than they take.

great series beginning: THIS is an author I want to read more of! Her love of books and reading shines through on every page.

The murder-mystery is well-thought out and plausible, although I do wonder about the lack of -- or lack of interest from -- out-of-town relatives. (difficult to phrase without giving any spoilers). I'll definitely be looking for other books in this series.

Read the series in order: Sixth in the series, and IMO not as good as its predecessors. The first half of the book moved very slowly, even for a reader who has devoured the first five and loves the back story. We didn't even have McCord's history lessons! (The explanation of "blood diamonds" was dry and convoluted.)

At about the 50% mark, the story took off and became un-put-down-able. This series is best read as an e-book, with ready access to an online dictionary/encyclopedia for terminology and architectural descriptions.

I received a complimentary copy from the publisher, Kensington Publishing, and this is my unbiased opinion of what I have just finished reading.

Again, not up to the hype -- just like the first three in the series.: Where did the author get those names for her characters? And was the editor asleep? Rife with the wrong word (foot rather than food ... and like mistakes) -- errors spell check won't catch. Very easy to predict who the "bad guys" were and what the scheme was.

A 1920s gumshoe whodunnit: I enjoyed this quick-moving mystery, but had a few issues with the writing (hence only three stars). The beginning of the story was overloaded with trite phrases: mountains , molehills, and crossed t's (you get my point). There were a few typos, the kind spell check won't catch, where wrong word was used or a word was missing. Lots of several sentence fragments and the misuse of commas -- sometimes a colon is appropriate -- made me crazy.

I liked main characters Jax, Laura and Tim. I think Ace could have done more than bark to communicate -- a sniff or whine maybe? I mentally cheered when he got to help with the rescue near the end. I did not guess the villain. I look forward to the second book in the series.

I received an advance review copy for free, (thanks #BookSirens) and I am leaving this review voluntarily.

more romance than dog training: This is a sad story about how seeing-eye (guide) dogs for the blind got their start.

Three main characters: Anna, Max and Bruno form a love triangle. I had trouble finding any sympathy for Bruno, even though the author tried to emphasize his regrets. The ending was a tear-jerker.

Another reviewer commented that this was more a love story than a story about how the dogs were trained, and I agree. I would have liked more insight into the training process and less discussion of clocks and turnips (rutabagas).

Sequel to MONDAY MOURNING: It's been a few years since I read MONDAY MOURNING, and BONES NEVER LIE is a sequel. I remembered bits and pieces of the first book, and was fine with the way this one flowed: enough "reminders" to not interfere with the story line yet refresh my memory.

In most of her Temperance Brennan books, the author has taken it upon herself to educate the reader on an obscure branch of medicine or science. This time, it was CAIS, a genetic abnormality, but she didn't go overboard with the explanation like she has in prior novels.

I was glad to see Ryan back in the story.

Disappointing: I really like Linwood Barclay. He is one of my favorite authors. This book was not one of his better books. I had it figured out from the second chapter and the way it kept going back and forth was a little annoying. All in all it was a disappointment.

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️Another absolutely amazing thriller!: ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️This is the fifth book I’ve read by this author. She is so good. If you like a fast paced page turner with great character development and touching relationships, I highly recommend “Her Perfect Family”. I can not say enough good things about this book. I could not put it down. I also highly recommend her previous four thrillers. All available on Amazon. My only complaint is that I can’t get her novels when  they are first released because they are published in the UK first. Also can’t get them in hard back.

Finally a decor book that doesn’t shame: I appreciate a design book that doesn't make you feel bad for not having a magazine worthy home. At a recent hospitality event, the speaker reminded us that its not about having the perfect home but how you make your guests feel in it. When I read the same sentiment shared by the author in the introduction, I knew this was gonna be a great read. The author gives a few suggestions on different ways to use her book: as Instruction, Inspiration, Motivation and/or Encouragement. It's easy-to-read with easy-to-implement tips, tutorials and ideas.  Depending on what you are looking for, there's something for everyone in these pages. I will be rereading this one often.

pretty lame: I am a dad joke aficionado, but these jokes are not even funny to me. Many are too hard for an 8 year old to understand, with outdated references (winding a clock) and puns that would go over their heads. I'm likely returning.
Reader: Entertaining
Great book: Great cook book
Very hard to put down.: This book is full twist and turns, it keeps you guessing and has plenty of action . I can't wait to start the next one in the series and I hope that he writes a lot more.

Great Birding Book!: I personally own an earlier edition of this book but bought this for a friend after visiting with her and she was telling me about all her birds at the feeders but knowing all their names. She didn't have a bird book (YET!), so I surprised her by ordering this for her after our visit. It's fun to learn the birds around your home, and for some they love it so much they become birdwatchers. This is a great book to identify and learn about different types.
Easy realistic recipes: Can’t wait to try the beef stroganoff!
Best book: This is is the best book to ever.  Just got into it so and want to read all the time now

Amazingly good.: I wanted a field guide to insects in order to be able to tie a wider variety of realistic-looking fishing flies. Of course National Geographic provides first-rate color pictures in this one, but also includes sizes of each species when they are mature. Nice to know how big to tie the flies!

Articles are also included for spiders and other such creatures.

Dark but educational if your into criminology/human behavior: I have a huge interest in criminology and psychology. As  criminal justice major and even after seeking a degree in Psychology the focus on serial killers is very little. It's funny how many want to be criminal profilers are out there who seem to think they can look at a person and know all about them. "To many criminal mind episodes" This book is based on facts and is a great book on anyone who really wants to understand the subject matter.

A much for anyone who carries a firearm.: Good info on what to expect in a possible attack by an offender. knowing how to use a firearm will keep you alive. Knowing when to use will keep you out of prison.

It was like taking a class in criminology!: It was educational. For those who are interested in criminal behavior this is a must read. I work security and our job is prevention and knowing how predators think and their MO is helpful in prevention.

Great historical novel.: I have read Mr. King's History works.  I was greatly surprised that in addition to presenting a very good story line, the book contained a great amount of history.  I am not sure why but I had the feeling that this history was not to impress but to provide information he thought necessary.  Unfortunately this wealth of information did slow the plot to a certain degree.

Great book for young readers!: I really enjoyed this and so did my niece and nephew. Great characters, lots of humor and situations that we can all relate to. Addresses issues but not in a depressing way, still very entertaining.  I look forward to more from this author. Check it out, you'll be glad you did.

Loved it: Oh how I love Angie Fox and her Sugarland crew. I love how the series has progressed and definitely recommend reading it in order, but I really don't think you would be overly lost if you picked it up midway, but you would then want to go read it from the beginning anyway...so to each their own. I am pumped that Frankie found out the way to break his link...I'm not sure that he's capable of doing what he needs to, or really truly wants to at this point, but at least we're not still hanging. And I must say that this is definitely my favorite book since karma is a B! Loved it can't wait for more!

"Lost" Short Stories should have stayed lost: If you are a fan of Daphne duMaurier, and I am, you will be disappointed in these stories unless you are a literary detective who likes to trace the evolution of a talent from un-formed to fully formed.  One story, "Limpet" is a character study, told in the first person.  It feels like a writing exercise [Write a character who unknowingly reveals her deeply flawed nature  in telling her story], but it is well done, though too long. One story, "The Happy Valley", has a hint of the unexpected and weird that I associate with duMaurier.  The rest are sour little stories about love affairs gone sour. I recomend you re-read "The Scapegoat" instead.

Virgil's homage to Homer, with a more mature hero, but still those interfering Olympians: Virgil’s Aeneid is in many ways a literary homage to Homer. There is the hero who encounters many obstacles, some monstrous, some tempting, in his voyage to his home base. There are the women who love him and lose him and find him. There is the carnage of battle, over and over, precipitated by conflicting claims on a woman. There is the antagonist who is loved by the gods and spirited out of danger over and over. There is even a visit to the underworld.
At first, I was feeling a bit of déjà vu. Aeneas seems like a dry stick compared to the volcanic Achilles and Agamemnon, or to Hector, the doomed family man. And those gods who keep interfering, particularly Juno! I grew impatient with the apparent lack of agency of the main characters, as the gods moved them about.
But toward the end the story grew on me. I was aided by reading Ursula K. LeGuin’s “Lavinia” in parallel with the last six books. LeGuin humanizes Aeneas by seeing him through the fictional eyes of his proposed bride, Lavinia, who in Virgil’s book never says a word. And I confess I did speed-read through the carnage of who killed whom and how exactly they were pieced, cloven in two, and whether it was brains or guts that splled. The last book is memorable for its alternations between the points of view of Aeneas and his antagonist Turnus, as the fortunes of war favor one or the other. It’s a fine conclusion, though many have said that Virgil left the poem unfinished.
And Fagles’ translation is admirable.

A young woman fights intolerance and poverty with books from the back of a mule: A lot of research went into Kim Richardson’s story of a woman who delivers donated books to backwoods residents of Appalachan Kentucky by muleback in the late 1930’s (an actual program sponsored by the Works Progress Administration).. Not only do we get a tremendous kaleidoscope of backcountry superstitions, customs, dialects, and problem, but we see them through the eyes of a Blue woman, “colored” according to the dictates of the backwoods, though her blueness is the result of a real genetic defect which can be cured with medicine (an actual historic condition), rather than a genetic attribute which is permanent. Despite the twin obstacles of poverty and prejudice, she perseveres.

Sometimes Richardson's research gets a bit in the way of the story, but it’s hard to resist a book about books, and even harder when the protagonist is an unjustly persecuted person is fighting for a normal life. Richardson makes Cussy Mary Carter, or “Bluet” more than just a megaphone for tolerance. She is someone I would have liked to know.

Hard truths lovingly portrayed: I reread “Olive Kitteredge” after seeing the excellent on-line version with Frances McDermand and Bill Murray. This series of short stories, in which the inimitable Olive is sometimes the main protagonist, sometimes only a minor character, is a bittersweet musing on love, aging, dementia, and death. It is perhaps too elegiac, too shadowy, for a young audience, but the harsh truths Elizabeth Strout examines are real and must be faced by the middle-aged and elderly.

Strout's conclusion is reminiscent of Thornton Wilder’s great play, “Our Town”, in its acceptance of death and rueful realization that we squander the precious moments of life that are granted to us. I liked this collection of stories when I read it ten years ago, applying its lessons to my aging parents. Now that they apply to me and my peers, I like it even more. “Olive Kitteridge” is a minor masterpiece.

Memoir of a rescued pilot who becomes a media "hero": This memoir of an Air Force pilot shot down in hostile territory is aimed at a YA market, but has enough technical detail and interior reflection to appeal also to adults. Michael French, the co-author with Scott O’Grady, the rescued pilot, has done a fine job of taking the pilot’s experience and shaping it into a story. Includes photos of the pilot’s childhood (not so interesting) and of the plane he flew (interesting) and the crew that plucked him out of hostile territory in Bosnia ( very interesting).

The last ten pages or so cover the publicity explosion that Scott O’Grady faced after his rescue. The first phone call he received after his rescue was from then-President Bill Clinton, eager for positive news he could be part of. This says more about our peculiar media-driven society than perhaps O’Grady intended.

An ingeniously conceived story tangles with a deep moral question: We are All Completely Beside Ourselves
This book is to Animal Research what “Overstory” is to Clearcutting Forests, but with a smaller cast and thus less of an epic feel. Rosemary and Fern are “sisters”, raised together from infancy. Rosemary is a human child; Fern is an infant chimpanzee. It’s a research project, but the impact when the project is forced to end is catastrophic for both infants and for the family they belong to. We have echoes of “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks”, “The Nickel Boys”, and even “Sophie’s Choice.”
Fowler does an excellent job of recreating how Rosemary might have felt about her “sister”’s unexplained disappearance at age five, and how the loss of this chimp child reverberated through the family. It’s a fascinating read; I am wondering how Fowler ever conceived of the notion.

Great characters and setting, flawed denoument: I hate it when, toward the end of the mystery which has me complely baffled, the detective says to his sidekick “I know, of course, who the murderer is, as you probably do also, but we lack the hard evidence to prove it.” It makes me feel quite unnecessarily stupid.
I also hate it when in making a confession the murderer reveals a completely new motive to which we had only the shadowiest of allusions earlier. (OK, on rereading this was probably a fiction to hide the true motive. Oh well, I still think it was unnecessary.)
I also hate it when a giant red herring is dragged across the path and never explained later. (Where does Dr. DuPayne go in his Jaguar on his long weekend outings?)
I like Adam Dalgliesh. I like his sidekick Kate Miskin. I like the character development of these two in this twelfth in the series of Adam Dalgliesh mysteries by master mystery writer P.D. James. I hated the above. If this sort of thing doesn’t bug you, and you have already read 1-11 of this series, forge ahead. There are fourteen in all.

Disappointing formulaic effort by a writer who has done much better: The Ruby in the Smoke
This is a formulaic Victorian cloak-and-dagger (literally!) thriller, with a lovely and resourceful teen-age heroine, a couple of truly malevolent villains, some comic relief characters who come through in a pinch, all circling around the search for a giant ruby with a cursed past (really!)
I was disappointed – Philip Pullman’s “Golden Compass” series was full of surprises in the way he developed his alternate universe and the complexity of his characters. Each chapter had its own twist, and each volume presented the alternate universe as if through a different lens. This little book feels like it was written to order. I’m not tempted to look for the next books in the series – and I wanted to be tempted.

A well-written memoir of murder and memory: The protagonists are Black, but the story of an abusive relationship could be true for any ethnicity. I found myself relating more to the problem of remembering, and how memories slip away, flitter back tantalizingly, and then escape again. Anyone who has lost someone dear, I think, will experience this frustration. In Natasha’s case, she purposefully blocked the memories of her mother’s death and what led up to it in order to minimize her own trauma, but in doing so she also blocked memories of her mother’s life. Only later, when it is too late, can she see past the horror of the murder and regret having given away the artifacts which held memories of her mother dancing, happy, hopeful, as she was before her death.
I have similar problems with memories of my mother and father. For both I was either a primary or a secondary caregiver, so my most vivid recent memories are of my father weak, emaciated, and furious about his body having let him down; and my mother weak, incontinent, plagued by visions and slightly demented. It has taken me a long time to re-awaken my memories of them as parents, neighbors, activists, friends. Sometimes I will be caught unaware by some trinket or turn of phrase which brings a memory back to life, and I try to hold onto it, nail it into some organized sequence in my life story, but it’s like a scrapbook with half the pages missing. So many questions I never asked, and now will never know the answers to!
As Natasha will never know exactly why her mother remarried. Her discovery of her blood relationship with Joey was a shock which she will never be able to explain.

A Philosophically Rich Imagining of the Mind of a “Good Emperor”: Marguerite Yourcenar’s recreation of the musings of the Roman emperor Hadrian is masterful. It took her over 25 years to achieve the understanding and maturity to begin to enter the mind of one who was in his time literally a Master of the Universe, and also a vulnerable human being. The book is full of epigrams of the sort that people put at the end of their emails, many of which seem eerily applicable to today’s world (e.g. “…in any combat between fanaticism and common sense, the latter has rarely the upper hand.” ) I wished I owned the book rather than having borrowed it from the library, because the urge to underline, highlight, and fold page corners over was so hard to resist.
It’s dense. Not a book to try to skim through in time to meet a deadline, but one to savor at one’s bedside for some time.

Not the best in the series, just the next after "Tripwire": This #4 in the Jack Reacher series of thrillers starts off with a great action sequence, with Reacher administering rough justice to a couple of protection racketeers. But then things slow down. There is a sub-plot involving Reacher’s girlfriend Jodie (from “Tripwire”) and a second sub-plot involving skullduggery and sexual harassment at the FBI. And there is the required bright and beautiful woman sidekick, in this case the lovely FBI agent Harper who is assigned to partner Jack as they try to identify a serial killer.
But there is too much detail of getting into and out of cars and helicopters and airplanes as Reacher and Harper criss-cross the country, and too much italicized musing in the mind of the villain, and it just takes too long to get past all the red herrings and wind up the plot. There is a second interlude where Reacher deals with the protection racketeers again, and this little side trip is the most satisfying section of the book. Skim through this one and proceed to #5.

An amusing and interesting premise carried on a tad too long: This memoir/scientific popularization starts with a fun story that has made the rounds, about the container full of bath toys that fell off a container vessel, and the resulting diaspora of rubber ducks around the Pacific gyre, along Pacific beaches, and maybe even through the Northwest Passage.
OK, now you ‘ve got the core. Donovan Hohn manages to expand this story for 378 pages, following the trail of the ducks by visiting a factory in China, taking passage on a container ship, doing beach cleanup along the Aleutian Islands, and attempting the Northwest Passage on an icebreaker. Meanwhile he muses on climate change, ocean currents, and the responsibilities of fatherhood, with a number of literary sidelights.
He goes on too long. Even for a bedside book, Moby Duck is more than gently soporific. It got tedious. I did read to the end, hoping against hope that he might find just one more bath toy.

Memoir sheds a dark light on the source of Conroy's writing: This memoir is meaningful for fans of Pat Conroy’s The Great Santini, The Water is Wide, and The Prince of Tides. It illuminates just how much Conroy depended on his own life to drive the characters and plots of his novels. Not an edifying example of family life. The Conroys put the “dys” in “dysfunctional family” with mental illness, suicide, repeated breakdowns, promiscuity, physical and mental abuse, sibling rivalry, and alcoholism all featuring prominently in Conroy’s tale of his family life.
Conroy doesn’t come off too well in the telling either. He verbally abuses his siblings and betrays his mother despite his “adoration” of her.
It’s all really grim. About two-thirds of the way through I was ready to quit, but I stuck with it to find out if there would be any sunshine at the end. Conroy does find a degree of reconciliation with his once-hated father, but at the funeral of the Great Santini there is still plenty of familial hostility to go around for a couple more novels.

Three Characters in Search of a Life: This novella likely wouldn’t have been published were it not written by comedian Steve Martin. But don’t look here for belly laughs, or insight into what makes Martin tick. “Shopgirl” is a serious effort to enter into the thoughts and feelings of someone who is nothing like Steve Martin – Maribelle. Maribelle is a salesgirl at the glove counter at Nieman Marcus in Los Angeles, an occupation which may be one of the most soul-deadening in the world, after being a toll-collector on the night shift on the Tappan Zee Bridge.
Maribelle’s life might be characterized as “for lack of anything better.” She has talent as an artist, but no self-confidence and less ambition. Yet somehow she attracts two admirers: Jeremy, who is if anything even more aimless than Maribelle, and Ray Porter, who happens to be a millionaire. What will happen when this empty slate gets written on? It’s a simple story, almost like a fable, about seemingly shallow people, but Martin gives it surprising depth.

A wonderful, bittersweet evocation of love and death in a remote but universal setting: A wonderful but bittersweet collection of stories linked by location and chronology. Harriet Doerr drew on her own experiences of life in a remote Mexican village.
Sara, the protagonist from whose point of view we hear of and experience the life of the village, lets us know early on that her husband is under sentence of death through leukemia, so that fateful foreboding hovers over all the stories.

Thought the village is remote, it is a microcosm of humanity, with its strengths – community feeling, faith, hope ; weaknesses – anger, alcoholism, promiscuity; and overall its helplessness against fate.
Harriet was admitted to the Stanford Creative Writing program as a Stegner Fellow after publishing several chapters of this novel as independent stories in various literary journals. She published this, her first novel, at age 75 – an inspiration to all of us who struggle to believe we can still do something exciting after retirement!

Long, convoluted, murky story with bizarre characters - so what's not to like?: If you like a hefty book (750+ closely printed pages) with Dickensian characters (e.g. Oliver Twist+ David Copperfield+ Pip= Theo Decker, the protagonist), richly evocative settings (New York City, exurban Las Vegas, Amsterdam) and whip-lash-inducing plot twists, you’ll settle right into “The Goldfinch”, as I did.

Supporting cast members also evoke Dickens – modern-day refurbs of the Artful Dodger, Mr. Micawber, Estella, the Doll’s Dressmaker, Joe the Blacksmith and others appear with comforting regularity. Surely all this Dickensian homage will result in a happy ending? Well… even Dickens didn’t always manage that. Just sayin’.

But if you are looking for a fast-read, gobble-and-go kind of thriller, or a comforting romance with a HEA ending, or a deep exploration of some exotic ethnic corner, this is not it. This is about some human beings, some of whom you might have encountered, some more likely not. if you like this sort of thing.

What if you just walked away and started over? Delia's gone...: Anne Tyler is the 20th century equivalent of Jane Austen - she absolutely nails a certain kind of middle-class morass that we are so often in danger of being sucked into. Her characters are real people, with real failings and blind spots, always trying to do the right thing despite cross-currents and unforeseen pitfalls. I don't love all her books, but then I don't love all of Jane Austen's work either. I stayed up until 1am reading "just one more chapter", and then left the last five pages unread because I couldn't quite bear to finish it until this morning.

Delia Grinstead is on a family vacation at the beach. Clad in a swimsuit and beach sandals, and carrying a tote with all the vacation money tucked inside, she walks away from her family after a tiff with her husband – and into a new life. This is a fantasy we’ve all had – what if we just walked away and started over from scratch? Not so easy, but irresistible to watch Anne Tyler try to work out the details.

An early feminist nails the consequences of patriarchy: [note: I read "The Yellow Wallpaper' as the lead story in a small collection of Gilman's writing. produced as a "Dover Thrift Edition". Other reviews seem to have read it as a stand-alone.]

The titular story of this small collection is truly marvelous and thoroughly scary. "The Yellow Wallpaper" was written by Charlotte Perkins Gilman in 1892, and tells of a young wife whose “nervous trouble” is not taken seriously by her physician husband or brother, but who gradually descends into madness prompted as much, the reader thinks, from their benign neglect and boredom than any other cause. Not to be missed, and not to be read in a room with patterned wallpaper!

The other stories were written between 1910 and 1914, and all reflect the attitudes of the time toward women, some more enlightened than others, but all skewered (no, Microsoft, I don't mean "skewed") by the feminist perspective of the author. Some of the writing is cringe-worthy, but the overall thrust is very modern. At 70 pp, definitely worth your time.

A classic tale of a plucky orphan, a bit dated by the sentimentality of 1908: This classic story was first published in 1908, and it is beginning to show its age.  Anne is still charming, and her struggles with her temper, her rivalry with Gilbert Blythe, and her love for her guardians, shy Matthew and crusty Marilla Cuthbert,are all still enthralling.  Modern readers may struggle with the long peaens to the beauty of Prince Edward Island which periodically interrupt the story.  If you have no taste for flowery description, perhaps you would do as well to watch the wonderful adaptation starring Richard Farnsworth and Colleen Dewhurst, available on DVD at your local library.  This adaptation is faithful to the story, including almost all of Anne’s adventures.  It cuts the sentimentality without losing the humor in Anne’s rhapsodies, and there could be no better Cuthberts than Farnsworth and Dewhurst.

An ordinary man rises to an extraordinary challenge - a book for hard times: In a time when the headlines are bleak, I turn to my “comfort books.” These are stories where ordinary people face difficult situation, rise to the challenge,and emerge triumphant. Almost a dozen of the comfort books on my shelf were written by Nevil Shute, and “Pied Piper” is one of the best.

The situation: An elderly (70, but in the 1940’s 70 was more elderly than we would admit now) Englishman goes for a fishing vacation in the French Jura in 1940, is charged with taking two English children back to England while their parents are in Switzerland, gets caught up in the beginning of the war, and as he moves toward a hope of escape to England finds himself accumulating more and more refugee children. Will he make it to England with all children safe?

You already know the ending. No matter. It’s a tremendously satisfying read.

An ambitious attempt to recreate the mind of ancient Greece: I enjoyed Madelyn Miller’s retelling of Greek tales, and the blurbs on her books kept saying she was the “best since Mary Renault”, whom I had never read. So when a copy of “The Bull from the Sea” appeared on the 25-cent book cart at the library, I snapped it up.
Comparisons are difficult. Miller’s retellings are decidedly 21st century and influenced by modern viewpoints on feminine empowerment and gender fluidity. Renault, writing in the 1960’s, was just beginning to feel these vibrations in society. Miller writes in “Song of Achilles” from the point of view of Achilles’ male lover; Renault barely breathes a hint of this at the end of “Bull”. Miller’s “Circe” is told from the point of view of the enchantress who turns men into pigs if they behave like pigs; her Circe has a complete backstory and is very humanly flawed. Renault’s Amazon princess Hippolyta is by comparison a cardboard Barbie doll.

Renault, however, works hard to show us a mythical Greek society through the viewpoint of a man, Theseus, who truly believes in the Olympian gods, and that his life is due to them, both in the sense of causation and of obligation. She almost succeeds in recreating the mindset of an Attic adventurer-king, nearly brings the ancient Greeks to modern life. Maybe if her women characters, Hippolyta and Medea especially, were more rounded, her success would have been complete.

A detached protagonist failed to engage this reader: This is a novel? It reads like a journal of day-to-day thoughts. There is no story arc. The narrator is a woman who has never married, who lives alone, who has had some love affairs but is now unattached. She has a slight crush on the husband of a friend and has several friendly encounters with him in public places, but when she is asked to house sit briefly when her friend’s daughter has an emergency, she realizes that there is no future for this mostly imaginary romance. She thinks about how she reflects both her father’s and her mother’s oddities. And that’s about it. Unattached is the word.

The jacket blurb say “…one day at the sea, both overwhelmed and replenished by the sun’s vital heat, her perspective will abruptly change.” I looked and looked for this, almost re read the entire book, but in the chapters where she is at the beach she seems as detached as ever.
If that’s the point, to see if the reader can become attached to a protagonist who has no story… well, Jhumpa Lahira has written other stories which have plot threadss, and have been very well received, so she can get away with this empty spool.

A wonderfully written evocation of small-town life, death, love, and sacrifice: Kent Haruf knows how to tell a story. I read this (his first novel) just after having plodded through 150 pages of a post-modern novella where almost nothing happened and I felt as detached from the protagonist as she seemed to be from the world around her. Such a contrast. Kent Haruf draws the reader in with the first paragraph and never lets go, as he builds a world that is real and close and characters who you feel you’ve known all their lives.
Haruf’s world is a rural town in Colorado; all six of his novels are set there. The characters in his novels are people you might expect to meet in such a town but he manages to bring out the unexpected in each of them. Not only are the characters real, but so is the setting. You can feel the heat, taste the grit in your mouth after a sandstorm, smell the earthy reek of a pigsty or a chicken coop or a dying dog.
Why waste your time reading “post-modern fiction” when you have Haruf’s real world to explore?
OK, you want to know what’s it about? A beautiful girl sacrifices love and adventure to fulfill the duty she feels she owes to her abusive, half-mad father and then to her self-absorbed, half-mad brother. Sound like a downer? It isn’t. It’s about strength and self-discipline and faithfulness to the familial tie that binds. If you don’t love and admire Edith Goodnough after reading this absorbing novel, then you deserve post-modern fiction.

A "classic" with some character flaws.: A children’s classic which I somehow missed. Reading it for the first time as an adult, I’m not as charmed as I might have been by the story of a rough-diamond hero who meets a fairy princess who transforms his life.

A boy from a hardscrabble farming family makes friends with the daughter of a white-collar couple who have come to the country to live the liberal fantasy of getting back to the basics. The girl is a tomboy with an androgynous name (Leslie), the boy has a talent for drawing which he mostly hides He gives her friendship in an alien environment, she gives him books and confidence.

Katherine Paterson has won two National Book Awards and two Newbery Awards, and her writing is polished and vivid. I just couldn’t quite believe in the alliance between these two very different children, from radically different upbringings. A bit too much of the fairy tale, maybe.

Miss Marple at her shrewdest: Agatha Christie is the master of mystery. Even seventy years after publication, They Do It with Mirrors feels fresh and clean. No need for the obscene language, gouts of blood, or scenes of butchery and brutality which too often are used in modern mystery writing to distract the reader from poor characterization or flimsy plots. Christie simply presents us with a puzzle. Can you work it out?
Miss Marple is my favorite Christie sleuth. In this episode of her life in crime, an old school friend alerts her to “something wrong” with a mutual friend, and Jane Marple goes to check it out. As usual with Christie, there are a number of characters, fleshed out just enough to make them human without letting their individual stories get in the way of the plot. I was briefly confused by the number and variety of relationships between the characters, but Christie reminds the reader just often enough to be a guide without seeming repetitive.

I don’t know how I missed this Marple before. I’m delighted to have been able to spend another cozy evening with Jane at her shrewdest. Four stars instead of five because I guessed the villain well before the end.

A true picture book!: I picked this off the shelf of the Children’s section of the library out of curiosity as to what a book the size of "War and Peace" was doing there. I was startled to see the gold seal of the Caldecott Medal on the front cover – the Caldecott Medal is for picture books! So I opened it up.

This IS a picture book, in the most literal sense. (Check out the “Look Inside” on Amazon to get what I mean.) At least half of the 526 pages are beautiful black and white illustration. It’s not quite a graphic novel, since the text is written paragraphs, not balloons.

Oh, what’s it about? An orphaned boy secretly lives within the walls of a Parisian railway station, taking over his vanished uncle’s job as timekeeper and making sure all the many clocks both large and small are keeping the correct time and ticking in unison. At the same time, he is trying to restore an automaton which his dead father had created, and defeat the curiosity and suspicions of a young girl whose uncle runs a toy shop in the station.

This book was the inspiration for the 2011 movie “Hugo”, If you’ve seen the movie, you should read the book. If you haven’t, read the book, then see the movie too!

Death makes a distancing narrator for a story of WWII Germany: A clever premise – a story of Germany in World War II, narrated by Death.
But Death is not a person. Death is a concept. No matter how adroitly Markus Zusak anthropomorphizes Death, it is still a concept of emptiness, of detachment, of separation, that intrudes upon the rather cozy caring personality that Zusak tries to create. The reader is distanced from the protagonist Liesel, an orphan taken into a foster home in the outskirts of Munich, and from her kind step-father, and her rough-spoken but golden-hearted step-mother, and from the Jew they hide in their basement.

It’s a bit like watching a very well directed and well-shot movie, but with the sound off.

So I can understand why this book won awards. But I couldn’t love it. I put it down many times, and picked it up again because my son said he “devoured” it. It’s finally off my ToBeRead shelf.

Note: I was surprised to see that this book was "#1 in Amazon's Children's Literature about the Holocaust" - is this just because it has a child protagonist? And the dirty words are in German? Perhaps the distancing makes it more palatable for an adult to give to "children" of, I hope, at least twelve. At 550 pages, it's a pretty big lump for a child to chew on.

Not much to attract a new reader in #43 of the series: There are plenty of folks who love Rex Stout’s Nero Wolfe and his sidekick Archie Goodwin, but somehow I never had gotten around to reading any of his adventures. When a copy showed up in the local Little Free Library I decided it was time.
I suppose I shouldn’t have started with #43 in the series. Aficionados probably greet hard-nosed Archie, Fritz the cook, Cramer the hostile cop, and Saul the spy like old friends. They probably grin at the menus that Fritz conjures up for Archie at short notice and run to the web to look up every variety of exotic orchid that Wolfe is cultivating in his rooftop garden. But I felt like a last-minute guest at a party where everyone else seems to know each other.
And the plot is weak. The detective work requires no great insight, the eventual villain is a poor soul, the motivation for the murder is crudely engineered and seems to contradict what we have been told about the character of the victim.
So, sorry, Wolfanatics. I can walk away from the other 46 Nero Wolfe books without a backward glance.

A better-than-average Austen pastiche: A better-than-average Austen pastiche, owing perhaps more to Georgette Heyer than to the original Jane.  The five daughters are as varied a lot as were the Bennet sisters, and their adventures in a London season under the loose chaperonage of their aunts Fitzwilliam and Gardiner involve quite a few brushes with scandal and betrayal.  It’s hard to imagine that Darcy and Elizabeth’s children would have grown into such a motley assortment of feminine fooleries and frailties, but the plot does move right along.

A fast read, is the best I can say: I could not like this book. It starts with a wife being snarky about her husband, moves to two teenage girls being snarky about almost everything, especially their parents. Then one of the girls, the pretty one, gets in the kind of trouble you might expect. Her BFF, the late-to-develop one (and narrator), gets in trouble trying to help her out. The pretty girl is stuck in the small town. The BFF goes to college, develops breasts, and becomes even snarkier. They grow out of touch.
So? I can think of a half-dozen novellas of less than 150 pages that were more worth my time than this skimpy effort. Looking at other reviews, I realize that if I had skipped the intro and the last chapter I might have liked it better. Being pre-conditioned by the first 5 pages to dislike the narrator did not enhance the rest of the book.

Twins separated at birth are reunited - how can you resist?: I couldn’t resist a story about twins separated at birth who are reunited by a lucky coincidence and end up happily with two loving families.
OK, now I’ve told you the entire story of “Separated @ Birth” You loved it in “The Parent Trap”, both the book (Under the original title “Lisa & Lottie”) and movies (starring Hayley Mills in version 1, Lindsay Lohan in Version 2). The difference here is that 1) it’s a true story and 2) the sisters were reunited via a friend of Anais spotting Samanth in a YouTube video and relaying the link to Anaisr.
Now I’ve really told you all you need to know aobut this book. Reading it was like picking up a teen-ager’s diary (wel, two teenagers). No deep thoughts about Fate or The Impact of Technology or Nature vs Nurture, just the normal angst about Meeting your Identical Twin for the First Time: nervousness, anxiety, astonishment, tentativeness, joy- it’s all here.
And some pictures.
If, like me, you’re a sucker for this kind of Amazing But True Story ,you can breeze through "Se;parated @ Birth" in a day. But actually, I’d recommend “Lisa & Lottie” more highly – more plot.

Go for Robert van Gulik's Judge Dee series instead: This is a modern extension of the Robert van Gulik series about Judge Dee, who was an actual historical figure in the Tang dynasty of China. Qiu Xiao Long writes a series about Inspector Chen, a detective in modern-day Shanghai; this volume purports to be written by Chen in his off hours. Chen is a poet by avocation, and there are quite a number of poems translated from Chinese classics in the volume.

An interesting proposition, but I enjoyed van Gulik’ series far more. I found the poetry distracting and unsatisfying, although Qiu does his best to use the contents of the poems as clues to the mystery. (Note: I have done some translations from Chinese classic poetry myself, so I am a harsh judge.)

An in-depth anthropological study bookended by wonderful myths and tragic history: Five stars if you are a scholar. Only three if you are reading for an overview.

This in-depth anthropological study begins with a narrative of the creation myths and migration legends of the Hopi tribe of native Americans.
The creation story involves a series of Worlds, each of which becomes contaminated by Man’s deviation from following the rules and rites ordained by the Creator, each of which is destroyed, first by fire, then by ice, then by flood. We are now in the Fourth World. The Hopi myth postulated that seven worlds will come and go before Man finally becomes one with the Creator.
The legends tell of the wanderings of the Hopi tribe over the earth until they reach their destined home in central Arizona. They seem to tell of travels originating in Mexico and going as far north as the Arctic.
These sections of the study are fascinating, as the myths eerily echo the stories of Genesis and other creation stories.
The second section exhaustively recounts each of the Hopi ceremonies which keep them linked to their tradition and to the Creator. Exhaustive is the correct word, as Waters with the help of his Hopi collaborators lists every detail of each dance, its participants, its location, its background, its costumes, its accessories. And there are a lot of dances. If your interest is not scholarly, you could skip most of this.
The last section is the History, a sad recounting of how the Hopis were betrayed by the American government over and over, their peaceful villages left unprotected against the depredations of their warlike Navajo neighbors, and dwindled to a hollow shell of their former culture and cohesiveness.
