I’m a big fan of Tony Hillerman’s series about Navaho policemen Joe Leaphorn and Jim Chee. This study gives a different vision of the Navajo tribe which is a useful corrective.

Allen's humorus take on his life, and dead serious self-justification re the Mia mess: A Propos of Nothing
This autobiography by Woody Allen starts of like a bunch of riffs from his nightclub act – funny and self-deprecating stories of his childhood misadventures, his warm, noisy, Jewish family, his love for New York. Allen notes that although he was always well-reviewed as a comic, he never saw a queue of folks lining up before his performances , and so he switched to movie script writing, and then to directing. I can understand why the fans didn’t line up - after a while the NYC patter gets tiresome.
Further on, we learn about Allen’s relationships with Louise Lasser and with Diane Keaton. And finally the probable cause for the book’s existence: Allen’s long-drawn-out tragicomic relationship with Mia Farrow. Some facts Allen stresses:
• He and Farrow were never married.
• When he began his friendship with Farrow’s adopted daughter Soon-Yi, the sexual relationship with Farrow was long dead; he maintained contact mainly because of his love for the two of her seven adoptees that he had also adopted.
• Despite Farrow’s claim that Allen had sexually abused his adopted daughter Dylan, the investigators concluded that there was no evidence this had happened, and plenty of evidence that Dylan had been coached by her mother to make the charges.
• Soon-yi was not “retarded and under-age” as the Mia-fueled media trumpeted, but a 22-year-old college student.
• And their relationship bloomed into a marriage which has lasted over 20 years.
I feel after reading this apologia that I should not have reacted so viscerally to the charges made against Allen, boycotting his movies for quite some time. Still, between “Hannah and her Sisters” and “Midnight in Paris” there weren’t so many Allen movies I wanted to see. Allen spends a lot of pages talking about why he made and how he cast each of his many movies – I paged through these except for the movies I had actually seen. But I also feel that, expect for Allen’s deepest fans, the summary above would be enough.

Fantasy about a Buddhist monk turned sports phenom - Plimpton delivers his usual sly humor: The Curious Case of Sidd Finch

This frothy confection is apparently an amplification of an April Fool’s article George Plimpton wrote for Sports Illustrated in 1985. It includes a send up of “experts” pontificating on the physiology of sports performance, the not-so-hallowed traditions of the National Pastime, belief in tantric capabilities of Tibetan Buddhists, and much more. Plimptdon himself appears as a minor character.

Putative narrator is a PTSD sufferer named Robert Trent who used to be a feature writer and now suffers from total writer’s block. The introduction of Robert Trent takes a while to get going, but once Sidd Finch, the English-born orphaned Harvard dropout apprentice monk appears and takes over as the principal protagonist, the plot picks-up. If a pitcher could throw a ball at 170 mph, what would happen to the delicate balance between the pitcher and the batter? Plimpton as a lifelong Walter Mitty of the sports world has a lot of fun with this fantastic premise.

And you learn to care about Robert Trent, too.

A Candy Confection of a Novel: In "The Ladies of Missalonghi" the meek and downtrodden do inherit the earth, with the aid of a .... but I don't want to give away the twist at the end.  The author of "The Thorn Birds" probably tossed this off the way the chef at a seven-course banquet might provide a fluffy meringue dessert or an amuse-bouche appetizer.  No chills, no thrills, but a lot of satisfying come-uppances delivered by our spunky and under-appreciated heroine to those who deserve them, and a feeling of satisfied expectations for the reader. For harmless entertainment - four stars.  Short one star as it is a shameless fairy tale with no more lasting effect than one of those airy meringes.

four stars only because it takes a while to get into: I have been reading at this book for two years. At first, it was slow to get going. The back cover blurb said it was a love triangle, but by page 166 out of 436 the third point of the triangle had not arrived. The point of view shifted from the Father to the Daughter to the Suitor without ever losing the ironic narrative voice which kept us distanced from all three.

And then War comes. War shifts every perspective. The Suitor becomes the Villain. The Invader becomes the Lover. The Child who appears as the Savior of Happiness becomes the Barrier to Happiness. And there is Natural Catastrophe which dwarfs any human idea of destruction.

I am not sorry I read this book over two years. I am not sorry it took me two years. The Doctor, the Daughter, the Suitor, the Villain, and other characters became more real as I took my time. And the Point of view shifted from comic to tragic without a hitch. I recommend this book – in slow doses.

Sir John Grey is a weak foundation on which to build a series: I have almost memorized the first three books of Giana Gabaldon’s “Outlander” series, but I just can’t get interested in the spinoff series involving Lord John Grey, his family misadventures, and his unfortunate affections. I rather enjoyed “The Scottish Prisoner”, but it was really because of the co-starring role played by James Fraser, who has all the wit, subtlety, and irony at his disposal that Sir John, the eternal straight man despite his sexual proclivities, regrettably lacks.

When I opened “The Brotherhood of the Blade” at the library, it fell open to a chapter in which Grey encounters James Fraser again, so I picked it up, hoping for an engrossing read and some interesting backstory about the lead characters. I was disappointed. The chapters involving James Fraser hint at some knowledge that he possesses involving Grey’s family, but the backstory is all about Grey finding out what we already know about the death of Genevra Dunsany, and the filling-in of story about the relationship between Grey and Fraser is all about Grey’s obsession and resentment of Fraser, lacking the charm of the hesitant but eventually stalwart friendship sketched in “Voyager”. The sketch was enough.

So I took the book back to the library without finishing it. I don’t really care whether Grey’s father, who died when Grey was twelve, was a suicide or a murder victim. I’ll wait for the last installment of “Outlander”, due any time these next seven years.

An old-fashioned thriller/mystery: A quick-to-read, lively thriller. Nine people receive a list of names, one of which is their own. You get to know something of each of the nine. One by one, they are murdered.

The homage to Agatha Christie’s “Ten Little Indians” is obvious; the book is mentioned multiple times. This connection does give you a major hint to how the plot will twist, but not so overt that it spoils the fun.
No detailed sex, carnage, or bad language. One of those old-fashioned books that leaves the filling in of details to your imagination, as Christie did. If this is the kind of book you like, you’ll like this book.

Theroux retraces his step but in a better frame of mind: Paul Theroux in this volume retraces as much as possible the route he took in his breakthrough travel book, “The Great Railway Bazaar.” I found that earlier book to be sour-tempered and besotted with drink. But I couldn’t help but be curious about a revisiting – would Theroux have mellowed? Would he find more to admire and less to lament in thirty years of change?

Yes and no. Theroux early on apologizes for the negative frame of mind which flavored his earlier book. He was homesick, often ill, and worried that his marriage was fraying apart. In the sequel the first marriage did indeed disintegrate but he has found new happiness in a second marriage. He has money enough to avoid the illnesses and hazards of his earlier travel, and he is finding some purely happy moments in the ability to travel cocooned from daily worries, but secure that a home will be there when he returns.

Theroux also has an acute eye for the changes in society which have taken place since his earlier trip. He can’t go to Afghanistan due to the conflicts there. He deplores the authoritarian governments which have arisen from the ashes of the USSR in Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, and which have replaced nascent democracies in Thailand and Myanmar. Japan is an island of order and harmony on the surface, but seethes with repressed sexuality and criminality. And Russia is simply tawdry.

But everywhere he meets kindness from individuals. This is the saving grace which redeems the book from curmudgeonliness and makes it a satisfying bedtime read.

A Irish immigrant finds love and complications in Brooklyn: Brooklyn
Colm Toibin does an amazing job of getting into the head of a young Irish girl. We see her frustrated at the limitations of her life in a small Irish village, challenged by an opportunity to emigrate to America, struggling to fit into the new life, culture, and expectations. A love affair with a young Italian is handled a bit tentatively, but since this fits the character of Eilis, our protagonist, Toibin gets away with it.
When Eilis has to return to Ireland for a month-long visit, she finds that her American veneer changes the way people think of her, but this adds some serious complications. I found the book’s handling of Eilis’s relationship with her mother especially good; relationships with her Irish and American girl friends not so convincing. If you’ve seen the movie, you will be fascinated by the choices made by the movie makers of what to keep and what to re-frame.

Does everything a fantasy novel should do.: This is what fantasy is for.  Tanith Lee creates a completely new world, or actually two worlds on the same planet, gives us a spunky heroine, an amusing sidekick, an origin mystery to be solved, no unnecessary blood or violence, and a unicorn to boot.  This is perfect escapist fiction for troubled times.  I can hardly wait for my unicorn-obsessed five year old granddaughter to learn to read so I can pass this on to her.

Lots of words, lots of erudition, start at Chapter 12.: The title is a bit precious and pretentious, coming from a conversation between a pretentious astronomer and a barely-tolerated house guest. The first part of the book labors to make us interested in the fates of two lovely orphaned sisters from Australia as they make their way through the London labyrinth of class and culture in a quest for love and security in the 1950-80 period.
The younger sister, Grace, is blonde, beautiful and pliable. She finds security with no trouble. The oldest, Caro, is brunette, exotically beautiful, and obdurately honest. She finds love with endless trouble.
It took me about 100 pages into this 340 page book to get into it. I would have given up earlier were I not tenacious, but once Caro follows imprudent love into the abyss, I had to find out what next, and there are enough twists in the plot to keep the pages turning, and enough dry satirical humor to leaven the amatory angst.
Does it deserve its National Book Critics Circle award for Fiction? Well, if you write for The New Yorker I suppose it’s a pre-qualification for a number of prizes. Would I recommend this book to anyone less tenacious than myself? Probably not.

An early feminist gone wrong: Ibsen brutally portrays a woman whose brilliance has been stifled by convention, resulting in a personality so curdled with bitterness and dissatisfaction that she cannot bear to see happiness, kindness, or achievement in other lives, and like Iago in “Othello” moves to destroy it without mercy.

Hedda commands our attention with every word and gesture, as she clearly shows us her contempt for her own life and her jealousy and resentment of others whose lives have more meaning. It’s not a pleasant drama, any more than is “Othello” and it can be seen as a landmark portrait of early feminism gone wrong. If only Hedda had been content to burn her bra!

Neil Gaiman channels Lee Child with a bunch of aging myths: Neil Gaiman combines sharp observation of current life with fantastical and surreal interpositions from Norse, African, Greek, and American Indigenous myth, for a novel that is part dystopian, part satire, part mystery, part love story. The version I re-read, the “author’s preferred version” released in 2016 to mark the 10th anniversary of original publication, runs 742 pages of close print, and rambles with its protagonist (Shadow, a big, competent guy reminiscent of Jack Reacher) around the American Midwest and south to Florida. Along the way he meets a number of de-throned mythological figures, most notably Mr. Wednesday, who seems to be plotting an uprising against the new gods of America (Media is named; the others seem to be avatars for Bureaucracy, Money, , Technology, etc.)
It’s spooky, insightful, scary, and at the end satisfying. The gods don’t die, they only morph into something different.

A potpourri of genres, put together with lots of charm and affection: This book is a mix of genres: it’s an intergenerational family drama, it’s centered around the Black Lives Matter movement’s origination in Minneapolis, much of the action happens during the first months of the COVID-19 pandemic, most of the characters are Indigenous Americans, a bookstore and its staff are central to the action, and the bookstore is haunted.
At first I wondered if I would get through it – the first section is told by a druggie about her prison experiences – a phantasmagoria of drug-induced surreality. Fortunately, that section only lasted about 10 pages; then it morphed into a story about a haunted bookstore, but one that is staffed by and concentrates on literature of indigenous peoples. Who can resist a haunted bookstore? And then it became a commentary on very contemporary issues: Covid-19 and Black Lives Matter. And at the end it becomes a family drama – all charmingly told with interesting and diverse characters. I thought the ending was a bit weak at knitting together all the concerns that had been raised.

Last volume of the Amgash series finishes a bit too neatly: Oh William!
This third in Elizabeth Strout’s Amgash trilogy is less satisfying than the earlier two volumes. It rounds out plot points very tidily, but at the expense of some of the emotions resonance and hidden joys between the lines that I found in the other novels, especially on re-reading. This is so often the fate of sequels – the need to tie up plot threads overwhelms the more delicate building of character and theme.
As I am anxiously involved with a family whose history resonates with abuse, abandonment, love, and pain, I related strongly to those themes in the earlier novels, and although they are still strongly evident in “Oh William!” the evolution is just a bit too neat.
The trilogy as a whole gave me some good insights into how the thread of abuse is perpetuated in families. And it's an easy read.

Astrology clearly explained: I have to admit, I have read so many books on how to read and astrological chart and so often I just cannot wrap my head around the concepts and the meanings of how to successfully read an astrology chart, let alone figure out a horoscope. Tanaaz Chubb has changed all that with her book "The Ultimate Guide to Astrology".

Once I read her instructions, it all has begun to click for me. I can now go beyond knowing my sun sign and how other planets in particular houses can have an influence in one's life. I am still a toddler in all of this, but after decades of trying to understand and failing, I have to say this is the best book to making sense of the art of astrology that I have read. The author has made it interesting and made it make sense at long last!

Great for those just starting out: Vervain Helsdottir's "Essential Oil Magic: Natural Spells for the Green Witch is a great little guide for apprentice and advanced witches alike. Like all decent books on magical practice, she starts out explaining the principles of magic, ethics, planning, location and other factors that can either make or break a magical working.

She also covers purchasing oils, oil safety, substitutions if you don't have a particular oil in your cabinet, and she also includes several decent recipes for protection of self, home, enhancing intuition or aligning you with prosperity or inner healing.

Picks up where The Secret leaves off: Everyone is capable of manifestation. Mystic Dylan's "The Witch's Guide to Manifestation: Witchcraft for the Life You Want", isn't just for witches. Manifestation is something that anyone can do and Mystic Dylan explains it in this clear, concise little book.

The author talks about meditation and the psychology behind manifestation in addition to the herbs, elements, stones and crystals and everything else that you can do to help yourself in creating the life of your dreams. This is a fantastic book for beginner witches and those who might be wondering what to do next after they've read The Secret and other books on manifestation.

Good for youth pastors: "The Aspiring Leader's Guide to the Future" by Clay Scroggins is a pretty good book for young people. The author does give good advice for the coming generations as to how to get started in making a difference in the world- even if they don't yet know it all. Scroggins stresses that they don't need to know everything. Just begin where they are.

That being said, it was very difficult (for me) to get beyond the religious overtones in the book. While he does keep that to a minimum, it was very hard to ignore the Christian-centric point of view within the book for those of us who are not themselves Christian. With the book being published by Zondervan, this should have come as no surprise - but I didn't check that part before I ordered it.

To his credit, however, the author does talk about having "people on the bus who don't share your point of view."

Helps to cut through the confusion: I wish I had Benjamin Sweeny's Digital Marketing Quick Start Guide in front of me ten years ago! It would definitely helped me to wrap my head around what was being discussed. I have taken courses in PR and marketing in college, I subscribe to business learning sites, and yet, this book put out by ClydeBank Media cuts through so much that I failed to grasp before!

Because digital marketing is now more important than ever, if you're thinking of starting an online business, it can be really confusing and frustrating to learn what it is you need to know. You not only want to get your product or service out in front of potential customers, you want to convert casual online traffic sers into sales.

I love the spiral bound format of this book because it makes it easy to read and focus on. and Sweeney makes it a point to go over the importance of having SMART goals for your digital marketing - which means you want Specific, Measurable, Actionable, Relevant and Time Bound. And he goes over the tools to help capture and direct potential customers toward not only sales but repeat business in a way that is easy to understand. He goes over social medial, email lists and SEO in a way that doesn't make you feel as if you need a marketing degree.

When you first get the book, you are immediately directed to download further digital assets and forms that can help you with your own digital marketing efforts. While it's great that you are getting these free forms, examples and resources such as Googles Analytics page, it did leave me wondering just why it wasn't simply included inside the book. I do know that this kind of approach is pretty much part and parcel of what most online marketing campaigns do - offer potential customers "free stuff" so that they will be more inclined toward giving you their email address so they can be moved further down the sales funnel.

The myth of "If you build it, they will come" is definitely not true. You need to have some sort of digital marketing strategy to make your online business work for you. "Digital Marketing Quick Start Guide" is a great place to start if you are considering launching a new or improving your existing online business efforts.

Bodhi is a great character: I have read all the Bodhi King novels and have learned to love him more with each book. Melissa does a great job of helping the reader see things from his perspective and maybe even teaches a thing or two along the way. I highly recommend these books.

I couldn't put the book down: My headline is not a lie or an exaggeration. I couldn't put the book down. Every time I thought it was time to turn off my tablet and get some sleep, I decided to read just one more chapter. The characters are easy to root for and I enjoyed seeing them develop in this book.
boring: What a boring book!  I didn't expect "Pride and Prejudice" but really, awful.

Gotta love Eva: As usual Ms Belcamino's books hook me from the first paragraph. This one is an Eva Santella escapade. Starting in Italy at her training camp for assassins traveling to Los Angeles to save a young woman being held captive and starving by her parents I couldn't put this down. I absolutely love Eva"s style. Her amazing ability to dress in black Vercace with Laboutin boots hiding her weapons and ability to pick locks and hot wire cars and get away from the bad guys and save the vicims. What an imagination this author has...now I'm left wondering how soon the next book will be available so I can continue this journey

To call this terrible is giving it too much credit: The following is an honest unpaid review from a parent whose child is actually using this workbook: This workbook was not thought out thoroughly or designed by an educator and it shows...abundantly. It's laid out in a one page per day format for each unit which is a collection of 15 words. The page in every unit labeled as day one is fill-in-the-blank with the correct word from the provided box, so the kids need to know the meaning of the words. The problem arises with the fact there's no glossary. Absolutely no way for the kids to look up unfamiliar words and it's full of them. So you try to use a dictionary and help your child find the word meaning. However the words have multiple meanings and you don't know which one they want you to use until you do the workbook page. To make matters worse by week nine they have the kids doing pages with word boxes completely unrelated to the spelling words or forming new words with the spelling words as a root word. Uh this is spelling, not vocabulary! Week 15, day 3 has a word box full of words that has nothing to do with the spelling words. I'm trying to teach my child that t-o-t-a-l spells total so that he doesn't ask me every time he needs to write it. This book is completely useless for that! I work outside of the home full time and don't have time to use the workbook as a basis for designing my own spelling curriculum. That's what I bought the product for. It's a complete waste of money and hasn't helped my child's spelling skills at all. So save yours and don't buy this garbage.
Good Book: Bought this for my daughter and she loved it.
Guardian Tarot: Arrived quickly and as described.

Well written and enjoyable: This is a mix of fairly short and long form short stories.  Sometimes with a twist, sometimes not, but always a good creepy mood.  It's pretty amazing that he started publishing at 18 and died at 30.  One addition that would have been nice would have been a short individual introduction for many of the stories.
Almost New condition: I loved that the book- rated acceptable condition was actually in excellent condition! Thankyou!

history: B01501NYAQ B016JC0THQ B00XVB938K B01LX301ET B07NL757ZF B0839JDRW9 B07RZ4V8TV
review: Top of the pile!: Your stories just keep getting better as you go and you can hardly put them down as you read them. Keep them coming!
So Heartbroken!: I waited for this for soooo long, and it is just so weak and, sad to say, AWFUL… almost unreadable. I can’t believe the same person who wrote this wrote Krampus and Lost Gods.

It’s not bragging if it’s true, right?: It’s certainly very interesting… philosophical, funny, flippant and wise… I enjoyed it more than I thought I would. He’s a mess, but a talent I’m really glad we have.

Absolutely Fantastic: This was handed to me by a friendly bookseller at Barnes and Noble who said, “Try this. I think you'll like it.”. Boy was he right. I loved it! The characters, writing and plotting are wonderful and work really well together. I bonded quickly with these people, which is rare.

An Intriguing Story…: Thanks to last night’s all night fireworks barrage, I read this in three sittings. It is very compelling, if a little longwinded at times. It could have been a smaller book, but the author had to have enough hay to hide the clues. However, I knew who it was on page 127 with the line, “Oh, it’s a long and tortured story. Something out of a novel.”.

But it’s still a pretty good plot…

A Fantastical and Tragic Must Read: I will start off with the “cons” of this book, because the “pros” are immense. My biggest complaint, if I had to complain, is some ‘confused telling’ aspects as well as overly long sections that (seemingly) serve a lesser purpose and bog down the plotting. The author skips around in time and between characters in a confusing way at times, which is distracting, causing me to have to re-orient myself in the story. However, I soon realized that the madness of the situation(s) was often being expressed in the confusing style.

Now the pros:
I felt like I was reading an old Arthurian tale, fantastic and highly symbolic, with a touch of “Catch 22” meets a macabre Python movie. The themes and symbolism are everywhere:
**Dismemberment** (from the truth, reality, justice, home, family, self) - Everything is broken and displaced… buildings, families, order… and, as I said, even the story itself feels disjointed at times.
**The Golem** of justice, protector and killer of his people because the world’s gone mad
**St George the Martyr** who is famous for slaying a dragon that demanded human sacrifices (like our pieced together Golem)… and, hello, **George Bush** and St George is associated with England and Christianity which brings more thematic ideas of a Christ figure in our Golem.
and we have Hadi, the liar and junk dealer (whose name is one of 99 names of god in Islam, meaning ‘The Guider’), trying to do something noble… like bringing his people together (in pieces and in whole) which the Whatsitsname/Golem tells us about all the time but especially on page 146 when he says,
“ ‘The young madman thinks I am the model citizen that the Iraqi state has failed to produce, at least since the days of King Faisal I.
‘Because I am made up of body parts of people from diverse backgrounds - ethnicities, tribes, races, and social classes - I represent the impossible mix that never was achieved in the past. I am the first true Iraqi citizen,…’”
Our Golem also says that he is “… the only justice there is in this country.”.

Another character, Mahmoud (whose name has the coveted H-M-D letters that denote “praise” and being “praiseworthy”) says, “ it’s hard to convince anyone of this nonsense, but organized nonsense of this kind stands behind all the crimes committed,…”

It’s a very deep, compelling, intricate, allegorical, fantastic telling of the ever branching, expanding horrors of brokenness and displacement that were inflicted upon Iraq and its people.

So, while this is not my typical, favored, immersive reading experience, it was fascinating. I did stumble a bit with the cons mentioned above, but what really slowed my reading was eager note taking and lots and lots of googling. Which makes this book one of my second favorite type of reading experiences: one of L E A R N I N G. I feel I was given a very personal, inside glimpse of an unknown world. And I did ~feel~ and do better understand the true tragedy that our country, America, both exacerbated and set in motion there.

The Sequel Stinks: What a mess… and a total bummer. I loved the first book (It’s a favorite, and I’ve reread it three times already), but this sequel is a horrible disappointment - in story and writing. It’s a jumble, without flow. There are too many characters and activity, and no depth. Basically, everything I loved about the original story is gone. Just so very sad and disappointing… I pre-ordered and waited for this book for a year (that felt like 10). Two stars feels generous.

Fantastic: The writing is superb. The way it takes you through thoughts, memory and action is brilliant, evocative, intelligent and wonderfully nuanced. The Sergeant is such a real person. I just loved everything… Well, until the end… which I am still coming to terms with. However, I am beginning to understand the brilliance of even that.

Kept me turning the pages: It was fascinating to read about a French town that I had visited.  Made me realise how much I had missed when I visited it on holiday - darn it.  The author focused as much on characterisation as she did on plot details and has a well-developed understanding of the French psyche - especially the snobbery about food and wine!  It was interesting to understand just how important family connections (to wealth and power) are in France and the insidious minor corruption that accompanies that.  Her hero, Verlaque, is flawed in terms of his ability to sustain deep personal relationships, but the author clearly has hopes for him.  The crime part was well-enough done - at one stage I thought the murderer was going to be one of a cast of hundreds, but the possibilities were quickly whittled down.  Let's see if the next one in the series is as good.

Main character is turning out to be a bit of a snob.....: This was the 3rd in the series, and I've bought the 4th.  I am enjoying them, because the author spends time on each character, trying to ensure you see them warts and all.  The stereotypes are getting a trifle annoying though:  main French character (the Judge) is rich, privately educated, a gourmand (hence references to his pudgy middle), very fussy about his wines and likes jazz.  His girlfriend is (of course) beautiful, tall, thin - although she shares her partner's love of degustation menus and fine wines, with nary a mention of the  gym - educated, and teaches at a university - and there's definitely a whiff of snobbery clinging to them both. Interestingly, in this book,  the murderer is someone of whom we know nothing.  He appears as a name, and that's all.  All of the other suspects were far more rounded out through the process of elimination.  I like this author's writing and I love her descriptions of French and Italian towns, churches, vineyards, soils, food, wine etc.  She's also willing to let the main character's colleagues makes some excellent deductions - it's not all down to the brilliance of the Judge.  The books are sufficiently immersive to stop me from impatiently reading the end first, and although a couple of times I have 'guessed' whodunnit, it's not glaringly apparent.

Just a "Die Hard" story in words: Really, really disappointed in this.  I had high expectations.  From the reviews, it sounded like there was good characterisation, good plotting, good sci fi.  But it just turned out to be another 'Die Hard' story with aliens and lots of shooting/killing, albeit the MC had a soft spot for kids.  I skimmed through, and read the ending.  Very predictable.

Charming murder mystery if you feel like a not-too-demanding read: I've been whiling my days away reading these mysteries (in the absence of good sci fi).  Somehow I felt that the murder mystery was just a device the author needed in order to tell us more about her favourite characters, foods, wines and French towns.  And I've gone along for the journey, whereby her MC, Judge Verlaque has matured, over 9 books, from a commitment-phobe to a happily married man.  This is the France of smelly cheeses, foie gras (from force-fed geese), veal, pastis, and smoking in restaurants and bars plus endless coffees.  In this book, a whole museum of, primarily, china/porcelain vanishes, and shortly afterwards two men are attacked - resulting in a death.  Of course we learn much more than we ever really wanted to about china and art, but such is the world of this author.  Occasionally her humour sneaks up on you for a laugh-out-loud moment - such as when Verlaque's colleague bought croissants - one almond and one plain and Verlaque after a false start managed to snaffle the almond one when his colleague wasn't looking - Verlaque's tummy has enlarged with each book, such is the life of a gourmand.  I've really enjoyed these books, particularly the descriptions of French life, including eating.  Makes you want to visit France - impossible here due to covid, alas.

High body count, blood/gore, venal humans & implacable deadly justice - the usual fare: I sometimes ask myself why I'm reading this series.  The author usually features a traumatised female character, who acts in a childish, sort of Bridget Jones way.  The key character in this story, Vicki, says things like "Oh gosh golly" or "deep doo-doo" as she stumbles her way through murders and vengeance killings.  The "Others" - fantastical characters who rule Earth, which they refer to as "Namid", have little compunction in dealing with wicked humans - no trial by jury here.  An inter-connected (but they don't know that at first) contamination of venal humans and "others" have converged upon Vicki's little town named Sproing to cause murderous havoc using Halloween aka "Trickster Night" to kick things off.  It takes the Chief of Police a while to sort out exactly who the villains are, and in the meantime the body count rises - somewhere around 8-10 in total.  Vicki's romance, if you can call it that, with Julian continues at a glacial pace.  Books and bookstores continue to be a key motif and the "Others" value Vicki as a "Reader".  The author has created a pretty detailed world, where humans are not the dominant species, and I've got to give her points for imagination and I even admit to some fascination with the world she has created.  But the misery/venality of human beings and copious amounts of blood/gore is both tiring and predictable.
Make this a movie!: As a huge Little Women fan I got this book. I loved it!! Make this a move, mini series, anything really!!!!

The most original SF novel I've read in years: By an unexplained fluke of quantum mechanics, Nat Morgan can't be remembered if he isn't seen or heard for one minute. He disappears from computer systems. He doesn't appear on film or taped records. He's the CIA's perfect thief, though he has to keep convincing them he works for them. He's Schrödinger's cat burglar.

That's how this starts. Then it gets WEIRD.

Eric Stone builds this plot around quantum theory to explain Nat's existence, then pulls unexpected but perfectly logical extrapolations from the basic idea. The story works, beautifully.

Nat is sent to stop to stop an Iranian billionaire from getting his hands on technology that will make possible a super-computer that can predict the future. He ends up meeting the only person in the world who can remember his existence, and finding out the job is much, MUCH more important than he thought, as well as more difficult and dangerous. Because the computer will not only be able to predict the future, but control it.

And in order to do save, he has to simultaneously help Russian ex-spy Yelena Semyonova and Iranian physicist Parham Rezaei with their own problems, problems entangled with his. I can't say much about this without creating spoilers, but I can say that I never felt Stone cheated to move the story along. Read this, I think you'll like it.

An Excellent Study of Self-Deception: Mary Mapes notoriously ended her journalism career in 2004, when she produced a 60 MINUTES WEDNESDAY that used forged memos to attack then President George W. Bush. This book is a revealing study of how she crashed and burned.

As this book reveals, Mapes decided back in the 1990s that Bush got into the National Guard through morally illegitimate means, and then failed to do the duty he had sworn to do. She hated and despised him, and was determined to bring him down. Unfortunately, she failed to consider that she might be wrong, and couldn't accept that proof might not exist even if she wasn't wrong.

In Edward Steer's book HOAX, https://www.amazon.com/Hoax-Hitlers-Diaries-Lincolns-Assassins-ebook/dp/B00AEV86B0, one of the recurring themes is the way people with a strong desire for something are easily taken advantage of by forgers. Mapes's desperate desire for proof of the Badness of George W. led her to Bill Burkett, who handed her "memos" with no provenance, memos which typewriter experts swore couldn't be produced on any typewriter ever made in the entire history of the world, memos that were intrinsically ridiculous. But she still believes that those memos were genuine. They have to be. It's unacceptable that she made a fool of herself, or that W. got away with his Badness.

Besides demonstrating her desperate gullibility, the book is also useful for showing how the press biases the news. If you check out various topics she brings up along the way, such as the fall of Eason Jordan at CNN, you will find that by leaving out important details she makes a story look the way she wants it without actually having to tell too many outright falsehoods. In short, EDITING IS LYING, and Mapes edits her stories relentlessly in the hope of concealing inconvenient facts.

So read this book, but also research the story from outside sources, especially the ones she condemns the most. The conclusion I think you'll come to is that Mapes did not tell the truth, and failed in her own duty as a journalist.
Child Pleaser: My great grandson loves this book and asks for it all the time.  He is 20 months old.
Helpful little book: Helpful little book
Important life skills: Important life skills
Nice life story: Nice life story
Sweet book: Sweet book
Interesting facts: Enjoyed the book.  Real interesting.

What a FIND!!!!!: Oh my......worth every page. The story takes us from 1021 London when Robert Cole is 9. Very well researched about life in London at that time, the guilds, the Saxon and Danish kings; barber surgeons, Persia and Jews. We travel through Rob's orphan childhood when he is apprenticed to a barber surgeon. He falls in love with medicine and realizes the only way he can become a physician is to apply at a famous medical school in Ispahan, Persia, as a Jew. Just a fascinating, I-can't-put-it-down-but-it-is-too-heavy book. I definitely am going to order the 2 others of the trilogy and the Rabbi

I read about him in the Forward and just had to read an internationally lauded book, by an American, that was almost unknown in the USA. Now I am on to reading all his others, as is my wont.

A really different and totally delightful Crais: Talk about "branching out"......I LOVED this book.....  Didn't realize it was not part of the Elvis/Joe series until 3/4 of the way and said.....hey....where's Elvis?  This is so incredibly different and really fascinating and lovely.  It's basically about an ex "Marine '' military dog, Maggie, whose handler was killed in Afghanistan and the dog was shot multiple times;  and an LAPD officer whose partner was killed and he was badly wounded.  OK.  So Scott James definitely doesn't want to leave the force but he is really in a lot of pain and isn't physically fit for a patrolman, but they allow him to join the K9 unit.  He is given Maggie and these two wounded and PTSD fellows bound and heal each other.  So much fascinating information about how dogs think and smell and a good mystery as well.  Definitely recommend it and you can read it without reading any other Crais.

This follows The Suspect: This follows The Suspect with Officer Scott James and Maggie, the PTSD German Shepherd and the addition, in the middle of the book, of our old friends Elvis and Joe.  Another great mystery........A young journalist is blown up in Afghanistan and the mother, a brilliant physicist, vows revenge on the terrorists.  OK, it's a stretch for sure, but I loved it......and Maggie is Some Great Dog.

Meh: Sigh. This was painful... It came so highly recommended on Goodreads Jewish Book Club and I still feel guilty submerging my reading life in detective mysteries, I felt I needed to branch out. Did she have a crystal ball??: I just found this paper back in a pile of books in my closet.  Knowing nothing I started it and kept turning back to the copyright page......really I kept turning back.....2009?  I'm reading this January, 2022 and it is really, all about a world wide panademic.  We are in our 3rd year of our nightmare and the book should be boring....Been that, done that......but she wrote it in 2009.  My jaw is still open.  I finished it in 24 hours.  Kasischke is a poet and her writing shows it.  Really lovely, flowing, lyricism, rounded characters, romance that goes awry; loved the realistic depiction of the the step children and their relationship to Jiselle.  This is (fortunately) a bit darker than our world as the "Phoenix flu" kills 1 out of 3 and the government has seemed to have collapsed.  No electricity, little news, no gasoline, nor food in stores, vandalism and looting; and a really odd reference to anti Korean hatred rumoring that it started in a lab in Korea.  So weird.  2009!!! .....and at the ending.......it just ends and one never knows.  Loved it.

Daniel Silva does it again: I was so distraught when I finished all the Gabriel Allon series and delighted to find some more Silva. He is such a great writer, and especially during these fraught times I need guilt-free distractions. I get great page turning mysteries and learn so much as well, with all of Silva's books. In the Mark of the Assassin
we meet a new quite likeable and not really flawed at all protagonist, Michael Osbourne. He works for the CIA. His wife is a DC lawyer and daughter of a powerful former Senator. I almost didn't read the book because the prologue was so extremely violent, but my curiosity prevailed and I am so glad I continued. Typical Silva, great writing, great rounded characters, great mysteries, rampant and frightening corruption and evil in the government. Loved it.

She was the kind of wife who turned heads at Personnel. Graham indulged her because she was beautiful and because she was gifted. She possessed a fire for life that the Service had long extinguished in him. He wore her like a loud tie.

. She set her unfaltering gaze on him. Somewhere during her ascent , Monica Tyler had learned to use her eyes as a weapon. They were liquid and blue and changed instantly with her mood. When she was interested her eyes became translucent and fastened on her subject with therapeutic intensity. When she was annoyed--or worse, yet, bored--her pupils froze over and her gaze turned unreflecting. When she was angry her eyes flickered about her victim like searchlights, scanning for a kill zone.

He looked once more at the western sky, the direction Monica's helicopter would come, but there was only a spray of wet stars, scattered over the black carpet of space, and a sliver of moon, white as exposed bone.

But what heart stopping excitement when I found this book: I had no idea that Jane Thynne (the widow of Phillip Kerr) had written more than the Clara Vine series. YAY!! when I found this and so enjoyed it. Her writing style and blend of true history is still there.

There are two distinct voices here: It's New York, 2012. The aging (and soon to be dead) famous chronicler, Cordelia Capel; and the recovering from heartbreak, journalist, Juno Lambert. Out of curiosity, Juno wanders into an antique typewriter store and buys a used typewriter , previously owned by Cordelia Capel. In the carrying case is..............drum roll........... carbons with half of a memoir about Cordelia's sister's life -- who had married a Nazi officer before WW2. Oh my................I was in heaven; back in Nazi Germany during WW2 , with the same real life characters as Bernie Gunther and Clara Vine had met. And a spectacular mystery as well. Highly recommend this brilliant and page turning book.

BA-BOOM! A great guide for pro or novice.: The Essential Guide to Comic Book Lettering belongs in your studio if you make comics or zines. If you don't have a studio yet and aspire to make comics, you still need this book. I have been an illustrator for decades and taught a college level class on making zines. I learned a LOT in the first hour I spent with this book. For example, I did not know the "pucker and bloat " technique for making consistent thought balloons.

Nate Piekos, a master letterer, demonstrates the fine art of crafting individual letters and words. He goes far beyond these basics. His guidance on the art of placement of balloons and the lettering within the balloons is clear and well-illustrated.

Don't draw your own lettering? Use fonts downloaded from DaFont or Piekos's own excellent Blambot site? You still need this book. It will help you use those pro fonts effectively. There will always come a time where you need to draw a unique sound effect, or maybe a distressed variation of that font for a road sign. This book will be your guide.

5 stars. Recommended without reservation. There is so much gold in this guide I could go on all day, but I need to get to my drawing board!

Stark Story set in Colombia.: AMAZONA- a graphic novel, by Canizales
Review by Kevin McCloskey 1/23/22

Translation to English by Sofía Huitrón Martínez
U.S edition, Graphic Universe, Lerner, pub date: April, 2022

The graphic novel Amazona, like Disney’s animated musical Encanto, takes place in Colombia. Two stories of refugee families forced off their land by violence could not be more different. Encanto‘s giddy Madrigal family sings about their refuge calling it a ‘casita,’ or little house. Their house is more like a casona, a mansion, so saturated in Disney-color the rainbow seems redundant.

On the other hand, Amazona is a starkly drawn graphic novel. It is mostly black graphite pencil on rough white paper. Ink washes and spots of color are used sparingly to reflect a very different take on the refugee experience.
On the other hand, Amazona is a starkly drawn graphic novel. It is mostly black graphite pencil on rough white paper. Ink washes and spots of color are used sparingly to reflect a very different take on the refugee experience.

The artist Canizales was born in Cali, Colombia. In his story an indigenous refugee family is relocated to a dilapidated casita in a Cali slum. Andrea, the young heroine, describes her new surroundings: “In the place where we live now, and forgive me if I don’t call it home, you’ll find: my sisters and brothers . . .My cousins and aunts and uncles . . .My neighbors, grandmothers, and grandfathers . . .And boys and girls who lost their own families. A total of thirty-eight people sharing a 600-square-foot space. The place is divided into two rooms with no windows, a bathroom with no door, a kitchen, and a patio.“

Canizales now lives in Majorca, Spain where he is a professor of illustration and an award-winning author/illustrator. Most of his artistic output consists of early reader picture books and bright bubbly board books. While his board books would not look out of place in a Disney store, Amazona is clearly a passion project. It is fiction, but based on real people and places. Canizales pledges a portion of the book’s profit to aid indigenous people via Resguardo Indígena Nasa de Cerro Tijeras.

The storytelling has tremendous momentum. I intended to simply glance at the review pdf that came my way, but I read it in one sitting. Canizales’s tale is an important story, not a pretty one. There is racism and violence, including an attempted rape. While the vocabulary is deceptively simple, Amazona is not a children’s book. It is a graphic novella for adults, including mature young adults.

I admit there were plot twists in Amazona that I found hard to believe. – Latin American magic realism? However, Amazona undoubtedly delivers more insight to the Colombian refugee crisis than Encanto. Hundreds of talented artists, writers and colorists are credited at the end of Encanto. Don’t get me wrong, Encanto is a great entertainment product and I appreciate full employment for artists, but it is not food for thought. Encanto was never intended to build empathy with the poorest of poor.

In contrast, one artist, Canizales, born in Cali, Colombia, created Amazona. Sure, he had editors, art directors, and in the case of the U.S. edition, a wonderful translator. Yet, Amazona is basically the act of a single focused imagination, a single hand. Amazona is an extraordinary achievement, worth the journey.

Turns out their parents know a lot more than we thought.: The second Fowl Twins book is just as good as the first one. Maybe even better than the first.

In Deny All Charges, we don't just get the hilarious antics of the twins Myles and Beckett. We get a lot more of their parents. Not only are Artemis Sr. and Angeline Fowl in the book, they are actually acting like parents. Not only do we see them laying down the law on the uncontrollable twins, we see how truly devastating the aftermath of The Last Guardian was for them.

Which honestly is maybe a clue as to why Artemis left the planet.

The actual plot is quite an adventure. Full of Colfer's trademark humor and narrative style. Be warned the bathroom humor is strong with this installment. The fart jokes quickly becoming a noxious haze that overshadows all other jokes.

Childish jokes aside, I really enjoyed this installment in the Fowlverse and am eagerly awaiting the next. If you are like me and were left scarred by the way Artemis Fowl: The Last Guardian ended, then I highly recommend this book. Because the only people left scarred worse than us readers were his parents.

Enola Holmes mini mystery.: This Enola Holmes short story takes place after the last book in the main series "The Gypsy Goodbye."

Enola is no longer on the run from her famous brothers. She is happily enrolled at a women's college and is no longer actively seeking out detective work.

When your last name is Holmes however, the detective work finds you.

The Boy in Buttons is a short story with all the charm and cunning of the original Enola series. It shows a more mature Enola focused on her education but still just as passionate about social reform.

Provides a window into my mother & auntie's escape from Shanghai: My mother and auntie had said that they left Shanghai on the last boat back in 1949 and genealogical US military documents of their father generally verified the timeline of events back in 1949. They never talked about their lives in China, and their journey to the United States. This wonderful book provides so many details of the physical and political conditions that were going on in Shanghai from the prewar days of the 1930s to the aftermath in the 1950s. It provides so much insight into what my mom and auntie experienced in their early lives. I can truly understand now why neither of them had any desire to ever return to Shanghai for a visit.

The focus on 4 people who fled Shanghai provide detailed insights into both a male and female perspective - and since they were about the same age as my mom & auntie, provided even more insight into their possible lives while in China. The stories and experiences of each one of them reflected characteristics of my mom in so many ways. The political background also provided a window into my own grandfather's Japanese internment camp experiences.

I plan on recommending this book to all of my cousins, since they also have no details of their mother's life in Shanghai. I think this book is the most memorable book I have ever read, for it provided a window into my mother's life in China as well as her initial experiences in the US.

Great collection of short stories in his various universes within the Cosmere: The main reason I read this novel was to read the Edgedancer novella, since I haven't read many of Sanderson's other works. I was very impressed with the storytelling of each short story, and it has made me want to read his other series. What made this collection stand out is that he added a postscript for each story that delved into his motivation and thought process of writing each piece. Also, having a preface that gave an overview of the solar system for the specific world teased at having the Cosmere become one cohesive work sometime in the future.

BTW - I would not read this on the Kindle, because one of his stories is a graphic novel, and another has annotations on each page.

Accurately describes his ideological enemies and alienates his ideological friends.: First of all, I'm reviewing this book based on the criterion of how well I think it meets it's objectives, and not how much I agree or disagree with the opinions expressed.

This book is essentially to me a long and well thought out editorial aimed at an audience I can't quite identify, except that it should resonate with anyone who is trying to understand what this "wokeness" is that has suddenly appeared to be everywhere all at once. (I actually saw the beginnings of it in Seattle about ten years ago.)

That said, I think it was a significant strategic blunder to trash Christianity and Trump supporters in the flippant, not well-though-out way that he did.

Like it or not, seventy to eighty million people voted for Trump, and McWhorter alienated them with a single sentence. It didn't even seem to occur to this author that many may have voted for Trump not because they loved him so much, but rather that they saw Trump as a way to stand up to the very "woke religion" that McWhorter wants defeated so badly.

And, based Christians know a religion when they see one. I am a Christian, and I saw this religious aspect of "wokeness" starting back around 2017, and I've been waiting for authors like McWhorter to expose "wokeness" for the religion that it is.

Well bravo, but I don't think McWhorter understands how much the first-wave civil rights movement was inspired by the Second Great Awakening, which Christianized much of the newly formed United States (we really weren't all that Christian from the start) and over the years changed the hearts and minds of untold numbers of white people against slavery.

Christianity succeeded so well at this time because it was voluntary, not the state religion, and Christians used persuasion, not brute force in the form of career destruction and character assassination ("terror" as McWhorter describes this in his book) to advance Christianity. He should appreciate the difference in tactics, even if he doesn't believe Christianity as a religion has any more reality behind it than the "woke religion" he wants defeated.

I don't think McWhorter understands that if he wants "woke religion" defeated and The Enlightenment saved, it will require all hands on deck, so to speak, not just skeptical cranky alienated Democrats. Ironically, McWhorter seemed to end up trashing everyone who isn't just like he is. But he won't try to get you fired from your job for disagreeing with him. What I think he wants is a level playing field where genuine debate can happen again. He wants the "terror" to end.

The section on how "Woke Racism" hurts black people (the chapter entitled "What's Wrong with it Being a Religion") was where I learned the most, since it is the most articulate and detailed expose I've read so far addressing how this "religion" of Woke is actually hurting black people.

So in summary, this book isn't the end of the "woke religion" or even the beginning of the end, but perhaps it marks the end of the beginning. Hat tip Winston Churchill.

For best results, read by gaslight.: First the good. This book is very easy to read, and I try to give a star just for that. I imagined a friendly voice speaking to me as I was reading through this book. The process of "data input" as I read was enjoyable, and many books don't have that going for them. And it is almost a "one stop shop" for this teaching, ideology, dogma, or whatever one wants to call it. So, there's an efficiency aspect as well. There are a lot of academic papers in the bibliography, and I'm sure glad I didn't have to read those.

But to me, there were to me perplexing aspects to the progression of thought in the narrative.

The author uses the word "socialization" to essentially render me non-existent. I have no objective reality and cannot be objective (page 9), and I am not an individual (DNA notwithstanding.) Individualism and objectivity are (page 9) "Western ideologies." On page 9 the author also writes, "Objectivity tells us that it is possible to be free of all bias." Says who? Why would the word "objective" even exist if someone hadn't thought, long ago, that it was possible to recognize and at least correct for bias to a large extent?

So, I can't be objective and I'm not an individual. And, there shouldn't be "meritocracy" because that's another dominant narrative produced by "Whites," (page 27). So, without being able to think objectively (I can't it seems), and with no meritocracy (nothing to strive for, except perhaps escalating degrees of anti-racism), and with no individualism, why should I care about anything at all? Why not just subjectively pursue my own comfort and avoid pain? What else is there?

On page 14 the author says, "If you are reading this and are still making your case for why you are different from other white people and why none of this applies to you, take a breath." Seriously? Am I in trapped in a "training" class at work? Did I just sign over all moral authority to a Ph.D. in multicultural education? If I needed to take a breath, it’s because of the hubris, not because of the content.

I did read to the end of the book and to me this book to me is a demonstration of gaslighting, that is, convincing “white” people that their minds really don't work at all in the area of racism. When it comes to race, "white" people are not sane or competent to discuss the issue, and should not trust the thoughts, any thoughts, on the issue coming from their own minds.

That may work on a person whose mind is wired a certain way, but it doesn’t work on me.

It's ok: Spoilers: if you're not familiar with the original Pilgrim's Progress or contemporary Christian (non-Catholic) institutions, you may struggle with this book.

The Babylon Bee returns to its Christian satire roots with this book. My familiarity with the original Pilgrim's Progress begins and ends with a reference in another book - maybe Franny and Zooey. That being said, its a hero's journey through an alternate but parallel universe - maybe some Heinlein mixed in. The story is told from an omniscient narrator's perspective as our hero makes his way through this strange but oddly familiar world to restore his faith in himself and in a Higher Being.

It's ok. I would recommend that BB produce some short videos explaining the Pilgrim's Progress as well as a "preacher reference" Bingo card. Many of the characters in the book are parodies of Christian preachers and theologians. A Bingo card would have made it easier to pay attention to the book.

This is the book I was hoping Operation Dragon would be.: Gen Pacepa is the highest ranking member of a KGB organization to defect to US. He and Ben Woolsley (former CIA director, DCI) co-authored Operation Dragon which exposed Soviet instruments of disinformation and terrorism. This book gets into the meat of the Oswald case. I've only just started it and it's well documented. He explains what the Warren Commission lawyers who weren't versed in spy craft completely missed. Typical KGB patterns and connections show up all around Oswald. The first books on the assassination came out before the Warren Report and were Soviet sponsored disinformation. They pointed at CIA, FBI, Mafia, Castro, LBJ. Both Khrushchev and Johnson had the same agenda: keep the finger pointed away from international (esp. Soviet) involvement. Great read so far.

That's not all, she inherits a client formerly her fathers, charged with murder, arson, etc.

I won't give away any more safe to say, this is the best " novel" I have read in my (67) years of mystery reading!

You are hooked, after turning that first page...

It doesn't get better than this: This will stack up as an equal with any novel from any period. As good as Jane Austen, as good as Tolstoy, as good as Fitzgerald. There is a mist-ical quality to the story. you are looking at the history of the period through a butler's eye although the butler neither pays attention nor can discern any unethical behavior of those he serves and through his seemingly straitjacketed emotional existence cannot touch or form a relationship with the woman who's nearby and whom he regards as an excellent worker. If you think English Butlers are repressed then Stevens is an embodiment of it. The story goes in and out of pre and post-war which offers an optical illusion of magical quality to the reader. Just an outstanding novel and quite probably the best to come out of England since clockwork orange. Decades after I read it still reverberates in me as one of the great stories. Even if he had not written anything else, this alone would be Nobel-worthy.

Absolutely sucks you in and you can’t stop reading!: Absolutely love it! It sucks you into the story and before you know it, you are head over heals for the characters and you never want to stop reading.

Family and second chances: I thought this was a good book about family, first and foremost, and forgiveness.

Sonny left Michigan behind as soon as she was old enough to leave. Her younger sister died and it practically broke Sonny. She felt like the only way she could keep going was by getting away from the memories. Everything about winter in Michigan reminds her of her sister. Sonny’s in her 50’s and she’s barely been back since she left for college. Losing her dad was the double whammy. But when she decided to leave and not look back, she left her mom behind and alone. They could have turned to each other, instead Sonny ran. She has been living in California for years. It never snows, it’s hardly ever even cold. Sonny loves her job as a successful tv meteorologist.

Then Sonny gets fired. The station has decided to replace their anchors with AI anchors that never age.
Sonny has an embarrassing confrontation about this on live tv. Unfortunately she goes viral. Now she’s not only lost her job but no one else wants to take a chance on her. Only one station wants her and it’s in Michigan with a woman Sonny wasn’t very nice to in college.

She very reluctantly accepts the job.
The station decides it would be fun to introduce Sonny to their viewers by making her do all the most wintery activities Michigan has to offer.
There’s cardboard sledding, yeti contests, all kinds of things that might be considered fun to someone other than Sonny.

The longer Sonny stays, and the more winter activities she does, the more her memories of her sister sneak up on her.

Sonny finally starts to face the truth: running away from everything familiar to her did not help her heal. Maybe it’s time to deal with the past. Maybe she can really be happy if she does. She has another chance to spend time with her mom and she has met a wonderful man named Mason who wants Sonny to open up to him.

I loved Sonny’s mother most of all. She’s a fantastic character. She’s very lovable and wise and a bit quirky too. The best parts of this story, in my opinion, were of Sonny and her mom.

Icicle is also a sweet character.

I liked that Sonny’s mom and Sonny’s love interest Mason are both teaching Sonny lessons about dealing with grief.
And I love that Sonny is able to teach her coworker Icicle some lessons as well.

Sometimes I found Mason’s conversations to be really wordy and more information than I wanted (not in a TMI situation, more that I care less about Leland blue than he does). If I were to change something, I’d just have Mason’s talks be a bit shorter. But, hey, I’m an introvert, I’m not a talky person myself :)

I somewhat misunderstood that this book would be a bit christmassy. It’s really not. This is not a light Christmas book, this is a rather heavy book set in the winter. But it’s a really good journey. I think you’ll be really happy to see these characters along on their journeys. It’s quite sad at times but every single one of them has the potential to be incredibly happy again and I think that’s pretty fantastic.

I read an early ebook edition from NetGalley, thanks!

Wow: Sometimes I find myself reading a book that I wouldn’t normally have found myself. A book that, if I heard it described, I wouldn’t even realize that I’d love it. I owe all the credit in the world to BookishFirst for introducing me to this book. I read an excerpt and I was immediately pulled into the story. Unfortunately I didn’t win the book which meant that I had to wait till it was actually released to read it. I’m so glad I found it, it was amazing.

If you hear the description and think maybe it’s not for you, read an excerpt somewhere and see if the same thing happens to you.

This book was heavy and dealt with some very dark issues that I normally shy away from reading about. But none of them were done in excessive detail and I’m grateful for that.

Now, on to the story.
Sal (I’m sticking with the shortened version of his name or I’ll have to change it on autocorrect) and Noor met when they were little children.
This story tells their story and also Sal’s mother’s story which starts in Pakistan.

Sal’s mother has just died. She meant the world to Sal and also to Noor. She loved. Or like she was her own daughter. When she dies, she mentions forgiveness. Noor sees it as asking Noor to forgive Sal after their big fight. They haven’t talked in the past year,
Noor immediately allows Sal back into her life and offers him all the support that she can.
Sal is in so far over his head. His dad is an alcoholic and they are very close to losing the motel that his mother poured her love into. He’s also upset because his mom might have lived if she’d had the time or money to treat her illness.
Noor wants nothing more than to get into a good college very far away and to leave. But her controlling uncle forbids it. She felt indebted to him for so long because he literally saved her life when she was a child in Pakistan. He wound up raising her and blaming her for ruining his life.

As Sal and Noor reconnect he makes some decisions that could forever impact the future of both of their lives.

I know these are fictional characters but my heart just hurt for them. I so badly wished for happy endings for them.

What a story. I’m so glad I read it.

Why are the days not in order ?: [[VIDEOID:664848939b2e36a151264ca464ea109d]] I love the layout, the shiny pages, the feel of this book and the playful way the information is presented. My kids love to celebrate weird things so I expected this to be a perfect addition to our daily homeschool schedule. But I can't get past the fact the the days are not in order !

I can understand not writing something for every day on the calendar but the days are all out of order. So I have to search every day to see if 1) there is something for that day 2) where it is ? Otherwise I end up missing a day and finding it later in the month which gets very frustrating.

If I could re-do this almanac for 2023 I'd ask that they do the days in order and on the days they don't have an activity or a paragraph of fun , they at least wrote down " March 31st National Tater day" so you can follow along in the book correctly without missing anything.

Emotional and well written: Minah lives in NYC with her father. Minah is 16 and they moved several years back when things got bad with Minah’s mom. Her mom struggled with addiction. Minah hasn’t talked to her mom in years and has lost contact with her mom’s side of the family. The only one she still talks to his her “play cousin” (I’ve never heard this term but I love it, it’s someone you see like family but you’re not actually related to). Minah gets an invitation to her family reunion, the invite contains a heartbreaking surprise: it is in memory of Minah’s mom. Minah didn’t know her mom had died. She is furious and she confronts her dad. He admits that he didn’t know how to tell her when every mention of her mother only made Minah mad.
So Minah has to grapple with the fact that her mother has been gone for six months and nobody told her. She might also feel a bit conflicted about cutting contact with her mom’s family.
Her dad encourages her to go back for the family reunion if she feels like it would be good for her to do, and she decides to go.
I don’t want to give anything away by digging too much into the story about when Minah goes back for the reunion. I will say that she has to deal with her family, what they choose to tell her, what is the truth and how she feels about her relationship with her mother.
This book was super short but it was emotional and powerful. It will definitely bring a tear to your eye and get you choked up.
If I were to offer constructive criticism I felt like the epilogue was not totally necessary.
I also wanted to say that I liked the format of this book. I’m not going to spoil that either :)
I found this book because I read an excerpt on BookishFirst. Thankfully I think won an early copy of the book from BookishFirst because I was totally pulled into the story after reading the excerpt.
I’d definitely recommend this book. It’s not something I would have found on my own and I’m glad I read the excerpt and got pulled into the story.
