On the Horizon: Ahoy there me mateys!  This book is apparently a prequel to sea of rust that shows how the end of the world began (though it can be read as a standalone).  I thought this was set in a different world.  That said, I really did enjoy this novel.  I loved Pounce the nannybot tiger trying to figure out his purpose in life now that the humans and the robots are at war.  Is his concern for the boy Ezra an effect of his programming or his natural inclination?

The highlight of this book was the introduction to Pounce and the lead up to the beginning of the war.  I loved getting the story from Pounce's point of view.  I loved his relationships with the other robots.  I loved his relationship with Ezra and how Pounce deals with the harsh new truths of the world.  I loved Pounce's inner turmoil and questioning identify and purpose.

The big downside for me was that I was not as enamored with almost the entire journey through the suburbs.  There were some unprobeable coincidences. There were light references to current politics which I wish had been avoided.  Also the book seemed too fast paced with not enough real exploration of the enemy or the consequences of Pounce's actions.  The ending was also silly.

I do not regret this one but did like the other book better.  Arrr!

I received a copy from the publisher in exchange for me honest musings.

Walk the Plank On the Horizon: Ahoy there me mateys!  I was excited to read this novella around Halloween time.  The pros for this book were the concept and cover.  The cons were the execution and characters.  I didn't love the writing style as it was a bit purple prosy.  However, the major issue is that I actively disliked all the characters and thought they were selfish and immature.  I have no idea why they were friends at all.  There was too much focus on character backstory and not enough focus on the ghost bride.  I finished this one cause it was short but was bored.  So this one walks the plank!  Arrr!

I received a copy in exchange for me honest musings.

On the Horizon: Ahoy there me mateys!  This book was much better than the first!  This story follows Rosalind, who accidentally enters the time slip and lands in the 21st century leaving her husband and son in the past.  When she gets back to the past, she finds out that everyone believes she is dead.  Fate takes a hand by getting her a job as a governess to her son.  How can she convince her family that she is back especially when ghosts are afoot and someone wants the governess dead?

The first book's relationship problems could have been solved with some honest communication. I am glad there was less of that in book two. Both books require some heavy suspension of disbelief.  I was annoyed that how Rosalind survives her many years in the 21st century are skipped over.  I also thought how threads of the plot tied together in the end were hasty stitched together.

Overall though, I focused on the story being a silly fun melodrama with ghosts and let it be light entertainment.  I did enjoy the relationship between Rosalind and her son.  I enjoyed watching the husband realize his mistakes.  It was a fun read for halloween. Arrr!

I received a copy from the publisher in exchange for me honest musings.

On the Horizon: Ahoy there me mateys!  I am a huge fan of this author and love his work.  I was thrilled to hear about this new series.  The novel takes place in a dystopian England with a western flair.  Civilization is held in a loose collection of cities and the wilderness is a scary place of blighted landscapes and creatures.

At home in this wilderness is a gal named Scarlett who is wanted pretty much everywhere for robbery and assorted crimes.  She fierce and stubborn and awesome.  She happens to come across a boy named Albert Browne who is basically a walking accident waiting to happen.  He is sensitive and dreamy-eyed and never sees the danger even as it is about to eat him.  Against her better sense of self-preservation, Scarlett helps Browne.  Her world implodes and she just knows that boy is hiding something.

The best thing about this novel is the juxtaposition between Scarlet's sass and Browne's wishing to view the world at its best.  The banter and development of the relationship between the two is pure entertainment.  Then ye have the world itself with the dangers of both creatures and people alike.  I loved the world building and the characters even if there are more answers than questions.

I can't wait to find out more!  Arrr!

I received a copy from the publisher in exchange for me honest musings.

On the Horizon: Ahoy there me mateys!  This be the first book in the series and I will certainly be reading the next.  Ye follow triplet princesses who have been raised for espionage and deception.  At sixteen they are being married off to princes of neighboring kingdoms as the first step in their mother's plan to become Empress of the continent.  Though willing participants, each daughter finds unexpected circumstances in their new homes.  Can they survive without each other?  Do they want to?

The premise sounds quirky and that is why I wanted to read this.  There were problems with this book.  The sisters were at times hard to tell apart.  Despite their oh-so-amazing training, all three are naïve and don't seem to use many of the skills they supposedly know.  And the romance elements are very silly.  These things would usually be a deal breaker but I had a lot of fun nonetheless.

While the plot was quite over-the-top, I did enjoy the many curveballs that the author threw in from the very beginning.  I may have rolled me eyes a lot but I also rolled with the entertainment of it.  In fact, I didn't realize how long the book was until I had finished and looked up the page count.  I enjoyed the learning about the neighboring kingdoms and the star magic.  I really loved how the book ended and set up the future craziness.  I shouldn't have liked these book given me personal preferences but I was won over in the end.  Arrrr!  

Thank ye kindly Delacorte Press for the eArc!

On the Horizon: Ahoy there me mateys!  I really, really enjoyed three days in april by this author so was excited to read this one.  This novel follows Mickey who works as an expendable on a human colony.  Have a job on the colony where the end result is likely death?  Mickey is the solution.  If he dies, no problem.  A new body is made and a backup of his brain is installed.  Only Mickey isn't so thrilled because those memories include how he previously died and the emotions that went with it.

There is also the rule of only one expendable per colony as making new bodies uses precious resources in limited supply.  Mickey7 has experienced death 7 times.  Circumstances occur where he is supposed to die but doesn't.  Only Mickey8 is already baked.  Problems ensue.

I really loved the set up of the book and learning about both the colony and how Mickey found himself in his weird job.  I also loved how flashbacks were used in this novel to slowly give details of the prior versions of Mickey to enhance the story.  I did enjoy Mickey7.

The plot did end up being a bit of a let down in the end.  The middle of the book was kinda slow.  The sections of the two Mickeys in the same colony were unbelievable and poorly done.  Both 7 and 8 should have been caught immediately.  There was relationship angst that could have been interesting but felt more like a red herring.  Also the native creatures aspects of the colony planet were glossed over and simplified.  The resolution of all conflict and the ending of the book left much to be desired.

Most of this book didn't work for me but I don't regret reading it for the parts I did like and the concepts of the expendables' usage in establishing a new colony.  I would read more of the author's work in the future.  Arrrr!

I received a copy from the publisher in exchange for me honest musings.

On the Horizon: Ahoy there me mateys!  I love books about shipwrecks, ghost ships, and ghost stories.  So this was a must read for me.  And it was a lot of fun.  The story follows Claire Kovalik whose crew is on their final mission setting up communication equipment on the far edges of space.  They are about to head out when their ship receives a distress signal.  Nothing should be out here but they investigate and discover a luxury cruise liner, the Aurora, that went missing over 20 years ago with everyone on board long presumed dead.  Why is it so far off course?  The crew wants to claim the ship for salvage and fame.  They don't get what they expect.

I really loved Claire.  She is an unreliable narrator due to past trauma.  Are Claire's ghosts in her head or literal?  I thought the structure of the novel set this up so nicely in that ye start in the present with Claire in hospital, go back into the past, and then get caught back up to the present before moving forward.  I was kept guessing the entire time about both Claire's mental state and if she even understood what the truth was.  It could be frustrating to many readers because not everything is answered.  I, however, thought it keep the tension strung out nicely.

I also thought the horror of the state of the bodies was creepy and fun.  How folks ended up dead was excellent even if the why of it ended up being a minor weak part for me.  That said, I loved the company's attempted cover up and how the plot resolved.  Aye, ye have to suspend disbelief a bit (especially for the final chapters of the book) but it was a fast paced read that I didn't want to put down.  I am so glad to have read this one.

I received a copy from the publisher in exchange for me honest musings.

On the Horizon: Ahoy there me mateys!  Horses were me first love before the sea stole me heart.  And I loved Iceland when I visited there.  So of course this novella was a must read.  And I truly enjoyed it.

This story is set in the 9th century and follows Eyvind of Eyri as he travels from Helmgard to Mongolia with a trading caravan.  Once there he finds sturdy horses and aims to bring them back to Iceland.  This is a slow paced journey that has the feeling of the parts of the Icelandic sagas that I have read.

The horses are in the later portion of the story but the main takeaway is Eyvind's journey and the people and different cultures he meets along the way.  I found Eyvind to be a thoughtful and lovely character.  There are evocative magical elements dealing with ghosts and other beliefs.  Overall the writing style was wonderful and loved it.  I just wish it had been a little longer because it ended too quickly.

I will certainly be trying more of this author's work.  Arrrr!

I received a copy from the publisher in exchange for me honest musings.

On the Horizon: Ahoy there me mateys!  I didn't think I needed to start any more series.  Well, I was wrong.  This was excellent.  This follows an Emperor's Justice, Vonvalt. As a Justice, Vonvalt is judge, jury, and executioner when necessary – with the help of a little bit of magic.  He travels a circuit to dispense justice.  Traveling with him is his clerk, Helena, and a guard, Bressinger.  Surprisingly the story is told from the perspective of Helena who is reminiscing at the end of her life.

The conflict of the story begins when Vonvalt makes a judgement in a small backwater town where an outlawed religion is in use.  His ruling is compassionate while being within the law and the cleric with them in incensed.  Later Vonvalt investigates a noblewoman's murder.  These stories intertwine and Helena relates how the world changed.

Helena is training with Vonalt with the idea that she will join the Justices.  However, she isn't so sure that she wants the job.  I loved Helena and Vonalt's relationship.  I also loved older Helena's commentary on her younger self.

It is hard to really explain the intricate plot and world building but I found it extraordinarily well done.  And I grew to love Helena and care about how Vonalt's choices are going to play out.  The ending was excellent.  I am very much looking forward to the next book.  Arrrr!

I received a copy from the publisher in exchange for me honest musings.

On the Horizon: I wanted to read this near-futuristic novella because it deals with the topic of an Universal Basic Income ("UBI") in the United States.  The idea is that on January 15th, the U.S. government hands out the UBI payment to its citizens.  The novella follows four people who get their payments that day.

The author was clear in her forward that she would not get into the specifics of how the UBI was determined or how the programs worked and would focus on how it affected the characters.  I thought this was a sad choice especially given the research briefly mentioned.  I personally would have preferred a sci-fi work that dealt more with practicalities.  Though I get that a novella would make this hard.

But ultimately this was just an okay read.  It felt like a slice of life piece with no real point.  Was UBI good or bad?  I don't know.  How the UBI really impacted the character's lives was very lightly touched on.  It emotionally felt like UBI was being criticized for helping no one but with no real details.  So I don't actually know if that is what the author was trying to say. The complicated issue of UBI felt like a backdrop with no realism.  

Also, for me personally, I felt that the characters all felt very one-dimensional - not quite caricatures but close.  Pregnant teen cult member.  Mother dealing with domestic violence.  Bored rich college kid.  Activist turned journalist who is jaded about the policy she set into place.  The plot felt surface level because it takes place on one day and none of the plotlines resolve.

It was a quick read that I felt didn't do the topic justice even it I thought the concept was interesting.  Arrrr!

I received a copy from the publisher in exchange for me honest musings.

On the Horizon: The story begins with following Beth, who is a mess of a person.  If there is a bad choice, she will make it.  I had a hard time with the beginning of the novel because I didn't find Beth to be likeable at first.  I also didn't like the continuing analogy of her being a "car wreck."  I did find her job of house-sitting for the rich to be kind of fun.  Beth is bored and looking for trouble so she goes to seduce the neighbor, Mike.  But the one-night-stand happens to coincide with the end of the world.

Mike and Beth initially don't know what is going on because they were focused on other things.  I enjoyed that set-up.  The two (and the dog) go to the local beach to collect meteors that fell that night.  While there, they begin to learn what really happened and also end up trapped in the car.  For a story where the characters are stuck, I actually found a lot of tension and suspense.  Both the characters and the reader are learning as the day progresses and that was a lot of fun.  Plus I enjoyed the reason the world ended and how Beth and Mike deal with it.  The strangers have to rely on each other to survive.

There were some negatives.  Things do not go well for Jake the dog and really was the dog necessary?  He seemed added in to elicit sympathy and be a plot device.  Also a third character is thrown into the mix and that is where both the plot and especially the ending did not appeal to me.  The book is filled with unbelievable things that are still fun but when third character arrives, the unbelievability involving the human behavior is ratcheted up and I didn't like it.  It is personal preference though.  Others might enjoy that twist.  Oh and there is a random sex scene in the latter part of the book that could have been tossed out for the better.

Overall though, I really enjoyed the tension of being trapped in the car on a beach with otherworldly creatures.  The ending was vague and the characters seemed hopeful.  But I don't think things bode well for them.  Arrr!

I received a copy from the publisher in exchange for me honest musings.

Abandon Ship: Ahoy there mateys!  This book sounded cool cause dragons, diversity, and a male courtesan as a main character but just ended up not really working for me at all.  I abandoned this at 62%.  Most of this stemmed from said courtesan, Koré.  He is a angsty character who spends half the time talking about how badass his political acumen is and all the secrets he has stolen from his clients and the other half talking about what a horrible person he is and moping about how he is a monster from birth who needs vengeance against the man who created him.  And yet Koré doesn't seem to actually DO anything with these supposed secrets or try to actually manipulate to get revenge.  He seems to do a lot of posturing on both fronts without accomplishing anything.  I got tired of him and didn't care about him as a character.  The world building was also strange.  I had a hard time understanding how the city was actually set up and how the streets and districts worked.  It was an odd mix of drones, dinosaurs, dragons, magic, sci-fi and fantasy.  I usually like the blending but it came across as nonsensical, particularly once Koré switches districts.  And all the sex scenes felt written for shock value but were just boring.  Too many random elements in this book to do any of them justice.  Even the diversity was somehow made boring.  Arrr! Thanks to the publisher and NetGalley for the review copy.
Excellent: Great book, just like all of the Alex Cross books. I thought it started out a little slow, but once I got used to the back and forth of Bree and Alex it was amazing. Recommend it highly.

excellent as always: Love this series, I always preorder it when I first hear it is going into publication. Never disappoints.  Lindsay Boxer is a Wonder Woman. Joe is the best husband for her. Julie is funny and runs that household. Recommend this book highly.

review: excellent book: I love all Kendra and Jessie stories and this one did not disappoint. Recommend it highly. The Johansen’s always deliver.
Great book!: Lots of valuable information and great recipes
Great book: Crammed full of great recipes
Couldn't Put It Down: A compelling but brutal story that centers on the push-pull relationship of two sisters and their family. I almost read the entire book in one sitting.

Great escapism: Beautifully written; the weaving of the past with the present is masterful, all in all a deeply satisfying read. This type of war story is traditionally written for men, but as a female I quite enjoyed it. Read it at one sitting.
Great read: Very good book

Amazing: This story was witty, gritty, and sinful I'm all the right places. I love paranormal romance the most - they always keep me in the edge of my seat. This was no different. The characters were amazing, and even though this was the second book in the series I didn't feel like I was missing out on anything

4 Stars: This is my first book from Sharon Cameron but definitely won't be my last. Cameron does a fine job of shining light on a perspective rarely seen in the WW2 Historical Fiction genre. Told in alternating time lines, Eva's story is easy to follow but definitely hard to read about. For me, this was the first time I've read anything about the German children either left behind when their Nazi parents either died, escaped, or were brought to trial. Cameron makes Eva relatable and readers will find themselves rooting for this young woman as she comes to terms with who her parents and her country are. It was hard to put this book down, especially as Bluebird raced towards its ending as Eva reveals secrets that change her life.

**Bluebird is based on actual historic figures**

Amazing Debut!: A Day Like This is, hands down, one of my favorite books of the year. The story was well-plotted, easy to read, and left me wanting to restart it right away, which hasn't happened since I read The Time Travelers Wife. I loved the characters, especially Annie. I'm looking forward to this author's next book!

Great Start to a New Series: Wow! Country took me by surprise and I'm absolutely delighted. I've heard around the community how great Lila Rose's MC series were and you can add me as a fan.

Rose easily captures the family element I always look for when I read a MC romance and the fact she did so when I started the series (which IS book one in a new spinoff series) without having read about any of the other characters says it all.

Country and Dusty are wonderful, engaging characters that made me laugh (and tear up at least once). Their romance is sweet, which was unexpected, but believable considering who they are. I would have loved a little more development of their relationship, but Rose makes it work.

I'm a total MC romance snob and I can safely say this series and overall extended world is one that I'll definitely read more of!

Thank you to Social Butterfly PR and the author for an early copy in exchange for honest feedback.

Good read, good story: Good read, and very beautifully told, if such a thing could be said about the story of a serial killer. I enjoyed Chizmar’s glimpse into his childhood, one that sounded a lot like my own hometown.  LOVE the “true crime” way of telling this story.  Very enjoyable.

Boom.: I came into the trilogy longing for Abercrombie's earlier material, and was somewhat disappointed by the first installment (A Little Hatred). Not anymore. Wisdom of Crowds is one of my favorite novels in Abercrombie's collection, which is saying something. So much of the story resonates with current events, and the characters that seemed dull (to me at least) in A Little Hatred come to full life here (Rikke in particular). Many of the negative reviews bash Abercrombie for a perceived wokeness, pointing to his propping up of female characters, themes of sedition, etc. Whatever. This is a fantastic book by one of our great living writers.

Essential for the modern airpower scholar: This book is crucial as a go-to source for modern air to air combat in the post-Vietnam era. While it shouldn't be sole-source, it collects the first-hand accounts of the US aircrew who have fought and shot down adversary aircraft in the age dominated by Beyond Visual Range missile employment, the advent of Red Flag and other advanced tactical training, and the tremendous technological advances in the 1970s and 80s fighter aircraft programs. A fantastic complement to works such as Dick Anderegg's Sierra Hotel.

A sometimes overlooked Inkling classic: Excellent overview and adaptation of the Arthurian myths based on Mallory's version, and prepared for younger readers but not condescending or sanitized for them. I read this as a bedtime story for my daughter over the past several months, one chapter a night when we did bedtime stories. I used it as an opportunity to talk about history and myth with her, concepts like chivalry and the role of the Church. Reading aloud, I grew a keener appreciation for the depth of classical storytelling and how the literature built upon earlier stories and formed foundational elements of culture. The Arthurian stories truly are the "Matter of Britain," as they speak to the departure of Rome, the decline of Romano-British culture, the arrival of the Saxons, and interplay of the Britons and Celts across the ages. The way in which early Christian culture provided a sanctifying skein to a pagan past. Whether one likes old stories or not, one should at least be familiar with them, and take them as they are. RL Green's membership in The Inklings further informs the richness of this book. One note, the epilogue, which relates some of the voluminous folklore surrounding Arthur's death and return adds an eerie coda to the story, especially the final mini-story, almost included like an afterthought, but in many ways a miniature ghost story, a bit terrifying an apocalyptic in implication.

Start with the basics: Matthew Kelly is one of those writers talented and skilled enough to pack a lot of power and wisdom into short, pithy works. This book has a lot of correspondence to Stephen Pressfield's The War of Art, they even use the word "Resistance" to describe similar concepts. Kelly's book explores Catholic Christian themes to explore what happiness is, how one knows it, and how to properly orient one's own self to it. Spoiler alert: it doesn't come from putting yourself at the center of things. As short as it is, I do not recommend reading it in one setting, or even a few days. Reading one to three chapters a day, and taking the actual time to think and meditate on them, is the best way to approach it.

Changed my life: This book made such an impression on me, changed my complete outlook, gave me the strength and and comfort to go on each day. A very small book but packed with wise words from someone who’s been there and lived to tell her story. I hated for this book to end. I have stage 3 breast cancer which to me was a death sentence but her Faith inspired me and strengthened my resolve. I no longer fear and have a stronger brave outlook…. a path to my future. This book has many scriptures on healing and positive words of wisdom!! ❤️

A good read, good story.: I enjoyed reading this book.  It moves right along, the story captivates your attention.  The characters are believable.  I would recommend the kindle version as the binding broke apart into three sections and the cover came off.  Still, I kept on reading.
Love it: Offers one of our great conundrums- jobs today versus a poisoned planet tomorrow

It started like gangbusters and the ending fizzled out: The book started so good . I felt it was probably the best fiction book of the year. And the end spoiled it. All the characters were terrible people with the exception of the professor. The main character Theo you root for him until you don’t for good reasons, I won’t go into details. The ending reminded me of a writer running out of gas. Also, the author misleads us thinking something is happening in the present when it actually was in the past without any explanation.
The plot is this woman kills her husband and never speaks again. Theo the therapist seek her and tries to help her. And there twist and turns- and a surprise ending.

I was a little disappointed.: I had high expectations for Eight Perfect Murders. I read his book , Her Every Fear and I really liked it. This not so much, characters, plot or twist didn’t hook me. Once I found out the main character story sort of lost me. I finished it but I was disappointed.honestly I don’t think the author has the chops to pull it off. Keyshaw namesake of the Dodger pitcher has no vulnerability or liable traits- Gwen the FBI agent if she had more involvement even better be involved romantically with the main character- it would made it a tad more interesting. An opportunity lost. Read it and make up your own mind.

I would say not one of my favorite Reacher’s stories.: I’m a Michael Connelly fan of Bosch and I wanted to try Child’s Reacher series. This one is my fourth book in the series. Honestly, I speed read some of the ending. The plot of Reacher going undercover and pursuing  a villain that survives  prior attempts in his life and lived stretched the truth a little too much for me. The plot was not compelling, he sees his enemy who he thought he killed  and CIA  gets involved and asked him to rescue an agent that off the books that was captured. I don’t buy it and characters were not that interesting.  Hence, three stars.

I’m not going to lie, the book was a disappointment but it did have some useful nuggets..: The author Burgis has good stories of people who succeeded and failed. Most notably Zappo and Lamborghni of people who were successful and on Zappos founder Tony Hsieg who succeeded and fail in his experiments on create a downtown where happiness was the goal. We desire what others want without people realizing it. The scapegoat syndrome through history served it purpose on blaming others for your situation and a way to unite people with a common enemy - the solitary for people to determine what they want and why. I like the example of imagine you on your death bed and you have to make a decision in your mind’s eye when gives you joy and which one doesn’t. The appendix was good with examples on motivation and why you did what you did- it usually involved others approvals. Because of this book , I ordered , Steal like an Artist book by Austin Kleon..
I’ll end it with what Burgis said,: what did we want in the past? what do we want now? and what do we want in the future? and most importantly Why?

Good book: Short and sweet. Takeaway -everyone steals. The trick is who do you steal from and what are you stealing. Another takeaway is  study your hero, then study his/her 3 heroes. Highly recommended.

Is a fable that has many lessons for everyone: In reading an article in Sports Illustrated about Ja Morant, NBA super star- he was told by his coach to read “Win in the Dark”. I bought it and just finished reading. Is about a young man dreaming of becoming a high-line walkers, those brave souls that walk tightrope above cities.
His grandpa a professional high line walker and teacher- teaches Nico the basics. My takeaways are in the dark when you grinding and there’s no one there to praise you- where the real work is done. The buffaloes run into the storm, be like the buffaloes, expect setbacks, do like the Navy Seals, visualizing trouble and see how you defeat it. And spoiler alert: letters for each occasion. That was touching.

wonderful: I loved this book!
I loved the setting. The atmosphere in this book was absolutely wonderful. I was worried at first that Tate was going to be a stuck up rich guy but I am so glad I was wrong. I am so glad that he was caring after all. Annalise’s character is beautiful! It takes a lot to raise kids and she did it without hesitation. It was nice to see that she was still able to be at Farm. I could sense what was becoming of her and Tate not long after they starting decorating the trees. The Sheridan family is a wonderful family. I was so glad to see them all come together for the farewell to Wallace.

Debbie does it again!: I absolutely love Debbie Macomber! All of her books have been a huge hit for me!

Dear Santa was such a loving and cozy story. Lindys character is such a sweet soul. I love that she reconnected with her childhood friend and found love that she truly deserves

Love this little book!: I really like the written explanation giving the reader a good beginning synopsis of Tai chi  Then the actual Tai chi moves are clearly explained and demonstrated thru drawings. Very easy to follow and can be worked into any exercise routine you might be doing!

Amazing, heart warming book: Love the snippets of breath prayers including the initial instructions in how to breathe my way thru all the activities of my day.  Love the simplicity and ease I feel using her prompts and suggestions.  Each breath carries a prayer making activity even the most mundane, so meaningful.

classic fantasy story: I read all the Pern books 30 years ago and greatly enjoyed them.  Now I'm buying them for grand nephews.  This was a gift for a 14 year old.  I hope he enjoys it as much as I did.
giftable: I read this series several years ago and enjoyed it.  Now I'm gifting it to my 14 year old great nephew.  I hope he enjoys it as much as I did.

A fun twist on the Robin Hood legend: I read this book when it was first published and I was working in a locally owned book store.  I've given it as gifts to nephews and nieces in the intervening years.  Now it is being given as another gift for a friend's teen aged son.  I hope he'll enjoy it as much as my nephews, niece, and I did.

gift for a precocious 8 year old: This is a tremendously fun story of an adventurous tomboy.  I'm giving it as a gift to my great niece.  I hope it captivates her as much as it did me on my first reading of it in the 1980s when I was studying to become a teacher.
timeless classic: I first read this, my very favorite E.B. White book, when I was 9 years old in the early 1970s.  Now I'm giving it to my great niece.  I hope she loves it as much as I did.

gripping tale: Island of the Blue Dolphins was the first book I ever bought for myself not through a book club order form.  (The first book I bought for myself was The Story of Ferdinand, which I bought the year before from a book club order form.)  I bought Island of the Blue Dolphins when I was 8 years old, at a PTA book fair.  The story is a compelling one of not just survival, but unlikely friendships, isolation, fear, grief, bravery, perseverance, and ingenuity.  I reread my original copy so many times the covers fell off and the pages fell out.  Now I'm buying it for my 8 year old great niece.  I hope she loves it as much as I did.

beautiful illustrations: The illustrations are gorgeous.  The nursery rhymes a slightly different variations of the ones I'm most familiar with.  The only negative is that the book has a bit of a musty odor.  That's often the case with used books, though.  I bought it as a gift for a 4-year-old who has a new sibling.  She sat down and read it with her mom right away and was very engaged.

classic: My brothers and I discovered this book in our school library when we were children.  We chortled over it and re-read it many times.  So glad I can still find it in print to give as gifts to children 50+ years later!
I love crosswords: The only thing I didn't like was not enough puzzles in one book.:)
Fun read: Always like Agatha Christie mysteries. Fun and often keep you guessing but doesn't bog you down like longer more detailed stories.

of most interest for physicists: I enjoyed this book because I am familiar with and have studied details in mathematics of quantum theory.  I expect the first half of the book is too obscure for the layman, while it is perfectly clear to someone like myself with a PhD in physics.  The second half is interesting for individuals who had the opportunity to work with some of the principals that are discussed, viz. Bethe, Teller, Ulam.
Her recipes are easy to follow: I watch her YouTube channel and I decided to purchase her cookbook. Her recipes are easy to follow. She is very down to earth, and her recipes are down home.
A truly great read!!: If you like crime stories then you can't go wrong with any and all of Connelly's stories!!!

2021: Turns out it WASN'T MOLD, and...: ...Julie ended up having (controversial) surgery for cranio-cervical instability in early 2021, followed by 2 more surgeries after that didn't work, this time for 'tethered cord syndrome', by an even more controversial doctor.

She's apparently recovering from that, but recently said on Facebook that "The past four years in particular have been utterly brutal."

So it wasn't mold after all, and running away from it, doing all the things she claimed to have helped her, DIDN'T. Not in the least.

Whatever you do, don't fall for this book. It's not science based at all...

OK story, cheap printing, weak illustrations...: The story was okay, some of the poetry quite effective. Not sure where people are getting the notion that this is a story about resiliency. It's more about coming together, helping each other out. After all, the tree comes back to life after a boy brings soil and other nourishment to help it after a damaging storm. It had nothing to do with resiliency.

I was more disappointed though in the publisher's choice to print this on thin paper, and also it's rather awkward layout -- where often the story doesn't have anything to do with the illustration on the page. And speaking of illustrations, that's the weakest part of the book. As you can see from the photos, the colors are drab throughout, the drawings themselves are tenative and sketchy, rather than bold and interesting.

Hopefully if it's reprinted, they'll correct these weaknesses.

HORRIBLY OUTDATED...: This book was first published FORTY-TWO YEARS ago, and the last printing (11th edition) in 1999.

Almost everything is out of date, and WAS out of date back in 1999. As a result, there are literally dozens of erroneous 'rules' in this dry 'guide' that haven't been followed in years.

Don't waste your money. There are much better books out there. And even better, read some real scripts from recent films. Many of them can be found online. You'll learn a lot more from them than this antiquated mess.

RIDICULOUS beyond belief...: Okay, I'll admit I should've paid more attention before I hit the order button, but I thought that this was an address/phone book -- AND a book for internet passwords. But it's just an 'Internet Address and Password' book.

Who in the h-e-double-toothpick needs a book just for their internet passwords? One of the other reviewers mentioned that it has "plenty of room for all your pass words". Well yeah, and plenty of room for your ENTIRE NEIGHBORHOOD'S passwords as well!

If anyone needs a book to contain their internet passwords, perhaps the problem is they have WAY too many passwords? It's just a ridiculous, nonsensical product.

2nd book by Annie’s Quilts: I was so impressed by the 1st book I ordered by Annie’s Quilting for beginners that I purchased this one - and it did NOT disappoint!  Okay so there aren’t oodles of patterns in either book but it is certainly a great one for beginners. My daughter, who has never done a piece quilt was excited because the instructions were simple and understandable, with photos and diagrams. The first book had patterns using jelly rolls. This one leans more toward Fat Quarters and a couple of pattern for other projects like table runners. Anyway you can let your imagination run wild with you own color choices. A great manual for beginners - you won’t regret it!

Love Annie’s Quilting Books!: Great for beginners like my eldest who wants to get into quilting. Don’t expect a lot of patterns but what Annie’s has is understandable patterns and instructions…but I love the series of Annie books!

Not just for children: Great book for beginners like my married daughter. Don’t expect a lot of patterns but what Annie’s has is understandable patterns and instructions…but I love the series of Annie books!
Great for beginners: Don’t expect a lot of patterns but it has understandable patterns and instructions 😉
Haven’t read it yet but…: Was a 1st Edition which is what I wanted 😉
Saw all the movies but never read the book: It really is a great read. You should read it!

If you “eat with your eyes” this book isn’t the one for you: Unlike Cook’s County which has photos of each dish, this book lacks that appeal.

Pros: There are a lot of recipes and it has pretty good step by step directions
Cons: Many of the recipes aren’t ones that would appeal to the average person throwing a meal together.

Most of us just want to throw things from our refrigerator and cupboards together. I am glad I now have recipes for those meals I want experiment with for special nights but I also wanted easy “any day” meals - and pictures to eat with my eyes. This book fell just a bit short.
Love it, Love it, Love it!: Pictures with each recipe (I “eat with my eyes”), they are easy to follow and most are recipes that use ingredients one has in their kitchen
Another Excellent novel by John Gray!: This second novel by John Gray is excellent!  Great read that holds your attention and has a beautiful message.  Looking forward to Chasing Italy next year!

Good read: I really enjoyed this book as I have enjoyed the whole series however there were a few unanswered questions that were not addressed by the end of the book hopefully they will be answered in the next one

No videos that follow the workout plan and days: The book is very comprehensive, and so is the website.  However, when putting together a plan and following it you have to keep turning to the pages to follow the exercises so it’s not consistent. There really should be a set of videos that follow the plan, like for beginner or beginner/active. Etc.  there are a few actually full videos on you tube, but they don’t follow your plan and there is only one of each level.  Lots of informative videos how to do a particular exercise, but they are only a few minutes long.  I would purchase a set of videos that follow my plan, and even as I move from beginner/active to the next level.  That would be great.

I have the mini version and the full size is on my wishlist!: A few things. I have this deck but the mini version. I adore it. The deck is a dark deck in it's imagery but so rich with it's symbolism. I did see a reviewer/Reader who said these aren't great to photograph and I can see that I have the same issue with my Revelations Tarot by Zach Wong . I did find the app on Foolsdog for this deck and my Revelations one and it's so awesome in my opinion and I too photograph my decks for Sitters readings. I put my images in the body of the document of my readings; card image, interpretation, repeat however many times, summary.

Bought at a used bookstore but reviewing here: As my heading says, I bought this set at a used bookstore.

Pros: nice box set, sturdy box, nice thick cardstock, *larger cards, *beautiful artwork, full color guidebook

Cons: Air and Fire are switched. So if you are like me; Pentacles = Earth, Cups = Water, Wands = Fire, Swords = Air....you're head may feel a bit twisted up! In this deck the suit of Air = Wands, Fire = Swords. Another thing is that you look at some of the images they don't seem to make sense for the card they should represent.

Overall: This isn't a beginners deck. Even someone who's got decades of experience may find themselves scratching their heads. *The larger cards are nice but I have larger hands. Someone with smaller hands may find them difficult to shuffle. *The artwork is indeed beautiful but it is confusing and you may find it's not easy to switch your brain on the Air and Fire thing. If the art had more visual cues I think that would help me personally wrap my brain around the switch.

These cards have no reverse meanings but if you read upright and reverse like I do that's easy enough to work with. Like I have said the hardest part is getting your brain from knowing things one way for decades for some of us to switching it up for one deck . You'll get it but it'll take some time. I actually wrote the suits on the inside cover of the box my cards were in.

Thin card stock nice Majors, rest are pips, nice presentation: I waited for 7 months for this deck after my preorder and when it arrived I was a kid on Christmas. However immediately after I opened the deck up I was so tremendously let down. The cardstock is awful the Majors are nice and the rest of the cards are pips which is fine, not ideal as I prefer the RWS style. After waiting so long and finally getting my hands on this deck it was a big deflate for me. I purchased sleeves for the deck and that made it worse not better. Now the deck is protected...yay....it has some sturdiness to it....yay....but it's now twice the size, it doesn't fit into the box properly, and because it's all sleeved it's a pain to shuffle and slips and slides all over so it's wash shuffle only. I don't even use this deck...I paid $21 for this and it's now out of the return window. I held onto it hoping I could connect to the deck or figure a good solutions out as I am a Labyrinth fan...but it's now in a box behind another deck.

I am not a collector who buys decks to just have I buy them to use them. This one is not a usable deck in my opinion because of the cardstock as is and now because the sleeves I had to put over the cards.

More than bad/swear/curse words. Totally inappropriate for kids and teens or more polite types: Soooooo if you want this for a teen or something DO NOT BUY THIS!

If you want this as a gift …KNOW YOUR AUDIENCE

If you want this for yourself BE READY FOR OBSCENE LANGUAGE

I am personally not offended by this journal at all and if the language upsets you don’t buy this.

I like how it ends on a positive note like once the rage is out you’re able to now see positive.

I love the extra thick cardstock!: I love everything about this deck and would not change it at all. I read the reviews about the cardstock being too thick and personally I think it is so perfect for me. My cards are meant to be workhorses and handle riffle shuffles and wash shuffles. This deck can handle it! I don't like the thinner cardstock personally because it's easier to bend and mar your lighter stock decks.

I am allll about the artwork and it really does follow the RWS so if that's your style like it's mine...I can easily read these cards. The guidebook is fun and well thought out. I love the little bits of song references sprinkled in there. If you were a teen or preteen even in the 80s early 90s you will get the references and find humor in that. The presentation is beautiful and I love the thought and details of the deck. I would not change a thing about any of it.

I don't personally suggest this to a new to reading all together Reader but if it resonates it resonates. That's the most important thing. For me personally I suggest learning on a regular standard RWS deck before getting into other decks. Even this one as much as I love it and love working with it.
Great story: Cool story with a twist ending. Definitely recommend.
Kid loved it: Worth the money

More clutter: I don't know how to review this. On one hand, the book seems to find itself in all different places, looking like clutter and reminding me that I haven't done anything yet.

On the other hand, the tips are really good. It's a mix of "be nice to yourself" and "get sht done, already", which is always pleasant.

I'll update my review when I start implementation, but I feel confident this is a five star book.

A MUST READ!!: I consider myself a fair student of history, and I found this book to be the most complete and definitive analysis via the eyes of Lincoln and Douglass as to what the Civil War really was about. Some scholars like to say it was about states rights, but this book completely debunks that notion. Very very well written and it gives new insight into the personality of Lincoln and Douglass. They should be on the bookshelves of every school library!
Great book: Loved this book well written and engaging story. Hard to put the book down. Easy to see why it is an award winner

Excellent way to start a day!: This is the fifth or sixth year in a row buying this calendar, and while the daily items are as good as ever, the cheap, flimsy "stand" required to keep this thing upright on my desk SUCKS!  It is so poorly designed the calendar continually falls over.  It seems like every year they make the stand design WORSE!  Come on, guys... quit making the stand part on these calendars so flimsy and cheap!
Didn't finish it: Too many really SILLY characters, goofy story, nothing to keep me reading it, so I didn't. I'll look for a better book to read.

There is a 2-3 pages on Housebreaking....: I like the author and enjoyed his sat am shows. However I bought this book- mainly for HOUSEBREAKING and nothing else! I've had Chihuahuas over the years a very difficult breed to housebreak but it can and was done. I was given a RESCUE; a 7 lb terrier. smart as a whip but one thing she rarely does is do her business; both outside the house! I have a 14 yr old Chi; who she refuses to follow when i let her out ; both of them in the fenced yard area. I have tried everything and it'sgetting old..
I love her; sweet and charming and smart but not on housebreaking...

Fantastic Book: Robert Pavlis shows in Soil Science for Gardeners the complexity of life living in our gardens. Without an understanding of this ecosystem we are pawns for the marketing departments of fertilizer companies. This book motivated me to send off soil samples for testing at our state university's soil lab. The results were very informative. I now have the necessary information to correct the pH imbalance and add only the missing nutrients - nitrogen and a bit of potash. I'm no longer just guessing or blindly following a fertilization routine.

I can't praise Robert's books enough. Soil Science and Garden Myths 1 & 2 are full of practical advice based on science and common sense. Simply the best.

Excellent read for adult and teen: I bought this for my granddaughter so that she would understand that the world is not as easy to live in as where she is. The story also showed the thoughtfulness and courage of the young author and my granddaughter and I had excellent conversation about life, history, human decency, survival, and our good fortune to not have lived as Malala did. We discussed her courage and her fortitude in documenting her life experience and I believe my granddaughter has new understanding of what those terms mean. I recommend it for teens, so that they gain a global perspective of how others live and need the courage to face each day.
The versatility of style: My granddaughter found this an easy guide and the way to draw clothing to be the most helpful.

It may have just been mine (it happened with another design in the past), but it was a distracting.  Overall, I do recommend these journals, but this cover just didn't work for me.

Only tried one recipe so far from this book, and it has an error: I am new to using an Instant Pot, so need very clear (and correct) recipes until I'm used to settings, etc. The recipe I tried from this book is the Saturday Afternoon Meatloaf recipe (I was in the mood for meatloaf). I pulled out and measured out all the ingredients since the recipe doesn't require any pre-cooking like a sautee of the onions. I realized as I got to the point of putting the meatloaf in the pot, that the last 4 ingredients in the list were not included in any part of the recipe except for the list of ingredients. I handed the book to my husband as a kind of "I'm not crazy" check. Nope. So, I winged it and combined them, and poured it on top of the meatloaf before putting it in the pot. The recipe was tasty and certainly moist, although I think there was too much liquid in the mixture because it didn't want to hold together. The meatloaf also wasn't cooked completely in the middle, even after cooking for the allotted time and resting for 10 more minutes, so I'm not sure if the problem is the timing in the recipe, or the recipe itself since I'm an Instant Pot newbie.

I hate reviews that say it's "laugh out loud" funny, but....: I really did laugh out loud at parts of this book.  So well written and the characters are such idiots (the author's term) and so funny!  What a great, and fast, story!  Excellent writing.
You just never know!: Each chapter is so funny and each chapter is different from the last chapter.  Great writing and timing.  Anytime I need a laugh, I'm into this book.  Never lets me down.
Never: So very scary!!! And also very possible in the world of nuclear power!  There are no easy answers....the end of life as we know it.

Great Starter Book on Weaving -- for Children and Adults!: This is a very cute book that covers many aspects of weaving! Although it is geared towards children, as an adult, I found that it had a lot of interesting information about various types of weaving that was quite helpful for my own weaving. In addition, there are lots of great pictures throughout the book that illustrate the various types of weaving found throughout the world. The book also covers introductory projects for the would be weaver, starting with simple projects involving weaving paper. The projects become progressively more complicated as the book goes on. Among other things, some of projects including basic tapestry weaving, basket weaving, bead weaving, and weaving kumihimo braids. There is also a section on building simple frame and bead looms! A nice book for sparking ideas forweavers of all ages!

I love dogs, and these Dachshunds are adorable and hilarious! My reluctant reader enjoyed reading this book: Funny age appropriate jokes.  I had a luttle girl who did not want to read because she did not learn her sight words like her twin did.  This book got her started and she could not wait to read jokes to her audience.  From here were went on to Silly Milly which she read aloud to her entire class.  Noyhing like a joke to get you started.

Elegant, timely, tremendously frightening: I was worried when my favorite novelist paired up with a politician to write a thriller. I shouldn't have been. Reading these pages brought me closer to each woman, I felt, in a way I never could be otherwise. To see into the inner workings of the White House, the inner thoughts of a female Secretary of State, has been a fascinating journey. And then, to also run into, in these pages, some of my all-time best beloved fictional characters! Fantastic!

Pretty darned good: This surprised me! As a writer, I hate poorly written books, and except for one chapter wherein the names were mixed up, this one is not at all bad. I'm not a romance fan, (well, in my own life it's great, but I don't read the genre) but loved the title, and you know what? I actually was very pleasantly surprised. Pick up this book for a fun holiday book.

Hilarious! Highly recommend: I’ve never laughed so hard with my grandkids over a book. I’m not kidding. They showed me their copy when I was at their home one day visiting, and we sat down and read through it cover to cover. It’s hysterical! We were all in stitches. I’m laughing as I write this. Very clever writing and great graphics. I’ve bought my own copy so we can read it at my home too. Highly recommend!!

It is wonderfully written, tons of beautiful photographs, and so much information that it will become your number #1 reference book!  Great Holiday Gift for the Gardener or Cook! Highly Recommend!

Very Well Written: This book tells you everything you could want to know about the boys PS it has lots of pictures
Disappointed: I expected a book about the elite of those times Instead I got a discourse on social ills More suited as a text book
D day: This book is the definition of D Day it details both sides
Chase  laugh chase laugh repeat.: One long chase. From beginning to end. All the way through. And so it is!  Lizzy and Diesel rock rocks.
Great recipes: Fun and yummy recipes. But on the lighter side. I have made 3 dinners already.

Didn't have a catch: I love reading and read nightly for many hours. This book bored me so much I fell asleep reading it. The mystery was more misery. I don't like giving up on a book but had to quit this one. There wasn't a catch. It had a boring premise and no mystery. I kept saying "give a chance".  I waited. And waited. And waited. Oh well, off to find a new read.
Terrific Book for Little Ones: This was a gift for my great grandson, ad I'm sure he loved it.

Inspiring story of a Polish woman in the Holocaust who risked her life to save Jewish refugees.: This is the story of Irene Gut Opdyke. She was in nursing school when Germany invaded Poland in 1939. From that point on until about ten years later, her life was about survival and her attempts to get back home to her family. In the midst of her attempt to save herself she also chose to risk her life to save 12 Jewish refugees, by hiding them under the nose of a German officer. Tyranny was all around her. I was amazed at her courage. Her story is verified as she has been added to the roles of Righteous Among the Nations. (Her story had to be corroborated by eyewitnesses.) Even more startling was her young age. She started her saga at the age of 17. Her courage is inspiring. One more thing. The author who wrote the book for her, Jennifer Armstrong, did a great job. She created the tension that was necessary to tell the true story. But she had a way of easing into the most horrific parts of the story. Horror needs to be disclosed for sure. But for the purpose of this book, I think Jennifer Armstrong and Irene Gut Opdyke gave us only what we needed. Some people might have put down the book had it been too graphic. This writer is grateful for the treatment by the author. We have enough bad and horrible news in the world at this writing.

Beautiful pictures: Full of fall images that are very pretty. There are a variety of pages so it’s easy to find something to color. I don’t really like the Amazon print paper but it works well with markers and if I want to use color pencils I print the picture off on my own paper but that is just personal preference.
The translations are off: Missing the "I/Watashi" example for many of the examples. Not helpful for beginners. It's just good for hiragana practice.
Beautiful: I have always had an interest in aspergers. So it was interesting learning about the opposite of it. First book I truly was excited by in years.

The Complete Air Fryer Cookbook: This book has a few recipes, a conversion chart that converts "C" to "F", and that's about it. I was looking for a book that would give some information about temp settings and the different settings needed to use for an air fryer compared to standard cooking or oven settings and times. Not in this book. Not worth the trouble to send it back so it will just take up space until I throw it away.

Meh: First off, what’s with all the parentheses?  Second, the plot is pretty easy to figure out not even halfway into the book.  The main characters are boring and unlikeable.  But to mention stupid because Jake never figured it out but had to be told.  All in all disappointing.  Do these people understand the meaning of “plagiarism?”  Apparently not.  Don’t waste your time.

Boring: The relationship between the two characters is just so bad that I cannot imagine mourning the loss of this guy.  He’s clearly an idiot and it’s hard for me to understand why any normal, attractive woman  would settle for this guy and be upset at the ending of the relationship fir weeks on end.

Not her best: So it’s hard to write a review about a mystery without giving away the ending.  This was a page turner until the last 60 pages or so.  Page after page of the main characters trying to escape and the ending was so absolutely ridiculous I can’t believe it.  Like seriously bad.  And you don’t guess the killer because there are no clues at all til they actually reveal the killer.  Bad.  Bad. Bad.

review:
Some extraordinary lines: "The silk suit felt good against my skin. It eased the itch from the prison rash I had developed over most of my body. I sat quietly next to Jennifer Aronson at the defense table and savored the moment of pseudofreedom and relief."

My brain instantly read "pseudofreedom" as pseudophrine. If it was deliberate it is brilliant.

Connelly, Michael. The Law of Innocence: 6 (Mickey Haller) (p. 240). Little, Brown and Company. Kindle Edition.

review:
Even if you've read many books about WWII Poland, read this!: One line in this book really stood out for me.

"There will be an entire generation of children in this country who were forced upon their mothers, and the lucky ones will grow up in love just the same.”

Most historical novels about WWII contain rapes but I had never considered the possibility that with a generation of children either sent out of country or killed, many of the next generation would be conceived by rape. The author has done a more thorough job of telling the long lasting affect of war time rape that is frequently gang rape.

It's not that rape has a more dominant presence in this book, it's that the physical and emotional pain is not swept aside by the desperate struggle for survival.

review:
Don't read another book until you've read this one.: At the end of 2021 I chose this as one of the first of three books I consider the year's must reads. The same was true of Drawdown in 2017. I read the interim book but didn't find it as compelling as these two.

Four years between the two books does not seem like a lot of time when originally we were advised that we needed to drastically reduce our carbon output by 2050. Drawdown was published in 2017 less than 3 years since after the Kyoto Protocol was reached December 2014 (and formally adopted as the Paris Agreement December 2015.) In the interim scientists have advised global warming has accelerated and we have only until 2030.

The top 2 US newspapers started 2022 with articles documenting that 80% of the US population experienced climate disasters during 2021.

Regeneration is about the already known, tested, and immediately doable things that must be accomplished now. Regeneration also reports why we cannot look to carbon sequestration to achieve the reduction.

The one aspect I disagreed with is that individuals changing daily habits cannot achieve enough. I disagree because changes in demand can accelerate corporate and political response. Margaret Mead said "never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has."

review: Compelling but depressing: It's tough to review this without saying too much and spoiling the story. The world, and the US specifically as the leading force, must address nuclear weapons. The world has known longer than all but a tiny minority have been alive the danger. Politicians tried and totally failed to contain proliferation. Perhaps this book may help incite a worldwide movement.

Another excellent installment in the series: A wonderful, heartwarming series with each book centering on one character but still including the other three.  Four women make a huge change in their lives when Michelle is gifted a property in Florida.  I enjoy how each faces her particular issue and moves forward—not always smoothly—but strong women with one goal in mind—opening their Inn and  cafe.  This story centers on Erin and her ex-husband, but the focus is still on the progress towards opening the Inn.  I am absolutely enjoying following the progress of each relationship, the minor conflicts and problems that arise, how it all works together to make an entertaining read.  I highly recommend the entire series and am looking forward to book five.  I received an ARC copy for an honest review.

I’ve had a private reading from him: I had a private reading from Anthony Williams. I was on a wait list and got the call from someone from his camp quite quickly that I was 1st in line. I booked my $500 reading. This was when his book first came out. I was so excited.  I had believed in mediums and was an avid watcher of Long Island Medium & John Edward.  I had someone come take notes for me as we couldn’t record the conversation. It was done over the phone. Unfortunately, right away it seemed he was simply guessing things about me.  The disappointment kicked in quite quickly. He assumed I was young like 20’s. My voice sounds younger than my age (40’s).  The supplements he wanted me to take were the same supplements in the book.  I am intolerant to juicing unfortunately and had to stop. The reaction was similar to food poisoning (if you’ve ever had that) without the vomiting and he wanted me to juice. There was just a lot of guessing and zero he knew about me. Toward the end of the conversation I asked him if it could be my silicone breast implants causing me issues. He said no. Basically that they’re benign in the body and don’t cause issues. I was diagnosed with Lyme disease and he said it was EBV. I took all the supplements and brands he recommended but had zero improvement. The thing that really confirmed to me that he is a charlatan is that he is now advocating for breast implant illness when he told me that they cannot cause issues.

Good Coloring Book: I like this coloring book, but not as much as I thought I would. Many of the "models" are the same person wearing different dresses. Plus, I have an original Godey's Lady's Book from the Civil War era and there is more diversity in styles than are depicted in this book that would have been good to include.  Oh, well--it is an inexpensive coloring book and gives me pleasure to color in it.  What more could you ask for?

Good resource for applying humanist values: This is one of the best parenting books I've read.  Instead of one author, this is a compilation from multiple authors/experts.  I find myself coming back to this book as my child ages.

An entertaining tale that will keep the reader’s attention: MEET ME IN MAINE is an entertaining tale that will keep the reader’s attention. The story is told through the eyes of Elizabeth, who is fleeing an oppressive relationship. She and Scarlett, her best friend, move to Maine, where they purchase a Bed and Breakfast and immediately meet attractive, single, former military men, who are infatuated with the Inn’s new residents. Not expecting to be thrust into the center of a town whose residents have been cursed, Elizabeth and Scarlett are horrified to witness several grisly murders, one of which occurs on their first night in the new town. As the story unfolds, the murders pile up and paranormal activity becomes apparent in the plot.
Overall, the story line is a good one. The characters could have been better developed with more detail regarding their backgrounds. I would have preferred more in-depth conversation among them. The dialogue occasionally came across as stilted, and could have been expanded to express more emotion. But, that is personal preference.

A lesson in history, through the eyes of the ghosts who lived it: A GHOST AND HIS GOLD is a well-written novel, but also a lesson in history. The history teachers are ghosts. Shortly after Tom and Michelle move into a new home, events occur that cause Michelle to suspect that her house may be haunted. With the help of a Ouija Board, Michelle’s suspicions are confirmed. Estelle is the first to arrive. Traumatized at a young age, Estelle lived through a personal war and even in death was prepared to fight the enemy, real or imagined.
Soon two other spirits make their presence known. Each has a story to tell about the lives that they led, on different sides of a brutal South African war. Although the ghosts lived well over one-hundred years ago, the modern-day couple’s lives are dramatically impacted by what was learned as the stories of the ghosts’ experiences unfolded. Throughout the novel, the characters’ passion and emotions are effectively described and it brings them to life. The horrifying brutality of war is depicted in detail and is as difficult to read about as it is to imagine.
The author did a superb job of intertwining the past and the present and showing that people are not so different, even though they lived over one-hundred years apart.

A page turning story of power and passion.: TWO FACES OF JANUS is an engaging short story set in the time of the ancient Romans. The characters are well developed, the atmosphere and their sentiments are masterfully illustrated.

Following the instruction for Lucius to “…clean off the remnants of death…” he “… gaped in horror at the sight of the bright red bloodstains…” just before his encounter with Brigata. The emotion leaped from the pages. Examples of desire, revenge, devastation, love and friendship are woven throughout the story. I enjoyed the dialogue, which made the scenes come to life.

It is well-done prose that will delight fans of Roman mythology, students of Ancient Rome, and anyone who enjoys a page turning story of power and passion.

NOT DRAGONLANCE!!!!! VERY disappointing!: After waiting for 18 YEARS for Wizards of the Coast to (finally) publish another Dragonlance gaming module, and eagerly awaiting Fizban's Treasury of Dragons, I received....THIS...?!?

Fizban is called "Bahamat" instead of Paladine, NO mention of Krynn at all, and WORST of ALL...

NO 5e Gaming stats for a Dragonlance! (Okay, granted I haven't gone through the entire book yet, I'm still too angry at being deceived) but it looks like WoTC, after that hostile takeover by Hasbro, has royally screwed us again! I'm ready to return it.

If you loved Dragonlance....do NOT be deceived into buying this book!
