A View of History: Interesting tale of a young girl hired to be a part of Marie Antoinette’s ladies in waiting. Working for the queen prior to the French Revolution throws Giselle into a situation of divided loyalties. She meets Leon in the streets during a demonstration
that leads to her having to juggle being loyal to the queen while
pretending to be pro-revolution and Leon. An exciting read!

Enchanting Tale!: A beautiful tale of India and a mystery to be solved. Mair has
discovered a delicate Kashmir shawl among her grandmothers things.
So begins her journey to discover the history of the shawl and how
it found its way to her grandmother. Exciting locals, interactions between the British and the Indian citizens makes for intriguing
reading. Highly recommend this book!

Fun, Exciting Read!: Easy read for a summer afternoon. Nicola traveling in Crete happens upon a wounded British man and his companion on a mountain path.
So begins a tale of murder, intrigue, and trying to stay alive. Nicola
becomes enmeshed in the mystery of the small mountain village
and who is responsible for the violence and who can be trusted.
Great read: Book club pick & really enjoyed it. WW II historical based fiction. Well developed characters, good insights, & well written.
Excellent writing by C.S. Lewis and reading!: I liked everything about these books!

Predictably dreamy: A thousand+ reviewers have accurately informed you this is an absolutely gorgeous, truly lovely book. It is. I am not sure anyone with a pulse could disagree. The teeny fraction of 1-star reviews are only about receiving a damaged item or something negligent in delivery. Because no one could genuinely dislike this book. It's good and you should buy it. But one day I hope to find one better?

I, too, appreciate how lovingly this book was put together and the truly stellar photos you’ll want to immediately drink in (mainly the peony in close up shots, or in nature). But as a chick who has an edgy style, one who is not overly girlie-girl, I feel like the peony is almost always represented in photography in one single way: muted, washed out (but yet still sunny) and in dreamy DREAMY bridal bouquet-esque shots. Or against a shiplap wall, farmhouse chic. A blond child in a sundress, scampering the field in a peony crown… that sort of thing. Heavy with the pastels and neutrals. While this book looks to inform you on this luscious flower (it is not just a picture book), I would find it so very refreshing if a handful of pics could have included placing some peonies in a stark modern home, perhaps against garish colors or in the hands of, oh I hate to say an ‘alternative’ model, but just some kind of scene that doesn’t fit the typical fairydust trope. (Mind you, this book doesn’t feature humans, just the flowers. I’m merely stating it would have been awfully nice if they stepped out of the box for just a few pictures, considering there's a photo on nearly every page of a 200+ page book). The peony is uber feminine, I get that, and it’s my favorite flower of all time. But it can do so much more and I hope to one day find a book that showcases it in all the dimensions it deserves. I hate how predictable peony photography tends to be. The arrangements included here are so very “very* romantic. And that begins to feel awfully one-note, old fashioned. And ultimately that’s a bit how I found the (photography) in this book.

Superb text, poor pictures: Let’s get the downside over first. The quality of the color reproductions in this book ranges from poor to abysmal. They tend to be dark with the different colors subsumed into a khaki grey. This in sharp contrast to other books in this series (I have 7 or 8 of them) and indeed to the full-page details used as chapter headings in this one. I came to the Amazon page to see if my printing was perhaps an aberration so I could claim a replacement, but others have mentioned this too. Ah well, there is always the internet!

Susie Hodge’s text, however, is superb. It seems that the field of art history has changed dramatically since I was a university lecturer in the 1960s. The old focus on great artists, style periods, and the primacy of painting has given way to scholarship that emphasizes context, continuity, and the full range of artistic endeavor, making no distinction between “fine” and applied art. All the Oxford books in this series that I have bought recently follow this view, but Susie Hodges writes the most coherent and understandable rationale for it, in a style that is immediately relatable and gripping

Context? You bet! This book tells you more about the purpose, production, technique, and economy of the arts than you would believe possible. And somehow Hodges manages to delve into lesser-known aspects and supporting detail without ever slighting the giants of the period like Van Eyck, Campin, Van der Weyden, or Memling. Most amazing of all, she manages to make one forget the model of Florentine progress to Renaissance Perfection that people of my generation all learnt, and convince one instead that it is NORTH of the Alps where it is really happening!

history: B005GT0LZE B0076Q1GW2 B00AFKIRH8 B0089LOE3Q B00AMOOBJU B00DPM7TIG B079DXLLPC
review: Carl Hiaasen...what more need I say?: Typical Carl Hiaasen, funny, irreverent, with a biting edge. I'm a long-time Hiaasen fan. When I either purchase or rent one of his books, I expect an evening of sheer entertainment. He's never disappointed me.

history: B005GT0LZE B0076Q1GW2 B00AFKIRH8 B0089LOE3Q B00AMOOBJU B00DPM7TIG B079DXLLPC B003Z9KFEO
review: Not about Paula: I agree with many of the other reviewers. I did not finish this book. Paula is basically a peripheral character around whom the author weaves her own philosophies and political beliefs. Actually, I pretty much agree with her points, but that's not why I downloaded this book.  I don't read for validation of my beliefs. Too much "I", "me", etc.

Good not great: After reading Blacktop Wasteland earlier this year I jumped on this.  It was very good but got a little too gratuitous with the violence late in the book. I also felt the fact each father came to grips with the son's being gay a little too convenient.  All in all though a good read.  I'll read anything this dude writes.

Boring and blah: My first book by the author.  Started well, but eventually bogged down.  Ridiculous subplot of widower who is in love with the protagonist, which of course meant the husband would die by the end.  Rape and revenge porn are horrible things but the way they are presented in this book is over the top.  It almost seemed that the author was using herself as the model for the heroine.  How many times were we told that the heroine's acting past was integral to her ability to deal with the issues she was facing? Then I read in the author's blurb that she was an actress.  Don't waste your time.

Better than her most recent two books: I've read all of her books and was disappointed with the last two.  That's ok; a writer with her track record can afford a couple of duds.  But she came roaring back with Apples Never Fall.  One of the best things about her books is the way she can create characters that seem very real due to her knack of incorporating elements in these people that seem familiar to the reader, like we know them or someone like them.  She stretches that skill a tad too far in this book, yet it still all works.  Liane - you keep writing 'em and we'll keep reading 'em.

Wow: Picked this up at the local library on a whim.  Had never heard of it or the author, but the blurb on the back sounded interesting.  The issue I normally would have with any kind of supernatural element to a book is that it allows the author to have their characters do anything, for the supernatural aspect absolves all sins.  But the use of Finn as someone dead leading us on this journey of her family and friends was brilliant.  I wouldn't have changed one single thing in this book.

Don't bother with the negative reviews: Roper's first book was great, and this one is just as good.  Great bits of humor sprinkled about while maintaining a sort of dignity over the entire arc.  He makes you feel as if his characters are real people, people you've known, all of whom are flawed but maintain the capacity for compassion and forgiveness.  I cried at the end of this book.  What a great writer.
Messy: My first and last book by this author. This is a predictable story with little tension or mystery. Won't go into the weak plot, as I'd lose interest trying to describe.

Great read - and the first of three: Loved this noir-ish story of a dirty cop and multiple bad guys.  Got this from the local library without any knowledge of it - I judged it based on the awesome cover.  Can't wait to read the next two.

Great read: This was my first by the author and I immediately checked out his prior work from the library.  For this was so well written, so well structured and compelling that I'm shocked I'd never heard of him before. He shows humanity in these characters without hitting us over the head.

Curse you, Don Winslow: I've read almost everything Winslow has written, and this latest work is about as good as anything he's done.  Knowing it's the first of a trilogy tells me he's taking his time with the main character (Danny Ryan), knowing we'll be sucked in to anxiously await books two & three.  So curse you Don Winslow - I want them NOW!!
I'm being generous: Bloated, far too complicated and just not that interesting.  It's somewhat ironic how desperately a book with a protagonist who is an editor, needs an editor.

Mystery With a History Lesson: Although I’d never read any of the other books in this series of mysteries that take place near the Wind River, I had no trouble immersing myself in the lives of Father John and Arapaho lawyer Vicky Holden. A Custer impersonator, Edward Garrett, is killed during a parade in the town of Lander, Wyoming, and suspicion falls on two of the young Arapaho men who took part in a dare ride around Garrett and the men impersonating two of his lieutenants. It’s up to Father John and Vicky to clear the names of the suspects by finding the real killer. The story is well-written, and the characters are fleshed out. The author has done her research on Custer and weaves what happened at the Little Big Horn and in Washita deftly into the story.

Weird and Wonderful: Very interesting book. Two stories told alternately, each in a different setting. The unnamed protagonist of the story set a modern Japanese city has more fantastical adventures even than the also unnamed protagonist who recently arrived in the kind of walled village that often appears in fantasies. Echoes of one story appear in the other. Both have a library and librarian, both have skulls, to be precise, unicorn skulls. Slowly but surely the relationship between the two stories becomes apparent and so does the fact that Muratami is talking about the human mind. But the writing is clear and humorous and that makes the book easy to grasp and enjoyable even when it goes into absurd science fantasy or difficult scientific concepts.

Action-packed thriller: Very interesting and action-packed entry in Sandford’s Prey series about Lucas Davenport. The plausibility that a Russian group, living in northern Minnesota may still be loyal to their Communist beginnings made it more than interesting. I liked the fact that the story wasn’t neatly tied up in a bow, not because this isn’t the end of the series, but because it made it true to life. Bureaucracy and politics prevent easy solutions. I also liked that the woman who was homeless at the beginning evaded being caught up in the drama. Finally, I like that Lucas is not a know-it-all. He makes mistakes in his thinking. He gets sidetracked. And he doesn’t always get cooperation of those he works with.

Developing friendship: At first, I couldn’t get into this book by one of my favorite writers, but it built and built. I especially enjoyed the development of the friendship between Vicki and Reheema, certainly more than the relationship with Dan. The idea that someone trained as a lawyer would take the chances she did was a bit surprising, but there wouldn’t be a story without that. She wouldn’t have been able to connect dots. I liked her parents at the end, and I guess she did too, but rather than Vicki telling us about them early on, I would have liked to see more of their interactions with her. The mix of murder, drugs and guns leads to a complicated plot.

Historical fiction: I’d heard of this book but didn’t get it to read until a friend invited me to join her and her book club for a discussion about it. The style is unlike any other book I’ve read but fits a story about Russia from the 1920’s to the 1950’s. I recognized places in Moscow mentioned in the book, although I didn’t visit the Metropole hotel when I was there almost fifty years after the story ended. Alexander’s transformation from a Count to just an ordinary bloke, but one with a full life is thanks to his childhood training and adaptability, but it’s his relationships with the hotel staff and with the two girls in his life that make the read most enjoyable. I don’t know how accurate the historical parts of the story are, but they don’t seem too far off from what I know.

review: Great: Another great Jury book with Plant and Wiggins. Sutter than some of them but full of action, suspense, emotions. Read and enjoy!

Wow!: This book was my first by John Hart. It held my complete attention throughout. The characters were believable, the story line did not falter, and the ending was superb...I did not see it coming. A very good read.
A+: Feral Instinct is the third Gordon Carroll book it has been my pleasure to read. Very good story, with believable action and characters, plus the good guy wins...always a plus.

A+ The Nameless Ones: I downloaded the book the same day it was released, then took six weeks to begin reading it. My reluctance was due to reading the previous book, which told of Angel's struggle with cancer and his recovery after chemo. I feared both Angel and Louis would die in this latest book, so eased into reading it.  Even though Charlie Parker just had a cameo appearance early in the book, Louis and Angel carried the story well. There are always history lessons to learn when reading John Connolly's books, and they are a pleasure to me. Well done.

Stalked: Brian Freeman is my new favorite author, although I do wish I had discovered him sooner. His stories are excellent, the cast of characters are diverse and interesting, and he keeps me guessing "who done it."

A+: The Poacher's Son was the first book written by Mike Bowditch, who is a new author to me. What an excellent book...a first rate story, and characters. Everything about it held my interest and kept me reading. The descriptions of Maine scenery made me feel as if I were in the midst of it. I enjoyed every bit of it and can hardly wait to read another by Bowditch. What a find.

A+: Thomas Perry has been a favorite author of mine for many years. Reading The Left-Handed Twin was like visiting with a favorite, well-loved friend...almost knowing at times what they are going to say...being aware of their patterns of behavior, always interesting and never boring. It also felt at the last like the good friend was saying getting ready to say goodbye.
Sigh: This wasn't a very good read- one of the worst in the Swagger series.
Super cute: Very cute book. Easy read for beginner readers.
Great product: great product i really like it.

Book: A super job of buying a book!

review: Always a satisfying read: Michael Connelly never disappoints.  This book contains two intricate and compelling stories and pulls you in with the first few words.  I love the Bosch connection to Vietnam.  I belong to the real generation of the fictional Bosch and I feel that the author portrays the emotions of that time perfectly.  This is a great read.

history: B01LZFL63S B001GXF2YY B07WG8L7WC B0852ZXJSD B000FCK44U B07TRVR8RP B01BU1ITMI
review: Exciting and relevant: It almost seems that it would be impossible to create an exciting story using the events of the pandemic and the defund the police sentiment of 2020.  It is not impossible and this book is the proof.  Renee Ballard seems an unlikely hero but she is a smart and savvy detective who Harry Bosch respects and partners with.  This book captures the reader immediately and doesn't let go, even after the last words have been read.  Please give us more Ballard/Bosch, Mr. Connelly!

history: B01LZFL63S B001GXF2YY B07WG8L7WC B0852ZXJSD B000FCK44U B07TRVR8RP B01BU1ITMI B08WLRG1L2
review: Thoroughly engrossing thriller: Not only is this a well-paced and well written story, but the reader learns some fascinating legal facts as well.  Some of those facts are truly terrifying because they bring to light some proof that fears that the judicial system is stacked in favor of the prosecution so innocent people can be convicted of crimes they did not commit.  It also brings to light that true criminals can evade the system and still walk free among us.  This is a top notch thriller that might make it hard for the reader to sleep at night.

review: Deadly secrets: This shocking and tragic thriller will get your heat pumping as the author unveils the evils played upon two young girls.  The resulting secrets destroy their lives little by little in different ways and the reader wants desperately for someone to help them.  We find that monsters can be very real and take surprising shapes.  This book is brilliant, scary, heartbreaking, and masterfully written.

history: B01LZFL63S B001GXF2YY B07WG8L7WC B0852ZXJSD B000FCK44U B07TRVR8RP B01BU1ITMI B08WLRG1L2 B0047Y17P2 B08LVSC93V
review: Fierce: Karin Slaughter writes a heart-pounding thriller like no one else.  This story is scary, devastating, frustrating, and terrifying.  Each character is fully fleshed out and an individual and the reader gets to choose whether to love or hate them.  Will Trent is the most unique character I have grown to love and I love Sara for loving him so completely.  This is a great read and one that will hang around in the reader's head long after the last page.

Incredible and a Must Read: 5 stars
American Made
What Happens to People When Work Disappears
By Farah Stockman
I had to sit and ponder on this book for a day or so just to process the realities of what I just finished reading. I am still not sure I can do American Made justice. Farah Stockman has written an inspiring, infuriating, and educational look at the mess left behind when a plant closes; as well as the limited options blue-collar workers have in the wake of losing their jobs.
Wally, Shannon and John desperately search for jobs that will pay as well as Rexnord while struggling to keep their families afloat. Stockman follows this trio for three years and has utterly managed to capture their personalities, their lives, and their struggles.
American Made needs to be required reading in every economics class taught across the country as this is a book that has the ability to make a reader question their viewpoint on the realities of free trade and the world economy.
I highly recommend this book!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher and Netgalley.

Love This Book!: 4 stars
Isabel Puddles Investigates
by M.V. Byrne

Isabel Puddles is quite like sitting with an older lady and having her regale you with every story about everyone she knows and as a listener/reader being completely enchanted with her stories of her town and her life.
M.V. Byrne writes the Puddles books almost as she is sitting and observing her in her day to day life and her thoughts. This second book in this series is filled with mystery, family, friends and deceit.
This is a wonderful cozy mystery that will appeal to most mystery readers. I really enjoy and appreciate books that showcase women on the other side of children and family still having a vibrant life and enjoying every minute of it.

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher and Netgalley.

Fascinating!: 4.5 stars
A Taste for Poison
by Neil Bradbury, Ph.D.
A fascinating book that immerses the reader into an in-depth look at poisons and how they have been used through the years to commit murder. Prior to reading this book, I had not heard of most of these crimes. It was quite interesting how old some of these murders were, it is easy to forget that murder is not something of just the last century but is as old as man himself.

I highly recommend this book.
I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher and Netgalley.

Great Book: 5 stars
Funny Farm
My Unexpected Life with 600 Rescue Animals
By Laurie Zaleski
Ms. Zaleski has written a heartbreaking, heartwarming and utterly unputdownable book. What a fascinating memoir on her very unusual childhood and her mother's start of the Funny Farm as she scrapped to get by and raise her kids after fleeing from an abusive husband.
Zaleski shares how it all began to where she is today with 600 rescue animals, countless volunteers and daily miracles saving many animals. I highly recommend this book, while it is disturbing at times, it is so heartwarming and an absolute must-read.

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher and Netgalley.
No New Info: Madmen in the woods is a good enough book. However, there really is not any new info here. Those who have never read about the Unabomber would like this book.

A Heartwarming Story: 4 stars
I so love the people of Honey Creek and this entire series of books about them. I truly hope there is another one because I need more of them, especially Lilly and Mr Wilson. I do so love Pop and Mason too.
Jodi Thomas writes books that draw the reader with characters so easy to love, root for and want to be a part of their lives. I truly enjoyed this book for a sweet, engrossing and easy read.
This book and any in the series are able to be read as a stand alone. They have carry over characters, but each one is a separate story.

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher and Netgalley.

Ugh, Just Not Up To Her Usual Standards: 2 -2.5 stars
I typically adore everything Amy Lillard writes. Dairy Dairy Quite Contrary was just okay. I had a hard time connecting with the characters and the ever present bumbling sheriff gets old.
The end was okay but honestly I was just glad it was over.
I will not be reading the next in this series.
Good book.: Easy and to the point. No fluff just a good book to pass the ham radio technician test.
Good study guide: Helped me pass my General license exam with no problem.

review: great story line: Couldn’t put it down.  Every free moment I went back to reading.  Fast paced… holds your attention.  I Highly recommend.
Love the series, perfect condition!: My love for the series aside, the books arrived in perfect condition. Still sealed! And it includes a map inside as well! 🤍

The TENSION ✨: The tension in this book was so, so, so good. The beginning was a bit slow but as soon as it picked up, I could not put it down. Brexley and Warwick, ugh. I can’t even put what I feel for them into words. The ending broke me completely. Starting book two now! 🤍 Recommend this wholeheartedly!

This book had me HOOKED!: Listen, when I tell you this book had me HOOKED, I mean it. Brexley, ugh, I love her. Warwick, the effect he has on me is insane. He is POWERFUL. Opie and Bitzy are my faves. Scorpion and Ash? Love of my life material for sure. This review probably doesn’t make sense, but I LOVED this book. Already have the next one in my hands to start it. The ending of this book left me so excited so I can’t wait to start the third ♥️

They own my heart and soul. The ending of this book stomped on my heart a million times, but I still loved it. Am I ready to read the last book and finish the series? Not even close. Great beginning to the series!: This was a slow read but not surprised due to the amazing world building. It definitely prepares you for what is to come and I liked that. I’m so ready for what comes next and I know I will love it. I already know I would protect Auren at all costs.

Midas can just go away because I can’t STAND him.

Waste of time energy and money: Once upon a time Gresham set a high standard.  Now he is coasting on his reputation.  This book is a poor excuse for a poor excuse.  I couldn't care less about the characters involved and that is a recipe for disaster.

Jack Reacher missing in action.: I had to force myself to keep reading and by the time I was a third of the way through I decided to look up the Amazon reviews to verify if it was as bad as I thought.  It is.  Painfully slow.  Jumble of a plot.  A complete waste of time, energy and money as far as I’m concerned.  I feel betrayed.  Will the REAL Jack Reacher please come back?
Needlessly depressing.: Such a dark view of life and humanity.  This author gives us nothing to feel good about.  Life is hard enough without this incessant negativity

Waste of time: A recipe for failure.  Till three or four stories at once and don't reveal a single character with any redeeming values.  Why should I care about any of these people?  Nothing distinctive.  This one goes on the scrapheap.
Another win for Bowditch: The guy never gives up.  He is humble steadfast and true like all the true heroes of the past.  He’s gotta stop getting those concussions !
Excellent: This book is so easy to read and comprehend that I ordered more to give to my grandchildren.  Everyone should read this book

Beginning of Hot New Series: I really enjoyed this book. Lots of creativity and fun for the imagination. Loved the balance of the two worlds. Michel Guyon has established the beginning of a great series with wonderful storytelling. Lots of positive messages tucked inside about being a good person and being respectful of all living things. Young readers (and parents) will love this book.

Not my genre: I'm glad I read this, stretching my reach outside my favorite genres. I found it intriguing, but at times I was also a little confused. There were some really well-written characters, I just didn't connect with it the way I thought I should.

Delicious Historical Fiction: I can't imagine being confined to one place for the rest of my life, watching others come and go. Deep connections made, locked in time and space.

Amor Towles is able to take a situation with extreme limitations and build a compelling story with endless possibilities. I loved this historical novel and its setting. The characters are beautiful and haunting as well.

This is a slow, poetic read, IMO. It's meant to be savored.

Secrets Revealed: A book about a book club- sort of. What is it with neighbors? We love to love and hate them. Gossip abounds in this tiny community bound by connecting streets. L. Alison Heller proves that the 'neighborhood drama' genre is pretty much endless. As long as people obsess over their neighbors, these stories will continue to entice readers.

More mystery than thriller, I enjoyed Heller's voice in this often explored genre. Heller keeps the lines of truth and lies, and known and unknown- blurred just enough to keep readers guessing. (I love how pretty much every novelized interpretation of 'book club' translate to 'wine club'.)

What won't parents do for their children? Or are they really just protecting themselves?

One of my favorites !: One of my favorites. About a time that was far from 2021 when LGBT had zero rights and were regularly persecuted and prosecuted. Add race to it and it’s another focal point for abuse.
Awesome strong characters of those who paved the way. 👍👍

👍👍 for Alaska Thunderf%*\ 5000: If you love Alaska you’ll love her book. She plays ditzy often in her work persona however she’s a critical thinker and has layers of messages in all she does, while having fun doing it.
Lady Bunny has been my favorite queen since the 80s, but nowadays Alaska has wedged her way in and theyre neck and neck. Bunny is savvy, very quick thinking, quite dirty/gross often times, and quite the business person. Alaska is her own person but is that that I described in Bunny as well.
They are both stellar queens.
This is a really great book. I Love it.
I gave for (Christmas) gifts w a gift card inside. They all loved it.
Can be sent to those you love, or even to those more conservative types, whether that be your brother or your boss.
I’ll keep buying more as gifts always
Plus it supports queer artist/ry.
Childhood memories: Loved the book. So many great recipes in there from my childhood. Mom always had a box of Biscuit in the cupboard.
Beautiful story to color: I am planning on giving this book to my great granddaughter for a keepsake. Amazing book
Enchanting: This is a enchanting book to color. Love the pictures.
Creative ideas abound!: Easy to follow creative ideas. Love this book!
Amazing woman!: More insight into the life of this amazing and talented woman! Admire her ability to maintain her lifestyle and belief in keeping our lives less complex and yet more fulfilling.
Disappointed: Expected normal wear; I.e., small tears,  a few dog-eared pages, but the book spine was entirely separated from the pages. Very disappointed!
Utterly charming protagonist: Molly the maid, a fascinating character, whose different-ness carries this utterly charming story into a book totally worthy of your time. Just read it already!
Good Book: Good Book
Good Book!: Good Book!

Not our favorite book of the series: This book tackles the subject of racism, but every instance of racism is with a white person being the racist.  I read through the book before giving it to my daughter and I feel like it sends the message that all or most white people are racist, which isn't true.  The storyline is ok, but the heavy emphasis on racism may be a turn off for many readers or their parents.

My daughter enjoyed this book: We have all three of the Contemporary Character books from American Girl and my daughter enjoyed this book more than the first one.  Like the first book this story also tackles the subject of racism.  The main character in this book is biracial and the story is told from Evette's perspective.

Enjoyable story: My daughter really enjoyed Maritza's story.  Of the three books in this series Maritza's story was my daughter's favorite.  It does discuss issues revolving around immigration.  All of the books in this series discuss issues that are currently in the forefront for our society.  The storyline for this book was believable for the most part.  Usually in all of the American Girl books there are some parts of the story that do not seem realistic, but this one has scenarios that are mostly plausible.

Beautifully written and inspiring: I've followed Leila's blog for many years now and I love her practical advice and writing style. She reminds me a bit of Mary Reed Newland. Her tone is such that you feel like you are chatting with a dear friend over a cup of coffee.

The Little Oratory is a bit like a modern day Mary Reed Newland book. Throughout the book, you find inspiration for making your home a domestic church that will inspire you and your family to grow to have a deeper relationship with God.

I particularly like her suggestions on how to set up a home altar. It's a nice way to have a corner or a table set up as a place to pray or even to remind you to pray. I have a few areas in my home that are set up like this and they're just peaceful areas to go and pray when everything seems crazy.

Leila's advice is real and practical. There's encouragement for for those who are singles, families with children. Along with offering advice for living your faith at home, she incorporates tidbits of advice about not cluttering up areas you are setting aside as areas that are meant to offer some beauty and inspiration, such as the window sill over the kitchen sink.

If you are someone who would like a bit of guidance for ways to make your domestic church more hospitable and help inspire you and your family, this book is an excellent place to start. I love how she offers explanations for how things are done in the Eastern and Western traditions. My husband's Grandmother belonged to an Eastern rite, and I like that I was able to find some ways to bring some of the traditions his family had remembered from his grandmother to our home so create a connection to a family heritage for my children.

Overall, it's a beautifully done book. Leila offers a wide array of information that will help you transform your home into a domestic church filled with beauty and peace that inspires faith.

10 year old enjoyed it: My ten year old daughter loves reading American Girl books, so she was excited to read about this year's Girl of the Year.  Corinne's story tells about her family moving into her new step father's home.  The book is well written, but Corinne seems older than her age, but perhaps her life experiences account for her seeming older.  What appealed most to my daughter was the fact that Corinne and her little sister Gwynn are both involved in winter sports.  Given that the Winter Olympics also just took place this book and the second book in the series seemed to have added appeal.

10 year old enjoyed it: My ten year old daughter enjoyed reading the first Corinne book, so she was excited to read the second book about Corinne and her little sister Gwynn.  This book tells about Corinne training her rescue dog, but also deals with some big changes happening in her newly blended family.  My daughter liked this book better than the first one in the series.

Good, practical advice: I've been into decluttering and minimalism when it comes to household items for several years now.  Whether you're new to trying to organize and declutter your home, or have been at it for years, this book has lots of helpful tips and suggestions for helping you to achieve an organized home.  It's a worthwhile book to read if you are overwhelmed and don't know where to start with regards to organizing your home.

Wide variety of bread recipes: This bread cook book is pretty good.  The book is filled with a wide variety of bread recipes.  I was surprised to find that there is even a section with some gluten free breads, as well.  The recipes are straightforward and easy to follow. It's a good book if you are taking first steps into bread making.

It's Alice Starmore: It's Alice Starmore... What's not to like?  Seriously, everything you expect from a Starmore.  Very detailed.  Not a compilation of patterns, more a "how-to".  Exactly what I was looking for.

Neat mittens - harder to find yarn, need to adjust: So, the mittens in here are pretty, but you may need to make some adjustments.  Most of them are written for 50-56 stitches per round for DK yarn.  I think that's important to know because DK yarn is hard to find in box stores (like Joanns and Michaels).  The only DK (weight 3) yarn they usually carry is baby yarn which doesn't come in the colors you'll need.  You could make them with worsted weight.  The stitch counts are fine for a large male hand or you can adjust them by removing stitches from the side.  I usually make mittens with fingering weight yarn and maybe a few with worsted.  With some know-how you can increase the mitten pattern reticulations for use with fingering as well.  I won't link pictures here - you can see pictures of most on Ravelry.  Overall, I think I will enjoy making many of these.

Excellent book: This novel addresses challenges students may face: bullying, stereotype challenges, profiling, AND teaches revising skills. This book was recommended on our school’s summer reading list. I read it with my son. I then bought a copy for my classroom library.
The author is an excellent writer and captures the inner workings of young student’s minds beautiful. Lot’s of social emotional teaching value there. It’s a MUST HAVE.
Excellent Book: Great! I can only recommend this book. Shipping was fast as well.

Great Stuff, Authors are authentic: To the point and informative. Legit fitness for anyone. I'm working on t herougj some weak and imbalanced muscles that have caused chronic pain. I've be spent thousands on chiropractic care that had only created more problems. BB wish I'd found this before I forked over all that cash. These people are for real

Awesome book!: I absolutely love Jane Goodall and I was not one bit disappointed with this book! I feel like I know her heart even better than I did previously!
It's easy to read, holds your attention, and I was heartbroken to get to the end.
You don't want to miss out on this amazing book!

Lovely Book: As a multiple dog owner I have enjoyed this book so much. Learning about my dogs behavior and what it means.
Oh and the photos are phenomenal. This is a book I will be happy to purchase and look at time and again.

Thank you so much, NetGalley, for allowing me to read and review this great book!

Sweet Calendar!: I love this calendar!!! I will never miss out again. I have my collection of the Crusoe family together now! Stay healthy gang! I love y'all madly!
Calendar is made very well!

i have read every patterson but.....: i thought with the name James Patterson, these would have to be good-i ordered 2 on amazon because i live in the CRAZY CALIFORNIA where masks are being forced so i haven't gone to the library like i used to- this book was SO 'not patterson'.....i almost quit reading it and i never do that-it was a chore to finish.

worst line in the book.....: i have read EVERY james patterson so i thought these book shots would have to be good......the writing, doesn't seem like patterson at all-BORING and for me, the worst line in the book:  Lindsay saying to Cindy "Go ahead, be my guest, and take a 'selfie' so i can see how my size ten clothing fits your itty-bitty size four bod".....it made me 'CRINGE'.....do women talk like that?  i don't.....

started very S L O W and boring: if i hadn't read that this book was 'really good' i wouldn't have kept reading it-it was BORING for about 40 pgs., no book should take that long to 'hook' you but it got better-the 1 star off is for the s l o w start.

don't judge a book by its cover: i would NEVER pick up a book with a cover like this, for some reason, i always just think it's blah-blah-blah romance garbage BUT, when i don't have a book and am waiting on one in the mail, we have 3 big book shelfs in the lobby of my apt. complex and i have read EVERY good one down there (i thought) so was forced to try one with a cover like this-this book REALLY SURPRISED me-it was good, nothing at all like i thought-i realize now-i have found some really good stories in books with covers like this-i would tell the authors-use better covers that make us KNOW, there's a good story inside.
i LOVED this book: i'll just say, the end of the book is worth reading the whole book-it also made me think of the relationship between me, my mom and my sister
GREAT read: i didn't want to write a review but looks like AMAZON won't just let me leave stars-i really enjoyed this book.

TOOO long to get interesting: i got this because i'd seen some people in a f/b group i'm in saying they loved it-i read EVERY night in bed and i was down to my last book (this one) while waiting on some more-i started reading and reading and reading, thinking, this is SO BORING, is it just me?  i was going to put it down which is something i never do so i picked it up again and kept reading, thinking the same thing-too many people and is it just me, or is this really BORING?  i put it down again-my books still haven't arrived so, again and this time, it DID finally get interesting and people and things started falling into place-maybe it's just me but in the end. i loved it.  just way too long to get to anything interesting
Great gift: I gave this to my husband for Christmas. He really enjoys the puzzles every day. Lots of fun!

A riveting book that puts your mind in a different place: A riveting book that puts your mind in a different place
The only thing that I can say is that it really change your perspective on China I never realized how deceiving and bad the CCP is A total eye-opener this is a must read book it puts a different perspective on China and its policies they truly are a threat

Could nit put it down !: The struggles of war snd the fact that through strife And bombings this family survives they work hard at it they’re loyal and the story is a wonderful story it’s it’s a thick book finished it in three days it was that good
Great book, if you like fast reading: Could not put it down.  Kept you very interested
Too much detail not enough story: Basically somewhat boring
Not great: Very boring

Very timely: I’ve just finished reading “The Madness of Crowds.”  Once again, a well written novel about an issue that may be more prevalent than we would like to think. Written on the heals of the pandemic, although it’s not over in the real world, it brings to the reader a concept that is too awful to consider in this 21st century. I won’t spoil it for anyone, but you won’t be disappointed in the content, our beloved The Pines family and their courage in fighting for a moral world. Thank you, Louise Penny.

Probably the funniest book I have ever read: So this is self-published and consequently has a few typos, punctuation errors, and mistakes of that type. The plot also is thin and has some scenes that maybe don't need to be there. But you're not going to be reading this for the plot: this is about the jokes, rapid fire one after another. Often they are based on the narrator failing to describe some key (and usually bizarre) detail of a scene which is then revealed in a later sentence, forcing you to reimagine everything.
This has many varieties and great photos: This book has many species of birds, their descriptions and nice photos of them and where they live.
Helpful: First one came scratched and it was promptly replaced!
Want to know the secret read it.: Very good read. Everyone has a secret, could not put the book down. The why's and who  kept me interested. A little twist it always a great ending.

Great twist: I enjoy the story line of the whole Denton detective family, each book gives us just a little more into the lives of the prime characters. In the drowning girls I did not expect the last twist.  Great read.

A really sweet book: I read this several years ago and loved it so I bought it for Christmas for my grandson's girlfriend who  is a cat lover too.  She was really happy to receive it as she had heard what an excellent book it is.
Wonderful representations of famous artwork using cats instead of humans: My grandson's girlfriend loved it.  She and he are great admirers of famous art and loved the representations

Female author: This was an enjoyable read. I will recommend this book, especially to female friends. I don’t believe a man could have written the scene where Jean confronts Luc, and I consider myself a feminist. But I didn’t find the encounter believable.

That said, self-forgiveness is important and all too rare in some people. (Others could be more self-critical.) The characters were interesting. The plot was a bit telegraphed. But the scenery and the food made for wonderful contexts.

Lots of suspense: Lethal Cover up

Lethal Cover Up was a very exciting book. Lots of suspense and surprises. I enjoyed Madison and Tucker’s story. Will they be able to rekindle their love? They are determined to find the killer of Madison’s sister. What will they uncover and who else will get hurt? There was no dull moments in Lethal Cover up. Never knew what was going to happen from one minute to the next. I recommend reading this book.

I received a complimentary copy of the book from Celebrate Lit. This book review is my own opinion.

Lots of danger: Girls of Summer

Girls of Summer was a very suspenseful story. Loved the story of Charlotte and Mac. There was so much danger in Girls of Summer but very inspirational too. Never knew what kind of trouble/danger Charlie or Georgie would get into. Charlotte landed in the hospital a lot. Charlotte was determined to find out who was after her. Will she ever be safe? Will the FBI figure it out or will Charlotte? Read the book to see.

I received a complimentary copy from Celebrate Lit. This book review is my own opinion.

Great historical: The heart of a Cowboy

I loved Linnea and Flynn story in The Heart of a Cowboy. Most of the time they are traveling; Flynn is trying to keep Linnea safe. This is a historical set during the 1800’s so traveling was by wagon and horseback. I loved how Flynn younger sister was always playing matchmaker. There is so much to the story I don’t want to give anything away. Heart of a Cowboy is a very good book. I really enjoyed Linnea and how brave she was and adventurous.

This is the second book in the series. The book can be read as a stand alone. I do recommend reading the first book also.

I received a complimentary copy of the book from NetGalley. This book review is my own opinion.

Love the children: A Picture of Hope

A Picture of Hope is set during the WWII where the Jews were treated bad. A very difficult time. I loved Nellie and Jean-Paul’s story. Nellie finds a young girl that was orphaned. I loved how Nellie took care of the children, how loving she was to them. I enjoyed reading the author’s notes at the end of the book, how she research the characters.

If you like books set during WWII you will enjoy A Picture of Hope. I recommend reading this book.

I received a complimentary copy of the book from Celebrate Lit. This book review is my own opinion.

Will they ever find love: The Paramedic’s forever family

Lindsay’s and Mason’s love story is definitely a rocky one. I read this book in just a few days and I haven’t done that for a while. I loved the dog in the story especially it being a chiweenie. Lindsay is a widow with two young children. Lindsay and Mason are best friends and next door neighbors. I really enjoyed Mason’s Grandpa. I really enjoyed reading this book. There is a lot of great relationships in the book.

I received a complimentary copy of the book from Just Read tours. This book review is my own opinion.

Great story: Her Cowboy wedding date

I enjoyed reading Carter and Tess story. A lot more to the story than just the wedding. Loved the part about using the special chocolate and the cooking competition. Also enjoyed the part of Grandpa trying to find the treasure map. This is the first one I have read in the Three Springs series. I definitely need to read about the books to learn more about the other characters.

I received a complimentary copy of the book from Just Read Publicity Tours. This book review is my own opinion.

History of family is important: Heirlooms

Heirloom is about two different time periods. I loved how Helen was a nurse and how she helped Eunhee. They are both widows that lost their husbands in the war. The author writes about a subject that is treated different in the two time periods. It was interesting to learn more about it. Helen granddaughter finds out family secrets when going through things after Helen’s passing. Cassidy had a lot of challenges with the house too .

Heirlooms was a very interesting book. I enjoyed it. I also enjoyed the author note at the end.

I received a complimentary copy of the book from Just Read Publicity Tours. This book review is my own opinion.

BUMMER: A waste of my money - don't buy unless you want to be bored To Death!  ha  The whole story concentrated around a woman dealing with a Something.  Mundane and repetitious.  i have read this author before, her only redeeming book in my mind was Craven Manor. The rest earned C, C- and one B (The House Next Door. This book earned a D.

Same ol same ol: Years ago I read one of his books and it was very good. Well, not so this one.  Don't waste your monies on it. His story was nothing exceptional - like so many books. I got tired of reading about this little chid and his problems talking, Sweetie, with his mom.  A love interest comes into the picture and it goes down from there.  Nothing special here.
Nothing Special: Boring.

Done After Reading Half of the Book: I have read most of her books and really enjoyed them, but this one fell flat on its face, and I am giving up on it.  None of the characters were worth my time trying to follow or like, and the pace of the book uneven - too many characters with crazy names to keep track of - the whole story failed me, and I won't be reading any more of her so=called fantasy stories!  I got so tired of this "runes" business too...... I am moving on to a story that is much easier and more relatable to read!
Fantastic True Story: I loved the story - tugs at your heartstrings.
A Good Book: A 'steady as she goes' kind of book, looking into Trump's White House.
Nice Cowboy Stories: However!  Some of his recipes seem rather exotic for being way out there on the lone prairie.  But overall it is a well put-together, enjoyable book.

Don't Buy: This was his worst of the Bayou series. I could not care less by the time I got to the end of who did what to whom. I bought the book thinking it just could have potential to be Scary. Ha.  Just a regular story line, and a poor story line at that. Did the author actually think that "Jack" , an alcoholic , would be someone we cared about? Another fun read in the Southern Ghost Hunter Series: Give up the Ghost is book number eleven in the Southern Ghost Hunter series by Angie Fox. This story continues on where book number ten left off, with a time vault in town opened, and all the items in need of documentation. The town watches as the items are pulled from the vault. A mysterious book that was not supposed to be in the vault is found, and it causes quite a stir.
This book is the center of the mystery for this story. It takes Verity Long on a hunt for an elusive ghost, and a possible solution to Frankie’s predicament of being grounded on Verity’s property.
Like the other books in the Southern Ghost Hunter series, Give Up The Ghost is filled with a cast of eclectic and fun characters, her dreamy boyfriend Ellis, and the cutest pet ever. We also learn more about Virginia’s past, and it’s not pretty. As book eleven comes to a close, I wonder if it’s possible that Virginia and Verity might someday have a civil relationship. I hope so.
As for her ghost, Frankie, it feels like two steps forward and one step back on his journey to freedom. He’s stubborn and resists change, even when it’s detrimental. He makes me laugh, but sometimes I also want to clobber him.
If you’ve read the other books in the Southern Ghost Hunter series, then you will surely enjoy this one. If you have just spotted this series for the first time, then I highly recommend that you go back and start from the beginning and read your way through, because you won’t want to miss them. These are supernatural cozy mysteries at their best. Angie Fox has a great sense of humor, and adds just enough snark to make me laugh out loud from time to time. The main character, Verity Long, is southern to the core. She’s smart, upbeat, considerate, and she sticks her nose in places she shouldn’t all for the greater good of the town she loves, and the people (both alive and dead) who need her help. Highly recommended!

Remedial History 010: This is the fourth book by Groom that I have read, the first three being The Aviators, The Generals and The Allies.  Those three I loved, to the point I bought The Admirals because I thought it was a Groom book-it wasn't but it was good.  This book however falls very short of the standard of the first three.  Groom barely scratches the surface of his subjects and brings nothing new to the discussion.  Each subject is discussed, almost completely divorced from the other two.  Accomplishments and failures are listed but very little detail or reasoning for said failures or accomplishments.  As I have read Chernow's Hamilton book and McCullough's Adams book, both referenced, and several books on Jefferson I feel like Groom wrote this book as a review of the others.  If you are completely new to the topic or a high school student this is probably as good a place to start as any, however if you have more than a passing knowledge of these three men don't bother with this book.

Another triumph for Jones: Great book, very readable, interesting from start to finish.
1,000 years in 600+ pages in a feat, in and of itself.
That Jones was able to keep in interesting, perfectly paced and highly readable is nothing short of amazing.
The book is not a straight path, which may bother some, but is broken into several "straight paths."
We walk through beginnings, endings of the age as well as several compartments of the age; Religion, architecture, Islam, Byzantium, Iberia, etc.
I did feel the last few chapters seemed rush compared to the rest of the book but then checked and the number of pages was pretty consistent for each topic.
The serious student of the Medieval Age may find the book a tad simplistic but this book wasn't written for them, it was written for those with a passion for history but not making it their vocation.
This was my seventh book by Jones and hope to find number eight soon.

Little known Chicago history: I've loved the history of my hometown in this series, and Drawn by the Current was no exception. The attention to detail was astounding, and I get such a kick out of reading about the sights and sounds in a place I love.

Jocelyn Green writes heavy subject matter, and this book dealt with domestic abuse. Unfortunately, plots about abusive men lying in wait for innocent women rank extremely low on the list of books I enjoy, so that whole plotline sullied the story for me. The double whammy was another personal preference item, being the portrayal of Olive as a "do it myself, don't accept help, therefore make blatantly poor choices out of my need to prove myself" character. I know a lot of people are like this and she was written correctly, but this personality is like the polar opposite of me and drives me crazy. So banging my head constantly did diminish my enjoyment of the story.
But, I recognize that these are personal preference items and don't speak to the quality of the story or writing. The mystery was engaging, the family relationships inspiring (I love Meg, Sylvie, and Kristof and am grieved that Nate has passed 😭), and I liked Erik except for his plot twist and Olive's overly dramatic reaction to it. Everyone shows growth and has a HEA at the end. The message was about relying too heavily on people, including oneself, and not God, and also references our identity beyond our jobs.

For me, definitely my favorite thing about this book is that it's a love letter to Chicago and highlights little known history about it. I'm pleased to have the Windy City series on my shelves.

I received a copy of Drawn by the Current from Netgalley and the publisher in exchange for an honest review, and all opinions are my own.

It was so odd for this book, and since none of the other reviews even gave a heads up about it, I thought some readers might just want to be aware.

Clean women's fiction: "However this turned out, there were some things you could always count on. Sunlight. Rainbows. Friendship."

Another lovely historical (general/clean) women's fiction by Camille Di Maio. Three female friends in Brooklyn make their way in a changing world, figuring out what they want from life, how they can contribute to the world, and what falling in love will mean for those things. Across the ocean, men in Easy Company struggle through the war, finding hope in the letters they send and receive from the girls. I love learning about Dick Winters and Easy Company, so I liked that this book featured them. Also living in Virginia, I enjoyed the locations referenced here, including Agecroft Hall specifically! The prose was smooth and history was well done. And everyone got their happy ending!

I read an ebook provided by the publisher and Netgalley, but I was not required to write a positive review and all opinions are my own.

A Masterpiece: Edward Sorel is a national treasure and his beautifully rendered life story is funny, touching and inspiring. His visual vocabulary is as distinctive as that of the greats with whom he shares space in the Pantheon of America’s great cartoonist/artists. Penmen/women such as Nast, Gibson, Held, Arno, Addams, Steig, Steinberg, Koren, Hirschfeld, Levine, Crumb and Chast.

The bonus is that his heartfelt words and incisive wit also carry a narrative that recounts a remarkable life lived in the most turbulent of times in the world’s capital of culture and commerce.

Among the most touching moments are his recounting of his budget Bar Mitzvah capped by the purchase of a volume of Peter Arno cartoons memorably shared with his mother and his inadvertent hostage taking of his soon-to-be former bosses top coat.

All of which is recounted in a narrative that recalls countless touchstones of popular and political culture crafted by Sorel into a progressive tapestry of our times.

Not only does the artist possess a keen BS detector but delivers knockout punches as well as laurel wreaths with equal effect.

I received this book with keen anticipation and am floored by it’s humor, wisdom, and heart. A true masterpiece.

Historical fiction well-written and worth reading: I was completely fascinated with the idea of this book from what I was imagining from just the title and a very brief excerpt of the first page or so.  What I imagined was not what I read.  It was better. With the first portion of the book, I wasn’t sure where it was going and felt it was a bit simplistic.  I kept reading and then stumbled upon a portion that almost had me stop reading the book because of my peculiar sensibilities and sensitivities.  I’m glad I did not stop.  Finally, I was so involved in life of the protagonist that I had endeared myself to her and was emotionally invested as the events of her life proceeded forward.  I felt many different emotions and conflicts which is the mark of a real storyteller.  The author involved me in the narrative and left me with both the feeling of deep sadness and also great triumph.  It does not have a perfectly happy ending but neither does life usually.  But in many ways, it has a satisfactory ending.  I did not realize when I began the book that the basis of the story was the creation of the Oxford English Dictionary and that this could be termed as historical fiction.  When I realized this at the end of the book, I became quite happy that I read it.  I do recommend this for word lovers and bibliophiles alike.

We love Odyssey: I heard these episodes on the radio when they originally aired in 1994 (I was a teenager).  I have owned this album on cassette for a very long time, but I recently bought the CD's so my husband and I could listen to them in the car.  We love Odyssey, and we usually listen to it in the car if the trip is longer than an hour.  We recently listened to this album trekking across Tennessee.  My favorite aspects about this album in particular is that it has the early stages of the Barclays being called into the ministry, and also the early stages of Eugene and Katrina's relationship.  These stories age well.  I enjoyed them as a teen, and now enjoy them as a middle-ager.

We love Odyssey: Grew up listening to Odyssey, from the time it originally aired on the radio in 1987.  I was in elementary school back then, and by the time the episodes on this album aired in 1994, I was an adolescent.  I LOVED them then, and I LOVE them now.  My husband and I have had the cassette tapes of this album for years, but bought the CD's recently so we could listen in the car.  We recently took a vacation, and listened to this album on the road.  We always listened to Odyssey in the car if we're going somewhere over an hour away.  Odyssey is especially great for trekking across scenic but sparsely-populated states like Nebraska and Wyoming (but that wasn't where we went this time).  You get to listen to the stories while you enjoy the countryside.

A Vital Book for all in Ministry: I grew up knowing the story of Jim Elliot's tragic death while reaching the Aucas (now called Waidoni) for Christ, and how his faithful widow Elisabeth continued that ministry to the tribe after his death. My own mother became a Christian as a little girl in Ohio in the late 50's as a result of that story happening and making an impact on the church in the US. I have served with a ministry that has a Jim Elliot missionary story that we share with children. I have seen countless come to salvation as a result of this story. Needless to say, I really had a high opinion of the Elliots. Then, something happened.

At age 20, I was dumped by a boyfriend I had thought I would marry. I was deeply wounded and grieved by this, and turned to Elisabeth's "Passion and Purity" for answers. That book was very difficult to read. At that time, I found myself deeply disappointed in my heroes (Jim and Elisabeth). Their courtship was not appealing to me, and I did not agree with a lot of Elisabeth's advice. I felt condemned, in fact (I had not sinned in my broken relationship, but I didn't meet "Passion and Purity" standards). Reading it made me feel like I was being yelled at by a very condemning professor I had in college at the time. Reading that book about people I had so admired was like learning Santa Claus wasn't real. I really struggled with how I was supposed to view this couple who had previously inspired me. I chose to still share their story with students, and admire them, but it wasn't the same. That was many years ago.

I eventually married, and am serving as a stateside missionary with my husband. I sort of "forgave" the Elliots for the things I had been bothered by in "Passion and Purity." I continue to share their story to this day. But when I saw "Becoming Elisabeth Elliot" in the bookstore, I knew I had to buy it. I had to unravel the mystery of this woman once and for all. In reading it, I found a woman I related to very much. I got a kick out of Jim's humanity (instead of being affronted by it, the way I was when I read "Passion and Purity" years ago). I took them as they were, no illusions. I admired what could be admired, and I accepted that I, personally, would never have been romantically interested in Jim Elliot, so it was okay if he didn't seem the ideal suitor in my opinion. I found myself relating to Elisabeth more than I ever thought possible. I'm not exactly like her, but I relate to her introspection, and even the confusion she sometimes found in trying to seek God's will (and God was faithful to her, just as He is to me). Even though I knew the story well, I still found myself hoping Operation Auca would succeed and the five men would survive and live long lives. I knew it wouldn't happen, but I found myself hoping it anyway, and cried when their inevitable deaths were described.

But there was something deeper for me as well. Everyone talks about how Elisabeth went back to live among the Aucas/Waidoni. They paint the picture of this selfless woman who forgave her husband's killers. And she did. That is true. But a part of the story that really spoke to me was how hard it was for Elisabeth to work with Rachel Saint. Their conflicts were described in detail, and I am so glad they were. Some people who have reviewed this book have felt that was improper. But I think it was very helpful and validating to all missionaries everywhere. We all have conflicts. There are a lot of psychological and spiritual reasons for the conflicts missionaries have. I have been in some very damaging conflicts with fellow missionaries. It is very frustrating. And mission organizations are so much less helpful or professional about it than secular companies are. I have been shamed by the ministry we serve with over this. I had really wondered if our ministry had some rottenness deep inside, and have worried about it. Reading this book assured me that both I and my sending organization are totally normal. Reading Elisabeth's and Rachel's conflicts were like reading my own diaries. Some of their conflicts were exactly like conflicts I had in the past. It made me feel a sense of peace and closure. It was incredibly healing and validating. At the same time, it was noted that both Elisabeth and Rachel went on to serve the Lord faithfully the rest of their lives, warts and all. That gave me a new perspective on some of the fellow missionaries I have struggled with in the past. They might not be my best friend. They might have been in the wrong in some of this, but they are still faithful, and they're in God's hands. I have been able to forgive one particular person as a result of reading this book. I didn't think I ever would, but God used this to help me. The way the mission agency tried to "help" Elisabeth and Rachel sort it out was totally lame, so similar to the way our ministry had tried to "help" in the past. There was a lot more attention given to superficially smoothing it over than really trying to understand or know the truth. And this told me that, yes, injustice does happen, even in wonderfully ministries. All we can do is trust in the Lord's goodness and justice, and move on in what He has led us to do. Elisabeth's example of moving forward was also an encouragement and challenge to me.

Conclusion, I think everyone in ministry should read this book. I think it gives a very realistic view of a life of walking with the Lord, following HIs will, surrendering to Him, and being human in the midst of God's work in our lives. Five stars.

Nothing overly complicated or intense: This ended a bit suddenly for me, even with the prequel to the second book of the series to read at the end of the book. I would have felt better with the rest of the early story told. Besides that, I enjoyed the read. Nothing overly complicated or intense.

history: B00CNQ7HAU B004FGMDLY B0048EKF3Q B00NMPN46W B00M70YWKK B0028PHC9C B01HXJREHW B0023SDPNG
review:
Thia is hard book to read because of some of the content, but I enjoyed it just the same!: Would not recommend it to anyone under college age! Sisters would understand
And love it. Lawyers and people of that persuasion would also think it was a hard
book to put down.

Another great story: When I started this book by Catherine Ryan Hyde I expected to read an amazing book as her other books were so great. When it started off different I was surprised that I wasnt thrilled with it. It was a story of friends - Suki, Nick, Ollie and Stephen which takes place the beginning of a war, the middle and the end of which brings us through many decades of friendship.

I was prepared to make this a 3 star read but the more I read the book the book hooked I was. The friendship of these men was amazing, heartwarming and chilling. When the bombing of Pearl Harbor draws the US into World War II, Suki and his family are forced to leave their home for the internment camp at Manzanar. Ollie enlists in the army and ships out. And Nick must flee. Betrayed by his own father and accused of a crime he didn’t commit, he turns to Steven for help. Hiding Nick in a root cellar on his family’s farm, Steven acts as Nick’s protector and lifeline to the outside world.

It takes place at a time when people were more narrow minded and not so forgiving. So what I am saying is stay with the story because it will bring you to tears and make your heart wrench because friendship is what it is all about. #fivestars #kindleunlimited

Lots of twists and turns: I havent read a Sandra Brown book in quite some time, so I thought I would go back and check out some of her books. This one sounded intriguing and it did not disappoint. It starts off great with Rye who takes a dangerous mission - transport a mysterious black box through a big snowstorm. Time is of the essence and danger is lurking. Of course, he almost crashes, but survives along with the box.

But when he is met my Dr. Brynn O'Neill and gets into a dangerous situation dealing with bad buys and who gets the box....we find ourselves turning the pages. Quite a few surprises (love when that happens) and a great ending.

Pick this book up for your next read. #fourstars

Lovely story: I am not a fan of cowboy stories but read this one as part of a reading club. I must say that even though this took me out of my usual genre, I loved it. Fast reading, heartbreaking sometimes, we follow Mallory Chance who just left her controlling boyfriend, Jared for a new life in cowboy country. She wants a carefree life, no attachments and happiness as a midwife in a small town.

But we all know that will not happen when she meets cowboy, Colt Daniels who is also broken with his own baggage. Of course they hook up but the healing begins with both of them. Loved the story and a new author to add to my ever growing list.

#fourstars

Another good one by Jackson: This book goes back to 1924 at the Blue Peacock Manor where we find Angelique and her husband Max have disappeared. People think they were on the roof, arguing and both went over the side. But what really happened? Bodies were not recovered and now its 2014, Sarah and her daughters have moved into the house, a new beginning..but there are many ghosts in the old house.

A strange story but one that gives us surprises and secrets you did not know were coming. Great read as always by Jackson.

Author never disappoints!: Wow. An amazing book I finished in one day! I could not put it down and found every chapter better than the last. Thanks to Netgally for this ARC, I have read this author before but was not prepared for this story.

It centers around a therapist (who lost her license, a story in itself) and still helps people put their lives in order as long as she can do it in 10 sessions. In walks Matthew and Marissa who admits cheating on her husband, is sorry and wants to put their lives back together. Of course we follow Avery, who has her own baggage and problems to deal with, but we also find some chilling secrets and surprises along the way.

Due to be released in March 2022, mark your calendars because you wont want to miss this one. #Netgalley #fivestars

A tangled web: Molly and Jake - now theres a love/hate relationship. Hes a lead singer in a band and she wants to become a writer. Can this relationship survive? They fall in love, he writes songs about her but alas, a decade later we find Molly married to someone else in Connecticut with a young daughter.

The story then shoots back and forth giving us a little bit by bit of info on what went wrong, and also how they will meet up again. Throw a woman names Sabrina into the mix and we find a very tangled web indeed.

Thanks to #Netgalley I got to read this one before its release and I am sorry you will have to wait until June 2022 to get your copy. But please put it on your TBR list because once you start reading you wont be able to put the book down.
It's a warm, wonderful story.: This is a beautiful book!  I would recommend it for any age!  (I cried, I'm 80.)
Wrong book inside!!!!!: The outside cover said The Silent Girl.  Inside was a completely different novel by a writer I don't know. I've never heard of that happening before!!  I threw it away!!
Sensuous: A book of poetry sounds...boring.  This volume contains arousing, sensuous, and romantic poems to be shared with your beloved.

FINALLY !!t Music Theory made fun and understandable: James Shipway is a wonderful teacher. I have found a book which teaches basic theory in a very understandable manner. 7th chords ,sus chords,, modes and scales are all presented in a plain and simple way that makes sense and easy to understand. I HIGHLY recommend this book. I can drive a car but I want to know everything it takes to make it go. The more I understand the basics of guitar theory the more enjoyable the ride. Buy this and the other Shipway " No Bull" books .

Wanna make bread then get this book: This book is very detailed and informative. It is not just a recipe book. It discusses the 12 steps to bread making. Bread making is an art and a science. The book labels recipes as formulas which I think appropriate.If you're into making bread ,I highly recommend this book.
Ripped (Off) from the headlines: This is the almost the exact real story about the Allenstown Four.  The total lack of originality is disappointing.
excellent book: I read for entertainment. This book met my expectations
Helps keep coins in order: This book helps keep your coins you have collected in order
Great gift: This is a great gift to give to someone who collects coinc

review: Full of violence, depravity, and excess verbage.: I am a fan of Karen Slaughter's books. This one, however, had she not been the author, I wouldn't have read past the horribly long first chapter that described endless abuse, both sexual, mental, and physical. Then, references back to that past were ongoing throughout the book. At the end, when I was hoping for some exciting courtroom drama, I was disappointed to find more violence and even torture. There was a rather interesting twist at the very end, but that didn't make up for a 436-page disappointment. The book had so much excess wordiness that it was easy to skip over pages at a time. I see that the book did have more than 60% five star reviews on Amazon, so apparently I am one of the few who didn't care for it. Still, hard to recommend this one.

I have a medical background and found it difficult to read. Also, the characters are in two countries and many  of the people investigated have more than one name. Almost need to take notes to read this one!

review: Unusual characters and intriguing story: Jack Lennon is a hard to love, but compelling character.  Detective Flanagan is tough, but all too human.  The other characters are also complex.  The story kept my interest enough that I couldn't wait to pick it up after I had put it down.
Great Read: As usual Ed and Lorraine Warren do not disappoint.  I actually slept with my light on. In a Dark Place is fast paced and binge worthy.

review: Riveting!: I saw the movie many times but I've never read the book until now.  I could not put it down.
Worth waiting for: This book was so good. Such a great story.  It  was a nice  change not to have the book focusing so much on the horrible ways the Nazis treated people.
Great!!  Lots of action and adventure.: This was my first Brad Thor book  and I will definitely read more and would recommend it to those who enjoy action/adventure stories.
Very much enjoyed: But TMI at end. It was a little difficult to follow chain of events at end. It was a frustrating end for me.

Written beautifully for everyone.: It was touching, heartfelt, brave, exciting, and memorable to say the least. Tears,sobs were for Isabelle and Vianne  and families in last two chapters, and recommend for all ages to remember how these times affected so many. Always remember and love one another.

Very intriguing, fun and surprising: Enjoyed from beginning to end with interesting characters and no idea who did what until surprise, exciting and  nerve wracking climax. Looking forward to next in series.
