Too Much Info Dumping: While this book was technically well-written, I ended up DNFing due to the story. I got about two hours into the 10 hour audiobook (or, rather, I'm in the middle of Chapter 5), and could not stand the main character, El. She is so cynical it began to rub me the wrong way. The more I got to know her, the more irritating she got.

The info-dumping is also a huge reason as to why I stopped reading. I feel like it really slowed the pace of the book. In the opening chapter, I felt like Novik just began throwing all this information at us about El and her family and the Scholomance and I didn't really get the point of the plot, and quite honestly, I still don't. I also feel like even though El is the one narrating, I still don't know her? She almost keeps the readers at a distance and I really didn't like that. I also don't understand the monsters/what goes after them. How do they work? How do they exist?

The worldbuilding, while overly done, is also so confusing. As I was reading, I was constantly asking myself clarification questions. Why does this place exist? Why are there no teachers? (I didn't feel like this was 100% answered). Why is there only one school? How does this fit into the real world (because London, Mumbai, and New York are all mentioned repeatedly).With all the world building and info dumping, I assumed questions would be resolved, but in turn, it left me with a sort of dreaded feeling whenever I turned on this book.

I'm a writer, and one of the basic things they tell you about fantasy is that you take one unbelievable thing and make it believable. I personally think Novik tried to take too many elements of the unbelievable type and make them believable. It just did not work for me.

Long & Rambling: Did the authors' interest in uncertainty lead to such an unorganized book.

Rambles on and on. I have studied uncertainty a little and nothing new in this book.

An unforgettable reading experience: There are few books I have read with the power of imagery and emotional realism to affect me so profoundly as Alex Lasker’s The Memory of an Elephant. This is not just another animal story. This is a story that originates in a deep sense of injustice, of moral sin, brought to vivid reality on an epic scale. It is a masterpiece that ranks with the best classics of animal stories.

Africa would not be Africa without elephants. The panoramic scope of the novel blends the life of an elephant with the lives of human players that surround the central character of Ishi. The germ of the story is the trauma of young Ishi, an elephant born in obscurity, whose loss of mother and clan happens to be witnessed by a sympathetic native observer. This much of the tale is based on a true incident. What evolves from that germ is given tragic depth by a masterful telling of a fictional life, poignantly imagined, bringing the reader into the mind of an elephant through the voice of Ishi, interspersed with pseudo-documentary action. The scope of the reader’s consciousness expands with lurid and factually accurate portrayal of the challenges of wildlife against the backdrop of the complex cultural milieu of the human players. Africa would not be Africa without powerful forces and conflicts of interest. Multiple strands of narrative, drawn with vivid characters, are skillfully interwoven in the grand scheme of the tale. But Ishi’s voice is preserved with a humility of purpose, a simplicity and honesty of emotion, that transcends human drama. Ishi’s life validates outrage against greed and killing. Ishi’s perseverance justifies human compassion and love. Ishi’s coming home at the end of a sojourn of 50 years stands as the ultimate measure of good, of justice.

A mirror to Ishi’s character is the beauty of the African landscape, which hovers behind and within everything. It overshadows human purpose, desire, or intention, and lasts beyond individual limitations, even Ishi’s. The greater purpose of the story is that we identify with a sense of the preciousness of life, all life, and especially wild life, and share the basic awareness of these truths that make our own lives meaningful.

Best read on wolves of Yellowstone: Having been bitten by the wolf bug, I first enjoyed Rick McIntyre's accounts of individual lives of wolves famous among Yellowstone watchers.  What Douglas Smith's book gave me was both an overview of all the various packs in the park over its first decade or more, with informative summaries of strategic issues intrinsic to the reintroduction project into Yellowstone, as well as further stories of some of his favorite wolf characters.  It helped to put it all together for me.  The book is extremely well written, flows easily, and is hard to put down.  It is a must read, and a cautionary tale for those who have not, or no longer can get out into the wild themselves.  Thank you for the inspired experience!

A disappointing read: Prepare to dumb-down if you read The Grand Lady of Yellowstone.  This is anthropomorphizing on steroids; this is a book far more about people watching wolves than it is about wolves--472, the grand lady of the Agate Pack, chief among them.  Rife with sophomoric humor, someone has spent a little too long gabbing with people who need to be cajoled to appreciate what they have come to view.  Not that many observations lack interest; but they might be more effective if presented simply and directly, letting the reader see for herself what makes them interesting.  Near the end the book takes on a confessional tone, bringing the author truly front and center.  I would rather have the wolves speak for themselves, in a cleaner, more objective tone.
Nostalgic and informative: I enjoyed this book a lot. It had all the Match Game stories one would want but was also incredibly detailed about Gene Rayburn's career triumphs and sorrows.

If you are expecting a nostalgic revisit to classic Star Trek, this book is not for you: The publication of this book has been delayed at least twice in recent years. My original hope was that it would have been a reflection upon the events of classic Star Trek episodes and movies, with some attempt to stitch together the gaps of what between been shown about Spock on screen. But the final product really is not for someone who shares that hope, as there is--astonishingly--reference to maybe a handful of classic episodes at most--primarily "The Menagerie" and "Amok Time," and those chiefly to talk not about the voyages of Kirk's Enterprise but of Spock's relations with Captain Pike and T'Pring. The book's chief figure outside Spock himself is, much to my chagrin, Michael Burnham. This is why the book was delayed, to allow for updates based upon the second season of Star Trek: Discovery. I don't entirely begrudge this editorial decision, but here much of Spock's life enters into the shadow of an intellectually superior older adopted sister, and it's frustrating regardless of what one thinks of Discovery because it rewrites Spock's whole life path when in reality Discovery was desperate to cash in on the popularity of Star Trek's greatest character after a poorly received first season, and it doesn't seem right to recast the whole direction of Spock's life because of a sequel series that has divided reception at best, leaving the original legendary series barely discussed. The greatest disappointment of all is how little of the book mentions James T. Kirk. There is some nonsense at the end about how Kirk's presence is to be understood on every page, and despite how Star Trek VI actually ends with Kirk admitting his prejudice and teaming up with Spock once again to save the galaxy, the Spock of this book remains estranged from Kirk after the events of TUC and barely reconciles with Kirk after the Klingon peace mission before Kirk dies (though there is no mention of the Enterprise B), and it reads more like the final months of Nimoy/Shatner than anything on screen of Spock/Kirk. In this book, Spock explains to the reader, who is Jean-Luc Picard, that enough has been written elsewhere about the voyages of the five year mission, and that's it, even though the premise of the book is Spock's sharing of wisdom from his whole life. I found the take on Sybok to be interesting and, unlike Burnham, it does not threaten to override the chance to talk about what a buyer of this book probably really wants, which is to talk about Spock's reflections on the episodes and movies with Leonard Nimoy. But so, so little of that is there. I can't recommend this book to someone who comes to it as primarily an original series fan. Some of the attempts to fill in gaps are okay; some are not. There is no reference to how Spock became Captain, for instance. And there is too much attention in some places, like Spock's regret over the mind meld with Valeris. I have never thought that was an assault; it seemed more to me like a body search as would happen to any prisoner to find contraband, although it should have been done privately and not on the bridge. But if one takes the approach that Spock violated Valeris, which this book does, then should one at least expect Spock not to describe what it was like going inside her mind? Yet he does, actually describing her mind as cool; compare that to invasive assault of a different nature and ask if a genuinely repentant assailant would describe sensations of the experience. The tone of JJ Abrams' Spock "Prime" fills the latter pages when Spock considers himself a failure for not helping Romulus as much as he wanted, though this is unwarranted, as it is no fault of his at all. The book often, especially early and late, has Spock referring to things he loved, which simply does not sound like Spock, not even the post-V'ger Spock who found "this simple feeling" of friendship. Saavik plays an interesting role; some might wonder if Spock says she did carry his child from Genesis, but she did not (which is fine with me). I knew some authorial license was necessary to pull off this book, and I was particularly interested in how it would fill the gaps between the series and TMP, TMP and TWOK, TFF and TUC, TUC to TNG, and then TNG to the '09 film. Some of these gaps are better filled than others. But the final word for me is that while the author's afterword claims hope of the reader "hearing" Leonard Nimoy's voice throughout, I heard that so very seldom, especially in the sections in which Spock uses the word "love" so casually. I wanted to like this book. I know it could not have been easy to write. Those who pick it up after coming to Star Trek after 2009 may like it much better than I did. I probably would have liked it more if it would have come out before Discovery, which forced childhood dyslexia, recurring visions of the Red Angel a hospital escape and sibling envy upon the younger Spock, which in my mind was just too much for canon to hold. But this Spock is not the one who has mattered so much to me for so many years. If you think I'm too worked up over a fictional character, by all means enjoy.

Sentimental but never sappy: I purchased this book along with Karen Knotts' recent biography of her father Don, primarily interested in what both books have to say about the production of The Andy Griffith Show. This book is nearly 400 pages, and if you are reading similarly for the early careers in the 1960s of the actors, over half of the book is on that, with plenty of detail on their parents that does not interfere with but actually brings to the fore why Ron and Clint became popular child actors who made rare successful transitions to actors who could do more than be cute on cue. There is no scandal here, although there is no hiding of life's hard bumps and growing pains. Ron does most of the writing, but I feel like I learned more about Clint and his tenaciousness as a performer. If you are a Star Trek fan and want to know a lot about Clint's time on the original series, that gets ample treatment. And one definitely comes to appreciate the intuitively helpful, steady guidance of their parents on who the brothers became.

Enjoyable Murder Mystery!: Carlene O'Conner's series of books are lots of fun and an enjoyable read. Siobhán and the entire O'Sullivan brood are very likeable characters. I look forward to more of Carlene's books!

You would never know This is only Alys second book with how amazing it is. We’re a little deeper into the apocalypse society’s grasps in this book and your heart will race. I’ve loved carter since web of lies but we get a better picture of who this broken brilliant man is. These men absolutely adore Kaycee. I can’t wait for the final book. This is my favorite series so far. Can’t wait to see what else aly  has up her sleeve in her career. Some people were just born to write and aly is definitely one of those people.

It gets better with each page...: I thought the book started rather slow and wondered when  Harry Bosch would make an appearance.  The author finally brought Bosch into the story when detective Renee Ballard sought out his help in a homicide.  Then, both retired Harry Bosch and Ballard  team up to hunt for the killer.  The pace picks up and we find that Renee Ballard gets  herself in several precarious situations.  In the end the bad guys get what they deserve, but Ballard suddenly finds herself on the beach on a surfboard, having been fired from her detective gig.  This leads to the question concerning what job she will seek out next, but we'll have to stay "tuned" for more of the Michael Connelly show to get that answer.  This was not Connelly's best book, but certainly worth reading.

10 Little Indians (on Mars): LOTS of plot holes in this one. NASA outsourced a Mars base? No problem. But they have *no* oversight? Don't monitor *any* communications? I don't think so.

Otherwise, good story. Lots of tension.

review:
Tense thriller: Same gaping plot holes as One Way, plus a few more (NASA sends seven astronauts to Mars, but outsources all communication?).

Aside from such maddingly plot flaws, about one-third through the tension really starts to ramp up, keeping me reading all the way to the end.

PS: I am also a rocket scientist, which perhaps compounds my frustration with the ridiculous plot flaws.

review: A fitting end: I have really enjoyed this series - each book has its strong and honourable characters and the villains who get their just desserts. Smart, Engaging, and Fresh: A Line to Kill could almost be mistaken for an outstanding episode of Midsomer Murders: a festival of sorts at the start, a series of murders, a pair of mismatched detectives, an abundance of red herrings, and a fairly  convincing twist at the end. But there's nothing conventional about the team of Hawthorne and Horowitz, and nothing as entertaining as the author's playful upending of familiar tropes. Another top-drawer performance by the chap who brought us Foyle's War.

A murder mystery mash up in the world of Jane Austen: It was delightful to revisit all our favorite Austen heroines all together in one ill fated house party. What really makes the novel is the small asides and descriptions that play on the well known characters from the original novels (the description of Mrs. Elton alone is worth the price of admission). The mystery itself was less important to me, more a vehicle to have the characters interact. mystery mash up in the world of Jane Austen. Layered, twisty mystery!: Really enjoyed this meta mystery that combines some of my favorite literary styles: locked room(ish) murder, book within a book, writer as detective, and an epistolary twist. I wanted just a little more “meat” to Hannah’s parts or the story,  but still loved that extra creative and engaging layer. Compulsively readable, and I’m still thinking about that last sentence - this would make an excellent book club selection!

Fun and Slightly Spooky Summer Adventure: A truly charming and delectably creepy adventure! I can’t wait to pass this on to my daughter, but she’ll have to fight me for first dibs on the next installment.

Highly Recommend: I loved this character driven, multigenerational story of a dysfunctional New York family. It handles unlikeable characters is a deft way that makes most of them (maybe not all) complicated and interesting instead of just your standard "terrible person." While not for people who need fast paced/plot driven stories - we don't even meet our titular narrator until half way through, and don't her her story until the 75% mark - I adored exploring this family and what made them they way they were.

Are any of us Okay?: I love nothing more than a book whose title somehow adds to the story, and I definitely found that here. A thoughtful novel of families, relationships, and diaspora. I found the perspective of Joan to be very well rounded and nuanced as we read and wonder: is Joan okay, and what does that even look like?

Compelling and bittersweet!: I bought this book on a whim because I had a few dollars left on my Amazon gift card, and I went in completely blind, not knowing what to expect. To my great surprise, I don't know how someone writes so well that I end up with a book hangover from reading a novella, but Lorraine Heath definitely has a way with words. Thus far, I've only read a little bit of her backlist, but everything I've read has been mind-blowing on so many levels. I don't think I've ever cried reading a novella before, but now I can say that I have. The amount of pining in this story.....my God, it was so wonderful, and I don't think I've ever been so satisfied by an act of defiance from a character, and when George decided to propose to Linnie anyway, I was ecstatic.

But then...

I was forewarned at the beginning of this book. I can't fault LH for that. But, damn. I really should've read the rest of this series first. Because I ended up ugly crying. A lot. This is not a traditional romance, but it was fantastically written, all the same despite how much it pulls at your heartstrings. So go read it! Just have the tissues handy when you do.

A good bite!: Not my favorite from this series, but it was still an enjoyable read!

What I liked most about this book:

❤️Lynsay's trademark humor
❤️A very unique storyline (how many times have you read about a vampire romance hero who is a romance author himself?!)
❤️A super surly hero (that has a very marshmallowy inside when it comes to our heroine)
❤️A strong, very determined heroine
❤️A fair amount of steam

Good overall!: For the first half of the book, I hummed along, feeling pretty happy and content, but once the plot twist got introduced, I was thrown for a loop, and honestly had no idea how Jennifer and Gordon would possibly get together, given the nature of what the plot twist was. (Read it, and you'll completely understand what I mean.) I kept telling myself that since this is a romance, there has to be a HEA, but I just didn't see how it was going to be possible with this book! Then we spend the latter half of the book dealing with soap opera-esque family drama and a secondary plot twist that completely erodes the first one. It definitely was unique, and I was glad to see them get together, but by the time these two get back together on the same page--literally and figuratively--we are super late into the book. I would've loved to have seen them together a lot more. Overall, it was enjoyable, but I think it would've been better in a shorter format, like a novella. Less time apart, more time together!

What I liked most about this book:
❤️A very unique plot twist; different than anything I've read before
❤️Lots of pining
❤️A very sweet hero

Love it!: A man on the run wrongly accused of murder and a spinster still grieving her mother's death find that their two worlds collide when the hero is struck by illness. This was such a delightful romp with all my favorite qualities in a book: low angst, a dash of insta-lust, a pinch of intrigue, and a cute horse and dog. (Well, I'm picturing them as being cute, anyway.) Haven't read the beginning of this series yet, but I am super excited to go back and read it. Good comfort read, and well-deserving of 5 stars.

Pretty good: Had some mixed feelings about this one. Oddly enough, I felt like the second book, The Duke and His Duchess, was actually more exciting to me than the first. The first seemed a bit more filler and fluff, with a courtship that was very easy and uncomplicated. They were both quick reads, nonetheless. Nothing too taxing on the heartstrings, and overall, just a good story depicting love and how it evolves—and endures—over time, even when ghosts of the past come roaring back to life; a very realistic storyline, overall.

LOVED IT!: If I could've given this six stars, I would've gladly done so! Where to begin, where to begin... I suppose the inner child in me is the reason why I absolutely love Cinderella re-tellings. Cinderella is, after all, probably why I have always been obsessed with the idea of true love, and finding Prince Charming and having a happily ever after. (Which is exactly what brought me to this genre as I grew older!)

But, wow. I loved everything about this. I love Benedict, anyway, and now, after reading this, I think he's probably going to end up being my favorite Bridgerton brother. (Sorry, Anthony, though I still love you, as well!) It combines some of my favorite tropes (love at first sight, pining, class difference) and all of it comes together in the most magical of ways. It's just fabulous. Go read it if you haven't read it already!

Enjoyable!: Loved the continuation of the Bridgerton family saga! I absolutely love Colin, so I was so happy to read his story. Of the books I've read it so far in this series, I wasn't in love with the main central conflict. Obviously, we knew at some point Lady Whistledown would be unmasked. I just felt like Colin's reaction was a little much for me, though I did understand why he was so protective of her. I ended up giving it a 4 out of 5, but still a very enjoyable read about the family I so love and adore!

Pretty good!: Another Bridgerton book, another great continuation of the series. So much pining, it is absolutely fantastic, so if you're a fan of pining heroes, this should absolutely get added to your TBR! I thought this greatly illustrated the agony of loving someone you shouldn't and loving someone you can't have. I was more of a fan of Michael than Francesca, mainly because she was still fighting her feelings long after things had gotten steamy and that was a bit over-the-top for me, and it drew out things unnecessarily. But overall, I still loved the story and the rawness of it. Just a great series overall.

Short stories offering a glimpse at some Cambodian-American lives in California: Stockton, like Long Beach and Lowell, has a significant number of Cambodian American residents (about 5% of the city’s population), with several “Cambo-American” restaurants, groceries, repair shops, donut cafes, and other small businesses.  It is in this city, 80 miles east of the Eden-like SF Bay Area, that the author has set nearly all of his soulful collection of short stories, a love letter to his region during a period of economic downturn.  Each story is narrated by a young Cambodian-American and shares a story of their attempts to make it in life and career.  But each story has a weight of remembrance of their parents’ traumas at the hands of the Khmer Rouge led genocide; and the effects of survivorship; marriage; divorce; the untimely, early deaths of parents; drug use and addiction; prayer; Moby Dick’s Ahab v Ishmael; and sex. Some of the “traumedy” stories appeared in The New Yorker, Bomb, n+1, Granta and other publications. The author was a graduate of Stanford, its Levinthal tutorial, and Syracuse.  I found his stories interesting and well-crafted, and was happy that several of the characters were recurring across the stories.  I was sad that some stories abruptly ended with that postmodern vagueness, but I realize such is life; events don’t wrap up easily with gift-wrapped closure.  At times I wondered if the author was pursuing an affectation and giving his readers stories that confirm "Orientalist" assumptions, but overall the stories were enjoyable.  I would have liked to have an end-of-book glossary for some of the words, but I assume one was omitted purposely.  (Battambang; cha quai; Mas; Mings; smashers; Oum; Pou; Gongs; amok; (srey; proh; kteuy))

A solid YA book.: <!-- wp:paragraph -->

Yes, I'm WAY behind on my TBR pile. I know this. I'm slowly working through it as I add many more to the stack. It happens.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

To be upfront, I won this book in a contest that was run on TOR.com when the book came out...gosh, 4 or 5 years ago. I loved the cover, knew nothing about the book. It sat on my shelf and if you've seen my YouTube videos, might have seen it on the shelf behind me. It wasn't from lack of desire that I didn't read it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

We recently took a trip to Florida and Georgia. Long flights back and forth. So, I chose to pick a book off the shelf to fill the time. Again, I knew /nothing/ about this book before diving in.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

It was quite apparent after the first couple of chapters, it was a YA book. I almost stopped reading because I wasn't in the mood for a YA book. But, it was the book I'd brought with and my phone wouldn't last the entire journey. Therefore, I stuck with the book.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

Now that I'm done with it, much like many other YA books of this type, I won't continue with the series. This is a personal choice as I don't find books of this type interesting.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

All that said, this is a good book for the right audience. I'm not that audience. Yes, I finished the book. I did enjoy it for what it is even though little caught me by surprise. Again, I'm not the right audience for this book. For the right audience, YA, most likely YA females, this book will be right up their alley. I'd recommend it to My Favorite Daughter were she into Sci Fi.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

SJ did a good job with building out the politics without being too deep. Good building out what a Diabolic is. There's even good character building in this book. If you're the type that loves books like The Hunger Games or even Maze Runner, this book will be something you'd enjoy. Pick it up, check it out. I'm glad to see there is more in the series.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
As with any book, there is a fun typo (no book is immune). There's a scene where someone is thrown into a pit and reaches back up to the main character. Reaches for her "food". This was supposed to be foot and made me laugh out loud on the plane. :)

Like you've never seen it before!: One of the many blogs I read is <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.newsfromme.com/" data-type="URL" data-id="https://www.newsfromme.com/" target="_blank">News From ME</a>. The ME being Mark Evanier. If you like musicals, comics, comedy, magic, show biz, Mark has one of those memories from all those areas and shares stories all the time. He's a writer of books, comics, TV shows, it'd ben difficult to collect all his credits in one location. One of his credits was being an assistant to Jack Kirby...yes, THAT Jack Kirby.

When he said this book was being published, I pre-ordered is right away. When Mark speaks about a project I listen. When he mentions one he's involved with, I pay attention.

I've been a comic fan for as long as I can remember. Mark wrote many of those comics I read as a kid. Mostly funny animal comics. I still remember an issue of the Hair Bear Bunch where everything on the menu of the restaurant they were at had cole slaw, so the one who disliked cole slaw decided to get a gumball and instead, got cole slow from the machine. It's weird to think about things like that.

At any rate, when Mark mentioned that he had an essay in the books, even though I'd read so much about Mark's time with Jack Kirby, I wanted to get this book.

Yes, I've read Fantastic Four many times over the year. I had the version that came with a record and that helped me learn to read. I read reprints, digital editions, and broken up versions. I've seen this comic many times. But never like this.

The creators got a hold of an original Fantastic Four #1 in near mint condition and did high quality scans of the pages. They blew up each panel giving it a page of its own. The entire comic is in the back in its original size on the pages. Also included are essays, one being by Mark. It's amazing to see the up-close detail in the panels and see the coloring and letting. Beyond that, the amazing art Kirby created when almost nothing like this existed. As Mark says in his essay, this book changed comics forever.

It's true.

Your Mother Was Right!: How Not to Die by Dr. Michael Greger will let you know right away...your mother was right. EAT YOUR VEGETABLES!

Being mostly vegan, it was still enlightening to read about how certain foods affect the human body. Eating a more vegan or vegetarian diet is good, but avoiding processed foods has a tremendous benefit to one's health.

I won't advocate eliminating meat from your diet. I get it. But if you consume a mostly meat and processed food diet, read this book, look at the studies, see the research. Replacing some will help, doing more will, obviously, do more.

If you are looking for content that challenges you to engage in serious critical thinking about how 3 nations evolved into our current political and economic quagmires, this is an excellent book to read slowly. Read a chapter and spend time pondering the information and perspectives of Dr. Hill.

It's very much worth your time.

informative alternative point of viewexploring the life of a exceptionally talented woman: The writing style, somewhat repetitive, is not crisp or well organized.  Feels unbalanced and lacks deep emotional feelings.  I am glad I read the book. I learned a great deal about this wonderful spirit giving me a glimpse behind her talent and the issues she dealt with.  Her strength and talents are simply awsome

Well thought out: I received an advance review copy for free, and I am leaving this review voluntarily.
I feel like this book was well thought out and had a satisfactory conclusion. Although a timekeeper may have all the time in the world, I did feel some pressure to get this book read in a timely manner which I think did take away something from the book for me. Being an ebook I can’t be a good judge as to whether this is a long or thick book but it was manageable and probably just the right length for the story; I can’t tell you how much I appreciate this as time travel books can go on and on (I felt this most with the Time Traveler’s Wife).
His book did not allow for a butterfly effect and did have some circling connections from past to present to future but all wrapped up adequately and I’m not one to sit with pencil and paper and write notes on the timeline to make sure it’s all correct. The only thing I had a problem with is the mimic watches: no one knows how the timepiece was invented but they were able to invent a mimic want? And we see how unsafe he mimic watch can be when the wearer is in the wrong place “at the wrong time” while wearing it. Madame Izri and Will stood in specific places when they travelled for this reason and we know what happens to the bad guys BUT how would the bad guys be able to be pulled through time chasing Will while wearing the mimic watches not knowing when he’d be activating the watch or what their surroundings would be like at the present location in the new local. So if the time piece was activated while they were in a car trying to catch up with will or when they were in a building searching for him, etc. who’s to say they wouldn’t just be flung around or into something...
Time travel books aren’t my go to but I have read several and enjoyed the majority for the most part as a silent observer without putting too much effort into understanding which is what I did with this book and I liked it well enough. The characters are few and developed and the story is very fast paced.

Solid 3.5 stars: I received an advance review copy for free, and I am leaving this review voluntarily.
I am a huge fan of historical fiction for the sheer fact that they lead me to true events that I haven’t heard of before which peaks my curiosity to read a fiction about it but also to research and discover the facts. I also, enjoy these books when I do know the true back story because it makes the novel more relatable for me.
In the case of the Last Mona Lisa I might be embarrassed to say I had no idea that the Mona Lisa had ever been stolen! It was so fun to get some real facts on the background of the theft while also joining along in the mystery behind the man who stole it. I was lucky enough to be reading this during the week the History channel ran their podcast on this very event! It was super fun to cross reference the historical facts from the podcast and the books.
This may sound sexist but this was pretty high emotion and drama which I’m not sure I’m used to from a male author. Jonathan Santlofer really did an excellent job painting the character of Luke Perrone. His bad boy background, his draw to his great grandfather’s criminal activity leading to a light art interest, his alcoholic past, and his macho man struggles.
This book makes you want to go to Italy and Paris to see all the pieces of art mentioned and not mentioned. I know I had to stop reading to google artwork multiple times.
As I write this review I’m tempted to give it 4 stars because there wasn’t much I didn’t like about the book but I have a set way of ranking books and this falls in the category of good, would recommend to a friend, but will never reread and probably just forget about.

Take a chance on this one: I received an advance review copy for free, and I am leaving this review voluntarily.
Ok, this to me is multiple stories in one:
1. Rape informational non fiction pamphlet; chuck full of statistics. The subject is not one desired when seeking out a book. What made this work is that the book was upfront regarding the subject of rape but there was the mystery of who the rapist was which kept the book moving. There author did an excellent job giving hints yet keeping the man hidden, even with multiple possibilities. I highly recommend reading past the ending and really reading the statistics and the why behind the book.
2. This wasn’t suspenseful but definitely was a multi mystery. The mystery behind the native America boy that starts off the book and reoccurs throughout, the mystery of what happened to Charlie, and the mystery of who is the rapist. The author did a great job ebbing and flowing these different elements into the story to keep readers engaged and on their toes.
3. A travel/destination book. I had never heard of Montezuma, the castle, the sink hole, etc. I love our national parks and my kids have earned a few junior ranger badges and now I feel I absolutely have to go to AZ and see this site for myself. The real life location and all of the reasearch to provide such accurate information really set the scene and made this story feel more real.

Good for gothic novel fans: I received an advance review copy for free, and I am leaving this review voluntarily.

I do like a gothic novel and this fits the bill. I like a bleak atmosphere and drug out mystery with a little supernatural suspense.

I think the characters could have been a little more developed visually speaking. It was very hard to imagine what Vaughan actually might look like: her short and frumpy? But dark haired and eyed and pretty? A lame leg and disfigured foot were very prominent but that was about all.

Nick was better described but I think only because his appearance transformed as his health improved.

I also don’t know why Rose Dixon would look like a princess or own a blue silk dress, how Joe looked except that he was good looking to Vaughan, etc.

The crying night child added a little suspense but fell very flat and kind of made no sense in the end.

I don’t think Mrs. Dixon’s actions as a midwife did anything to enhance the story and Bedford and Mrs. Wilson’s actions were also a little strange.

I read quickly through the second half of the book but it was pieced together a little too complexly with everyone having a piece in the puzzle although again I felt this completely unnecessary for the actual story and imo it actually took away from it a little making things confusing with a lot of needed explanation tied together.

The end concluded in a weird feminist way which I understand was Vaughan’s thing from the beginning but also jarring after all of the events at Morton. And the reunion and happily ever after for all involved was almost wrapped up with a bow too well for my liking.

Basically I really liked all of the book until the ending which probably to most was very satisfying but for me was disappointing.

Between gothic novel and pirate adventure: I received an advance review copy for free, and I am leaving this review voluntarily.

First I’ll start by saying as an advanced reader copy in electronic format I ran across some problems. 1. Whenever a word was cut off at the end of a page and continued via a hyphen, it would not continue on the next page; the next page would start a whole word or two. This was extremely frustrating as I’d either have to guess fill in the blanks or change the font or size to adjust the word so it wouldn’t be cutoff. This happened a lot. Another drawback was the index and maps were not made known to me until the end after I’d finished the book. It would have been nice to have had the maps to reference prior and throughout the reading as well as the language translations which again I did not know about until after completing the book.

I appreciate a historical fiction which this was and honestly the post script was one of the more interesting parts.

I don’t even really know how to describe this book as it goes in soooo many directions. The beginning is pretty miserable and when Ruth’s story is told without Owen it has a Wuthering Heights, Ethan Frome feel about it. Then when they are together or turns into a pirate adventure story. Ruth is a heroine of sorts but her actions are so questionable especially for the period that it’s almost too unrealistic to read. I also feel that the writer would lead us to believe one thing would happen by then end of a chapter then the start of the new chapter would begin the complete opposite making the thoughts/ideas/plans feel unreliable. The ending Is just too fantastic to believe and almost doesn’t fit the tone of the book. It would have made more sense to leave it as an unhappy ending or unclear but instead it’s all neatly wrapped up and all’s well. Overall it had its ups and downs and if you can stick with it there is probably a few chapters you will enjoy.

Timing Seems Wrong: I am surprised to see that this book has so many very positive reviews. It has a pretty good story, although the plot is pocked with improbable twists. There is a subplot that adds very little. The protagonist takes some silly risks — but that is not unusual in mystery/thrillers. The writing is generally good, with the exception of some usage errors like dangling participles. What really bothered me was the timing of the story. It takes place in two time periods: 1977 and “the present day.” Since the book was published recently (2019 or 2020), I took “present day” to mean around 2017 or later. That means that forty years have passed since the crime that fuels the story took place. The two main characters in the book were both teenagers at the time of the crime — which means that in the “present day” they would be in their mid-to-late 50’s. Yet, they do not behave like people in their 50’s, and the adults from 1977 do not behave in the “present” like people who are over 70. They all act much younger. A good editor could have persuaded the writer to shorten the time between the events without losing much of the story and helped her to deal with the usage issues.

Beautiful item and exceptional service: This book is one of the most beautiful and interesting books on art that I have experienced. I love Vermeer’s paintings. I am also an artist and really enjoy what the author has done in this book. The book has very nice prints of small parts of Vermeer’s paintings, along with the author’s thoughts on what the artist was intending to do by his placement and rendering of the object/person in the detail. It is so well done. And the seller was prompt and very careful in their packaging of the book when they sent it to me. I am very happy that I decided to buy this (rather expensive) book.

Hard to put down: Enjoyable easy to read story that I could not put down until the end. Marissa Clarke has a gift for creating engaging places with characters who  are fun and unique in their own special ways.  The end was a bit of a surprise and definitely is a warm fuzzy happy ending.

PERFECT for October!: I am a Xennial that loved Fear Street, Goosebumps, Christopher Pike ... etc. So, if there's a creepy middle-grade book available, I am all over it! What Lives in the Woods is just the right kind of creepy for me! I was on the edge of my seat, but not so creeped out I had to put the book down. This would make a great family October read-aloud, or a read-aloud in an upper elementary or middle school classroom. Or just for your middle age kiddo (8-12) that loves creepy books!
A must have for middle grade readers!: If you have a middle grade reader and you haven’t handed them Barbara Dee’s books, change that immediately! They are a must have for this age group!!!

Perfect for fans of Daisy Jones and the Six!: This was one of my most anticipated reads of 2022 and it did not disappoint! I’ve been a fan of Jane Green for a really long time and have read her newest book each year almost as soon as it came out! This one was such a fun one - I loved the 60s setting with the rock and roll background (and yes, lots of drugs). I recently finished Daisy Jones and the Six and this was the perfect book to read right after it.

Save the Monarchs!: We absolutely loved this adorable picture book!! Perfect for families or classrooms that are learning about butterfly life cycles. My daughter wanted to go out and plant milkweed right away!

Differential equations for Dummies: Really easy to read and understand.  I bought the book to help with my tutoring, to give me alternate ways of teaching differential equations.  Overall, it is a good book, but I've found a few errors, especially in the Laplace Transform section.  The Transform table is incorrect.
Twisted: Though I liked the twists to the story and the basic characters, I did not like who was found to be Jack's parents. That's a little too twisted for me.

Russian spy conspiracy: Good read for anyone into government conspiracies. Some things were a little farfetched but overall an entertaining.
Background on Kate and Will helps with other books .
beautiful cards: these cards are beautiful==large but did not require extra postage==the box that they came it can be used later!

Best US history book I've read: I rarely review books on amazon but this one is amazing. It is so well researched and well written. Engaging, new information is presented in an easy-to-read way that actually sticks in my memory. I wish history had been this good in school!

This is a classic texrbook with an exhaustive history of the Arab peoples.: This is not light reading, it is an academic, extensive history of the Arab peoples covering pre-Islamic times through the 20th century. If you are looking to acquire knowledge of the The Arab culture and the rise of Islam in detail, this is an excellent book to start with. It is a classic textbook on the subject.
Good value, fast shipping: As a fan of the history of the H.L. Hunley, this book is a must to finally learn what happened to the 8 man crew of the Hunley. This book explains the mystery.

A good summary of the financial mess we're in.: The writer makes a lot of sense about what has happened to our financial system and how we got there. The scary part is that there is no good way out of the mess at this point, as the author goes through the scenarios that are left for the Fed to do. It's clear in this book that the Fed has boxed itself into a corner and has no real strategies to get out of it. I think the author has done his research and presented the information in an understandable way.

Action filled story: The story is based in the Detroit, MI area and it was good to recognize some of the places mentioned. However, I don't know why the author didn't mention any of the restaurants by their real names since none of the action was happening in the restaurants. There was one place where Belle Isle was referred to as Belle Island (nope, no one in Detroit ever called it that) but another place where it was correctly named. Really terrific story!: This is a fabulous book! The premise was different, but well carried out. Strong, lovable characters that were realistic and deep.  Truly enjoyed watching Nick and Sasha get their HEA. Would love for this author to write more M/M romances!

review: Wow!!!: I love these books. They are so heart wrenching and down to real life. This book cut to my very soul. I lost my Husband a year ago. This brought out all the feelings I am feeling. Which is scary and real. But so true. Lisa Regan is a great writer. Josie Quinn is so very believable.

Fiery YA Epic Fantasy: 4.25/5 Stars (Super specific, I know!)

Holy heavens, this book. Full disclosure, I don’t read epics very often. The simple reason being... they are too long. I made an exception for this book and...it was phenomenal. There came a point where I had my own “all is lost” moment when I’d been reading it for days and I was only 50% through. I started to wonder if I'd ever finish it. I did and I’m soooo glad.

~Plot
You will fall inlove with the world of the Fireborn Epic. Of Fire and Ash is an epic fantasy that throws us into a war-torn world of fire-breathing horses, gut-wrenching battles, and outcasted royalty. This is what makes the novel worthwhile. The solborn concept is so fresh, fantastical, and somehow realistic. Bravo for this fantastic world-building.
I also loved that the author created art for each breed of solborn. I found myself wondering what these majestic creatures looked like. It was such a pleasure to visit Gillian’s instagram and actually see what I was reading about.
There is definitely a different “feel” to each storyline. Ceridwen is very much the military fantasy plot. Rafi was kind of a superhero story line (quiet life gets interrupted by some terrible event and he discovers that he has a magical “power”...it’s not a power...I just don’t want to give anything away). Jakim’s storyline is much more emotional, as he struggles the most with abuse.
The overall pacing of the novel was great. I was invested with Ceridwen’s story the most from about 1-50%. I started to waver at that point. Then I really got into Rafi’s perspective. Jakim was fairly steady throughout until the end when I was so invested in Ceridwen and Rafi’s perspective that poor Jakim was almost an interruption. (Sorry, Jakim!).
~Characters
Hands-down, Rafi is my favorite character in this book. I admired Ceridwen’s fire (literally) and Jakim’s determination, but I connected the best with Rafi. He’s funny, his actions are believably cowardly, and I was cheering for him the entire time. I loved seeing him develop throughout the entire novel.
And his “sea demon?” I want one. Desperately. Their friendship was so vibrant.
Having said that, all of the characters were complex and well-written.

~Writing
I would say that this is a traditional fantasy novel. Third person perspective, multiple viewpoints, rich descriptions of the environment, magic, etc and the people speak an easy-to-read version of medieval English.
Gillian Bronte Adams is an extremely talented writer. Her descriptions were poetic yet not overwhelming. And honestly, the writing is flawless.
Having said all that, I became a little winded at that 50-75%.

~Content
Ages 12+, probably. No swearing or any other kind of content that would be bad for younger teens. It’s just a huge book with epic battle scenes.

Would I Recommend?
Definitely. This is a LOOOOOOOOOOOOOONG book but if you can get through it, the ride is definitely worth it.
Thank you so much Gillian Bronte Adams and Enclave Publishing for letting me read this ARC!

Exciting YA Fantasy for Fans of The Chronicles of Narnia: Fyrian’s Fire is a vivid, magic-filled journey and I really enjoyed the ride! I think it’s perfect for fan’s of the Chronicles of Narnia series, but it’s spiked with a touch of romance to really engage a female teen audience.
I really enjoyed it and would definitely recommend.
~Plot
The story begins with tension and that’s what had me turning pages until the very end. Tess;s drama held me at first until the larger danger of an invading kingdom, dying matriarch, and magical creatures, took over.
I loved the world of Fyrian’s Fire the most. I loved the concept of animals wielding golden magic, evil animals wielding red, and I loved the shenil. The magic was so unique and visually vivid, but totally believable. I also thought the author did a great job of world building, with the promise of exploring more in the future.
I still can’t figure out what happened to Ember (did I miss that??) but everything else tidied up so well that it doesn’t bother me too much.
~Characters
Tess isn’t my usual cup of tea, but I enjoyed her nevertheless. She’s a little prideful yet introverted. It was a very interesting combination. She’s a noblewoman brought up under the spotlight, expecting all of her needs to be met by her new fiance, Prince Linden. Only, he won’t give her the time of the day. On one side, you feel pity for her, on the other, you want to shake her.
I loved her character journey. It was perfect.
Linden was kind of an unlikeable character, but in a good way? He was totally believable. As in, his faults actually made him likable (unlikeable).
Tynaiv himself was a likable gray character. Loved his personality. However, I kept wondering why he was so drawn to Tess? It seemed like he was right from the get-go, even though she was a noblewoman. Still, I liked his part in the story and the chaos he causes.
I think Ryon was my favorite character. The kid was a beast with a slingshot ;)
~Writing
More of a traditional fantasy style. Similar to Narnia, I’d say, but much less wordy. There were points, particularly at the end, where I started to skim, but I think that’s more because of my own writing preferences rather than a fault with the author.
~Content
I’d feel comfortable allowing audiences 12+ read this, just be aware that there’s a couple quick kissing scenes, epic battles, and some animal fighting.
~Would I Recommend
Yes! If you’re a fan of the Chronicles of Narnia, you’re almost guaranteed to enjoy this book. It’s well-written, full of action, and promises more magical adventures in the future.
The publisher allowed me to read this ARC. This review is voluntary and my opinions are my own

Loved this Werewolf Romance: It’s been a while since I’ve read a good werewolf romance. First Shift is GREAT. There are so many things that make it stand out. First and foremost…Sam. He’s the hero the YA world is looking for. I feel like a lot of werewolf books lean on that alpha male thing. Sam is not like that at all. He’s a cinnamon roll boyfriend. Sweet, considerate, yet masculine and squeal-worthy. I love that we took a deep dive into his perspective. Honestly, HE feels like the main character of this book, rather than Megan and I loved that.
I also loved the themes throughout the book…mostly “love is a choice.” Man, those conversations were so deep and honestly thought-provoking. There’s this realness to this book that makes it so memorable.

~Plot
The first 50% of the book mostly focuses on Megan’s transformation into a werewolf. It’s very…intense. And detailed. And angsty. Part of me loved that. Part of me didn’t at times. I was sucked in IMMEDIATELY. I faltered around 30-50%. After that, I became obsessed. Couldn’t put the book down, read it past bedtime, the baby can take care of herself, type of obsession.
The worldbuilding in First Shift was actually pretty impressive. It’s hard to make a werewolf story unique but AJ Skelly actually pulled it off. There’s definitely a promise of a larger, more robust werewolf world for future books.
I did think the ending was oddly abrupt. I ached for a little more closure between the characters and where they arrived (trying really hard for no spoilers here). Having said that, I am anxious to dive into book 2.
~Characters
Extremely well-done. I felt like everyone had genuine personalities. Sam was certainly my favorite but not because he made a great love interest. He’s just a good dude and an extremely likable character. I struggled with Megan but I don’t think that’s the fault of the author, so much as it’s a personal preference of mine.
The relationship between Megan and her grandpa was beautiful though. I think in a lot of YA fiction, the protags are very independent and parental figures seem to go MIA. In First Shift, you see Megan evolve from a totally dependent teen to an independent woman that is able to still have frank, honest conversations with the guy that raised her. I loved their relationship.
~Writing
For the most part, the writing was fantastic. Great dialogue, fight scenes, gut-wrenching descriptions of the shift…I mean, I loved it. Oddly enough, some of the writing got a little repetitive and choppy towards the end of the book. I started noticing repeated sentences (just stated in a slightly different way). This obviously wasn’t a deal-breaker, but it did pull me out of the story.
~Content
PG-13, I would say 15+. Little to no cussing. There’s some werewolf violence. Steamy kisses. Talk of sex (it’s kind of an important plot point) but very teen-appropriate.
~Would I Recommend?
YESSSS. If you’re intrigued by werewolf romance, you need this book. If you simply love YA urban fantasy, you need this book. Can’t wait to read Rogue Shift!
Thank you to Book of Matches Media and AJ Skelly for allowing me to review this ARC.
This is a totally voluntary review and all of my opinions are my own

A Great Cookbook: We ordered this cookbook after watching the TV Program on their top 20 recipes in the last 20 years. There are so many fantastic recipes that we are dying to try. I’m sure he dislikes some performers but this is not what this book is about, he wants us to know some great people.  No gossip here, no juice, just funny people.

The book’s title says it all.: It is all about him.  For the most part everything is the best, everybody he meets is the best and everything has been the best.  I wish him the best and I hope it is all true.  Kinda boring though.
For Great Grandson❤️: As described!
As described✅: For Great Grandson ❤️
Not your typical werewolf tale: This is tale of a heart breaking beginning but oh my stars and garters what a tale ! Read along to discover Barnabas riveting story. This is an absolute must read. !
All of his stories are great.: That's all one needs to know.
Written by a Wonderful Human Being!!: Every book that Mitch Album writes is a treasure.  Wish I could have gotten a signed copy as I have signed copies of several of his books.

A Book Written to be Mother of a Screenplay.: It will absorb you and be difficult to put down, a good read in spite of being loosely edited and bettered if a few thousand words were shaken out. Add it to your reading list.
Awesome Book!: If you are a fan of Charles Band and Full Moon this book is for you! I promise that you will love it.

Great addition: If you are a series addict and love romantic suspense Stephanie St. Klaire should be on your one click list. Action, adventure, suspense and humor in every book.  Eli and Cally are well written and will draw you in to their world.  I couldn't put it down.

Where to begin?: There's no per-chapter overview (nor any general over-view); Ehrenbach just starts at about one-million B.C. and references every important individual who's ever lived south of the border.  Six hundred pages without a guide or an explanation of where he's going.  Jam-packed with pages of names and places that presumes you already know Mexican history and just need more detail.  (Six hundred pages adds maybe too much detail.)  Not even the maps are much help (in the paperback edition; the hard-cover may have had better graphics.  Written many years ago, contains some politically incorrect memes & tropes.  Nonetheless, everything you ever wanted to know about this important neighbor.

Utterly charming!: If you were in advertising, magazines or publishing in the 1960s, you remember Ed Sorel.  Maybe not his name (although he was...and is...justifiably famous) but you will immediately remember his style: he was...and is...one of our top-ranked caricaturists, illustrators, cartoonists.  This book is his autobiography of growing up in the world of Madison Avenue, New York magazine, The New Yorker, Esquire, Vanity Fair (back when it was a great magazine), Rolling Stone, GQ, the Atlantic, the New York Times, and on and on.  Like Zelig, he was here, there, everywhere...and he knew absolutely everybody worth knowing  He tells his story in a warm, personable style: his humble beginnings, his struggles, his triumphs, and--as the title promises--the book is profusely illustrated.  Very.

A promising tale disappears in thin air: Alexandra Kleeman has terrific powers of description, but she's not much of a story teller.  "Something New" gets off to a wobbly start, with a shaggy story about a book author who accepts a menial job with the film company  which is turning his book into a movie.  You expect a sarcastic, satirical comedy like something out of Terry Southern.  The Left Coast is awash in a water-substitute called WAT-R (clever).  Nothing much happens for the first few hundred pages (of a 350-page book), until the realization that WAT-R is causing something like dementia in all who drink it.  A good premise for sci-fi, fersure, but here it's the writing that's becoming demented.  The behavior of Patrick, book author, and Cassidy, the puckish star of the film being made, becomes more and more erratic, as they caper around in the desert in an End-of-Days scenario.  Well, what remains of the plot disappears up its own tail and the reader is left with a feeling of abandonment.  Not resolution, not satisfaction.  Nothing.  Nothing at all.

For our future entomologist: Sometimes it is hard to get my grandson to read and the have to read something every school night. This book was grabbed out of the book and disappeared upstairs. At dinner he had lots of things he found in the book to tell us about. He loves bugs and Smithsonian has made a great book on his favorite insects.
Cute intro to cute animals but better than fuzzy kjttens: No fuzzy kittens but you will go "awwwwww"

Compelling worldbuilding: Worldbuilding. I’m quite convinced, now; worldbuilding is the single most important factor in excellent science fiction. It’s not the only important factor, mind you, but it is the one thing that makes the most difference. Building an entirely new world is something at which this author excels, and nowhere is it more evident than in the Endurance series.
I have come late to the party, in some ways, and Mongrels United is the first book in this series that I have read. (It takes a while to learn the significance of the title, though the journey is well worth it to make the discovery. It’s important, trust me on that.) The book was so well-plotted, the characters so well-developed and — dare I say it — relatable, that I almost couldn’t tell that I was stepping into the latter parts of a lengthy series. That, in itself, is a gift from the author: I was welcomed, even though I hadn’t arrived at the beginning.
The Endurance, a generational ship that was built in space and has now been traveling toward its final destination for over 600 years, is as much a character as the people who are its passengers. As the plot progresses, the Endurance becomes a living, breathing character of its own, and the story of the ship marches alongside the stories of the captain’s chief of staff, her friends, and the discoveries they make as they attempt to find a solution to an ever-deepening problem. The world of the Endurance is deeply multi-textured and the detail of the everyday lives of its 5,000 inhabitants (not more, not fewer) is astonishing. One of my favorite moments in the book is an excellent example of this exquisite attention to detail. Grady, the chief of staff, shows us her writing box. Inside were items we would recognize: a pad of paper and a pen. Nash, who she is interviewing, is out of his depth. He guesses that it’s paper, though he has never seen any before. The pen is confusing, and when she writes he can’t read it and thinks she must be writing in some kind of code. He can read her printing, with some effort, since it doesn’t look exactly like text on a screen. But, Nash wonders, why has she learned how to do something so unnecessary? Grady answers in one of my favorite moments of the book: “My father learned of theories that the physical act of writing makes learning more thorough and efficient. The hand-eye coordination is part of it. To write out something yourself makes the words stick in your memory.” (Truer words...)
I highly recommend Mongrels United. It’s an exciting story with all shades of emotions, a mystery (that I did not solve, which doesn’t happen often these days), a romance, and so many intriguing details that you will enjoy discovering for yourself. How to name children when they are assigned to you, rather than being born to you? There’s an answer for that, and it’s a marvelously inventive one. What about food, clothing, furnishings, education, entertainment, transportation, maintenance, and all of the other thousand-and-one details of life? There are answers for all of those, too, and it’s a fascinating ride. Dive right in! I did, and it was a great read.
I received a complimentary copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.
Oh,yes. In addition — for those sticklers out there like me, and I know there are some — I abhor bad spelling, usage of the wrong words and, most of all <shudder>, the misuse of homophones – those pesky words that sound alike but do not mean the same thing. I’m happy to note that all I found in this book was a handful of typos and nothing else on my bad list. The fun factor in reading this book was much higher because of this.

A joy to read: I don’t often like “sweet” historical romance novels, but I absolutely love Sofi Laporte’s books! She writes lyrically, creates evocative mental images, and has a far better command of language than most writers I have read — and I read a great deal.

Lady Ludmilla’s Accidental Letter was a joy to read. There was a journey through a wide variety of emotions, and I couldn’t help but be annoyed, bewildered, concerned, devastated, excited, fidgety, guilty, and happy whenever Lu was. It was a real rollercoaster of a ride, with occaasional chuckles and laughing out loud. I was reluctant to put it down (but my family, quite unreasonably, expected dinner), and I was invested in the story from the very beginning.

The plot is great fun, and I was surprised at the ending, which was very satisfying indeed. The characters are well-drawn and three-dimensional, their emotions are appropriate and never rushed, and not once is there a case of someone believing gossip and immediately going forth to do something incredibly stupid. I truly appreciate that last part!

I received a complimentary copy of this book in exchange for an honest review, and I mean every word of it. If you are looking for something amusing to lift your spirits, or for a fun read while wrapped up in a soft knitted afghan on a cold winter’s afternoon, look no further than Lady Ludmilla’s Accidental Letter. It’s marvelous.

Atmospheric mystery novelette: Although a novelette, light in its number of pages, The Indecent Agent is jam-packed with content.  The atmosphere of South Africa is all but tangible; I could see it, feel it, and even smell it.  Historical details abound, advancing the plot and further enhancing the sense of both place and time.  The fully-developed characters welcome the reader into a rapidly developing mystery as it progresses, moving along at speed to its conclusion.  The author, well-known for her ability to develop complicated plots and resolve them in unexpected ways – and without ever cheating the reader – does not disappoint in this story.  I received a complimentary copy of The Indecent Agent and am giving my honest opinion.  It is well worth a read!

Another great Patterson novel.: Keeps you reading. Can’t put it down. Alex Cross at his best.
Fulls of excitement and mystery. End will be a surprise.
Alex cross at hi best: Liked the dual aspects of the book with Alex involved in a case as well as his one trial. Could be a little slow in parts, but always picked up.
another Patterson hit: Keeps your interest from comer to cover with  adventures of Bree, Sampson and Alex. Descriptions of battles well done. You won’t want to put it down.
Past and present magically  collide: I loved the balance of history, love, loss, restoration, and a long-suffering hope. I feel like I've visited the island and experienced the culture.
Love this book!: This is a wonderful toddler read along book! And such a cute story! I used it with my oldest grandson and now I’m buying a copy for my newest addition a granddaughter!

I couldn’t put it y!: I enjoyed the fast pace of the book.
The ending was a clever twist.
I really recommend it
