Engaging Story & Characters: As a fellow author, I look at the writing style, plot, and those supporting cast of characters. For me, Tingle got all three. The style is crisp and tight enough to have kept me engaged, as was the fast-paced plot. And those characters? Who wouldn't be entertained by Floppy? His eccentricity and unending knowledge of just about everything, both useful and trivial, made me laugh quite a lot. Dale with his rough-edged loyalty and friendship was irritating at times, but also touching. Overall, I loved the story and will read the next in the series...so, hurry up, Tingle! I'm anxiously waiting!
I like it: My 1 year old laughs at this book. It just does realistic animal sounds only 4 or 5 animals but he likes it and that’s all I care for
Excellent Book!: Having read over a dozen books on Custer and the Little Big Horn this book gives insight to the battle movements that I have not read before. Highly recommend this book.

"Life had manifested the heart's invisible furies on his face...": The Heart's Invisible Furies is the most magnificent book I have read in a very long time. I am, admittedly, a reader who has shied away from long tomes of late. After a bit of a reading slump, it has been difficult for me to get through a novel that is more than 350 pages without feeling ready for it to end... but this book - this book was different. I was hooked from the very first paragraph, and became so engrossed in the life and world of Cyril Avery that 580 pages passed by in the blink of an eye, and I was left wanting another 580 pages to devour! My only regret is that I had not picked this book up sooner.

And what a tale John Boyne has crafted. This story is that of a young man coming of age in an Ireland that is still holding fast to the tenets of the Catholic Church; an Ireland that shuns homosexuality yet looks the other way at the many crimes and indiscretions of those in power. Growing up in these turbulent times, Cyril Avery discovers not only who he is, but also what true, lasting love and happiness are, and the power of atonement and forgiveness.

Not since reading Angela's Ashes have I felt so morose and joyous at the same time, as is fitting for two books about bleak times in Irish history. The characters are all perfectly flawed and fleshed-out, and there wasn't one that I didn't love/hate at least once during the book. I laughed out loud too many times to count, and I wept at the conclusion of The Heart's Invisible Furies. I don't want to give away too much of the storyline, so I will just implore you to READ THIS NOVEL. I would be willing to bet that it will stay in your heart for a very long time.

An epic family saga set in the last great American frontier: Ughhhhh THIS BOOK! I loved it. And honestly, I kind of wanted to hate it... but it was a wonderful read. Why did I want to hate it, you ask? I've long felt that Kristin Hannah's novels are overhyped and overly-verbose, but to be completely fair, The Great Alone is the first one I have actually finished. The Four Winds was a DNF for me - I found it to be too depressing and, quite frankly, rather boring - so I was very hesitant to pick up another 500+ pager from Hannah. I am so glad I gave this book a chance, though, as it turned out to be one of my top five reads of 2021.

The Great Alone chronicles the journey of one family, the Allbrights, who move to remote Kaneq, Alaska in the 1970s after the patriarch, Ernt, returns from Vietnam. Ernt was once a loving family man to his wife Cora and daughter Leni, however the experience of the war left a horrible mark on him and he is prone to depression and outbursts of anger and violence. As the family settles in Alaska and learns to deal with an unforgiving landscape and harsh winters, coupled with neighbors who do not share Ernt's view for the future of their small town, Ernt's fragile mental state begins to rapidly deteriorate. Soon, Cora and Leni realize that they are in a fight to survive not only the elements, but also an imminent danger right in their own home.

Hannah's characters certainly were realistic in their emotions, flaws, desires, and actions. I absolutely detested Ernt, and I really could not like Cora for a good 2/3 of the book, but I felt she redeemed herself toward the end (albeit only when backed into a corner). Leni was a wonderful character to get to know, and seeing the world through her eyes was in part like reliving one's teenage years - the quintessential feeling of being awkward and out of place, but also falling in love for the first time and finding a previously untapped inner strength. I came to care deeply about what happened to Leni, along with her friend-turned-love Matthew. The story was an epic, emotional ride set in the wilds of Alaska, and it really inspired me to want to visit (although not in the winter!) and experience the landscape for myself.

I'm now planning to tackle The Nightingale in 2022 - I'm hoping it will be an experience on par with this book, as I would highly recommend The Great Alone to all.

A unique and intriguing plot concept, but the execution fell short.: Matt Haig's The Midnight Library has gotten so much hype over the past year that I felt I needed to see what all of the fuss was about.  Unfortunately, I cannot say it was the life-changing experience I was hoping for.  While it was an enjoyable enough read *at times*, large portions of this novel felt either too preachy and predictable, or just plain boring.  The premise was certainly unique - once you die, you go to the Midnight Library, a sort of in between place (not life but also not true death) and in the library you are able to choose from an infinite number of books, each one telling the story of what your life would have been like had you made a different choice at any point in time.  The execution of the plotline, however, fell way short of the mark for me.  I didn't particularly care about Nora, our main character, or any of the myriad of people she met in her journey through her alternate lives, and more often than not I questioned whether I was really reading a novel, or a self-help book instead.  By the last few chapters I was very ready to be done reading, and while I certainly did not HATE this book, it wasn't worthy of a place on my shelves of favorites, so I left it in my local Little Free Library for someone else to hopefully enjoy more than I did.  Ultimately, it was in between 2.5 and 3 stars for me so I rounded up for reviews.

This creepy book is a super slow burn.: It seems that the literary world was much abuzz about Mexican Gothic around its release, so I recently grabbed a copy and eagerly settled in for what turned out to be a very, very, VERY slow burn of a novel. I have been looking for a book that will really scare the pants off of me, and had high hopes for this one. The book centers around Noemi Taboada, a young socialite from Mexico City who, upon receiving a frantic, terrified letter from her newly-married cousin Catalina, sets off to the remote mountainous wilderness of Mexico to check up on her. Catalina is living at High Place, her new husband Virgil Doyle's family home, and once Noemi meets the entire Doyle family and spends some time (a few days? weeks? I'm still not sure...) roaming the house and grounds, she begins to realize that something is very wrong at the foreboding estate. Little does she know that her troubles - strange, vivid dreams and walls that seem to listen to conversations - are just the beginning of the horror she is about to face.

Horror is what I was really looking for when reading Mexican Gothic, and I truly believe that was what Silvia Moreno-Garcia was aiming to convey, but for me this book started off agonizingly slow and repetitive (how many times can Noemi wander the cemetery full of mushrooms) and about 3/4 of the way through, turned just plain creepy and gross. I can't say I was scared at any point, but certainly felt sick to my stomach at some of the scenes. I found Noemi to be vapid and unlikable, and the rest of the characters were very one-dimensional. The only character I cared about at all was Francis. I was intrigued by his amateur botanist hobby and I found that I was rooting for him and hoping for a good outcome on his behalf. Francis came across as kind, sincere, and timid, and I felt for him throughout, but even his storyline couldn't make up for the mostly slow pace followed by weird twists and turns that happened at a frenzying pace at the conclusion of the book.

Moreno-Garcia has a vivid style and definitely shows potential, and as the story was left a bit open-ended, I would be interested to see if she writes a sequel at some point... although maybe not interested enough to read it myself. Unfortunately after reading Mexican Gothic, I'm left with my scaredy pants intact and still on the hunt for that elusive great horror novel. 2.5 stars rounded up to 3 for reviews.

An epic and magical saga in the making!: 4.5 stars – what an enthralling and magical tale! I am not generally a fan of fantasy reads, but despite that, and the fact that I let A River Enchanted languish on my shelf for over a month before finally reading it, I was engrossed from the beginning to the end with the sweeping saga of Jack, Adaira, Sidra, and Torin. The mystery of the missing lasses of Cadence also held my rapt attention, and I found myself truly rooting for the Tamerlaine clan (and of course loathing the Breccans) and hoping for the best outcome for the young girls.

I cared about Jack and Adaira as people, but I did not really care about their love story, which felt a bit forced from the outset. They were supposed to be nemeses, but not much background is given to that other than the repetitive mention of one incident when they were children which caused Jack to leave the isle of Cadence for ten years. I would have liked the author to have delved a bit deeper into this relationship and fleshed out their history, because it would have made their change of hearts and falling in love more impactful. In my opinion, Sidra and Torin’s love story was much more genuine, relatable, and realistic. They really are the star couple of this novel.

There were a few twists which really added complexity to the story and made for good segues into the next book, A Fire Endless, which will be released later this year. I am not usually one to read a series but I am eagerly anticipating the conclusion to this story and will be picking the sequel up as soon as it’s available!

A gorgeous novel with an all-encompassing plot: This wonderful book has officially earned a place on my "All-Time Top 20" list. What a stunning novel!

Where The Crawdads Sing is the story of Kya Clark, the "Marsh Girl" of Barkley Cove, a small fishing town on the North Carolina coast. Having been abandoned by her entire family at a very young age, she lives alone in a cabin in the marshland near town and develops a deep love and passion for the natural world, as she does not fit into the civilized one. Her adventurous youth centers around nature, and around two young men from town who will ultimately shape the course of her entire life. One of them, the popular teenager Chase Andrews, is found dead - and Kya becomes the prime suspect. With this accusation, her peaceful existence in the marsh is threatened.

Part coming-of-age saga, part murder mystery, this novel drew me in from the beginning and kept me wanting to do nothing else but read it to the very end. I alternately belly-laughed and sobbed through portions of the story, wanting at times to throw the book with either joy or outrage. I also enjoyed the vivid descriptions of nature, and felt I was an amateur naturalist by the end of the book because I had learned so many interesting tidbits! It's been several months since I finished WTCS and I still find myself thinking about Kya's story often. Five stars, a truly enjoyable read!

Fans of sweeping family sagas, The Dutch House is for you!: Ann Patchett has long been a master of the modern family saga, and her latest novel, The Dutch House, is no exception. I enjoy Patchett’s writing immensely because she always seems to be able to make an ordinary life extraordinary. Most people will not live a whirlwind life of fame and fortune; instead we will live relatively “normal” and, at times, somewhat boring lives. Patchett doesn’t write for the famous or for the rugged adventurers – she writes for and about ordinary people, and she does it with ease and grace.

In The Dutch House, we readers are transported into the world of Danny and Maeve Conroy, two siblings with an unbreakable bond whose lives are also marred by tragedy. The Conroy family lives in an enormous mansion in Elkins Park, Pennsylvania (a suburb of Philadelphia) referred to as the Dutch House in homage to its original owners, the now-deceased VanHoebeeks.

Early in the novel, ten-year-old Maeve and three-year-old Danny are abandoned by their mother Elna, a woman who has no other ambition in life than to help the poor and who, in consequence, cannot stand living in the opulent Dutch House. Elna’s departure leaves the door open for the patriarch of the family, Cyril, to remarry. His unfortunate choice of taking a young woman named Andrea as his second wife, and his untimely death when Danny (our narrator) is only a teenager, will ultimately lead to the expulsion of the Conroy children from the fairytale Dutch House and will alter the course of their lives forever.

One of my favorite parts of reading this book was coming to truly love Danny and Maeve and to care about what was happening in their lives over the course of the five decades the book encompasses. As much as I loved the siblings, I despised their stepmother Andrea with a passion. The ability of an author to make us feel for the characters is crucial to the enjoyment and success of a story, and Patchett certainly doesn’t disappoint here. Because of her detailed, compelling, and heartfelt writing I felt completely immersed in the lives of the Conroys and savored each detail, from the reason for failed and strained relationships down to the story of the painting of Maeve as a young girl – the very painting which graces the cover of the novel.

If you are a fan of Ann Patchett or of sweeping family sagas, give this wonderful book a read.

A beautifully-written masterpiece: How does a family go on after their boy - their son, their brother, their twin - ceases to exist? How does life continue after a mother, father, and sisters watch the boy being lowered into the ground? How does a marriage already strained by distance and time apart bear this loss? These are some of the themes explored by author Maggie O'Farrell in Hamnet, a beautifully-written masterpiece which imagines the story of the life - and death - of William Shakespeare's only son, Hamnet.

The year is 1596 in rural Stratford, England. Eleven-year-old Hamnet (a name interchangeable during this time with Hamlet) lives with his mother, Agnes, and sisters Susanna and Judith (his twin) while his father - whose name is never mentioned - resides in London, finding great success as a playwright and ensemble actor on the city's stages. One day, while the rest of the family is out, Judith falls ill with the plague. Within a day, her loving and devoted twin will play a trick on Death, exchanging places with Judith, and ultimately sacrificing his life so she can live. What follows is an exquisite tale of unbridled grief, of learning to survive when a part of you is missing forever, of forgiveness and healing and bearing life, and of turning loss into inspiration - in this case, inspiration for one of the most famous tragic plays of all time.

I absolutely loved this book. Admittedly, although I have read several of Shakespeare's plays and seen many movies based on his works and life, I have never read the play Hamlet. I found, however, that this didn't take away from my enjoyment of the novel at all. The writing is so gorgeous, like that of an artist painting a picture, or weaving of a detailed tapestry. The tragic love story of Hamnet's parents blooms in tandem with the equally tragic story of the young man's last days and untimely death. I have never before read a story in which the death of a beloved family member is described with such heartfelt and soul-crushing detail. This book is a thing apart, and the business of feeling, the love and loss, emanate from every page.

Hamnet has garnered such amazing critical praise, and for a very good reason. In my opinion, it's perfect. I savored every page and each individual person's story. I have a bad habit of not re-reading most books, but I feel that I'll be revisiting this one in the future, and will again feel ALL the feels for Hamnet and his family.

Boring and inconsistent, and I'm so disappointed in the "discrimination" storyline: Recently, I decided to give audiobooks my first try. (Seriously, it's 2022 and I'm just now getting around to audiobooks? But I digress...) Unfortunately, The Book Woman of Troublesome Creek was the novel I chose as an introduction, and what a mistake that was. I DNF at 28% and have deleted it from my devices. No more, please and thanks.

I really disliked the portion of this book I did complete on so many levels. I know most people who have read it, loved it and were enthralled, and I'm clearly in the very small minority on this one but my honest opinion is: DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME. I had several issues with this book. First, it was flat out boring to listen to. There was some "excitement" in the very beginning centering around the main character Cussy Mary Carter's arranged marriage, and then literally nothing of interest happened up to the point that I quit listening, which according to my calculations would be approximately page 87 of the physical book. I started to dread my listening sessions during my commutes, and knew I couldn't continue.

The second issue I have with this book is that it is very inconsistent - not only in the pace of the story (see above re: uneventful for long stretches) but also in Kim Michele Richardson's use of dialect. I feel there is a difference between a character speaking with an accent that is indicative of Appalachia, and speaking the local dialect. What I mean by that is, Cussy Mary most certainly would have spoken with a drawl, as she is living in 1930s rural Kentucky. However, Cussy Mary is also supposed to be one of the more learned people in the area, being a Pack Horse Librarian - so she would certainly be well-read and well-educated enough not to use words such as "knowed" in place of "knew." This little inconsistency, when multiplied time and time again during the book, became pronounced and grating in my brain.

My last, and most important, issue with this book is that Cussy Mary's character is one of the Blue people of Kentucky. In and of itself, this storyline may be interesting - I had never heard of such people and apparently they actually existed - cool! Tell me more! The author proceeds to weave a story which compares the sufferings of these "Blues" (notice the capital B too) with the sufferings and injustices of Black people. This is ridiculous and, as other reviewers have mentioned, is flat out appropriation. In fact, the reason I finally gave up on this book was that a scene took place in which Cussy Mary is literally interacting with a Black woman, and the author talks about how the Blues have it so much worse. Being a white woman living in 2022, I clearly do not have the authority to speak from personal experience one way or another, but the author was really asking me to suspend belief on this point, and I was not willing to do it.

I purchased The Giver of Stars recently and it's sitting on my TBR pile, so since I'm still interested in the Pack Horse Librarians' history, I will definitely give that book a read. I know there was a lot of controversy regarding Jojo Moyes "stealing" the idea from Richardson, but I have a feeling her book will be much more entertaining, enlightening, and likeable than this one.

100% highly recommend: Try to avoid accidentally starting on the third book of the series if you can 🤦🏻‍♀️😏 but even if that happens, this book is outrageously well-written with a fast-paced, action-packed and emotionally charged plot. The characters are deep and full of life and even those without the will to live will live on in your heart for ages to come. 100% highly recommend this epic story.
great spooky read!: This is a perfect read for Spooky Season. I enjoyed it as much as one can enjoy such a dark and twisted tale!

Fantastic Thriller: (Purchased and listened to on Audible) It’s not very often that I find a REALLY GOOD Christian fiction author but I’m looking forward to reading more of Andrew Franks after this! I loved this story from beginning to end. It’s a quick listen on audible with a narrator that really made you feel like you were inside the story. It made my 4 hour drive feel like nothing! The premise and plot are interesting. The characters really suck you in. And the intricacies and implications of religion in today’s world as a whole, they’re spot on and scary accurate to some of the things I’ve seen growing up in a religious household. Throw in some fantastical horror and you’ve got yourself an intriguing read that might just keep you up at night, scared to come out from under the covers.

I really thought this was going to be a 5.: It started out fantastic. It was really gripping and crazy right from the very start.  When it slipped for me is when I kept waiting for that major amp up towards the end and it didn't really come.  The story line kept right on going and then it was just over.  I still would say it is totally worth the read just for the thrill of it to begin with.
Teenagers with problems: I felt the writing didn't approach the quality of his other two books which I thoroughly enjoyed.

Starts our hopeful then goes to every level of sad….: She’s a great writer. This story is just so dark.  I made it about 1/3 way in before I googled the ending and just gave up. There’s no reason to invest a ton of time with this book unless you enjoy feeling sad.
Loved this: I got the audible version and I simply loved this.  It was enjoyable all the way through.  Excellent writing. Fantastic characters.
Fun to Read: This book kept my interest, certainly had a lot of interpersonal drama!  Some of the passages about the war and the brutality were a bit too graphic for me, but I did enjoy the book.
Kept my interest: I enjoyed this book, historical fiction is one of my favorite genres, and this was a fun and interesting book to read.

Good but looonnngg….: The first 2/3 of this book is great….sad, brutal and heart-wrenching, but great. The last 1/3 is long. I think the story could have been wound down and completed a lot sooner. Overall I really liked it but like many books now days, it seems like the author could have made it even better had it not gone on for so long.

Political Garbage: I listened to about half of this audio book and then had to quit. His stories and dialog in the first part of the book was great. His command of the English language is very entertaining. But then in Part 2, he eases into politics and it goes down hill from there. I enjoy Mr. Offerman as an actor and humorist but with the venture into politics this takes, I couldn’t do it. Another actor who thinks that we care about his political opinions. Disappointed I wasted 6 hours on this!

Brutal and intoxicating.: An amazing story of kidnepping, control, brutality, warped love and fear. Great character and plot development. Takes you into the life of a psychotic personality. Softened by the scenic outdoors and Native American folk tales.
Could not put it down.

Sad: I have read other books by this author and loved them. This one is so depressing in every possible way starting with the childhood of the main character through to the very end of her life...and on, as a matter of fact. The story takes place at the time of the tragic Dust Bowl that came right on the heels of the Great Depression. It is good that we not forget the depth of suffering that existed for American Mid-western farmers at that time. We get rather myopic groveling in the pain of our current times.  But there is no rainbow at the end of the rain in this book. Hope is one theme running through the long, sad story, but there is no joy in a hope undelivered.

Worst Feel Book: This is the worst touch and feel book I’ve ever seen (and I have 3 kids). It’s mostly smooth pages with small bumps for texture or a tiny square of fabric to touch. It has very little variety in textures. The pictures are misleading-They show yarn hair and sequin mermaid tails…it is a smooth photo of these textures. This book isn’t worth more than $1.

Terrified my child: This book has disturbing illustrations and scared my child so badly. (It was read to him in his kindergarten class). The story isn’t a good one either. My child cried over it for several days and was afraid to go back to school! Also kept asking if these bad things were going to happen to his body. He was afraid to go to sleep. I also believe it contributed to doctor visits anxiety.

My kid has never reacted to a book this way.

Please listen to the one star reviews!

If you’re a teacher, please do not read this book to children. There are thousands of books to choose from and this one is awful!!!!!

Traumatizing: What an awful book! Disturbing images and promotes bullying. Does not send a good message. It was read in my child’s elementary school and caused many tears! I can’t believe it is still read in schools. Little children will not understand it’s message. My child is now afraid to tell the teacher anything, even ask to go to the bathroom! They’re too young to understand what is “tattling” and what is necessary to tell an adult.
Children should be able to ask or tell an adult anything. I never want them to be afraid to speak up. Sure it isn’t always an emergency, but until they’re much older, they need guidance!

Please listen to one star reviews and avoid this book, especially if you’re a teacher or work with children.

Great book, misprint though: As others mentioned Larry and Ludwig are labeled incorrectly. My son was disappointed that Wario and Waluigi are not mentioned. They mention several other less popular characters, so this was a surprise.
Other than that, the pictures and descriptions are great! Daughter loved the princesses and Toadette are included. Still liked it enough to keep it.

For big Mario fans, I would recommend it.

Not the best Uni book.: We like some of the other step into reading Uni books, but I returned this one. I didn’t realize the theme would be about being afraid of the dark. My children are not, so I didn’t want to put this thought into their minds.
The story was okay. Uni goes to school was much better IMO.

Writing is terrible: Like all of the books in this series, the writing is awful. It doesn’t flow or rhyme well and my kids loose interest quickly. The illustrations are colorful and eye catching. I keep hoping they will be better but they are always bad. I won’t be buying anymore. They have potential but it’s just so poorly written. Don’t recommend this or any in the series.

Not good: I agree with the low star reviews. It isn’t what I expected. It is mostly just questions. Also the children look unhappy in all the pictures, which my children noticed. It’s weird. Don’t understand the good reviews at all. I returned it.
Beautiful: Such a beautiful book and a beautiful story! If u haven’t read this 10 out of 10 I highly recommend it!!

Long and boring: I labored through the book until the last 100 pages.  The author then preached about Communism.  Couldn’t finish the book after that.  Interesting how those who get rich off Capitalism, think Communism is a good idea.

GO WHERE YOU'RE TREATED BEST: I have protected my country during the Cold War and consider myself a patriot. But when my country forsaken me and my family, I consider my option and find where the American idea still exists.
I love her story's: These Dark Hunter book series is one of the best
This is awesome: Love these books
This is awesome: I love these books
This is awesome: I love these books
Crusoe 2022 wall calendar: Great calendar with Crusoe, Daphne and Oakley.

Best cookbook: This cookbook is my favorite of all time because it is simply written. I got my first copy as a wedding gift, more than 4 decades ago. I bought my 2nd copy but binding didn’t hold and I lost pages. I’ve given it to my daughter and nieces. They love it too for good food and simple instructions
Great book for my grandson: My grandson, who is biracial, loves this book. It gives him role models he otherwise would not know.
Awesome book: Full of all kinds of vintage stickers; I plan to buy some more as gifts....

Great book, good quality, but arrived damaged.: Thick book, lots of great info, nice quality paper. However the book arrived with significant spine damage. Hard to say when it happened as the book wasn't really packaged very well. Oversized box with a single strip of packing padding that wasn't stopping the book from flopping around in the box very well at all (could tell when I first picked it up as the book slid around inside).

I didn't get this for collectors value, simply for use with table top roleplaying games, so it's not the end of the world and I'll use some heavy duty clear tape to patch it up, but I suspect this issues was combination result of poor packing and rough shipper care.
A captivating book from start to finish: Many well known authors have reviewed this book, so I do not need to repeat their options. I will only day that it was a fascinating story of a true heroine.
Book: One of the best books I have read! Very well written and hated for it to end
Wonderful: It his was an excellent book- hard to put down
Very good: Really enjoyed this book

Love where you least expect it: When Ava decided to run away from a terrible match to a lukewarm one, she never expected that getting stuck as the cook at a roadside inn would be the key to finding the perfect match. I loved watching Ava and Hamish--both people who thought they had nowhere to belong discover that they truly belong together. This was another delightful story from Martha Keyes. It was the perfect way to disappear from the stress of kids and back-to-school. I'd highly recommend it!

A Happy Ending!: I was waiting for Christina’s brother to show up and be the hero of one of these stories, and here he is! Alastair Innes is almost too perfect. Handsome, funny, kind, hard-working, willing to overlook significant class disparity…Glenna Douglas is Christina’s former maid and servant at Glengour Inn. They are thrown together at the Inn, and then you can guess what happens…and that’s probably my only complaint about this book. In this genre, I expect a certain level of predictability, but I felt like this story didn’t leave much to guess at. But it was very satisfying to see a happy conclusion to the series!

East of Eden, a milestone book: Having seen the movie fairly recently, and am now in the process of reading the book (about 200 + pages in) this book has everything Steinbeck is known for: A realistic telling of the way life was in the early American West, the frontier as this country was coming of age, before and after the introduction of automobiles, people of all classes, as they really were, not just as we sentimentally might wish them to be.

If you want a compelling word picture, John Steinbeck is your author. It's the kind of writing you don't want to put down.

A FASCINATING BUT INCOMPLETE TAKE ON HEMINGWAY: This book caught me a little off guard, as it first appeared to be a diverse collection of photos from the famous author's colorful life.  And true, it's an attention-getting book. However, so many of the photos appear with no captioning, leaving us wondering what they are about.  I guess that leaves the reader wondering: Why not include more commentary? Tell us more about those photos. Really, that's why I am leaving only a three-star rating.  This is an attractive book, but leaves one wishing for more.  If you really want an in-depth, yet easy to read and not-too-long look at Ernest Hemingway, with many photos, get Anthony Burgess, Ernest Hemingway and His World.

Of course, Rockwell is an American Icon: Having grown up with Norman Rockwell pictures on magazine covers, his work was ingrained in my mind as the perfect definition of everyday life.  He had a special talent for capturing real people doing real things. Some critics thought this was not "real" art.  They were wrong, for Rockwell could capture life as did few others.  That was true art.  Anyway, I bought this book to enhance my appreciation of Mr. Rockwell's creativity.

A typical Hemingway look at Africa: Hemingway's earlier writings on Africa tell of his exploits in the 1930's.  This book is a compilation of his later-discovered manuscripts, edited after his death by his family.  We can't be sure, of course, if Hemingway himself would have put these collected writings together in the same way, but none-the-less, it's an intriguing read.  If you tell someone you've just read True At First Light by Hemingway, they might say, "Well, that's one I never heard of."  And they'd be justified.  It's not a well-known book. Part of my motivation for reading this book was that It provided some insights into an area of Africa that I had visited some three decades after Hemingway.  His approach, as the proverbial big game hunter, is quite different than that encouraged later by Kenya that emphasized tourism rather than trophy taking.

good book with a unique plot: This book made me want to keep reading.  Sort of just one more page!  Natalie, a young girl and her friend Hector and Natalie’s other friend Tim were an interesting heroic combination!
Bukowski, good as ever.: The last of his novels that I had to read. Very good and right on point.

Truelly a great writer: I wasn't sure that I liked this at first, and then I quickly realized the true genius of Celine's writing. This story is very dark, but you can't help but read on. Worth the read, a true classic.

Author: Craig Lefebvre
Will open your eyes to things you’ve never thought of before. MUST buy: Eye-opening and incredibly insightful book
Phenomenal Book on the Markets and Trading — Provides Different Perspective d: One of the best books written on the markets and speculation. the only book I really liked from this author

Priceless: This book is simply priceless. Just…buy it…
Life Changing!

An Indictment of American Capitalism: This book is an incredibly well written, well researched, and insightful report on the Boeing 737 MAX development and deployment. It is a story written and rewritten in America of unrestrained capitalism with its only goal to make money by any means possible. The result is destroyed companies, destroyed people, and vast rewards for a select few. Regulatory agencies are taken captive, lies are told, safety of people is a distant second to money for shareholders, the board, and executives. It is a story that has happened at Lucent Technologies, HP, Purdue Pharmacy, ENRON,, and countless others. It is a story that will continue to happen at countless more companies.

Peter Robison gives a detailed account of the history of this tragedy in the making and the frustration of the engineers who tried so hard in a hostile environment. He talks of the pain of the families because of the greed of the executives. He talks of the success of the executives who were responsible. And he concludes with the unsatisfactory outcome that the problems of neither engineering nor management, nor regulation are solved.

The 1940s Italian version of Forrest Gump: Supposedly based on a true story, the protagonist’s fortuitousness to be in so many incredible moments (both personal and historical) was a little too hard to believe. The odds seemed to be overwhelming, and if true, made him the original Forrest Gump.

After the first third of the book (after Pino becomes a driver for Hans Leyers), the story picked up its pace and became a page-turner for me. I was pulled into the book and thought about it often when I was not reading it (which is a good thing).

The story could be confused as an apologetic for the Roman Cathcolic Church (RCC), painting the RCC in the best light possible—ignoring the fact that the Vatican aided and assisted many Nazis after the war, even helping them escape to Argentina via the “ratlines.”

CONCLUSION
Sex: It happens, but it’s not explicit or described in much detail.
Violence: Yes. It was set during the war and a lot of violent things occurred.
Profanity: Some. Most of which was taking God’s name in vain.
Worldview: Pro Roman Catholic, as many Italians in that era and in Italy were. I did get a chuckle, however, when toward the end of the book Pino went into a confessional but before getting into any detail, his anguish caused him to leave the priest and go find a spot where he talked (prayed) directly to God, effectively throwing out the false RCC doctrine of needing a mediator (be it a priest or Mary) between God and man besides Jesus Christ.

In conclusion, I really enjoyed the book and became deeply involved in the story. I recommend

A lot on backstory, and little on the actual murder . . . but still a great book.: This book contains a lot of background information, history, and stories on the Hollywood film industry, the mob, Washington politicians, and the LAPD, and how all of these elements converge (directly or indirectly) to set the stage for what led to Marilyn’s demise. Most of the book, in fact, deals with this backstory, with an infinitesimal portion addressing the actual events of the night Monroe was killed. However, I still recommend this book.

This author’s historical overview helped me get a better picture of the the rich, powerful, and crooked of that era, as well as the tone and atmosphere of the world at the time all these players operated in (eventually leading to the additional organized assassinations of MLK, RFK, and JFK).

As someone who is a student of the JFK assassination, I truly appreciated this book because it connected so many dots between the Kennedys, the mob, and the rouge alphabet government agencies—as well as filling in some holes in this sordid time in American history.

The only thing I wish the author delved into was: if those in charge of LAPD’s OCID were friendly with the Kennedys (up to and including covering up the Kennedys’ involvement in Marilyn’s murder), then why did they also aid in the cover-up of the assassination of Bobby that occurred in LA just a few years later? I’d love to have known what changed in the relationship between OCID and the Kennedys in those short years between Marilyn’s murder and RFK’s.

My only gripe is that I wished the book was written in less of a disjointed fashion—it would have had a better impact. Although it was written with British spelling, that was no biggie. However, the writing itself was a little clunky, and oftentimes poorly worded, requiring me to read a sentence more than once to fully capture the point the author was trying to make. In spite of this, I still highly recommend this book.

CONCLUSION
This is an important book that continues to expose the fact that in our “democracy” there was, is, and continues to be, rogue elements within law enforcement agencies who act like the Stasi with complete impunity, wielding incredible power (via blackmail) to control those in power—whether they be chiefs of police, mayors, senators, governors, and even presidents.

Just what I was looking for.: If you are looking for an extensive pictorial on the events surrounding the Kennedy assassination, look no further, this is the book you will want.

This volume contains a cornucopia of photographs that help the reader to understand the facts about what really happened. Others books may contain a few photos, but this one is full of photos (on every page).

This book also contained some astonishing info I had never heard before.

In a nut shell, if you are wanting to learn more about the Kennedy assassination, look no further. I cannot recommend this book enough and it should be on every researcher's bookshelf.

Full of info, but a wee bit outdated.: Last publishing was 2012, so some of the info is a wee bit outdated (especially when referring to technology and the internet).

Overall, it had decent information, especially helpful for someone with little to no knowledge of the field, but anyone who’s been a PI or LEO for any period of time probably already knows much of what’s in the book.
Couldn't Put It Down: Literally, I read this straight through from cover to cover. At least once I laughed my ass off and at least once shed tears. Great read and great story.
Beautiful: Beautiful and cute book. I love it 🤩🤩
Cuteeeee: Same as the picture. I love it. Great addition for my collection. Get it!!!
Awesome: Same as the picture. This is a gift for my boyfriend and I hope he likes it same as me.

beautiful and heartwarming: Perhaps too much of the plot is given away in the blurb but I can assure you there is plenty more! Helen Hoang is an accomplished writer who admits to putting more of her own life into this novel than her previous ones. Both Anna and Quan are multi-layered and very real, especially as The Heart Principle is presented by both their voices, alternating, in the first person. The story is told straightforwardly, without any whizzing back and forward in time as has become so popular of late.

Anna is particularly vulnerable and this is mostly her story but Quan too has some vulnerabilities, struggles, problems and choices. These are delicately but clearly set forward for the reader to consider and this is definitely one of those novels where "I wonder what I would do" frequently comes to mind. But this is not just a consideration of manners nor a psychological examination of characters and behaviours (Anna's family is complex). Above all, this is a beautiful and heartwarming love story. And it offers throughout an explicit exploration of the progress of a new couple's sexual relationship, intimately detailed without ever being gross!
Kerby’s books are fantastic!: I have all of Kerby’s coloring books. They are well drawn, fun, great paper, and exciting to color! Just wish he would put out more than one a year!
Great pictures!: Good quality paper. Fun pictures. Had not used this artist. I like it!  Some are very detailed!  We try other books by this artist.

Great book!: It’s a great book! Mostly training the owner! What we do that influence our dog to behave and follow our instructions. Main point is patience!  Repeating small steps to insure your pet knows what you want of them! He tells stories of trai  That he has done with difficult pups. A very good read for helping you understand your furry friend!
FUN to be a SEAL!: It's both interesting in the point of view as a Seal, and it's HILARIOUS from Admiral William McRaven's  perspective. Loved reading the book!
Better Angels: It's an interesting point of view, plus it's a perspective that could tug at the soul of Patriotism.

Tedious: Using the audiobook, I was unable to skip through the tedious parts. Had I read the actual book, I could have finished it in 30 minutes. There is enough material here for a magazine article but, in order to make it a book, the author recounts every relatable experience of her life, sometimes over and over. The birth experience takes us through the whole nine months and ends with a a description of every contraction, a minute-by-minute recount of the whole labor and delivery saga that lasts forever, and ends with an ordinary and unremarkable birth. I get it, a new mom bonds with her baby and renews thoughts of "why did my mom give me up?" but we don't need to be dragged through this exercise in banality. There is a lot of navel-gazing as Nicole Chung serves up not the unexamined life, but the super-examined life. It's akin to a long bus ride and finding yourself next to the stranger who gives out recipes for foods you would never ever want to consume.

author mixes up its and it's: Bought this for my grandson. I liked the content (mostly) and the breezy kid-friendly writing style. But found numerous instances of basic grammar mistakes, most often mistaking the possessive its for the contraction it's (it is). For example, page 223: "That's not such a farfetched idea on it's own." NO, get that apostrophe out of there. I started circling all the wrong usage so when my grandson reads it, he will be aware that the author could use a copy editor. It's disappointing to see a book written for kids reinforcing bad English. That's why I rated 3 stars instead of 4 or 5.

Smacked by reality: Slogged my way through the book thinking it was "meh," just OK. But a jarring discrepancy can ruin an otherwise acceptable read. For me, it was when Kya's book about the local flora and fauna is accepted by a university press, which awards her a $5,000 payment, and goes on to be a major best seller and her ticket to fame and employment. In that year, $5,000 was big money -- about the average yearly wage. In truth, if a university press accepts your book, good luck getting any kind of payment. Most U press books sell only about 10 copies -- to the author's mother -- and the writer gets royalties only if the book makes back the cost of publication. That seldom happens. Also, the money allows her to install electricity and plumbing in the shack in the middle of nowhere. I can see a septic system and a well, but a single electric line going for miles? It's also hard to believe a book about a specific region's plants and birds would become a publishing sensation anywhere. The fact that this author's fantasies rewarded her so well is only testament to  the paucity of really good contemporary writing.
Not as good as First series: I enjoy the Shadowhunter world and this series was OK but characters and plot weren’t compelling.  It was enjoyable but not a page turner.
Reading: Great author and book!
Returned: Definitely for older child not for 2 1/2 year old
Perfectly done: Granddaughter loves this book
Who knew H. G. Wells wrote 'comedy': Nice insight into H. G. Wells's writing. Didn't know he wrote like this. I'll read his other books, like Tonga-Bungay, Kipps, etc.

A great book about a remarkable lady!: This book was so interesting to me, as I am a former hiker (mostly in the West), who has hiked a tiny, tiny bit of the Appalachian Trail. I could certainly related to this aspect of her story. Greatly admire Mrs. Gatewood for her perseverance!  Highly recommend it for hikers and non-hikers alike!
A lovely calendar for birders!: Love the illustrations for this calendar.

Great read: This was recommended to me by a friend.  It was a fast and easy read. Lots to keep you involved and thinking. I would recommend to any football affecionado or even just interested in history.
Does Not Include Amendments: Guess I missed seeing that this didn't include the amendments.
Easy Reading Informational Handbook: Provides all the basics for making decisions on planting and care of the plants and fruits.
Easy Reading Informational Handbook: Provides all the basics for making decisions on planting and care of the plants and fruits.
Not bad: This one took a little longer to get through than the others. The story lulled at times.  This won't stop me from moving on though.

Bound back book: I felt things getting stagnant and stale in the last book and was hopeful things were going to be different in this one.  Definitely pleased. Brian did an excellent job in mixing the past and present of Strides life in this one. Well done!
Wow: This one will really make you dig deep as to who you are.  The emotions run tempo in this one. Crying at the end. Good luck.

history: B002RNYGNA B000V770BY B07TV2WDW8 B07TT5BS9R B07TV26L7F B07YKLFCWK
review: A good series: You should just make sure you're going through this. The problem with this was that it wasn't really bad. I'm missing something

history: 1908843357 B00AXIZ3HE B00IJJUIMY B00BEK6ZEK B001BYAPNQ B00IRIR7K8 B00NMPN46W B00J273XP6 B000FC13M2 B003V8B5W0 B00U6DNZOY B000Q9EXGC B01MUDRSND B00J1JQ96K B00G3L1CTI B00MQCNQ0G
review: A real winner: I've read about five books by this author and every one was a 4-5 star. Stories are excellent and easy to follow.  Kevin O'Brien is one of my favorites. Plan on another one after I finish this review.
Great value: If you enjoyed the comics this Omni is a steal. Oversized and complete run. Includes original book and several mini-series.
Book: Es la segunda vez que obtengo este libro en lo personal me gusto mi hijo aprendió y esta vez lo compré para regalo

A Dramatic Conclusion: This last book in the series was a nail biter. I was gripping my screen trying to figure out how there was ever going to be a happy ending between Valroy and Abigail, because it just seemed so impossible!! I was really impressed with how the author navigated the seemingly impossible situation without sacrificing any character's personality and values.

In the conclusion we finally learn the secret of Valroy's maze, while Abigail must choose between the man she loves and protecting two worlds from him.

And we see Anfar smile. That was worth it.

Anything Kat writes is Gold: I have never read a Kathrynn Ann Kingsley book I didn't like.  I applaud her for going full lovecraftian horror with this one.  She is so unique to the horror romance genre that I feel like she is practically pioneering the horror-romance genre all by herself.
Easy reference for general know how.: Easy to read. Not techie.. Got it for my son studying Psychology courses.

Great Winter Story: What a great holiday/winter story for children of all ages.  Loved the message of not leaving anyone behind, and thinking creatively.  Definitely a book to give as a gift or for your home!

a slow but solid build: It took a few chapters for me to really get into this novel, but once I did, I was thoroughly settled in. A dark story, yes, but a universal one that explores the ideas of friendship, identity, and learning to accept oneself.

Very entertaining read: No one better than the king! Everything he does has such depth to it. Or you can read it without the depth and still be entertained. He’s amazing in this way. Another great book and great read. Loved it. I’m sure the show will be great also.
Pretty fun little read: Nothing crazy here. Just a semi believable story written in a pretty good way. What ya read is what ya get. No reading for depth here just a good book to read. Enjoyed it.

First Mary Higgins Clark read: While I read a little bit of everything, I wasn’t sure how much I would enjoy this book going into it. Being a 30 year old man it just didn’t seem like something I would like. But that is the beauty of books I do believe. This book was extremely entertaining and hard to put down. It doesn’t take a genius to read it or anything deep going on, but it was fun!
Alright book: This book was enjoyable. While a little slow and not really having a real kind of ending it was worth my time. Nice little random wal mart book section pick up.

as always, the king!: 30 of his novels down so far, this one had a little different feel to how it read, amazing how many styles he has. Great book, great read. Recommend this to anyone, no doubt about it!
love!!!!!: Even though I had already  seen the show(which usually kills it for me) I still absolutely loved this book. Anyone could read this and love it. Will look for more from her for sure!
“Game on” book 28: WOW WOW WOW! Another awesome read!!!! When is the next one? I can’t wait’ read this book in three days!  You go Janet!!

This is still a great book to share💗: I bought this book to read to my 5 year old grandson. He’s still a bit young to sit and listen very long, but he will enjoy it in a few years. My classes always loved to listen to this story.
Obviously, he can’t read it to himself at this point, but the vocabulary isn’t above his listening level. He just needs time to experience more listening.

Disappointing ending: I have been waiting for a new Scarpetta novel from this writer for a long time, and initially it did not disappoint. HOWEVER, the ending was a huge let down! It almost seemed as though she ran out of ideas of what to do to finish it and just added a random person as the killer. And the bit with the astronauts was totally surplus to the story too. It's a shame, I love Patricia Cornwell's writing, and especially the Scarpetta character but this was rather lacking.

Delightful: I’ve thoroughly enjoyed all the books in the Peachtree Bluff series, and learning about Ansley and her three daughters. This third book with a focus on the youngest, Emerson, was no exception. I only hope it’s not the end of the series!
Enjoyable: Third book in the series and they get better with each one.  looking forward to the next book in the series.
Great book: I really enjoyed this book. Quite different from most I've read lately. Focused mainly on the US but told what happened in other countries too. Wish it had continued longer.
What a page turner!: Started this book and didn't put it down till I finished it! If you love paranormal and alien and supernatural this one is for you!

Amazing addition to the Grishaverse!: This book is so good! I love how Kaz almost always has a plan for everything! The relationships are the best part of this book, well that and Jespers banter! Nina and Matthias are my absolute favorite! so love how they hate to love each other!

The heist in this book was so creative, and I loved the deception and betrayal at every corner! I really loved how diverse all the characters were. I also really loved how body positive Nina was!

My favorite aspect of the book was that it was told in present tense with flashbacks so that we can better understand the characters! I cannot wait to see what happens in Crooked Kingdom!

Great Book!: this book was super cute! the main character is suffering from memory loss after a car accident a year prior to the start of the book. I love how someone anonymously is sending her clues to remember/relive the missing eleven weeks! I absolutely loved Andy! He was my favorite character in the book! My favorite scene was definitely the chocolate making class! This is a perfect light read for anyone who loves ya romance!

Intense Sequel!: I really enjoyed this book! I loved how the plot was never lacking! I really enjoyed watch Lou & Reid’s relationship grow and be tested at every twist and turn!

There were so many new characters in this book! I really enjoyed how each one of them added something unique to the storyline although I could have done without Nicolina, she was absolutely terrifying 😂

The end of the book had me sobbing, I really wish it would have ended differently, but I am interested to see how the storyline develops in book three!

Great Book!: I really enjoyed this one! I thought it was so much better than the first book! I adored how loyal Hollis was to her new family! Scarlet and Hollis’ friendship is my favorite aspect of the book! I was also glad to see the return of Valentina! I did feel that her relationship with Etan was a little rushed but I enjoyed the enemies to lovers aspect of it! I really loved the ending and how everything seemed to work out!

Great Conclusion!: This book had me sobbing! Of the three, this one definitely has the most action! The beginning was so frustrating that none of the characters realized what was happening! I absolutely despise Nicholina no matter what her back story is, I cannot stand her or La Voison. I even like Morgan’s better than them, and that is saying something 😂

I love how Lou makes Reid fall in love with her all over again. It is such a precious addition to the story, and I am so glad at how it all ended because after sacrificing their self for the other at every turn they deserve to be happy.

I adored the Ansel chapters, he was my favorite character so this was the best part of the story in my opinion. Overall I think this was a great conclusion to the trilogy!

Great Book!: I really loved how Grey and Lia Mara’s relationship blossomed in this novel, especially the ending! It was so precious! I am happy that everything worked out in the end! I absolutely despised Lilith. I’m very glad that they did not redeem her in the end. It felt very rushed towards the ending for me and I think that I would have enjoyed it better if Rhen and Harper ruled Emberfall and then Lia Mara and Grey ruled Syhl Shallow. Rhen and Harpers ending seemed a little unresolved for me, so I would have liked maybe an epilogue! I really enjoyed that we didn’t have to experience the two brothers going to war against each other!

loved it!: This book was really good! I really enjoyed the twist on the Beauty and the Beast story! One of my favorite aspects of this one was that Gaston and The Beast were friends! I think it adds a nice change to the original storyline. The Odd Sisters are so creepy, I am beginning to wonder if they will appear in all of the books in this series! They seem to be the cause of all things chaos! It was so interesting to see what he was like before the curse and everything that changed him!

loved it!: This book was really good! I absolutely adored the backstory that they gave The Evil Queen! I love how everything stemmed from her insecurities and childhood trauma, rather than her being innately evil. I love how sweet she was in the beginning and how she cared for Snow. The Odd Sisters seem to enjoy stirring the pot! I felt so bad for her because she kept trying and trying to be rid of the mirror and it would not leave her alone! The ending was also super crazy!

great retelling!: I really enjoyed this addition to the Disney Villains series! I love how the Odd Sisters literally know everybody! 😂 I really wish there would have been more content about Ursula and Ariel, I feel like the book primarily focused on Nanny and Tulip. I understand it was vital to move the storyline along but The Little Mermaid is my favorite tale so I would have loved an extra fifty to hundred pages to really dig into Ursula and Ariel! One of my favorite parts of this books was that it had the entire Poor Unfortunate Souls song! I also love how mysterious the ending was! I cannot wait to see what happens next!

Loved it!: I really enjoyed this addition to the Disney Villains series! I think Maleficent’s back story is my favorite of the villains so far! It was so sad to see all the bullying that she endured as a young fairy, and it just goes to show how other people’s actions can turn someone good into someone evil. I really enjoyed the plot twist of who was the true villains of the tale. I felt so bad for Maleficent throughout the entire story and the plot twist with Aurora blew my mind! This is a must read!

great book!: Okay this book was so cute! It’s the first book in the Disney Villains series that has pictures accompanying the story! I absolutely loved that added detail, it made you feel like you were actually reading a fairytale book! It was so cool getting to know the Odd Sister’s backstory! The plot twist of the origin of them legit blew my mind! It also had Family Trees in it which was so helpful!

great book!: I really loved getting to experience Gothel’s story! This one is full of so much heartbreak and betrayal! I loved how much back story that we got about Gothel! This one made it feel like we are finally getting an overlying plot rather than individual stories about villains! I really enjoyed how much Gothel cared for her sisters! I didn’t like the darker magic themes of this one and that’s the only reason that I gave it 4 stars instead of 5!

great addition to the series!: This was a really cool way to tell Cruella’s story! I absolutely adored the backstory that the author gave her! I really enjoyed how this one was told by Cruella in a memoir type of novel. I really enjoyed the twist of her being friends with Anita! I found it a little odd not having all the usual characters in it like Princess Tulip and the Odd Sisters but I enjoyed it still! I also found the ending so interesting, it alluded that she may appear in the future books? Also the jade earrings have set us up for a captain hook story and I am so here for it!

loved it!: This book was incredible! I loved how you get Scarlet’s story while continuing Cinder’s! I absolutely fell in love with Wolf. His crazy appetite had me cracking up! It was so pure how he never had tried a tomato before!  I loved his protectiveness of Scarlett. I think the author did a great job of weaving the stories together and introducing Thorne! Thorne gave us some good comedic relief! I can’t wait to read Cress and find out everything that happens!💖

great book!: This was a pretty good addition to the Disney villain series. I loved lady Tremaine’s backstory and I love the twist of who is the actual villain. I wish we would’ve seen more of a lady Tremaine’s downfall. I feel like most of the book was her backstory and what happened to her but it doesn’t really show the moment that she switched and turned into the villain. I was just expecting her to be the worst villain of all the way that they had talked in the previous books and I feel like hers was one of the ones that was the biggest injustice done to her. I did however love the redemption for the stepsisters and I really love the change of heart from the fairy godmother because she was really bothering me in all the previous books. I am super super super excited for the next book though and super hopeful because Captain Hook is my favorite villain and I cannot wait to see what plays and his story and how all these jade pieces of jewelry intertwine.

great book!: I really enjoyed this book I thought it was so cool to see things from Edwards point of view! And hasn’t really really hoping that maybe will get one from Jacobs point of you or like an epilogue where we to see what Jacob has been up to since Breaking Dawn. it’s been a couple years since I’ve read twilight but I just found it so intriguing to see it from his point of you and he gets to hear everybody’s thoughts. Honestly my favorite part of the book was getting more depth into all the other characters like getting to see how Jessica actually felt about Bella and how Mike Newton felt about her. The only reason I gave it four stars was because I felt it was a little drawn out considering the first track twilight book is 300 to 400 pages and this one was 660ish pages.

If you love Jane Eyre, skip this book.: I love Jane Eyre. My book club picked this book and I knew it would be a poor retelling. The author doesn’t like any of her characters.
If you’ve never read Jane Eyre, I bet you’ll like this. If you love Jane Eyre, you’ll find the characters too far removed from their originals to be recognizable. And honestly this feels more like Rebecca than Jane Eyre. I endured this book.

Most amazing book: I especially loved the author’s note at the end, which told us the truth behind this book. The main character in this story had a resilient, loving spirit and was so inspiring! This book had me hooked from the beginning until the end. This was my book club’s September book — and I’m so glad we chose it!

Mediocre yet hot: There were parts of this book that I really loved: the sex scenes were hotter than hot, the romance between Marcus and April was absolutely obsessive and the thought of a bigger woman like myself being with an ultra toned heartthrob sang melodies to my dreams. However, the book was too long for me and I felt so many parts could’ve been taken out — there was a lot of fluff in between the joy. In addition, the book was confusing at times for me for whatever reason.

Rating: 3.5/5

Very amazing book: What surprised me was the beautiful love story between Jin & Suja. The people in one of the darkest places in spiritual, mental & physical terms want the same things as me & you — love, the ability to work for fair wages, freedom, & a government that doesn’t require them to worship them (Juche) & who allows them to make their own choices without the fear of death or punishment. I remember floating balloons full of food, world newspapers sharing the reality of the outside, & Bibles into North Korea on multiple occasions, & I hope these packages made it to the people they needed to get to. Sometimes, I would listen to a North Korean share their story in the public streets of Seoul or in an intimate conversation with a small group or a church. When I read this book, it was just confirmation that I need to keep praying for North Korea & that I need to continue to spread awareness about their plight.

You won’t be disappointed!: I loved this book so much that I finished it in 3 days! I simply couldn’t put it down! Then again, the other book I read from the author, #behindcloseddoors, was a page turner as well. Though the culprit behind terrorizing the main character was predictable, the second culprit was not! In addition, this book reminded me of the movie Midnight Lace with Doris Day!

Total Mind F: This story was a total “Alice in Wonderland rabbit hole” — it spiraled into insanity…in a good way. I just couldn’t wait to see who did what and why, like your average Sherlock Holmes. There were parts that were triggering for me (as a sexual abuse survivor), but I made it through them. Also, as a person in recovery from alcoholism who knows a little about NA, I had to ask, “Why is the main character drinking if he is supposed to be sober?” In NA, alcoholism is counted as a substance to be sober from.

The hype lied: Everybody and their mom has been raving about this book…but it wasn’t my favorite. I just didn’t feel connected to the main character, and I couldn’t wait for the 12th part to be over with. I’m rating it higher than I normally would because there WERE parts that hooked me along the way, but overall, this book fell short of my expectations. 🤷🏻‍♀️

A maze of intrigue: This book was a delightful maze through insanity and depth. If I blinked, I missed a detail - I really had to pay attention to it! That being said, I loved every moment of this book: it forced me to finish it within a few days, despite its nearly 500 pages.
Mediocre: I loved portions of this book and parts of it made me laugh. However, as a whole, I wasn’t utterly enthralled by this book.

Worth it: This book that #wegetlitbookclub read for the month of December was so cute and I loved all of the holiday touches that the authors included in it — events, snow, and more! In addition, the romance parts were enough to make me feel fuzzy inside. Side note: The Holiday Swap should be a Hallmark movie!

Heartwarming: This was a great book!!! My heart felt so warm as I read this book and I really felt as though I was in the middle of a Hallmark movie. Melanie and Bryan’s relationship was admirable and I rooted for them.

Not worth it: I DNF’ed (did not finish) this book because there were a lot of digs at overweight people and fat shaming. I hate it when authors do that — as if picking on people who are not the weight and size expected by society will get you more sympathizing readers. No, it is in fact a cruel tactic that reproduces the cycle of bullying and erroneous, unattainable perfectionism wreaked on our society. At least including a trigger in the beginning of the book will save a reader from reading the trashy “skinny” sentiment within a book’s pages.
In terms of writing, this book was good - but I’m not a Samantha Downing fan in regards to her writing style.

A Must Read: Y’all—— THIS BOOK WAS A. MAZE. ING!!!!! 👏
The Yellow Wife is a must read for those who truly want to know what happened in the USA during the 1800’s, when so many people were enslaved, tortured and murdered by others against their own will.
Chilling: This book is a must read! It was very enthralling, page by page, and I could not put it down.
Relatable: This book was so relatable for me. Are you sure the author was writing about my life?
Boring at times: I loved this book more than its predecessor. However, I found myself bored at certain times.
Timely Read: This book is a timely read that is necessary for all readers to get their hands on. From page to page, I was engrossed in the plot. The only thing I would change is the length.
Perfect Mystery Trope: This book was the perfect mystery trope for me! I found myself intrigued page by page.

A Must-Read: I am in love with this story! From start to finish, I just HAD to know how Maria’s story ended. She Wouldn’t Change a Thing was a twisty, shocking, edge-of-your-seat “will she or won’t she” kind of story…and I absolutely loved every part of it.

Beware of body shaming in this book: I’m really disappointed by this author. While I enjoyed her first book, The Hunting Wives, this book definitely needs a trigger warning in the front of it. In My Summer Darlings, author May Cobb uses multiple “fat” and body shaming words. Beware if you are recovering from an eating disorder or struggling with one.
Great book: Felt like you were there. This was the beginning of John Grisham’s journey, a journey I have greatly appreciated as his books were always winners. Would wait impatiently for each one.

When all is said and done...: This is really a romance dressed up as a fantasy adventure story. Which is fine. The Paladin  and the Perfumer are very likable characters and Kingfisher put all that research regarding the history of perfumes and poison to good use. There are a few places where the danger is contrived (I really detest "but I didn't do it!" arrests, trials, etc.) and I had to skim rather fiercely, hence four stars instead of five.
OK but...: This one isn't a novel. It's barely a novella, more like a longish short story. If you're expecting otherwise (as I was), think again.

Sigh: This one is a horror story masquerading as a "college friends coming of age" story masquerading as science fiction masquerading as social commentary. It's also a religious tract exploring the themes of good (friendship, mothethood, with all their flaws) and Evil, variously labeled the Serpent, Highways, Technology, End Stage Capitalism, The Cowboy, and Lululemon. Three stars because it is told flashback style for three quarters of the book. Also, because the inevitable betrayal, telegraphed a long way out, is such a cliche.  Because, of course it would be...well, you'll read this otherwise excellent book and find out, won't you?

Original and unexpected: This was a wholly original book, and so you don’t really know what’s going to happen next. The funny parts (all dialogue-driven) are  genuinely funny, while the horror is genuinely creepy. Some of the perils that children are put in was a bit much for me, and a part of the ending seemed unearned, but still, overall, as a whole, this was a great read!
What a fun read: Fun, funny, and surreal without being meaningless. I thoroughly enjoyed this book.

A lot of heart, a lot of fun.: Looking at the cover, this book looked like one of those hack jobs put out by those writers who pump out a tie-in book every six months. What a pleasant surprise! This book was fun, well written, and had tons of heart. Yes, the bones of the story are basically a D&D campaign. But a well-crafted campaign is all about storytelling, and this was pure storytelling, with humor and characters that you actually become invested in. Loads of fun! A+

Just OK: A fun read but nothing special.  There never was a "wow, I didn't see that coming" moment, no plot twists or anything unexpected. But most annoying was the main character Mason...it was hard to cheer for or feel for this self-centered narcissist. He was a quite unlikable person.

Witchy read!: This one felt a lot like Salem with its closed minded religion and customs of marrying as soon as first blood. Immanuelle’s birth was cursed from the start. Her mother’s decision to disregard the church's law and seek love in an outsider's arms brought her family to ruin. Not only that but her mother ran for the forbidden woods and only came back to give birth to Immanuelle. They say the woods are where the witches live and those who enter never return.

I really enjoyed that Immanuelle was so driven to find answers and do the right thing. Being in the time period and setting that she was in, it was always a risk to burn at the stake. Women were burned and killed for just about anything. The scenes in the woods were the creepiest and I couldn’t help thinking of “Salem” the whole time. I love that show! The only thing that got me was that it was all written in third person. I can enjoy the story but have a hard time connecting to the characters in this point of view. There is so much going on in this book with plagues and the curse that it's hard not to be invested in the story just to want to find answers. I would definitely add this one to your witchy TBR.

Genre: Sapphic Horror/ witches

Go ahead. Take a vacation to Greece. 😉: I finished rereading “secrets we hunt” and it still fills me with those warm happy feelings. Wes and Zoë are literally the perfect duo. Favorite points:

🌺 NUMBER ONE is that downright filthy sex scene. IKYK. I wouldn’t have wanted it any other way. 😛
🌺 A scene where the FMC totally Doms! Love, love, love and I need more of that sometimes.
🌺 Glimpses of the past. With this being a one night book, I was happy the characters had some history to build on that connection. (Friends - to enemies - to lovers trope)
🌺 Getting to revisit characters from the first book is always fun. I love getting to see how they are doing.
🌺 Last but definitely not the least is Owen. We get a hint into the next book and I have my hopes up for what’s to come.

Downright loving these quickie one night books. They are fun, fast and kinky. Each one keeps getting better than the last. If you’re looking for a slump buster book Or even a book that can help you travel to a place warmer in the winter, then you should pick this up. Go ahead and take a trip to Greece for a few hours, it’s all nice and warm there.

More nick and holly… yes please!: Dana is one author that can make me succumb to her wicked sweetness and come back begging for more. We continue to follow Nick and Holly’s life through the holidays with all their kinky adventures.

❤️ We love a good count sesh
❤️ Excuse me but I’ve been a bad student
❤️ I hope someone cleaned up the mess 👀
❤️ We’re getting high on stolen breaths
❤️ Do you know the safe word? 😘
❤️ Sexy soundtrack for the immersive experience

I love seeing their relationship and sex life grow. What will Nick and Holly do next and when?!

Yes yes yes .. more please: I love Clio’s spicy scenes! They are always on point with all the dirty talk. 🤤 It’s so good. Even better is the plot that I am now so invested in and just keep picking out tidbits with each book.. i'm ready for one with the Barista and you know who , please!!! Anyways let’s get to the fun stuff 🥵

💦 FFM … yes yes yes!!!!

“𝘿𝙤 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙝𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙮𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙙𝙤𝙣’𝙩 𝙬𝙖𝙣𝙩 𝙩𝙤 𝙙𝙤?” “𝙉𝙤𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙄 𝙘𝙖𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙠 𝙤𝙛. 𝙄 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙖 𝙡𝙤𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜𝙨,” 𝙌𝙪𝙞𝙣𝙣 𝙨𝙖𝙞𝙙 𝙦𝙪𝙞𝙘𝙠𝙡𝙮. “𝙄 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙡𝙡𝙮 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙥𝙖𝙞𝙣. 𝙄 𝙡𝙞𝙠𝙚 𝙨𝙪𝙗𝙢𝙞𝙩𝙩𝙞𝙣𝙜.
