Don’t forget to check TWs
Excellent book!: Worth every penny. Great read.

Small towns can have major crime too.: Another great read from AFC Bookens. Great plot with many twists and great characters.

"Everybody knows about" often leaves people in the dark who really need to be in loop. Like the sheriff.

Paisley has another salvage job. She shows up at the scene and finds another body. It's a body dump, so volunteers and police search the mountain for the scene of the crime. Paisley's group finds a recently abandoned camp site. It looks like someone has been there for a while but took off without taking their things. Trying find out who has been camping out in the federal park leads to another crime, kidnapping. Are the kidnapping and murder related? Who perpetrated the crimes? You'll need to read "Blood and Back Stitches to find out.

I would recommend this to anyone who likes clean mysteries with a look into small town life and a bit about the salvage trade. This book is excellent.

I received an ARC copy of this book. I am leaving my honest review.

Family stories don't always meet well with history.: Paisley salvages an old chicken coop and discovers bones when she is raking the site for and 'treasures'. With the help of Santiago, her family and friends, she searches out information about the bones hoping to be able to put them at rest with a name and background. The truth turns out to be stranger than they thought.

'Fatal Floss' is a great story of love and sacrifice in the past. With well-developed characters, plot twists and history, 'Fatal Floss' is a wonderful read I would recommend to anyone who likes their mysteries clean, involved and informative.

I received an ARC copy of this book. This is my honest review.

Magic, sword buckling and treachery start the journey to Atlantea: 'Through Titan's Trail' is the start of an epic fantasy with magic, weapon fighting, fantastic species and good, evil and ambiguous characters. After the introduction of the major characters of the epic the journey to Atlantea begins.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book and look forward to reading the next in the series.

Halloween weekend in Salem. What could go wrong?: Cat Green has written a wonderful book with 'Silenced in Salem'. It grabbed my attention on page one and wouldn't let go. I can't wait to read more adventures with Nina, Holly and Jasper.

'Silenced in Salem' starts with Nina's arrival in Salem. It is Halloween weekend and the town is already dressed for the event. Nina is escorted to and on her ride to the hotel by a man dressed as an 18th century ship captain. But the driver never saw his second passenger. It is just the start of the spooky happenings that fill the book.

I received an advance review copy for free, and I am leaving this review voluntarily.
Text & photos a winner!: This is a great book with text and photos. All angelenos should own it.
Fantastic guide!: This is so thorough and a delight! All angelenos and visitors should have it in their library!

Exciting Bunker Hill Old LA /Fascinating !: It is an exciting and beautiful book and explains what we see left today —- a comprehensive picture
of Bunker Hill /downtown history , architecture , local artists , LA noir in film and books, whoever knew!
If you love LA , You’ ll love this book which includes a wealth of photos.

Excellent read with photos!: A comprehensive article  about  actress Gloria Grahame with lots of information  and beautiful photos! A great read —the whole magazine was terrific-and especially the Gloria Grahame article !
It was okay: I like these easy read books. Some scenes could have used a lot more to them. It was very simple and to the point.

Alot to take in but worth it: No words can really desribe this novel. Its dark, sinister, full of revenge and hatred. Its gut wrenching and depressing- but it is one of the BEST books I have read. Its about two people who love each other in the oddest of ways. They share YEARS of childhood trauma and take revenge. I love this book. It was hard to read because some of it was relatavle (unfortunately), but the romance and revenge is so worth it. Buy this book, take breaks, acknowledge the emotions and absorb it. It is NOT like the other books. Spoiler/heads up: I knew this was a dark novel, but I wish I was told there was two r*pe scenes with young children within the first 50 pages.

Great series!: The main female character is strong and fiesty.  She has a smart mouth and has gone through years of abuse. This series is about her going through her life and moving forward. Great read! Definitely buy the first three books!

Awesome!: Amazing series! Cliffhangers left me wanting more, so I made sure to immediately buy this book ASAP. Had some s*xy scenes in it and it's totally worth it! The plot, characters, and development are awesome!

Kept me guessing: I love this book! I am a sucker for a great romantic suspense, but so many of them focus on the sex and just throw in a little suspense to keep to the genre. Not so with Nichole Seven and her Hunting Grounds series. I really enjoyed Over the Flames but Into the Veins was even better. Just when I thought I knew what was happening I was proven wrong. This story had perfectly imperfect characters and kept me guessing to the end. I can't wait for the next in the series!
I did receive a free copy of this book.

Couldn't put it down: The third installment of Nichols Severn's Hunting Grounds series is even better than the first two. If you enjoy a good romantic suspense then read this series! Bits and Pieces can be read on its own, but it is better when you read it as part of the series. I am still in suspense to know who is behind this group of serial killers and I can't wait for the next book!

Sweet romance: Loved this sweet story! Ten years after Nicolas was an exchange student in South Dakota he has two girls from his host family come to visit him in Belgium. Avery has sporadically been in touch with Nicolas for the last ten years and finally decides to put herself first and ask to visit Belgium. This is a great romance where both main characters learn to put their dreams first because of each other. If you love sweet romance you will love It Started with a Note.
Truth that the Left does not want told.: This is an unread gift for a forthcoming college graduate, to allow her to read what they are not taught in school.
Excellent detail: This book describes in detail the final days of the Third Rieich.would recommend to anyone who has an interest in the history of the European Theater in World War II.

A perfect duet!: And another one. I love Wren. She is such a well written character. I’m glad she got her HEA!

review: Great twist on Alphas and Omegas!: I’m not really big on omegaverse, but I love the way it’s done in Knot So Perfect. Kayla is smart, sarcastic, and independent. She’s so not what you would think of when you think omega. I like that the Alphas accept and support her independence. Really got twist on Omegaverse!

A tasty delight ...: We loved this book!
Good memoirs are hard to find and this one it's just so well done. We love memoirs that tell stories and don't brag about all the 'clever things' the author might have done ... Expressing that view point we feel this book is just so perfectly done! You jump right into the lives of these people, it's almost like you're a quiet member of the family. The author tells wonderful stories, vignettes, about the life and times of that era.
Bottom line? We totally recommend this book.

Funny: My son did a mini bookclub with his grandfather reading this book. It was a fun read for him and my dad. Now they are going to follow-up by watching the movie. My son is 10 and it kept his interest. The chapters are short and is relatable.

good repetitive practice workbook: This is not a teaching workbook. There are no explanations. It is good for repetitive practice. Each page has nice, large writing with plenty of space between problems. 16 to 12 problems per page. Good for children who just need extra practice and larger spaces. Which is EXACTLY what my daughter needed.

A wonderful story.: Until Leaves Fall in Paris is a page turner. A book I was happy to stay up late to read.  A historical story that took me on a journey through time. I really enjoyed  the charming characters and story. Highly recommend this book and look forward to reading more from Sarah Sundin.

Lovely art, make up your own story: The art in this book is very pretty but if the audience is very young (my granddaughter is almost 3) they might find the text confusing. It is written more for an older audience. Instead, I make up a story: “the leaves turn!beautiful colors and start to fall as the cold wind blows them along the ground… the robins are flying south when it gets colder but the cardinals stay in the bushes … the sun throws long shadows across the street…” etc. basically we talk about the autumn scene on each page.
(Unfortunately the other books in the series are the same style. )

Beautiful book: When we were young my husband and I hiked to many of the locations photographed by the author - seeing them again brings back the beauty of this amazing park. There are plenty of gorgeous photos and not too many pages of text!

The Nostalgia IS REAL - Even smells the same.: [[VIDEOID:68be0488ce878123a65e3b42b210c462]] Ok. We all have that one book series, while in your teens, that you read cover to cover to cover.
These books were it for me.

I have kept this in my list forever.
I've never pulled the trigger on purchasing until now.

And I don't know how you did it. But this may actually be the book I once owned.

No joke. I swear.
Either that or the paper ages and smells the same way

It's in impeccable condition.
And is so kitschy and adorable to read again.

Thank you

“THE GUEST LIST”
BY: LUCY FOLEY

It was good but it wasn’t great to me. A good “who done it” type of story. I do like books that remind me of the game of Clue. But it didn’t do much for me as far a physiological thriller usually does. It really did not pick up until the middle of the book, but I finally understood why it was dragging so much in the beginning. It was a build up to the plot twist, which is really good, but yeah no. I am only giving this book 3 stars. I saw a few great reviews about this book but it just didn’t do it for me. Maybe you would like it.

3 STARS ⭐️⭐️⭐️

Great story telling: I have had this book on my list for years now and I am glad I finally picked it up. I heard so many good things about it. This book will teach you how spoiled we are in America and how we take things for granted, I have thought this for a while now. Cultures are sooooo amazing in their beliefs, and I love reading about how other people live and how other cultures think. Even if it’s fiction, there is some truth to this story because the author is from the country that the family is from in the book. Very eye opening and anyone can learn from this story. I was sad at what the family had to do at the end of the book. This was a great novel and I am looking forward to reading more novels about other cultures.
Funny: I love the rhyming. The author is clever. Kept me laughing.

My favorite short story writer: I really connect to Frank O'Connor's short stories. I will say that I like the ones that originate in Ireland better than those that were written while O'Connor was living in the United States.
Love it!: Friends always recommended but I hadn't read. Glad I have it now.
Used by like a brand new book!: I received the book early. It was in pristine condition and looks perfect!
not my favorite: There were snippets in the book that were great and I thought now it’s going to be a good read. But not really. Just a slow read,
Excellent!: This is an exciting look at the backstory of the SNAP team! This story moves at a perfect pace. I can’t wait for the next book!

Amazing!: I don't even know how to describe this book! It was so amazing! Ronie Kendig has created something amazing with this series! There's so much depth to the storyline. I was riveted! I made time to read this every moment that I could. I just had to know what was going to happen next! There's such a great lead up to the final book. I can't wait to see where this is going! I would definitely recommend reading this series in order!

Upstairs Downstairs whodunit: The lady of the house is suspicious that the staff has it in for the lord of the manor so she invites a friend to investigate during a weekend house party. The friend ,Kate, has her hands full playing detective to a murder that takes place during the party. Good solid mystery with many subjects under suspicion.

Page-turning post-apocalyptic mystery / thriller: Felt the need to add a rare positive review, as a lot of reviewers I think are missing the point.

The setup to Hanna Jameson's Novel, The Last is indisputably enticing: Jon Keller, an American academic, attends a conference in a remote Swiss hotel, when WWIII breaks out. In the aftermath of nuclear war, Jon and some of the other guests find the body of an unidentified girl floating in a water tank on the roof. Foul play is suspected. Jon, our unreliable narrator, becomes obsessed with finding the truth, in part (as he says) to avoid dwelling on the unknown fate of his wife and children back in the US.

A lot of commentary has focused on the ending of the book. I think people are just uncomfortable with an ending that is left a little ambiguous, or, maybe more accurately, left unresolved. With that said, by the end of the book there are no loose ends to tie up; the mystery is solved. If there are details missing, it's because the whodunit was never fundamental to the points that the author wanted to make. If readers are disappointed that we don't know the fate of the characters after the book closes, I struggle to understand how this is no different than any other work of fiction. It seems to me people want to read the lines, "And they all lived happily ever after." In life, we don't always get tidy endings, but all the character arcs reach a satisfying conclusion. In retrospect I found the book uplifting and hopeful, but also tragic, leaving the reader with a sense of longing.

To me, the central message of the book is articulated in the last few pages: "Perhaps the thing we do have to consider... is that the world didn't end. If the world had ended, we wouldn't still be here, surviving, grieving, and writing about it day by day... Maybe what's been f****** us up, more than anything, hasn't been finding a way to cope with the world ending, but finding a way to cope with the fact that it didn't." (p.339) As an avid fan of postapocalyptic fiction, The Last made me reflect on the genre as a whole. I came to the realization that postapocalyptic fiction isn't about worst-case future scenarios; it's about the present. Our lives, right now. In the postapocalyptic fiction, after the collapse the world becomes a dog-eat-dog world. Ordinary people devolve into vicious cannibals. Crime and violence become rampant. In real-life disasters, research has shown that, far from degenerating into animals, people generally become more cooperative, altruistic event. A sense of common cause and community develops, much in the way the author sketches out through the course of the novel. Rather, it's "ordinary" everyday capitalism which promotes alienation from one another, creates a cutthroat hyper-competitiveness in which everyone is out to stab the other in the back. As Jon ruminates late in the novel, "None of us had been happy [before the apocalypse]. Any image of our former lives hurt like trauma from an old wound. It was never happy, but it had been familiar. You knew every day that it wasn't sustainable, but we'd all had to live it, somehow. It wasn't happiness. It wasn't peace. But sometimes, for us, it had been quiet." (p. 283-284)

*minor spoiler below*

.

.
.

My only quibble is that in a scene in which an OD'd character is revived using Narcan, he pops back into consciousness. I'm assuming the author has never dosed someone with Narcan before. I've done it a few times now and people generally groggily wake back up; it's not at all like the scene in Pulp Fiction which the characters reference.

I thought I could tolerate the  violence, I couldn't: I only read about 26%.  I didn't mind the adult characters had violent, sexual, lives.  I found the main character Ecks interesting. The description of the killing of a family, "She didn't mind when they shot the father or even when Robair forced the mother and teenage daughter to do a stripteases before killing them...Robiar...decided to take the four-year-old son in the backyard to use for target practice".  Was just something you cannot "unread".

Perfect as always: The Dishes Hardy, Abe Blitz my and full cast books, are always supremely suspenseful.  With humor thrown in that makes them so human.  Having read them all, you come to believe you are reconnecting with people you know well.  Best legal thrillers available in my opinion.
Excellent read!: Wow! One of the best books I've read so far this year! This harrowing and heartbreaking story is told so delicately yet so boldly. Definitely a must read!
Good read: I enjoyed the storytelling as well as the intertwining of found relationships; however I was hoping for an ending that reunited the sisters.

A solid and honest read of what happens when the war end.: We were taught in school that the Allies won WW II in Europe. Hitler feeling defeated, committed suicide. American GIs came back and the USA had a baby boom.

While these facts are true. There were any harsh facts we were never taught. The hardships suffered in Germany. The harsh treatment of non-Hitler German supporters by the Germans that truly believed o Hitler.

This book is a beautiful and tragic story of three German widows whose husbands were part of the July 20, 1944 plot to kill Hitler. Each woman has a story. Each woman has a secret. Each woman does her best to survive and keep her children alive.

Great book for a book club

Move away from just cooking veggies: I recently subscribed to a food service and a lot of the recipes called for using a sheet pan for the veggies. I was successful with this technique but wanted to expand my experience to seafood, poultry and meats. This book gave me just the directions and recipes I was looking for.
The author starts out with the basics, how to buy a sheet pan, how to clean one and the equipment and pantry supplies to use to make sheet pan cooking easy. She them takes you through vegetarian, seafood, poultry and meat recipes. She includes enough veggies in cooking the recipes to make complete meals; easy cooking/baking and easy clean up.
If you want to learn about using sheet pans to the best extent, I heartily recommned this book.

Cool Setting, Poor Story: With such a thrilling concept as Napoleonic aerial warfare, it is shocking how the story manages to remain so unengaging. Reading as a fan of steampunk and military fiction, The Guns Above strikes me as a poignant lesson in the difference between conflict, which here is plentiful, and tension, which is scant. The hook of novelty that is so attractive to the prospective reader gradually fades away into caricatured characters, muddled tone, and a steady pace of unsatisfying scenes.

Without the sprinkling of mature language and references, The Guns Above could be easily mistaken for a Young Adult novel. It has all the video-game action, shallow world building, and wish fulfillment that such an audience would find appealing. To the standards of an older reader, the appeal is less.

As expressed by other reviewers, there certainly are some positive aspects, but not enough to make me pick up the second book of the series. It was hard enough to not put this book down halfway though.

far-fetched but good to read: I did enjoy this story but just a bit far-fetched. The controlling husband was a bit cliched. However, it was a compelling enough to keep it an interesting read.

Excellent: I’m an avid thriller and mystery reader and I can count on two hands the books that I’ve read that merit 5 stars in my humble opinion, as this one does for me. I loved how the characters were developed, iIn a way, I thought, got you to like them even with their very human faults. I also agree that this story has a redemptive end for each one of its characters. Even if some of that redemption, comes at a cost: of love, of freedom, of self esteem. Mr Searles has a witty way of making the characters accessible. I could identify with most if not all of them.  Great stories within one narrative ;great beginning, middle and end. I place this book up there with Stephen King’s 11.22.63, or Nelson Demille’s Word of Honor, or Tom Clancy’s Without Remorse in that a set of differing perspectives that you know ahead of time will be connected at the end, but you can’t fathom how as you are reading. I look forward to reading mor books by this author. HCSR

Great read: Del to me is complicated on one hand she is the first to try to help someone in anyway but she’s also the first to put you in your place. I also feel like she was very aware of herself, her faults and her anxiety. But she was unaware of the awesome parts of who she was. In truth she represents so many of us in reality who are struggling. I loved Rocco for her because he was upfront, willing to go by her decisions and was patient. In the end this slow burn romance was very realistic in a way that was refreshing.

Worth the read: June is completely relatable to those who have grown up in a toxic environment as a child and experienced that betrayal from a parent. That feeling of being worthless manifests in ways you never understand and is easily manipulated. I feel like June tried traveling so much to search for what she really desired to be unconditionally loved and wanted. But when you’ve grown up in that life it’s hard to imagine it ever happening or would last. This story really goes through several scenarios and how she has to deal with this heartache. It was well written. On top of the great character development there was also a lot of banter. Loved Zed and June together I think there is just enough back and forth that is great.

Bad Book. I Regret Buying It: Maybe Atkinson is good reading for NPCs. Look, the mainstream media says he's good! But for the rest of us, it is a nauseating affair.

This guy should focus on writing screenplays as that is clearly where his heart lies, and not with the history.

I truly regret buying this book. Most books, even if I don't like them, I can still learn a few things, or appreciate the author's effort. Not here. This book annoys me so much I will likely throw it in the trash.

I need to read a biography of Dr. Seuss after this book: As far as pluses, the author is a good technical writer. The prose is easy to read.

But that's about it.

The most annoying part of the book is the author's insistence on judging every action of Seuss's life in terms of modern day political correctness. This guy reads like a bureaucrat writing a report to Mao on how well Seuss complied with Communist Central Committee mandates.

He repeatedly judges Seuss and tells us Seuss acted okay "to Seuss's credit" or "this was not Seuss's best moment" because of some imagined misstep against whatever ideological doctrine Brian Jones has in his head.

There is one especially bizarre point when Brian Jones accuses Seuss of being misogynistic for writing a cartoon that really makes fun of a guy for being lecherous.

The way Jones uses the term "Seussian" so much is just obnoxious.

Another problem is, I have no real sense of who Seuss was. Jones says Seuss drank frequently, but I have no idea if this was a few drinks a week, or multiple drinks a night, and if he was just quiet and reading books when drinking, or a loud boisterous obnoxious drunk. I have no idea whether people liked Seuss on a personal level, or if he was just an artistic genius so people dealt with him.

Or why was he buying all those properties and moving all the time? To escape his dad? Cause he was spoiled brat? Because he loved adventure? Because his wife wanted to?

Brian Jones gives zero sense of these things. And zero insight that a reader can really enjoy and use for something beyond just learning the basic facts of Seuss's life.

I learned some things about Seuss. But after reading 300 pages of this tome, I'm gonna stop. Will probably throw it away too. Not worth crowding my bookshelves with this.

Thank you Muriel Spark: I made it through and enjoyed learning about Muriel's life, work and relationships.

Lots of research involved to make this biography and I give credit to the labor intensive effort of putting together all the notes, interviews, data. This book is a commitment and requires work to get through.

I love the work of Muriel Spark, When I read my first novel, I was amused and delighted. Thank you Muriel for your dedication, talent and prolific industry. You make me laugh. No one does it like Muriel.

Muriel, alone and sometimes with friends, travelled quite a bit and I really enjoyed learning this detail about her life.

This biography is chock a block full of publishing minutia (specifically Macmillan) detail; and one learns not so easy or at times lucrative for Muriel's talent and industry. Shame.

Did not learn so much about her Catholicism which was a disappointment.

Muriel suffered with a hip issue over surgery later in life. Breaks your heart. She was a strong woman who was dedicated to her work and the written word. A brilliant woman, a genius.

Another book to consider is Appointment in Arezzo by Alan Taylor. He was a friend of Muriel and Penelope's and stayed at their home while the two were traveling. Earthy with an illustration of San Giovanni and their environs in Italy.

They lost several dogs to the inhumane poisoning that truffle hunters did and do in that area. An outrage Italy! Shame, Shame!

Enjoy Muriel Spark's books - 22, a great gift to us.

Crazy Indeed: Not for everyone. I was intrigued to learn the physical regime and system SEAL candidates undergo to become a part of this elite team. I chose the wrong book. I have to abandon the book as it demonstrates an overblown obsessiveness with the male anatomy. Personal habits of SEAL members, nudity and other episodes are driven home for sensationalism and a sad effort to sell the book. Offensive and not engaging.

Too much info on the old, pioneering archeologists: This book should be called the story of the people who found dinosaur bones (and their lives and problems) with advanced academic information about dinosaurs. Which, early on in the book, is more often than not quite dull.

I was SO EXCITED to read this book given the number of positive reviews. I loved my University of Washington archeology classes, I loved the labs and looking at ancient bones, etc. This book is often uninteresting when it focuses on these people's lives and then the information presented about dinosaurs is often too technical for the layperson. Some chapters become a list of names and terms which don't mean much to someone not immersed in the field. I don't want to have to study the biology of dinosaurs as a prerequisite to read this book. I found myself having to skip full pages (or barely skimming them) realizing that none of the information early on(prior to chapter 7) is going to stick with me or impact my learning whatsoever.

I'll change my review if it gets better after chapter 4, but the outlook is bleak. I'm FORCING myself to continue.

Update: is getting better. Chapter seven's discussion on bronotosaurus was actually quite good as it managed to stay focused on the dinosaurs in question. The authors experience and research shows that his final conclusion is at least very logical if not simply correct. Upgrading to 3 stars. The book does what it says, just doesn't do what I wanted.

YUMMMMMMM: Anyone that knows C Tosi knows what’s gonna be in this cookbook, and it does NOT disappoint. I got this for Christmas (after many less than subtle hints) and I’ve spent hours now reading and poring over the stories and recipes and honestly? It’s worth every cent. She is sharing the recipes that made MilkBar famous (yes CrackPie is in here) as well as lots of pro tips to improve your baking in general, which I greatly appreciate. Totally TOTALLY recommend!!!

Hard to describe. Harder to put down.: In this book, an alchemical genius works to embody the Doctrine of Ethos-- the alchemical Unified Field Theory, if you will--  into pairs of male and female twins who can be played off each other for stability and control. Needless to say, it doesn't work as planned, since even alchemical children have lives of their own and the wills to protect them. This is not a savant story. Roger and Dodger are fully-realized, flawed human beings who love deeply, fear greatly, and glory in their power a slow step at a time. Fans of McGuire will find reflections of many works here: the numbers of the cuckoos, the road and the candle, the embodiment of fairy tales, and many more.  Luminous and amazing.

Great story and ending which is always a surprise.: As usual with this author you can’t put the book down once you get about 25 pages into the story. This is my 3rd novel by this author. Love her books.

review: Don’t get the buzz. Definitely do NOT recommend: Wow! Were it not for the fact that I had only this book on my 6 hour flight to Hawaii I would have DNFed this abut 30% in. Really, really boring and just flat out not fun. The central character is odd/ on the spectrum, which could be endearing, like other books that have similar characters, but instead it’s just maddening. She’s not particularly likable, and the fact that she gets bullied constantly isn’t fun to witness. The “mystery” takes a back seat to the character study—really nothing happens until the last 1/5 of the book, which picked up pace slightly but OMG just pass. Not worth the time!
Loved!: Um hello this book was great! I absolutely loved it I kinda wish we had a series 🤭 I need more lol Glory and Rage yes yes yes!!!
My favorite CoHo: I have read everything CoHo had written, this series is by far my favorite. With a custom soundtrack that goes with the reading the experience was unique.

LOVE: This book! Annabel Monaghan has just gone to the top of my instant buy list with her upcoming release of Nora Goes Off Script-a book that has jumped to my top reads of 2022!

In Nora Goes Off Script we meet Nora, a recently divorced mother of two who writes screenplays for The Romance Channel (TRC) - think Hallmark Channel. After spending the entirety of her relationship with her husband making herself small so as not to outshine his lack of contributing nothing while taking everything, he up and leaves her and the children. She pens a new screenplay based on the relationship that becomes her first Hollywood film. As the backdrop of the script takes place at her home, Hollywood comes to her quite setting to complete a couple days of filming. From here, Nora and the leading man Leo start up a friendship that blossoms into something that could be pulled straight from one of her TRC movies.

A couple of years ago I decided that I spent way too many of my waking hours in front of a television screen and basically cut that down to almost nothing and filled that time with more reading. One of the only things I miss about television is my guilty pleasure for Hallmark movies-especially the Christmas ones. Annabel Monaghan has given me everything that I love about those movies in this book.

I can't recommend this one enough, I loved everything about it!

Great read: The Setup is the first novel that I have read by Lizzy Dent, and let me tell you I am now a fan!

In The Setup, we meet Mara, a 31-year-old woman who has spent the majority of her life doing everything she can to remain invisible. Mara tries to shield herself and maintain that invisibility by limiting her circle and not allowing people to get close to or know her, At the heart of Mara, she doesn't trust herself, and that prevents her from trusting others. Unable to trust in her ability to make decisions, Mara relies on the stars and uses astrology and horoscopes to make both large and small decisions in her life. What follows are laugh-out-loud moments of awkwardness that kept me turning the pages well past my bedtime!

Overall, The Setup is a story about a flawed yet lovable MC that learns to value herself and her ability to make, and trust in, her decisions. Her circle grows to include an ensemble of perfectly flawed and lovable characters that unite for a common cause and just fit together perfectly.

She's Back and She's Beautiful: J.R. Ward is a creative force who never disappoints. The world of The Black Dagger Brotherhood stretches as far as the mind can see in every direction and through every plane of time, and somehow she still manages to make something fresh and magical out of all things dark and dangerous. Her rollicking voice urges readers on past inhibitions and doubts, and her boundless empathy for the broken pulls something wonderful out of even the most hateful villains and most despairing heroes. There's no black and white in Ward's universe: there is only silver moonlight and whispering fog and reaching shadows. And somehow, even knowing full well what genre I'm reading and how every other book of hers I've read has ended, I am utterly flattened and certain that this one WILL have a terrible conclusion right up until the last minute. This novel was a little more laborious in its viewpoint shifts than her previous ones, I think because there was such a very wide swath of time and characters to accommodate, but absolutely worth the time engrossed. And as usual, she leaves me starving for the next book the moment I finish this one. Lassiter!

Consummate Debut: I was stunned to reach the end of this story and discover it was Caytlyn Brooke's first book. Exquisitely written and perfectly executed, Dark Flowers is a darkly original tale that nonetheless manages to fulfill every expectation of the horror genre. Brooke combines the grimmer and more grisly side of Fae often ignored in literature with a contemporary story of the abandoned and disaffected to marvelous effect. As the reader approaches the climax, they realize that Brooke told them everything they needed to know in the first two chapters and then masterfully obscured it all again so that the conclusion is at once disbelieved and awfully anticipated. Brooke is a master of her art.

A Hymn of Grief: This reads less as a novella and more as an elegy to grief. There is something terrible and beautiful and cathartic about walking through the transgressive and taboo aspects of the magical thinking that follows loss. Although it's possible someone reading this book might feel validated in self-harming, I think the author clearly shows that is an error, and the very opposite of what the lost beloved would ever want. In fact, walking through the doomed process of attempting an impossible trade might well help someone decide not to tread that path themselves. Our family has suffered the loss of a child, so I can only read this book through that lens. Parents who have endured this unendurable loss may well find a strange solace in the acknowledgement of all the madness that loss entails in Hightower's novella.

Lyrical Ghost Story: Rich in history and trade skill, Immortelle is a ghost story satisfied by vengeance. A quiet thriller fed by the ruminations of a pensive and emotionally distant mother, it reads almost as a devotional to craft, be that the craft of pottery or parenting or poisoning.

review: Spectre Collection: Owl Eyes Motel is a closely-knit collection of tales that remind me of an adult version of Scary Stories to Read in the Dark, with overtones of Stephen King's rendition of the Stanley Hotel. Every hotel resident has a tragedy of their own, and whether or not there's truly any rest for the wicked is a question the reader must resolve. The payment for one of these rooms is the heartbreak travellers have tried in vain to hide, but at least the breakfast is free.
Awesome: Some times you just need to take a chance outside of your norm. ...great read

Wendig is an excellent storyteller, and his dark tales always contain plenty of chills. Sure, it's not as good as Wanderers (which is absolutely fantastic), but The Book of Accidents is still a strong, engrossing piece of entertainment.

review: Nearly as great as the first instalment: Dan Simmons' Hyperion is one of the best SF books I've ever read, so following that masterpiece up with a sequel was always going to be a tall order. But this second book delivers on all accounts. It is still as deep and poetic as its predecessor, but now with a much grander scope. A fantastic addition to a compelling universe. If you enjoyed the first novel, then this is a must-read.

review: Only of scholarly interest.: I finally got around to reading this classic. And I can see how this would be the kind of books about which others write books. About which others write more books. Sure, it's an interesting look into the class and gender divisions of Victorian England. But it's telling that those divisions are the only chilling part of this otherwise anaemic ghost story.

review: Intriguing, if repetitive.: I enjoyed these case studies of famous videogame productions. Laced with intriguing anecdotes and interview fragments, this book works well as an introduction to the inner workings of the industry. Granted, it could have been shortened to avoid repetition, and I wouldn't have minded a deeper analysis of the dynamics towards the end, but it's still a worthwhile exploration of the medium and the people who create it.

Can't do it DNF 32%: Lailah is too dumb blonde for me. She gets so lost that it has to be meantioned a thousand times, apparently she doesn't lock her phone so we know that's gonna be trouble later.

The bullying is lame; she's getting bullied for having a scholarship like wtf?!? Cami is the typical loud, wild, lesbian side kick when she could have easily been apart of the harem.

I don't get why so many authors follow that trope but don't wanna add a female that is devoted to the MFC like the men are. They even sometimes have the men go with each other but again the only other female around the main lady is a tiny lesbian that HATES the D.

Also Cami started off saying she didn't want Lailah to go after the guys yet when she talked about Brayden the hungout with Parker at the party, she was all "you go girl." Make it make sense.

AWESOME AS USUAL!: Lyndsay Sands Mile High with a Vampire is amazing, fun, entertaining, keeps you on the edge of your seat. Love these books!
Can't wait for the next one!
~Author Treasa Kloth!
Shiny!!: Aside from small font (I'm old) this book is great! Re-watching the series while checking for translations is a blast. The author organized them by episode to make it easier and I love it!

The Martian Meets The Aliens: Love this book! Won't give anything away, it's just a terrific what-if brilliantly creative science fiction story with the type of character we already know well from The Martian and love all the way through this one. Fun (dare I say heartwarming) read ~ oddly, with nary a cuss word to be found--well, maybe one or two. Not sure what that was all about, but highly recommended.
Awesome D&D campaign setting: Started reading this I'm looking forward to running a campaign in this setting

Great resource on the Abyss and the 9 Hells: I've already read a large part of this book and it has already gave me great ideas for my correct campaign. It has lots of details about the Nine Hells and the Abyss, plus other races. 100% worth buying if you play D&D
Very DM needs this book.: This book is a great resource for any DM or GM even has a few one shots you can run or add to a campaign.

Can't put it down: Never read this author before but could not put down this book.  Recommended it to others.  Some of my friends read it in a day because they could not put it down. Great read. Ordered more of her books.

Not worthy of John Sandford.: Too many characters, hard to keep up with, too many minute details and road descriptions. Not your typical easy quick read of Sandford's PREY or Virgil Flowers books. Disappointed.
Good read...good Grisham: Always a good read from Grisham
love a slow burn romance: Denise did it again. Love the character Maddie & can’t wait to read the next one. Such a big DGS fan.
up to minute issues: Not what I expected. People living their lives online is just not very interesting but the plot was engrossing after a while and I hate to not finish a book.
Amazing book bad binding: Amazing book but the spine is bad I’m getting a second replacement hopefully it will be better
Cool: Cool book awesome quotes

If you want to get more ...: If you want to get more to the story than what is on the tv series, get the compendium. It fills in some of the side stories, sacrificed for time. Anyone who likes the graphic novels and the character of Mark Grayson should consider this one.
too much unnecessary details: Too long for small plot.  I’ve had a cat so I don’t need cat behavior details.  This book is practice for Crais's better books.

The special edition is gorgeous. The book felt like a fever dream: This book was like waking up from a dream that you kind of remember but everything is really fuzzy.

I have zero idea about the setting. There were a few descriptions, but other than it taking place at night…..I have no idea what this island looked like. What season is it? Were there trees? Are the streets made of cobblestone or brick or just dirt? I haven’t the foggiest.

The prose was too flowery for my taste

“Tasted like midnight”

I’m sorry have you ever tasted midnight? Because I sure haven’t. There were also colors associated with every single thing that Scarlett ever felt or thought and I have no idea what that brought to the story?

Speaking of Scarlett, child are you 12 or 18? I couldn’t tell you. Other than her obsession with protecting Tella and needing to get back to her wedding, I don’t know what else makes Scarlett tick or who she is as a person.

Julian could have had so much more intrigue. He was so flat though. And Tella was obnoxious. Like I truly didn’t like her.

The plot could have been so good though. If the magic and the background and the setting….okay if everything was more fleshed out and we spent more time on that than the flowery language it could have been a knockout.

As it is, I felt like I was in a knock off scooby doo cartoon with how easy the clues came but how poorly the setting and set up were.

Excellent: I give the book 5 stars as it was a fast paced read that kept me entertained. However, the book came with the cover ripped in half, which is the fault of the packer. The exterior package was not damaged in any way. I am really disappointed as this was a gift.
Interesting coffee table book: Started me on a decoupage hobby! Very informative

John Donaldson delivers!: I.M. John Donaldson's book Bobby Fischer is the best researched book on Fischer anywhere. Previously unseen scoresheets and photos are just part of this fine book. John takes the high road; and focus' on Fischer's impressive contributions to chess, rather than dwelling on Fischer's mental demons. This is a must read for all Fischer fan's.
Inspiring: This small book by Admiral McRaven contains stories of persistence and determination. Very well done.

Easy to read and apply: This was a gift for my son who is actually my In-Home Support Services caretaker. Absolutely appreciate it, he said it was easy to read and understand. Lots of good information.
Beautiful deck: The artwork on these cards are absolutely beautiful.
Balloons, Allies and Dead Guys: I think this was the best book in this series.  I never figured out who did it until the very end of the book and who did it was a very big surprise.

Worldly Problems: I have followed Sara Wilde since I discovered the series. I saw her as a artifact hunter and now I see her as a Justice! Her character has grown in many ways and she is strong! Her love for the connected is endless and now she is battling the Star. Not only is she fighting the Star but many on the council are as well.
This book is packed with lots of action and many surprises! What I find most interesting is that Sara is one who will play a big part in saving many people. Her love of the Magician is strong and you will see it throughout the story. If I say too much it will ruin the book but I will say one thing that towards the end of the book you will be given a glimpse of what could be many separate stories. As I was reading it there was a point when the story really touched me and tears fell from my eyes. I really love the writings of Jenn Stark and I have enjoyed the Sara Wilde story which I hope will continue. There is no way I could give this book only five stars because it is worth more than tens stars!

Freedom: When you think about the past lots of things come to mind and one is that sometimes your past can bite you in the butt. This story starts out with the opening of a time capsule which would have stayed where it was except for changes to the field and the flag had to be move. So as the items in the time capsule are revealed the one which will have the town in an uproar is the blackmail journal found in the capsule.
In this instant one person will be really going through some changes but it is a case of her past is biting her in the ass. Yes, there is a murder and there is a hunt for the journal for a number of reasons but the main one is to free Frankie! Verity handles it very well and does get to finally give Ellis’s mom a bit of advice. Lots of things and surprises in store for the reader but keep reading as the book is so well written and will keep you on your seat.
Ellis is busy with a stake out because the murder involves family. Add to it race horse, goats and a bit of a love sick skunk and the fun begins. The question is will Frankie take the knowledge he is given and free himself? Well you will have to read the book for that answer! Enjoy as I think the next book will be even better!

history: B00S4YJKXM 0805089306 B006RV8576 B075VCVRJT B07BWXQ327 B016NSY72O B07JR9W3GF B004JF4MME B07PFL4G1L 1091569002 B07S4HPPW9 B07VRWT31Y 0995123446 0995123489
review: Another great story for this series!!!: Vega is at her best and helping cleaning up messes that others have been causing all the in mortie world!! Magic has been leaking into places by people who don't know what they are doing and what they might be attracting to them. Fae are very dangerous and evil people who are always on the look out for untrained magical people.  Vega is now on the hunt for these people who are unknown have magical powers. But how many can she save???
Excellent: This wad very well written.  It is so pleasant to read a book with little or no editing errors.  The characters were complex and interesting.  The California background was really good.

I absolutely love the Demonica world!: I am a huge fan of the Demonica world created by Larissa Ione - and Bond of Destiny is a prime example of as to why I love this series so much.

Born werewolf Tracker was sold into slavery as a baby - and has lived through pure hell (well, quite literally). When Harvester regained her heavenly wings, she transferred the slave bond to Jillian, a human mated to Reseph, knowing that he would have a good life bonded to her.

Stacy has been drawn to Tracker from the moment she met him. Trapped in a blizzard with Tracker, and no cell service, the two begin to grow closer than she could have ever hoped. But the slave bond prevents him from acting on his feelings without permission from Jillian.

I loved Bond of Destiny. As tracker learns what it means to be truly happy, his biggest fear is having it taken away. Ad Stacy finds there is so much more to Tracker - and incredible strength, despite all the the horrific events of his life. These were some of my favorite characters in the Demonica world.

WOW! So good: Wow. Just really - WOW. A Shadow in the Ember completely blew me away. After devouring the offerings in the Blood and Ash series, I was so excited to dive into the history of the world Armentrout has created, when Gods and Primals still roamed the earth.

Promised to the Primal of Death years before her birth, Seraphina was born in the shroud of the Primals, trained to become his consort from birth. And trained in secret to fight - to be strong enough to stop the Rot killing the lands. When she was rejected by Nyktos at 17, she was distraught, as she was the last hope to save the kingdom.

Three years later, a chance encounter with the God Ash set the wheels in motion for the tide to turn in her favor, giving her hope that she could one day save the lands. Claimed by Nyktos and taken to the land of the Gods, she was awed by the beauty, and the amazing creatures she would meet. And let me just say, I am completely and utterly enamored of the Draken.

A Shadow in the Ember is filled with new information - the history of the Gods and Primals. The deviousness of some, the cunning of others. I was enthralled from the first page to the very last - and good Gods, what an ending. The turn of tides is brilliant...I don't know how to keep my patience for the next book in the thrilling world of Flesh and Fire. I am on the edge of my seat - anticipating how Nyktos and Sera will triumph over the evil spreading through both the mortal and godly realm. I need more - like, yesterday!

A wonderful holiday novella!: I really loved the most recent installment in the Juniper Ridge series. We met Jessie and baby Joy in book 3 ... but imagine her surprise when the unknown baby daddy shows up in Juniper Ridge - and just so happens to be the son of the bakery owners.

Navy Seal Joe is home on a three week leave - and when he discovers the beautiful Joy, his heart cracks wide open.

I loved seeing Joe and Jessie learn about each other, and discover how well they work together. And the draw they felt that snowy Christmas a year ago continues to deepen with each passing day.

These two were beyond sweet. I absolutely loved experiencing this couple - these unexpected parents - grow into a real family. This is the perfect holiday novella to get you into the Christmas spirit.

Rage and Cora bring major heart eyes: As a long time fan of the Bad Billionaire series, I have got to tell you, Rafe is something special. Pulled into Cora’s family at a very young age, he has always been so much more than a best friend to her six (yes SIX) older brothers. He is part of the family, has loved and been loved as part of the family for the bulk of his life. Which means he has joined right in with her brother’s in chasing away any man that got within 6 feet of Cora.
When Rafe shows up unannounced (of course) needing a place to crash (of course), sent on behalf of her brothers to keep an eye on her….. well, you know the drill, Cora is livid, and decides its time to take the sass up a notch, “letting” him overhear girls night in. But something has changed. All of a sudden Rafe doesn’t need to protect her from other men. He needs to protect him from him, despite the fact that Cora has no interest in being protected, and aaallll the interest in seeing what Rafe has to offer, because his kisses turn up her internal temperature to overload.
At the heart of Bad Best Friend is a man that had a terrible family life, but was blessed to have a “found” family that loved him, and would always love him, despite his own doubts of his worth. Watching, reading, praying and hoping that Rafe could see, know and feel the depth of this families love for him it was truly one of the most heartfelt stories in the series.
Now Cora’s brothers – I can’t wait to see those six get bitten by the love bug. I think they’re going kicking and screaming.

Enjoyed this one so much!: In the War of Two Queens, the reveals are coming hot and fast, and I am so here for them. The Blood Queen is holding Cas, and Poppy will stop and nothing to find and free him, and end her mother's reign.

With the intent to take each Rise peacefully, Poppy and her armies are nevertheless ready for a fight. And the atrocities that have been committed by the Ascended leave them with little recourse but action.

Let me tell you, this book is filled from front to back with action, love, steam....and reveal after reveal, and when everything comes to a head, the actions of the Blood Queen and her Ascended will result in long lasting repucussions.

I devoured this book - we learned so very very much about Poppy, just as she is learning about herself.

You WILL want to read a Shadow in the Embers
You WILL get payoff in a major way, and it is hot hot HOT.
So much will be revealed - and so much is left to discover.

Pick this one up, and enjoy the ride.

Loved this installment: Ah Matteo. I really loved his story. His record's been cleared and he's headed home to see his sisters. The last thing he expects is to run into his ex... and her adorable toddler.

Renee was it for Matteo. He didn't want to cut and run, but he knew there was a dirty cop after him, and he did what he had to in order to keep Renee safe. But now he's out, and Renee's been in hiding with AJ almost since he left. Someone's been following her, and when it becomes clear her cover's been blown, Matteo steps in to keep her safe. With a little help from his friends Dante and Seb, they escape town and head out on a "family" road trip.

Renee was burned by Matteo, but the time they spend together reminds her just how much she was invested in Matteo, and she can't help but find herself drawn to him.

These characters were so much fun. Matteo may be dedicated to protecting Renee and AJ, but Renee is a strong, resourceful woman. The two of them mesh so perfectly that I devoured the book cover to cover.

Beyond My Darkness: Georgia Danvers has not used her curse in years - she swore she would never use it again. She's built a life for herself, and is lined up to be the coroner once her fellowship ends. The job is perfect for the woman who wants nothing more than to keep to herself.

But now bodies are showing up at the morgue, and they're all talking - telling her to warn Bronson Cortez, leader of the Scorpion gang. Setting foot in Scorpion territory is the last thing Georgia wants to do, but she tracks down Bronson at a local diner and provides him the warning she was sent to give.

Bronson is both suspicious and intrigued by the woman who shows absolutely no fear of him, despite his reputation. And when Georgia defies his orders and enters his territory for a second time...he finds himself completely drawn to her. Soon she is among those that fall under his protection. But someone has it out for her, and they may not be able to survive the fall out.

R.C. Boldt has become a master of dark suspense, and the paranormal twist just brought this one home. Beyond My Darkness is a must read, and will leave you rooting for the bad guys in the end.

review: ONE BAD THING ABOUT THIS BOOK....: There are some things to know about this book. First of all, the designs are REALLY nice.  That's the good news. The not-so-good news is that the paper soaks up ink and spreads it like crazy. So, you can only use crayons or colored pencils on the mandalas within. The bad news is that the pages are NOT made to be removed and, honestly, it's difficult to comfortably access them in order to color. You will either need to engage in a mighty struggle or cut them out with a razor blade.

review: BETTER THAN I EXPECTED!: OK, I was wrong. This was a better story than I expected it to be. I got it as a freebie and assumed it would be rather lame, but I totally misjudged the author. The story zipped along and didn't spend a ton of time on describing cake baking, but I did learn a few tidbits about  building wedding cakes. And, you know what, it was really interesting. On top of that, the characters are shaping up, and the story felt plausible. Actually, all you need to know is that I enjoyed it,. In fact, I just bought the next book in the series. What? Give away plot points in my review?. NEVER! I don't want to ruin the fun for you. ENJOY!

A phenomenal read!: Fantastic! I just inhaled this in about a five hour sitting cover to cover. Dave Grohl is indeed quite a storyteller. I couldn't put this down. I will 100% be getting the audiobook version of this as well to enjoy with my guy because I know he will love this even more than I did and that's really saying something.

Timely, smart and wickedly satisfying!: 4.5 Stars

Well well well, this was an absolutely delicious little morsel of Feminist Magical Realism. It was the perfect balance of dark and light. At times the subject material (in several different ways) was harsh and is difficult to look at but mostly because there was such a chilling undercurrent of truth in ALL OF IT. Terrible little chunks of ugly truths (most especially for women) but to combat that there was a fantastic trio of strong women that you couldn't help feeling like you wished could be your best friends in real life.

I loved that these women were middle aged! It was refreshing and a great highlight on some of the very real struggles and triumphs that can come in that time of your life. As someone that has a kid in college that is making my way to the back 40, I found I could relate to some of the content.

As a side note, I started reading this the day after the Supreme Court leak about Roe v Wade and to be honest I think it was a fitting read for this time especially. Jo, Nessa and Harriet helped lighten the load a bit in a sense and helped inspire to not back down in the face of injustice. I will say that I did figure out the larger plot line fairly early on but there was a lot more being said in this story other than the whodunit which kept me more than happily blazing along.

Must read: I'm not very good at reviews so I'll say this. I couldn't put it down. This has to be one of the best books (and series) that I have read. The only part I'm disappointed in, that was the last book. But, Like all of her books, I'll snatch up the next one she publishes.

Have you forgotten, Ms. Roberts?: I have read every work of Ms. Roberts and her in Death series has always been a favorite, but now I'm wondering is she is just too bored to continue. The flashes of brilliant character development are gone now. The delightful relationships that sprung up almost against Dallas' will are given only passing nods as if the author depends on our sentimentality to compensate for her disinterest or laziness. Devoted readers usually take these "filler" books in stride but Dallas and her crew are being kept idle rather than moving toward the significant life events that are possible. It's not the murders that keep us buying the books, Ms. Roberts. It's the relationships. Its the growth of the characters. It's the witty conversation and the laughter .  Have you forgotten these things? Have you forgotten us?
18-month-old loved it loved it: 18-month-old loved it
Child liked it: Child liked it

Beautiful book. Brilliant quality.: This quality Bible is not only functional, but pretty to look at.
The pages are quality, and the red lettering helps discern passages attributed to Jesus' teachings.

Such a Great Read!: I’m going to start by thanking B2Weird for allowing me to take part in this blog tour. I was excited to hear about this book, and I’m so glad they included me.

This was the first book by Moreno-Garcia that I’ve read, and I immensely enjoyed it. At first, it read like a continuation of “Mexican Gothic,” but it’s not. For me, this book was a breath of fresh air. The story takes place in Mexico City, and the author describes everything in such detail that you feel like you’re there. In addition, the characters of Atl and Domingo are engaging and intriguing. As a vampire noir, I expected this to be extremely dark, borderline horror; however, while it was dark, I wouldn’t put this in the horror genre.

The city is full of vampires from several cultures, as Mexico City is less restrictive. However, the town has outlawed vampires of all kinds. As a result, Atl is in danger at every turn; rival vampires and humans are hunting her. Of course, they have reasons for pursuing her, but they ultimately want to achieve the same goal. The only allies Atl has are her dog, Cualli, and Domingo, a street-savvy young man who wants to be her friend. Can Atl safely get out of the city, or will one of her enemies find her first?

I thought this was fantastic. I enjoyed the multiple point-of-views because it really added to the story. It was nice to get everyone’s perspective. Also, Atl and Domingo are adorable characters. I enjoyed reading their interactions. It was also great to get a bit of history about myths surrounding vampires. I didn’t know there were vampires from different cultures. It’s always nice to learn something from what you’re reading.

Although this wasn’t a continuation, it made me interesting in reading “Mexican Gothic.” I enjoyed the cultural aspect of this, and I can’t wait to read more from Moreno-Garcia. She’s on my list of go-to authors now.

#B2Weird

Fast-Paced Adventure: I couldn’t put this book down. There was action, dark humor and vivid imagery. Jonathan Stroud created pretty awesome characters in Scarlett and Albert. I didn’t think I could imagine a dystopian Britain, but Stroud puts me right in the action. I liked that Scarlett was self-sufficient, even though she had some violent tendencies. Albert was endearing in all his awkwardness. The dynamic between the two was intriguing, with a fast-paced plot. I would love to read more from Stroud.

Can't Wait for the Sequel: “The Agency” has to be one of the most interesting books I’ve read this year… and it’s only March. Initially, I wasn’t sure what to think. I was a little confused in the beginning of the book about what was happening. However, Monica McGurk’s writing was fantastic and I didn’t want to put the book down.

This misfit group of potential nannies consist of Bree, the first American nanny this British academy has admitted, Dasheill, the academy’s first manny, Ruby and Susie, a socialite on the edge of ruin. These four characters really bring the story to life, and each character brings something different to the story.

I loved everything about Ruby, and I enjoyed how close Ruby and Bree had become. I also enjoyed the relationship between Bree and Dash. I thought it was rather obvious who the villain was; however, it didn’t detract from the book at all. If anything, it made me want to read more to see how it would be revealed.

The pace of the book started off a little slow; however, for me, it quickly picked up when the true meaning behind the academy was revealed. The book does leave some questions unanswered. As it is a series, the unanswered questions should be answered potentially in the next book. I look forward to getting those answers because this one was just too good to put down.

Eagerly Anticipating the Sequel: This is a stunning book, from page one until the end. I was highly impressed with the world-building and the magic. The magic system is different from any other book I’ve read. What I thought was interesting was how high the stakes are, but the writing completely put me at ease. While the pacing was slower than I anticipated, I was hooked from the first chapter.

The description of everything, from the tea brewing to the meals, was fantastic. The character development was great. The backstories were well written, and I felt like I knew each character. But Ning… she was my absolute favorite character. She was smart, brave and kind. I’m excited for what’s to come for her. There is romance, and I hope that gets explored a little more. (Perhaps in book 2?)

The lore and culture were beautifully written. The competition was interesting, and I couldn’t put the book down. Ever since “The Hunger Games” series, books with competitions will always have a hold on me. This was no exception. I enjoyed watching each character navigate the competition and the politics.

Overall, the magical world Lin has created with her beautiful prose will keep you enthralled with this book. So curl up with your favorite cup of tea and enjoy!

A Nice Read: I didn't have any expectations coming into this story. This had more narrators than I was expecting. So it kind of made it difficult for me to get into. The writing was nice and covered important topics, but the pacing was just a bit off for me.

Makes me want to cook: I don’t love cooking, but I stumbled on Jennifer’s blog and loved her recipes. It makes cooking more enjoyable knowing the recipes will be delicious after spending time cooking and doing the dishes. This cookbook is no different. I’ve already made the pasta primavera which was great. Next up is the chicken sheet pan dinner. I just ordered a second book as a gift!

Recipes not tested: I tried the banana bread and the recipe clearly wasn’t tested. The pan was way too small and took twice as long to cook. It didn’t taste great either. Makes me nervous to waste money on the other recipes. Very disappointing.

Amazing Hillbilly Cook Book: I'm delighted to receive my cook book by Becky Walker. It is filled with absolutely wonderful recipes I cannot wait to try. Whoever is searching for a cookbook with down home 100 year old recipes needs to pick this book up. The photographs are also amazing..

Great Book, Great Read!: This book is packed full of information any gardener will need to know. Learn about seeds, garden plants, and what plants to add to let's say your tomatoes. I have subscribed Brian Lowell's Youtube Channel for a while now, and I have to say he is not only knowledgeable, but he understands plants.

history: B00NC1GHA6 B017PJOMYS B01GD9GIG6 B01F1DY49I B0768PYVPQ B08R284ZFQ B0968SCYGP
review:
Judge Not: This was another good book by this author. I have read most of the books by TL. I have loved them all. And have reread most of them, several times over. This book was good from the first page to the last, and as with all of her books, there is an actual life lesson to learn. Anywho, I hope Cain gets his story. There is a story there that needs to be told. He needs something good to happen to him. I hope Lily gets a story as well. She needs a HEA as well. Now, I will patiently wait for the next book by this author to drop and reread something else of hers as I wait.

This book was chalked full of everything that makes a TL book and I loved the southern characters. Being from the South myself , it felt good to read all of the southern sayings and know that people actually what a " pop" is. Jude and Iris' love story was about two people healing, love of family, and surviving, regardless of what life throws at you. It was about love without limits and acceptance of others how they are. It was about never giving up and growth. This was a great read and Eli was just awesome. I hope when Cain gets his story and Lily gets hers, we get more of Eli and Aunt Blue. Now, if you want to know who they are. Well, you gotta read this book. ☺

history: B00NC1GHA6 B017PJOMYS B01GD9GIG6 B01F1DY49I B0768PYVPQ B08R284ZFQ B0968SCYGP B09M7SV6LD
review: Dang good: As always, another excellent TL novel. I loved the story of Jack and Kim. I loved how two hurt souls healed each other. Each was suffering in his or her own way and each one was ready for something but was unaware of what that "something" was or should be. I loved how this story was about learning to live, learning to love and learning to trust again. This was a really good read and I highly recommend it.

Short, but sweet!: Excellent debut for new author August Cox. The writing style is slightly different than other books in this genre but thats what makes this such a nice change of pace. When you’re needing a quick read with suspense and a hint of darkness, this is perfect! Definitely recommended.

Some scars are meant to be healed: Dare I say it. I'm sure I've said it before. Ok here I go; I think this is my fave KM book to date.

I'm still running off the highs of this book as I just finished reading it. The highs are totally understandable as this book just completely absorbed my every thought.

Halle is ready to fix her scars and become the woman she knows she is and start the life she deserves. She knows the one to help her on her journey is Dr. Vance Potter.

Dr. Potter can no longer be any one's fixer. How can he help his patients when he can't even help himself. He cannot risk someone else as he's already done. It doesn't matter how much his brothers try to help him; or that fiesty blonde he's already thrown out of his office once keeps trying to convince him that he's her only hope.

"Her fight is exquisite. Her resilience is magnificent. And her body is… beautifully flawed and perfectly crafted. Exactly what my dreams are made of."

While Halle wears her scars on the outside, Vance wears his on the inside where he can hide them from the world. That is until a very determined, sassy, spitfire of a Georgia peach starts breaking down walls that he works his hardest to keep up.

"You may not be a Marvel hero, but a potter sounded pretty perfect to me.”

Will Dr. Potter become Halle's hero the way she knows he can or will his demons destroy both of their possible futures.

“You create futures, Dr. Potter. Don’t let your scars take the freedom of this room from you or your patients.”

Gripping, enthralling, intriguing: Overall this book was fantastic!! It drew me in, kept my attention, had me going back for more, but. Yeah there’s a but. I found the present parts a bit slower and not as intriguing at times as the past. There were a couple times where things didn't jive or present itself as smoothly as it could but those were far outnumbered by the very great aspects of this book.

A very gripping, enthralling, intriguing mystery to try to wrap your head around.

Kudos to Ms. Fisher for another brilliantly twisted book!!

**Received ARC through NetGalley. Voluntarily reviewed**

Paranormal rom com gold: Hell's spells, what a hexing awesome book!! Not the Witch You Wed by April Asher is a wickedly funny, charming and enjoyable read.

I love so many things about this book but at the top of my list is the witty banter between Violet and Lincoln. Absolutely brilliant. I had so many laugh out loud moments.

In addition to Vi and Linc, I really loved the cast of characters and I cannot wait to see what happens in the next book.

Spooky and full of small town mystery: The Lighthouse Witches was such a great blend of mystery, magic, and history. The island seemed like a quaint and quiet place for Liv and her family, but it was also one of those weird small towns where locals have their own ways of dealing with things. Everything felt eerie from the start, though Liv’s kids seemed to be enjoying the island and exploring the lighthouse.. were they really safe there?

I love that the book jumped through time a little and was told from the perspectives of Liv and that of her daughters. I thought it was cleverly told, especially considering how everything turned out.

This is the perfect fall read.. witchcraft, folklore, and a little bit of mystery and small town secrets. It was so atmospheric and interesting without being actually creepy or too much for those who aren’t quite into horror. I wasn’t sure what would happen or why the island had so many issues with missing children, but I enjoyed piecing together the mystery.

I definitely recommend this one!

Not quite a romance, but good: Let me start by saying I love gothic horror, but I’m not 100% sure I enjoy gothic horror as YA at this point. I requested this awhile ago before I actually committed myself to reading the Stalking Jack the Ripper series and had I done that first, I don’t think I would have requested the ARC of this book because I didn’t enjoy that series as much as I seriously thought I would despite my love of gothic horror. The two were kind of similar in regards to the general plot with the main character being from a prominent family and hoping to enter a field of study not open to women and generally morbid. I love gothic horror, so I just don’t understand what about this YA aspect doesn’t work for me. Maybe I need my characters to be older and more afraid to make waves and yet still have to think about things like money when she does?

Still, I did enjoy Anatomy: A Love Story and wouldn’t actually categorize it as much of a romance at all. The story did not linger too much on any romance for very long. It was mostly Hazel’s POV and her drive to learn and attend classes about surgery. She was kind to the staff, she wasn’t into the limitations of her time period and attending parties, and she was stubborn. Jack had a few POV chapters and he was a likable guy who dug bodies for the surgical doctors in his spare time as well as worked at a theatre. He just wanted to survive and wasn’t afraid to get a little dirty to make money. He didn’t initially fall all over Hazel, either, and they both were simply curious about each other and then slowly got to know each other.

I did think the ending was actually pretty realistic and good.. not a super outrageously inaccurate way to wrap up a story set in this time. Overall, I liked the story and I think I just wanted more.. more details, backstory, and development of the rest of the characters and their motivations.

Anatomy was an interesting gothic tale and one I recommend to fans of YA, gothic time periods, and historical fiction.

Quick and Entertaining: Black Tide was great! I love a little bit of end of the world fiction and, I’ll be honest, a lot of stories with sci-fi and horror and apocalyptic aspects can be really long and complicated. I love books like that, but sometimes I just want a quick, short, enjoyable Bird Box type of story without too much explanation. Black Tide was exactly that. I loved not really knowing what was going on because I felt like I experienced what the characters were experiencing. I flew through the pages and felt like it was easy to visualize it. I highly recommend this book, especially to fans of horror with some sci-fi elements. It’s not overly long or big in the world building, so it’s the perfect spring/summer read with likable characters, some humor, and survival elements.

So good!: This Vicious Grace was so good.
I enjoyed the premise and the characters. It’s been awhile since I felt like I could sink into a good YA fantasy that didn’t somehow feel either too young or frustrating in regards to the MCs decision making process, but I didn’t feel like that at all with this one.
I loved the blend of fantasy, Italian influences, magic, and romance. Even though Alessa was somewhat sheltered, I love that she had a backbone and rebellious streak.. and one that wasn’t so bad it felt over the top and unrealistic for her background.
The romance and the whole fate of the world hanging in the balance made me feel like I was on the edge of my seat. I definitely recommend This Vicious Grace and I’ll definitely pick up the rest of the series once it releases!

Loved this book: You don’t wanna miss this summer release!
Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow was amazing and so much better than I anticipated. With books about video games, it's easy to touch on the nostalgia factor, but sometimes it's too much of that. I loved that Sam and Sadie were complex people and shared a love of gaming. I loved that the book touched on the artistic side of games, the storytelling and the motivation of players.
The book was mostly about friendship and the way people grow and change, but with the backdrop of being video game developers and connecting with people over game mechanics and stories.
I feel like my words cannot really do the story any justice.. it was so good and I loved the writing so much.
I enjoyed the authors other book, The Storied Life of AJ Fikry, even though I don’t typically enjoy books about books. In the same way, I enjoyed Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, so I think even those who don’t enjoy video games would love this one, too.
I highly recommend this book and I feel like it would be a great book club read.
Snowed in with the Firefighter: This is a delightful, wonderful book that everyone needs to read.  Will will love reading it!  Good luck in finding this!Enjoy
THis is not an adult book.: THis is not supercilious.  It is a waste of time.  I would suggest as a gift to a middle schooler to encourge reading..

Great book for history of NYC: Wish I had read this when Cousin Kathy was still alive.  I would have loved to visit the places discussed.  As the book moved to the later years of 1977 and forward, it became more about the families and less about the history.  There was still a lot of history there.  4 out of 5 stars is a good recommendation.  GOod read

Ruined by propaganda: As many others have written, I really wanted to love this book. I have read and watched "The Martian" and loved it. This offering: not so much. I enjoyed the narrator far more than the narrative. There were just too many problems to be solved by the lone Earth and Arrid (sp?) astronauts. It got rather old and there was zero tension.

Still, as I bought the book on sale for only $7.00, the narrator was good enough to make it pleasant and there was a laugh or two. Then came the propaganda out of nowhere. Of course the Earth was in the throws of global warming when the sun starts to get eaten by astrophages <<snort>> and suddenly starts to cool down. Rather than moving along and leaving out the global warming (which added nothing to the story arc), the author inserted an opportunity for a lecture about the horrible consequences of fossil fuel burning and a slap at "deniers".

Thanks, but no thanks. This sort of stupendous story breaking crap is why I stopped buying Kevin Hearne books because he could not stop himself from attacking the oil industry in an horrific way

Bah! At least I didn't waste a whole credit.

THIS, from a premise where the Earth bound heroine had enough clout to order the production of just about anything imaginable except the technology to replace fossil fuel burning, apparently.

Ok book but not great.: I had high hopes for this book, but it was a miss for me.  I expected it to be more of a homage to the noir like crime scene photography of the early 20th century, but in reality a great deal of the book was just normal photos of people in process of the arrest and criminal justice system. It reminded me more of some of the crime compilation books.  It was ok but nothing to get excited about.

One of the best books I've read in a while: Robin Olds is one of the last widely known military heroes, with a larger than life personality that polarized people.  They either loved him or hated him.  This is a very entertaining book, that was a quick and easy read.  It's well worth your time.
Cousin Robin: His wife Ella Raines was my father's cousin. If you want to read about a man born into destiny this is your book. Ohhhhh, to be a pilot under his command.....
