A deeply moving book: Songbirds has many facets , like a cut gemstone , and speaks with several voices. We meet Nisha a beautiful foreign worker in Cyprus, her employer, Petra an opthalmologist, Yianni the man who loves Nisha, Aliki the daughter of Petra who is being raised by Nisha, Kumari , Nisha's daughter in faraway Shri Lanka, Tony who offers help to the foreign domestic workers ,Seraphin the songbird poacher and many others. The author gives us a vivid picture of modern Cyprus with it's beauty and  it's ugliness.

when they inoculated against typhoid, they found they had a para -typhoid. then they gave 2 shots, one for each of these. then they found a second para-typhoid. they then gave the boys 3 shots, one for each of these, where upon they found a fourth disease - influenza - and the world's highest recorded death rate.

One of the best fantasy books I've ever read: The author's care and skill show in every line of this poetic work. It's like a bit of myth, telling of the fall of the last remnants of a once-grand region, and a handful of good people who are caught up in that fall and find themselves making very difficult choices that may put them at odds despite their friendship.

I rarely like slow-paced works, but I found myself happy to stick with this one due to just how gorgeous the prose is. I wouldn't call it flowery; the vocabulary is simple, but each word is placed just so. The love and romance are treated with respectful subtlety. All the characters are mature adults who face real and difficult conflicts; there is none of the "failure to communicate" that is so cheaply used for conflict in so many other stories.

My main quibble is that I think I would have related better to the main male characters if they'd had actual weaknesses. (Stubborn pride does not count.) But overall it's a magnificent book, one of the few I have ever given five stars to.

Not a typical book: I think this book is best thought of not as a novel, but as an experiment, or some kind of prose-poetry hybrid. If you go in expecting a straightforward plot or even traditional character development you will be disappointed.

It took me about 1/3 of the book to get into it or start liking it. Each chapter takes place in a new setting, and the descriptions and mentions of various tech or strategies fly by without any chance for further development. In that sense, a good chunk of each chapter is stuff that essentially doesn't matter to the plot and will never come up again. This made it hard for me to focus sometimes, knowing there was no purpose for much of what I was reading other than to spark wonder or set a mood. It was basically just poetry.

The characters also don't get a ton of development, and it's pretty inexplicable how they fall in love over the course of a few letters. I still enjoyed the book. It's always a treat to see enemies fall for each other, and some of the ideas and phrases in the book were pretty intriguing. So I'd recommend it, even if I'm not exactly looking to read something like this again.

Huge map with microscopic scale: This map may be useful to get an overview of where major locations are. Beyond that, it's essentially useless for travel use/planning.

First, the map is enormous. Impossible to use in any vehicle other than an RV with a big table. The paper is also super thin.

Then, there's the scale. About the only roads readily discernable are major highways. Even using a magnifying glass only helps marginally.

Unless you only want to see where cities and some parks are relative to each other, get a different map.
fun: Fun to follow Ramage’s career. The up close and personal moments of indecision and decision make for good suspense. Surprise works well.
Agatha Christie Miss Marple: excellent transaction

Disappointed: The reviews all indicate that it is leather bound or at least in a simulated leather cover. The picture on Amazon shows the grain of leather, however, it is a paper cover. This was to be a special gift for my grandson and I would’ve preferred a leather cover, but the colored pictures are beautiful and I’m sure he will appreciate it.
Good: Uplifting

Captivating Read!: Erin Flanagan has done it again! Though prior to this, Flanagan has focused on short story collections, with this book, she's cemented herself as one of my favorite novel writers. Just like with her short fiction, Flanagan focuses on the authenticity of her characters and setting, giving us a genuine look at small-town life in the Midwest. And her characters! How quirky, unique, and yet completely relatable! A complex, multilayered novel that kept me turning the pages. Well done!

Fantastic Book!: I found this book when I did a search for the best book on writing memorable characters, and I'm so glad I did. This is a true gem of a book, one that each writer should have on their shelf. It's a practical writing guide that gives so many great examples, an approach that helps both emerging and seasoned writers. One Goodreads Reviewer noted that the "book not only gave me a map of the world but a compass to find my way through it." So fitting!

Heartwarming and enchanting!: What a charming book! This first novel in the Harper Landing series makes me want to read more, so I'm eagerly anticipating Good Catch, which will be out in October. Bardsley snared me with the town of Harper Landing, a quaint small town with lots of personality. She held me there with the story of Julia and Aaron. I especially appreciated each character's growth, though weighed and/or influenced by past struggles, obstacles, and heartaches. If you're looking for a clean romance with all the feels, this one is for you.

A must read!: This is an amazing set of essays and stories that draw the reader in. I loved going back in time with some of the pieces and remembering what I was doing during those years. Rizvi's beautiful writing and attention to detail reveal the love she has for her family, friends, and community, and I found myself taking some time to think of my own set of circumstances and being grateful for all that I have. I can't wait to see if Rizvi has more in store for us with another book!

One of my favorite books of the year!: This one had been on my TBR list for a while, and I'm sorry it took so long to get to it! Keema Waterfield's moving memoir snared me right from the beginning with both its subject matter and the beautiful writing. What drew me in the most was the obvious love that Waterfield has for her family despite the unconventional upbringing (I don't want to spoinl the story!). Thought-provoking and poignant, full of lessons but not preachy, this book sticks with you.

A must have!: If you're ready to take a crack at your own work, grab this book and go! This book is easy to comprehend so that implementing changes to your work isn't overwhelming. The examples, the exercises, the self-editing checklists--unbelievable. This is a must-have book for any author's toolkit!

Honest and engaging.: Sharing our vulnerabilities isn’t something for everyone, but Suzanne Roberts manages to do so in an engaging and conversational manner that drew me right into Animal Bodies: On Death, Desire, and Other Difficulties (and the gorgeous cover didn’t hurt!). This varied collection of essays captured Roberts’ thoughts on so many topics such as divorce, infidelity, grief, sexual assault and conveyed them in a way that will resonate with many readers. Her prose is lovely and her words are thoughtful and honest. Reviewer Mary Cook wrote of the book, “Indeed, Roberts’s Animal Bodies refreshingly holds up a mirror to readers and to the world, causing us to critically examine both our inner and outer existences,” a sentiment I wholeheartedly agree with.

So informative!: My daughter wanted to write her own Scooby-Doo Encyclopedia, but someone beat her to it. This book is chock full of information even the hard-core fan might have forgotten. If you have a Scooby lover in your home, I'd suggest sending this to them. So much fun to read!
Just o.k.  I donatd the book to my church libery .: Nothing special

Unique and heartwarming: First, love this holiday mash-up! Such a clever idea to address the power of belief with characters from two kid-adored holidays. The question the book poses is straightforward: Ginger (a witch) believes in Santa, but does Santa believe in witches? The journey to the answer will take you along a magical path complete with a pumpkin-adorned Christmas tree and a Christmas broom! It's a really fun tale that is perfect for both Christmas and Halloween reading!

Great books: My 5-year-old early-reading daughter loves this series. It is one of her favorites. We only had the first four and she was adamant that I try to find more. The stories are cute and not too long to hold her attention.
Not what I thought: This is more for non readers or very beginning of reading. I was disappointed as it was no challenge for my grandson and much of a story.
Get this book!: Absolutely amazing story. I read this in one short day as I just couldn’t leave it alone without knowing the outcome. I highly recommend this wonderful story.

Unusual detectives create a unique team.: I enjoyed how the story and the characters took shape. The mystery was intriguing and the ending unexpected. A great read.
Fun mystery: There’s excitement and a bit of nail biting in this interesting—socially and historically—plot. The end was quite a surprise. Delightful.

An excellent mystery-thriller: With the backdrop of post WWI England, this intriguing puzzle/thriller, kept me riveted from start to finish. The language is strong and full. The characters wee-drawn with references to Freud’s theories, just finding an audience back then.

Lisbeth is a one hell of a character that I’ve loved following after. I’d certainly never want to be in her sights.

Fabulous series!, Highly recommend!!!!

Straight from the Horse's Mouth: A thin little sofa table book that cuts to the chase.  "Of the 285 accounts in SC Narratives, 114 or 40% of those interviewed have something to say about 'when the Yankees come,'" and not a biased read at all as it includes all references of Yankees, from gentlemenly soldiers to the violent, drunken brutes. The former slaves relay varying reactions ranging from ambivalence to downright anger and hatred for the destruction, and starvation that ensued. And reflects some insight about the master/slave relations, too. So much history in a tiny book!

Just as guilty of bias and disdain: Growing up in what is commonly called the most progressive of the Cotton States, I was taught by children of the Civil Rights Movement and was altogether oblivious to the Lost Cause ideology. After reading some staunchly pro-Confederate material, I thought this book would offer some insight into the phenomenon, but not so much; it simply turned the tables of hateful ridicule from one angle to the other. I read half the book, then put it away. It seems geared more for anyone who's generally spiteful toward Southerners or resentful of having been "betrayed" or "lied to" in history class and I think he's just as guilty of bias as the neo-Confederate pandering he seeks to dismantle. If people have aggrandized Lee by downplaying his opponents, that's exactly what the author's doing here and he writes with double-standards if not flat out contradiction. He mercilessly disparages Lee, then puts Grant up on a pedestal. For instance, according to this book Lee's colleagues and contemporaries only spoke favorably of him because they were constructing a mythology, however the author is somehow free to quote the testimony of Grant's men as proof of his character. He charges Lee with issuing vague, impotent orders, while hailing Grant for being absolutely unerringly clear and exacting (yet just vague enough to afford wiggle room for opportunity.) Whether Lee's armies travelled in long wagon trains with supplies or independent free-roaming brigades, it's always wrong in the author's opinion while Grant's small, free-cell armies were unwaveringly tactical and brilliant. While I wanted to get excited for the statistical data as well as the descriptions of battles and military maneuvers, his language was unceasingly riddled with glaring hyperbole.
On the subject of the American Civil War I'm still reading and learning as much as I can, but I felt this book is flawed by it's disdainful tone.

He Hit the Nail on the Head ...18 Years Ago and Today: I've been indulging in lots of Thomas Sowell, Glenn Loury, John McWhorter, Shelby Steele, Coleman Hughes, and having just finished "Cynical Thinking: How Activist Scholarship Made Everything about Race, Gender, and Identity," by Helen Pluckrose and James Lindsay, I figured this book would be complimentary reading. Although it's less refined than the work of the aforementioned and the style reflects Shapiro's youth in dated political context, it does retain his style of sarcasm and quip (assuming that's what you appreciate in him.) As he relays personal experiences from UCLA along with national data and statistics, the points with which he takes issue range from classic partisan differences, the trademark elitist narcissism of the radical collegiate, digenerated values, to the all-out "woke" absurdity completely divorced from reality which hasn't ebbed but rather flowed to tsunami proportions since this book's publication and has spilled out into mainstream media to drown us all. The only thing disconcerting about Shapiro's book is how it's all dreadfully true and shows no signs of stopping.

Great for Hunter Gatherers: I got this for my husband who loves to hunt and fish and cook! Perfect for the guy who has everything.

Great opening - blah middle - and bummer end: Bummer. Is it because none of the characters were likeable - or perhaps because the multiple POV’s seemed muddled and needlessly sporadic - or maybe because the plot tried to be clever but fell short into trying to hard to be clever and twisty? Who knows. I had high hopes and this left me checking how many more pages were left in each chapter to see how much more there was to read - never a good sign. Clever premise with how each section starts with a book club selection -  but what a bummer because that was my favorite parts of this novel - to see what they were reading every month. Thanks to Flatiron for the advanced copy. This one was a miss but I’m so grateful for the opportunity to read and review it.

Magnificent!: Magnificent. Belonging and yet not belonging - race and family and fear and strength are all tenets of this exceptional collection of short stories. I’m blown away. Get this one. Get a few so that you can gift to others. I rarely reread books but will definitely reread this one to catch things I know I missed. Packed with meaning with gorgeous writing - I’ll read whatever Ms Johnson writes. Heartfelt thanks to Henry Holt and Co for the generous gift of this book. I’m grateful.

Jaw Dropping: Hard to “like” a book filled with so much injustice, sadness, cruelty, generational trauma, and inhumanity - but this book is wonderful. The author describes his time as a child and then given a life sentence at 13yo - spending the majority of his sentence in solitary confinement. Our penal system is barbaric and illogical. The author is a incredible poet and a fine writer of prose.  I am so grateful I read this and was given the opportunity to do so by Pantheon Books as they sent me a copy. Highly recommend.

FASCINATING!: Holy moly - who knew? This book is the reason I love reading. I had never heard of E.O. Wilson and when I stated reading I didn’t know if this book was for me - but I kept reading - and am so glad I did. What a fascinating person! This book is compelling in the way it’s written and I learned things I never knew - which I loved. I recommend this book and am grateful to Doubleday for giving me an advanced copy.

BREATHTAKING: Gorgeous. This is my favorite kind of book - vibrant characters with their own lives and complex stories who are intertwined with other characters with complex stories. The writing is beautiful and includes breathtaking internal and external dialogue. I took out a notebook to write down certain bits of dialogue and descriptions. Everyone will relate to this book - and excellent book discussion book. Bravo to author Ethan Joella. Heartfelt thanks to Scribner / Simon and Schuster for the advanced copy. I loved it.

FANTASTIC: Read this one!  Part thriller - part family drama - part redemption story - this book truly has something for everyone. Beautifully written, I found myself absorbed in the story, holding my breath when the characters were in a “tense” situation - which was often. It’s the best kind of book because I felt all emotions - whew - what a ride. Heartfelt thanks to Minotaur for the advanced copy. I truly loved this one and will recommend to anyone who will listen!

Powerful must-read: Wow. I’m going to be thinking about  this book for a long  time. The writing is breathtaking and does not hesitate in describing the horror and inhumane conditions the Stolen (slaves) endured from the Thieves. Every word felt intentional and needed. I loved some of the characters in the book while I feared others. This is writing at its best and I highly recommend. Take your time with this deceptively-short book. It’s full and deep and I hope you give it the time and pace and attention it deserves. Heartfelt thanks to Simon and Schuster for the advanced copy.

Propulsive read!: A meaty debut with something for everyone - under the exciting backdrop of a celebrity and a mystery to unfold, this book takes on a lot  of important topics (abortion, family relationships, being a woman in a corporation trying to succeed) and shines a light on  complexities therein. I appreciated the discussion points within the story including personal integrity in the face of money and fame. As I finished the book, my first thought was the author tried to do too much as I wish the novel would have focused a bit more deeply on a few hot topics instead of peppering so many into the story. This would be a good book club discussion choice - lots to think about and share with others. Heartfelt thanks to Ten16 Press for the advanced copy.

Fascinating!: Fascinating. The author starts this work of historical fiction by talking about mass shootings and how she has always wondered about the families of the shooters - I have too. This book does a lot. It gives a thorough telling of the Booths generationally and the hard life in which they lived.— all during the time of Lincoln and slavery and the polarization of the United States during this time in history. At times, the writing felt slow but I still enjoyed all of it. I wanted to know more by means of endnotes. A fascinating look at a monumental time in history. I’m so grateful for the advanced copy. Thank you Putnam Penguin!!

Lovely and smart: What a lovely, easy-to-understand, common sense, insightful book to help us make better choices to keep the world cleaner and less toxic. I took lots of notes and appreciated the manner in which this valuable information was conveyed. I love the idea of taking a couple of ideas from this book and implementing them instead of feeling overwhelmed and giving up before you even start.  It is a lovely, smart book that everyone will get something out of. Thanks to Harvest Books for the advanced copy. Loved it.

Gorgeous: Just lovely.  A story about a family and the complex relationships within not only two sisters but with their parents. The title is apt for many reasons and while I usually don’t appreciate a multi-meaning title, this one worked. I had nothing in common with the characters but found myself nodding my head when emotions were expressed and actions explained. Go in cold. Don’t read a summary. It’s a beautiful novel and I’m so grateful to Dutton for sending me an advanced copy. Brava to author Cecily Wong.

Hollywood & kilts & spice…OH MY!: Rory has the love of his life, Zoe by his side. While he knows in his heart they’re meant to be, how can he be sure Zoe feels the same? His mother has a personal vendetta against her & Kinloch castle, his heritage, is about to go bankrupt. There may be hope, but it may cost him everything, including his love.

Brad Bauer, Hollywood smoke show & Zoe’s celebrity crush wants to film his newest blockbuster Braveheart 2 at the castle, saving it from financial ruin. To top it off, Brad is convinced he was married to Zoe in a past life. As Hollywood descends on Kinloch, it’s not just the tiny village facing upheaval. By saving his castle will Rory lose the greatest love he’s ever had?

Rory & Zoe are officially my fav fictional couple! The combination of their witty banter, spicy alone time & deep connection you feel between these two make them relatable & lovable. Alexander created a world within the pages so immersive I found myself actually missing the characters (and the castle) when I reached the last page. For me, that’s a huge signal of a good book & a superstar author.

But every love story needs a good antagonist & Hollywood Games has plenty of them. You’ll love to hate them; their shenanigans sprinkle a bit of whimsical comedy into a storyline focusing on the ‘What are we?’ phase of a relationship.

If you’re looking for a fun romance book filled with spice (and kilts!) definitely pick up this one!

Oh Brendan…: Self-proclaimed Beverly Hills “It Girl” Piper Bellinger is a bubbly, party-loving, attention seeking rich girl…at least that’s what she presents to the world. After a string of bad decisions, Piper finds herself in the hot seat with her stepfather. He wants to teach her responsibility, so he cuts her off & sends her and her sister Hannah to a small Pacific Northwestern town to run her late father’s dive bar. Piper doesn’t think it can get any worse…

Enter Brendan Taggart, a gruff bearded local sea captain set in his ways. He loves the simplicity of his town & flashy Piper doesn’t fit in. Brendan doesn’t think this Beverly Hills ‘princess’ will last; Piper wants to prove everyone wrong. As she becomes comfortable in the small town she finds herself warming up to the hot sea captain, but he’s a distraction to her ultimate goal of getting back home. Besides, they’re polar opposites…so why do they continue to find themselves drawn to each other? Will Piper follow her heart or go back to the life she knows?

Guys…the way I imagine Brendan saying ‘Honey” with that gruff voice of his…I’m done…

I honestly didn’t think I’d connect with Piper; she started out sort of shallow, self-indulgent & entitled BUT as the story progressed Tessa Bailey took her through a journey of self-discovery that was pure, sort of clumsy but perfectly right for Piper. It was heartwarming. Meanwhile we find that Brendan’s gruff exterior was just a mask for the grief & responsibility he struggled with; his need for structure & sameness was a classic trauma response. I was quite surprised to see such complex interpersonal issues woven into a story where the protagonist is a seemingly stereotypical ‘shallow rich girl’.

The spice level was on point even though some of the dirty talk was a bit cringy for me. But Brendan…perfectly imperfect Brendan. Oh my… My savior complex was immediately activated for this gruff, angry man who just needed his heart thawed…I can fix him… My frail mental stability was tested with this man.

It Happened One Summer is a must read! It has it all…depth, top shelf character development, spice & Brendan Taggart.

One of my Top Ten Reads of 2022!: “He smells like limes and bad decisions” (pg. 192)

Kenna Rowan isn’t a bad person; she’s made bad decisions she can’t take back…and she’s paid for them. She’s just spent the last five years in prison for the most tragic mistake she’s ever made. But now she wants her life back…even if that means returning to the town where everyone knows her past.

Kenna wants to reunite with her young daughter but everyone in her life wants to shut Kenna out…except Ledger Ward. Ledger is drawn to Kenna in a way he wishes he wasn’t; the connection is undeniable. As the romance grows, so does the risk. Ledger could lose the trust of everyone he loves while Kenna can lose the future she so desperately wants. Will the pressures surrounding Kenna & Ledger be too much for them to survive? Can Kenna, and those closest to her daughter come to terms with her past & move toward the future she wants?

Where do I even begin?!? My heart is still trying to heal from the emotional rollercoaster I just went on. I mean that last line of Chapter Forty-One BROKE ME. Like on the floor, puddle of tears, hyperventilating, ugly crying BROKE ME. Colleen Hoover, I both hate & love you.

Grief, guilt, shame…these aren’t emotions you often find sprinkled into a romance book yet here we are. We have emotionally delicate yet determined Kenna dealing with all the nitty gritty emotional baggage that comes with trauma and big-hearted Ledger grappling with a savior complex he uses to shield himself from actually addressing his past traumas. Yes, the theme is suppressed trauma & how it affects the future self. However, Hoover beautifully illustrates how processing through these heavy emotions, really walking through the trenches, clears the path for the good stuff to grow…hope, understanding, love.

This is one of those books everyone can relate to; you may see pieces of yourself in Kenna and/or Ledger that’ll have you feeling emotions you may have long suppressed. Heads up: have the tissues ready, get the comfy socks on, curl up in the warm blanket with a nice calming cup of tea/coffee/whatever crutch you’ve got. This one will destroy you.

Reminders of Him is without a doubt in my top ten books of 2022.

I really wanted to love this book: First I must say that Jessie Burton is a lovely writer. The amount of research that went into this book definitely showed in the details and her descriptions of Amsterdam and her people in the 17th century were beautifully written.

With that being said, I have to admit that I was disappointed but I didn't know I was disappointed until the very last pages of the book. Although entitled The Miniaturist, that particular character actually had little to do with moving the plot of the story along. Oh, the character comes up ALL throughout the story, but they serve no purpose ultimately. I really thought she would hold the key to all of the mystery that surrounded Nella and all the events that happened to her once she arrived in Amsterdam. I even hoped beyond hope that she may offer salvation in the form of some sort of hidden knowledge about Johannes' situation that could help him. But alas, she did not and in the end all the mystery that surrounded her was never explained. Sure, we (sort of) find out who she is, but this revelation offers no explanation as to how she knew the secrets of Nella's life.

The story was definitely a page turner and hard to put down, beautifully written with gorgeous detail and history, but in the end, I was disappointed. I know not every story has a happy ending, but I just felt there were too many unexplained events that were never resolved.

Interesting: I have mixed feelings about this book. On the one hand, I think Mantel's writing is witty and brilliant, yet at times the dialogue itself felt a bit tedious.

However, Cromwell was truly a genius, or at least, the way Mantel portrays him he is, and I don't think I've ever read a book that delved so deeply into the character of a man as in Bring Up the Bodies. I know I've never walked away from a book feeling as though I had just spent an intimate evening in dinner conversation with someone but that's exactly how I felt after reading this book.

Kudos to Mantel for this exceptional recreation of what I imagine to be one of England's darkest hours.
good information: I liked the information, the layout of the book, the only dislike is the constant reference to Walmart, I hope Anne is getting a kick back from them.

Page Turning Thriller: Thank you to NetGalley, Dreamscape Media and Sam Holland for an ARC audiobook copy to review. As always, an honest review from me.

Trigger warning: the book mentions self harm, animal abuse, murder, rape

Like:
- Mentions of self harm amongst adults - not that self harm is good, but it’s a good representation of mental health struggles beyond the stereotypical
- The murder mystery and detective work overall. It was easy to be intrigued by the premise of the mystery and want to keep reading to find out what happens.
- When the main characters actions and motivations finally make sense (about 1/3 of the way through) then I finally connect with them and enjoy the book even more. I’m the type of reader that needs to connect with the main characters to enjoy the book.
- Definitely has that got to keep reading so I can find out what happens type of vibe

Love:
- Really descriptions of the settings really like paint a realistic picture for the reader and makes it easy to feel as if you are really there
- The character of Nav- Really feel for him and he seems very relatable and likeable.

Wish that:
- There was less confusion in the beginning about the unlikely partnership of these two characters investigating murders- why? It literally makes no sense why Jessica joined Nate and that strange behavior really bothers me. Eventually it makes sense, but in my opinion it takes too long to clue the reader in.

Dislike:
- The sex scenes and random hookups amongst the murder mystery - makes Jessica seem very unlikeable. As the main character, she’s quite unrelatable in the beginning.
- The descriptions of murder and torture are to be expected in this type of book, but are more graphic than I would like. Very horror and crime fiction to the max.
- Seems a bit unrealistic of a storyline overall - don’t want to go into specifics as to not spoil anything but it definitely seems like it’s trying to hard to make it all connect together

Overall, a good page turning crime mystery that has unique flawed characters. However, some aspects seemed a little unrealistic to me. If you’re really into this genre of books, I’d say give it a go.

A must read for lovers of southern fiction!: River Jordan is a gifted storyteller and this collection shows how talented she is. Each story is different, proving that the southern fiction genre has roots that run deep and stretch into other genres. There's a mix of humor, heartbreak, true to life, and mystical magic -  and River's voice comes through loud and clear in every one. If I had to pick a favorite, it would be A Muddy Grace or The Inglorious Hanging of Good Molly Brown or Scorched or Priceless or Sugar Baby or .... honestly - every single story in the collection! Don't take my word for it, get a copy and see for yourself. You can thank me later.

If you like David Joy, Ron Rash, and Larry Brown- you're going to love James Wade.: Fantastic read! If you like David Joy, Ron Rash, and Larry Brown- you're going to love James Wade. River, Sing Out is a must read.

Put this one on your TBR list!: Lots of great writers in Atlanta-and Veena Rao is one to watch. Her debut novel Purple Lotus is a story that connects with readers everywhere. Her main character leaves India to escape an abusive marriage and patriarchal family and finds herself in the American South. But she's not alone for long-thanks to the kindness of her new friends, she starts to see her self worth and learns how to make a life for herself. Veena shows us that no matter where we're from we're not that different...Put this one on your TBR list!

The Cicada Tree is one of those books you'll be thinking about long after you read the last page.: Robert Gwaltney is the new author to put on your list of favorites. The Cicada Tree is one of those books you'll be thinking about long after you read the last page. His writing is beautiful, his characters are real, and his story will pull you in and hold your attention. I haven't read anything like this in a long time and I can't wait for his next novel. Until then, I'll enjoy reading The Cicada Tree a second time. It's that good.

Tidal Flats is much more than a story about marriage...: I loved this novel by Cynthia Newberry Martin and couldn't put it down. I read it in two sittings because I was fully invested in the characters. I HAD to know how Cass would come to terms with her buried secret, how far Ethan would go to repair the damage he caused to their marriage, the fate of the Fates and Howell House, and if Cass would find the courage to trust herself to make the right choices. Life - and marriage - is full of compromises. I found myself nudging Cass towards finding herself and cheering her on with every turn of the page. Well done Cynthia Newberry Martin!
Powerful: Strong work Emily Serena

It's not your average love story . . .: Absolutely loved Head Over Heels by Hannah Orenstein. It's not your average love story. Orenstein does an amazing job of weaving the world of gymnastics and its real-life, relevant complications through a story of what I would call recovery and healing.

Avery is a former elite gymnast whose career ended with a heartbreaking injury. While her body has healed, emotionally she has a long way to go. Not quite finding her place in the world, until being called back to her home gym to help coach a potential Olympian. It doesn't hurt that the gymnasts full-time coach is a former gymnast she crushed on as a teen. As in real-life, scandal rocks the gymnastics world, forcing everyone to reevaluate the way they think.

This was a "can't put down" book. Highly recommend and can't wait to see what's next from Orenstein.
Great Book: I love that the author makes it seem like you’re there and know the characters.  Great read.
Great Book: Love that these books make you freel like you know the characters and are right there with them.  Great read!  Highly recommend this whole series!!

Great Read: Love this series of books!!  Once you start reading you don’t want to stop.  You feel like you know the characters and they hold your attention in wanting to know or trying to figure out “who dit it”.  Would highly recommend!
Great Read: This whole series is great!  Holds ones attention and feel like you know the characters.
Great Recipes: Like the variation of recipes.  Would recommend.

Pathetic Alcohol Abuser Shares Interesting Information: There are plenty of items in the book of interest, but I don't know if I've ever encountered a less likeable narrator/protagonist. It got really old fast: ....And so I got drunk. I rushed out to find a bar. Got totally plastered. Had 8 beers and half a bottle of Sake. Smashed out of my mind. Hung over.
Please, frat boy.
If he's exaggerating the extent of his perpetual drunkenness, that's really juvenile. It is is accurate, he is a very sick individual. His attitude towards women is no more honorable as he constantly prowls the bars for action.
I liked the short chapter format of the book, and the small nuances revealed about being a foreigner in Japan. But I cannot recommend a story so inexpertly told, about a life so poorly lived.

Great Options!: I haven't had a chance to make a ton of the recipes yet, but the handful I've had been able to make have been really good.  The instructions were especially nice, considering how often they can be lacking.  Especially when using online resources. That's why I'm such a fan of paper recipes.  No ads to deal with.  Everything was concise and measured out nicely and I couldn't be happier with the end results.
Sweet romance: Such a light fun romance. Perfect summer read

Unique and amazing: I’m glad I didn’t listen to the reviews. No this is not tied up with a neat little bow at the end but it’s wildly engaging, imaginative, well written and satirical. I am better for having read it.
Adored this: I read this on one afternoon. So original, laugh out loud funny, relatable, sad, silly, poignant, dark, and different. I wish I was still reading it.

Makes me question amazon ratings!!: I have to say, I have maybe never read a more superficial, completely pointless book that had this many amazing reviews in all of my adult life. The writing is fine—nothing original or compelling; the story could be compelling and shocking but ends up being every bad lifetime movie without even an ounce of true horror. Just meh. Character was flat, descriptions were generic. Why so many good reviews?? Makes me question if there are probably hundreds of wonderful books I pass up bc people don’t seem to like them, especially if this is what people like.

Read some good old fashioned Stephen king if you are interested in creepy and disturbing. This was a total fail and that’s saying a lot for a book I bought in the airport.

Fictionalized story of the women who go missing on highways in Canada: Fictionalized story of the women who go missing on highways in Canada. This one was really good and kept me up reading past my bedtime. Told from two different points of view, this tells the tale of Hailey and Beth--both are trying to solve the mystery of who killed Amber. Lots of suspense and a twisty ending. Definatley recommended.

Psychopath hunting psychopaths: What happens when a psychopath starts hunting down other psychopaths? Who can you trust? This story is told from multiple points of view....and all of them are up to something. So, as you are reading, you don't know if you are dealing with an unreliable narrator, or is everyone telling the truth? I liked this one quite a bit. Definately recommended.

How far will you go to keep a secret?: The plot: How far will you go to keep a secret? Poloma was adopted from Sri Lanka as a teenager and has been keeping a secret ever since. After her roommate is murdered while blackmailing her, Poloma needs to get to the bottom of what's going on. This book was told in a flashback format between current day and 20 years ago. The nonlinear timeline added to the story (as the backstory is very important). Super surpise ending. Highly recommended.

Fun read: The plot: Burgeoning psychic helps a detective with an unsolved mystery that also involves her murdered fiance.
My opinion: This one was a super fun read. The main character, Leda, is funny and flawed and relatable. The mystery was interesting to follow, especially when Leda's mystery and Grady's mystery collide. Quick read. Recommended.

WW2 mystery: What happens when your father is shot down during WW2 and you discover he has another family? And when you rope your aunt into finding them, you learn about her secret past life as a Zeigfried girl in NYC. This was so good. There were two tales and both were intriguing. I love historical fiction that makes me stop what I'm reading and go research the time period. This book did that. Great read. Definately recommended.

Could be a TV series!: This one could be made into a TV series with no problems and I would still love it. This is the tale of a discharged Ranger who is protecting his parental rights. The first 75% of the book is detailing why Cooper and Finch are living the way they do. BUT the last 25% of the book was engaging and emotional. Quick read. Loved it. Highly recommended.

Alex Carter is back!: What happens to a wildlife research team when the humans are more dangerous than the polar bears? Alice Henderson's sequel did not disappoint. I really like Alex's character--her independence and intelligence. I also like that I learn about some amazing wildlife throughout a suspense thriller! The briefly alluded to stalker from book one was brought to full life in this book (thank goodness) and the ending was left open for more to come. Recommened!

Want to read about a cult?: This one was nuts. Three stories. First: man trying to find a missing children's book author who disappeared into the woods. Second: couple living in a wooded commune wondering if the world "out there" is as dangerous as they've been told. Third: girl find herself pregnant and unwanted by the father...what are her next steps? Told from alternating time lines and points of view, this was a crazy read. If you are into someting like Station Eleven, this might be for you.

What happens when no one believes you?: What happens when no one believes you? Jane is convinced she knows the last person to see her sister before she went missing, but no one believes her. It also doesn't help that she's up against a super wealthy family with tons of resources. Great read. Surprise ending. Recommended.

So good: This book was SO GOOD! Told from emails, texts, police reports, etc...you will follow the characters from their words instead of thier actions. Super originial and refeshing change in the typical thriller. Loved it. Highly recommended.

Mystery set in the summer of love: What happens when your sister goes missing during the Summer of Eternal Love? Did she run away or was she kidnapped? This one was ok. The missing person story was good and had lots of angles to follow, but I found myself skipping pages when some of the description got long. The information about Laguna in the 60s was new to me and the relationships felt real. Overall good.

Fast-paced and disturbing: I don't even know what I just read...it was that strange. This is the tale of a family with so much money they are bored. And ruining unsuspecting souls lives is what they do for fun. Until they meet Demi. Fast-paced, creepy, and ultimatley crazy, this was a thrilling read. Definately recommended.

Already a 2022 favorite: This will be one of my favorites of the year. Molly the maid is a unique character--it's never stated, but she most likely is autistic. While she doesn't always understand nuance, her friends come to save the day when she is accused of murder. The was a fun, quirky read. If you liked Eleanor Oliphant, this one is right up your alley. Highly recommended.

Finlay Donovan is back: Finlay Donovan is back and this follow up did not disappoint. Finlay and Vero find themselves trying to track down who wants to kill her ex-husband, Steven. High jinx and drama ensue. If you liked the Stephanie Plum books (which I did), then Finlay is for you. It's funny and twisty all at the same time. Looking forward to following this series. Definately recommened.

Marriage counseling meets twisty thriller: What happens when you cheat on your husband and your only hope of saving your marrigage is a rouge therapist? This was a twisty thriller told from multiple points of view. The characters were likeable and sympathetic and the ending was a true surprise. I find I like anything that the Hendricks/Pekkanen team writes. Definatley recommended.

Love true crime podcasts? This one is for you.: What happens when your favorite teacher is found murdered? When you are a hopeful investigative reporter and podcaster...you investigate. If you are into true crime podcasts (as I am), then this is a story for you. The story of Natalie and her mother, Helen, is told through alternating chapters and both stories were full of suspense. While the ending was a total surprise, it was satisfying, with a spark of hope. Recommened.

So so good: Do you ever finish reading a book and think: Wow. Now that was a good book. This was a good book. Everyonce in a while I need to take a break from my thrillers, and this was perfect. This is the tale of Elizabeth Zott, a brilliant chemist, who refuses to live like others expect her to. While Elizabeth is the main character, her daughter, thier dog, the next door neighbor, and a minister all have thier own stories to add to the mix. If you liked Where'd You go Bernadette, this is up your alley. Highly recommended.

Read this in one sitting: Wow. I read this in one sitting. Pandemic. Time Travel. Suspense. Told from different spaces and times, it's one of those books where there are different stories going on, but they all connect at the end.  It had it all. If you liked Station Eleven, this is right up your alley. While I thought that reading a book that had a pandemic element would be really heavy, it wasn't. Highly recommended.

Kate Quinn does it again: I love anything written by Kate Quinn and this one did not disappoint. Set in Russia during World War II, this is the tale of Mila becoming Lady Death with her sharpshooting skills. There is also an assasin out to frame her for killing the President. Two stories woven into one with a FANTASTIC ending. Highly recommeneded.

So good: This is my first book by Nora Murphy and it won't be the last. This is the tale of two abused women who stumble upon a way to help each other...by murdering each other's husbands. I don't think that was a spoiler since it was the opening scene in the book. The plot line was so fascinating that I ignored the improbability of it actually working in real life. This is a really enjoyable read. Highly recommended.

Raw and honest: When Kiara can't find a job and needs to pay the bills, she turns to prositution. Unfortunately, her best customers are police officers. When she gets involved in an investigation into police corruption, it affects everyone she loves. Wow. This one was good. Raw and honest. This is will be a book that's talked about. Highly recommended.

Coincidence or fate?: Is it coincidence or are you running into all your past boyfriends on the same day? Cult Classic is hard to genrify--little bit romance, little bit science fiction, little bit mystery. The story tells the tale of Lola who has become recently engaged, but she still needs to "deal" with her past relationships. Luckily for her, her former employer's new business venture can help her with this. While it wasn't a fast-paced read, it did make me think about how all of your relationships make you into the person you are today. Recommended.
Love these books: Have most of these books and love coloring in them. I also print them on my own paper.

Heavy Content written beautifully: “Too black. Too white. Never quite right.”

Living in the Sugar Town slums of South Africa, Amandla is turning 15, but bears a lot of responsibility on her shoulders. As a mixed race teen with a white mother who isn't quite all there, Amandla is doing the best she can to succeed in school to better her life. But when an address in her mom's purse leads Amandla to her lost (and very rich) white family members she never knew existed, she will be forced to fight for what is hers in order to find the truth about what happened to her mother 16 years ago.

Sugar Town Queens is a beautiful book. It tackles tough themes, such as racism and poverty. Living in post-apartheid South Africa, you are broken down into black, mixed, or white, with whites having privilege and vast opportunities. Being mixed leaves you at the bottom of the food chain. The author does an amazing job shining a light on Sugar Town and contrasting it with the demographically white city of Durban. While Sugar Town is a slum, filled with poverty, drugs, and crime, Amandla's story juxtaposes it against the good side of the township - her neighbors, the school, friendships.

Amandla is a fighter and quite honestly, I am not sure I would make it living the life that she does. Fiercely loyal, she protects her mother, despite viewing her as crazy and is loyal to her friends. Fighting for what is right, Amandla has a strong moral compass, even though she does not feel like she truly fits into a box in her life. The letter at the end nearly broke my heart, but gave me hope for Amandla's future.

As a history teacher, I have a vast background knowledge of South African's apartheid history, so this story touched me deeply. The author does a great job giving the basics of the dynamics of South Africa, that makes it easy and digestible for younger readers to grasp.

Thank you Penguin Teen and NetGalley for the advanced copy.

AMAZING MUST READ YA: I want to preface this review by saying that I do not normally gravitate toward thrillers or books with anything paranormal or "spooky." This is not a book I would have normally picked up, but I participated in a buddy read with my book club and I am so glad I did!

Logan travels with her dads Alejo and Brandon to Snakebite, Oregon to scout a location for their ghost hunting TV show. There, the family is immediately rejected by the town locals and ostracized, when they believe Brandon is to blame for the disappearance and potential death of a local teen. As more teens show up dead, Logan takes it upon herself, with the help of local teen Ashley, to solve the mystery of the deaths and to figure out what the dark is that is seeming to always be lurking around.

The Dead and the Dark had me invested in the story from the first chapter. I was captivated from the beginning and could not put it down. Many times, I can guess the twist or "who done it" in books, but this one kept me guessing until the very end. There were so many connections and twists that I just didn't see coming which had me floored.

The town of Snakebite felt incredibly real. The entangled relationships between the locals, plus the deep-seeded past of Logan's dads with the town slowly unfolded and left me shocked many times. I appreciated how the author explored many difficult topics, such as homophobia and sexuality. The author even included content warnings at the beginning of the book, which as a reader, I very much appreciated.

The Dark as a character made the book for me. The entire book was so intense. I felt like I was watching a scary movie and I was constantly on the edge of my seat. I had my theories about certain characters, but none came close to the actual plot, which made this book so fun to read.

I simply loved this book. I am going to recommend it to my students and all my friends. This is a book that needs to be read.

Thank you Wednesday Books and NetGalley for the advanced copy!

Amazing mental health rep: Sometimes you come across an author that just speaks to you. For me, that is Roni Loren. I fell in love with Roni's writing when I read Yes & I Love You, so What If You & Me is one of my most anticipated releases this summer. This book does not disappoint. I felt so seen with this story.

Andi, a true crime podcaster and horror novelist, is content living in her 1920s shotgun apartment until she keeps getting interrupted by her extremely noisy nocturnal neighbor. Constantly playing the "what-ifs" in her mind, Andi is trying to move past her anxiety and post-traumatic stress from high school. She's on a dating hiatus as she figures her life out. When Hill Dawson, her retired firefighter neighbor that's also dealing with his own baggage, pounds on her door in the middle of the night, the two spark a friendship...until it's not. Hill doesn’t date after the breakup with his fiancé, because he doesn’t want to be seen as a charity case. He's also haunted by the sights and sounds of the house fire and building collapse that took the lower part of his leg. Both are not willing to enter into a relationship, but a friends with benefits situation just might allow both to heal, build trust and eventually break down each others' walls.

Roni Loren’s books make me feel seen. She has a brilliant way of taking heavy, taboo topics and normalizing them, showing people that everyone deserves a happy ending, no matter their circumstances or previous trauma. While I loved Yes & I Love You, because of my son's Tourette's diagnosis, I loved What If You & Me, because I saw so much of myself in Andi. In the first book, Andi seems carefree, sarcastic and an extreme extrovert. But, in this book, we see the anxiety that she carries around, but masks around most, something I really relate to. Where Andi uses horror and true crime as an outlet to process her anxiety in a safe way, I find books to be my escape.

I adored Andi's character in Yes & I Love You and immediately wanted to be friends with her. After reading this book, I could not love her more. Andi is open, honest, and extremely brave, especially with the trauma of her past.
She makes zero excuses and owns her anxiety, instead of trying to hide it. I love how passionate she is about horror films, and when she speaks about them, her entire face and body radiates with enthusiasm.

Hill is the absolute perfect man for her. Their immediate chemistry brought snarky, sarcastic banter that was utterly adorable. I loved their awkward interactions. The best part of their relationship was how they both pushed each other when they needed it and would call the other out on their crap without fear of damaging the relationship. On top of it, Hill was incredibly respectful of Andi's boundaries. I would take Hill as my grumpy werewolf any day of the week.

What If You & Me lived up to all the hype and I loved it. All the stars, all the feels. Roni Loren is a new favorite author of mine and I can't wait to read the third book in this series. I loved being able to see Hollyn and Jasper again. Their organic friendship group is something I want to be a part of.

⚠️ CW: PTSD, anxiety, depression, assault, physical disability, partner infidelity

Thank you to Sourcebooks Casablanca and NetGalley for the advanced copy. All opinions are my own.

Schitt's Creek meets steamy romance: Hands down, this the best book I've read all year. My book hangover is going to last for awhile with this one. It Happened One Summer has been hyped by all my friends and it absolutely lives up to the hype. In a love letter to Schitt's Creek Alexis Rose, In Happened One Summer is her happily ever after.

Piper Bellinger is the typical LA party girl. With zero drive in her life to accomplish anything other than napping and a wealthy stepfather to bankroll her shenanigans, Piper is the definition of privilege. But when one night lands her in jail, her stepdad has finally had enough. To set her life in the straight and narrow, he sends her off for 3 months to Westport, Washington to live about the dilapidated bar that her dead birth father once own.

When she arrives in Westport, Piper is not so welcoming greeted by a band of king crab fishermen, including Brendan. With a rough exterior and zero tolerance for crap, Brendan doesn't find Piper's high maintenance act charming at first. As the two work together to give the No Name bar a face lift, the sparks start to fly. But when Brendan yearns for forever and Piper sees everything as temporary, what will happen to their hearts?

Brendan is such a grump, set in his ways, but incredibly loyal and vulnerable. As he continues to cope with the grief of his wife's death, Pipers insertion into the town completely shakes him up and I fell in love with his character. He showed major growth throughout the book, stepping out of his comfort zone to meet Piper halfway. The scene where he takes off his wedding ring had me sobbing. It was so raw with emotion and reflection. I love that he was described as a man that came with a whole roll of caution tape around him.

Piper is so Alexis Rose and I was there for every minute of it. She is painted as a dingbat with a tough exterior, but deep down, she struggles to identify her self worth. She has this softness to her that only Brenden seems to be able to decipher. As she spends more time away from LA, she starts truly seeing herself for the first time and I loved how she allowed herself to struggle with growth, but was open to love.

Together, Brendan and Piper are perfection. Both are learning to lean into the scary. They were simply made for each other. Brendan sees through all Pipers defenses and calls her on her crap. Piper challenges Brendan to live a little and go more with the flow, instead of being paralyzed by anything out of the ordinary. Because Brendan is all man and put together, he's the perfect person to settle Piper down. He knows what he wants and isn't afraid to work for it, even if it's a challenge.

Overall, I loved the book and cannot wait for Hannah's book next. This is a super steamy read with amazing character development and explosive chemistry.

Mrs. Kim is my hero!: Thank you to NetGalley, Avon and Harper Voyager for the advanced copy. All views are my own.

Jessie Kim has been the high achievement path her entire life. Pushed by her parents and her Korean heritage to always do more, Jessie has a high powered NYC Wall Street job and is on the path to promotion. That's until she gets fired over a group Zoom call for "not being a leader." Giving the chauvinistic men at her job the proverbial middle finger as she walks out, Jessie moves back to Nashville to live with her parents and lick her wounds. She isn't allowed to wallow long, when she runs into her middle nemesis, Daniel, who's now rich and hot. This, plus her mother's loud mouth, pushes Jessie to start her own meal kit hack YouTube channel, and Daniel just might be the key to help her succeed or potentially the downfall to the entire operation.

Suzanne Park's writing makes me smile. You can feel her character's emotions jumping off the page. I adored Loathe at First Sight and So We Meet Again did not disappoint. I did feel this book was more of a woman's fiction than a romance. There's definite romantic tones with Daniel's character, but for me, the book was more about self discovery and Jessie's complicated relationship with her mom and her culture's expectations.

Let's talk about the most important character in the book - the food. OH MY GOSH! This book had me craving Korean food the entire time and I felt like the food featured was on par with Accidentally Engaged. Creating a YouTube channel to hack meal kits?!?!? What a genius idea! I found myself wanting to buy these sauces and to follow Jessie's videos.

Jessie is fighting the good fight. What she dealt with at her company happens far too often. Being Asian and a woman, Jessie has a double whammy against her in the corporate world. I loved that this issue was tackled in the book and that while it hurt Jessie and caused her a lot of self doubt, she didn't let this moment define her. With that being said, Jessie is beautifully flawed. Dealing with a lot of guilt for never quite measuring up to expectations, she works hard to find her self worth and I loved the journey she took to get there. Plus, the inspiration she gained from Sun Tzu, who totally would make a great TED talk speaker today, was hilarious.

However, Mrs. Kim is the real MVP of the book. That woman was HILARIOUS. I about died when her mom jumped into the video, telling Jessie what to do and tasting the food, along with her dad. The entire book, Jessie is fighting what she thinks her parents want for her, which in turn holds her back for a time. It takes Mrs. Kim to shake Jessie out of her complacency to get the ball rolling. I was incredibly touched by the evolution of Mrs. Kim and Jessie's relationship and how the two women ended up understanding each other in the end. Jessie putting her perfectionism aside to allow her mom to help brought tears to my eyes.

Perfect Cinderalla Reimagining: In this Cinderella retelling, shoe obsessed Cindy is moving back to LA after a less than stellar senior year at Parsons. With little job prospects, she moves back to LA nanny her triplet half siblings, but finds herself competing on her step-mother's reality dating show. Only entering the competition to gain notoriety and prize money to start her own fashion line, Cindy is shocked to discover that the suitor she's competing for is none other than the Prince Charming she met in the airport on the way back to LA. When Cindy starts falling for Blake, are the feelings real or a product of doctored reality TV?

This book is such a breath of fresh air! From the opening pages, I could already tell this would be a five star read for me and I was obsessed. I had a hard time putting down the book and binged it in 24 hours. It completely got me out of a major book reading slump.

Cindy is everything. She is confident, knows her strengths and won't back down. I love her obsession with shoes and how she believes each pair tells a story. But I also appreciated her journey through grief and trying to figure out her life after the death of both of her parents.

Mr. Prince Charming, Henry, is super swoony. The banter between Cindy and Blake was easy and hilarious. I adored their meet cute in JFK. I found myself falling for Henry right alongside Cindy. In this closed-door romance, their interactions are adorable and easy. The pair just fit together.

Even though this is a retelling, I loved the strong female relationships in the story. Her step-mother and step-sisters were extremely likable and supported Cindy no matter what. The complicated relationship with the other front-runner, Sara Christine, was totally relatable. Cindy wanted to be friends with her, but when she realizes they are both falling for the same man, it pushes Cindy to figure some things out. The deceptions, unique dates and the comical mean girls kept me engaged and entertained. I loved the behind the scenes antics and workings of reality dating shows.

⚠️CW: death of parent, body image

This series just keeps getting better: Finally...FINALLY we get Rooney and Axel's story and goodness, it was absolute perfection. So many times when authors write series, their books become formulaic, following the same beats and pattern that are predictable. Chloe Liese's books don't. Each new book feels fresh, different and truly fits the Bergman sibling that it showcases.

Needing a break from law school to focus on her health, Rooney sets off to spend alone time at the Bergman A-frame. She runs smack dab into Axel, who's been fixing up the house, while trying to hide its true state of disaster from his entire family. With an artistic creative block, Axel's art is not selling and he has to come up with a plan to get the money to pay for the repairs quickly.

Axel has been a man of mystery in the first three books and it was a treat to get into his head throughout the book. Nobel and stoic, Axel craves to take care of things for his family, despite their sometimes rocky relationship. Ever the loaner, he's constantly at war with himself, battling the feelings for Rooney he's kept deep for two years. Axel wants to love, but he doesn't think he's capable of it. To his surprise, Rooney is also yearning for a sense of belonging and purpose. The two fit together beautifully. Axel comforts her insecurities and knows the right things to say in Rooney's moments of doubt. And Rooney truly sees Axel for who he is - imperfections and all - and still loves every bit of his being.

Chloe Liese is the QUEEN of slow burn romances! This pair has been doing a careful dance around each other for two years and the way they pine for each other and fight their feelings is just so good. Their romance is angsty and done beautifully as Rooney and Axel figure out their feelings for each other and what love looks like and means to them. I am always curious how a marriage of convenience trope will play out in contemporary romances and With You Forever does it perfectly. It's believable and realistic.

While we get small glimpses of some of the other Bergman siblings throughout the book, we get to know the A-frame and its neighbors more intimately. Wherever this A-frame and tiny town are located, I need to travel there. I can see it so clearly in my mind and it screams comfort and safety. I loved the inclusion of new characters. Skylar, Axel's goddaughter, is a hoot and adds impeccable comedic timing to every scene she enters. And the animals and Axel's relationship with them warmed my heart.

Once again, the short glimpses we get of Viggo is making me fall in love with his character more and more! He is such a big personality and I love the way he meets his brothers where they are to help them understand their feelings through romance novels.

There is truly only one word to describe this book: PERFECT. It's a hug for your heart and makes you believe in love for everyone. I couldn't have dreamed a better story for Rooney and Axel. I didn't want the book to end. If you haven't read this series, WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR?!?!?!

Women's Fiction: “Gwen didn’t need pity. She needed some help. Really, she needed a vacation.”

Gwen, a former stay at home mom, is now thrust back into the workforce when her husband loses his job. On the other side of the country, Iris is struggling to keep her marriage together all while hiding her dependence on wine. When these two friends will reconnect after losing touch year earlier, they just might be the lifeline that each other needs to pull through their struggles.

Reasons for Avoiding Friends was one of the realest books I've read in awhile. It frankly depicts life as a wife and a mother and let's face it...it's not always rainbows and sunshine. Growing up, you have this vision of what your life is going to be and soon you wake up almost 40 and you realize that your life is nowhere near that vision. Amplified by tough times and a crumbling marriage, it's never been more evident.

I related to both women, but Gwen's character spoke to me a little louder. As a wife and a mother, it's tough. Gwen's a great mom, but she lacks confidence in herself, especially as she ages and realizes her life is veering down a path she never thought it would go down. Coupled with financial problems that thrust her marriage into uncertain circumstances, it can feel almost impossible to wade through.

Reasons for Avoiding Friends has heavier themes, including alcoholism, rehab, cheating and stealing. It looks at perceptions that people have of others and the age old "the grass is always greener on the other side" mantra. It tackles how life choices in adulthood can impact our futures, whether we want them to or not.

Thank you to the author for a gifted copy.

Children and hangovers do not mix: I honestly didn't think I could love Alexa Martin's books more until I read Mom Jeans and Other Mistakes. It shows tremendous range to be able to write a novel so different from your last series, but still entertain and make the reader feel. This book is not a romance, but it does have hints of it along the way. This book is about friendship, motherhood, and the struggle to be all the things.

Lauren and Jude could not be more opposite, yet they are the best of friends, and have been since middle school. Now the pair are down on their luck and moving in together to help each other pick up the pieces of their lives. Single mom Lauren is the rule follower. Social media influencer Jude dances to the beat of her own drummer. But together, they are the definition of what it means to be a friend.

Lauren and Jude had such distinct voices. They were both hilarious and extremely relatable. As a mom, I felt Lauren's plights with her daughter Addy, who hands down stole the show for me. I mean seriously, how can kids lose their socks and shoes constantly?!?!?! I easily placed myself in her shoes with the day to day demands of motherhood and wanting to be everything to everyone and still follow the rules along the way.

While Lauren's struggles as a mom spoke to my heart, I also found myself relating to Jude's sailor mouth and unapologetic pursuit of her dreams. Jude has a lot on her plate and this leads to a very frank depiction of mental health struggles and alcoholism. I am so glad this was included in the book. At times, Jude's story was hard to read, but it was an accurate depiction of how complicated relationships and outside pressure can ultimately cause people to break.

Addy stole the show for me. That 6 year old tiny budding feminist captured my heart from the first pages. Whip smart and extremely funny, she's likely to rule the world one day. The authentic relationship between Jude and Addy is extremely endearing and sweet. I also adored Hudson, Lauren's love interest, who was a true stand up guy. Tender and so completely into Lauren, he had me swooning, but only after his disaster of an opening line, "reproduction is dope."

Mom Jeans and Other Mistakes is a must read. It celebrates true friendship and motherhood. It examines life in a digital age, where people have their outward persona that doesn't necessarily match the true state of their life and the toll it takes on a person. It delves into tough topics of mental health and race. It was everything I was expecting and more. GO OUT AND BUY THIS BOOK!!!

Perfect New Adult Hockey Romance: I absolutely adored C.W. Farnsworth's last sports romance, First Flight, Final Fall, so I jumped at the chance to read her latest one, Famous Last Words. I am so glad I did. This book is sneakily addictive and I just couldn't put it down.

Conor and Harlow have a mysterious and connected past that they just don't talk about. Both seniors at Holt University, Conor is aiming for the NHL, while Harlow has aspirations of being a marine biologist. They all but ignore each other on a daily basis, until a memorial marathon in Harlow's hometown thrusts the pair into training together. With forced proximity comes emotions, temptation and a whole bunch of steam.

As I get older, new adult isn’t a genre I am normally drawn to, but there is something about CW Farnsworth’s writing that just draws me in, especially her sports romances. Farnsworth has a great knack for nailing the pulse of being a collegiate athlete, especially with high aspirations and tenacious drive. I loved both Conor and Harlow's characters and the way their past connection was slowly revealed had me addicted. The couple had great banter and high chemistry.

I also appreciated that even though this is a new adult book, the characters were mature and layered. Both have been through some things in life. Neither were one noted and the layering of family drama, plus uncertainty about their future aspirations made for a compelling book.

A huge thanks to the author for the gifted copy.

Beautiful story of survival and friendship: I've been fairly blah on historical fiction lately. I feel like I keep reading the same thing about World War II over and over again. However, I decided to give The Keeper of Happy Endings a shot and I am so glad I did. Even days after finishing the book, I am still thinking about this powerful and incredibly original story that brought me to tears, gave me goosebumps and completely captivated my heart. I simply could not put this book down.

The Keeper of Happy Ending 40 years of history. Told in dual POV's, we meet Rory in 1985 who is devastated with the news that her fiance has been kidnapped while working with Doctors Without Borders. Struggling with a tumultuous relationship with her mother, she goes against her wishes to stay in school and plans to open an art gallery in an old wedding dress shop heavily damaged by fire years before. Her new landlady, Soline, is a bit of a recluse, but the unlikely pair strike up a friendship, when Rory returns a box of Soline's most prized possessions that she found while renovating.

This book intrigued me from the beginning; it was a surprise in the best way possible. Not heavy on history, The Keeper of Happy Endings is a story about hope and keeping faith, even when all is lost. It has air of suspense and mystery throughout. It gives just enough snippets of the past to wet my curiosity and then moves back to the “present."

I loved both Rory and Soline's characters and was deeply invested in their story. Soline's heartbreaking story of survival was completely captivating. The friendship between the two was so beautiful and I loved how there were lessons learned by all characters throughout. This is the first book to make me cry in a long time. I cannot recommend this book enough! It is surprising, wonderful, and so, so beautiful.

Thank you to the author and Suzy Approved Book Tours for the gifted copy.

Interesting glimpse into marriage and cultural duty: In a story that spans multiple continents and different cultures, The Baseball Window tells two concurrent stories about family, assumed duty, and love. Christine and Hideki live their lives according to baseball. With two children, one disabled, they struggle to find balance. Daisuke has come back home to Japan after a few years living in Atlanta to play baseball in hopes of making it to the championships. Told in multiple points of view, The Baseball Widow explores what happens when life isn't exactly how you imagined it would turn out.

It took me a hot minute to get into the story and sort out the different characters. But once I did, I found myself quickly turning pages to figure out what would happen next. I really enjoyed the glimpse into Christine and Hideki's struggling marriage. It seemed like they had a lot stacked against them and the author explores what happens when life isn't exactly what you signed up for when you say, "I do."

The portrayal of Hideki's plight to make it to the championships as a coach felt very real and accurate. Being a high level coach is difficult and the pressures can not only impact yourself, but also your family. There is truly no off season and this hinders you being able to see your family.

The story line of Christine's struggles with her disabled daughter and son who was being severely bullied was heartbreaking. As a mom, you want to do everything you can to help your children, but when raising children as a Westerner in a foreign country, it can be a struggle at best. Clashes of tradition, cultural expectations and lack of resources drove Christine to make some suspect decisions, but when faced with surmounting pressures, I can see why she did what she did.

New YA Fantasy Series: Teen Lilah finds herself in foster care after her grandmother passes away. The only silver lining to living with her weird new family is Joey lives next door. Joey, her deceased twin brother’s childhood best friend, is harboring a secret that threatens to separate the two with one lifelong decision.

I loved the mystery and intrigue of the Noliana carnival and how intertwined all the main characters were in the fabric of this fantasy world. From the spooky 🕷 symbols throughout and the motto of weaving our own destiny, I found myself needed to read more to figure out what all the clues meant. I also loved the inclusion of the tarot card readings and thrill-seeking rides.

Both Lilah and Joey share a traumatic past and their shared experiences help catapult them into a quick relationship. The book delves into themes of foster care and abandonment with care. Ending on a cliffhanger, I definitely want to continue to with the series to find out what happens next.

Pertinent Self-Help for Struggling Mothers: Sometimes you read books at exactly the time you need to hear the message. That was the case for me with the book Slay Like a Mother by Katherine Wintsch.

While the pandemic was hard on so many, the past 1.5 year has been incredibly difficult for me. Not only have I struggled with motherhood and juggling all the things, while still attempting to maintain my identity, but I also internally went to war on a daily basis with my own self-doubt. This ultimately led me to seek out therapy to work on myself so I could be the best mom and wife for my family.

“I suffered at the hands of my own unrealistic expectations, an ability to say no, and relentless pursuit of making my life appear as though it was under control.”

In Slay Like a Mother, the author provides personal anecdotes coupled with concrete examples to help you process the information presented. She offers prompts for reflection and actionable items. The book is witty, humorous and incredibly frank and honest.

So much of this book felt like the author was speaking directly to me. I grew up hanging my self-worth on the opinions of others, was overly sensitive and was in constant pursuit to overachieve. There were so many points the author made that deeply resonated with my personal journey.

A few takeaways include the knowing the different between struggling and suffering and the importance of setting boundaries in your personal and professional life. I especially loved the discussion about changing your social media feed to help your mental state. This has been a topic of discussion among my friends over the past year.

Bring the Tissues!: Super yacht stewardess Jo is feeling lost. Still reeling from the death of her nephew Samson three months earlier, Jo' is tasked with watching teenage nieces this summer while her sister works on her marriage. Then by a stroke of fate, the stranger she kisses at a bar turns up in the galley of her super yacht as the new chef. Together, the group helps Jo complete her 30 by 30 list through unforgettable events that not only solidify their bond, but also help Jo and her nieces with their grief.

Love, Lists and Fancy Ships captured my attention from the beginning and had me wanting to do nothing but read. I cannot believe this is a debut novel. I knew I would love it before I even read it and let me tell you, the book did not disappoint. It got me out of my reading slump. This book made me smile, laugh, and cry.

My husband and I are OBSESSED with Bravo's Below Deck and this book made me feel like I was in the middle of an episode of my favorite show. Everything felt so real and the characters came alive through the pages. I could feel their emotions right alongside them and there were moments in the book that completely shocked me.

Whether blood or found, this book explores the importance of family. Jo's relationship with her nieces extremely endearing. I love how both Kitty and Mia push her out of her comfort zone. They help Jo see that she has been keeping everyone at arm's length, afraid to get heart and afraid to truly feel. Their adventures in pursuit of the 30 by 30 list were so fun and original. And I am obsessed with her bestie Nina, who delivers quirk and sass in every scene. I cannot wait for her book next.

The group is muddling through the grief of losing Samson in their own ways. I loved how each character dealt with this tragedy completely differently, but they all are working toward the same goal of healing. They offer each other heart-warming gentle nudges along the way, which makes them realize that you can't ignore or outrun your grief. There are so many raw and vulnerable moments in this book.

Love, Lists and Fancy Ships is more than a romance. It's more than a chick lit book. This book is emotional, real and relatable. It is absolutely beautiful and an incredible debut novel. Bravo, Sarah.

Amazingly Original P&P Retelling: I have read my fair share of Pride and Prejudice retellings over the past year, but hands down, A Certain Appeal is one of my favorites! Set against the New York City burlesque scene, this book brings the original story into the modern day with a fresh and unique twist. I was immediately entranced by the world created in the opening pages, and the excellent pacing kept the book moving quickly, which is not normally the case with most.

I absolutely adored the heroine Bennet. She is trying to find her way in life, lost after a disastrous internship in LA. I loved how Bennet is shown not only as a ultra-feminine burlesque sex symbol, but then juxtaposes that image with her tough, tomboy side, rock climbing and playing dirty when she needs to, armed with a smart mouth full of sass. She doesn't back down from a fight and is loyal to the core.

The enemies to lovers relationship between Darcy and Bennet is done so good. The palpable, electric chemistry radiates off the pages, especially as the pair try hard to crack the others' resolve. A Certain Appeal is a super slow burn with steam, but it is so worth the wait. The underlying theme of consent is not only beautiful, but incredibly sexy.
