Both Darcy and Bennet put high esteem in building trust first, so when they finally give into their desire for each other, it's nothing short of magic. And oh Darcy...he is so tender under his prickly, tough exterior. I loved watching Bennet slowly break down his emotional walls.

We also get an added bonus of so many amazing secondary characters, it's really hard to pick a favorite. The supporting cast truly brings this retelling to life. The theme of found family was so well-done; I was rooting for the ragtag Meryton group the entire time.

Fun and Wild Cozy Mystery: In the third installment of the Sassy Cat Mystery series, Mimi is back and ready to solve a new crime along with Marshmallow and her boyfriend, Josh. When the couple go on a romantic getaway to Catalina Island, they are shocked to find out that the last renter turns up dead after trashing the rental. Mimi's friend and financial backer, Pixie is suspected of the murder, when a threatening letter is discovered. But the case heats up when missing valuables are reported missing all over Catalina Island.

This book is definitely my favorite of the series. I love Mimi's quirky character and enjoyed getting to know her friends and family throughout the three books. The added tension of relationship troubles between Josh and Mimi added another layer of drama that really drew me into the book. I really enjoyed this cozy mystery!

Boy Band Coming of Age Story with Tons of Heart: I have been dying to read If This Gets Out since Sophie Gonzales told my book club about the premise of the book earlier this year. Let me tell you, this book does not disappoint! I absolutely loved the book from start to finish.

Boy band Saturday is getting ready to kick off the European leg of their tour and the foursome is getting antsy. Everything about the band is curated by their management team. Each member has a different personality and what they do and say is strictly enforced; every member plays a distinct role in keeping the public's attention and adoration for the group thriving. With the group forming at a summer camp, the band, now all almost 18, are starting to have growing pains as they realize their true identities don't necessarily match up with what their team wants for them. When romantic sparks fly between two of the band-mates, the pair has to decide how far are they willing to be pushed without sacrificing all that they love and stand for, especially when everything starts to fall apart.

This was such a fun read! I loved getting the behind the scenes look at boy bands, especially as an 80s baby, who was raised on boy bands. The interactions between the band members were so fun and I loved how they supported each other through anything, even the tough stuff. If This Gets Out makes me question so many of the outward personas of celebrities and artists, many who are probably stifled having to live part of their life as a lie. The theme of found family was hopeful and the book gave me definite The Charm Offensive vibes. I was obsessed reading to find out what would happen next with the band and completely devoured this book in less than a day.

I absolutely adored Ruben's character and how he stood with his convictions. He knows who he is and what he wants out of life, so he never really lets his guard down completely around management. I hated that he was forced into hiding his sexuality, especially after he finally got everything he had hoped for. Loved the theater geek aspect of his personality and how understanding he was with Zach.

Zach's journey was so beautiful and a story that needs to be told. He was thoughtful and incredibly creative, striving to write the next great song for Saturday. While the other members grew up privileged, Zach takes nothing for granted, working tirelessly to provide for his mom. His path to figuring out his sexuality was honest, emotional and so well-written.

I LOVED Zach and Ruben together as a couple. This friends to lovers m/m romance was so sweet and tender, especially highlighting a first love. Both characters gave each other space to figure out what they wanted, but they also supported each other, forgiving the other when they may have inadvertently done something wrong. I highly recommend this book!

Regency Romance full of fashion (and horses!): Evelyn Maltravers has two passions in life - horses and fashion. Thrust into London society to attract a husband, Evelyn enlists the help of up-and-coming designer Ahmad Malik to create one of a kind riding habits for her season. When the pair band together to take the fashion world by storm, sparks fly in this forbidden love regency romance.

The Siren of Sussex was such a fun read! I immensely enjoyed the fashion and could picture each outfit Mr. Malik created for Evelyn. The characters shared a common ground of family duty, which stood in their way for most of the book. This slow burn romance had amazing sexual tension, although I was hoping for more steam. The historical aspect of class and racial divisions was handled beautifully and I appreciated the Author's Note at the end of the book.

Both characters show growth, but I especially loved Evelyn's transformation. She goes from someone who is more confident on horse than in the company of people to slowly finding her voice and stands up for what's right, not per society's norms. At the end, she's a force to be reckoned with and I enjoyed all the twists and turns that brought Evelyn and Malik together.

What I loved most were the small acts of love that the pair did for each other. It was sweet the lengths they would go for each other. The secret pockets in the riding habits was the best. As a history teacher, I loved that Evelyn wanted to learn about the colonization of India not from the British perspective, but from the Indian perspective.

I cannot wait to see where the series goes next, especially with the teaser at the end of the book!

Beautiful and Tender LBGTQ Romance: Recently divorced, Dahlia is looking to reinvent herself. Too bad her first impression in the Chef's Special TV show is tripping and sending her fish tacos across the room in front of the judges. After announcing their pronouns on the show, London has their eye on the prize to win, but love was never on the menu...until they meet Dahlia and decide to throw their recipe right out the window.

Love & Other Disasters was an absolutely beautiful and endearing love story. It is a story about self-discovery, sexuality and friendship. Full of touching and emotional moments, I laughed, I cried and I swooned. Both London and Dahlia are struggling with their own inner demons, which gave their characters and the plot great depth. They have fun together, but handle each other’s emotions with care and when obstacles arise, the figure it out together.

Frantic and a little all over the place, Dahlia brings the quirky charm. She can be a friend to anyone with her eccentricity. I loved how messy and vulnerable she was throughout the book. Ever reserved, London tends to observe their surroundings. In a world full of inequalities and uncertainty, cooking is what London can control. Dahlia and London balance each other out and truly make each other better.

Let's be honest. There's something super sensual and sexy about cooking together and this book brought the heat. It was super steamy and yet intimate and tender at the same time. With a bisexual and non-binary leads, I loved the diversity portrayed in the book. I hope Love & Other Disasters starts a trend for more open and honest romances that celebrate all forms of love.

Steamy Billionaire Romance: An arranged marriage between two billionaire families can only mean one thing...there's a new power couple in NYC. When Crew and Scarlett tie the knot, they are merging their families and money, but will they also be merging their hearts? Or will their marriage only be a business deal?

Fake Empire is so different from anything C.W. Farnsworth has published so far, but I was completely along the ride for the entire book. I loved the range shown through the writing and the rich world created. There were unexpected twists and turns, so I was hooked right from the beginning. Once I started reading, I could not put this one down.

Scarlett's character enticed me from the beginning. Painted as an ice queen through the gossip train, there is much more to her than people realize. Because of her circumstances and upbringing, Scarlett is incredibly guarded and has immense emotional walls up to protect her heart. Even though the public perception is that everything is handed to her, Scarlett has had to fight for everything she has. She is determined with an immense amount of grit. I loved how she went toe to toe with everyone, but especially Crew.

I loved Crew's character. On the outside, he's cocky and gets anything he wants, but in reality, he's committed and sensitive. Crew is different when he's with Scarlett and it was endearing how he worked so hard to win her over. Even though he challenges her at every turn, Crew is incredibly sweet, caring, and supportive of Scarlett.

Together, Crew and Scarlett are an instant power couple, even though they are both determined to keep their relationship nothing more than a business transaction. They have great banter and I absolutely loved how they would try to one-up the other in pet names. Watching these two fall in love, despite them fighting at every turn, was a treat. The pair faces obstacles and through them, they become each others's support systems in a world where you can trust no one.

Fake Empire is a steamy billionaire romance with unexpected twists and turns in the elite world of the NYC rich.

So freakin good: Ugh...this book! I laughed and nearly cried all in one day of reading!
Lake and Will have had a very strong connection from the moment they met. They have a perfect first date. Their little brothers become immediate best friends. What could go wrong?
Well let me just tell you that Colleen Hoover knows exactly how to throw a wrench into any love story, but she does it so beautifully that you can’t even be mad at her for it!
Such a great story from start to finish!
Second book in series: This book was good as a sequel, but as is often the case, the sequel is rarely as good as the original.

Must Read: Look, I pre-ordered this book as soon as it was available. The day it released, my physical copy wasn’t here. I thought, I can wait a couple days for it to arrive. In the meantime, I’m mid 2 kindle books and an audio. My physical copy arrives, I’ve just finished my audio but still mid the 2 e-books. So I do what any sane person does, I buy the audible and start it. I finish one of the e-books so I decide to pick up the physical copy of this book and start where my audible left off. After reading for a few hours I decided it was time for bed (after midnight) but when I got to bed I couldn’t turn off my brain. Again, being the same person I am, I downloaded the Kindle Unlimited copy of this book and read for a bit more until I fell asleep. Woke up this morning and dove right in and now I’m done.
This book had me feeling all the feels that only Colleen Hoover can evoke. You don’t need me to recap the story, that’s what the synopsis is for but hot damn this was a good book! Thank CoHo from the very bottom of my heart for this masterpiece!

A Classic for a Reason: There is a reason Dune is one of the classic scifi books and it’s completely justified. I’ve had so many meaningful and deep conversations with my spouse and my co-workers about this book, from the conservatorship of ecology to feminism and LGBTQIA issues in the 60’s.

If you read scifi and haven’t picked this one up. DO. Yes, it’s long, but IT’S SO WORTH IT. The chapters themselves are often short, each with action that drives the plot. You are NEVER going to find two pages of dense description. That is not Herbert’s style. It’s well paced and information is doled out in just the right ways and at the right times to keep you reading and simultaneously wanting more.

Dune is about the Atreides House being relocated to the desert spice planet of Dune. Spice is one of the most important substances in this universe, responsible for trade, seasoning, and some crazy trips. When Paul’s father, the Duke, is assassinated, Paul and his mother, a powerful woman with skill taught through decades of training, escape into the desert. Paul soon learns that the indigenous people of Dune, the Fremen, have been waiting for him, their savior, and he leads them out of the dark caves and into power.

The popular main criticism with this book is it’s white-saviorism, which is very evident in a Black Lives Matter age. I also read it through the lens of feminism and LGBT equality and it held up far better in one arena than another, but not perfect in either regard. This book was first published in 1965, so to expect those things is to be let down. Dune has many strong and powerful women and girls: Jessica, Paul’s Mother, Alia, his sister who can kill someone by the time she’s four, and Chani, a Fremen fighter. However, the final lines of the book basically say, “they may marry someone else, but people will know that the mistresses hold the power/his heart,” which just centers three incredibly strong, intelligent, powerful women in how they relate to a man. This book also has one of my most hated tropes: the only known gay person is a pedophile. I REALLY hate that plot device for the obvious reason as it’s a hate-mongering dog whistle for the anti-LGBT. I know nothing of Herbert’s politics, but I really hope he was cool.

Despite all that, I really thought this book was fantastic and I may consider reading more in this universe.

Don’t forget the movie comes out in October and the prequel tv series on HBO! Better get reading now! -Ford

Better Than Six of Crows: Another amazingly well-paced heist book by Leigh Bardugo. Crooked Kingdom picks up right after Six of Crow, so I recommend reading that one first, just to get a sense of the stakes and how injured all the characters still are.

I really love a heist book and Bardugo wraps so much action into her books it’s hard to tell where the traditional book structure is. What is the inciting incident? Where does Act 2 start and end? Just so much well-crafted story to immerse yourself in.

Other than their boundless amounts of energy and lack of needing sleep, I often forgot this team was teenagers.

There is a moment towards the end of the book where the team fakes a plague and boy, was that part so accurately written. It was uncanny. - Ford

CW: stabbings, death, pandemic/plague, gambling, sexual assault, physical assault

A perfect depiction of Persephone: I’ve been a longtime follower of Punderworld when it was on WebToons and I’m beyond delighted to see it get published.

Volume 1 is a short, quick read -it’s a graphic novel- that’s a re-telling of Persephone and Hades. This segment of the story shows their chance meeting, wistful longing from afar, some meddling from Zeus, and their crash landing in the Underworld. Linda Sejic perfectly depicts the razors edge of Persephone’s personality, the maker and the destroyer. Hades is a shy, introverted, workaholic who isn’t smooth but senses Persephone’s awkwardness matches his. His nervousness in her presences is the ultimate sweetness.

I cannot wait for Volume 2! -Ford

Fantastic!: This was such a thoughtful, lovely, representation of what can happen when two adults are in a relationship. It’s honest and sexy. They talk to each other, they have healthy and not-so-healthy relationships with people outside of each other. They set personal goals, they show up for their friends. They make mistakes. They own up to the missteps and correct them.

This was such a refreshing read because I didn’t need to give it slack to be good enough, it was good without any mental gymnastics.

My only caveat is that the original permissive is built on a lot of exposition, it took me out of their relationship in the current moment, just a bit.

On the other hand, I would watch the hell out of the first three seasons of Gods of the Gates.

Lastly, if anyone knows where I can find the Cupid/Psyche pegging fic? (Second book, you say? See you there.)-Sky

I'm confused about the white-centered storyline...: I was loaned this series by a white friend as a continuation in my study and learning about Black stories and what a better one, than the most popular black superhero: Black Panther.

This collection was very surprising to me because it’s a white guy, Everett K. Ross's POV. He’s the attaché to T’Challa and gets swept up in dangerous plots to overthrow the Wakandan King. At the end of this volume, he becomes the interim king of Wakanda. A white guy. I’m just continuously confused at the white-centered narrative in a black comic written by a black man.

My white friend told me to wait for it. There is a payoff to it all, but I don’t want to see Wakanda besmirched by a white ruler. I want Wakanda to stay black forever!

Priest does a great job of balancing the white-centered story of Everett with depictions of Black love between T’Challa, his friends, his family, and his fellow superheroes. There is also an amazing spread in “Uptown”, #17, of Black Panther, Iron Fist, Power Man (Luke Cage), and The Falcon fighting Deadly Nightshade, Stiletto, Morgan, Cottonmouth, and Cockroach, all of whom (with the exception of Stiletto) are people of color! It’s an incredibly powerful fight scene to see. Falcon and Power Man are passing everyone, just delightful.

I’m going to keep reading to get to this white guy payoff, but also, more importantly, to experience Black stories and Black power. I’m so happy that Wakanda exists out there for people. -Ford

A love story written in hunger and colors.: A love story written in hunger and colors. In science fiction poetry. Set in time known, unknown, and remade. This book is beautiful and difficult and so very everything. It is flavors and sounds. Nature and machine.

I’m swept away by this story about Red and Blue, two agents on the opposite sides of a time war. Their letters to each other first begin as taunts and then turn into something more, something beyond time but still held within a seed.

This book has made me feel undone and then stitched back together in Red and Blue thread. -Ford

Bachelor meets Bridgerton: I adored the romantic storyline in this series, especially in book 1. It's similar to the Bachelor in that Prince Maxon is choosing a wife from 35 girls selected from each district in the country of Illea. However, the way the characters fall in love is very similar to Bridgerton- two characters who befriend each other and end up realizing they cannot be apart. I could read the romantic scenes again and again.
The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars is because the plot is a little frustrating in the second and third books. The main character, America, keeps going back and forth between the two men in her life and honestly probably should be eliminated from The Selection several times. Also, I felt like the ending was extremely rushed. I wanted to hear more about things are resolved with the love triangle and with the rebel forces that they are facing throughout the story. Luckily the romance outshines these problems, and I still find myself wanting to read this series again and again.

This series deserves more hype: I discovered this series after reading The Selection and seeing it on a recommended book list. I honestly don't think it's that similar other than the fact that it involves a caste system and royalty, but I am glad that I decided to give it a try. I absolutely LOVED the storyline of this series. The characters are all likable and have good character development. Even the main antagonist, The Duchess of the Lake, had some moments when I felt bad for her and wanted to learn more of her story. I do think that readers should be aware of the heavy amount of abuse and violence that the characters face in this series. It could definitely be triggering for those who have dealt with abuse or just are uncomfortable reading about it. That being said, I liked how the characters became stronger and fought back against the evil treatment of the royals. There is a romantic storyline, which I enjoyed, but it isn't as front and center as other YA books. Only the first book in the series really focuses on the romance, and then it's more minor in the second and third books. I thought I would be disappointed by this, but the overall story was so compelling that I didn't feel like I was missing out on anything. My only complaint is that the third book is a little slow for the first half, but it was worth it to see some of the side characters developed more leading up to the big ending.
This is definitely a series I plan to read again and again.

Intriguing Story of Female Empowerment: 4.5 stars

1 out of 5 steam level- kissing only

Trigger warning- terminally ill parent

Sixteen year old Rhen Tellur lives in Pinsbury Port, a seaside town in the province of Caldon where each year eligible males are invited to take part in The Labyrinth- a competition for a university scholarship. Rhen is tired of living in the shadow of men. She wants more than to just be a wife and mother and decides to disguise herself as a boy to compete in this year's competition. Her goal? To go on to university and discover a cure for the deadly disease that is plaguing the citizens of Pinsbury Port, including her mother. Will Rhen survive the competition and get the resources and training to find a cure? Or will her identity keep her from achieving her goals?

I really enjoyed this book! As soon as I read the book summary, I was intrigued by the idea of The Labyrinth and what the competition might entail. I'm happy to say that I wasn't disappointed. It felt a little bit like The Hunger Games in how the competition was dangerous, competitors turned against one another, and they had to figure out how to move forward to the finish. It did take awhile to get into the story at first, and I was surprised that I got halfway through the book before the competition even started. Luckily, the characters and love triangle in the beginning kept me hooked, and the actual Labyrinth was exciting and mysterious. And even though the result of the competition was a little predictable, there were still some surprises even near the end of the story that kept me interested. I really enjoyed Rhen as a main character, and I liked seeing her torn between the two love interests, Vincent and Lute. Her cousin, Seleni, was also a loyal friend, and I liked seeing her help out and encourage Rhen throughout the story. The only reason I couldn't give this 5 stars is because there were a few fantasy elements like ghouls and other dangerous creatures that seemed kind of unnecessary to the story other than during the time spent in The Labyrinth. Other than that I really liked the book and was happy with how the author wrapped everything up for the characters.

Follow me on Instagram @readwithsuzie for more reviews!

Tessa and Luke bring the romance: Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐💫 (4.5)
Steam Level: 🔥 (kissing only)
Trigger Warning: infertility, death of a parent and cheating mentioned briefly

Ever since learning she can't have children, Tessa Johnson has put all her focus into being successful at her career. So when her boss tells sends her to Turks and Caicos to delay the opening of a new hotel, Tessa is determined to do whatever it takes. The only problem is the contractor, Luke McKenna, is a broody workaholic who doesn't like Tessa leading team-building activities and wearing high heels on a construction site. As Tessa tries to waste time, Luke only seems to work harder to get the job finished. But these complete opposites can't deny their physical attraction to each other and soon find themselves opening up and spending more time together than they originally intended. Will love distract them both from doing their jobs?

Kortney Keisel has done it again! After reading the first two Johnson sibling's stories, I was excited to see how things would play out for Tessa. When she first meets Luke she does come across as superficial and high maintenance, but we soon learn that it's all for show and a way to cover for her insecurities. The beginning of the book did move a little slow, since Tessa and Luke try to avoid each other and work towards opposing goals. Luckily the second half of the book is where things kick into high gear with steamy chemistry and tender moments between the two leads. I adored the moments when Tessa was vulnerable and really opened up to Luke about her infertility, the loss of her mom, and her insecurities about her job and her appearance. The way Luke reacted in those moments was so sweet. I was nervous as we got to the main conflict in the book, but I felt like it was resolved well without being brushed off too easily. And I was so excited to get some glimpses of Ben, the love interest in Brooke's story that's coming next. Friends to lovers is a favorite of mine, and I look forward to reading their story!

This gave me all the feels!: Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
Steam Level: 🔥🔥🔥🔥 (very descriptive sex scenes)
Trigger Warning: death of a parent

Fifteen years ago Macy met Elliot, and he became her first everything- best friend, kiss, boyfriend, and more. They only got to see each other on the weekends or over the summer, but their worlds revolved around each other. Then it all fell apart, and they lost touch for eleven years. Now Macy is engaged and has a residency at UCSF while Elliot is using his love of books to write his own novel. When they happen to see each other at a coffee shop, they're both brought back to the years they spent together and the way things ended. While Elliot is ready to move forward and pick back up where they left off, Macy has to decide whether or not to break off her engagement and put her heart on the line again. Could her first love be the one she's meant to be with forever?

Wow, this book gave me all the feels! I love when writers use a then and now timeline to help readers understand what the characters went through and how it shaped their future. I think the flashbacks actually hit me the hardest in this one. Macy and Elliot had an instant connection, and I just loved seeing them grow up together and deal with grief, jealousy, and sex during their high school years. I was actually surprised by how many intimate things they discussed, and it definitely added to the angst and tension. When they reunited, I really felt for Elliot and his desire to get Macy back. It was hard to see Macy with her fiance, but I think the love triangle was handled well. And I definitely wasn't prepared for all the details of how things ended between them when they were younger. Let's just say that it was really emotional, and you will want your Kleenex box ready. I do wish they had talked about the past sooner, but I suppose it was more dramatic with how it came out near the end. And even though things wrapped up quickly, I enjoyed the ending. This is definitely one of my favorites from Christina Lauren.

Precious but Tragic Story: Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
Steam Level: 🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥 (very descriptive/erotic sex scenes)
Trigger Warning: death of a parent, fatal car crash, gun violence, attempted rape, brief mentions of domestic violence and cheating

Sixteen years ago Archer Hale's life was changed forever when both of his parents died following a car accident that also left him unable to speak. Ever since then he has lived a secluded life, unable to communicate other than through writing. Then Bree Prescott comes to town. When she crosses paths with Archer, she becomes curious about him and his past. Since she is fluent in sign language, she slowly gains Archer's trust and begins spending more time with him. Bree realizes that Archer has little to no experience with things like driving, texting, and sex. But Archer's kindness and work ethic make up for what he lacks in social skills and soon Bree finds herself falling for him. As secrets about both of their pasts are revealed, Archer worries that Bree won't be able to handle a life with him. Is their romance destined for failure or will true love win out in the end?

Archer Hale is the most precious human in the world and you cannot change my mind! Reading about his tragic past was heartbreaking, but he still grew up to be a selfless, smart, and considerate man. Even though most of the book was from Bree's POV, the chapters from Archer's perspective were really special and deeply emotional. I hated that the town basically neglected him after the accident and thought he was a weirdo, but in the end it was heartwarming to see some of them apologize for the past and try to get to know him. Bree was really likable for me. I loved that from the very beginning she saw something in Archer and refused to just listen to the gossip about him. The fact that they were able to communicate with sign language was so beautiful and just added to the intimacy between them. And the ending! I was not prepared for that emotional rollercoaster 😭 My only complaint is that there were A LOT of descriptive sex scenes. I had to skim several of them as the book went on. Otherwise I absolutely loved this book and highly recommend it!

Not enough info for a true beginner: I had to do quite a bit of research to find the equipment needed. I wish the authors had given brands for all the equipment. They recommend a 2-quart dutch oven and it is very difficult to find such. Perhaps it is a supply chain problem. He uses Lodge and they do not list it on their website and it is not on Amazon or elsewhere. His co-author, Kerri, uses Le Creuset and they make a 3 1/2 quart dutch oven. So just getting set up is a major project! I hope to get there, but it is requiring patience.  I was inspired by Mark's piece in the NYT and podcast. I am a true beginner when it comes to bread and in his podcast, Mark makes it sound much easier and less timely than the recipe actually is.
TBR: TBR List

Great addition to the storyline: I have been binge-reading VGO 1-5 and chronologically, Side Quests was next. Absolutely loved the short stories of Travelers we have not heard about that could make an impact down the line. Plus, a main character is fleshed out and the most enjoyable chapter about a spider. I really hope we hear more about the spider in books 6-8. Be sure to include this book on your VGO reading list.

So glad to see Vince Flynn reincarnated!: Flynn's style and pace and the incredible Much Rapp carries on still! Always a great mix of politics and international intrigue and Kyle Mills doesn't disappoint!

Fell flat, ending very predictable: I really wanted to love this book, but I just couldn’t. The ending was predictable way too early, and in what felt like an attempt to throw the reader off, the author has the MC suddenly doing things unbeknownst to the reader, which didnt make sense with the flow of the whole book. Instead it felt like a cheap attempt to surprise people with an ending. The one character i actually liked got a horrible ending, which was probably the only surprise to the whole book.
Interesting idea with the shadows and shadow magic, but I feel it could’ve been done much better.
Pitiful. Waste of time, contrived, hack job, trading in brothers name.: Cheap knockoff, no plot, stupid waste of money.

Great book!!! Well written too: I’m getting a second book so each of my elementary age children can see the dangers of censorship and the evident hysteria when they get older. My 10 year old will read it this month. By the time they are adults, the unnecessary damage done, especially to children, and complete collapse of scientific debate in order to find truth, will be well known.

What I want my kids to see, and Alex’s book does a great job of explaining, is that a meaningful minority of us saw the truth very early. I always tell my kids don’t stop until you get to the source - the source document or data. It’s terrifying that real information has been available throughout, yet my generation, ruined by an obsession with over simplified bubble tests, was simply too lazy to read the actual studies or look at the actual data.

Yes, the media has lied - which is nothing new. We were getting out of grad school with the WMD Iraq lies. This book captures those lies and will eventually become an important piece when future generations attempt to answer the questions “what made the world go completely insane all at once? how did that happen?”

Our refusal to stand up for our own children and seek truth and protect our children from predictable physiological and educational damage is heartbreaking (they don’t need to be protected from a virus that poses virtually no risk to them). Thank you for this important book Alex!!!!

Great book. Must read for balance: This is an important book for all adolescent girls to understand the power of social contagion. As a young girl I was convinced I should have been a boy. Like most, I outgrew it naturally as I got older and I’m now a happily married mom of 2 with strong but comically female body I love. More than that, I love my body for my marriage and, most of all, that I grew and gave birth to 2 amazing humans from my body.

I am still a Tom Boy at heart who breaks a lot of molds, and I love doing that in the one body I get in this life. I am so sad to think how many girls are being robbed of that choice as adults because of perceptions and feelings they cannot possibly understand as kids or teenagers.

I fully support adults living however they want, so long as immutable biology remains recognized in sports and private spaces. Before any girl makes permanent changes to their body that interferes with its natural reality, they should at least consider the important information in this book. There is no “right” way to be a girl, and there is no replacing mutilated reproductive parts.

Every noice made me jump!: Great story, Vivian Delaney goes missing from The Sun Down Motel, fast forward over thirty years her niece takes interest in finding out what happened. I story full of mystery and wandering spirits that will make you jump in your seat.
Addictive: Great plot, with a couple of surprises that I was not expecting, kept me wanting to know what happened next.
Do not bother....: This book took a meandering path to a non sensual ending.please don't waste your time and money it will be wasted.

Fun fast read: This is one of Parker's best books, and Holly Barker is a great addition to the story..

I highly recommend this book.
Panzerwaffe: Service and material excellent
Delicious, easy to follow, lots of photos!: My family loves these recipes. There s no calorie, carb counting here!!

Unputdownable!: As with any TF book, I went in totally expecting to be taken on a wild ride. I was not disappointed! I started it before bed one night and didn't sleep until I finished. I was not going to stop until I knew how everything played out!! Tarryn weaves a thrilling and addicting web of twists and turns that kept me glued to the story. I was absolutely invested in Rainy and her crazy life story. I loved how the stories of the past come together with the story of Rainy's present. There were some shocking and unbelievable moments that made this book a page-turner. An Honest Lie is an honest hit!

Fascinating character and interesting sleuthing aspects. Goes deep into some global finance history.: I enjoyed the very well developed main characters in both books in this series and loved the overall plot lines. The story went more deeply than I would have liked into historical financial agencies, governmental wrongdoing,  and corruption. But that's when the skimming option came in handy, and I did, overall, very much enjoy both of these books. Very well written, with just 2 or 3  typos across both substantial  books.

Great Tips That You Will Use: I had purchased Pogue's other two books and really enjoyed them, so this was a slam dunk. I like books of this type and he's got some really obscure tips that you'll like as much as I did.
Awful narrator: The reading of the audible story is horrible. Don’t recommend it.

Rich in history: I have loved this whole series, but this book was especially well written and rich in history of the Irish struggle for independence. Jean Grainger is an expert storyteller for sure, but she takes it to the next level with this book, weaving history with a great story that has drama, love, mystery. Historical fiction at its best!

history: 031603438X B017R5C79W B01HH4QZNC B079L51HZG 1791516424 B08NW8TTNM B08WZH544S B09CRN5QKJ
review: Loved this series: Jean Grainger is a master storyteller whose characters you grow to know and love through this series of stories. I always learn something about Irish history, and this book was no different. She also addresses womens issues, racism and the struggles of gay men in that era. This book can stand alone but I almost wish it didn’t. At times I felt the story slowed by having to go back and explain who was who from other books. All the books in this series are rich with interesting characters and the roles they play in the overall storyline. This finale was entertaining and satisfying.

history: 031603438X B017R5C79W B01HH4QZNC B079L51HZG 1791516424 B08NW8TTNM B08WZH544S B09CRN5QKJ B09QFDCHT7
review: My 26th review for this author: I have loved everyone of Jean Graingers books and my reason is the same for all of them! Great storytelling, dialogue and characters who you can relate to. I loved the characters and the settings in this newest series, can’t wait for the next installment! If you want to escape to 1950’s Ireland with family drama, love story, intrigue, then you will love this book!

Quite Comprehensive: How to cook everything in your air fryer is explained within this book.  From very simple to more complex, you'll find it here.  YOU WILL find things you never would have thought to put in your air fryer!
Overall Great Cookbook: Overall a great Vegan cookbook.  No bells and whistles, no pictures, just bunches and bunches of recipes. You're sure to find some you will find some that you will love.

Must Read Epic Fantasy: The Pariah was my first book by Anthony Ryan and he is a master at his craft. His story telling is nothing short of phenomenal. I was honestly drawn to it by the cover. It’s haunting singular character, face cast in shadow, sitting with a sword, is beautiful. The reader instantly wants to know: who is this character? Is it indeed The Pariah as named? They say never judge a book by its cover, but in this case, it’s safe to say that my judgement was correct. The book is told in the first-person narrative of Alwyn, later known as Alwyn Scribe. Not only is it first-person, but Alwyn often addresses the reader as he is writing his tale
Mr. Ryan’s battle scenes are on par with the best I have read. They are brutal, bloody, gritty and real. War is not clean, and Mr. Ryan holds nothing back. While there is gore and violence, the reality and odds these characters face are driven home. The action is well-paced and, yes, descriptive. This is necessary not only to bring the reader into the battle, but to show what Alwyn, Toria, and Brewer (Alwyn's friends) are facing.
The Pariah is easily on par with the best of fantasy novels in the genre. With brilliant character development, beautiful writing, and world building, The Pariah is sure to become a classic. Told in the first-person perspective of the main protagonist, Alwyn, the story unfolds in a unique and exceptional way. The characters are very well developed, each with their own complexity and story arc. There are battles, gore and torture, but it is an essential part of the story, and the reality is, that war is not neat and clean. When the story is told in the first-person narrative, it makes sense to see the grit, blood, and hard choices of life and death in battle. Alwyn’s narrative often speaks directly to the reader, which I found very interesting and it makes us feel Alwyn’s experiences. As the first book in The Covenant of Steel Series, The Pariah certainly has it off to an excellent start. I eagerly await the next book in the series.

Strong Debut Fantasy Novel: With a strong female protagonist, Ryia Cautella, Among Thieves is a unique and fantastic debut fantasy novel by M.J. Kuhn. The action starts from page one and doesn’t let up until the last page. The story takes place in Carrowick, part of Thamorr. Each part of Thamorr is ruled by various kings. However, the real power of Thamorr lies with the Guildmaster, and it is all tied into the magic system of the novel. It is a very clever system that Ms. Kuhn has developed. The Guildmaster has the ability to know when a child is born with magic. When they are, they are taken from their parents by the age of one to be trained as an Adept. For this reason, most parents do not name their children until after their first year. They must give up their children to the Guildmaster if they possess magic. How he knows, the reader does come to find out. Those who are the strongest will stay with the Guildmaster. Those who are not, become devoid of all emotion and sold to nobles at an auction. It is also unknown how the Guildmaster strips these Adepts of their humanity. Adepts possess one of two types of magic: the Kinetics, who have unnatural strength and speed or they are Sensers, who can smell physical danger and the intent to harm. I thought it was incredibly ingenious to have Adepts who move quickly and are unnaturally strong to be called Kinetics, as kinetic energy is the energy of motion.
Among Thieves is an excellent debut novel by M.J. Khune. It has all the elements that makes a great fantasy. The character development is fantastic. There are three strong female protagonists in the book. Ryia, the main character, has a fully developed story arc. She has characteristics that one would often see in male protagonists and she really is an amazingly well-done character. The prose is beautifully done, with each chapter focusing on one character at a time. The chapters are woven together to move the story forward with well-paced action interspersed with character interaction. The idea of Adept magic called Kinetics and Sensers is a unique magic system to add into the fantasy genre. Overall, Among Thieves is an excellent debut novel by M.J. Khune. I highly recommend it.

Brilliant, Moving Science Fiction: I can’t even describe how brilliant this novel is. If I was blown away by Goodbye to the Sun, I was even more so by Jati’s Wager. Jati’s Wager picks up the story nine years after Keen Draden’s death. Gender fluidity is still an important and essential part of this novel, just as it was in the first. One must always ask how one identifies their gender, no matter who, and not to do so is considered extremely rude. It is identified by a suffix added to the end of their name. Inclusivity is very important in the genre, so this in itself was an amazing concept to include. Jati, who identifies as non-binary, now heads the People’s Army fighting the Tide War as a well-respected General. They have made great gains in taking back planets from the Garassian council and preventing terraforming
Jati’s Wager is an absolutely magnificent novel. The characters are fully developed, and have complete story arcs. The main protagonists, Ailo and Jati fit so well together, as Ai comes to see Jati as parental figure and teacher, and becomes protective of them. She in awe of the them. Jati is a mentor, warrior, leader and teacher to his crew. They are the glue that binds them together, and it all works. The prose is beautiful and unique. The first-person narrative chapters are of Ai’s subconscious “friend” Gerib, who helps to keep her difficult memories at bay, thereby protecting her psyche. Other chapters move the story along with both action and character development. The story itself is an emotional roller coaster. When you can so deeply about characters and the story, you know you have just read an incredible novel. Jati’s Wager is perfection and science fictions at its finest. I highly recommend it.

Beautiful Debut Fantasy: It is hard to imagine a more beautiful debut fantasy than Daughter of the Moon Goddess. I always find it refreshing to have fantasy novels that are not set in a “traditional Eurocentric” world. Sue Lynn Tan has created a magical world for the reader to be immersed in. The overarching theme of family and love permeates the book and drives the characters and story forward. By writing the story in the first-person narrative of Xinging, we feel the heartbreak of Chang’e having to hide her daughter by sending her away, and Xinging’s determination to free her mother so she can see her again. The romance between Xinging and Liwei was on point with the character development and flowed naturally with the story. The prose is amazingly crafted, creating worlds that are both gorgeous and frightening. I wanted to step into the worlds and just marvel at the beauty Ms. Tan wrote. I can’t praise this book enough and I highly recommend it not just to fans of fantasy, but to all readers.

Excellent New Fantasy Trilogy: 4 1/2 Stars
The Age of Ash is masterful epic fantasy. With the incredible world building in the creation of Kithamar and the characters who live there, the two elements wove seamlessly together. Kithamar dictated everything the characters did. We were drawn to the intensity of the city, and both the main protagonists and antagonists of the book. The third person narrative allowed the reader to see the character’s motivations and how they developed. I think it was excellent choice to get the many perspectives rather than have the story told by Alys. We would not have gotten the feel for the city and its importance for all who live there. The character development was on par with the best of fantasy. Alys’ loss of her brother made her relatable to all of us, as we see the echoes of those we loved and how we reacted. Sammish is the friend we all want. One who knows us best and will also be totally honest with us. The magic is unique and dark, making the main antagonists, Adomaka and Ausai particularly brutal. I feel that diversity is important in any genre of books, and while it is albeit a little heartbreaking, there is LBGT representation. The Age of Ash was an amazing read from start to finish. I look forward to the next installment.

Gripping Grimdark Fantasy: 4 1/2 Stars
Jonathan MaBerry’s Kagen the Damned is an excellent grimdark fantasy that pulls no punches. It encompasses all the elements of the genre and weaves them into a thrilling, page turning story from the start. Kagen, Miri, Ryssa, and the Witch King are all expertly developed characters. As Kagen, Miri, and Ryssa deal with the horrors of the invasion, the Witch King revels in his atrocities. There is also an amazing cast of supporting characters that weave this story perfectly. It is dark, gritty, violent, and filled with despair. However, through it all, there is the hope that Kagen clings too, to overthrow the Witch King. The development of the characters through the story elicits many different responses. If they were not constructed so well, I wouldn’t care about them, but I did. This is great writing when I can feel what the characters feel and want to know how their stories will unfold. There is also LBGTQ representation, which I feel is important to add diversity to the genre. While some parts can be brutal and at times hard to read, it flows with the narrative. The invading army, though they attack out of revenge for their oppression, we see gruesome acts they commit is no justification. Overall, Kagen the Damned is an excellent book and I highly recommend it for any fan of grimdark fantasy.

Beautiful Conclusion to The Wilderwood Series: For the Throne, Hannah Whitten’s sequel to For the Wolf is a just as beautiful and unique. As with the first, I loved everything about this book. Neve’s growth as a character, becoming more confident, stubborn, and hesitant in who she trusts, was a highlight of the book. Red remains steadfast and strong, never wavering in rescuing her sister. The two books are mirror images of each other, one light and one dark. Red is light to Neve’s dark, and neither can be whole without the other. The paths they have chosen, as they navigate the worlds they are in, are very similar. Red, needing to trust Eammon, and Neve needing to trust Solmir’s. However, Solmir is morally gray, so it is more difficult for Neve, as he deceived her into taking magic in from the Shadoworld. As Red becomes the Wilderwood with Eammon, Neve becomes the Shadow Queen. Each are setting out on a journey to find the Heart Tree to free Neve. It is different for Neve as she wants to leave the world she is trapped in, but Red chose to stay. In trying to rescue her sister, Neve set in motion events that wreaked havoc on the Wilderwood and the Shadoworld. The worlds were vastly different, but again, the light and the dark are what runs through the books. The beauty and color of the Wilderwood contrasts with bleak, colorless Shadoworld.  The pacing and prose are again excellent. It is told from multiple POVs, most often Neve and Red, and chapters also dedicated to Raffe. This telling is different from the first book. We need the different perspectives as freeing Neve is a puzzle, they must all solve. Raffe, in love with Neve, must confront, as does Neve, their true feelings for each other. The love of Red and Neve once again makes For the Throne a story of unconditional love, loss, and what one will sacrifice to save someone they love. It is of course all threaded into an amazing page turning adult fantasy story. For the Throne is a brilliant epic conclusion to a brilliant fantasy duology. I highly recommend this series for all readers, not just lovers of fantasy.

Excellent 2nd Entry in The Covenant of Steel: 4 1/2 Stars
The Martyr, the second book in the Covenant of Steel series, is as excellent at the first book. The characters have further developed and new characters have been introduced. It continues the tale of Alwyn’s life as only he can tell it to the reader. As we see his character develop more, he is honest about who he is and the things he has done. While he is a morally gray character, I like Alwyn because he makes no excuses for himself. As we see more of Evadine and she embraces status as the Risen Martyr, her actions can be questionable. The characters are very well developed, even the newly introduced ones also have their own complexity and story arc. While there are many battles, gore, and torture in this book, it is an essential part of the story. This is the world that Alwyn lives in and he cannot describe it any other way. Characters rely on ingenuity and strategy to beat overwhelming odds. When the story is told in the first-person narrative, it makes sense to see everything and hard choices that Alwyn must make in this book. His actions are often not the right course of action, and he knows it, but he is tied to Evadine and he protects her at all costs. What the consequences will be, we do not know yet. Alwyn’s narrative often speaks directly to the reader, which I found very interesting and it makes truly us feel Alwyn’s experiences and how he sees others. The Martyr is excellent and is certainly setting up a thrilling continuation of Alwyn Scribe’s life. I highly recommend this series, and eagerly await the next book.

Wonderful Fairy Tale Fantasy: Half a Soul by Olivia Atwater is a captivating and enchanting fairy tale fantasy. I absolutely loved this book. The characters were so well-fleshed out, that they leaped off the page. Dora and Elias were superb. Their banter and wit were funny and charming, and I found myself laughing at how Dora would best him with her comebacks. Their chemistry was palpable and how they played off each other was so enjoyable. The other characters, Vanessa, Albert, Auntie Frances, and the others in Regency London complemented Dora and Elias so well. Ms. Atwater wrote such an exceptional character in Dora. She showed that even with half a soul, the part taken where she could not really feel anything, Dora had more empathy and compassion than many of those around her. She was able to see pain and suffering, and put the needs of others before her own; her own need to find the other half of her soul to be whole again. I think that perhaps Ms. Atwater was showing us is that you don’t need a whole soul to know love, compassion, and understanding. This is truly an amazing book and I highly recommend it to all readers, not just lovers of fantasy. I think you will find it as enthralling as I did.

Loved this Unique Magic: My first book of Brian McClellan’s, In the Shadow of Lightening, was a thoroughly enjoyable and engrossing fantasy. With the use of different types of forged glass, he created a unique and imaginative magic system. Different types of glass, typically in the form of an earring, is used by the wearer to enhance certain abilities, or for healing and reduce pain. The character development was excellent, each character having their own complete story arc. There was an array of character traits, ranging from good, to outright bad, and to morally gray. The third person narrative from the perspective of the main protagonists allowed us to keep track of the various storylines in the book. In the Shadow of Lightening was a rollercoaster ride from the start, and drew me in from the first page. It never let up with a story of murder, political intrigue, war, and a mysterious threat to the empire. The storylines all came together seamlessly in a cliffhanger of an ending. I highly recommend In the Shadow of Lightening and look forward to the next book in the series.

Comprehensive manual for this vehicle: I bought this for a young man who is an automotive repair trainee in Uganda.  He needed a book that covered repairs to this very common vehicle in a relatively wide range of years.  This one met the requirements.

A great book covering the basics of various welding technologies: I bought this for a young man in a vocational-technical trainee program in Uganda.  He needed a book that provided information on various welding techniques and technologies.  This one met the requirements.
Bought as a Christmas present: skimming the contents made me hungry
So soon?: Got the book way before I expected it and it is in excellent shape.

Could not read it: I bought this book at a library sale with some other books. I loved the cover of the book and had never read anything by this author before so I thought I would give it a try. Got 3 1/2 chapters in and was like nope just can't and jumped right to the end and I never do that. The Delta Ladies was full of unhappy some were stuck up angry people who had secrets and resentment for other people. I thought this book would light hearted and a fun read but it's not. I don't think I will be reading anything else by this author.
Loved it: this was a fun read. I loved the banter between Nora and Charlie. But didn't care for Nora's sister calling her sissy all the time.
A fabulous novel: This novel opens all sorts of questions, leading to an interesting discussion. How many characters are really talking? I think schizophrenia plays a major part.

Clever Girl is not bad: A Most Clever Girl is adequately written but a bit too long. The surprise at the end was somewhat predictable. However it does reveal some good tips on how to be a spy, useful for any of us non-spies.
Great first of a series!: Really fun cozy mystery

Great start to a new era!: The beginning is suspenseful, the first half of the middle is boring but it picks up after that and never stops! The new bad guys are horrible by the end of the book. The new tech is super cool. The ending is more like the empire strikes back than a new hope. I predict this era will be full of jedi in the throes of a war with the final book being a triumph.
One last note is this: this is more like a first chapter than a standalone book. They build up the world, the characters, good and bad, and the story is not over. You need to finish the book to get the full experience.

Drawing Geometry Primer!: A great book providing "practical instruction in drawing two-dimensional geometry by hand". Includes detailed  illustrations (b&w / colored) and instructions to ensure your successful drawing of geometric shapes -- from two-sided and up to thirteen-sided. Artists, Designers and Architects as well as complete novices will benefit from the information presented. The author's goal (in Acknowledgements) was met ...I am inspired!

Novices and skilled artisans will benefit!: Another great offering by Lora Irish, this book would be great for both newbies and skilled artisans of "Wire-Wrapped Jewelry Techniques". Those skilled in teaching others (workshops, etc.), will find this a great resource.

Beautiful, close-up color photos appear on nearly all pages! Wires, Tools and Beads are described and depicted in "Materials" (Chapter 1). Thirty specific techniques (Chapter 3) are described with photos, as depicted in "Contents" and "Technique Quick Reference" chapters. "Projects" presented in Chapter 4 provide step-by-step instructions including "Supplies" for pendants, necklaces, earrings and hairpins.

Those skilled in teaching others (workshops, etc.), will find this a great resource.

Clearly written techniques are described and depicted throughout. Enjoy!

Design and create it today - wear it tonight!: Another great offering and wonderful resource by Lora Irish! Along with beautiful close-up color photos on nearly every page, great foundational techniques are provided. Many inspirational designs are presented, and will likely spawn your own personal creations. Novice and skilled artisan jewelry makers alike will benefit from information presented here.

From "Materials and Tools" (chapter 1) through the "Projects" presented in chapters 4 & 5, clearly written descriptions and instructions will have you wearing your new creations -- tonight!

As with many of her books, Lora covers materials and tools, wireworking basics upfront. In this way, each book "stands alone" -- a reader (even a novice jewelry-maker) can pick up the book, gather the required equipment, supplies and materials and create the chosen project (in this case - earrings) in short order.

Those skilled in teaching others (workshops, etc.), will find this a great resource.

Having particularly enjoyed the earring "Projects" depicted in Chapters 4 and 5, I plan to do just that! Enjoy!

Wire Pendants -- Create Stunning Wearable Art!: The authors' statement in "How to Use This Book" says it all: ""Build Your Own Wire Pendants" is an easy-to-follow guide that introduces you to the joy of making unique pendants to enhance your jewelry designs".
Nearly every page has close-up colored photos and, along with well written, easy to understand descriptions and instructions, you will quickly be on your way to making your own wearable art!

Starting with "Safety Basics", everything you need to know about wire choices (shapes, type, measurement conversions, temper and gauge) and various optional tool items, Kimberly provides good information about the tools, equipment supplies and materials associated with creating wire pendants.

Over twenty inspirational projects are presented with clear pictures, great descriptions of associated materials and supplies and instructions. I particularly enjoyed the use of "mixed media" depicted in many of the designs. Your own personal creations will likely be spawned by the projects presented.

Those skilled in teaching others (workshops, etc.), will find this a great resource.

Skilled artisans and aspiring jewelry maker novices alike will no doubt be inspired by the wire pendants presented here. Enjoy!

You Too can create exquisite wire wrapped wearable art!: Author Sarah won Bead Dreams 2014 Competition in two categories -- Best in Show and Best in Wirework!! In 2015 she published this incredible work and shares with us her award winning love of wire working!

Colored photos appear on nearly every page. Extensive information is provided in the preliminary chapters (Introduction, Materials, Tools, Techniques & findings). The "Techniques" chapter covers various aspects of wireworking including wireworking tips, basic weaves, design elements and finishing touches.

Seventeen fully described inspirational Projects are presented by level: Beginner (five), Intermediate (eight) and Advanced (four). Each project, replete with colored photos, provides associated techniques (previously presented) along with associated materials and tools. Resources and an Index are provided. Your own creative projects will undoubtedly be spawned by having read this book.

Novice and skilled wireworkers alike (as evidenced by other reviews) will benefit from the information provided by this highly ranked book on wireworking. Those skilled in teaching others (workshops, etc.), will find this a great resource. Enjoy!

Fantastic 300+ pages of inspirational designs and detailed instructions: Novice wireworkers and skilled artisans agree (as evidenced by reviewers): Rachel Norris has authored a well written, inspirational, detailed, easily understood project-oriented book of wirework designs. Project instructions are thorough, clear and concise. Hundreds of close-up color photos / illustrations support the written instructions. Mastered techniques can be used with projects inspired by those presented here. Fantastic!

Those skilled in teaching others (workshops, etc.), will find this a great resource. Enjoy!

Great Primer providing enthusiasts, students and teachers with valuable information: "Chosen as a top three finalist in Soul & Spirit Magazine's Spiritural Book Awards 2018 for Best Crystals Book" and (as of this writing) ranked #97 in Divination with Crystals within "Best Sellers Rank", this well written book provides a wealth of great information for newly "drawn", long-time enthusiasts and teachers alike. Chapters provide information about Sacred Geometry, grid "components", crystal care and activation, your intentions / affirmations… AND about grid configuration, maintenance & care.

If you are "drawn" to get involved with crystal grids… you are in the right place!
Those skilled in teaching others (workshops, etc.), will find this a great resource. Enjoy!
Too cool: Kids like it.  Mostly impresses your in the know adult friends.

The burden of abundance: This beautifully illustrated book recounts the story of a couple that have become our answer in this century to Walden pond. It is sensitively written, frequently quoting journals from Art and Nan. Since I read her motivation to move to Placentia ( to escape the burden of abundance) I have been facing my own.  In this time of extreme ecological crisis it is good to find a story of two people who directly met life with simplicity and commitment.

Very well written history of a time that shaped our sense of democracy: Dan Jones has written a highly interesting book that takes one to the roots of power-sharing and justice. His history is filled with personal insights from the times, and a full picture of each person he writes of emerges. So much of our modern world began in this time. It is easy to read and very enjoyable.

Meh: For me, this book is like an assignment for descriptive writing. You can see and feel the scenes, but there is no real story telling. I find it to be emotionally flat. Yes these are terrible things that happen but you aren’t drawn to the characters enough to really care about them. It is one bad thing after another. A very dismal, dark, and mean life, with a few instances of kindness.

This could have been a great story if fleshed out. I kept waiting for the story to begin. I don’t care for this type of writing, but I guess there are those that do.
Loved This Book!!: This is a great rom com with a little bit of modern Taming of the Shrew and I loved it! I can’t wait to read more from this author!
AMAZING STORY!!: This is the fourth book in the series and I have LOVED every single one of them!! 💚

Eh: I gave the book three stars because I go back to 2002 with O&A and decided to be generous.  This book could have and should have been so much more.  O&A talked for years and years about putting a book out someday, and over a decade later we got this short little memoir that is mostly just stories Anthony has already told on the air.  We could have gotten a lot more depth on what happened off the air, the behind the scenes battles with management, the feuds with Howard Stern and other radio rivals, and on and on.  Decent if you are a die hard fan like I am, otherwise don't bother.

Well-Written Book: This book is an absolute must for those raising children with autism. The biblical perspective is a great way to view the topics discussed, and Ron is very knowledgeable of this subject. I definitely plan to read other books written by Ron!
Hubby bought this with an Amazon gift card. Gets one each year.: Looks up facts on these all the time.
Another comical mystery by this author.: Another in the series by Donna Andrews about Meg and Michael. Interesting and ironic. Have read most of the older ones so far. Always with a murder to solve.

interesting plot can’t wait for the movie!: Interesting to the end! Molly’s example of kindness to all should is a good one for all to follow. Kindness to those with disabilities is often overlooked by so many. Some intriguing plot twists will keep the reader wanting to read more!
The 29th Day book: This book is amazing and will keep your attention from the moment you open it! A must read. A true adventure story and very well written.
Daily Coyote- Amazing!: I loved this book and so did everyone else I loaned it to. And wait till you see the wonderful photos of this delightful coyote.

Enemies or Lovers: Maddie and Gryff have always been "enemies" from something that occured between their families long ago by one of their distant relatives. But when Maddie and Gryff come across illegal contraband by accident they work together to discover who the leader is. But they will need to determine if all the teasing and tricks they played on each other as children was that as enemies or if it was the beginning of deeper feelings they have been harboring for each other as children.

This was a wonderful read. I received this book from Netgalley for an honest review.
Too Gruesome: I was so prepared to like this book knowing Galbraith was pseudonym for JK Rowling, and I’d enjoyed all of the Harry Potter books. Not so in this case!

Worth waiting for: Why I should try to underestimate anything Paul/Beatles-related, I’ve no idea. STELLAR book. Many, many beautiful new (to me) photos. And what a wonderful, and truly sensible way to present Paul’s life, song by song. It IS an autobiography, not just a guided tour.

Good, except for one peculiarity: For the most part, I enjoyed the book; the clothes are beautiful, and Kate looked exquisite in them. I did find introducing Meghan into the narrative for the sole purpose of making Kate appear to be the better person of the two, jarring and odd.

Straight-forward true crime book: First off, the author has writing talent. There were a couple of chapters that were quality writing. With that said, the author does embellish quite a lot in her writing. It's obvious she "makes up" dialog, and "window dresses" scenes. I found it to be disingenuous and detracts from the story. Sometimes, it's so obvious, it's almost laughable.
There were a few unexpected twists in the story which added interest. But other than that, the book is an average straight forward telling of a horrible crime.

Perfectly Crafted Thriller: In my personal opinion, Alice Feeney is the queen of unreliable narrators. 𝘏𝘪𝘴 & 𝘏𝘦𝘳𝘴 was one of my favorite thrillers of 2020 and Feeney did not disappoint with 𝘙𝘰𝘤𝘬 𝘗𝘢𝘱𝘦𝘳 𝘚𝘤𝘪𝘴𝘴𝘰𝘳𝘴.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Told in the alternating perspectives of a husband and wife who are snowed in during a weekend away to a converted chapel, this book kept me guessing and had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. I could not put it down. Definitely one of my favorite thrillers of the year! ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
And just like Feeney did with 𝘏𝘪𝘴 & 𝘏𝘦𝘳𝘴, there's a third perspective that really keeps things...interesting.⁣⁣

Quintessential Holiday Family Vibes: When Summer Dowell writes a Christmas novella, your #respecttheturkey rules go right out the window and you read a Christmas story in October.

I absolutely adored Elle & Oliver! Such great chemistry! I could easily have read an entire novel about them. But even at just 126 pages, I felt like I had read a complete story.

I think my favorite part of this story was the ensemble cast of the Carter family. They were that quintessential holiday movie family. Think a little The Family Stone with the Callaghans from While You Were Sleeping. They had me audibly laughing and wishing that I lived next door.

If you're looking for an adorable holiday romance, The Elle Project is it!

I received a gifted copy of this book. This is my honest review.

Not the best. Not the worst.: Grabbed my attention at first as the story took off pretty quickly. Short chapters and alternating perspectives made for a quick read. However, this one just started losing steam for me along the way. Events towards the end felt a bit unrealistic. The conclusion also made the entire journey feel irrelevant.

Not the best. Not the worst. It just doesn't stand out to me from other things I've read this year. It's not going to be one that stays with me a month from now.

I received a free copy of this book in exchange for my honest opinion.

Back and Better Than Ever!: {Thank you to Minotaur Books and Netgalley for the opportunity to read an early copy!}⁣
---------------⁣
⁣
Finlay is back and she's on a deadline! Her publicist wants her next book finished while it seems that someone also wants her ex-husband finished. With her trusty nanny/bestie by her side, Finlay is determined to find out who wants Steven dead and who might be the one to do it. ⁣
⁣
I cannot get enough of Finlay & Vero! They might be one of my very favorite literary duos. Move over Frodo & Sam. These women take "ride or die" to a whole new level. ⁣
⁣
I would dare to say that I loved this sequel even more than the first. Cosimano brought back all of the humor and intrigue that made me fall for book 1 but upped the stakes. She possibly even made me switch sides when it came to Finlay's love life. Maybe. Undecided.⁣
⁣
This one ended with me laughing and jaw dropping at twists. Thrilled there will be a third book. This series is just too fun! ⁣
⁣
If you're already on this friends/hit-woman/mafia ride, you won't be disappointed. If not, get on this train!

Eye opening: This was a very well-written book about the horrors of what radium can do, the lives of the women who worked with the element, and the horrible struggles they went through, not only as their bodies failed but also just to get the world to listen to them.
Good plot with a lot of twists: I really liked the suspense and there were a number of twists I wasn't expecting. However, don't look for a good guy vs. bad guy theme. There are no good guys.

Fast paced and grim: A fast-paced horror novel that I couldn't put down. There were some characters that I wanted to smack throughout the book and some scenarios that made me cringe with how they reacted, but otherwise very well written
outdated and odd: I've read many soapmaking books but this one is just not that useful. I would not buy this again.
Just ok.: I wouldn't buy it again, it's just ok.
Gorgeous book: I love this book. One of the few soapmaking books I don't regret buying.
Great story: Replaced the book in my library.  Read it to kids in a church pre-school

history: B00NJQIZ0Y B00NEO38UI B01EFLYHF8 B01M22B8EN B07RWSL54Y B085ZN9MJL B07WG8L7WC B004NEW57A B07SC6GJQP B08KSNFGB5 B07S4BCQMJ B003V8B5W0 B07T74W5Y9 B0755VMX4G B087JTTB78 B072BLVM83 B00B60D9WY B004NNUWVW
review: Good Read: Another five star read from O’Brien. His books are my go-to’s when I need a good book. Fast paced, relatable characters and smart writing. O’Brien doesn’t give every single stinking detail, but allows his readers space for their own thoughts, while knowing we’re smart enough to fill in the “between the lines” details. Good writer, one of my favorites.

history: B00NJQIZ0Y B00NEO38UI B01EFLYHF8 B01M22B8EN B07RWSL54Y B085ZN9MJL B07WG8L7WC B004NEW57A B07SC6GJQP B08KSNFGB5 B07S4BCQMJ B003V8B5W0 B07T74W5Y9 B0755VMX4G B087JTTB78 B072BLVM83 B00B60D9WY B004NNUWVW B08MBFW5LL
review: Just Okay for Me: I was suckered by reviews. This book was just “okay” for me. It just seemed…messy. The characters, the storyline. I read a lot of thrillers and mysteries and this one missed the mark for me. Cliches…the cheating husbands, the nannies, the ex boyfriend who is still strangely in the picture. It wasn’t suspenseful at all. Way too much info and repeating of same info. Parts were just confusing. Something about the way the author tried to tie it all together, just didn’t work - no, it took too long to work. It was about 100/150 pages too long.

history: B00NJQIZ0Y B00NEO38UI B01EFLYHF8 B01M22B8EN B07RWSL54Y B085ZN9MJL B07WG8L7WC B004NEW57A B07SC6GJQP B08KSNFGB5 B07S4BCQMJ B003V8B5W0 B07T74W5Y9 B0755VMX4G B087JTTB78 B072BLVM83 B00B60D9WY B004NNUWVW B08MBFW5LL B082Q4Q1MZ
review: I liked it: Fast paced and well written. But the cop is kind of dumb and makes decisions and mistakes no professional cop would make. Good characters and a good story,  but an unbelievable cop. He put them in more danger than he kept them from, lol. My first Stuart Woods book, will read more. This book was written in the 90s and we know so much more about investigating, law enforcement and how it all works these days.

history: B00NJQIZ0Y B00NEO38UI B01EFLYHF8 B01M22B8EN B07RWSL54Y B085ZN9MJL B07WG8L7WC B004NEW57A B07SC6GJQP B08KSNFGB5 B07S4BCQMJ B003V8B5W0 B07T74W5Y9 B0755VMX4G B087JTTB78 B072BLVM83 B00B60D9WY B004NNUWVW B08MBFW5LL B082Q4Q1MZ B0013FOUIE
review: Okay: This was a good story, and while the swearing doesn’t bother me, it seemed overused and unnecessary in places. I did not like Laurie at all. And the story let her get away with things that I found a bit unbelievable. Only three stars bc this story went on and on and took forever to get to the meat of it all. It was kind of all over the place for me, too many details in places where it was tmi overkill.

history: B00NJQIZ0Y B00NEO38UI B01EFLYHF8 B01M22B8EN B07RWSL54Y B085ZN9MJL B07WG8L7WC B004NEW57A B07SC6GJQP B08KSNFGB5 B07S4BCQMJ B003V8B5W0 B07T74W5Y9 B0755VMX4G B087JTTB78 B072BLVM83 B00B60D9WY B004NNUWVW B08MBFW5LL B082Q4Q1MZ B0013FOUIE B07KVLCVP4
review: another great one: Kevin O’Brien never disappoints. He weaves stories just intricate enough to keep you flying through the text. Relatable characters, good plot twists and good editing. He trusts the reader and doesn’t bombard with TMI. Read one O’Brien book, you’ll be hooked!

history: B00NJQIZ0Y B00NEO38UI B01EFLYHF8 B01M22B8EN B07RWSL54Y B085ZN9MJL B07WG8L7WC B004NEW57A B07SC6GJQP B08KSNFGB5 B07S4BCQMJ B003V8B5W0 B07T74W5Y9 B0755VMX4G B087JTTB78 B072BLVM83 B00B60D9WY B004NNUWVW B08MBFW5LL B082Q4Q1MZ B0013FOUIE B07KVLCVP4 B00G9ABXTM
review: Great Read: This book was fast paced with good, relatable characters. This author trusts the reader and doesn’t over-explain things. The story was weaved together in such a way that it kept me guessing. Looking forward to more from Finlay.

history: B00NJQIZ0Y B00NEO38UI B01EFLYHF8 B01M22B8EN B07RWSL54Y B085ZN9MJL B07WG8L7WC B004NEW57A B07SC6GJQP B08KSNFGB5 B07S4BCQMJ B003V8B5W0 B07T74W5Y9 B0755VMX4G B087JTTB78 B072BLVM83 B00B60D9WY B004NNUWVW B08MBFW5LL B082Q4Q1MZ B0013FOUIE B07KVLCVP4 B00G9ABXTM B08BYC481D
review: Good read, fast paced: This book didn’t drag at all. Characters were interesting and relatable. Murders in the shadow of what happened on 9/11. I didn’t know this was a series when I started and was a little disappointed when I got to the end and there were still loose strings. Other than that, good writing, interesting story.

history: B00NJQIZ0Y B00NEO38UI B01EFLYHF8 B01M22B8EN B07RWSL54Y B085ZN9MJL B07WG8L7WC B004NEW57A B07SC6GJQP B08KSNFGB5 B07S4BCQMJ B003V8B5W0 B07T74W5Y9 B0755VMX4G B087JTTB78 B072BLVM83 B00B60D9WY B004NNUWVW B08MBFW5LL B082Q4Q1MZ B0013FOUIE B07KVLCVP4 B00G9ABXTM B08BYC481D B007UPDEJW
review: great: Looking forward to book three in this series! Good clean writing, fast paced, author trusts the reader and doesn’t give TMI. Good read.

Recommend for any animal lover or techie: Space, police 7, AIs recognized as sapient, enhanced memories helping solve murders and alien species, and romance.  Pretty much hits a bunch of categories.  Very enjoyable.

The mystery deepens and love prevails: Book 2 of the trilogy brings on more info about both the good guys and the bad guys. Lots of regen in store!

Looking forward to the 3rd book and maybe more aliens. In some ways, XK9s are more like dogs than one realizes.
WW II Buffs-Don't miss reading this.: Fantastic !! There is nothing else to say.
Great book!: Great book!

Meh.: I really love Heller's books. I thought this one, with an older female protagonist, would be great. But it was just....meh. She murder mystery itself was far-fetched  (I don't want to give anything away). The character development seemed forced and Celine fell back on cliches of female intuition. She was just...too perfect at everything. I had hoped for more time spent in Yellowstone, Tetons etc as that is where Heller really excels.
So Easy: Delicious recipes are perfect for a 3 qt Instant Pot.  I don't have to calculate when I make a meal.  Her rice for one person is foolproof.

Disillusioned!: I thought the storyline was entertaining, but, very predictable and the characters were just ok. However, the fact that there were two stories instead of one and not having been given a "heads up" by the authors or publisher was pretty underhanded and deceitful. Very disappointed in Patterson!

It's Thomas So we'll! Just buy this book: If you are looking for "The book" to buy in order to understand economics, this is it. If you are looking for the smartest guy to break it down for you, Thomas Sowell is the one.
excellent: Very quick read and worth every minute!

Historical fiction about the Battle of Vienna in 1863: This book has become my favorite by A.L. Sowards. I loved how she interweaves history with fiction.

Before the Fortresses Falls had me on the edge of my seat from the get go. I knew next to nothing about the Battle of Vienna, but by the end of the book I was doing my own deep dive into. That’s how much this book peaked my interest about it.

The characters in this book were great! I enjoyed seeing their character development as we read about the events of the battle from their perspectives. Although, I will there were times where I could careless about some of the point of views. But that’s just how I get when I read a book with multiple point of views.

This book will take you on an emotional roller coaster but it is definitely worth it.

Fake dating: "You don't know what Marvel is? Do you live under a rock?"
"Oh, wait, that's the superhero stuff, right?"
He closed his eyes slowly. "I am so ashamed to be friends with you right now."

I’m with Jackson on this, everyone by now should at least know about Marvel. 😂 I think it would be hard to fake date someone if they don’t know about Marvel.
