This book addresses religious prejudice well, making Margaret and Wes outsiders because of their family's religion. They are bullied and tormented but they bear it and overcome it with empathy and grace.

The pace is glacial at first, and while it never gets anything like fast, it does gradually increase. I recommend giving it longer than normal to hook you because once it draws you in it really is a magical read.

I received a review copy of this book.

excellent guide to helping with kids' worries: This is an excellent guide to helping your kid work through some worries. My kid worries - a LOT - and I will definitely be reading this with them. I can definitely see how some of the exercises could really help them.

The information is presented in a clear, easy-to-understand, and visually appealing way. It is easy to work through the entire book or just the section that is relevant to the child's current worry. There are incisive questions to ask the child and exercises (meditation, etc) to help deal with each specific type of worry.

I received a review copy of this book.

an amusing and engaging romp: This was my first book by Eloisa James and it shan't be my last. It was an amusing and engaging romp and I enjoyed it a lot. The characters were relatable and sympathetic, the side characters quite amusing, and the premise just absurd enough to inject quite a lot of humor and shake up the typical regency romance plot.

I greatly enjoyed hearing about Cleo's mother and seeing her work through her grief and mixed feelings. I also enjoyed the wardrobes Cleo and Jake created for one another -- and especially Byng's joyful and colorful takeover of the designs. Cleo and Jake's closeness and respect for one another was also quite wonderful.

The plot at times felt a bit thin, and the ending a bit contrived. Also, Cleo got over her shame and humiliation just a little too fast to be believable. It felt a bit like the story had to hurry up and conclude within a certain page count.

Overall though, a highly enjoyable read and I recommend it. I also look forward to the sequel(s).

I received a review copy of this book.

gorgeously written with magic and music and mystery: This book was EVERYTHING. Gorgeous slow-burn enemies-to-friends-to-lovers f/f romance? check. Magic? check. Music? check. Beautiful, lyrical writing? check.

This book reminded me of An Enchantment of Ravens (which is probably why it's listed as a comp title on goodreads). They both have magic swirling through the story but also a deep and abiding love of art (painting in Enchantment of Ravens and music in this case) that underpins and transforms everything. Also similar is the journey and slow blossoming of love, and the writing of each is utterly gorgeous.

The story has music and magic and mystery in spades and combined with the gorgeous writing, it's catapulted instantly onto my favorites list. It's SO atmospheric and you can really feel the music and the magic as the journey and mystery unspools before Sofi and Lara. I FELT things. So many things.

The way Sofi slowly came to realize that her father's methods of teaching her were actually abuse--and that she took that abuse further upon herself--was painful but also cathartic. Her discovery that she wasn't as alone as she thought was beautiful.

I would definitely recommend this to fans of Margaret Rogerson and Maggie Steifvater.

This is definitely one of my favorite books I've read this year and after reading the arc I will immediately be purchasing my own copy because I can't not own this and I will absolutely be rereading it.

I received a review copy of this book.

layers upon layers of secrets and stories: This was a wild ride of stories and secrets, shocking reveals, betrayals, and allegiances that shift like the sand. And so, so much magic. I absolutely loved it.

The four characters on their quest (Louli, Mazen, Aisha, and Qadir) were all very different, and all hiding secrets, and it was so satisfying to watch them become closer and slowly reveal them. Some of them, anyway. They were all like onions, slowly peeling back the layers, offering up stories that were A truth but not always The truth. Piecing it all gradually together was very satisfying, like completing a challenging jigsaw puzzle.

I loved the djinn relics and how they tied everyone together in unexpected ways. I loved the secrets behind them, and the magic. I loved how they kept showing up where they weren't expected and revealing new tidbits of information each time.

The story was so vast and grand and full of tales within tales and stories that aren't only stories and truths that aren't the whole truth that I still can't quite wrap my head around it, and I know I will be rereading it before diving into the sequel when it comes out. And I absolutely will be reading it as soon as I can get my hands on it because that ending left me with so many questions and not nearly enough answers.

I received a review copy of this book.

wonderful adventure: Mulan is my favorite Disney princess, so I was a little apprehensive about this retelling, but I ended up really enjoying it. Blackburne captures Mulan's character and spirit perfectly and brings in old friends and new (as well as new enemies) as a supporting cast.

Mulan's troubles felt very real and believable, and I was transported to ancient China throughout. I felt for Mulan and grieved for her friends who fell and rejoiced with her triumphs.

There were a few places I felt like the writing could have used some improvement, and where things got a little shaky, and it did strike me as a tad Disneyfied and perhaps a bit more PG than it could have been, but overall it was a wonderful adventure.

I received a review copy of this book.

beautiful colors and useful techniques: This book showcased a variety of techniques for working with inks, but especially highlighted ways to simplify a piece while still retaining the essence of the subject. This is a very useful skill, especially when working small and with delicate media. It also stressed the importance of color palettes and ways to combine color most effectively in an ink piece.

I wasn't terribly interested in recreating most of the projects, but they did inspire me to think of other uses for each technique - many of which I had previously been unfamiliar with - so I definitely feel like it was a useful book for me.

I received a review copy of this book.

I loved it: I enjoyed reading this book. I found myself turning the pages faster than I could read. This was a fun read full of adventure. I hope the author writes more books about Beatrix and Thomas.

A fascinating story: I truly enjoyed this book. The amount of research that went into it is truly amazing. I learned so much about both Anna and Fyodor and can highly recommend this to anyone who loves history.
A remarkable novel: I loved this book. The author brought these remarkable women to life and by the end I felt like I really knew them. What an enjoyable reading experience!

So much fun!: This book is the perfect escape, it does what good books do best, it makes you forget everything around you. I truly enjoyed every minute of my reading experience and I'm looking forward to a sequel.

A fantastic read.: I truly enjoyed 'Dear Inmate' which is book 2 in the Paddy Series. I adore Rosaleen, who is an Irish Immigrant fighting for better treatment of her fellow immigrants. I couldn't turn the pages fast enough and I'm looking forward to book number 3 in this series.
An important book.: The author paints a very candid picture of sex addiction which is often joked about and not taken seriosly. I can highly recommend this book.

well written and great lesson in American history (the history they hide): I read the first of the three book series quite awhile ago, A THOUSAND WHITE WOMEN.  It was a wonderful story and I wanted more at the time.  I was delighted to find out about the second and third book.  All three are based on true journals of women who were "traded" for horses with the Cheyenne Indians.  The second book, THE VENGENCE OF MOTHERS, was just as good and the first and STRONGHEART does a great job in tying the ends together.  I'd recommend the book to anybody interested in history and stories about strong women.

Meh: I love an Elle Kennedy New Adult novel, generally speaking. I love a good girl/bad boy trope. This was a funny, sexy read, with well written characters. However, it just fell a little flat for me. I felt like I'd read this before, which is fine, but that's it. Fine. I would still recommend this book for lighter romance readers.

I mean it's Preston and Child: If there are two things I love, it's a new book by Preston and Child and alien conspiracies. I've really been enjoying the Nora Kelly series, and this one did not disappoint. Nora was still  annoying but somehow that works for her. I liked that Skip was in this one more. It's fast-paced, action packed, and (as always) very well researched.

Good hijinks but missed the mark for me...: I was pretty excited for this one, and though pranks are not really my thing, I can enjoy some good hijinks. I'm also a sucker for a fake dating trope. Overall...this book was fine. There was just SO MUCH going on, I found I couldn't really focus on anything.
beautiful and informative: The illustrations in this book are beautiful. The flowing text is informative and fun. Highly recommend!
wonderful message: Aww, such a sweet little book! Fun illustrations and a wonderful message about the beauty of loving who you are.

Fun and informative: This book contains A LOT of information about the changes that occur in plants, animals, and nature during Spring, but it is also fun! The illustrations are beautifully colored and bright. A perfect book for talking about Spring!

stunning setting: This was my first read by this author. It was good. The characters were memorable, the setting stunning. A nice slower read; I was invested in the story and characters but felt like I could just take my time and savor the moments described so beautifully.

Thank you to Revell and NetGalley for a complimentary copy of this book. The opinions expressed in this review are my own.

engaging, beautiful story: 4.5 stars! Under the Golden Sun will transport you from dreary WWII London across the sea to lush and stunning Australia. This book slowly drew me in and before I was aware of what was happening, I was completely hooked. The characters were lovely (except for one that I didn’t care for) and I couldn’t wait to pick up the book, again and again, to see how their stories ended up. This was my first read by Jenny Ashcroft and I will be checking out her backlist. Highly recommend! (I would have rated this a 5 but had a bit of a hard time keeping track of the tertiary characters at first. I don’t feel it detracted too much from the story, though.)

Thank you to St. Martin’s Press and NetGalley for a complimentary copy of this book. The opinions expressed in this review are my own.

fun, magical adventure: River of Lights by Melanie Dobson is a fun, magical adventure. I was completely hooked from the beginning. This would be a great read for elementary age kids. It’s not too long and there’s nothing questionable. The next story in the series sounds wonderful, also!

Thank you to the publisher and NetGalley for a complimentary copy of this book. The opinions expressed in this review are my own.

history: B00U6DNZOY B07YSNB24G B01BU1ITMI B085C74285 B085T2BJD6 B006VFLIYK
review: Good book but not great: It was not his best work.  I enjoyed reading it.  I have read several of his books but did not enjoy this one

Well written mystery: Jane and the Year Without Summer is the 14th book of the Being a Jane Austen Mystery series which mixes Jane Austen’s real-life events with fictional mysteries the author keeps facing and solving.
This story takes place in 1816 when our dear author travelled with her sister Cassandra to Cheltenham Spa in Gloucestershire in an effort to improve her decaying health. While lodged at Mrs. Potter’s boardinghouse, they meet several interesting characters whose lives will prompt Jane into another exciting mystery.
As in Stephanie Barron’s previous books I found the story engaging and hard to put down once the triggering events take place. This particular volume has mystery, humour and even some romance, which was my favorite part of the book.

What I particularly loved about it:
Real life events – In Jane and the Year Without a Summer, real events in Jane life, but also major events that took place in that time period find their way into the story in a smooth manner, and I love the fact that as we read this story we get a chance to learn more in an interesting and unknowingly manner. Stephanie Barron has the ability to bring facts into the story in a seemingly fashion and without causing any disruption to the story. The historical elements are perfectly articulated with the fiction history we’re following, and that brings added value to the narrative without affecting its pace.
Raphael West – I loved getting to know this character in Jane and the Twelve Days of Christmas and I was very happy to see him return in this book. His presence brought constancy and security to Jane’s character, and I love how balanced Mr. West is. In fact, I wish he had played a bigger part in the story and helped more in Jane’s investigations. This might have been the last time we saw him, but deep down, I hope he will find his way back to Jane in the next novel of the series.
Jane’s romance – We know much about Jane’s life but we don’t know everything that transpired while she lived, and I was very happy to see that she got a chance to have a beautiful romance in her life that spanned across several novels. In Jane and the Year Without a Summer her romance is simultaneously tender, beautiful, and sad because we know she won’t live much longer. I particularly liked seeing the P&P references in her own love story and the maturity with which the characters feelings were handled.

What I wasn’t so fond of:
Slow beginning – While the story was very engaging and unputdownable after the triggering events took place, I found the story too slow paced until that moment. It is true that I found the Garthwaite’s antics funny and even grew tender feelings for Thucydides, but I would have preferred to have had a faster pace in the beginning of the story and for the characters build to occur simultaneously with the mystery unravelling.
Summing up, Jane and The Year Without a Summer is a well written mystery that will bring readers closer to Jane Austen and wishing the series stops following real events and finishes with a fictional ending for our heroine. It is an engrossing story and I recommend it to all readers who love Jane Austen.

Amazing debut: Truly a page turner. I am so glad I listened to the reviews.
Also it has been my experience that debut novels with rave reviews are really good. More so even than with seasoned authors.

X marks the spot!: Absolutely astonishing that orphan X continues to provide such a great mix of fun and adventure, interesting insights and philosophies you want to adopt and live by. Did I mention he is a Hitman by training? Can't wait to enjoy what  X, Mia, Peter and Joey will do next time out, along with Dog the dog and Vera III.

Very good book: I wasn't sure but I decided to give this book a shot. Turns out, I couldn't put it down. Literally read it in 2 days and was unhappy when I had to postpone my reading for a few hours. Give it a shot. You will be hooked and surprised by this excellent book.

It's amazing what a name change can do: Diamonds and Deadlines by Betsy Prioleau is the perfect balance of multiple elements. The story of newspaper mogul Miriam Leslie (among a host of many other names), Prioleau writes a biography of a complicated woman who is part fraud and part trailblazer. This can easily become a dry list of personal accomplishments, hero worship, or gossip mongering. Instead, Prioleau tells a nuanced story which takes into account all aspects of Leslie's life whether the facts make her look amazing or awful.

The perfect example of Prioleau's adept handling of the subject matter is the description of Leslie's many fashion choices. Often, authors fall into the trap of showing off how extensive their research is by over-explaining the grandeur of any given wardrobe choice. Leslie's choice of dress is vital to her character, but Prioleau quickly highlights her very expensive choices without bogging down the narrative with pages of explanation. Her narrative is even and never slows down to focus on needless details. It takes this from a good biography to a great read.

(I was provided this book as an advance copy from Netgalley and Abrams books. The full review is available on HistoryNerdsUnited.com)

Dinosaurs!: Well, I didn't think a book could make me sad about dinosaurs but here we are.

Riley Black's The Last Days of the Dinosaurs is like nothing I have ever read before. It follows the time right before and then very long after the impact of the asteroid which killed the dinosaurs. Black focuses in on various animals and how they cope with the massive changes around the globe in a way which makes you actually feel like the dinosaurs are old friends of yours. I anticipated there would be times where the science would bore me, but Black sidestepped all of that by creating an actual narrative about animals which went extinct millions of years ago.

Black's love of dinosaurs truly comes through in this book and it is all the better for it. Jurassic Park references certainly help as well. "Life, uh, finds a way."

(This book was provided as an advance copy by Netgalley. The full review is posted to HistoryNerdsUnited.com)

Whoop'em by land, Whoop'em by sea: American privateers are the subject of this book. It’s a can’t miss prospect.

Eric Jay Dolin is once again doing what he does best. He takes a very big idea and distills it down for anyone to access the amazing aspects of the subject. You want to hear about funny boat names? He’s got you covered. You want to hear about how the British were sadistic scum in handling American prisoners? Oh, plenty of that.

I don’t want to undersell how hard it is. The American Revolution and the people in it leave so much to go over. Very often, these types of books meander about and tell you stories only the author finds interesting. Dolin tells you the stories you need to hear, want to hear, and gets to the next point.

Oh, Florida: Leave it to Florida to once again give us something to talk about. Unfortunately, this story is not funny in the least.

We Carry Their Bones by Erin Kimmerle is an important book with some riveting information. The book tells the story of the Dozier School in Florida where numerous children were sent to be tortured and killed some mostly minor offenses. Kimmerle and her team are ultimately called upon to investigate the unmarked graves at the school to bring closure to numerous families over the 100 years the school was open.

The good parts are very good. I liked hearing about Kimmerle’s own experience before this episode in her life which gives a lot of context around who she is. I absolutely loved the science and the process of excavating the school. It showed an extreme measure of care and illuminates the parts shows TV shows cut out. The stories of the boys and what happened to them are heartbreaking.

Unfortunately, there are a few missteps in the narrative which I feel really hamper the book’s flow. It certainly seems Kimmerle intended to settle some scores. Specifically, a blogger is mentioned multiple times as a hindrance in her work. While he certainly seems like a pain and devoid of empathy, he also seems mostly tangential. The book doesn’t explain how much of a problem he really ended up being. If he was so easily swept aside, then it would have been prudent to just ignore him entirely. There are also strange asides which seem out of nowhere. A crack about a relative makes about Catholics makes it into the book without a clear link. There is also a section in the end of the book with a rant on mansplaining. Kimmerle and her team did righteous work in the face of some strong opposition. These examples seem beneath her.

Ultimately, I enjoyed the book for the most part and am happy people like Kimmerle and her team exist to bring the closure these families needed.

Never has a book title spoken to me like this: Full disclosure up front: I love Tom Segura and know enough of his stuff that I read it in his voice and cadence. As with any comedian who writes something, I suggest listening to their comedy first and see if it’s for you.

If you don’t like Segura’s comedy, then this book will not change your mind. Admittedly, Segura makes it pretty clear he has no intention to. This is a collection of random essays which are mostly hilarious and sometimes heartfelt. A few are stories you have heard in any one of his specials. I loved it and will probably now rewatch a special or two.

Its truly amazing more men weren’t stabbed on planes.: women in my life, “It’s not that surprising to me. Men are terrible.” Fair enough!

When you hear something amazingly sexist, you tend to think it was in some archaic time far from where we are today. Sure, there are still many things we are trying to figure out between the sexes (understatement alert), but at least we aren’t expecting women to step on scales at work and then firing them if they are a pound over. We haven’t done something like that in like 100 years, right?

Nope! Welcome to the 1970s where stewardesses had such job perks as getting weighed at work in full view of coworkers, girdle checks by fellow employees, and when you turn 32 you are fired no matter what because you are old, and no one can possibly be a stewardess after 32. It’s just science.

Nell McShane Wulfhart uses this backdrop to tell the story of how multiple women came together to start making change happen in the airline industry. This book is a breeze to read even when talking about union politics which is no easy feat. Wulfhart mixes part biography, part workers rebellion and comes up with a great book. And before you start to think this is a book which bashes men, I would like to correct you. There is no male bashing in this book at all. Which makes sense since the men in this book make themselves look pretty bad without any help.

A Gripping WWII Story: The Winter Rose is a powerful story of hope and healing in the midst of tragedy. The dual timelines connect a daring escape during World War II with the present day. Grace, a young Quaker woman, is dedicated to rescuing Jewish children from occupied France during the war. Her journey with the children kept me on the edge of my seat, hoping they would escape the Nazi’s grip. But that wasn’t the end of the danger for Elias and Marguerite, who came home to America with Grace. The trauma they faced during the war followed them and led to a betrayal that affected their family for generations to come.

In the present day, Addie, a young widow, is searching for healing for the man who rescued her. She thought that her search for the truth was for the benefit of her mentor, Charlie, but it turned out she needed the healing it brought as well. The two storylines were perfectly woven together in a beautiful, satisfying conclusion. With characters that steal your heart, vivid descriptions that transport you into the story, and powerful themes of redemption and forgiveness, this is a story that will stay with you long after the final page. I highly recommend this book for fans of historical fiction and authors like Sarah Sundin and Heidi Chiavaroli!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

A Captivating Story of Unexpected Love and Courage: Sarah Sundin sets the standard for WWII fiction in my book, and Until Leaves Fall in Paris is no exception. Every time I read one of her books, I learn something new about the WWII era. It's apparent Sundin does her research, and the historical details come to life through her characters and settings. This is a captivating story of unexpected love in the face of adversity and unexpected courage in the face of evil. The romance between Paul, a misunderstood man of principle and conviction, and Lucie, a charming heroine who discovers she is stronger than she believed, is an enchanting part of the story. The suspense and intrigue of their work with the resistance make the book almost impossible to put down!

Until Leaves Fall in Paris is Sarah Sundin at her finest - engaging characters and powerful truths woven into a story that will stick with you long after the final page. I highly recommend this book to fans of historical fiction, especially those who enjoy authors like Michelle Dobson and Amy Lynn Green, and also to readers who love finely crafted, compelling stories in any genre.

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own. Thank you, Revell!

Hooked from the first page: Caroline George has written another gripping, evocative story in The Summer We Forgot. I don't usually read YA fiction, but her voice, style, and ability to write such layered characters has made her a must-read author for me. This murder mystery follows a group of high school seniors whose lives were all turned upside down two summers ago, but they can't remember why. The story drew me in from the beginning, from the coastal setting on 30A to the friendships between the characters to the twisty, layered plot.

"We're part the lies we believe about ourselves and part the truths we forget."

This is a coming of age story that readers of any age can relate to, as we question along with the characters whether or not we will let our past mistakes define us. If you are looking for a clean, deeply moving story that blends mystery with romance and friendship, look no further than The Summer We Forgot.

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

Delightfully Funny and Full of Heart: I love a good Bethany Turner rom-com, and The Do-Over was just the fun read I needed! Her writing is the perfect blend of witty humor, clever dialogue, and charming characters. I found myself rooting for McKenna from the first page, and I love that her family is such an integral part of the story. Her relationships with her sisters add plenty of depth and heart! Henry is the perfect hero for her: a high school rival all grown up, with the ability to make her question everything she thought she knew about how her life would go. Their sweet romance, sprinkled with plenty of twists and funny moments, makes for a delightful story from beginning to end. I highly recommend The Do-Over to readers who enjoy authors like Melissa Ferguson and Jenny B. Jones!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

A Delightful Trip Back to Hope Harbor: Returning to Hope Harbor feels like going home! This beautiful seaside town is the perfect place to escape to for a few hours in one of Irene Hannon’s beautifully written stories. Sea Glass Cottage is a fairly light read, but that doesn’t mean the characters don’t deal with some tough issues and tricky situations. Christi and Jack are both dealing with pain from their pasts - including pain they caused each other. In the secondary storyline, Beth and Steve are dealing with grief and regrets after the death of their son. Both second-chance romances will touch your heart and bring a smile to your face.

Long time readers of the series will love the appearances from fan favorite characters, especially Charley the taco artist and his seagull friends, Floyd and Gladys. Hope Harbor is the perfect place to find peace and hope, for characters and readers alike. Fans of Denise Hunter and Christina Suzann Nelson will enjoy this series!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own. Thank you, Revell!

A Treasure Hunt Through Time: Kelli Stuart is a new-to-me author; the beautiful cover and premise of this book drew me in. I wanted to like it, but I never felt connected with the characters in either timeline. The treasure hunt in the present day seemed a little unrealistic to me, especially towards the end. Even so, I did enjoy learning some history about the Russian Revolution and Fabergé eggs. I know that many readers loved this story, so if you enjoy treasure hunts and early 20th century history, this book might be for you!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own. Thank you, Revell!

Gripping and Poignant: This powerful sequel to Night Bird Calling brings readers back to No Creek, North Carolina, in a split time story that spans two wars. The cover is gorgeous, and the story inside is even more beautiful! The ramifications of the Civil War are still impacting the characters we know and love during the WWII timeline. The racism that still exists in the 1940s is made more evident by the war, as young black men are sent to fight on behalf of an oppressed people, only to return home to the scorn and injustice that has persisted through the last 80 years.

In this book, we see Celia Percy grow into a courageous young woman, willing to stand up for justice. The discovery she makes one stormy night may have implications for the town that no one could have imagined. Celia draws strength and inspiration from the story and diary of Minnie, the young woman who lived at Belvidere Hall decades earlier. The tragedies and triumphs of these characters will steal your heart from beginning to end, and this poignant story is one that will stick with you long after the last page. If you enjoy gripping stories that bring history to life, don't miss A Hundred Crickets Singing!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

Captivating Historical Time Travel: When the Day Comes is an absolutely captivating story by Gabrielle Meyer! It is a unique twist on the dual timeline & historical genres, with the heroine, Libby, living in both 1774 and 1914. As she approaches her twenty-first birthday, she must choose one path to live for the rest of her life. This fascinating premise is handled brilliantly, with rich historical detail and engaging characters.

Libby is such a relatable heroine, and I found myself rooting for her from the first page. She is faced with tragedy and difficult decisions in both timelines, and Ms. Meyer did a wonderful job of weaving powerful spiritual themes throughout. I enjoyed seeing history come to life through Libby's eyes, as she lived through the beginnings of both the American Revolution and World War I. The twists and turns kept coming, leaving me holding my breath and wondering how Libby could possibly have a happy ending. I was surprised and delighted by the satisfying conclusion, and I am very much looking forward to the next book!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

A Sweet Story of Family and Second Chances: The Sweet Life is a fun, lighthearted story, perfect for a spring or summer day at the beach! I love the New England setting - Suzanne Woods Fisher is great at writing about small towns full of quirky characters. I also worked at an ice cream shop as a teenager, so I enjoyed going back to that fun time in my life through this story!

Dawn and her mom, Marnie, are an unlikely mother-daughter duo - they don't see eye to eye on much, but they both find themselves needing a fresh start in life. Opening an ice cream shop together tests their faith and their patience, as they work together to overcome opposition and heartbreak. This sweet story of starting over and second chances, sprinkled with heartwarming moments and spiritual truths, will delight readers and ice cream fans alike!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

Fascinating History with Amazing Characters: Elizabeth Camden has written another fascinating story that's impossible to put down! Written on the Wind reunites us with characters we first met in Carved in Stone, but it can be read as a stand alone. This novel brings the story of the Trans-Siberian Railway and the Boxer Rebellion to life with rich historical details, compelling characters, romance, and political intrigue. Natalia and Dimitri are opposites in so many ways, but they share a determination, strong moral character, and courage that sees them through hard times they face. While I loved the historical aspects, their witty dialogue and dry humor were some of the my favorite parts of the book!

If you are looking for well-researched historical fiction with characters you won't soon forget, you can't go wrong with Elizabeth Camden! Written on the Wind, and the entire Blackstone Legacy series, are destined for the keeper shelf.

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

Edge of your seat suspense!: What an action-packed, nail-biting take on the suspense genre! This was the first of Mary Alford's books I have read, but it won't be the last. I loved the unique twist of a suspense novel centered on an Amish community and a small town police department. Leah is a strong, smart heroine who has taken the tragedy of her past and used it for good, although her past comes back to haunt her in this book. Unbeknownst to her, she and Dalton are connected through that tragedy ten years ago... now that the killer is back, they are thrown together as they race to put an end to his twisted plot once and for all. Full of likable characters, a fast-paced plot, and plenty of surprises to keep you guessing, this book will delight fans of DiAnn Mills and Nancy Mehl!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

Action and Adventure with Heart: What an incredible story! Susan May Warren takes us on a wild ride Key West, Africa, and finally back to Alaska. This book introduces us to the second Kingston brother, Ranger. His calm, collected demeanor and his warrior heart make him the perfect match for Noemi, with her vibrant, colorful personality. Their banter and chemistry leaps off the page, and you can’t help but feel their pain, doubts, and triumphs right alongside them. Marriage of convenience is one of my favorite tropes, and I absolutely loved the way it played out in this book!

I would definitely recommend reading the series in order, as characters and plot lines from previous books are woven into this story. The next book can't come soon enough! If you enjoy books full of adventure, suspense, and second chance romance, don't miss Sunburst!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own. Thank you, Revell!

Riveting Story of Sacrifice and Unconditional Love: The Record Keeper is the riveting conclusion to an incredible series! Murphy Shepherd is back, and this time he and Bones are on a mission to finally put a stop to the criminal mastermind they have been fighting for so many years. The raw, gritty truth of human trafficking is contrasted with the unconditional love and sacrifice that marks Bones' life. The ending is heart-wrenching and bittersweet - everything wasn't tied up in a neat bow, but it was the perfect, fitting ending. You will remember this powerful story long after the final page!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

Nail-Biting Suspense with a Cyber Twist!: Critical Alliance was my favorite of the Rocky Mountain Courage series! The focus is on Alex and Mackenzie, but we also get to catch up with characters from the first two books. I would recommend reading the series in order, but you won't be lost if you start with this one!

The action and suspense in this story will definitely keep you on the edge of your seat! The ruggedly beautiful Montana setting is the perfect backdrop for the twists and turns Alex and Mackenzie face as they race to find out who is behind the threats to her life. The cybersecurity angle was a unique element, and not hard at all to understand or follow. The blend of character development and action kept the story moving at just the right pace. If you enjoy inspirational romantic suspense, I highly recommend Critical Alliance and the whole Rocky Mountain Courage series!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

Life Changing: The Secret Society of Success is a great book about the mindset and heart we bring to our work! It can apply to so many areas of life, not just the work we do to make a living. The chapters are short, easy to read, and full of practical advice. I loved all the real life stories and examples of people who don't define success the way the world does. Anyone would benefit from reading this book, from hourly workers to CEOs to entrepreneurs, no matter what industry or stage of life you’re in. It would make a great gift for high school or college graduates!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.

Truly Extraordinary!: "I simply tried to love people as best I could for as long as I was privileged to be with them."

What an incredible book! I wasn't sure what to expect from a debut novel, but I was pleasantly surprised to find a captivating story in these pages! It might seem strange to call this book delightful, since it deals so honestly with death, but it truly was a delight to read. While it is somewhat bittersweet, the way Mrs. Kip's faith was evident in how she lived and faced death was both convicting and inspiring. Her wisdom and spunk can charm the toughest of audiences, and Aidyn's growth and transformation was so moving. This heartfelt story will make you laugh, cry, and want to be like Mrs. Kip when you grow up!

I received a complimentary copy of this book from the publisher via NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own.
Cute: A cute story, if a little on the empty side. A few too many poster-type “wise” sayings for my taste.
The recipes are easy ones that do not require a lot of time, and still they are good.: Great for easy recipes and especially when you want to try something new.

You Will Love The Maid: The Maid is a uniquely refreshing book due to the main character, Molly. I immediately fell in love with her and wanted the best for her. I did not want to stop reading this book.
Riveting: I could not stop reading the book.  It’s non stop action and it was thrilling to the very end.  The outcome was unpredictable to the very end.
Great read!: This book is very well written.  Complex plots that eventually coalesced all the way to the end.  I can’t wait to read the next book of the Camel Club.  I highly recommend this one.

review: what a finale!: This is another one of CJ Box’s super exciting and thrilling books.  I highly recommend this.  I have now read all 22 of Joe Pickett’s series and hope he continues to work as  game warden.
Highly recommend!: An excellent novel. Very impressed with the mixture of fiction and non-fiction. Character development  was impressive and really personalized the novel.

Excellent!: I thoroughly enjoyed this mix of history and fiction. Character development was well done and truly painted a picture of each.

Highly recommend
Another good one: Have read all of the Joe Pickett novels.  This one is as solid and captivating as all have been.  Great (continued) character development and intriguing story.
Twisted psychological thriller: How the need to be loved can be so desperate, that we loose sight of right and wrong? That we become controlled by this person and really not loved at all
mental and physical abuse: How can a belief of right in the Lords eyes be a justification for mental and physical abuse! I so loved her recovery and intellect
Murder mystery: If you have knowledge of French, you will enjoy and possibly figure out the murder.  Loved all the ways Agatha put it all together

review: No one does it better.: Fair Warning was a blast to read. Beautifully crafted, timely and so believable that it’s terrifying. Connellly is a master storyteller.

review: Mosley is the Master.: I doubt anyone needs my two cents on this classic, but Devil in a Blue Dress provides readers with a penetrating glimpse of another culture and another time. Only a master wordsmith can mix suspense, eroticism, and humor with philosophy and social commentary.

review: It doesn’t get any better.: Sandford is the master of the genre and Certain Prey is his masterpiece. It’s book ten of the Prey series, but if you’re curious you might as well start here.
Meh: Other than a couple recipes, these are very ordinary, made up recipes with no originality.
Patterson book? Hard to believe?: Not the good books Patterson writes. Did not like the  style.

Dense, thick: I have not made it really far into this book as it is thick and dense. Filled with all kinds of information! How to make things (one picture is of Kombucha) to kefir, yogurt and probably anything else you can think of.
There’s 13 chapters in all, 413 pages worth of information Plus extra reading material.
I doubt I will ever read every word on every page but I do think I will reference it often and frequently.
There are some colored photos but most are little sketches on the side of a page.
From what I’ve read it’s not terribly witty but there are some humorous parts here and there mixed in. Helps break up the dense parts.
All in all I’m happy with the purchase and would probably buy it again but I’m not sure this is a book for the faint of heart as it is dense and thick.

Bought twice: I like this book so much I bought it twice!
I have my older copy to a friend and then I wanted to look something up and I couldn’t so I bought it again. I gave away 5 books but this is the only one I replaced with a new copy.
The information is a little bit dated as it was wrote something like twenty years ago but it is still all relevant. He writes in an easy to understand way that a person can zip through. It’s easy to take notes as the layout is nice. There are a few recipe ideas in the book and it was easy for my to jot them down in a notebook.
He covers pretty much all issues related to dogs and has natural ways of treating them. There are a few herbs mentioned although this is not an herbs for dogs book.
All in all this book might be a little older but it is still well worth the purchase and the read through.

Changing my life!: This book is filling in so many blanks and questions I have had over the years. Reminding me to practice old thoughts (like visualization) in order to accomplish more in my life.
I started with the audio book and then I bought the soft cover so I could easily reference back to the parts I wanted to highlight.

I have probably 30 different horse books but I think this one is by far the most helpful and informational.
If the travel path of your life is more about communication, relaxation and being able to accomplish more by doing less then this is probably a good for you.
Dr Fay talks about brain waves and different ones go with different emotions: anxiety, stress, worry, calm, happy, joyful, etc. Dr Fay goes over the difference between intention vs goals. So far I am absolutely loving her work!
Highly recommend this book and her other informational resources to anyone looking for this type of travel path within themselves and with their animals, mainly horses.

Book shows the type of parent who raises a psychopath: I always wonder how on earth do psychopaths and serial killers get formed. This book shows that one contributing factor is certainly self absorbed parents who lack empathy. The author is the mother of a psychopath and you can see from the book how serious her own mental problems are. Being self centered she is incapable of seeing anyone else’s perspective but her own. Wasting her life on this book also shows how little compassion or understanding for Cassie, her sons victim, she has. The book is creepy and I hope to never encounter these types of psychopath killer families.
great series: Great books
Like New: Short, beautifully written heartbreaker.  In pristine condition, so I passed it on as a present to a friend.

Favorite nitey-nite book.: Beautiful illustrations, calming gentle text, just a perfect book. The board book was a little warped, which was disappointing as I couldn't bend it straight before giving it as a gift.

fabulous book: The imagery is wonderful but not long-winded. The main character is tough but likable, and he's observant, smart. Overall, an easy read with a good plot, and an interesting portrayal of Appalachian culture.

Slow and contextless start, couldn't recover: I will say up front that I read one fourth of this book. I was really looking forward to it, as I know it was a National Book Award finalist and I really loved the short stories of Groff's "Florida."

From page one, I felt like a chapter was missing or that I'd missed something. The main character is someone I grew no attachment or fondness for, and the first fourth of the book extended about a year in time where almost nothing actually happens.

I was losing interest after Part One but thought I should stick it out. I went through some of Part Two and didn't foresee a different trajectory, so I stopped reading.

Read this book!: A group of coed psychopaths, a secretive research program, revenge, and a killer on the loose. Now that's a recipe for a great book.

The writing is so clever and easy to follow, I can't recommend this book enough.

New favorite!: Having read most of Lexie’s books I must say this is by far my favorite series. I was hooked on this book from the first page and couldn’t put it down until I was done. I highly recommend giving it a shot even if it’s not something you’d think you’d be into because it is that good! I loved learning more about the different characters and seeing the relationships develop. Very well written and nicely paced. I am already dying for the third book.

Loved it: Perfect ending for this series. Everything tied up really nicely. This book was fast paced and flowed really well. As sad as I am that Harlow’s story is over I can’t wait to read Jacinta’s and Hope’s story. I just really hope we can get a novella with Harlow and her men in the future because I’m not ready to say goodbye.

Fun quick read: I really love the concept of this storyline. Zada is a vampire who starts off with a strong sense of duty to her kind. I loved watching her grow throughout her journey. This book had a little bit of everything - steamy moments, action, betrayal, and shocking twists. I really can’t wait until the next book comes to see where things go from here. My one and only complaint is how fast paced the book is. It makes for a quick read which isn’t horrible but it was so good I wish it was slowed down so I could appreciate it more.
Chainsaw man: It’s Chainsaw man
Amazingly wonderful!!!!: Lila and Pierre are so adorable. You'll love this book. Get it!!

Wow! Another powerful Mitch Rapp adventure.: This novel was one of the best. And, I have read everyone of them. It delves into the motives of some of the most powerful people on earth, with localities and betrayal center most.

I loved it.

Another fun read: I love these books!  I read all her books.  I forced myself to read 5his one slowly, savoring it. I’m a fast reader and it was hard but worth it. As always her characters are vivid, unique and memorable. The book is a mixture of fast pace action and hilarious situations and dialogue. This time Diesel was prominent.  But, we still had a chance to drool over Morelli and Ranger. Keep them coming, please.

Joys and Sorrows: It's a joy to read another marvelously inventive book by Carlos Ruiz Zafón; it's a sorrow to realize there'll never be another. This posthumous collection of short stories should appeal to the millions of readers who have come to know and love one of the most creative of contemporary writers, and it could also serve as an excellent introduction to those meeting him for the first time. Upon finishing the book, I felt a desire to read through the Cemetery of Forgotten Books cycle again. The book is magical, whimsical, perceptive, and poignant -- all qualities that made Ruiz Zafón the treasure he was and that he continues to be through the phantasmagoric books he left us.

Great Series!: I  first read these individually but having them all together makes it better. You don't have to wait for the next installment just read the whole book. It kept me guessing until the very end. I can't recommend it high enough.

history: B003NX7540 B00LD1ON4E B01BJSRSA6 B004G5ZY7E B000OIZUYE B07P5HXFJY B07WQPHD3M
review: A Long Goodbye: I was caught up in the first maybe half of this mystery, but althought events were potentially exciting, as the book progressed, it started to drag.  The later characters became stereotypes.  The author seemed to feel she had to include every twist and turn she could.

What a lovely way to discuss anger and bullies with kids!: I absolutely adored the lessons “Clovis” helped illustrate for my kindergartener. We’ve had a rough transition into school but the mindfulness techniques in this book fostered such a good conversation between us. Big feelings, grace, and tea make “Clovis” our new favorite for bedtime.

My kids love it!: Hilarious! My boys thought it was so funny that I had to say “poo” so much. 😂 A great addition to our bookshelf. We loved all of the previous books from Katelyn Aronson but “Poo-dunit” is the one that made us giggle the most!

Fabulous!: As a librarian who reads six to eight books a month, I adamantly disagree with everyone who has submitted a negative review of this book. I sailed through the 600 plus pages of this novel completely absorbed, finding the book hard to put down for a minute. One of he very best that I have read in a long time. Brava, Maggie Shipstead. Five stars, highly recommended.

Triptych: 1580’s.  Tom Lutton, a deaf-mute and apothecary is used as a spy in the court of Queen Elizabeth 1. He has a story to tell and has painted his life story on a triptych and hidden it .  2019. His descendant Mathilde Lutton inherits his estate that has been passed down generation to generation for five hundred years. Good reading!

You will not forget the Forgotten Garden: An awesome story, as spiraled as a corkscrew. As the story slides down the side of the corkscrew it touches many stories as it goes around the turn. Is this a love story? Yes. It it a story of great grief? Yes. Eliza escapes to her other world by writing magnificent fairy takes, of which contain bits of truth of her own life and those around her.
The author has a way with words and puts you in her pocket and lets you see the story with her as she goes. Her vocabulary is extensive and I so enjoyed looking up some of her words. Lovely!
The Garden is so beautiful it makes your heart cry to begin mulching and planting in you own space.
At times I did have trouble and became confused with which voice was speaking and had to loop around to find the right place.
I hope you enjoy the genealogy, history and depth of this tale. I did.

Smell the Glove: Bobbi Flekman ("This is Spinal Tap") would have a field day with the dysfunctional cast of media professionals in this saga...that I could not put down.
Hats off to Katie who survived, flourished, and even served comeuppance on occasion. Things were at their weirdest at CBS..."I always liked Les Moonves even though he was a close talker with bad breath". Maybe that's why Cybill Shepard rebuffed his alleged sexual advances. Hmm, her comedy "Cybill" was abruptly cancelled. The 60 Minutes cast and producer that Katie had to work with were insufferable.
What was not enjoyable, however, was imagining the family members who were victims of parental public disgrace (Matt Lauer's son in boarding school).
A balanced, candid, even humble memoir.
Brilliant: Read it. You won't be sorry.

I’m in looove with this family: How cool is to belong to a group where no excuses necessary for lack of empathy or societal norms. It’s just how they are wired.

The family that slays together stays together. This series is so much fun, can’t wait for more.

Oh my Stars ⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️: First off, how could the twins get any cuter?

I love me some Felix. Super fierce and delicate who cuts first then asks questions. And Avi is his freak just like Felix is Avi’s person. They all fit together nicely.

Can’t wait for the story of the next couple to step up. Gonna be a good’un.

Not quite what I expected: I thought this would be a short little book with the basics teapot song I know and love but it’s so much more. At first I didn’t think I’d like it but it really grew on me… and now it’s one of my toddlers go to books. I like that each page and each adventure fits with the original teapot song and love all the fun details in the pictures

Not what I expected: I thought this would be a nice illustrated version of the classics song we all know and love. Only the first page is though. The rest of the book goes off on a crazy tangent… if it matches with the tune of the classic song I’m not doing it right.
Arrived early and in great shape!: Arrived early and in great shape!

history: B008AK8FHM B00DMCPQUW B004TI5N38 B01BU1ITMI B000QUCO58 B01I9FFDI6 B001MSMULG B000OIZV4S
review:
That Billy! What a character!: Not always easy for my small brain to keep the chronology straight, as the book juts between past and present so frequently…But Billy Harney is an interesting guy: a detective with a dad and a twin sister also ‘serving and protecting’ as Chicago cops; he’s sometimes sensitive, most times not very subtle, and almost always a smartass comedian. He’s no saint, likes/loves his women and drinks like a fish. He’s a stubborn battler for justice!

This book isn’t always very plausible, but then, as crazy as Chicago politics can be, it keeps you turning pages—especially if you ARE a Chicagoan (I am!) and you know the streets, the scenes, and the neighborhoods described.

I read this trilogy out of sync, beginning with book rwo. Don’t do that!

history: B004EEP9AE B00ERU1AE4 B00R8B8L0K B00WSSE4JU B01COJUGOE B01INMZL00 B01LBQMA5Y B01M716DW3 B071RBPMVB B078G2SWRJ B07BNVQW3N B07W4RDMKW B07Z43N1F6 B07XJQMF2T B08PZFYS6R
review:
about time: love this series. this book was great lots of suspense, murder and surprises..
can't wait for the next story.
All the characters are fun and lovable..

Had some great scenes to remember: A super action run of a thriller. This is my first read of this author and I'm pretty impressed. The scenes played out like real life, written by a man who expirenced those kind of intense moments.
Good fun.: Silly, fun stories for adults and teens alike. Solid writing and an entertaining mix of stories that will make you laugh as time flies by.

Yuck.: Such as the days of Stephen King thrilling us are all but long gone! His polictical rants have consumed his stories for years. And me being a Trump advocate for the man who didn't bend to government B.S. that controlled our senate and such is offended by these rants. If you think you can do better Mr. King, then run for president yourself and leave it out of your stories.
If you're looking for good S.K. stories you're gonna have to go back in time to the days of his early and middle works when the stories were genuine and meant to entertain to the hardest degree. Now his stories are heavily sauced with political anger and poor conclussions leaving the reader greatly unsatisfied.
Filled with lots of color opportunities!: A cute book perfect for the little ones! Nice illustrations!
5 year old approved story!: A super cute, fun & funny story my granddaughter loved. Brilliant illustrations, too!

I wanted a bit more.: The book, although written well, seemed to lack for me. It came off as an intense mystery/international thriller but the story took too long to pull me into its grip. By that time, I was ready to be done with the story and move on to something else. Overall, I wouldn't mind checking out something else by this author.
A must have!: Loaded with info to benefit small businesses like mine. This is a no-brainer investment to get wonderful tips to market your dream business and make it everything it can be.

Strong writing with a fun plot.: Chapter 1 kicks off an interesting killer start to this book. As a personal preference I would have enjoyed the momentum to continue. Though I will say after that begins a bit of a slow pace as our main character gets accepted and travels to her new school home. She meets lots of people and her way through this new school before the story gets rolling into the depth of the mystery flashback of chapter 1. I completely understand the character and plot building here before the leap into the nature of the heavy plot structure. Once Bexley settles in the story ramps up well.
All in all I enjoyed it. The writing is accomplished and edited nicely. Well done, Ms. Warm!
Needs much work: There's hard to ignore errors within this mystery. This would be more readable cleaned up by a professional editor. I just couldn't dive into it the way I wanted to.

Great for tactile addition and subtraction: I have several tactile learners, and being able to move their fingers to add and subtract is a HUGE help for them. Greatly recommend these for tactile or kinesthetic learners!

Great princess book for Little Princesses: Bought this for a reluctant second-grade reader who loves princesses.  She sat down and read through it immediately.  As a teacher, I am constantly looking for books that match a student's interests and reading level.  Too many words tend to discourage her, and I think this had enough words to exercise her decoding but enough illustrations to engage her.  Perfect Christmas addition to a class library or a child's personal library.

A must have for budding cartoonists and readers!: The Narwal and Jelly series is one of my favorites for the classroom.  They are engaging, hilarious, and kids enjoy the humor and wonderful illustrations.  I love showcasing artists and writers who specialize in children's literature, but especially children's graphic novels. Students from kindergarteners to fifth-grade have enjoyed this book, and they will even come up and point out their favorite parts or quote bits to me in class.

Beware: This book may spark spontaneous cartooning on homework!: Bought this for a student who collects the Dogman series.  He loved this book, but be prepared to endure colorful and imaginative cartooning on every scrap of paper that comes to hand!  As a reading and art teacher, this book is a perfect combo.  If you have a child who enjoys doodling, Dav Pilkey's books are a perfect match.

Wonderfully fun: Spies, magic, and a girl and her aunt need to have an income so she learns she can sew glamours into dresses. Annis is a wonderful character and you'll find yourself hoping she gets the answers she needs.

Great creepy YA novel: I wasn't sure what to expect when I started this book, but was surprised at how quickly I was pulled into the story. With likable characters and a plot with great tension, this is one for the keeper shelf.

More like 3.75 Stars: Since you already know how it is going to end there is no suspense. It can be a slow read, or in my case, listen. I did the Audible. I was completely intrigued by the detailed description of Tokyo, and its culture and history. I learned sooo much and it was fascinating! This was my first true crime book and I really enjoyed it.

Freedom or control?: What is the ideal form of government?  How much does it depend on what you think of the nature of human beings?  Is order more important than freedom?  What happens when good men do nothing in the face of evil? I love seeing the world through Snow's young eyes.  Through the book I quickly come to love him.  I understand him.  I sorrow for his suffering. And I watch him make choice after choice.  If we do not stand against evil, does that evil reel us in?  If we do not oppose evil, are we helping it by default?  Brilliant book.
Great family read aloud: We read this as a family read aloud. We all loved it

This is pure Scott.: I only just now got around to reading the book, which was apparently an ARC.

I normally don't do biographies, much less autobiographies, but I like the clothing (I first purchased them when they just started their relationship with Thinkgeek) so probably bought it just because of who it was. It was actually for the most part quite funny and easy to read. I have no doubt he wrote it himself and did not hire a ghost writer or anything like that. This is pure Scott.

He is a shameless promoter, if you ever interacted with him, you would already know that so that is throughout the book. If you are expecting anything humble, don't read it. If you don't mind or don't care or are used to Scott being... well... Scott, well you will like it.

Based on some of the amazon reviews, I think people were expecting this to have more solid business advice, I don't think that is the take-away lesson from the book. The main take away is that you can do great things if you have a lot of passion for whatever it is. That is the POINT.

(For those who rated it low because it says "unauthorized," Scott is trying to be funny. While many of the times his jokes "land," sometimes they don't. He is a business man and a former lawyer, so pretty sure his classes did not include comedy.)

An excellent book on shamanism: It's really hard to go wrong with this author who was one of the leading experts on shamanism when he was alive. I wish he was still around so I could learn from him directly.

Turns vampire myths on their heads, intense and moving: I was very impressed by this manga. I was expecting the usual vampire tropes, and I found instead something rather new and different. En, a newly turned vampire, has to learn all about his new existence. To his surprise, the vampires he meets are intensely engaging, quirky and melancholy. In turn, the vampires find in En someone who is endearing, naive and kind. Icchi in particular is drawn to En, and they begin a relationship that confuses and enlivens Icchi. The intimate scenes are realistic and novel, they actually advance the story and the character's relationship. The volume ends with an alarming and tense revelation. I'm looking forward to volume 2.
Very Informative: This book is a must read for any small business owner.
Great content.: Bob tells you how to do it, not just what to do. Great content that, if used properly, can change the impact of all your communications.
One of my go-to authors: Great flow to the story
Great advice for the common man/ women.: I gave a copy to my daughter and my grandson. He is just starting his career.
Very interesting: Lots of history in this book. I fell in love with Her. Too bad she couldn’t fine love.
Short Doggie Tales: A perfect collection of true short stories about the authors caring of his doggie patients and interactions with their owners and fellow colleagues. A relaxing read.
Medal of Honor recipient story: A very informative history of a soldier's Vietnam experiences and military life as well as his family's history. A worthwhile read.

Changing relationships.: The author gives an historical perspective of once thought to be good relationships soured by political misinformation,  some of which turned bitter.  Personalities are dissected to explore how they came to be.  Keeping track of names can be trying (as the author admits).  Misinformation vs the Truth is dangerous especially to an uneducated society.

A great read!: This was a fabulous exploration of Chinese mythology, told in a way that everyone can enjoy. I loved the detailed descriptions of tea and how it has such a strong impact on everyday life. I connected to the main character, Ning, and her struggles to save what's left of her family by participating in this dangerous competition. There's royal scandal and cous, magic and tradition abundant in this novel, and it's very enjoyable. Thanks Netgalley and yallfest for the chance to read this arc before it was released!
Page Turner!: Couldn’t put it down until I finished the story. So creepy and horrifying, but I had to keep reading. Super enjoyed it!
Poignant Memoir: Superb first book for Mr. Johnson. No spoilers.
The Best of the Best!: Received right away and in excellent condition.  Love the book nice pictures and so many recipes to try.

Well done: Good procedural .The characters well formed and it certainly kept my interest. I liked the move back and forth in time.
Worth the read.

Good times with old friends: "The past is another country-you can't get there from here".  But i can spend time with  my best buds from thirty years ago.  Breathed is one of my favorite author/artists,  and i miss  these characters every day.  This book is wonderful.
Even more good times with old friends.: See my review for "Best Read On the Throne".

A Story Of Courage In The Face Of The Nazis Over-running France: A French middle-aged artist makes a hazardous  escape to England in the face of the Nazi onslaught.  He then immediately volunteers his services to the English to help set up the beginnings of what would become the French Underground.

Fascinating.: A well-written memoir of the career of a retired FBI agent. Noesner's experiences, including his role in investigating the famous plane hi-jackings by terrorists in the 1980s and moving on to his experience as the FBI's chief hostage negotiator, were informative and compelling.

Knowledge of an interesting but obscure topic.: Some years ago, I read ‘Sea People’ by Christina Thompson. It was a fine introduction to someone that knew little of Polynesia. ‘Voyagers’ adds more information on a fascinating topic, the peopling of the Pacific. It’s well written and interesting even for a novice, like me.
Moving and inspirational: I couldn't put this book down! It is so captivating and gripping. Park's story is important and needs to be shared freely and widely.

A great read!: I was hooked by this novel from the very beginning. The middle part felt a little slower to me but by the ending, the story really picked up again and I found myself rooting for Gabriella's happiness. The ending pages were pure perfection. What a good book!
Wonderful read: I loved this book! It was so engaging and I found myself invested in everyone's story. Thanks for a great read!
Nice copy: Arrived in timely manner. Gift quality!
Great book.: Gives a good picture of life under totalitarian government rule.
Pages are misprinted: Excellent story!!!! Birthday present for Dad. We didn't realize the pages were poorly printed until after the return window. Check each page when you get it!
I would not recommend  for younger children.: Questions seemed a little advanced for our 6 yr. old . But great for families with a little older children.
22 Seconds: For the life of me I cannot fathom how this man pulls out winners time after time, but he does. I’m always happy I read it and sad it’s over, simultaneously. Great read and so very good.

One of the best: This was an amazing book. She really did her research. I could almost feel I was in the old south. I know I could never have done what these sisters did, but I admire them tremendously. They shined a light on the truth of slavery.

This is going to be a good series!!: I have been waiting for this to come out!! I can tell from just this book I am going to be waiting on pins and needles for each additional one! Traded was the first book in Lisa’s Vegas Aces: The Quarterback series. It was hot, full of humor, and so much sass!

Kate first met Jack at a party where they seemed to hit it off until Jack delivered some bad news. The second time they met, he may have caused her to have some rage. The third time they saw each other Kate was being introduced as his new behavior coach. Needless to say, their track record might not be so hot!

How hard can living with her one-night stand, his fiancé, and their baby, as well as being a glorified babysitter be?

I have to say, I was not a fan of Jack when I first met him in Lisa’s Vegas Aces series. But he might be growing on me… This book was such a great start and I can’t wait to see where everything will go!

On the edge of my seat!!!: Nooo!!! I mean, I knew it was going to happen…but the cliffhanger…aggghhhh!!! Why Lisa, why?? Tackled was the second book in Lisa’s Vegas Aces: The Quarterback Series and must be read in order!

Kate and Jack may have had some photos taken of them that alluded to more than what was going on. Would it be the end of Kate’s job or would Jack manage to save her?

Jack has definitely been growing on me, he just can’t catch a break! I know the next one will end in a cliffhanger that will leave me craving more but I can’t wait to get my hands on it!!

I am fully Team Jack now!: I am fully in love with Jack now…I knew from the start what this series was going to do to my heart but I still wasn’t prepared! There were so many emotions! Timeout was the third book in Lisa’s Vegas Aces: The Quarterback series and MUST be read in order. It may have been heartbreaking but I am craving more!

Jack’s wedding was approaching fast and neither of them were ready to handle it. Kate knew she needed to ensure Jack went through with it, but her heart wanted something else.

Gah! Again with the cliffhanger!! I guess I will have to impatiently wait for the next one. I love how each book gave me a few answers but raised even more questions! I’m sure my heart won’t agree, but I am ready for all the twists and turns of the rest of their story!

So close…love this series!: HOLY SMOKES…just when I thought I knew where things were going…Bam!! Cliffhanger! Turnover was the fourth book in Lisa’s Vegas Aces: The Quarterback series and must be read in order. It was

Kate had fallen for someone who was never hers. When she left, she not only lost him, but her job! With nothing left to keep her there, maybe it was time to head back home and admit defeat. But could she bring herself to do it?

Gah!! I knew this series would have cliffhangers and I thought I was going to be prepared, nope!! I can’t wait to see how this ends, I am sure it will be amazing!

Perfect Ending to an Amazing Series!!: And we have a touchdown!! What an amazing series! Touchdown was the fifth and final book in Lisa’s Vegas Aces: The Quarterback Series and must be read in order! It was full of angst but in the end it left my heart full of warm fuzzies!

Just when Kate thought it was finally their turn they began to fumble. Little things quickly turned into major roadblocks. She knew what she had to do but it wasn’t going to be easy. Could they ever get their happy ever after?

Gah! These two!! I was not a fan of Jack at first but he completely made me fall for him! I loved every crazy second of this series! Can’t wait to see what is in store for us next!

I Love This Group!!!: I honestly couldn’t wait to get my hands on this! There is just something about this group of friends that captivated me. I was so excited to get more but also sad to say goodbye. Missing The Rules is a novella that goes with The Dating Playbook series and I would recommend reading it last. It was honest, raw, and breathtaking.

Even though five years had passed, Lincoln and Raegan were still finding their way. Life didn’t always go the way they planned but would a few missed rules really threaten their bond?

I loved these two!! It made my heart happy to see all of the gang once again. I wish this series could go on forever!

Loved everything about it!!: This was my second time reading this amazing novella and it was just as perfect as the first time!! There was so much passion and sweetness! I loved every aspect of it!

Sawyer was a single mom on vacation and was not expecting to find love but it certainly found her. There was only one catch, they lived thousands of miles from each other but was their connection enough to overcome it?

Hudson had been a single dad for years and didn’t need the complication of a woman until he met her. There was something that just drew him in, but would he be able to take the next step?

They were so cute together!! Such a fun and swoony read! It had all the feels and I didn’t want it to end! I hope we get to see more of them in future books ❤️

Too read of 2021!!: I am speechless! I was just going to read a few chapters before bed but I was completely captivated and couldn’t stop reading. I have absolutely no regrets on staying up and finishing this book. This was one of my top reads of 2021. Ripple Effect was heart wrenching, but also full of laughs and love!

RJ was once on top of the world. He used to be part of a famous boy band but when he tried to go solo, it didn’t go so well. He knew he needed to be alone and decided to hide in plain sight. Living in a run down area in a small apartment was just what he needed. Until his neighbor couldn’t leave well enough alone. It’s not that Dani knew who he was, it was that she got under his skin. They may have never fixed the war waging between them without Mother Nature.

Holy Moly! I don’t think I even read the blurb on this one. I knew I would love it no matter what and boy did she deliver! This book had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. I laughed (out loud, numerous times), I cried (uncontrollably at times), and I didn’t stop smiling!

Full of passion & charm!: Get ready for a bewitching tale of loss and love. Only Ever Yours was the latest epicness by Nikki Ash. It was emotional, enthralling, and hot!

Camilla had been having a hard time with life, so when an opportunity to make some quick cash presented itself, she decided to take it. Stepping in as an escort for her best friend turned out to be a step towards her future. But when she finally let her guard down, would she end up broken?

Issac knew from the moment he saw her, she was everything he had ever wanted. But in his line of work, there are always consequences. Would their love be one of them?

All the passion, charm and insta love! Loved the twists and turns. I started reading and couldn’t stop. Such a good book to start 2022 with!!

Sweet & Emotional ❤️: I was excited for Izzy and Jude! I loved getting to see little glimpses of them in the previous books leading up to this. Reckless was the third book in Abby’s Wildrose Landing series. It can be read as a stand-alone but I suggest reading them all, they are just that good! It was super sweet, full of emotions, and had all the chemistry!

When Jude proposed to Izzy, she pretty much laughed it off. Only, he was being serious! He needed a wife and who was she kidding, of course she said yes. After all, she had been in love with him for years!

Jude knew it was all business but Izzy was having trouble distinguishing reality from fantasy, especially as time went on. When everything started crashing down around them, would they be able to hold on or would hearts ending up being broken?

Oh Izzy! I felt all the things throughout this book. I was rooting for them the entire time! I loved the banter and how they eventually found their way. Can’t wait for the next installment of this fun series!

Way to kick off the series with a bang!!: Oh Ben! Lisa certainly didn’t disappoint. Tight Spot was the first book in Lisa’s The Tight End series. It was sweet, full of sizzle, and the banter was on point!

Kaylee had never wanted to date a football player but somehow she found herself fake dating a tight end. Ben’s reputation needed some help and she was just the person to do so. Except not everything was how it seemed and they might both end up loosing.

If this first book has indication on how the series will go, we are in for a wild ride!! Once I started I couldn’t stop reading and then I wanted to throw something! I knew the cliffhanger was coming but gah!!! I NEED to know what happens!! Can’t wait for the next one!

history: 030746542X 1089382561 1086605233 1706091559 1672457521 B08DBVR236 1950884112 B08W7SQ86D B08WJPN2FT B08XYFP2J8 B092P78MTH 0399590315 B08N1JMLVW B09CRQNSH7 B09DMTLV4H B09FS9S7FQ B09GXK16JD B09GZDW3ZR B09M54VP9N B09MX98W1Y 1949975363 B09NN55PX2 B09R3DJ9S9 B09SNMYCFB
review:
Gah!! Just Amazing!!: Oh my heart…Lisa!!! What are you doing to me?? I think this had to be by far the most OMG cliffhanger ever!! Tight Hold was the second book in Lisa’s Vegas Aces: The Tight End Series and must be read in order. It was sweet, sexy, and left me in complete suspense!!

Kaylee had been holding her own with her “fake” relationship with Ben. They both knew that their relationship had an end date but what would happen when feelings got involved? Kaylee wants a future and Ben wants to live in the moment. But when Kaylee’s ex decided he wanted to try again, would Ben just let her go?

I loved the connection these two have! I know their story will have lots of ups and down but I have confidence that Lisa will give us the best ending possible. Now to not so patiently wait for the next one. Fair warning, the cliffhanger was heart stopping!!

history: 030746542X 1089382561 1086605233 1706091559 1672457521 B08DBVR236 1950884112 B08W7SQ86D B08WJPN2FT B08XYFP2J8 B092P78MTH 0399590315 B08N1JMLVW B09CRQNSH7 B09DMTLV4H B09FS9S7FQ B09GXK16JD B09GZDW3ZR B09M54VP9N B09MX98W1Y 1949975363 B09NN55PX2 B09R3DJ9S9 B09SNMYCFB B09TDW84YQ
review:
Lovin’ This Series!!: I am in love with this series!! Their connection keeps growing stronger and stronger! Tight Fit was the third book in Lisa’s Vegas Aces: The Tight End series and must be read in order. It was sweet, sexy, and had all the feels!

Kaylee and Ben have lots of things trying to break them apart but it makes them that much more committed to each other. When they get to spend time just to themselves, their feelings become even stronger. Except are those feelings really real?

Gah!! There were so many hints for what is to come and I can’t wait to see how everything plays out! Kaylee and Ben are just so perfect for each other but they need to figure out their own paths first. Of course in true Lisa style it ended with more questions than anything! Can’t wait to get my hands on the next one!

history: 030746542X 1089382561 1086605233 1706091559 1672457521 B08DBVR236 1950884112 B08W7SQ86D B08WJPN2FT B08XYFP2J8 B092P78MTH 0399590315 B08N1JMLVW B09CRQNSH7 B09DMTLV4H B09FS9S7FQ B09GXK16JD B09GZDW3ZR B09M54VP9N B09MX98W1Y 1949975363 B09NN55PX2 B09R3DJ9S9 B09SNMYCFB B09TDW84YQ B09VGSCXHD
review:
Loved Loved Loved!!!: Oh my, this was absolutely precious! Pretty Little Thing was the latest installment in LK Farlow’s Central Valley U series. They are all interconnected stand-alones but you should check them all out! It was sweet, swoony, and full of charm!
