review: Love stories by David: I just can’t get enough of David storytelling. So far, every book I’ve read of his just continue to amaze me and our true page turners.
Incredible writing: One of the best authors ever, weaving people and their stories into the narrative of the country.  Amazing book.

Excellent story of Italian immigrants in NYC: I discovered this book at the Tenement Museum in New York. I was mentioned as a great story about the Italian immigrant experience in the first part of the twentieth century. It definitely lived up to that promise.

It’s a story with a dominant matriarch who carries her family forward in the face of challenges and even tragedy. And of the next generation trying to get ahead and out of the Italian ghetto.

Although the mafia is barely present in this tale, Puzo said that the matriarch shared many of the qualities that made Vito Correleone a powerful character.

Highly recommended

Fun, easy reads: Books and display box in almost-new condition. The set makes for an attractive display. Inspires nostalgia and sparks my excitement to re-read these books that were such a great part of my early reading experiences.

Great intro to dinosaurs: A great intro to dinosaurs from a very young age! Colorful illustrations, well chosen streamlined text (with some additional info on each page for when toddlers are interested) and a nice variety of most recognizable dinosaurs.
Good continuation of the story: Got a little convoluted in parts

Love this: Ahhh tongue and daphne they do hold a special place in my heart. This series would not be the same without them. The love shown in the book is not healthy but is secretly what we all with we had !!!!!

Love it !!!: Oh Boy Atlantic City chapter is quickly becoming one of my favorites. These men love there women so fiercely. Such a great story it keeps you invested from
Beginning to end.

Well done Hannah, give me more please!: Hannah McBride you evil genius! You got me addicted! Again!
When I first heard about this book I admit I had some doubts, the generic theme sounded a little cliché to me. But it was Hannah so I knew somehow she would turn it around into a magnific story, so I put all those silly doubts behind and applied for the arc.
I’m so glad I did ITS AMAZING!!!!
This isn’t your typical “twins found each other and switch places” story, it’s a fair cry from being just that. What starts with a simple plot becomes a mind game of mysteries, once the rich, spoiled, extremely mean twin dies (not a spoiler its in the blurb of the book) and our main character Maddie finds herself stuck in her twin’s life. What was supposed to be a relaxed summer vacation now turned out into a negotiation about money in a world where everyone is the predator and knows how to play the rich game, while Maddie just wants a shot at a better future but finds herself surrounded by sharks. In the middle of this she has no allies since it becomes painfully clear very fast, that her sister had more enemies than friends. As the story goes, we realize that our dear departed Lainey had a lot of secrets, some of them real big and those secrets might now hunt for Maddie, stuck in her sister’s persona.
To the outside world Maddie is Lainey so everyone treats her as such, which its not easy for Maddie in the beginning since the two sisters couldn’t be more different. Where Lainey was spoiled, egocentric and mean, Maddie is a girl used to a tougher life, where she had to look after herself and was basically alone. She is not a party girl but she is funny and sarcastic and has a big kind heart. I really liked her and the way she managed to navigate her sister’s life, play her, but still keep her personality and values.
The side characters are really interesting too, Bex is amazing, a good and Loyal friend that is many times the voice of reason. The boys were a nice addition too, specially Linc he is the funny silly friend but that sees everything going on around him.
But then we have Ryan….and here is where I have to take my hat to Hannah. I though she wrote good romantic interests with Remy and his good boy vibe but Ryan… mother of God, Hannah is even better writing a bad boy. He is NOT a good guy, he is demanding, arrogant, can be really mean and a huge jack*ss, but behind all that he is a guy with big secrets and a lot to protect. Someone who, when he considers someone his, would go to the end of the world for them. And who doesn’t love a protective alpha bad boy?
I loved the book, all the twists, the little things Maddie discovers about her twin and the impact those things bring to the story and to Maddie. There is a control game being played here, I have two big suspicions about Lainey’s death and I’m extremely curious to see if I am right.
The romance was totally swoony too, the way Maddie and Ryan go from “I hate you” to “shit, I like you”, once they start to know each other.
The end was the source of my anguish and book hangover for days and days, Hannah knows how to punch you in the guts and leave you desperate for the next book. I am mad at everyone except Bex! They all should have known better.
Hannah please don’t leave me to suffer for long, I need the second! I need to know how the mess that is this end will turn out and how fast a certain someone will figure out the mistake.
For fans of romance and mystery this book is perfect, it not a thriller and I don’t see it as bully romance even if it has a little vibe of it, but it has a lot of tension, mind games, secrets and crimes that turned the plot into an amazing book that will get you addicted, maybe not from the beginning, but once things start to happen? It’s impossible to settle the book down!
5 FULL STARS, well done Hannah, now give me more please!

3.5 stars: This is a book that has been on my TBR list for years! I liked the Russian old vibe of the world, the way magic is approached, my biggest issue with this book were the characters.
Alina is not the typical main character of an YA book, she is not a stunning girl unaware of her own beauty, or a timid girl that out of the sudden become a super badass. No, she is a normal girl, with an average look, she is timid but has some attitude, and I liked that, the fact that she is so normal, it’s refreshing. On the other hand, I didn’t feel like she grows that much as a character, yes she starts to think and act more like a strategist but at the end her focus is still Mal an her stupid crush on him which end up annoying me. Mal, for me, is just annoying and useless, his only purpose is to be one of the love interests, he takes Alina for granted and only after she I gone does he remember that maybe he misses her, I rolled my eyes everytime he showed. The best characters for me are The Darkling and Genya! I really enjoyed Genya’s survival instincts and how she adapted to her background and history and how that affected her choices, and The Darkling is the most interesting character, the mystery, the moral grey area that surrounds him, but I do not see him a love interest actually and I know I am a minority here.
So, what made me give it 3.5 stars? The world. The Grisha powers, their military, the Morozova plotline, even the small glimpses we have of the other countries, Leigh Bardugo did develop a really interesting and different world. The general plot and the plot twist weren’t a big surprise for me but have a lot of potential for the rest of the books and I am curious to how the author is going to play that out.

Hard Science brought to life through Fiction: Well told stories bring the emerging science to life.  Essays at the end of each story go in depth on the technology, political and ethical implications.  The future is both amazing and frightening depending on whether  the best of natures rules our decision-making.
Engaging and frightful: A chilling narrative of Chinese and  American over-react and miscalculation that feels all to real and prescient.
Well documented and engaging: Full of confirmation and surprising revelations.  The last chapter, on cyber crime, is worth the price of the book and a must read for the concerned citizen.

An Important Mirror for Our Time: Just as How To Be An Antiracist confronts the buried racism that exists in everyone, Our Own Worst Enemy confronts the biases, inconsistent, contradictory and increasingly self-destructive voting behavior of the American electorate.  This an important and timely opportunity to reexamine who we are, who we want to be and how we can find common ground before our democracy collapses from within.

The best civil war novel: Read Rebel Yell first. Non fiction covering Stonewall Jackson, then killer Angels about life after Stonewall Jackson. Longstreet tried to fill Jackson’s shoes but Lee rejected and the South lost it all in one day.

Authentic: I was a southern CA police officer when this book was first published. Great read and very authentic. Every pd of any size had characters exactly like those in the book.
Our night shift debriefings frequently included the younger and better looking waitresses in the area—/not conducive to long marriages.

Tough read: This was very challenging, and certainly not like a modern book on spirituality. I found many passages repetitious, with concepts and themes being presented again and again over many pages, that could have been stated in a paragraph or two. So it is helpful to remember this is as much an historical document as it is a religious how-to guide. It also pays to know something of the historical and cultural context in which it was created.

However, after pushing past the ancient style and discounting issues specific to her contemporary audience, I did find a few enlightening themes that in fact give me more helpful insights into the soul's relationship with God---which is exactly what I was seeking when I felt led to read this.

So, as tough as it was, I am grateful I finished it!!!

Like a mini-vacation: Mary Stewart's novels are really enjoyable. They are beautifully written, with engaging, relatable heroines. The Shakespearean Tempest-theme running throughout was an entertaining device. And the island of Corfu was so vividly depicted that it really did feel like taking a mini-vacation--I was sad that it ended so soon!

Fascinating yet terrifying: This is the classic work by David Lindsey that heavily influenced both C. S. Lewis and J.R.R. Tolkien. It is a hero's journey, telling the tale of Maskull, a young man invited to join two mysterious characters on a trip to the planet Tormance, orbiting the two suns, Branchspell and Alppain.
Once there, Maskull travels many miles through fantastic terrain, and undergoes many physical, mental and emotional changes. He encounters numerous mysterious beings, with whom he has deep conversations about the nature of mankind, pleasure, pain, God and evil.

The depiction of the planet, its inhabitants and the emotions they provoke in the protagonist are incredibly imaginative, truly alien and unforgettable. However, in stark contrast to Lewis' version of similar elements, A Voyage to Arcturus has a decidedly darker opinion of the nature of reality and existence. Lindsey's view is very Nietzsche-like in its stark cynicism, and the overall tone of the work is nightmarish in many parts.

But it is undeniably a work of genius and very much recommended.

Important to have: I feel like this is very important to have for everyone. It teaches legal terms as seen in the eyes of the law. It also has the constitution, the declaration, the articles, so much at one time.

Intriguing Historical Fiction: I've read several Lydia Kang books, and they all have incredible attention to historical detail and provide insight into intriguing facts (ranging from poisons/antidotes to lesser known historical figures and forgotten societal conventions). I always feel both entertained and educated by her books, and The Half-Life of Ruby Fielding is no exception. This time, we're taken to WWII-era New York City and get a behind-the-scenes view of the Manhattan Project and Brooklyn Navy Yard, with plenty of romantic interest and mystery to keep the pages turning. Highly recommend.
very nice !!: I really liked the book and i love how there’s an index of a bunch of herbs and flowers in the back. came in good quality no rips etc.

A Good Read: A fun story to read about a family in distress on a remote island. Great Read.

"Harlem Shuffle", Colson Whitehead's seventh novel, focuses on the seedy underworld of 1940s to 1960s Harlem. It is a revel in Black entrepreneurship and Carney, son of notorious crook Big Mike, struggles to make a name for himself in the furniture world. Inevitably, Carney's past catches up to him as his cousin Freddie drags him into one caper and then another. Bound by a sense of family loyalty, Carney struggles to protect his cousin, his own family and his business.

What really draws me into this novel is the way Whitehead immerses his audience into the era he choses. I truly felt like I was in Black Harlem, surrounded by the sights and sounds of the era, from the decline of radio to the rise in space tech. It's a fun historical drama which also tackles some pretty serious issues of race relations, families and morality. A thoroughly enjoyable read!

Whew, Jesmyn Ward has assembled a fantastic lineup of contemporary authors for this anthology. From new & emerging authors like C Pam Zhang to eminent literary giants like George Saunders, the collection explores the mythical, mystical and realistic. There are fairy tales, hood tales, Gothic tales and even an odd email or two. I absolutely could not stop reading it! Highly recommend this collection to anyone in the mood for a change.

Great Debut!: Thank you to Ecco and NetGalley for the Advanced Reader's Copy!

Now available!

Eloquent and elusive, The Collection Plate maps religion, Black girlhood, and family in an urgent manner. Flowing through the collection is a theme of water, muddled, clear and haunting. Blood waters that tie together family, environmental waste water that plagues generations, cellular water that helps us survive. Absolutely stunning!

Incredible Engrossing Debut: Thank you to Simon&Schuster & NetGalley for the Advanced Reader's Copy!

Available January 2022.

Every mom has a very bad day. Some, though, get caught during their very bad day. In "The School For Good Mothers", Jessamine Chan paints a compelling and terrifying look at a near future. When Frida Liu gets contacted by CPS about leaving her infant daughter Harriet home for two and a half hours, she can hardly imagine the consequences. Soon, Frida is submerged into a world of motherese, artificial children and endless counseling. Chan takes our current ruthless CPS system to its logical conclusion, exploring the heartbreak the system causes on families and communities, especially in Brown & Black neighborhoods.

There was no point in this book where I was not clenching my teeth, tightening my fists and looking over to my own infant for reassurance. I loved how the author manages to capture the illogical approach of CPS, of trying to measure motherhood with austere rubrics, of trying to weigh out who is a "good mother" by society's standards. As a new mom myself, Frida was wholly relatable & watching her emotional turmoil definitely uncovered my own feelings towards motherhood in America. Most of all, I appreciated how the author subtly points out the lack of institutional, social and community support for newborn moms & the way systems that are supposed to help parents often do the opposite. A wonderful book!

Great Collection!: Thanks to Grove Atlantic and NetGalley for the Advanced Reader's Copy!

Now available.

Truly one of the most incredible short story collections I've read in a while. Dantiel W Moniz's Milk Blood Heat doesn't shy away from the awkward and uncomfortable topics, it embraces them. Each story is a different coming to terms, a reckoning of sorts. Rooted deeply in her beloved Florida, each of these protagonists grapples with identity, growing up, violence and trauma. I loved how the title repeats itself in many different iterations, Moniz is wonderfully playful despite the heavy topics. All around great read!

Darkly comic book: Thank you Penguin Random House and Netgalley for the Advanced Reader's Copy!

Now available.

Brandon Taylor weaves a darkly comic, lonely New York as seen through the love trials of Lionel and his ever expanding concerto of lovers and friends. I loved how Lionel's universe is so self-contained, how it expands and then shrinks back down.

Incredible!: Thank you to Simon and Schuster & NetGalley for the Advanced Reader's Copy!

Available July 5th 2022

Keya Das's Second Act is a remarkable work of fiction. With all the pathos and timing of an Indian drama series, the story follows the Das family, a group of Indian Americans living in New Jersey. When Shantanu Das finds his younger daughter's secret play in the attic, he is forced to reckon with a past he had thought he had left behind. in time, the family faces fears and dreams they had held onto for so long. One of the many things I admired about this book is the way Deb uses Bangla without transliterating the language. It is rare and beautifully done. The characters have so much depth that you almost wish they were real people you could call. This is a feel-good novel that will make you want to spend more time with your family!

A remarkable lady. Well worth the read.: Although having read Hidden Figures and seen the movie I was interested in reading Katherine Johnson’s Memoir to hopefully capture some of the more personal insights that might have been left out of the Hidden Figures story. Her book does that and shows what a life purposely lead could achieve in spite of the vagaries of life and the obstacles that are inevitably encountered. And she had more than her share.
Her recounting of her days and work at NASA Langley both during and after the early space work on getting to the moon are appreciated. This is something that the movie focuses on, but she is careful to point to the realities and where the producers took “artistic liberty” to compress the story. I especially liked her comment, repeatedly made, was that her focus was on her work and getting the job done to the best of her abilities, regardless of attitudes of some towards her race and gender. As a former employee there, I found that “getting the job done” was the dominant attitude of most of the employees I knew. Race and gender were not an issue for most, but there are always exceptions. And as she pointed out, for most of those, she educated them to the world she lived in and almost always they understood what they hadn’t before. Needless to say, her work was outstanding and established not only her legacy, but for those who would follow her.
Well worth the read.

review:
Well worth the read for the very personal story it tells.: Like many of our original Astronauts, Leland grew up in a small town. Although Lynchburg, Virginia made not have the small town culture that many of those Astronauts experienced, the community that he grew up in certainly exhibited many of those same traits. It is difficult to say what in that environment contributes to their later drive and success, Leland’s book attempts to do so from his perspective. He came from a supportive family and many of his qualities that would serve him well throughout his life were imparted by his parents. His life’s journey, as with most people, involved overcoming obstacles that he encountered and he talks about them here. In addition to what most people face he had to overcome race issues that others did not. He addresses this throughout his book.
I met Leland at NASA Langley when his Branch Head sent him over to assist in the assessment of the impact of some advanced technologies on the supportability of the future reusable vehicle concepts we were considering. This assessment is almost never done during the development of new technologies. I remember the very earnest and thoughtful effort that he put in to provide me his reasoned opinions on these technologies, and I was so impressed by that meeting that the memory of it stuck with me over the years. This was at a time I knew nothing of his background and it would only be years later that I learned of his having been an NFL player and of his having become an Astronaut. I was not surprised.
His book did surprise me though with so much that I did not know about him and the frankness and self assessment with which he presented it. The organization of the book seems to take you through the memories of his life as if he is talking with you, and as we all tend to do to jump back and forth in time that sometimes can be confusing to the reader. But he always returns to his themes of never give up and the second chances that brings into your life. He also wants to make sure to give credit to those who helped him achieve his dreams which is certainly good, but at times carried to a fault. His book, as with other Astronaut’s stories, provides the story of the person I did not know. If you follow the space program, or if you just follow personal achievements, the book is well worth the read.

history: B00SI02EQC 0393339912 B003G93ZCM 0061824739 1478722916 B000FCKGWK B07LD61F2W B00BH0VPS8 B08G1MTFMS B01L6RD3SG
review:
Very revealing of the science and technology as well as the character of those involved.: The attempts to develop a method improved on astronomical observations and developed techniques by Galileo to measure longitude that while they could not be used at sea vastly improved the ability of land surveyors and cartographers to map the earth for the first time with a degree of accuracy provided by his technique to measure longitude. Not much changed from that time for over several hundred years, till John Harrison took interest in the problem.
One degree of longitude equals 4 minutes of time at the equator, but the distance between longitudinal lines goes from 68 miles at the equator to 0 at the poles. Each fifteen degrees of longitude represents an hour of time difference. So in order to know how far one had traveled from his starting point, it was necessary to know the instantaneous time difference between that point and the time of the location he had traveled to.
Some beneficial side consequences of the search for the ability to use the stars, planets and the moon included the first accurate determination of the weight of the Earth, the distance to the stars, and in a recognition and measurement of the speed of light by Danish Astronomer Ole Roemer in 1676 using the Paris Observatory.
Without the ability to accurately measure longitude, many ships and lives were being lost, so the British Parliament created the Longitude Act in 1714 with a prize of 20,000 Pounds, for a “Practicable and Useful” means of determining longitude.
Harrison ultimately claimed his rightful monetary reward in 1773 nearly forty years after his first clock met that criteria in 1736. His desire to make improvements in his design resulted in 3 more clocks, each with ground-breaking improvements, before his final timepiece, now referred to as a chronometer, was submitted. In the intervening years, a number of adversaries came forth to try to claim the prize using astronomical measurements and progressively rewriting the criteria his timepieces had to meet. This book is the story of that battle. In addition the author weaves into much of the history that contributed advancements that took place over those years.
Very revealing of the science and technology developed during that period as well as revealing of the character of some who made significant contributions to the progress of the sciences, but let the lure of money and or fame lead them to take unethical actions. Very much worth the read.

review: Good overview of the era.  Many factual errors.: The author says  “First and foremost, American Moonshot is a work of U.S. presidential history (not space studies)”. And he was certainly right about that, (P467) but he waits to tell you that in the Acknowledgements at the end of the book.  I certainly was misled by the title!  Having worked for NASA and grown up during this time period, it was, for the most part, a very good walk through of that era.  As a good historian Brinkley does give the historical precedent leading up to the Apollo 11 landing on the moon, as well as world events that were occurring at the times President Kennedy was having to make tough decisions about the NASA programs relative to this country’s responses to them.  As the author points out, decisions were made due to international events, and could not always be made clear to the public.  A case relevant to our own times.  Brinkley does a good job of this.  But what I cannot understand is how an historian of Brinkley’s reputation could make so many errors in facts and timing of the space program as other readers have pointed out.  For that reason, I caution the reader who chooses this book.
Beautiful: Oh my ❤️ - what an incredible true story picture book. Such value to be found in a little house!

There are thousands of mysteries better than this!: This "mystery" is nothing to write home about! Boring, boring, and boring.  Characters never fleshed out. Author embarrassed Native Americans by including them in this "mystery".  Shame on him!  Do not bother yourself reading this book...

Copyright 2004, so not terribly current. OK, but not nearly as good as Homicide by David Simon.: This book is a collection of newspaper articles written by Connelly in the 1990's. They are of some historical interest, especially those on LAPD "rogue" police activities. David Simon's "Homicide: A Year on the Killing Streets" is an infinitely more satisfying journal of big city policing during this period.

Unexpected: This is an amazing book. One of the best books i have read in a long time - and i read a lot. There are so many twists, turns and surprises. I was totally captivated. Extremely creative and interesting. I think it is a must read.
Good book: For me, this book is ok but not great. There were parts i really liked and thought the momentum was rising but it actually did not. Still enjoyed reading but not one of my favorites.
Hauntingly Excellent: One of my favorites. Thought this would be a relaxing bookstore story but it was much more. Recommend for a “different” kind of read. Thoroughly enjoyed it. Very creative too.

Farming: Extremely important topic and easy reading. Although not overly easy. Again, another very important topic that i hope people start reading about and think about the hard work and toil of our farmers.
Compelling: Another attention getting book. Some real twists and turns that makes the brain churn. Great read. I read it in a few days.
1960’s: I can relate to the 60’s. Girls and women’s issues. And here we are.
Super Interesting: This book should and will change your mind about the grocery world. Not in a good way either.
Beautiful!: Growing up as a Cowgirl, this book depicts the way of life perfectly.
Boring: This was one of the most boring books i have read in a long while. I was so looking forward to it but so bored by it. I would say he droned on and on. Very disappointed.
Excellent: Nothing else to say - beautiful book.

Super Fun Read Aloud Packed with Yiddish words!: This book is funny and sweet and super fun to read aloud. The illustrations are so cute and laugh-out-loud hilarious. There is a narrator, but much of it is written as a back and forth dialogue, so you have to do voices to make it work - and it's important to get the voices just right! I love that it shows different parts of each character's personality, that it's okay to feel all the feelings, that friends bring out the best in each other. ⁠
⁠
The story is also packed with Yiddish words with a glossary in the back. After reading it just a couple times, my 4-year-old was already saying some of the words in other contexts (oh, she has shmutz). I love the way this book challenges the idea of what makes a book a "Jewish book" (or an Asian book, or an [insert marginalized identity here] book). It is not explicitly about identity or holidays or heroes, and it is still very proudly and joyfully a Jewish book. We need more books like this. Books that allow people from marginalized communities to be fully human and celebrated for it.⁠

Also, I noticed that someone left a pretty aggressive 1-starred review, which was changed from a 5-star review after an disagreement on social media with the author. I would invite folks to check out the author's social media pages to decide for themselves whether she supports or silences Jewish voices and/or issues.
⁠

Sweet story with deeper meaning: I love the beautiful watercolor illustrations and the sweet yet deceptively simple story of a shared father/son weekend ritual. Not too far beneath the surface of this tender story is the highlighting of the fluidity, complexity and beauty of life on the border. The depiction of life on both sides - so similar and filled with family and friends - makes readers wonder about the reasons behind maintaining the border.⁠
⁠
Carefully chosen phrases also contrast the policing of the border with the familial and shared lives of people on either side, including the stop to visit friends who have been stuck on the bridge for half a year waiting for asylum. This sweet visit to say hi and drop off supplies is a beautiful opening for discussions with young readers about border policies that keep out families looking for better lives. This book creates openings for deep discussions without hitting readers on the head with didactic teaching. They are all folded in subtly and sweetly into a story about every day life.

Full of bat facts and a powerful environmental message!: Not only is this story about environmental sustainability and community action, it is about the power young people have to create change. It's chock full of bat facts - I found myself exclaiming, "I didn't know that!" as I read and super cute illustrations. ⁠
⁠
I also love that it's about BATS. Though in popular culture they're often demonized and misunderstood and portrayed as creepy (hello, Halloween!), they are cute and play a vital role in the ecosystem! They're right up my daughter's alley - cute and kind of weird and seemingly villainous but actually very helpful. It's just the kind of thing she likes! So, she loves this book. She never lets me read the backmatter in any book (not even in the ones I've written) and she asks me to read the backmatter in this one!⁠

Sweet story of friendship in unexpected places: The author's note explains that El Cucuy is "also known as the Mexican Boogeyman" and "lives in many South American countries and takes on different forms. Generations of Latin American mothers and grandmothers have used El Cucuy as a tool to get children to behave" and it strikes terror into the hearts of children."⁠
⁠
This sweet story flips this narrative and shows a sweet friendship grow from an unexpected place. Through Ramón's relationship with El Cucuy, readers may recognize the fears and feelings that come with moving homes and schools, and they will find that strength and courage can take on many different forms. ⁠
⁠
My kids - especially my daughter - love this book! She woke up and asked me to read this to her first thing this morning. The illustrations are packed with color and so adorable.

Got me at piece of toast wants to be a dog :-): Honestly, this book got me at "piece of toast wants to be a dog." 😂 I died laughing at the idea and the book more than delivered! ⁠
⁠
Debut author/illustrator @sarah_s_hwang's adorably funny text and perfectly paired illustrations really will have you giggling on every page. And, if you dig deeper, you might see how the inspiration for Toasty came from her childhood experiences as an immigrant - finding close friends came from her own willingess to be herself. The art for Toasty came when Sarah saw a piece of toast that reminded her of the way she drew dogs as a child 😭😆⁠
McCatney's life and work in two lavish volumes: The two volumes are gorgeously made, and represent the ultimate source on Paul McCartney's life and work.
Ultimate Book about Burma campaign: This book is there most completer, best sourced, and best written account about an important but forgotten theater of World War II.
Sweeping History: The book's scope/coverage is ambitious.
Exceptionally Interesting: The lives and fates of extinct creatures come into sharp focus in this stunning book.
Excellent edition.: I found the Larrington translation to be very readable and the introductory material and notes to be instructive and helpful.
Excellent edition.: Informative, detailed, and easy to read; a useful addition to the history of the campaign.

The Founding Fathers did Not Gather to Sign the Declaration of Independence on the 4th of July.: The Sacrifices of Our Founding Fathers were numerous. Some lost their lives. Some lost their possessions, and some lost their riches. They gave all that they could to save a land where men could live free. Once we lose freedom, it is extremely difficult to gain it back.

Hayley Mills Child Star: I grew up watching Hayley Mills's movies on the Disney channel. Hayley began working an actress in a movie called "Tiger Bay" with her father. Disney discovered her for that movie and wanted her for the part of "Pollyanna." Hayley discusses her experience starting acting, her show business family, and signing a contract with Disney. I never knew her Dad was part of the entertainment business.
Hayley goes into detal about experiences working with Disney and actually getting to know Walt Disney. As she got older she comments it was difficult working with Disney because she wanted to work on more adult movies. She wanted to star in "Lolita" and other movies that were considered inappropriate for her to star in.
Fans of her Disney movies will enjoy reading about "Pollyanna", "Parent Trap", and her other Disney movies.
I didn't like reading about her relationship with her ex husband and how it turned out sour. The rest of the book was mainly about her troubled marriage. I would have preferred that she talk about the movies and TV shows she made as an adult. I remember seeing "Parent Trap 2" and the other sequels as a child. She also starred in the TV series that became Saved by the Bell.
The chapters of Hayley's book also are really long. She should have made her chapters shorter. It seemed like she wanted to take a chapter and talk about a certain movie or event, but it made the book longer than it was.

I adore this book: This is a lovely book for any thoughtful person. I keep it by my bed and read some at night and it makes me laugh and smile and feel better about my inner life. I have purchased 4 copies to give as gifts and plan on getting many more. Its brilliant.
Don't listen to the negative reviews: I was hesitant to buy this due to the top reviews, but it's an excellent book. I guess it takes a certain type of person to get it.

Not my usual genre: Generally, I choose thrillers as my choice for reading.  But somehow I noticed this title and couldn’t put it down after speeding through the sample. Initially, I thought the plot device was hokey and lazy but it served to provide a rich understanding of how this family and perhaps a lot of families function with all of the dysfunctional paths of their lives.  The book is light and optimistic which is exactly what we all need right now.
Great book!: This book was well written. Stacy did a great job. Good story line, great characters, moved along well,suspenseful & I didn’t want to put it down! Recommend it!!!
Great book!: First book I ‘ve read of hers. Loved it! Great characters & story line! I look forward to rest of books in this series!
LOVED!!!: Wish this Queenstown Series didn’t end! Fell in love with the characters! Great Series!

Loving this Series!!: First time for me for Jean
Grainger books. Will read more! Love her style, characters & setting for this series!

A beautiful story of sibling love, grief and redemption: I finished The Beached Ones by Colleen M. Story, racing through the last third of the book without putting it down. It’s the story of Daniel Shepard, a stunt rider whose last stunt --before the book opens-- apparently ended in disaster. Daniel finds himself in Harlan, Iowa, a short distance from Butte, Montana, his hometown where he last performed. He doesn’t remember how he got to Iowa, or why he’s there without his keys, wallet or watch.
All he knows is that he has five days to get to San Francisco where he has promised to meet his younger brother, Tony. Daniel —who just might become one of my favorite characters of 2022— is determined to keep his promise to the younger brother he has always tried to protect from a life of abuse at home.
Story’s steady, confident pacing allows the reader to get acquainted with Daniel and with Jolene, his troubled ex-girlfriend, before being transported into an alternate reality which doesn’t, at all, seem a stretch by the time we get there.
The Beached Ones is masterfully crafted and plotted to explore sibling bonds, grief, love, and redemption before harrowing revelations lead to an explosive ending. A thoroughly absorbing and thought-provoking read. A definite 5-stars.
Mehhh: This book is just okay. Kind of redundant. Not very well written.
As always a gripping tale: Daniel Silva keeps the pace moving. Plus you get invested in the characters. Great read. Look forward to the next book
Great first All on book: I loved the intrigue and the fast paced action. Jacqueline Devaroux was a great character. I have read other Allon books and wish she was in others

Gorgeous and emotional.: This book is so lovely. The writing drew me in from the first page, and Bertie is a heroine to root for, inquisitive yet empathetic. She’s a painter in post-WWI England who gets her first commission to paint Castle Braemore, an earl’s country home. As soon as she arrives, she falls under the spell of the house, the grounds, and the people she finds there: the Earl of Wakeford, a reclusive and haunted war veteran, and his younger brother and sister. I fell completely under the spell of this book as well. It's got English country house energy, it's got 1920s Bright Young Things energy, and I don’t think it’s a spoiler to say things get romantic. Loved it!

Sweet, but not too sweet: If you’re looking for a comfort read, this is it. Sampson doesn’t shy away from sad topics - June, her very sympathetic protagonist, is grieving the loss of her mother and has a difficult time dealing with social situations - but the arc of the story is triumphant. What could be better than a bunch of misfits coming together as a community to save their town library? It’s sweet but not saccharine, with delightfully eccentric characters, gently snarky observations, and one particular shopping scene that made me laugh-cry, and June’s growth into a more confident and happy person is as satisfying as the library plot.

Sharp, funny, and always entertaining.: I loved this novel not so much for the whodunit twist near the end (though it’s a good one!) as for the smaller, character driven surprises throughout. You may think you know what a psychopath is, but the participants in the study that sets up the premise of Never Saw Me Coming are as individual as any other human being, and the book is a fascinating look inside their heads. I’m glad Kurian made the choice to write multiple POVs. This book is many things: a campus thriller, a character study, psychological suspense, feminist revenge fantasy. It also performs the extremely difficult trick of making a manipulative, selfish, scheming character not only sympathetic but...likable? OK, maybe not. But absolutely entertaining, and if you’re not rooting for Chloe at least part of the time, you’re probably a better person than I am.

(Note: apparently there’s been some confusion that this book is YA. It is, emphatically, not. Teenagers can definitely read it! I mean, I read Stephen King when I was 12 and I’m not warped (much). But CW for swears/violence/sex/immoral behavior without comeuppance.)

A sharp and twisty character study!: I love thrillers that are also character studies, and I love books where the twist makes you flip back and re-read certain scenes in their new light. MY SWEET GIRL is both of these, and it’s wonderful. Jayatissa turns the struggle narrative and the immigrant story on their heads with Paloma, the most sympathetic unlikable narrator I’ve read in a while. She’s angry, raw, abrasive - but in so much pain that you can’t help but empathize with her. Being inside her mind is claustrophobic, but her sharp, wryly funny observations make her relatable.

There’s plenty of overt eeriness (a disappearing corpse! A child who creepily sings “Que Sera Sera” over and over!) but some of the most unsettling elements are done with a subtlety that puts me in awe of Jayatissa’s talent. And the structuring of the twists leading to more twists blew me away. MY SWEET GIRL is an absorbing reading experience with a tremendous payoff.

Growing Young is the best book I’ve read on life extension and its implications: Sergey Young approaches longevity from a perspective of empathy to his reader. Unlike other books in this genre, Growing Young is a fast easy read that explains the key elements of how to think about this topic:

- Why we should consider living longer
- What technology already exists to extent our lives
- What technology is in active development and will emerge soon
- Longer horizon predictions about what’s coming
- Ethical and moral implications of what living longer might mean for our society
- A bonus chapter of what we can all do today (e.g. sleep better, diet, exercise)

Sergey is not a doctor or a technologist, but he literally puts his money where his mouth is by investing in the most promising longevity technology today. He also counts the major thinkers in this sphere as his close friends and advisors.

Personally, I have some skepticism in this field. This is why I enjoyed this book so much. Sergey explains all the elements in such a way that I feel 10x more informed than I was previously.

Such a fun journey! Almost Nabokov-esque: I was lucky enough to get an advanced copy of this great book. Written in the style of a fun tale (like Wilson’s Panorama City or great works by Zadie Smith and Andrew Sean Greer), the book isn’t quite what you expect.

The narrator meets an old friend in the lounge of JFK Airport. The old friend is now very rich and tells him a long tale. The book is the tale with the narrator jumping in every now and then. But as you keep reading you realize it’s not quite a straight ahead tale.

When you finish reading I bet you will go back and re-read parts again. It’s immensely compelling. Almost like great Nabokov novels where you realize every word had more meaning than you realized.

Strongly recommend!

Wait for it....: Though the novel has an interesting premise.  It really, really, really drags it out.  In fact, it's not until the final 10 pages or so that the author finally lets you know what he was hinting at all along.  Which makes this about 290 pages of boring teen drama and 10 pages of, "Hmmm, I guess that's kind of interesting."

A baby, a mystery, and Roscoe on the loose!: Tinkle is ready to pop, but not before getting one more mystery solved! Sarah Booth and the critters keep Tinkie from getting carried away while trying to figure out who is killing bad men. Sweetie Pie proves her loyalty again and Roscoe is his wild self. A fun visit with old friends from Zinnia and the joyful arrival of a much longed for heir.

history: B001FA0T28 B007679KEW B00NAAQ7LS B00A31UCE0 B00TE45IVO B00Y6RB1MO B00ONTR5CA B0099CW7OC B003M68UDI B01K6DXHVE B01DABYGIM B07MCZTJHZ
review: A long story!: This book was not the best true crime book I've ever read and it is not the worst. At times it seemed slow and it seemed to drag. Without wanting to give away the ending, I'll just say that as the final verdict  seemed farther and farther away I began to lose interest but the author successfully brought the ending together quickly. I would recommend it to other true crime buffs.

history: B001FA0T28 B007679KEW B00NAAQ7LS B00A31UCE0 B00TE45IVO B00Y6RB1MO B00ONTR5CA B0099CW7OC B003M68UDI B01K6DXHVE B01DABYGIM B07MCZTJHZ B0073H7UDI
review: A Good Read: This is a really good book. The horrific crime took place quite a while back but I had never heard about it. The author did a great job giving plenty of detail without making it seem too long or boring. It's hard to beige that a SON of such LOVING PARENTS could put a gun to their heads and then leave for a Hawaiian "honeymoon." It is a long and difficult story to tell and it was done perfectly in this book. It is a must read for true crime enthusiasts. You definitely won't be disappointed!

history: B001FA0T28 B007679KEW B00NAAQ7LS B00A31UCE0 B00TE45IVO B00Y6RB1MO B00ONTR5CA B0099CW7OC B003M68UDI B01K6DXHVE B01DABYGIM B07MCZTJHZ B0073H7UDI B004IWR3NS
review: Wow...do you think you can really hide murder?: Can anyone hide his wife's murder? Apparently Stephen Grant thinks that is possible. He squeezed the life out of her. He rolled her up in plastic. He drove around with her in the car and he cut her up into 14 pieces! THEN he pretended she had left her family on her own! Stephen Grant is a fool! An evil fool! At least that's my opinion. Read this book to see if it is your opinion of Stephen Grant. It's a great read!

Good for Newer and Younger Fantasy Readers: Shape-shifting flying lions in YA fantasy books. Sounds intriguing, right? And to me it was. I was curious as to how something like this could be done well in a YA storyline. Was I completely impressed with how this book was executed? Not really, sadly.

So we have three main characters in The Endless Skies, all with their own point-of-view chapters. First is Rowan, a headstrong Leonodai warrior-in-training; Callen, the boy who loves her; and Shirene, Rowan's older sister who works for the King. Because there were three POV characters, and none of their voices were particularly unique, it was very easy to get them mixed up and forget who we were following in each chapter. At least one POV should've been cut, maybe two. We got way too much information out of Shirene's chapters, due to her political role, that would have been better off coming as surprises to the primary character, Rowan. Then, plot elements could've been surprising to the reader as well. As for Callen, having a POV from a boy who has been rejected romantically by the main character is quite interesting, but since Rowan and Callen are in the same locations a lot of the time, theirs were the easier chapters to mix up.

Rowan herself isn't all that interesting or unique from other YA female fantasy characters, either. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but if you've read a lot of fantasy, this may not be the book for you. Because of the lack of difference in characters' inner voices and the lack of individuality of characters, this book read really young. I would recommend it for 12-14 year-olds, not upper YA readers.

The world building, while completely unique in the shapeshifting abilities, is just okay. There's not enough description to really connect readers with the locations, other magical shapeshifting creatures, or even the catastrophic things that are happening to the children of the land. Oh, and a major warning here for a disease that kills off kids. If you're at all tired of diseases or even triggered by diseases because of the world's current circumstances, do not read this book. I know that's one reason I just couldn't get into it, in combination with the stuff I mentioned earlier.

Despite the disease, the book is fast-paced, so readers can devour it pretty quickly if they're so inclined. And because it's not a complex magic system, and the characters have a rather modern dialect for a fantasy world, it's an easy book to give to new readers and not bog them down in complexity. Oh, but speaking of world-building, I was super confused as to why an entire magic system rests on the shoulders of a small child when the father is still alive and should have had magic as well. Maybe I missed something about this in the story, but I found it extremely odd that rescuing a baby was key to the entire Leonodai existence.

All in all, The Endless Skies is simply an okay read for those who have devoured fantasy books for many years. While, to a newbie, it may be something super enjoyable. I think if I handed this book to a sixth grader, they'd have a pretty good time.

*Note: I received a NetGalley ARC of this book to review from the publisher. This in no way affected my opinion/review.
Very cute!: This was very cute. I wish it had been a little longer, but I think it was still a fun read. It gave me Dumplin' mixed with Simon vs. the Homo Sapiens Agenda vibes.
Fitness Pete: My kiddo loves this cool cat. If it's a book with Pete, it's going to be read. He wants to do exercise and eat broccoli whenever he reads this so he can be healthy.

A Meaningful Stab at Redefining Business Objectives: Gelles’ thoroughly reports on the impact of prioritizing profits and focusing on quarterly finance and operational results.

His findings will lead business minds to reconsider the importance of their role in society, and develop a necessary sense of longer term accountability for the decisions they make. As Paul Polman writes, “Profits should *not* come from creating the world’s problems, but by solving them.”

As much as a well researched evisceration of Welch’s approach to business Gelles provides ample evidence that stakeholder collaboration and pursuing long term objectives, over shareholder demands and short term profit, is good for economic prosperity.

Gelles makes it clear to the most ardent of capitalists (like myself) that Welch’s leadership and well documented fixations has had a negative net impact on economies, communities, families and the planet.

GE under Welch made (or at least demonstrated) massive profits, yet Gelles’ deep research and patient presentation of the wider impact of Welch’s leadership beyond GE provides a longer term analysis that is critical to consider as attention spans are reduced to tweets, announcements and daily news cycles which prioritize short term and jeopardize long term results.

In short, Gelles’ research unequivocally presents a case that the approaches that Welch espoused accelerate inequality and ultimately threaten the sustainability of economic prosperity, societies, and the planet.

I agree with others that mention this book would be a good text for business school professors to incorporate. I will reach out to IESE professors that will appreciate the research that conclusively supports the approach to business our Business School encourages.

A Tremendous Account of Who and What is Important: I had the good fortune of meeting Chief Pfeifer when he came to the Kennedy School at Harvard to study. (I have spent 38 years in the fire service).

Joe Pfeifer is a special person, a consummate gentleman, and a fierce leader of the men and women under his command, both in times of crisis and those of routine firehouse responsibilities.

This book introduces the reader to the life of a firefighter, on the front lines as well as the firehouse routines, that help nurture and develop men and women into the greatest job going.

His easy to read writing style brings the reader into the back seat of Battalion One as he witnesses and responds to the greatest challenge the fire service has ever encountered. The reader can feel themselves in the lobby, at the Fire Command Center as crucial decisions are made and orders are given and obeyed without reservation.

As tragic a day was for the FDNY on September 11, 2001, it was also a day when the department stood tall and effected the greatest high-rise rescue operation in the history of the fire service. That fact is often lost on many people.

Chief Pfeifer takes us beyond September 11th, through the grieving process as he lost his own brother, Lt. Kevin Pfeifer that day. A supreme sacrifice that no doubt weighed heavily on him as he gave an order to his brother to take his company up into the compromised tower to save lives.

This book is highly recommended reading for many, but I think in particular a lot of our young people, high-schoolers would benefit from reading this book to realize the traits of sacrifice and dedication are critically important and perhaps needed more than ever today!

Summer Feel Good RomCom: Hook Line & Sinker—book reviews
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5

I recently saw a review that said “the problem with a good book is you want to finish it, but you don’t want it to end”.

That is exactly how I feel about this book. The Bellinger sisters…man AMAZING! This book can be a stand alone but I recommend reading them in order. I loved the Westport, fishing town setting. Gave me all the summer vacation feels, and made me want to travel. I really like and felt connected to Hannah when I was reading the first book, so I knew I was going to love this one. Hannah is more down to earth, knows who she is and what she wants, but is afraid to go for it due to imposter syndrome. I related to her so much, and Hannah and fox’s banter was 🤌🏼

It is a perfect slow burn, friends-lovers romance book that were such a great . This was the perfect break from my usual fantasy books that I needed.

You can find me channeling my inner Hannah, & listening to playlist that match my books 🎧

This book was so unique. Unlike any other book I have read before. Sue to a center old curse nightmares comes to life on the new moon, and as dream wardens it is Clem and her fathers job to destroy them. This stand-alone had both strength of the characters as well as an amazing magic system/world building. This book has amazing enemies to lovers romance, perfect plot twists, and mystery’s that keep you guessing up until the end. Clem is so charming and witty. You will easily fall in love with this MC.

Wanted to Love it- just a little slow: The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue-book review
⭐️⭐️⭐️/5

“𝔸𝕟𝕕 𝕟𝕠 𝕞𝕒𝕥𝕥𝕖𝕣 𝕙𝕠𝕨 𝕕𝕖𝕤𝕡𝕖𝕣𝕒𝕥𝕖 𝕠𝕣 𝕕𝕚𝕣𝕖, 𝕟𝕖𝕧𝕖𝕣 𝕡𝕣𝕒𝕪 𝕥𝕠 𝕥𝕙𝕖 𝕘𝕠𝕕𝕤 𝕥𝕙𝕒𝕥 𝕒𝕟𝕤𝕨𝕖𝕣 𝕒𝕥 𝕟𝕚𝕘𝕙𝕥.”

I went into this book with very high hopes and expectations just based off what I have heard about it. The writing was great, and I will definitely be picking up more books by V.E Schwab.

Now for the review…..(do not hate me)
I wanted to love it soooo bad, but I just could not get into it. It was a beautiful story, and it did suck me in right away. I loved learning about Addie and seeing where her story started, and how she lived through major events in history. Then we got to pages 100-300 and I was just lost. A lot of back and forth between times and I just couldn’t keep up. It was also just a little slow for my taste,but I kept pushing through because of how much others liked it. It tended to be predictable at times, but that is never a bad thing in my opinion. Now we get to the end and I was sucked right back in and sent on an emotional roller coaster. I ended the book being team Henry, love you bb 😘

Overall I enjoyed reading this book, it just was a little slow in the middle for me. I cannot wait to read more by this author

READ THIS NOOWWWWW: Lady of Ashes -book review
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5

“ᴛʜɪꜱ ᴡᴀꜱ ɪᴛ, ᴛʜɪꜱ ᴡᴀꜱ ʜᴇʀ ᴄʜᴇᴄᴋᴍᴀᴛᴇ. ᴛʜɪꜱ ɪꜱ ᴡʜᴀᴛ ᴡᴏᴜʟᴅ ʙʀᴇᴀᴋ ʜᴇʀ”

“𝕿𝖍𝖆𝖙 𝖜𝖆𝖘 𝖏𝖚𝖘𝖙 𝖙𝖍𝖊 𝖇𝖊𝖌𝖎𝖓𝖓𝖎𝖓𝖌. 𝕾𝖔𝖔𝖓 𝖙𝖍𝖊 𝖊𝖓𝖙𝖎𝖗𝖊 𝖜𝖔𝖗𝖑𝖉 𝖜𝖎𝖑𝖑 𝖇𝖊 𝖔𝖓 𝖋𝖎𝖗𝖊”

Welcome back to the wonderful world of Scarlett. This book picked up right where book 2 left off, and if you thought Sorin was possessive before just WAIT until you read this book.

I love that this book really dives deep into the history surrounding this story, and gives us more insight into the world and the supporting characters. We had not gotten that yet in the two previous books, so this was an amazing addition. We also get to know more about the areas surrounding the fire court and the royals who live in them.

This book shows us that our FMC is not perfect, and she does make mistakes. Scarlett is left to face the consequence of her actions from book 2, as well as deal with some demons from her past. Some people are not who they seems, and surprises are around every corner. I thought I knew where the author was going with the plot and then BAM it changed. This is truly one of my favorite worlds to ever be written.

Also Melissa thanks for that ending…I will be ruined until book 4 comes out 🥲(in the best way possible). I am so thankful that I was chosen to be apart of Melissa’s ARC and street team. She is a wonderful author and person, love being able to support and cheer her on!

*this is not a Tawlyn stan account and any varying opinions will not be accepted*

Such a great read!: A legacy of storms and starlight-book review
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️✨/5

“𝐼𝒻 𝓉𝒽𝒾𝓈 𝒾𝓈 𝓌𝒽𝒶𝓉 𝒾𝓉 𝒻𝑒𝑒𝓁𝓈 𝓁𝒾𝓀𝑒 𝓉𝑜 𝒷𝑒 𝒸𝓊𝓇𝓈𝑒𝒹…𝒸𝓊𝓇𝓈𝑒 𝒶𝓁𝓁 𝑜𝒻 𝒾𝓉…𝓂𝓎 𝓂𝒾𝓃𝒹, 𝓂𝓎 𝒷𝑜𝒹𝓎, 𝓂𝓎 𝒽𝑒𝒶𝓇𝓉. 𝐼𝓉’𝓈 𝒶𝓁𝓁 𝓎𝑜𝓊𝓇𝓈.”

This book was so good, I could not put it down. It is very fast paced, with interesting characters and I would say a very unique world. This books revolves around the characters and that is what drives the plot.

I LOVED Zylah(still don’t think I’m pronouncing it right😂). I love when we get to learn all about the world through our MC’s eyes with them. Zylah is a strong, bold female and I can just picture where her character will go in the following books. After tragedy strikes Zylah finds a hot mysterious fae male, who leads her to a new city and her own found family. Ummm also animal companions, she has an owl names Kopi. All I could picture the whole book was this adorable little owl flying onto her shoulder and chirping. I think there will be more to Kopi in the coming books. This book will bring out so many feelings:happiness, sadness, laughter, frustration! This book reminded me a lot of Defy the Night in a way, but also totally different 😂

This book had me left wondering and with so many questions, and I cannot wait to pick up right where I left off in this world. 4 1/2 stars soley because I just wanted more plot answers, which I think will come in future books.

This book includes:
🗡love triangle in the making?
🗡evil king
🗡fae & other mythical creatures
🗡political struggles
🗡found families
🗡hidden identities(hinting to it)
🗡ANIMAL COMPANIONS
🗡spice 🌶🌶
🗡first in the series

This is definitely a book all fantasy lovers will enjoy!

MUST READ OF 2022!!!: The Sunken City-book review
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5

“This knowledge should terrify me. I have never needed a person like this before. It goes against everything Omar taught me- to be strong, to be independent, to never reply upon someone-else for my own well-being.”

“It’s fine to not be fine” 
This was an mesmerizing fantasy book that combines witches, mermaids, pirates, Atlantis, the little mermaid ALL into one book. This book is a must read for all fan of daughter of a pirate king!

The way Emma builds her world is just amazing, and it had me captivated from the beginning. I felt like I was in the story and learning about The Sunken City along with our FMC. The world is full of amazing magic in a new and unique way. The use of witches, mermaids, ancient gods, pirates, etc was all new and refreshing.

I loved Amare, our FMC, as well as her two best friends. I loved seeing their relationships grow and their banter was just so fun! Amare is snarky, independently, strong, and badass. She doesn’t let anyone tell her what she can and cannot do. Also the lost princess troupe is done very well in this book, and w unique in its own way!

If you know me I usually HATE love triangles(except for these twisted bonds) and this book. Holy cow can you say Salvatore brothers vibes 🥵🥵🥵. We have Fin and good brother who follows the rules and does what he believes is right. Then you have Lukas- the morally gray, mysterious brother who happens to be very handsome! Can confidently say I am not team one or another right now, but we love a morally gray man!!

The authors goal is to have this whole trilogy published in 2022. Right now Books 1 &2 are out, with book three coming in December!

This is one of my top 2022 reads—>I highly recommended this book.

Love books about books!: The Roughest Draft-book review
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️✨/5

“Forever is about reaching into the future, into years far away and unknowable. Always is about every second of every day. It's as far reaching as forever, it just starts sooner.”

“...in the end, the best part of a love story isn’t having it. It’s getting to keep writing it”

I went into this book completely blind, after seeing it at my local library and thinking it looked pretty 😂 .Now I have to admit I read this a day because it was due back to my library and I ran out of renewals, but oh my gosh I LOVED it. I am a sucker for books about people who write books. I would say it’s comparable to beach reads but not as sworn and romance worthy. This book is definitely YA. It was angsty, miscommunication troupe, touched on mental health topics.

This was such a good contemporary romance. It gave me slow burn BUT also second chance romance vibes. This story is about two another’s who co-write stories together until suddenly one day Kat “retires” from writing after a one of their mysterious fight. 4 years later she is contacted because the two authors have one last book left in their contract they need to compete.

I love the way the authors wove in Nathan’s and Kats past and present through out the stories with flash backs. I love that this book was co written by a newly married couple, which brought a lot of realism to our main characters.

This was a great summer romance read ☀️❤️

Love teacher FMC!!: The Royals Next Door-book review
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5

“You think I won’t protect you?”
“It’s not your job..”
“It doesn’t matter..I’ve now made it my job”

This was a great fresh, fun summer read. Not going to lie I was drawn to the cover and the fact that it was about a second grade teacher…relatable 😂.

This book has great slow burn and the build up is perfect! The two main characters had great banter as well as some of the side characters. I would occasionally be shouting at the characters “VOICE YOUR FEELINGS”, but isn’t that most rom coms! By the time I was half way through this book I could not put it down. I want to make sure to keep this review spoiler free, but it is far better the last half of the book. I would say this is a book with spice in it, but not overly spicy.

This book was so interesting, the side characters gave me prince Harry and Megan Markel vibes. It also had a unique approach to mental illness( board line personality disorder, PTSD, anxiety disorder,etc.) I would classify this book more in the enemies to lovers/forbidden love section of books.

Also the last chapters all about self discovery, standing up for yourself, igniting your inner rebel and standing for what you love and believe in….even if it’s romance novels!

This a fiery, thought provoking, powerful and fun read for the summer!

Fun unique read!: The Inheritance Game-book review
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5

“𝔼𝕧𝕖𝕣𝕪𝕥𝕙𝕚𝕟𝕘’𝕤 𝕒 𝕘𝕒𝕞𝕖, 𝔸𝕧𝕖𝕣𝕪 𝔾𝕣𝕒𝕞𝕓𝕤. 𝕋𝕙𝕖 𝕠𝕟𝕝𝕪 𝕥𝕙𝕚𝕟𝕘 𝕨𝕖 𝕘𝕖𝕥 𝕥𝕠 𝕕𝕖𝕔𝕚𝕕𝕖 𝕚𝕟 𝕥𝕙𝕚𝕤 𝕝𝕚𝕗𝕖 𝕚𝕤 𝕚𝕗 𝕨𝕖 𝕡𝕝𝕒𝕪 𝕥𝕠 𝕨𝕚𝕟.”

“𝒲𝑒 𝒶𝓇𝑒𝓃’𝓉 𝓃𝑜𝓇𝓂𝒶𝓁. 𝒯𝒽𝒾𝓈 𝓅𝓁𝒶𝒸𝑒 𝒾𝓈𝓃’𝓉 𝓃𝑜𝓇𝓂𝒶𝓁, 𝒶𝓃𝒹 𝓎𝑜𝓊’𝓇𝑒 𝓃𝑜𝓉 𝒶 𝓅𝓁𝒶𝓎𝑒𝓇, 𝓀𝒾𝒹. 𝒴𝑜𝓊’𝓇𝑒 𝓉𝒽𝑒 𝑔𝓁𝒶𝓈𝓈 𝒷𝒶𝓁𝓁𝑒𝓇𝒾𝓃𝒶—𝑜𝓇 𝓉𝒽𝑒 𝓀𝓃𝒾𝒻𝑒.”

This is exactly the break I needed between fantasy and rom coms. I felt a slump coming on because I hadn’t found a new book that surprised me, this book did just that. I was sucked in from the beginning, it was so different than any book I had read.

I enjoyed Avery has the FMC, she never let all the money or wrath go to her head and stayed true to herself. I loved how each brother had their own mystery and I didn’t see them coming. All their personalities were so different, and learning about their childhoods were so interesting. If you have read this are you Jameson or Grayson???

This whole book had me saying why, how, WHAT!!!! It kept me on my toes in the best way. It was a really good YA mystery, and I have already started book two!

The book itself was also really well written, I liked the shorter chapters. Only thing that would make it better would be more Max(Avery’s BFF) and maybe multiple POVs from the brothers!!?!

I highly recommended this book to all!

NEW FAVORITE SERIES!: The Fallen Witch-book review
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5

“𝙸𝚝’𝚜 𝚊 𝚟𝚎𝚛𝚢 𝚛𝚊𝚛𝚎, 𝚟𝚎𝚛𝚢 𝚋𝚎𝚊𝚞𝚝𝚒𝚏𝚞𝚕 𝚝𝚑𝚒𝚗𝚐 𝚏𝚘𝚛 𝚝𝚠𝚘 𝚙𝚎𝚘𝚙𝚕𝚎 𝚝𝚘 𝚏𝚊𝚕𝚕 𝚒𝚗 𝚕𝚘𝚟𝚎 𝚒𝚗 𝚎𝚡𝚊𝚌𝚝𝚕𝚢 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚜𝚊𝚖𝚎 𝚖𝚘𝚖𝚎𝚗𝚝.
𝙼𝚘𝚛𝚎 𝚘𝚏𝚝𝚎𝚗 𝚝𝚑𝚎𝚗 𝚗𝚘𝚝 𝚕𝚘𝚟𝚎 𝚍𝚘𝚎𝚜𝚗’𝚝 𝚑𝚊𝚙𝚙𝚎𝚗 𝚒𝚗 𝚑𝚊𝚛𝚖𝚘𝚗𝚢.

“𝑰 𝒂𝒎 𝒑𝒐𝒘𝒆𝒓. 𝑰 𝒂𝒎 𝒅𝒂𝒓𝒌𝒏𝒆𝒔𝒔. 𝑨𝒏𝒅 𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒓𝒆 𝒊𝒔 𝒏𝒐𝒕𝒉𝒊𝒏𝒈 𝑰 𝒄𝒂𝒏𝒏𝒐𝒕 𝒅𝒐”

I have completely fallen in love with this world. Not only are the outside of the books beautiful, Emma does such and amazing job of world building and making you feel like you are in the story.

I LOVE this series. The magic. The angst. The love triangle. The Salvatore..I mean mason…brothers! THE CLIFFHANGER! It was all sooo good.

“𝑳𝒐𝒗𝒆 𝒂𝒏𝒅 𝑰’𝒎 𝒏𝒐𝒕 𝒕𝒂𝒍𝒌𝒊𝒏𝒈 𝒂𝒃𝒐𝒖𝒕 𝒑𝒖𝒑𝒑𝒚 𝒍𝒐𝒗𝒆, 𝒉𝒆𝒓𝒆. 𝑰 𝒂𝒎 𝒕𝒂𝒍𝒌𝒊𝒏𝒈 𝒂𝒃𝒐𝒖𝒕 𝒓𝒆𝒂𝒍 𝒍𝒐𝒗𝒆, 𝒕𝒉𝒆 𝒌𝒊𝒏𝒅 𝒚𝒐𝒖 𝒕𝒓𝒂𝒗𝒆𝒍 𝒂𝒄𝒓𝒐𝒔𝒔 𝒕𝒉𝒆 𝒐𝒄𝒆𝒂𝒏𝒔 𝒇𝒐𝒓.”

Book 2 picks up right where book 1 left off, and we are thrown right back into this amazing world. The writing in these books is so well down, I mean the pirate jargon…it felt so real. The chapters are short and fast paced, which kept me up all night having to know what happens next.

Amare is growing and finding herself. She is not the same pirate we met in book 1, and is on the journey to except who she really is. I cannot get enough of her friendships with Cora and Shoa, they are just perfect and really help
make the book amazing.

“𝙍𝙚𝙖𝙡 𝙡𝙤𝙫𝙚 𝙘𝙤𝙢𝙚𝙨 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙣𝙤 𝙨𝙩𝙧𝙞𝙣𝙜𝙨 𝙖𝙩𝙩𝙖𝙘𝙝𝙚𝙙｡ 𝙉𝙤 𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙩𝙞𝙣𝙜𝙚𝙣𝙘𝙞𝙚𝙨｡ 𝙔𝙤𝙪 𝙙𝙤𝙣’𝙩 𝙝𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙩𝙤 𝙘𝙝𝙚𝙘𝙠 𝙘𝙚𝙧𝙩𝙖𝙞𝙣 𝙗𝙤𝙭𝙚𝙨 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙢｡ 𝙔𝙤𝙪 𝙙𝙤𝙣’𝙩 𝙝𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙩𝙤 𝙘𝙝𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙚 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙢｡”

I LOVED getting to see inside Skullhaven and getting to meet a whole new band of characters. I would love to see more of them in book 3, as well as more history on Skullhaven. I about cried happiness when we got to see Omar and his crew again, and his reaction to her..PERFECTION.

Great Summer Murder Mystery!: The Guest List-book review
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5

This book was so interesting and different from what I usually read. My husband and I were driving to Chicago and needed and audiobook, and sadly he doesn’t love fantasy like me. We agreed on this book and we both loved it.

It has one thing I usually stray away from and that is too many POV’s. I do think it worked in this book and helped you really understand the whole story and what was going on. It was easier for me with the audiobook, since the narrator changed with each character. This book is SLOW BURN and I’m not talking in the romance way. We are left completely in the dark as to what is going on until the end of the book. Now some of the twists I did guess before they happened bud two of them BLEW MY MIND, and I did not see them coming!

You do need to focus when reading this book, because any little detail mentioned could end up bigger something bigger later on. It is such a wide cast, with so many different personalities. I don’t want to give too much away, so you will have to read to find out the rest 🤣

All in all I don’t usually read mystery thrillers, so this was very new for me but I didn’t hate it! So here is to expanding into new

Emily Henry does it again!!: Book Lovers- book review
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5

“𝕄𝕒𝕪𝕓𝕖 𝕝𝕠𝕧𝕖 𝕤𝕙𝕠𝕦𝕝𝕕𝕟’𝕥 𝕓𝕖 𝕓𝕦𝕚𝕝𝕥 𝕠𝕟 𝕒 𝕗𝕠𝕦𝕟𝕕𝕒𝕥𝕚𝕠𝕟 𝕠𝕗 𝕔𝕠𝕞𝕡𝕣𝕠𝕞𝕚𝕤𝕖𝕤, 𝕓𝕦𝕥 𝕞𝕒𝕪𝕓𝕖 𝕚𝕥 𝕔𝕒𝕟’𝕥 𝕖𝕩𝕚𝕤𝕥 𝕨𝕚𝕥𝕙𝕠𝕦𝕥 𝕥𝕙𝕖𝕞 𝕖𝕚𝕥𝕙𝕖𝕣. ℕ𝕠𝕥 𝕥𝕙𝕖 𝕜𝕚𝕟𝕕 𝕥𝕙𝕒𝕥 𝕗𝕠𝕣𝕔𝕖𝕤 𝕥𝕨𝕠 𝕡𝕖𝕠𝕡𝕝𝕖 𝕚𝕟𝕥𝕠 𝕤𝕙𝕒𝕡𝕖𝕤 𝕥𝕙𝕖𝕪 𝕕𝕠𝕟’𝕥 𝕗𝕚𝕥 𝕚𝕟, 𝕓𝕦𝕥 𝕥𝕙𝕖 𝕜𝕚𝕟𝕕 𝕥𝕙𝕒𝕥 𝕝𝕠𝕠𝕤𝕖𝕟𝕤 𝕥𝕙𝕖𝕚𝕣 𝕘𝕣𝕚𝕡𝕤, 𝕒𝕝𝕨𝕒𝕪𝕤 𝕝𝕖𝕒𝕧𝕖𝕤 𝕣𝕠𝕠𝕞 𝕥𝕠 𝕘𝕣𝕠𝕨.”

Emily Henry take all my money. This book was perfection. A masterpiece. The banter was amazing, and not just between the two MC. I love the sister dynamic…now do I love that they call each other sissy….absolutely not BUT I digress.

“𝙸’𝚍 𝚜𝚊𝚢 𝙸’𝚖 𝚊 𝚛𝚎𝚊𝚕𝚒𝚜𝚝, 𝚋𝚞𝚝 𝚘𝚗𝚎 𝚠𝚑𝚘 𝚍𝚘𝚎𝚜𝚗’𝚝 𝚊𝚕𝚠𝚊𝚢𝚜 𝚞𝚗𝚍𝚎𝚛𝚜𝚝𝚊𝚗𝚍 𝚠𝚑𝚎𝚗 𝚠𝚑𝚊𝚝 𝚑𝚎’𝚜 𝚜𝚎𝚎𝚒𝚗𝚐 𝚒𝚜𝚗’𝚝 𝚛𝚎𝚊𝚕𝚒𝚜𝚖.”

I love Nora so much, she feels so real and CHARLIE FREAKING CHARLIE…swoon. I loved the premise of Nora being the girl who gets left behind in rom coms: she is career driven, ambitious, loves fancy cloths, and is proud of the life she is living. I love how Emily never punishes Nora for being ambitious and driven, but finds a man who meets her there.I also was cracking up at all the ridiculous stories of how all her boyfriend left for small town loves. Typical Halmark stuff 😂

“𝗜𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝗻 𝗶𝗰𝗲𝗱 𝗰𝗼𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗮 𝗯𝗼𝗼𝗸𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗼𝗻 𝗮 𝘀𝘂𝗻𝗻𝘆 𝗱𝗮𝘆? 𝗜 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻, 𝗮𝘀𝗶𝗱𝗲 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗵𝗼𝘁 𝗰𝗼𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗮 𝗯𝗼𝗼𝗸𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗼𝗻 𝗮 𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘆 𝗱𝗮𝘆.”

Emily Henry is one of my go-to comfort authors. I know I will be obsessed and completely fulfilled after reading her books. They are refreshing and unique and the only thing that could make it better would be multiple POVs. Because I need to be inside Charlie’s head!

Beach Reads is still my all time FAV, but this book was just a masterpiece.

The way I felt after reading this books reminds me of why I love reading so much!!

watch paint dry instead: i hated everything about this book, but most of all being trapped in a moving vehicle listening to it. and the reader was Scott Brick, who is terrific.  He could not save this turkey. If ever a book should have been abridged, it is this one. Come on, Lee Child.  Was the rent money due?  This one was  painful, not to mention full of really boring and unnecessary violence.  Plot stunk, characters silly and uninteresting  (mostly). Please, amazon readers,  move onto some really good stuff...... Michael Connelly and the beloved  Bosch.
Susan Mallory is a fantastic writer and never disappoints: Family is more than blood it is friends and this book definitely portrays that. Loved the book.

Not impressed: The whole story was about jealousy. It bored me from page 1 to the last page. I thought Pressfield was a better writer than that.  I'll have to think hard about spending any more money on his books from here on out. Very, very disappointed.

Cute holiday romance: I'd like to thank Netgalley and St. Martins Press for providing this ARC in exchange for an honest review.

This was such a cute holiday story that had a Hallmark movie written all over it. This is a second chance at love trope and the characters seem drawn to each other from the beginning. I love the little surprise twist at the end of the book. It made the story so much more. This is a feel good easy story that I really enjoyed. Perfect for the holidays!!

Loved It: Thank you Netgalley and St. Martin's Griffin for providing this ARC in exchange for an honest review.

I love Tijan and was so excited to receive book 2 in the Insiders Trilogy! Now I can't wait for the 3rd and last book to come out.

If you're into mafia billionaires then this series is a great one to pick up. It is pretty intense, lots of sexy scenes and steam, full of suspense and drama, and everything you would expect if you are a Tijan fan.

This is a continuation from book 1 so it's not one you can read out of order. Kash is just as steamy, protective and secretive as in the first book. Bailey is growing more with her new family, settling into school and finding her own strength and who she is. One of my favorite parts is when she took a part out the Chrissy (her mom) playbook and stood up to the villains in the story.

This book took a new turn with having Kash's grandfather show more of a presence in the book and Quinn making bail to terrorize the family again. The end left me so heart broken and on a major cliff hanger so if cliff hangers bother you it is a pretty big one.

Well done Tijan!!

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6
review:
AJ and The Crows - Drawn together by the darkness inside: Crooked Crows was my first book by Elena Lawson and it didn’t disappoint! This is a high school, enemies to lovers (not quite there yet) reverse harem romance with a heavy helping of gang violence/involvement.

Ava Jade recently lost her father and her wealthy aunt made her a deal that resulted in her being sent to Briar Hill to finish her last year of high school. She’s fierce, independent, takes no crap and definitely has some darkness in her that comes out to play when the situation calls for it. From the very beginning, she catches the attention of The Crows...for better or for worse. She’s drawn to these three guys and finds herself pulled into their lives.

The Crows...Corvus, Rook and Grey. They rule the school due to their adoptive father Diesel’s position as the leader of the Saints, but also due to their own intimidating natures. Corvus is the tall, strong, quiet, analytical planner, Rook is the ruthless fighter with demons of his own and addiction problems and Grey is the sweet talker who can charm your pants off and drive a getaway car like no one else. They all have dark pasts that we get little glimpses into during this book, but there’s so much more to learn. These three are adopted brothers - they work together as a unit to keep each other out of trouble and to keep things on track for Diesel and the Saints. They’re caught off guard and intrigued when Ava Jade comes to their school, refusing to bend to their will or back down from a fight.

Ava Jade and The Crows are inexplicably drawn to each other - I feel like their darkness calls to one another, making it hard to resist. Their relationships with each other are just starting to form in this book and I’m looking forward to seeing how it grows from being enemies who are attracted to each other to something else in the coming books.

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X
review:
Brutal Lies and TONS of revelations: Brutal Lies picks up right where Broke Trust ends and I was so ready to get more from Hadley, the Princes and Beck! This story is full of half truths, steam, violence, twists and some good old high school angst.

Hadley is a unique character - she’s really strong and independent, but she’s also pretty emotionally stunted after all the (still unknown) things she’s survived. She really has an opportunity to grow, make friends and start to trust people in this book and it was nice to see her be more like a normal high schooler, well as normal as things get at Pacific Prep. But, she’s still holding on to a few secrets...and they just might drive a wedge between her and the guys when they finally come out.

The Princes in this book are so much more likeable - Mason and West totally stole this story and made me love them. They’re so enthralled by Hadley and are trying to figure out how that works with all of them. Cam is all over the place in this book, rightfully so, but I’m really hoping he starts to pull it together soon because he’s going to start doing more harm to himself and everyone around him soon. Hawk is really growing on me and he’s quickly becoming my favorite - his relationship with Hadley is developing into something really sweet and unexpected and I’m here for it. The one I have my eye on is Beck - he seems to be Hadley’s biggest supporter and the one who understands her most, but he’s also hiding things from her and the Princes, so I have to wonder if there’s more he’s hiding.

This book is super steamy as Hadley’s opening herself up to relationships with some of the guys. They’re getting to know each other, dropping their walls, but they still have a long way to go. I’m really interested to see how all of these relationships continue to grow and change as more secrets are shared and darkness comes to light.

I can’t wait to see what revelations are made in book three - a lot came out here, but I’m still a little frustrated that I still have so many questions. There’s big things coming for all of these characters and I’m excited to see how it all works out.

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X B09CRLXWFJ
review:
The perfect finale and HEA for Bash + Kieran!: Sexy. Swoony. Sweet. Hot. Loving. Funny. Wonderful. So many words to describe Bash and Kieran’s story and none of them are exactly right. I loved this trilogy by Ella Frank and Brooke Blaine so much - it was unexpected but made me laugh, smile, cry and fall in love with these two characters even more with each new book.

Bash and Kieran had to make a big decision in this book and I was so curious to see where they would go with it. There wasn’t a wrong choice to make, but someone’s life was going to change completely once they did. I loved seeing them both together again in Chicago and in South Haven - their connection is so genuine and electric that you can feel it coming off the page. Even though things happened between them quickly, they developed such an intense relationship that only continues to grow as they experience more and more together. Things between them are just easy, like they’ve always been together, supporting each other and encouraging them to be the best version of themselves they can be. They’re so sexy, steamy and sweet together that I can’t get enough!

I seriously loved all of the character crossovers coming together - seeing part of the Chicagoverse and South Haven finally meet and form friendships of their own was the perfect way to close out this crossover series. I hadn’t thought of how everyone would fit together, but they meshed together like they’d always known one another and it made me so happy!

While I’m sad to say goodbye to Bash and Kieran, Truth or Dare was the perfect send-off for these two. I laughed, I cried and I loved every single second of their story!

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X B09CRLXWFJ B09GZR9P7Y
review:
Dark, emotional and so steamy!: Beyond Vengeance picks up right where Brutal Lies left off and it keeps getting better the deeper we get into Hadley’s story!

Even though she’s still keeping some secrets from the guys, Hadley really starts to open up in this book. She’s trusting the guys and her friends, starting to act like a normal teenager for once in her life and is finally feeling what it’s like to love and be loved. I’ve really enjoyed seeing her start to flourish in her new environment with the help of the guys and her friends - she’s still the badass character she was at the beginning of the series, just with some more emotional attachments.

I loved the guys in this book! Hawk really embraced his big brother/protector role and was so, so sweet with Hadley throughout this book. He absolutely killed me towards the end...so many feels! Cam finally got his crap together and started to be there for Hadley again - the two of them together are so cute. Mason continues to be the quiet but strong one in the group who is always working to support Hadley in everything she does. West’s dominant side really comes out to play in this book and I’m here for it! He takes control of the group when they’re together and it’s so steamy. And Beck...he’s been suffering in silence for so long and I’m glad he finally has people to confide in and share his burden. He has some hidden depths and I feel like we’re only now exploring them further. Oh and West and Beck finally getting to know each other? The absolute best!

All of their parents are some of the most infuriating and morally reprehensible characters I’ve ever read. Their lack of compassion for any of their kids and the way they use them as bargaining chips blows my mind. I can’t wait to see what happens to them because they deserve the absolute worst.
