The biggest thing I didn’t love was Hadley continually freezing up every time she was in Lawrence’s presence. After everything she’s been through and all the challenges she’s faced and overcome, her inability to control her situation is frustrating at times.

Be warned - there’s a cliffhanger at the end of this book and it’s pretty killer. My heart hurt for all of them in the last couple chapters and I can’t wait to see what R.A. Smyth has in store for us in Break Free!

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X B09CRLXWFJ B09GZR9P7Y B09HG2RZZR
review:
Sweet second chance romance in snowy Colorado: Eight Days of Christmas was such a sweet holiday rom-com with a little bit of angst to keep things interesting. If you’re a fan of Christina Lauren’s In a Holidaze or pretty much any movie on Hallmark during the holiday season, this one is definitely for you!

Isabella and Leo are childhood/high school sweethearts who went to different colleges after graduation, pulling them apart and keeping Isabella away from Pineridge, Colorado for ten years and breaking both of their hearts in the process. She’s headed back for the first time for her sister’s wedding on Christmas Day and happens to run into Leo, the last person she wants to see, on the way home. Izzy is struggling to figure out where she belongs after a breakup and is anxious about returning to Pineridge. She’s emotional and sensitive about her family’s remarks about her return and feels like she has to make up for lost time. Leo is finally starting to live his life, starting his own business and doing things for his own happiness. Izzy broke his heart and it’s taken years for him to feel better, but her reappearance has his feelings rushing right back.

I thought Izzy and Leo were really sweet together. There was clearly a connection there, even when they thought they hated each other, and I really liked seeing it grow into more as the truth finally started to come out. Their relationship development was believable and I loved how everything ended after they got through all of the hurdles placed in their way.

I loved all of the Whitley family Christmas traditions - they all seemed so fun and really brought the family together. Even with their kids all grown up, they’re all excited to participate and look forward to all the activities that happen that week.

Some of the conflict felt manufactured to me and definitely fell into the lack of communication trap, which always frustrates me. If they would have just come out and said things instead of dragging them out or let the other talk, so much conflict could have been avoided. I also felt like there was something going on with Norah and Landon leading up to their wedding, but nothing ever came of any of their cold feet/weird feelings/hesitation. Just felt like a dropped plot thread to me and didn’t really add much to the overall story.

If you’re looking for an easy-to-read, enjoyable holiday read, I’d definitely recommend giving Eight Days of Christmas a shot!

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X B09CRLXWFJ B09GZR9P7Y B09HG2RZZR 1648980996
review:
Takeovers and True Love for Ellison and Grey: It started as a dare, but it was SO much more than that. Ellison York and Grey Blackwood met in college at Yale and the night they finally acted on their attraction, insanity ensued, changing their paths and pulling them apart for 15 years.

Ellison is a corporate lawyer for his father’s company, but he’s getting out to do something that he loves, not continuing to do the corporate grind. Even though he’s a corporate lawyer, Ellison wants to help those who didn’t have the opportunities he did. It’s his passion and he’s putting his all into it, using his connections, intelligence and drive to make it happen. He’s weeks away from freedom when everything goes crazy again, 15 years later, thanks to Grey Blackwood.

Grey Blackwood thought he lost everything 15 years ago, but it really just made him work harder and set higher goals for himself to pull himself out of the poverty he grew up in to create a better life for himself and his mother. He’s a workaholic, self-made billionaire and he’s flawlessly executing a hostile takeover of Ellison’s father’s company. But, like Ellison, he’s also dedicated to creating opportunities for people that were in his shoes and will do anything he can to make their dreams a reality.

The dynamic between Ellison and Grey is so interesting - there’s some bad blood between the two, but they’re also inexplicably drawn to each other. To save his family’s business, Ellison agrees to be Grey’s PA for the last two weeks of his contract, signing up to be at his beck and call and live in his penthouse apartment with him for the duration. These two are full of chemistry, longing and pent-up emotions and watching them navigate all of that along with the business side of things together was so much fun. Even though they initially hated each other, they become each other’s biggest supporters and turn their relationship into something really special, despite all the obstacles in their way. Their relationship is a slow burn, but it’s definitely worth all the build up!

There were so many things happening in this story with takeovers, contracts, transfers of shares, real estate dealings and venture capitalism that it was difficult to keep up at times. Also all of the action was kind of slow burn too, not really picking up until about 65% through and then going full throttle from there.

I loved these two together and really enjoyed their second chance love story. If you’re looking for a fun, complicated romance standalone, this one is for you!

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X B09CRLXWFJ B09GZR9P7Y B09HG2RZZR 1648980996 1954857217
review:
Instant chemistry in Quincy: Indigo Ridge is the first book in The Edens series and it definitely did not disappoint! After reading the Christmas in Quincy prequel, I couldn’t wait to get back to Quincy, Montana and meet the Eden family and their significant others.

Winslow (Winn) Covington is young, but after spending 10 years as a police officer and detective in Bozeman, Montana, she’s moving to Quincy to be their new Chief of Police and help her grandfather (the mayor) breathe some new life into the department. She just got out of a long-term relationship and is looking to start fresh - no romantic attachment, more responsibilities and a new city. But she also is carrying around emotional baggage that’s weighing her down. Winn is everything that I love in a female character. She’s tenacious, confident, tough (but not unapproachable) and genuinely cares about doing her job well and helping to make Quincy a safer place.

Griffin Eden is the oldest in the Eden family, the most influential family in Quincy. He runs the family’s 90+ acre ranch, getting his hands dirty every day while also managing the business side of things. He’s uninterested in a relationship, especially one with someone from Quincy, and puts most of his time and energy into the ranch and his family. Griffin is sweet and thoughtful, has a dirty mouth and knows how to rock cowboy boots and a shiny belt buckle.

These two have chemistry from the second they meet, but things are rocky between them at the start. We get a little enemies to friends with benefits before it gets real. And it gets real fast - Winn and Griffin were drawn to each other in a way they couldn’t explain. Their relationship is mature and deep and (thankfully) doesn’t include any unnecessary misunderstandings or disagreements. Winn is everything Griffin didn’t know he wanted in a partner and Griffin has all the love in the world to give to Winn.

While the two of them were figuring out their relationship, there was also a lot of mystery and suspense throughout. I simultaneously was wrapped up in their romance storyline and trying to figure out who the culprit was. I really enjoyed how the two storylines weaved together and made the story unique and interesting.

I loved this introduction to Quincy and all of the Edens (Griffin is one of six!) - it’s such a fascinating small town full of some unique characters and I can’t wait to see where Devney Perry will take us with this series. I’m already looking forward to reading Juniper Hill when it comes out next year!

A sweet and low angst “forbidden” romance: When I saw that Nicole Dykes’ new release was going to be MM and teacher/student’s parent, I couldn’t wait to get my hands on it! Totally Schooled was sweet and a lot less angsty than I anticipated.

Nolan Burke is a kindergarten teacher and has the sweetest soul - he’s always looking for the best in people. He’s gotten into relationships with the wrong people thinking he could help them with their problems and ended up getting burned. But he’s looking for more...more commitment, more love and more of an equal partnership. One of Nolan’s students, Hailey, has an intense and broody father who catches his eye even though a relationship between them isn’t exactly encouraged.

Rafe Scott is a single dad trying to make ends meet in a new town to provide for his daughter, Hailey. After growing up in a small town with really narrow views and facing homophobia from his best friend and parents, he’s hesitant to show his true colors in his new environment and he doesn’t trust the easy acceptance he finds in others. He’s not looking for a relationship, now or ever, and his entire focus is on his daughter, making sure she’s happy, provided for and loved.

Nolan and Rafe are both instantly attracted to each other at Hailey’s school but start to develop a friendship outside of that. They’re in a precarious position because of how they met, but they can’t deny the pull toward each other. Eventually it becomes more, something they don’t want to label. I think the two of them really work well together and when you throw an adorable kindergartener into the mix, there’s no denying that they make each other happy. I loved that Nolan’s family was so welcoming to Rafe and Hailey before they even labeled their relationship - they needed people to love them after everything they’d been through and Nolan saw that and brought them into the fold, right where they belonged.

I didn’t mind the pacing throughout, but in the last 15-20%, things moved really fast. I would have loved to see more of their happiness together after all of their back and forth. I’m really hoping we get to see some more of that when Nicole writes Gavin’s book (Totally Played)!

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X B09CRLXWFJ B09GZR9P7Y B09HG2RZZR 1648980996 1954857217 195069271X B09KN9YN9B
review:
Love is love...even when it's "forbidden": When I read the description for this book, I immediately put in a request for an ARC copy - I had to know where it was going to go! Malachi and Isaac’s story is unexpected and a little hard to read at times, but there was so much love between these two that I couldn’t put it down.

Malachi Foley is the new youth pastor in town. He’s looking to start fresh, follow the path he told his parents we would before they passed away and avoid the temptations he encountered before Bible college. He’s spent years repenting for what he did but not feeling sorry for his desires, thinking that if he doesn’t act on them again, everything can be forgiven. But it’s left him feeling empty and lost, looking to scripture, prayer and his friend Zeke for guidance.

Isaac Van Dusen is the pastor’s only son and he’s keeping his sexuality a secret, but it’s causing him to withdraw, spending time in his room, writing songs to deal with his emotions and keeping things to himself to avoid accidentally outing himself. His father cares more about his flock at the church than he does about his own son and this disinterest and hypocrisy has Isaac counting down the days until he turns 18 and can head to Nashville to pursue his music dreams.

Everything changes for both of them the second Malachi shows up at the Van Dusen house for dinner on his first day in town. The pull between these two is undeniable, even though Malachi tries desperately to fight it. Malachi feels guilty for his desires and tries to hide them, avoiding Isaac in the process. But Isaac sees a lot of himself in Malachi and seeks him out, forcing him to confront his feelings and embrace their relationship because it will make them both happier than ever.

This story was full of turmoil, longing and angst due to the circumstances of Malachi and Isaac’s meeting - the church and religion played a big role in keeping them apart. They were taught that their feelings were wrong, that they’d be condemned for their desires and they’d be cast out. Malachi was afraid but seeing Isaac’s confidence in his acceptance helped him to finally be brave and expose their truth.

I really enjoyed this book. It was difficult to read at times, but I’d love to see more of Malachi and Isaac embracing their happiness and success together. Hoping for that and so much more in the next book...hopefully Zeke’s story!

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X B09CRLXWFJ B09GZR9P7Y B09HG2RZZR 1648980996 1954857217 195069271X B09KN9YN9B B09GZFHZHM
review:
Surprisingly sweet enemies to lovers romance: Savage Rivals is an MM, enemies to lovers story with so much tension, you could cut it with a knife. High school stories can occasionally be difficult for me to get into, but I couldn’t get enough of this one!

Asher and Levi are rivals - captains of rival football teams who have made it their mission to one-up each other, pulling pranks, destroying property and getting into fights. Since the first game of the season, they’ve been thinking of ways to get back at each other, but their relationship is so much more complicated than that.

Levi is from Alstone High and has everything he could ever need and more, something Asher can only dream of being from Highnam Academy. Their rivalry starts with football, but goes deeper - Asher thinking Levi is privileged and spoiled and Levi thinking Asher is a jerk with something to prove. As they’re pulling pranks, vandalizing school property and fighting with each other, Asher and Levi start to realize their obsession with each other is more than a rivalry, turning into flirtation, stolen kisses and eventually a full-blown relationship.

Once they accepted their connection and pull toward one another, they started to open up to each other and get to know the people behind their preconceived notions. They’re vulnerable around each other in a way that’s surprising and so, so sweet. Even though their relationship was unexpected, they jumped in with both feet and it was steamy and passionate - you could feel their connection jumping off the page.

The ending of this story and the epilogue killed me - I could have read about Asher and Levi forever...they’re so sweet, loving and funny. Definitely recommend giving this one a read if you love MM and enemies to lovers!

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X B09CRLXWFJ B09GZR9P7Y B09HG2RZZR 1648980996 1954857217 195069271X B09KN9YN9B B09GZFHZHM B09LGNR3PK
review:
A wild, action-packed ending for Hadley and the Princes: Break Free was a wild ride. After reading the first three books in this series, there’s no other way this series could have ended and the last book definitely didn’t disappoint.

Hadley has one of the craziest baskstories I’ve ever read and everything that happens to her in this book goes right along with that. She’s been through some crazy stuff and has made it to the other side, not totally unscathed, but with way less lasting trauma than anyone else in her position would have. I really liked seeing her open up and finally accept the love and kindness of her guys, her family and her friends - that was huge growth for her. My favorite part of her development? Her twinmance with Hawk. I loved seeing the two of them together and watching their relationship develop until they could sense each other, like they’d known each other all along. It was super sweet and exactly what I wanted for them!

Mason, Cam, West and Beck really show up in this book - they use their connections, their smarts and their brutality to take control of their lives and to save Hadley from their parents and herself. They’re almost single-mindedly focused on doing whatever they can to make sure Hadley’s safe and that their futures are completely their own. This book is full of violence and plotting and revenge for each and every one of the guys, finally giving their parents what they deserve.

My biggest complaint is that, with everything going on, we didn’t get to see Hadley bond more with the guys. Their relationships were still front and center and there’s definitely some steamy moments, but I don’t feel like they grew a lot, especially their individual relationships. They plotted and planned and enacted their revenge, but I feel like their relationships only grew because of the action.

Really hoping we’ll see glimpses of all of these characters in the upcoming Black Creek series - would love to see where they end up after the events of the epilogues!

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X B09CRLXWFJ B09GZR9P7Y B09HG2RZZR 1648980996 1954857217 195069271X B09KN9YN9B B09GZFHZHM B09LGNR3PK B09M9PQWD2
review:
5 too good to be true stars!: Homecoming King was the holiday goodness I never knew I was missing from Penny Reid! This book is full of quirky yet endearing characters, laugh out loud moments and slow burn sweetness that only Penny Reid can capture in one place.

Abigail (Abby) McNerny is completely clueless about love and relationships, especially after she was burned so badly in the past. She’s a crafting queen who hasn’t found a medium she doesn’t love, a bartender and one of the quirkiest heroines I’ve ever read. Her past definitely makes her guarded, but she’s making strides to see more for herself than her current situation and Rex is a huge reason why.

Rex “TW” McMurtry is a professional football player and has some incredible matchmaking skills - everyone he goes on a date with and introduces to one of his friends ends up married to them (major Good Luck Chuck vibes, thankfully minus Dane Cook). He’s gruff and blunt, but once he started to open up, he was incredibly thoughtful, so sweet and incredibly kind to the people who meant the most to him. He’s constantly fighting to overcome the “Training Wheels” moniker the news has saddled him with and Abby is the perfect person to help him make it happen.

Their relationship is the definition of slow burn, but it makes the pay off so much sweeter in the end! Rex and Abby go from acquaintances to business associates to friends to lovers and their relationship is funny, awkward and so adorable at every turn. The way they both want each other is palpable, but they each have their reasons for keeping their feelings hidden. But, once they finally open up, these two are the perfect match for each other, full of steam, naughty fantasies and a deep understanding they haven’t felt with anyone else.

I didn’t want Rex and Abby’s story to end! I love this new group of characters and can’t wait to see what amazing stories Penny Reid brings us with the other two books in this series - Drama King (Cyrus?) and Prom King (Alastair?). Oh, and the appearances from characters in other Pennyverse series? The best! So excited for the next two kings!

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X B09CRLXWFJ B09GZR9P7Y B09HG2RZZR 1648980996 1954857217 195069271X B09KN9YN9B B09GZFHZHM B09LGNR3PK B09M9PQWD2 1942874820
review:
Lots of yearning and guilt before a relationship: 3.5 stars, rounded to 4

After reading Unholy Craving, I couldn’t wait for more in this series! Unholy Yearning is a little far fetched and full of a lot of internal conflict and reflection, but Zeke and Levi really kept me interested.

Zeke is a Christian counselor at a church in Philadelphia - he’s dedicated his life to the church, but has recently felt unmoved by the sermons and ceremonies surrounding everything. His upbringing was a little unconventional, but he still fears accepting his truth as a bisexual man because of his profession. Zeke’s newest assignment is premarital counseling for a young couple who are middle school sweethearts and the groom-to-be just so happens to be someone Zeke’s met before.

Levi is a new grad from Bible college, but didn’t pursue a degree in seminary because of his love for numbers. He’s dealing with some major trauma from his childhood full of neglect and disinterest and has some ongoing struggles with depression and anxiety. Levi relies on his best friend and fiancee, Lily, to be his rock in hard situations and to be the support he never received from his parents. But, he’s keeping a secret from her. One that could destroy their relationship and their friendship, especially when Zeke enters their lives.

These two had an instant connection months ago and it hasn’t faded one bit, even though their circumstances are less than ideal. Their relationship is full of complications, misunderstandings, awkward encounters, guilt about their true identities and tons of mutual yearning. Their draw to each other was really clear from the beginning, even when they couldn’t be together. I didn’t love that there was some cheating in the development of their relationship, but I was intrigued by how they ended up figuring out their impossible situation to finally be together in the end.

I could have done with less miscommunication between not only Zeke and Levi, but Lily too - so many things could have been avoided if they talked things through instead of feeling guilty about the things they felt. I also really disliked Lily’s character. I think we were supposed to based on how she treated Levi, but her immaturity and selfishness were both out of control and left me feeling really even more terrible for Levi.

This was full of drama, crazy coincidences and lots of mutual yearning, but I enjoyed this one and loved the little appearances from Malachi and Isaac throughout. I’m really looking forward to the next book in the series for Aaron’s story after everything we learn about him in this installment!

history: B07WG8L7WC B08X5WCWQB B095GD37P2 B096LPVBSH B0974R273Z B0991C6HYQ B099BWT97Z 1950087093 1942874731 B09BYDGVL6 198972311X B09CRLXWFJ B09GZR9P7Y B09HG2RZZR 1648980996 1954857217 195069271X B09KN9YN9B B09GZFHZHM B09LGNR3PK B09M9PQWD2 1942874820 1955635161
review:
Love and personal discovery for Tanner and Lucy: Cream and Punishment is another sweet addition to the King Family series, this one focusing on Tanner King and Lucy Dillard’s second chance romance. Oh, and they’re also new coworkers, so there’s a little workplace romance in there too!

Tanner is the sweet, cinnamon roll hero I never knew I wanted him to be! After reading about his younger brother Wyatt’s playboy ways, I wasn’t sure what to expect from Tanner and I ended up loving every minute he was on the page. He loves his 16-year-old cat, Lord of the Rings, literature, poetry and Lucy Dillard. But she ran scared when he told her he loved her and he’s been heartbroken ever since. Tanner’s also struggling to find his passion and his place in the King Family with his father’s unreasonable expectations and manipulations hanging over his head.

Lucy is the most responsible one in her household and has been for years - she has a full-time job that she loves, but she also cooks, cleans and helps to pay the household bills for her mom and brother. She doesn’t know that she can ask for help or that her friends would be willing to do that and shouldering all of the burdens stresses her out even more. She wanted something casual and fun with Tanner, but he ruined that when he went and fell in love with her, causing her to react poorly and ghost him. Her mother is a master manipulator, taking advantage of Lucy’s kindness and inability to set boundaries and wreaking havoc on Lucy and her brother’s lives every day.

I think Tanner and Lucy’s progression from “enemies” to coworkers to friends to lovers was really believable and realistic and I loved that. It wasn’t full of relationship angst, but they work through a lot and get to know each other more before they dive into their relationship again. The first time they tried, they weren’t on the same page but after some much-needed communication, they finally got there. They both made some major steps to better themselves and to find joy together and that made me smile.

Really looking forward to more from the King family soon and I’m especially excited that the next book (Pint of Contention) is about Ryan…I’ve been intrigued by him from the very beginning!

Interesting intro to Sterling Falls - ready for more!: After reading Thrill in an anthology in the fall, I couldn’t wait to get my hands on this book to learn more about Olympus, Hades, Ares and Apollo!

Kora Sinclair ends up in the wrong place at the wrong time and suddenly becomes the invisible girl with no scholarship, no job and no options in Sterling Falls. But she’s determined to stay in school, so she makes a bad choice, one that keeps coming back to haunt her. I appreciate that Kora is a survivor and is so determined to change her life/situation, but there was something about her character’s reckless decision making that bugged me. She made choices without thinking about the consequences and then was sickened and surprised when people came to collect what they were due. So far she’s not my favorite heroine, but there’s three books left in the series to change my mind.

Wolfe (Ares), Apollo (Apollo) and Jace (Hades) rule over both Olympus and Sterling Falls. There’s so much mystery and intrigue surrounding these three and I can’t wait to learn more about them and their backgrounds. Wolfe is immediately drawn to Kora at Olympus and has a 6th sense for knowing what she needs in any situation. Apollo sees some of his past in Kora’s present and does everything he can to help her out. Jace is the most standoffish with Kora, but he also helps her sleep at night and puts her mind at ease. These three grew up together and have a connection like brothers and it’s really interesting to see them work together and interact both in and out of Olympus.

This is definitely a slow burn reverse harem story. Kora and the guys are just getting to know each other but it’s pretty clear there’s a connection between all of them. She feels safe with them and they’re intent on protecting her/getting her out of her bad decisions. Things get really interesting once they start spending more time together - you can feel the tension between all of them, even if they don’t want to admit that they all feel the same way. Really curious to see where their relationships are going to go, especially with how things ended up.

Somehow S. Massery managed to write a triple cliffhanger and I’m dying to see where this series is going to go next. Is it April yet?!

Sweet second chance love for Nash and Adrian: I couldn’t wait to get my hands on Backslide after reading Runaways - I knew there was so much more to Nash than what we saw there and I’m so glad we got to see it here.

Nash Davis is grumpy, protective and hardworking but you can tell he purposely keeps to himself, not allowing people to get too close or to see what’s behind his stoic exterior. He’s been living in the Ozarks helping his brother Lawson, sister-in-law Rae and best friend Hayden build and maintain their cabins. This peaceful lifestyle works for him - he’s happy because he knows those closest to him are happy and taken care of. But his happiness is disrupted when the Walker family descends on their resort, bringing a blast from Nash’s past with them.

Adrian Walker has spent years cultivating his persona as the perfect political son, doing what his father expects of him, keeping his personal opinions to himself and dating the girl his father picked for him. But when his family heads to the Ozarks to vacation, he’s confronted with his past - Nash Davis. Adrian’s kept his true self hidden to not cause waves but he’s realizing that hiding isn’t worth it anymore.

These two met on the first day of their senior year of high school and immediately felt a connection that led to them seeing each other in secret, stealing any moment they could to be together and making plans to run away after graduation. Until Adrian has second thoughts and leaves Nash heartbroken. Now that they’re together again, there’s still a pull between them and there’s a lot of back and forth between them and so many complications. Adrian makes some big decisions about his life and Nash is there supporting him at every turn. I wish there was more catching up between the two of them - so much of their renewed relationship was based in the physical and I missed some of the emotional connection and getting to know who each other was after so many years apart/with no communication whatsoever. Their relationship is full of heartbreak but it ends with so much support, love and growth that it makes it all worth it.

I loved seeing Law & Rae flourishing and settling into their new life and Hayden continuing to be the sweet talking flirt he’s always been. Hayden and Nash’s friendship was so much fun to read and I can’t wait to see more when Hayden finally gets his own story!

5 stars for this fabulous regency romp!: Something Fabulous is the gay regency romp I never knew I needed in my life and never wanted to end! It was outrageous, over-the-top, hilarious, incredibly sweet and a little raunchy - everything I could ever want in a story! After Valentine Layton, Duke of Malvern, proposes to Arabella Tarleton, she runs away and her twin brother Bonaventure (Bonny) enlists Valentine’s help to bring her back home, resulting in a ridiculous cross-country chase.

Valentine is reserved, naive and lonely, hiding behind his duties as a duke instead of putting himself out there to live his life. On the flip side, Bonny is charming, flirtatious and so creative. They’re opposites in almost every way, but as they get to know each other again, their relationship takes a really precious and endearing turn. Valentine’s demisexuality and inexperience is definitely in stark contrast with Bonny’s flamboyant nature and wealth of experience and it makes for some awkward and sweet conversations and a lot of growth.

The banter and chemistry between Valentine and Bonny was next level. Their grumpy/sunshine dynamic pulled me in and What started out as Valentine thinking Bonny was just a ridiculous man obsessed with romance and stories turned into a fun and emotional journey toward self-discovery, acceptance and unconditional love.

I really wanted to take off half a star for Arabella Tarleton’s character - she was so irritating, dramatic, violent and rude that it drove me up a wall, but I couldn’t take any stars away because without her insane antics, Valentine and Bonny would have never had a chance to fall in love and be together.

This book is campy (in the best way possible!) yet intelligent and deep, all things I’ve come to love about Hall’s writing. Like always, I didn’t want it to end, but when it did, I had a huge smile on my face for Valentine and Bonny. I can’t recommend this book enough!

Emotionally charged MC love with beautiful men: Devil’s Dance is an emotionally charged, action packed, exciting and steamy ride featuring three complex, intense, compassionate and beautiful men. I didn’t know exactly what to expect from this book going in, but since it’s one of Garrett Leigh’s I knew it would be full of incredibly sweet men underneath their tough exteriors.

Cam O’Brien is the president of the Rebel Kings MC, but he’s so much more than that. He’s a compassionate leader who’s invested in the well-being of his brothers and is working to turn the club into a legitimate operation. But that of course comes with a lot of complications - there’s a price on his head and some of his own brothers are intent on turning against him. Cam’s constantly in danger but finds some calm in the storm when he meets Alexei at a random bar one night.

Alexei is an enigmatic guy through and through. He keeps details about his life hidden but it’s clear that whatever he did in his past has made him dangerous, cold and calculating. But once Cam breaks through that exterior, Alexei is incredibly caring and loyal in ways he didn’t think were possible. His lethal skills come out to play when he needs to call on them to keep Cam safe.

The two of them went from a casual encounter to so much more pretty quickly - the draw between them was undeniable, each feeling like they’d found something they didn’t know they’d been searching for all along. They immediately gelled and quickly became each other’s safe space in the messy worlds they come from.

While so much of this book is about Cam and Alexei’s relationship, there’s a piece missing - Saint Malone. Even when he’s not there physically, Cam and Alexei talk about him, think about him and are drawn to him. He’s the MC’s Sergeant-at-Arms, but he’s also gorgeous, quiet, dangerous, fiercely protective of Cam and incredibly intrigued by Alexei. Saint is such an interesting character and we don’t really get to know much about him in this book, but I have high hopes for breaking down this complicated man’s walls in the next book in the series. The three of them are beautiful, damaged men who come together to create something incredible.

I can’t wait to see where the next book (Saint’s Song) takes these three. If the sneak peek at the end of this book is anything to go by, it’s going to be just as steamy and emotionally charged as this one was and I’m SO here for it! And all of my fingers are crossed for more stories from the Rebel Kings MC - there’s so many stories to tell that we got a glimpse into and I’m really hoping we get them eventually!

Reconnection and unquestionable desire: After reading Unholy Yearning, I couldn’t wait to get my hands on Aaron’s book. All of the books in this series have been a little forbidden because of their faith, but Aaron and Ezra’s story was especially taboo since Ezra is Aaron’s father’s best friend.

Ezra Jamison has been overseas, serving as a missionary, setting up a church in the Ukraine and marrying a woman he met during his time there. After his wife passes away, he returns to the US to live with his best friend and his son while he gets back on his feet. But, Aaron isn’t the 14-year-old boy he left behind 15 years ago and that, coupled with his guilt about his wife’s death have him feeling out of sorts and questioning his faith.

Aaron Westfield put his life on hold three years ago when his father was diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease. He’s been his sole caregiver, working crazy hours every day, dealing with his father’s deteriorating health and struggling with his own depression. With Ezra back in their lives, he has someone to lean on for help and support, giving him the reprieve he desperately needs. Ezra’s always been his hero, even more so now that he’s back exactly when Aaron needs it most.

Living under the same roof, Ezra and Aaron’s feelings become unavoidable - the tension between them is undeniable, their connection is palpable and their unholy desires make them question their faith and what it means for their future. Even though things are complicated and messy, you can feel how much they care for each other coming off of the page. Even though there’s a large age difference between them and some other roadblocks come up along the way, they find a way to persevere together and overcome it all.

This series keeps getting better and better. I’m excited to see where things will go next with Unholy Temptation!

An unexpectedly great pairing: After meeting Pietro Bassani in Nothing Ordinary (highly recommend reading this one first!), I felt like I couldn’t get an accurate read on him during his interactions with Gabriel and Ezra, so I was excited to see where his story would go. Switch-Hitter was really enjoyable and covered some heavy emotional topics while introducing us to two intense and complex men who are unexpectedly perfect for each other.

Pietro is an MLB player who feels like he has something to prove. His team looks at him as a disorganized mess of a human even though he’s a dedicated and influential part of the team but so much of that stems from his ADHD, something he keeps hidden from almost everyone. His brain is a chaotic place at the best of times, so focusing on his craft takes most of his energy, leaving him eating frozen meals because he can’t cook and relying on those around him to keep him in check. Pietro’s lonely and trying to deal with a lot at once, so hiring a personal chef sounds like the right thing to do.

Thierry Bourget is the last person in the world Pietro expects to see in his home, interviewing to become his personal chef after their questionable past together and Thierry’s injuries. After being shot while working as a bodyguard, Thierry is adapting to a new life, one with physical limitations but also the opportunity to do what he loves for a living - cook. He’s constantly overcoming obstacles in this story and I was rooting for him to succeed. While he’s a little grumpy, he’s also determined to make the most of his new life and to be a better man than he was before.

I really enjoyed seeing how Pietro and Thierry grew together. After way too many years of being put down by a narcissistic, toxic, and controlling man like Hervé, they finally started to realize their self-worth and importance thanks in part to one another. They’re both damaged in their own ways, but seeing them overcome their emotional and physical challenges and hesitations about being together was really special. They fell in love slowly and almost reluctantly but that just made it mean more since they went through so much to get them to a place where love and a relationship was possible.

Even though baseball isn’t my thing, I’m intrigued by this fictional version of the MLB and can’t wait to see which characters will get their HEAs next and what other stories E.M. Lindsey will tell.

Sweet characters, quick read: Off the Deep End was my first book by Emily Silver and it was really sweet, low angst and included one of my favorite things - the Olympics. Wes Cooper is a professional diver coming back from an injury to make a run for the next Olympic games. Finn Anderson is the journalist assigned to cover Wes’s comeback even though he has zero experience with diving. There’s chemistry between them right off the bat and once they acknowledge it, things progress pretty quickly. I felt like it was almost a little too fast - I wanted some build up to the story and their relationship, not just straight to the physical. They were really sweet and understanding, but both characters felt a little flat to me.

I did really enjoy that there was such a realistic focus on mental health in athletes - this isn’t something that comes up often in books and this take was great with Finn already detailing Wes’s road to the Olympics. This was a short, quick read that was enjoyable but not as detailed as I would have liked. Wes and Finn were sweet and relatable, but ultimately weren’t characters that will stick with me.

All the frat fun, brofriends and mayhem!: Robbie and Brandon…need I say more? I couldn’t wait to go back to this funny, weird, accepting world that Saxon James created! Robbie and Brandon’s friends to brofriends (aka cumpanions haha) to boyfriends was hilarious, sweet and so sincere - I couldn’t put it down!

After seeing (and hearing) Chad and Bailey get together in the last book (Frat Wars: King of Thieves), Robbie is questioning his sexuality and looking for a bro to help him experiment. I loved how open he was about everything - his sexual exploration, personality, clothing choices, opinions, everything. He’s a big guy who can rock cargo pants and a fanny pack while making everyone around him smile with his antics. Brandon is his best friend and even when they disagree (which is pretty often), he knows he’s a bro he can trust.

Brandon, being the great friend that he is, accidentally volunteers to help Robbie explore his sexuality, something incredibly risky for the frat house risk manager. But he figures out that it’s not a risk at all - Brandon and Robbie have been fighting like an old married couple since they met four years ago, so this next step in their relationship isn’t as strange as he expects and he finds himself drawn to the big, goofy, confident man he’s been friends with for years. Brandon’s risk averse by nature, but loves to have a good time, something that Robbie pulls out in him time and time again.

I really liked these two together - they clearly had a deep connection from being friends for so many years, but once things went from friends to more their connection went even deeper. They were funny and sweet and so caring even when things were up in the air between them. I loved that this book was super low angst and full of moments that made me smile and laugh out loud. Even though they were both pretty unfamiliar with committed relationships, they fell into something special really fast. And, I have to say, Robbie’s big declaration of love was absolutely perfect!

The Sigma Beta Psi brothers are so great and showed that again in this book with their easy acceptance and support. Robbie and Brandon were adorable and I can’t wait for Zeke and Charles’s story next…those two are going to be a ton of fun!

Opposites attract and low angst love: It’s been a while since I’ve read a high school MM story so I was expecting all the angst from this one, but was pleasantly surprised with how mature and low angst this story was!

Rhett Moore feels like he’s broken and that he doesn’t deserve all of the incredible things he’s been given lately. As a former foster kid, he isn’t used to even the simple luxuries his adopted parents Rhys and Blair have given him and his best friends/also adopted siblings Bree and Fletcher. He’s had a plan for his life once he turned 18 since before he was adopted and even though things are going well, he feels like he has to see it through. Rhett is an artist with a huge heart and broody temperament but he’s confused about who he is - none of the labels he knows fit and it makes him feel like even more of an outcast.

Grayson Lancaster is the school golden boy - the smartest, most athletic, most handsome guy who seems to have it all together. But he’s hiding a huge part of himself from his friends and especially his family so he feels disconnected and isolated from it all - he knows he’s gay but feels like he can’t be out because of who he is. He’s going along with his father’s plans for his life so that he can make a difference one day and use his family’s company for good again even though it means sacrificing years of his life and his happiness. Grayson is captivated by Rhett and wants to get to know him - he’s persistent and driven and always has a smile on his face.

I really enjoyed the back and forth between these two when they were becoming friends and more than friends - Rhett gave Grayson everything he had to keep him away and Grayson took it and saw past it to what he really meant. Even though they were opposites in so many ways, they seemed to fit together so well and complemented each other. Their journeys toward self discovery and knowing their worth/value were great to see and I loved how they both supported each other so easily, even when things were hard. While I don’t love angsty stories, I think their story could have done with a little bit more - everything that they feared seemed to be resolved really easily…almost too easily.

The epilogue for this story was the sweetest and I felt like I could have lived in that last chapter, sharing in their happiness. Fingers crossed for even more glimpses of that in Fletcher’s book one of these days!

Austin + Caleb - the perfect pairing: Pitcher Perfect was the low angst love story I needed after a few dark reads! This friends to lovers, workplace, small town romance is the first in a series about four queer brewery owners and it was a ton of fun to read.

Austin Hewitt is the head brewer at Tap That Brewery and he loves his job, so much so that he’s given everything to it for the past year to help make the brewery a success. He’s driven, a little shy and incredibly sweet. His backstory and his relationship with his parents made my heart break a little bit, but I loved that his aunt and uncle stepped in and that he formed such a strong relationship with his cousin, Tyler, and the two other co-owners of Tap That - Dom and Ethan.

Caleb Larsen is a food truck owner who’s in Dahlia Springs looking for a place to call home and to connect with his mother’s roots. He’s determined to open his own restaurant in town and keeps putting himself out there so that the owner of the space will give him a chance. Caleb is a fixer - always trying to make sure the people he cares about are taken care of and their problems are solved, which has been a sticking point in his past relationships.

Austin and Caleb meet in a paper store in Portland and bonded over their mutual love for good quality notebooks, ink and analog processes but they missed their chance to exchange numbers. Months later, they both find themselves in the same small town, brought together by their friends to enter a food and beer pairing competition. They become friends first and it’s a slow build to them becoming more and even that takes a while for them to accept. They’re really sweet together and understand/appreciate each other’s drive to be successful and achieve their goals. I loved how they collaborated so easily for the competition and how Caleb had Austin’s back even when he came face-to-face with his idol who just so happened to be Austin’s estranged father.

Austin’s co-brewery owners were hilarious and made this story a lot of fun - I can’t wait to get to know them more in the rest of this series! They were so supportive of Austin and Caleb’s relationship even before it happened and I can’t wait to see them all happy. I didn’t love that Austin’s problems with his dad were wrapped up so easily and that both Austin and Caleb continually compare each other to their past failed relationships

Really looking forward to the rest of the Tap That Brewery series after reading Pitcher Perfect! I already know Dom’s story is going to be a ton of fun to read next!

Lackluster ending for Austin and Rae: I really, really wanted to like Raelynn and Austin’s story. I was so excited to get my hands on it after reading the quick sneak peek at the end of Nova’s story, but it just didn’t all come together for me in the end. I didn’t get pulled into the story and honestly I kept closing the book and coming back to it minutes or even hours later.

Raelynn Vos has a big personality, strong opinions and doesn’t know how to take no as an answer (for better or for worse). She was such an instigator in Vera and Nova’s stories but her aversion to relationships came through loud and clear throughout this series as her best friends fell in love. Rae is intelligent but hides it behind her party girl ways and only brings it out when someone accuses her of being flighty. I know a lot of readers loved Rae in the other two stories, but she wasn’t ever my favorite and this book definitely cemented that. She’s incredibly stubborn, set in her ways and secretive, keeping so many things to herself and self-sabotaging things every chance that she gets.

Austin Caldwell is Rae’s best friend and the only guy who’s ever turned her down. Despite things being platonic between the two of them since college, he’s loved her from afar, keeping it hidden and always being there when she needed him. He’s a graphic designer with every intention to only marry once after seeing his dad be a serial husband - marrying and divorcing women like it was nothing. Austin is a really sweet guy but he has so much hidden underneath that handsome exterior and I loved seeing it come out - it was unexpected and so, so steamy. But he moved fast from the time they decided to play out the marriage for both of their families, probably too fast, and made things increasingly difficult for himself the longer it went on.

Rae and Austin were best friends first, but that didn’t stop him from falling for her long before they got drunk and woke up married. Things started off rocky between the two of them but they found their way back to friendship and so much more, slowly but surely. But the one big problem with their relationship was their lack of communication - even before they got together romantically, it seemed like these two didn’t talk about anything other than the present day and that felt really unlikely. I wanted them to truly be best friends and open up to each other about their pasts, beliefs, desires, fears, everything.

Overall I enjoyed this series all together but this last story just wasn’t my favorite. I think Rae and Austin could have been great together - I typically really enjoy the friends to lovers trope, but these two had a lot of unresolved issues between them both individually and as a couple that I just couldn’t believe the quick resolution.

Grumpy/sunshine soccer love: He’s a Keeper was my first soccer romance and my first Stacy Tracy read and it definitely won’t be my last!

Holden Sanders is a professional soccer keeper and the captain of the San Francisco Strikers. He’s grumpy and a little rude but also charming underneath it all. After getting embarrassed by his ex, he’s closed himself off to love and relationships and dedicated himself completely to soccer. When he gets a concussion during a game, he finds himself with a lot of time on his hands and nothing to do. He takes his niece to the library and runs into Molly.

Molly is a librarian at a private school and part-time at a San Francisco public library branch. She’s perpetually happy, always upbeat and excited but she’s insecure about some things, including her abilities to connect with the kids during story time. Her past always comes back to make her feel even worse but Holden’s presence seems to finally make her hope for more.

They start as acquaintances, Holden helping Molly with story time at the library, but after a drunk text, they get so much closer. I feel like things moved quickly between them and wanted a little more development in their relationship but they balanced each other well and I liked their bantering moments back and forth. I would have loved more chemistry between them - they were cute and drawn to each other, but I just didn’t feel all the sparks I hoped to. The ending of their story was pretty great though - both what Holden did for Molly and what their next steps are together.

I’m intrigued by what’s happening with the Strikers team and new owner and I’m looking forward to seeing how it all plays out. Also excited for Tim’s story next - sounds like it’s going to be a fun one!

Easy romance and low angst love story: Bruised But Not Broken is everything I’ve come to expect from Nicole Dykes - sweet main characters, a cast of interesting side characters, easy romance and low angst.

Ben has a bit of a hero complex - he loves to swoop in and save the day, something he finds himself trying to do often. He owns a gym and is a workaholic - putting his all into making his business a success. After his wife is attacked and springs a divorce on him, he feels adrift and confused until Colby wanders by his gym.

Colby found himself stuck in an abusive relationship for years, something that he thought he deserved. But once he gets himself out from under his boyfriend’s thumb, he’s in need of a job and a place to stay, which led him to Ben’s gym. Once he’s comfortable, Colby starts to recognize that he has some lingering trauma from his past relationship but is drawn to Ben’s stability and safety.

These two went from boss/employee to friends to boyfriends pretty quickly. They started opening up to each other about their pasts since they didn’t feel comfortable sharing at the Spark of Hope trauma support group happening at the gym and they built a relationship from there. Even though Ben hadn’t ever been interested in men before, Colby captures his attention. Once Colby accepts that he’s not just Ben’s experiment but someone who means something to him (and that he deserves it), their relationship turns into something solid and lasting.

I felt a little disappointed with all of the negative talk surrounding therapy. Ben and Roman are extremely outspoken about their feelings and I think it created a negative opinion with all of the gym workers. Since this is the first book in the series, I’m hoping it improves as more people are helped by the Spark of Hope group.

We met a lot of great characters in this series introduction (Roman, Andrew, Ethan, even Brooks at the very end), so I’m looking forward to seeing where this series will go next.

40+ one-night stands led to a fun romance: Hitched is the second book in the Licking Thicket: Horn of Glory series and was full of fake fiances, non-stop one-night stands and meddling teammates.

Quinn Taffet was the clear star of this book. He’s a wedding planner working to make a name for himself in big Nashville weddings but opening his shop in Licking Thicket to get things started set him back a bit. Quinn is hilarious, honest and both immune and not immune to Champ’s charms. I loved his inner monologue and how unafraid he was to give Champ a piece of his mind and make his opinion known. Even though he’s a wedding planner, he’s skeptical of marriage and committed relationships, so he’s not sure what to do when he finds himself wanting more one-night stands with Champ and missing him when he’s not around.

Percy “Champ” Champion is a former Marine and a current security company owner who always puts the mission first. His team is his family and he doesn’t do relationships after his last one crashed and burned. Champ is driven, bossy, opinionated and protective, which serves him well in his career, yet not so much when it comes to his personal life. He’s incredibly focused but finds himself losing his mind over one man over and over again - Quinn Taffet.

I really loved that Quinn and Champ were together from the very beginning of this book. It made things interesting and I enjoyed seeing them both unknowingly fall more and more in love with each other as their one-night stands continued. Even though they’re totally different, they both wanted to protect their businesses and do what it takes to make them a success, which just so happens to bring them together. When they finally start to listen to each other and open up, you see how well they fit together.

While Hitched was set in Licking Thicket, I felt like I was missing some of the Licking Thicket punniness in this story. All of the usual characters were around and wreaking havoc like usual, but I feel like I laughed a lot less than expected. I missed that absurd hilarity from the other books!

Quinn and Champ were well matched but I’m dying to get my hands on Hux & Kev’s story! We’ve been building up to it for the past two books and I can’t wait to see how things end for them!

Incredible MMM love story with non-stop MC action: I’ve been (not so) patiently waiting for Saint’s Song since reading an ARC of Devil’s Dance and I’m SO happy that this story lived up to and even exceeded my expectations for Cam, Alexei and Saint.

After the turmoil and pain from the first half of their story, this book is full of action, intelligence gathering, scheming and discovery for these three. There’s always something happening with the Rebel Kings MC, the Crows, the Sambinis and the Russians, leading to non-stop threats and plotting to help the Rebel Kings stay one step ahead while recovering from their physical and mental wounds from their first battle. All of the Kings were tense with so many unknowns for their future and their well-being, which kept me on the edge of my seat. I devoured this book because I needed to know what was going to happen to not only Cam, Alexei and Saint, but also all of the Kings we’ve come to love so much.

Cam, Alexei and Saint went on a journey in this book - learning more about each other, figuring out how to read each other and finding out more about their pasts, especially Saint’s. My heart broke for Saint as more of his story came out. He’s been through so much, survived so much that no one should have had to endure and came out on the other side as a true unicorn - so unique, unexpected and surprising. I fell in love with him as much as I did Cam and Alexei in the first part of their story. As the three of them grow closer together, it becomes very clear that they’re meant to be together and can’t survive without each other. They’re three parts of a whole, feeling each other’s feelings even when they’re separated and becoming stronger for it even when things go wrong.

Saint’s Song really was everything I hoped for and much, much more. I loved this book so much - it was a non-stop adventure supplemented with so much love and acceptance from Cam, Alexei and Saint. I can’t wait for the next Rebel Kings story (hi, Embry and Mateo!!) and to spend some more time with my favorite broken and wonderfully sweet MC members.

Angst, jealousy and blindsided by love: Blindsided is enemies to lovers, roommates, bi-awakening, college romance goodness and I couldn’t put it down! Once I picked this one up, there was no stopping me - I was so invested in Noah and Liam’s hate, angst, jealousy and attraction.

Noah is just starting university and finds himself rooming with a bunch of footballers, his personal nightmare since he was teased by the footballers at his high school. But he quickly figures out that the guys aren’t so bad, even his broody roommate Liam. I really enjoyed Noah in this story - he’s confident and snarky and adorable. He surprised me with how mature he was about everything and how patient he was while Liam worked things out.

Liam instantly hates Noah after their less than cute meet cute accident and hates him even more when he learns they’re stuck in the same house. But some of the animosity between them was likely because Liam couldn’t sort out his confusing feelings for Noah. Liam is a footballer who feels most at home on the pitch, is always out searching for a new girl to spend the night with and he knows who he is. Or does he? Noah makes him feel things he never expected and makes him question everything he’s known about himself.

These two meet under less than ideal circumstances and it leads to some awkward first interactions. But you can feel the attraction between them coming right off the page and all of the angst-y jealousy before they give in to their feelings just made it even better. I loved the back and forth and the progression from hate to friends to love but almost wanted more of the hate - it was so well done! Their HEA was hard won but a little quick for me but the epilogue left me swooning for these two!

And can we talk about the cameos from other Becca Steele characters in this book?! I loved every minute of it…Preston, Kian, Levi, Asher, Carter, Raine - they were all so great!

Already anxiously awaiting the next book in the LSU series and hoping we get some Elliott and Ander love next!

Ethan + Luke - Friends to lovers romance with lots of complications: Playing for Keeps is a M/M rugby, best friends to lovers story that I couldn’t put down - I loved Luke and Ethan’s connection!

Ethan Lewis is a professional rugby player and a single dad to Theo. He’s a jokester above all else, always having a joke or story ready to go no matter what situation he finds himself in and a smile on his face. His childhood was less than stellar, so he finds himself giving his all to Theo to make his life more like his childhood best friend Luke’s was. Ethan and Luke lost contact after he and Luke’s twin sister Char got pregnant at 18 after one night together when Ethan had been missing Luke.

Luke Hunter is also a professional rugby player who is moving back to New Zealand to finally play for his home country and be closer to his family. After Ethan betrayed him 6 years ago, he left to play rugby in Japan and hasn’t been back until now. He finds himself on the same team with his former best friend, trying to navigate their messy remains of a friendship and also get to know his family again, including his 6-year-old nephew. Luke has always been in love with Ethan but was afraid to do anything about it when they were younger and now they face too many complications to make anything happen.

I really loved Ethan and Luke’s connection - they had so many years of friendship to fall back on and even when things were awkward between them, they still found a way to fall back into their old ways. They had the same sense of humor, shared inside jokes and knew each other inside and out - their love story felt inevitable. Obviously Ethan having a child with Luke’s twin sister threw a major wrench in their relationship and caused a divide between them and Char, but I think the way things ended as well as they possibly could considering the circumstances. Ethan and Luke were such a great couple, even when they weren’t officially together that them finally making things official just felt right.

I do have to say that I felt terrible for Jonathan, Luke’s boyfriend who moved from Japan with him, throughout this whole story - he really did deserve more than second place and I was so happy to read that Jax is expanding this series to give us Jonathan’s HEA! Can’t wait for more lovable rugby players!

Insta-love held together by a special and funny kid: Line Drive is an opposites attract, single dad, MM sports romance that’s driven by insta-love and a really special and funny kid.

James “Scooter” Harney is a professional baseball pitcher for the Denver Vikings and is out and proud. Not only is he an athlete, but he also owns a successful nightclub and recently purchased a bookstore in a small town. Even though James is a part of the Vikings team, he feels lonely but thinks he doesn’t have the time to give to a relationship. He’s been through a lot in his past that majorly impacted his life and while it’s mentioned in little bursts throughout the story, I wanted more insight into those times, not just passing moments of information dumps.

Ridley Holland is a high school baseball coach and a single dad. He’s overly protective of Phoenix and wants to shield him from all of the potential hardships he’ll face in the world because of his disability (he has cerebral palsy) or because he’s transgender. It created a riff between them and also caused Ridley to put everything he does for himself aside. James forces him to really consider his sexuality for the first time in his life and kind of causes him to go into a tailspin about expectations. I think Ridley was naive and kind of self-centered throughout the whole book - I expected more empathy from him but kept being let down when it wasn’t there.

James and Ridley don’t meet each other until about 25% into the book and I feel like I missed out on that time that they could have potentially been getting to know each other. Phoenix brings them together in a really unconventional way and they get close but Ridley throws a wrench in things with his inability to do anything to make himself happy. Their relationship felt really insta-lovey and I don’t feel like they got to know much about each other beyond surface level things. I think James was way more invested in their relationship and clearly wanted Ridley to be happy but Ridley was cutting James down and ignoring his feelings throughout the whole book.

Phoenix Holland was the stand out character in this book - he was funny and irreverent and really drove the action here. Without Phoenix, we would have no James and Ridley. Also loved the interactions between James and loved up Pietro. They were so sweet and wholesome and I really enjoyed seeing their relationship continue even though Pietro has Thierry in his life.

I’m really curious to see where things go with Orion’s story next - looking forward to it!

Amazing book: This book was everything!  Harry Potter references, appearances from Jeremy and AJ. An awesome college hockey team, a heroine who reminds me so much of myself it was scary at times, Uber steamy scenes and laughs that just kept sneaking in. I really enjoyed every second of this book.

A fantastic new series!: After devouring all of the Rosehaven Academy books by Leila James I was beyond excited to hear she had a new series!  Let me tell you this book didn’t disappoint. Leila is a master of twists, turns and of course a big cliffhanger as well.
Great sequel!: This was a great follow up book and took us through Maia’s journey. It’s fast paced and amazing!

history: 1699590583 B08W7DWW9D B0915BLFX5 B094TJKHND B09B4M7L2H 1913878155 B09SP1FPQ1 B09Y2T973W
review: A wonderful anthology for an amazing cause: So many wonderful short stories by some of my favorite authors and some new to me. Each book is amazing in this collection!

Loved!: I LOVED this book! It was the sweetest romance I’ve been looking for, full of some of my favorite tropes.

Maybell was such a great fmc. As someone who has her own ongoing alternate universe to make real life more palatable, I could really relate to her. I loved seeing her growth throughout this book, and how she was the one who helped Wesley when he needed it most with his anxiety.

Wesley was a dream. He was so grumpy at first, but as he grew more comfortable, i loved seeing his personality bloom and their romance develop. He was so sweet to her and GAH i could gush about it forever.

This will definitely go in my favorites pile! 💖

5 Shiny A** Gold Stars: It only took reading the first few sentences and my heart already hurt in the best possible way so I just knew I would love Rider and Cam‘s story.

I love their friendship, their support for each other, their banter, Rider's nicknames for Cameron, Cameron‘s obliviousness … and written so beautifully I highlighted A LOT.

One moment, one second in the whole of our lives was enough to change everything forever, a stick in the path that dislodged the wheels roving over it, launchingus into a new direction. One that would either send us on a path to paradise or crashing over the edge, there was no in between.

So many awwww moments,
a touching story with great characters (the bank, Maia, Cams mom)
– I‘m glad I found Duckie Mack, a new to me author and I‘m excited for book#2 more Crow yesss please

And this beautiful cover 🖤 I really need „All the stars“ in my paperback collection

review: A Beeutiful Story: This is a charming book teaching kids to not only believe in themselves, but also to be kind and understanding with others, even when they aren't so kind to you. As is often true, everyone has challenges, and try to remember that and treat people kindly.  In doing that you gain as a person, but also can gain friends.
The stories in the book and the author: Excellent book. Was a gift for my son who is a vegan. We have followed Jane Goodall for years and admire her.

A cracking good story: I've been a sucker for a good pony story for nearly forty years now so, when I saw review copies of M J Evans' new historical fiction novel, The Sand Pounder available for the blog tour, I was keen to take part. I previously enjoyed Evans' book Pinto! and really appreciate how she takes inspiration from little-known events in history, bringing the eras back to life for modern-day audiences. The Sand Pounder does just that so I learned about this wartime extension of the US Coastguard operations and also about the mistrust and paranoia against Japanese-American people in the aftermath of the Pearl Harbor attack. Evans cleverly brings these two story threads together.

I admit that I'm not within the target audience for The Sand Pounder as it is a young adult novel intended for younger teen readers, however as an adult reader I still found it to be an engaging read. The characters felt authentic, especially Jane/John whose gender-defying role reminded me of Sisters In Arms by Julie Wheelwright. Her interactions with the other characters allowed me to fully understand her motivations and how the situations she encountered helped to shape her perceptions of both herself and her country. (There are several tense moments within this story, but no disturbingly grim or gruesome depictions.) I thought that the use of letters was a nice touch too. This helped to keep central those characters who were physically in distant locations.

I'm happy to have had this opportunity to read The Sand Pounder and feel that the novel has wide appeal to readers from early teens upwards and to readers who like to learn their history while being entertained by a cracking good story.

Such an insightful and inspirational story: The Art of Traveling Strangers was a wonderfully rewarding novel to read and I am delighted to have had this opportunity to review a copy. Leading character, Claire, has such an infectious enthusiasm for the historic artworks that she and Viv go to see that I frequently found myself wishing that I could follow in their footsteps, together with such a knowledgeable guide. I hadn't considered myself a Renaissance or Medieval art fan prior to reading The Art of Traveling Strangers, but now I think I just never had the right teacher!

I loved both Claire and Viv as characters to spend time with. Neither is actually particularly likeable as a person, but the complexity and depth that Disigny gives to each one made them feel convincingly authentic and I really appreciated being able to watch how each helped the other to overcome their personal demons. This novel is set in the 1980s and clever details, such as European currencies prior to the Euro and unashamed eating of foie gras, gave the story its historical credentials, however the problems that Claire and Viv struggled to overcome are just as pertinent today. Claire's toxic relationship with her husband rang especially true with me so I could completely empathise with her difficulty in breaking free.

While The Art of Traveling Strangers does explore challenging issues surrounding personal identity and the best way for each of us to be ourselves, it manages to do do in a very readable and engaging way. My own struggle while reading was to make myself stop and set the book aside from time to time. Disigny's writing so swept me up into Viv and Claire's adventure that I became deeply invested in these characters and didn't want to leave them for a moment. I highly recommend this book for fans of Italian-set novels or of art history, for readers who enjoy stories about women finding their true selves, and for road trip fans. If you have ever fancied going on an Italian art tour, The Art of Traveling Strangers could be inspirational.

An entertaining mystery: Having so thoroughly enjoyed Lauren Carr's newest Mac Faraday mystery, Shadow Of Murder, last week I was keen to catch up on more books in this series. Readers who only follow through series in order had better look away now because I've jumped from book 14 to book three, the similarly titled Shades Of Murder! Although there is an overarching narrative timeline throughout the series, each novel contains a standalone cold case so I didn't find any problems reading backwards (so to speak).

Mac Faraday is yet to come to any agreements with his German Shepherd dog, Gnarly, in Shades Of Murder so their relationship is particularly fraught. Mac is also still coming to terms with his unexpected inheritance which gives an interesting angle to his interactions with Deep Creek Lake's generally affluent residents. One of the very richest is the focus of Shades Of Murder as his wife's murder is the cold case which captures Mac's attention. I loved the intricacies of this plotline. I did manage to work out what must have happened before it was revealed to readers, but Carr kept me eagerly guessing as to the how. The novel is so cleverly plotted with several fun distractions featuring animal characters including the aforementioned Gnarly as well as a wonderful cat, Irving, who resembles a skunk and has 'issues'.

Overall Shades Of Murder was an entertaining crime mystery Initially published almost exactly a decade ago, it was interesting to spot nods to concerns of the time and I liked the synchronicity of the cold case being a decade old too. I'm certain you will catch me reading more from the Mac Faraday series very soon.

An intriguing tale: The Beached Ones is the first of Colleen Story's fictional works that I have read although I have previously found her nonfiction books - Writer Get Noticed! and Your Writing Matters - interesting and well-written. The ambiguous opening chapters of The Beached Ones really captured my attention an intrigued me. Was this a magical realism novel, or a ghost story, or something else altogether? It turned out to be an ambitious and deftly crafted combination of all those aspects and I loved how Story allowed the reader's awareness to grow just in advance of Daniel's so we could share in his discoveries.

His childhood scenes were sometimes upsetting to read, especially when they veered towards neglect and abuse. Seeing this from a future where we already know something has gone haywire for Daniel gives these moments a deep sense of foreboding. I just had to keep turning the pages to find out what was going on! The dysfunctional family relationships are another aspect of The Beached Ones that give this fantastical story a solid and authentic grounding. Valerie is obviously not coping as a mother, so young Tony's insistence on clinging to the idea of her as a capable Mommy is heartbreaking, particularly when contrasted with Daniel's entrenched cynicism borne of so many more years of lived experience and a darker estrangement.

I recommend The Beached Ones as a powerful read for fans of family dramas and alternate reality tales.

very enjoyable: The book and show are sufficiently different that you can enjoy both. The writing especially takes off at the climax, making it even more effective.

The book didn’t have some of the logical problems I saw in the show, but the show was still fun too. I’d recommend both.

Thrilled to discover the books, thrilled to read them!: This is a great set of books about two very fascinating ladies. To my knowledge, the lives of these two sovereigns have not been examined in such depth.

I highly recommend the books as an addition to the libraries of those who have admiration for and an interest in Victorian/Edwardian England and the latter Romanov dynasty. Some readers may feel that here is a tendency to go a little bit too much in depth about history of their countries and families at that time, and the writing may seem to go off subject. HOWEVER, as an avid student, researcher and reader of both the Romanovs and the English royal family during the Victorian and Edwardian eras I must admit that it never hurts to refresh the memory and quite frankly, no one knows everything! I picked up a few new facts!

These books are also excellent for those who do not have a great deal of background knowledge of the era in English and Russian history. This knowledge certainly helps with the understanding of the very unique ladies and what made them "click" and respond to the people and events in their lives.

Very well done, as far as I am concerned, and I have very particular requirements for books I read. HIGHLY RECOMMEND the entire set! Only one criticism: multiple spelling and grammatical errors exist that should have been corrected prior to publication.

boring: Book started out ok but more than half was the legal jargon! I can deal with some but not as much as was in this book. I feel i wasted my time reading it!

Couldn't put this book down: I read this book in two days! I literally could not put it down! I saw the crime show about it and decided to buy the book and i am so glad that i did. The book was in really good shape looked as if it was new! I highly recommend this book!

Coloring Time: This is a beautiful coloring book!
I recommend this book 100%

I find myself rooting for her to get together with Xander each and every instalment in this series, but it doesn't seem to be in the cards. At least not yet. So much is happening with him and with her mom, I can't wait to read more in the next book!!

Not one of her best.....: I really like Sandra Brown's books but this one just didn't cut it for me.....too much going on, no suspense, kind of slow repetitive, didn't like the ending and just overall not a "wow" for me.  I felt that the "hero" spent too much time explaining to everyone what was going on instead of being the hero.  Nope, not one of her better novels.
