True History of the U.S.: Zinn presents the reader with a research-rich text documenting that at the expense of the other, this country was built.

Christmas Karen Does It Again!: Karen Schaler is my go-to author when I’m looking for Christmas books. Each story she writes has me smiling from beginning to end but full of intrigue. As the story unfolds, emotions are tugged at and in the end I’m left with warm, fuzzy feelings. Much like watching a Christmas movie her stories are light-hearted and easy to devour but, you don’t need to screen and can use your imagination. A Royal Christmas Fairytale reminded me of her screenwriting in Netflix’s A Christmas Prince but, as the story unfolds it becomes it’s own with unexpected twists, likable characters and Christmas  traditions. If you’re looking for something to read that will bring you back to the true meaning of Christmas look no further and buy this book!

Disappointing: I was very disappointed in this book. The subtitle is very misleading. Evidently, Dr. Z did set out to write his memoirs but didn't come close to finishing them and the supposed "Lost Memoirs" of the subtitle actually consists of the fragments he did finish fleshed out by reprints of a lot of his Sports Illustrated pieces.

Fun Adventure through Rocky Mountain National Park: Mystery in Rocky Mountain National Park is a book that hits a lot of the things I love- it's Middle Grade and a mystery, making it perfect to add to my library shelves for next year, it's a series so there will be more titles for everyone to dig into, and lastly, it's set in the National Parks, and for those of you that know me, you know that next to books my absolute favorite thing is to visit the National Parks.

I was stoked to get a copy of this book and even more excited to discover how good it really is. This story follows Jake who is on a summer road trip with his family and some family friends- before they leave, Jake is gifted a scrapbook, and a scavenger hunt complete with several mysteries to solve. It was his grandfathers, and now it's his to work his way through. I don't want to give too much away because the unraveling of the different threads is really what makes this book so much fun. I also really loved that the story jumped back and forth from the late 1880's when the area was being explored and settled (and fought over) and present day. It really gave some extra context not just to the story, but also to the area that eventually would become Rocky Mountain National Park.

You don't have to love the National Parks to get into this story, but I can promise that if you have a outdoorsy adventure kid (or if you were/are an outdoorsy adventure kid), this book will definitly land for you. What I founf the most exciting was that Johnson includes several illustrations and maps in the book- if you've been to Rocky Mountain National Park you might find yourself thinking "I've been there!" or "I know right where that is!" as you read. If you haven't been, but want to go, this book will give your kids some spots to find as you travel through the park. Several trails and landmarks are featured prominently in the book, and make for a great jumping off point. It would super fun for a family to take the hike to Alberta Falls and Bear Lake just like Jake, Wes and Amber do in the book. I know that while I read I kept thinking of the pictures I'd taken that almost exactly matched the illustrations in the book!

The other thing that Johnson does that I really appreciate is include both history of RMNP and the people referenced in the book and outdoor safety tips in the Author's notes. There were a few points in the book that I worried that it would be giving kids an unrealistic expectation of roaming the National Parks relatively unsupervised. In the story Jake, Wes and Amber are allowed to take hikes, ride their bikes, and generally explore on their own. Their parents take tons of precautions, but even still, heading out into the wilderness, even on maintained trails, can be dangerous. As the story progressed though, the parents shared more and more safety tips and in the Author's Note, even more safety information was shared. I really appreciated that this book was fun and full of adventure, but didn't ignore the very real dangers that you can come across out in the wild.

To wrap this up, I'll just say that if you and your family like mystery books, adventure and especially if you love to travel, this is a great book to pick up.

A Question of Evil: Charles F. French’s debut novel, Maledicus, is the first in The Investigative Paranormal Society series. The Society is comprised of three long-time friends, who couldn’t be more different from one another: Sam, a retired police officer, Jeremy, a retired antiques dealer, and Roosevelt, a retired history professor. Their common bond is a compelling interest in life after death. Each man has lost a loved one before his or her time, so their interest in the paranormal is not idle or academic curiosity. The stakes are high, and they’re very personal.

Before we meet Sam, Jeremy, and Roosevelt, the novel opens in ancient Rome with the introduction of one Lucius Antony Caius, a trusted advisor and procuror for the Emperor Caligula. For his own treachery, debauchery, and torture of innocents, he is known as Maledicus. He will become the evil entity with whom the Investigative Paranormal Society must do battle. And an evil one he is!

My favorite parts of the novel were the scenes set in ancient Rome with Maledicus. Anyone who thinks he could be a match for the evil (and insane) Emperor Caligula immediately has my attention. In addition, these scenes were well-researched and executed (pardon the pun).

I was surprised that Caligula dispatched Maledicus so quickly–although I probably shouldn’t have been, given Caligula’s reputation. However, I would like to have spent a bit more time with Maledicus in his earthly incarnation before he was sent howling into the netherworld.

The Investigative Paranormal Society are brought in when Maledicus sets his sights on the five-year-old niece of a local teacher. He proves an intractable enemy for Sam, Jeremy, and Roosevelt, as well as the people they enlist in their fight. In fact, there were several times I was genuinely shocked by what Maledicus did, which for me was one of the biggest strengths of the novel. Although shocking, the horror was not gratuitous or stomach-churning.

I would recommend Maledicus to readers who enjoy horror, the paranormal, and the question of the difference between an evil person and an evil spirit–which I found a fascinating one as I read the novel. If a person can be truly evil, how can this evil outlive its corporeal existence?

Curious Tales That Tantalize and Beguile!: As its subtitle indicates, Tales from the Annex is a collection of seven stories based on H.P. Lovecraft’s Herbert West character, followed by seven other tales.

I went into the collection not having read Driscoll’s Herbert West novels or anything by H.P. Lovecraft. I was very curious to see whether these tales could stand on their own, as well as to gain insight into why this character would inspire a contemporary writer to reanimate him in her own fiction.

About half-way through the Herbert West section of Tales from the Annex, I sought out and read Lovecraft’s original story: “Herbert West: Reanimator.” I had my answer: Herbert West is in the literary tradition of the prideful scientist who seeks to conquer death by bringing the dead back to life. Endlessly fascinating!

After reading the seven Herbert West stories, I was left with the same intriguing question prompted by reading ekphrastic poetry: For a work of art (or fiction) responding to another work, what is the relationship between the inspired work and its inspiration? Should the inspired work be about to stand on its own, or should the two work in tandem? (That said, I would recommend readers who haven’t read the original H.P. Lovecraft story read it before reading Tales from the Annex.)

The remaining seven tales are a mix of character sketches and speculative tales. “The Ice Cream Truck from Hell,” an imaginative riff on the siren call of the ice cream truck,” was one of the standouts for me. Another standout was “The Colour of Magic” about an exceedingly strange tenant of a basement apartment.

As a bonus for readers, Driscoll includes an Afterward detailing her inspiration for each story, which I appreciated and enjoyed.

Overall, the biggest strengths of Tales from the Annex are the excellence of the prose and the engaging nature of the voice. Both made for a very enjoyable reading experience.

I would recommend this collection to fans of H.P. Lovecraft’s Herbert West character, as well as readers who enjoy curious tales that tantalize and beguile.

Outstanding Collection of Contemplative Poetry: Merril D. Smith’s debut collection is poetry of the felt but unseen, those moments in life when we feel in touch with something greater than ourselves to which only poetry can give voice. Even then, we can never fully understand it. We just know it’s there, a form of faith we never knew we needed.

The title poem, “River Ghosts,” introduces the idea that our sensory experience of the natural world–”dusty grass,” “a gull’s laugh,” “cloud-light shimmering,” “spring-scented rain”--can evoke memories and dreams we thought we’d forgotten. However, it becomes apparent after reading the entire collection that we can only hear a “whisper in that dusty grass” if we are attuned to the wavelength on which it travels.

Smith does not limit her experience of the natural world to earth and water. A number of the poems look skyward to find hope, “the stardust / that connect us all” (“Ghost Links”).

Smith uses a variety of forms in the collection, including free verse, metered and rhymed verse, prose poem, and ekphrasis. In addition to demonstrating her mastery of craft, this variety of forms also follows the many moods of a river, depending on the season and the time of day.

Along with river imagery, the collection is structured to emphasize the fluidity of time and memory, with past, present, and future emerging, submerging, and emerging once again, often through the vehicle of love and grief.

River Ghosts ends with the standout of the collection for me–”Half-Concealed and Half-Revealed”--which begins “How will we remember these days / of grief and sorrow for our world.” As much as I would love to quote the last stanza and describe how it moved me, I won’t. I want readers to experience it for themselves.

Readers who appreciate contemplative poetry that evokes insights into their own experience in the world–as well as the experience of those different from themselves in time, place, or circumstance–will relish this collection and return to it often.
A Great Transaction!: I received the book, as described, in a very timely manner!
Great: Great book

Really interesting concept: I have never read anything before from this author but found the concept really interesting and new. I am not very knowledgeable in Voodoo or New Orleans culture and maybe that is why I found this so interesting and fun to read. While there were some grammar errors and misspellings I don't feel it took away from the story.

As others have said there is no hint as to why the MFC is stuck at this "carnival" and you find out when the MFC does. All in all great book and I can't wait for the second one!

perfect for my style of travel: Before and after seeing a sight, I want to look it up and see a brief history of it.  I have bought the Rick Steve's travel books in the past, and yes, they tell me what train to take or where to eat, but I don't care as much about that as I do the history and the stories surrounding a place or sight.  I like pictures too.  I think this book does go into transportation etc., too. but a lot of the time, it is out dated by the time the book is published anyway and I have the internet for that kind of stuff.

Lots of stories in a heap: The author made the mistake of trying to tell too many stories not very well. I frequently had the feeling, "Here we go again." Note that this book was written in the early 1960s. Prebble's history leaves off in the 1860s, whereas there were important events that occurred later, like the "Battle of the Braes" and the Glendale uprising of the 1880s on the Isle of Skye, or the Crofters Act of 1886. The Napier Commission receives scant mention. The book shows its datedness by the absence of interaction with apologetics for the clearances that have been written since Prebble's work. Find a better book on the subject.

Setting is Not Believable: The characters were  kind of interesting, although there was nothing extraordinary about them. However, I am a New Englander and I have to say that the setting is completely unbelievable. This is supposedly set in western Mass., but there is hardly any description of the weather or even the fall foliage! New Englanders love to talk about the weather, and western Mass. is jammed  with busloads of "leaf peepers" in the fall. The setting is very unrealistic. Also, are you serious about referring to the Mass pike as the "freeway?" This is not LA! If you are not from New England, please do your homework. Where are  the editors on this? It was jarring and the "sense of  place" was certainly not there.

Misogyny at its Finest: This book is fairly well written, although way too long. However, what jumps out most of all is Franzen's misogyny. His protagonist, the noble minister, Russ, has decided to abandon his wife, Marion, for a younger woman because his wife "has made herself unattractive to him" by gaining a few pounds. Marion has had four children and now weighs 140 pounds, which is probably considered an average, normal weight for a middle-aged woman. However, previously Marion looked like "Twiggy" and Russ adored her---because anorexia is so attractive! Franzen seems to think that this weight gain is all the justification his character of Russ needs to ditch Marion and pursue another woman! Did Franzen miss the lesson in creative writing class about not creating flat characters with shallow, stupid motives? I am trying to slog through this book but it's so long and epic I feel like I deserve a medal if I finish it.

Good book, could've been better: This book is great for fans of the Star Wars Expanded Universe on the one hand, in the sense that it includes stories that were previously only available in individual issues, so I really appreciate being able to now read them in this fiction collection and don't regret buying this book. On the other hand though, this book has some issues which is why I gave it a lower rating. This book arrived with creases on the cover. That is not why I gave it the rating I did. I gave it that low of a rating because it isn't obvious from a casual look at this book cover, especially the front cover, that this book includes stories from not just the Star Wars Expanded Universe (aka the Legends timeline) but also stories from the new canon timeline. Unless you're a fan of both timelines you'll be disappointed with the inclusion of stories from both. Still highly recommended for anyone searching for a specific story from the magazine who can't find or get the individual issue that contained it. I hope future volumes are SWEU/Legends only and that the Disney timeline stories are released separately.

Great book: I thought this book was great. I loved the intrigue and mystery. I thought it was great on how the cops were so confused and to be honest I was a little confused also. Once you start the book it is hard to put down. Can't wait to read the next book.
Fun Book!: Love this author and her stories.  Great character development, so key for me in enjoying the book.
Fun contemporary romantic comedy.: Great character development which is key for me in enjoying the book.
Repeat business does not mean loyal business: Shep has an expertise on getting Customers to emotionally want to return back versus just coming back out of habit

Perhaps for Comic Fans: I bought this because The New York Times called it "Witty and wholly original" and "surprisingly moving." Did the reviewer owe the author money? Was it opposite day at The NYT? Set in the world of comic books, I assume it was intentionally written in the potboiler, melodramatic style of the genre, but the dialog was eye-rollingly trite. It name checks comic world notables, films and songs of the 70s, the period in which it is set, but that's not enough to evoke the atmosphere of the time. The rickety plot only clatters along because characters repeatedly share a piece of information, darkly hint they know more, but then refuse to say without any apparent reason. The protagonist remains in jeopardy largely because she lies when it is obviously against her best interest. I was continually jolted out of the narrative by some implausibility. If it were a movie, I would be yelling at the screen, "Aw, come ON!" I can't think of a single element of this book that worked successfully. Perhaps it appeals to comic fans, but if you are seeking a juicy noir, peer down another alley.
Thriller with a difference: If you’re interested in Silicon Valley, or a fan of thrillers, this fast-paced debut novel is a fun read.

The Queens Reign: In Death May She Reign!
The code that the Queen must embrace and on the fly learn! Just when she thinks she has it figured out… Here comes the drama. This book moves you at a pace that makes it impossible to put down. Delivering wit on a level that will have you laughing out loud literally or leaving speechless.
As long time fan of the author i have to say this is my now favorite book of hers. These characters are amazing. I can not wait for the next book and look forward to seeing where this all ends!

Except the Unexcepted is not just a warning here: The chapter we all have been waiting for is here. Who is the Rofendo really? Who really the lovely people of CC? Dose Tempest have in her to kill her beloved sister or will her heart cost her throne? In TRUE Rourke fashion question are answered in the most bizarre of ways leaving you asking “WAIT, WHAT, HOW AND WHO” Divine Decay is not the ending I expected in the least, but it is the ending we needed. Once again Rourke has brought has her unique charm and wit so an untold story and given us character we love and characters we love to hate and of course character that we love to see time and again.

Easy to read historical fiction!: Loved the voice in this book and the setting. It felt real and authentic to its place in history but was still an easy read (a lot of historical fiction isn’t this way for me). Also, quite the adventure!!

It only takes one mouse...: In her first book after wrapping up The Unwanteds series, Lisa McMann has done a fantastic job of sharing the ups and downs of an unlikely friendship, the power of hope, and the unique bond of family.

Mutiny is a word Clarice had heard before but didn’t fully understand until is was happening around her. In the middle of the chaos, Clarice is separated from her only remaining family member, Charles Sebastian. Clarice promises to find Charles Sebastian again but how is that possible when everything seems to be going wrong and there is a cat who threatens your very existence?

“It only takes one mouse to believe in you, and I am that mouse.”

Edge of your seat kind of book: Lisa McMann has created a whole new cast of characters who will connect with young readers. 5 children with superpowers embark on a journey to discover the truth about their criminal parents. Students who are fans of super heroes, adventure, or magic are sure to devour this book. I cannot wait to put this book into the hands of my students! (I also can’t wait for book 2!)
Great series: I read the first three books as a teenager. I never was able to find the rest until now. I have never really been a fan of the fantasy genera but this changed my opinion.

the point though is that the book provides a loose framework for how to see lines and translate those lines into whatever it is you are looking for... a hobby, a mindfulness exercise, art, illustration, a passion

history: B00KEOF6Z6 B01N7OVQSI B000FC139K 0743286936 B00413QQ1E B072BLVM83 B008EKMDC6 B087PKF9LZ
review:
Why your American Dream isn't coming true: Bestselling author Kurt Andersen delivers an eye-opening examination of why the American Dream is so elusive for so many of us. There's no question but that our citizens are working harder for less (less money, fewer benefits, less job security, more questionable retirement), but how exactly did things flip around so completely from the 1950s and 1960s when you could expect to get a good job (even with a high school diploma), work steadily until retirement, then spend your later years with your feet up, doing what you'd been imagining through all those working years.

We might think it was an accidental confluence of economic and national events, but we'd be wrong, says Andersen. Behind it all is a cabal (my word) of right-wing, pro-wealth, long-term strategists who carefully steer the economy and political world to make sure the rich keep what's theirs *and* gain more, while you and I are stuck in the trenches, scrabbling for scraps.

Every hard-working, blue-collar worker and farmer who loyally votes Republican needs to read this book. They've been playing a long con that's so stealthy, we can all be excused for missing it.

Beginning many, many decades ago (1970, if I remember correctly), Milton Friedman, a University of Chicago "libertarian economist," published what became known as the Friedman Doctrine, which essentially said capitalist greed is good.

Now many of us agree with capitalism. But some of us also believe capitalism shouldn't abandon the workers: a decent wage so they can pursue the American dream is a necessary balance. But Friedman, and others who came later, essentially said, "We don't need to care about anybody *except* business owners and shareholders."

Doesn't sound so bad, but what it evolved into was slashing jobs (saves money and increases profit), gutting benefits (saves money and increases profit), sending jobs overseas (saves money and increases profit), among other things.

Andersen describes the Business Roundtable (see chapter 6) as consisting "only of the CEOs of the biggest businesses, and they were all expected to attend important strategy and decision-making meetings themselves and lobby elected officials personally." Essentially saving money and increasing profit, and looping in the legislature and courts to make it easier to do so.

Your life has been manipulated. If your American Dream has crumbled in front of you, read this book. If you wonder why the rich keep getting richer and the rest of us keep struggling, read this book.

The one fault of the book is that Andersen often writes in an academic style that makes parts of the book feel like reading a dry, elitist textbook. If you manage to struggle through those sections, the book is well worth it and you'll never see the economy, the government, the courts, nor your own life the same way again.

history: B00KEOF6Z6 B01N7OVQSI B000FC139K 0743286936 B00413QQ1E B072BLVM83 B008EKMDC6 B087PKF9LZ B0852NXWR5 B005EXS7E4
review:
Great start to a legal drama series: Rarely do I finish a novel and click the option to go directly to the Kindle store to find out about the next book in the series or another book by the same author, but I did that as soon as I finished "The Last Chance Lawyer."

The book is well-written, clips along at a decent pace, and has enough courtroom drama to keep a legal junkie like me turning pages. Despite how unlikeable attorney Daniel Pike is in the early chapters, I knew if the author was worth his salt he'd give us enough of a transformation that we'd be ready to root for him, and I wasn't disappointed. The cynical, hard-driven, crass Pike is quickly softened by the heart-wrenching predicament of a young immigrant girl who needs his legal expertise, his courtroom savvy, and his personal passion.

Beyond a compelling plot, the premise is intriguing enough to make me want to read more books in this series: the Last Chance Lawyers, a tight group of varied experts brought together by a mysterious Mr. K to take on cases on behalf of those who are down to -- you guessed it -- their last chance.

There are a few throwbacks I found a little distracting and they detracted a bit from an otherwise terrific book: Mr. K is just a bit too much like Charlie from "Charlie's Angels" -- a faceless voice who doles out the case in the beginning and renders his own verdict on the team when all else is said and done. Like any wise writer, Bernhardt anticipates readers will make this connection so acknowledges it in the narrative, but I still wanted something a bit more original.

Pike's approach to witnesses on the stand in the courtroom scenes felt like a nostalgic nod to Perry Mason -- badgering, preaching, making closing arguments rather than asking questions. I'm no lawyer myself, so perhaps this is permissable, but at one point I even thought it might have been more effective if Pike had approached one particular witness with a series of questions to get where he was going rather than starting with the point he wanted to make and working backwards.

Despite these weaknesses, which are pretty picky I admit, this book finally satisfied my need to read a great legal thriller in the absence of a handy Turow, Grisham or Connelly. Now on to the next book in the series!

history: B00KEOF6Z6 B01N7OVQSI B000FC139K 0743286936 B00413QQ1E B072BLVM83 B008EKMDC6 B087PKF9LZ B0852NXWR5 B005EXS7E4 B07NVVDB63
review:
Doing a detective's work: I've been a fan of Arthur Hailey for decades. Immersing myself in the detailed worlds of finance, medicine, hospitality, transportation through his characters and settings gave me what felt like an inside look at how those industries operated, and how those involved in them were affected. It was fictional expose.

All of that remains true with "Detective." Believable characters and strong plotting -- hallmarks of Hailey's work -- are found here.

What I'd forgotten, in all the years since reading one of his books, was his comprehensiveness. Every character's background is revealed. Motivations are examined. All of this detail makes for slower pacing. I found myself checking the page number. "How many pages is this book?" I wondered. Unfortunately, that meant I was thinking about the reading I was doing, rather than being completely absorbed in the book.

I followed Hailey's book with "Burden of Proof" by Scott Turow, and the pacing in that is likewise glacial. Perhaps it was a convention of the times in which they were written and originally published: big books, expansive breadth, hundreds of thousands of words.

But in the case of "Detective" I can excuse Hailey by saying he was ahead of his time. If I read the book on a meta level, I see he's doing exactly what his characters are doing: examining everything, turning over all the stones, considering all the possibilities, weighing all plausible motives. Hailey, in researching this book, had to use the skills of detective to ferret out the nuances of the job and workplace; he had to assume the mantle of someone figuring things out, just as his characters do in the book.

So we have two layers of detective work going on in this tome: the work of the characters, and the work of the writer. Together they take us deep into the world of police work where things do go on and on and on, and where patience is key.

Tipping Point will make you rethink what you know about modern warfare.: Today's headlines are consumed with news that 1,000's of Russian troops have staged on the border with Ukraine. It's a clear sign that we live in a tenuous time, where a simple miscalculation could spark a global war. Tipping Point: Escalation throws us into the world of politics and war, pitting the United States against China in a race for economic and military supremacy. Leaders of both countries understand the cost of attacking their adversaries homeland so they fight a proxy war throughout the oceans. John O'Brien keeps us at 10,000 feet with an occasional ground level glimpse through his characters eyes. His storyline keeps you guessing what the next page will bring. For his first foray into this genre, O'Brien has done a fantastic job while playing out what could be real life scenarios. I'm eagerly awaiting the next book.

Immediate suspense!: This book was wonderful! Fans of Sullivan's other books that take place in Elan will really enjoy this one too. The new characters are at once familiar and unique.

The book started off with suspense from the start, and it never really slowed down.

While the author says it can be a stand alone novel, I loved the easter egg nods to Legend of the First Empyre, and I suggest reading those first.

Continues to surprise: I have enjoyed so many of these books.  This continuation of self and family discovery is as enjoyable as ever.  You laugh, you wonder a little, and you get swept into the story.
Creative and Fun: The world that Vall created this time is unique and the characters are memorable.  I have enjoyed reading this series, and I am looking forward to book 8.

Augustus roared, " Varus where are my legions": This true event enhanced by the authors story telling brings to life the slaughter of three legions with the loss of their Eagles. This major disaster stopped Rome from expanding the Empire beyond the Rhine river.

There's lots of tension and angst between them - Colt likes messing with Logan and Ash, but has no intention of doing anything, (past with a cheating ex). After finding out the truth about how badly Logan treats Ash, he confronts him to do better, that she deserves better. Even though Logan and Colt have been friends since they were kids, they are opposites in a lot of aspects - the biggest being how they treat others. Every time Logan was mentioned, I feel like I had a permenant scowl on my face until Colt was brought up and I was being swept away by him just treating her like a person. ~New book boyfriend alert with Colt!~ Logan's going on my list of characters I hate/extremely dislike.

Great tribute: Loved most the music from AC/DC way back in the days. This book is a great treasure troll of information and "did you know" about a great band.

Awesome children's book: Love the book! Vivid and colorful illustrations and easy to read large letters. Great storyline and adventure on trying to find out why grandpa is grumpy. What made grumpa happy, also makes me happy!

Excellent tool: I have always wanted to learn more about speaking Spanish. Although this book is not a language teaching tool, it does help in how Spanish words are used in interpreting. Most of the jargon went way over my head, but I was able to gleam lots on useful information.

Great self-defense instructions: I did not care for the format of the book but it did contain some great self-defense information, techniques, and ideas for ladies and others. The mental aspects discussed were of great interest because I have a family member who is non-combative and very shy. Perhaps that will help her.

Excellent insight and vision for the future: To say this man's vision and passion for a better Africa is "nice" is a huge understatement. He dissects, with pinpoint accuracy, the many issues of the past with rulers, powers, and authorities. But in the midst of it all, he never loses all hope that situations, aided my those in power and those out of power, will one day become better through investments aimed at a better life for ALL the people of Africa.

Excellent book: Being from the "country", the "broken" language the writer used throughout the book made me feel homesick. I could vividly imagine Granny. Mama, and characters like Locke and others doing and saying those exact things. Great character develop and storyline, and conversation development. Very interesting story and action scenes. Did not notice any editorial errors. Great book.

Good information: I have always wanted to travel the US and visit famous sites during a road trip. This book is packed with good information about places to go and things to do throughout the US. Good travel companion.

Very good book: Patience is the key for appreciating this wonderfully written book. Characters are very well developed and the storyline and plots are meticulously designed for maximum effect. I did not notice any editing or formatting errors. Very professionally done. Good book.

Could be much better: I was very disappointed that after all the author build up, touting the experience and knowledge of the author, and several character witnesses at the beginning of the book, that he only wrote about 9 pages, one chapter out of 34, and six points about teamwork that do not reflect the rich experience. It is hard to read 34 people who write differently, share different points with different emphasis. To me, its like reading 34 books. Some of the points made by the 33 other writers were very good. I disagreed with others such as "nothing has meaning until you give it meaning..." Really?  Good book but could be much better.

Great writing style and build: The book builds slow just as a mystery should. I was surprised to learn many things just from the opening chapter--things that made a person invisible from clothing, choice of food during ordering, to even hair styles. Sounded like a great spy movie with some interesting characters. I could see myself and several people I know in some of the characters--the high-maintenance blonde with the attitude, and more. Characters were built with great details and the flow of the writing never got off-track. Did not notice any editing or formatting errors. Very good book.

Action packed with great characters: The opening of the book started my imaginative juices flowing. The action started strong and temporary let up during periods in the book, but was consistently exciting. I love the main character and can see some of my veteran family members in him. Great character development with humor in areas to ease the tension. My only small wish is that the book was written in past tense instead of present tense to make it stronger (using words such as "he sees"  to "he saw." Other than that, an awesome read.

Excellent read for youth: This scary and suspenseful thriller for youths is worth the read. I love the writing style and how the characters were developed and presented to the reader. The book flowed well and the actions scenes felt like a real surprise as opposed to being forecasted. Did not notice any editing or formatting issues. Highly recommended.

Great information: We all can see what major issues are taking place due to supply chain problems and this book, I believe, lays out a great set of plans and actions that can be taken to lessen the supply problems. My only minor issue with the book (ebook at least), is the formatting and font choice. I believe a great editor and book designer could bring major improvement. Other than that, great book.

Great for a guided reading with kids: I came across this book entirely by accident while looking for books with my daughter in the local library, and we enjoyed it so much that I decided to buy it.

I'm aware of the "slant" in the text, but I'm not triggered by it as some of the negative reviews here seem to be, and find it possible to skip certain sections if I need to.

What I find best about it (and have been looking for a long time, and unable to find elsewhere), is
(1) a sense of "a coherent whole" -- it's nice to have _some_ sort of "a story of the world", and while nothing is perfect, this at least aims to provide one
(2) an easy and informal style -- I've found lots of books and materials trying to present a lot of disparate information, but they end up being very boring
(3) engaging! -- I like having books around to reduce screen time, and it's a struggle, but she actually enjoyed the style of this book, the way "the story progresses".

Great way to do some math together: Explicit exercise books don’t go down well.

This is a great “casual” way to do math together with kids.

(Without being useless, like an unfortunate percentage of books out there)

LOVED IT!!: Wrenched Fate is my first foray into the Bluegrass Security series by PJ Fiala.  With a wonderful, strong, independent heroine, Dani Stewart, who was caught in a rough spot between two rival drug cartels, it’s up to Bluegrass Security co-owner Jeremy Dirks to try and keep her safe.  I loved the interaction between these two main characters.  When Dirks asks Dani out, everyone in their small town knows before they even started the date.  But keeping her safe turns out to be harder than Dirks counted on and it leads them to realize that they truly in love.  Thank you, PJ, for a great love story with a twist.

Then I realized this was an anti-hero book.  There are no good guys, only bad & worse guys.  I gave it four stars because I liked the characters in the other books more than I liked these.  That said, by the end of the book I was rooting for the new guys.  The ex-cop was a nice addition to the cast.

Fantastic!  Intellectual, thought-provoking mystery: Gamache stories are always great reads, but this one is exceptional.  Although some of the topics are disturbing and serious, the twists and turns keep the mind and heart actively engage throughout. Louise Penny's writing is, as always, sophisticated and lyrical. And her descriptions of cozy Three Pines make me wish I could visit and sit by the fire with hot chocolate, even though I hate the cold!  One of those books you can't put down, but also don't want to end.  Can't wait for the next Gamache installment.

Another win from Lisa Jewell: Thank you atriabooks & netgalley for my copy of this book in exchange for my honest review 💙

Happy pub day to one of my auto-buy authors! Lisa Jewell’s books are so fun and the perfect domestic mystery/thrillers.
Her latest ‘The Night She Disappeared’ is no exception.

Jewell tells the story of a young mother who goes missing after a night out through several points of view. All great characters and perfect pacing that kept me turning to the last page (seriously. I read this one in a day lol)

You want domestic suspense? Read this!: I will probably always pick up books by this duo. Their books do not disappoint and this one was no exception.
Solid domestic suspense.
I LOVE a dual perspective novel, and this one was perfect because we get two very different and interesting characters. Very well written and fleshed out women,
I also love the slow unfolding of the drama this book brings. A slow burn is a hit or miss for me and this is a hit.
If you are looking for a page turning domestic suspense this is definitely one you need to pick up.

Fantastic Read: I could not put this book down. From the first sentence to the final line, this book was so good. Reggie and her sister Dena, both strong women making their way in this crazy world where love just seems to evade them. Our girls are together with family in the tiny town of Wishing Tree where Christmas prevail in all things. How crazy that snowmen decorations can’t be displayed until the first snowfall and that snowfall has a very distinctive definition.

This was such a good read from Reggie and Dena to the men who enter their lives the story flows so smoothly you will be captured from the beginning. And let’s not forget Miss Belle and her rather extensive wardrobe.

Friends, don’t let this book get away from you!

Great read!: Good read on these cold, rainy evenings. Another dysfunctional family – wife and mother, cheating husband, grown children. Add in a friend on the verge of destroying everything. It doesn’t take much to join Robyn’s support group and feel the pain of believing you have basically let your life go in support of your spouse and children. Now divorced, basically an empty nester in a big, expensive house, struggling with the next chapter in her life Robyn runs away to a loving Aunt to get some perspective on her future.

True Susan Mallary form the story takes unexpected turns – tears and laughter – Robyn’s family follows her to Lillian’s where she is able to find the peace and joy in discovering hidden talents, an exciting pathway forward, and a retired military man.

Bravo Susan, another best seller!

It will break your heart.: There are over 27K reviews of Shuggie Bain at the time I'm writing this, and I doubt many will even look at this review. I feel compelled to write one, however, because Shuggie Bain is one of the best books I've ever read. Stuart is a patient writer, conveying poignant scenes in incredible sensory detail. Each scene leaves an imprint and dominant impression. For all of the pain he communicates, he also illustrates the human capacity to absorb and withstand, if not overcome, it. I've read several reviews criticizing Stuart's portrayal of mining towns. I got a sense that he wasn't trying to portray mining towns in general, but only this one--the Pit--in particular. Each character, even the minor ones, were fully developed in all of their grace and cruelty. And although the novel is named for Shuggie, Agnes and her withered, angry heart, looms over the novel. Her character is finely drawn, demonstrating the scourge of alcoholism upon the human psyche. I found myself furious at Eugene, one of the more likeable characters, for his misunderstanding of the power of addiction, and how he refuses to stand by Agnes in spite of his fault in returning her to the bottle.

After I read the novel, I set it aside and, hours later, cried my heart out for Shuggie, for Leek, for Agnes. That's what a good writer does: moves us, takes us to places we've never been, opens our hearts to love.

Honest, engaging, informative: This book was incredibly informative about the struggles and joys disabled people face. I appreciated the heartfelt honesty in this book as well as the intellectual rigor; not only are legal issues regarding disability discussed, but also the moral ramifications of these laws.

Classic Tyler plus cultural insights: I've always enjoyed Anne Tyler's books--since my teen years!--and this one is no exception. She details domestic life with heart, wit, and humor. I appreciated the insights into Iranian culture she illustrates here. Maryam and Dave are my favorite characters
This book got me out of my reading slump: I was hooked from beginning to end.
Good Read: Well said and truthful.

The best book I've read this year: Clear, detailed explanation of how Autocracy, and with it the craziness of the alt-right, is taking over in swing states across America. Terrific, terrific read. And a strong list of suggestions at the end.

A Carefully Woven Tale of Courage!: Once again Erika Robuck has done her homework and crafted a page turning story.  She masterfully tells the two tales of these heroic women whose lives intersect in history.  Bravo!
This is a good history of the evolution of the Pullman Railcars.: This is a good history of the evolution of the Pullman Railcars.  It is full of photos and illustrations.

Loved it!: This book took me a little while longer to get into than I thought, but I loved the characters! I got a more emotional vibe at the end rather than a thrill vibe but I actually liked it because I felt closure from the events that happened. I think Stevens writes wonderfully and I liked how the chapters were separated by two characters so you could see what was going on all around the town of Cold Creek.
Great writing Held my interest: Josie and her detectives and her family life intertwine makes for good reading She is a good author Love the series

Hot, spicy, and leaves you wanting more!: I devoured this book! Mafia romance is becoming a favorite subgenre for me, and this book cemented that! Kier is the type of alpha I love. He pushes Sailor’s boundaries but doesn’t actually cross them, which I appreciate. I loved seeing Sailor grow back into herself and work on figuring out who she was after her husband. I liked both of them learning more about themselves and what they brought out in each other. And that ending!! I absolutely can’t wait for the second book! If you’re into mafia, possessive alpha anti-heroes, and smart-mouthed heroines who won’t back down; you definitely should check this one out!!!

Best Lola Glass book yet!!!: As much as I love Lola Glass's contemporary/urban fantasy, her second world fantasy is always the greatest. This book was no exception, and has won my top spot for favorite Lola book!! I could not put it down. The world building was really cool. I liked the concept of all the different packs and how shifters work in this world. All shifters have a wolf form, and most have even more. And then there's the two queens- the human queen and shifter queen. The magic was really interesting too.
The best part is of course the characters. Mesa is the human queen forced into hiding when a rogue pack attacks, killing the shifter queen. Now she's on the run and hiding, but found by the fearsome Blood Pack. The rumors of the blood pack paint them as a ruthless group lead by an even more terrifying alpha. But what Mesa finds isn't the cutthroat, blood-soaked land she expected. She's taken care of and even starts to make friends, all while trying to keep her true identity secret. But she catches the blood alpha's eye. Trying to protect her identity and play the part of a shifter being magically punished while also trying not to fall in love with the deadliest shifter in history...
I loved Tuslan too. I liked that he wasn't the jerk rumors made him out to be. He protects his pack and isn't afraid to dole out justice when needed, but he cares for his people and wants to keep them safe. And I loved seeing him and Mesa grow together. It's not as romance heavy as some of her other books, but it's there. And it's a lot of building up to more in the next book. I liked that it's not insta-love or love just because of the magical connection. Mesa still has autonomy and a voice.
I really loved the other Blood Pack characters and Mesa's growing friendships with them. I definitely hope we see more of them in the coming books.
So much happened at the end of the book, and I'm so excited to read the next one!! I can't recommend this book enough! If you like shifters, unique magic, great world building, and fresh takes on tropes like fated mates, you'll love this one!!!

Exciting and fun read!: I loved this story back in its Vella days, so I was so excited to see it get a full book!! This story is another take on fated mates, where werewolf men have no control and start “hunting” the second they lock eyes with their human mate. Tea and Jesse were such great characters. I liked watching her try to understand this new side of the world she uncovered. Tea is super independent and doesn’t let go of what she wants. I like how their relationship developed, especially with Jesse being stuck in wolf mode for so long. This is a great new series start, and whether you read it on Vella or not, you should definitely grab this one!

I’m loving this story!: This book picks up right where we left off in book one. I was personally victimized by the ending of book one, so I was dying for this one. And it did not disappoint in any way!! Leia and Julie are so good at writing high stakes, action packed stories. And the characters!! I loved getting to know all of them even more through the story, and I love so many of them. I really enjoyed the new characters in this book! And of course seeing more romance develop. I liked the nice romantic moments we got in this one with all the action.
And omg the ending. You’ll just have to read it for yourself because no spoilers!!
I’m already dying for book three! You absolutely need to read this series because it’s so dang good! You’ll get sucked in immediately and won’t be able to put it down!

Loving this series!!: This is a great continuation from book one! It’s so good. I love the world building. This feels like a new and unique take on werewolves and I like that. Also Kass and Keaton are my favorite. I love how their relationship is building and the way they compliment each other. As usual, I finished this in one sitting. It’s so engaging and keeps you hooked from the start. This one is fast paced and definitely a series I can’t recommend enough!! Go start it now if you haven’t yet!

Fun and cute!: I always love Lola’s characters and the believable romances. This one is no exception! I really liked the contrast of Ford and Ebony’s story to Tea and Jesse. I like that these two moved faster than the previous book, because it gave us more insight into the mate hunt and how it all works. I liked learning more about the pack dynamics too. As always, it was fun, spicy, and cute! I definitely enjoy that this series is coming out not just on Vella because it was nice to binge all at once! I definitely want more from this world and more stories of the other guys in the pack!

Excellent ending!: This series was excellent from start to finish! I just loved the characters, the world, and the plot. This is just as action packed as the others. I love Tatum and Gage and I’m sad to see all these characters go! There’s funny moments, heart pounding moments, and sweet moments throughout. I loved all the action in this one. And seeing our Angel Gang develop and grow even more. This series really is a masterpiece and I can’t recommend it enough! Don’t miss out on it!! Leia and Julie are two incredible authors and this collab proves it!

I’m absolutely obsessed now.: After the ending of book one, I was a little nervous for this book (especially with the title!) but I’m really happy with the way this one went. It picks up right where book one ends and keeps you hooked. I liked learning more about the world and the characters. The tension is so so good in this series. I really can’t wait for book three, and the cliffhanger was killer!! It’s one of those books where you keep trying to swipe through for more pages but there isn’t any. I really liked the development between Seren and Kadoc. Their growth is wonderful. And I love the side characters too. I can’t wait to see how this all ends!

Excellent series ending!: I’m sad to see this series go, but I loved this ending! Lola Glass always writes such real relationships. It’s my favorite thing about her books. I love how she handles trauma and sensitive subjects too. Seren has a lot to heal from and I love that her mate and their relationship isn’t the magic fix for her. I feel like that happens too often in books, so it was nice to see Seren have to work through things herself, with the help of her friends and family. I also loved the found family in this one. Seren learns to trust the family she’s found, and realize that they love her for who she is. There’s plenty of action and adventure in this one too, but as usual the relationships and friendships shine! I can’t recommend these books enough!!

Love this series!: I’m really loving these Mate Hunt stories. Del and Rocco’s story was great. I liked the difference in Del and Rocco’s mate journey. She was quick to accept his wolf and I liked that they grew a friendship before a relationship. I’ve liked how each of these stories show a different way of handling the mate bond. Im excited to see this series continue and definitely recommend this one!

Great banter: Though I hadn’t read the first book in the series, I had no trouble following the action here. I loved the banter between characters, the new take on the cozy mystery and the plotting was very good. I enjoy humor in mystery and appreciate the subtleties here with family dynamics. I will read more of this series for sure.

Eerie vibes, monsters: McMahon’s latest book has all the weird and strange vivid elements you expect of her work. I’m constantly impressed at how she writes in such a dark but also captivating way that you find yourself just reading and reading.

Like many of her stories, we have dual timelines: 1978 and 2019. In 1978 we see Dr. Helen Hildrith’s unconventional treatment of patients at a creepy treatment center where she lives with her grandchildren after their parents were killed in a car accident. Vi and Eric love Monsters. They secretly have a Monster Club where they read everything they can about monsters, watch all the movies when they can sneak into the drive in and have a hideout in the woods. When their grandmother (Dr. H) brings home a girl, Iris, who has obviously experienced some kind of trauma. Eventually, Vi and Eric invite Iris into their club and together they work on The Book of Monsters where they detail all that they know about monsters. Iris doesn’t talk; she wears her clothes inside out. She looks a lot like Vi. What happened to her? Where did she come from? Why does she wear that orange hat everywhere?

2019: Lizzy Shelley is the host of a popular podcast, “Monsters Among Us”. The latest case has her returning to Vermont, close to where she lived as a child and where a teenage girl is missing.

That’s all the summary I think you need. There’s a lot of 70s references and nostalgia. Like all of McMahon’s books, it’s big on atmosphere. You will notice nods to Frankenstein but this is so much more than that. I love the way McMahon layers her narratives and here we have excerpts from The Book of Monsters and from a book called The Helping Hand of God: The True Story of the Hillside Inn throughout the narrative.

It’s so good. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

More than romance: I knew Emezi’s writing from the other genres they’ve written in, so I should have known that they would write something that defied categorization. This novel is a brilliant commentary on grief and loss but also love, consent, and navigating relationships.

I’ve never read anything like this. There’s something so incredibly inviting about Feyi and her world. She may be closed off to her lovers but not to us as readers. I loved and recognized parts of her immediately. But of course, there is also so much I learned from her as the story progresses.

There’s more than romance, sex, and grieving, here, but I have a hard time describing exactly why and how Emezi works. I’m so glad to have read this.

Important YA Romance: As a girl who grew up a fan of sports, especially football, I was excited to read this. Adler captures the difficulties of being out in high school, of living up to unrealistic expectations, and of the deep misogyny and homophobia in sports, particularly in high school. That isn’t to say this romcom is a bummer; it’s sharply funny at times and plays a bit with stereotypes (quarterback/cheerleader) in refreshing ways. But it doesn’t shy away from honest portrayals of misogyny and homophobia which were difficult to read in places. So know it isn’t light and fluffy going in.

This is a clever book with lots of queer representation and characters you want to root for and some against. I didn’t love the redemptive-ish arc that some of the characters get after being such villains and I wish there were more actual sports scenes, but the ones that are present are well done.

Some of Amber’s choices and her approach to relationships felt a bit messy but I also understand she is trying to work it out for herself and is a teenager who feels like there is a lot on the line.

The pacing felt unfocused at times, particularly with so much internal commentary that is sometimes repetitive and doesn’t always move the action. Near the end of the book, the action is tighter and cleaner and near perfect, though. And I really got into the story at 45%.

Overall, this is an important and readable YA sapphic romance. I would recommend this to sports fans, especially queer ones and to readers looking for bi and polysexual and queer representation especially.

More depth than expected: This is not your light-hearted rom/com despite its use of tropes (fake dating, forced proximity). There’s more emotion and depth as well as some intense subject matter: addiction, invasion of privacy, death of loved ones.

This is a slow burn romance with lots of tension.

Grey is an actress coming off of a successful series but she’s hoping to get a movie she’s writing with her best friend made and struggling to get meetings with the right people. While she’s waiting to hear about a blockbuster film she’s up for, she’s restless and spends most nights alone. She is set up with Ethan who needs some positive publicity as he’s planning to make a comeback after been a teen star and successful actor, writing a script and starring in a film with his best friend, Sam who died tragically. Ethan’s marriage ended and he’s been hiding out, getting drunk ever since.

This is partly a story about redemption and partially about grief and loneliness and the dark side of fame. There’s romance but not comedy. I’d say this is women’s fiction with open door scenes. It’s tough not to root for Grey and Ethan. The conversations they have seem real, even the snarky ones. The side characters are diverse and lovely, adding to a rich set of relationships in Grey and Ethan’s lives. I particularly appreciate how Ethan’s ex is portrayed. I’d read a spin off book about her finding love after her divorce from Ethan! I loved her!!

I read this quickly, and found myself needing to know what happened. The only reason this isn’t 5 stars is that I wish I’d had a little more of the healthy relationship rather than just the epilogue and in that the pacing felt off. I wondered if there was more and chapters were cut.

I don’t think the cover does this justice, at all. I don’t dislike it but I find illustrated covers don’t always reflect the serious content.

4.5 stars
Great: Wonderful🤩
Great: Wonderful🤩
Great: Fast delivery and accurate, most popular book for my kids now🎉
Quick: I purchased 4 series for my daughter, she loves this book, thank you

excellent book: Stuey was a legend of the card games and a genius having been raised around gambling from a young age..Surprised I never heard about him all these years..The book is very well written and if u like gambling stories u will appreciate the story of 'the kid' whose life was much to short.

A promise is a promise: I have been waiting for Apollo’s book since Drew’s book came out. I really loved how patient and caring he was towards April. And I love how much April grew as a person. Marie James never disappoints.

I received a free copy of this book via Booksprout and am voluntarily leaving a review.
Single mother: I like this book but it’s not like the other cerberus books. I also wished that their was more of an epilogue on Lucy and Snakes life.

Loved it: I have loved every book in this series, and this new edition did not disappoint. It was well worth the wait.

Dalton and Becca had an intense connection and I really enjoyed the fact that they really got to know each other. I also really loved how strong Becca was.
Bodyguard: Piper is a popular influencer and Tristan a quiet brooding military vet. When a deranged fan comes after Piper, Tristan has to do everything he can to protect the woman he loves.

Alpha male: I really enjoyed reading about Ethan and Faith. Ethan is a very protective guy and Faith is very strong willed attorney.

Trouble seems to follow Faith around, when unexplained things start happening will he be able to save her?

Steamy: Finn and Lily only know each other from the gym and although Finn wants more he doesn’t want to date someone from the same building he lives in.

Lily is just trying to make ends meet for her and her three kids when Finn accidentally gets her kicked out.

He tries to fix it, but he doesn’t realize she is a mom. Lily’s kids are hilarious and Finn’s reactions are just as funny.

Second chance romance: We met Grace in a previous book and now she is all grown up. Grinch and Grace used to date while they were in the military. When Grace is kidnapped, Grinch will do anything to save her.

review: Emotional: From the beginning there was so much heartbreak from Harley. Him trying to learn how to be a single father and trusting a newcomer with his daughter. Then having to deal with his attraction to Ali. Ali had her own demons that she had to  work through.

review: Spicy: The perfect ending to the BSB series, so spicy and definitely a page turner. I’m sad to see this series end, but it’s great to see everyone get their happily ever after.

history: 1696433800 1702765741 1651312982 1711733695 B085RTHYNB B087L4KCH5 B08B3334TD B08HQ6WP85 B08KTHXPV1 B08NF2Z8JG B08QBY9N8L B08T4DGK31 1637820380 B08XZQ9DQF B093CD5ZT6 1946087440 B0977Q35MB 1637820127 B09DZXQ2QL B09FC9YPJL B09HWVX7K1 1637820305 B09NRDMK8N B09RK6BPXK B09SNWBTV1 B09Y9BVJ35 B0B289TW1R
review:
M/M romance: Ever since we met Landon and Rick in previous books, I couldn’t wait to read their story. What a surprise to find out that they were going to end up in love.

After a falling out and avoiding each other they are now forced to be in the same dorm room. Lots of angst and growing up before they get their happily ever after.
Great Read: This was really a great book, well written. Deeply enjoyed the honesty of Andre Agassi. He told his story in an interesting way. I even started playing tennis!!
Incredible!: Absolutely love this book. The patterns ate fantastic, and easy to follow the directions.
Excellent instructions: If you have ever had problems with your crust this book is for you. How to for different types of pies. Easy to understand and follow.

Absolutely Love: Absolutely love the designs. Be careful of the patterns. Starry Night templates do not fit a 10" block. Some readjusting of the pattern pieces is needed for use with the 10" print block. Make one first before cutting all of the fabric out of something else.

One of the best books I’ve read this year!  Tearjerker!: One of the best books I have read this year!  I laughed, I cried and all other emotions.  At first I didn’t know if I would finish this book, but once I got 50 pages in, I couldn’t put it down!  When Emma’s husband, Jesse, leaves on a business trip, things are going good, but then he goes missing.  Then Emma runs into another friend from high school, Sam.  Things start improving for Emma and she starts to LIVE again, but all of a sudden word is that her missing, declared dead husband is actually alive.  What should Emma do? What choice will she make?  Stay with Sam or return to Jesse?  Which would you choice?

good adventure: a truly interesting adventure-mystery-cultural study
I will purchase the rest of the series. A very good read.

Perfect for the age range: This color by numbers book is perfect for the age range. The drawings are cute and appealing with a variety of complexities from very easy to some that will take a little more time. Even better, there are fascinating facts for kids to read and learn.

This is a really sweet color by number book.

Favorite book of all time: Edenbrooke was the first regency romance I read and remains, after all these years, my very favorite. Marianne and Philip are wonderful and the story is so immersive and keeps you flipping pages. The emotions are written so well and the chemistry between the characters will make your heart race.

A short post war/ Christmas special story: After all the action and plot from the previous book (A Court of Wings and Ruin), I honestly knew it couldn’t get better. Not disappointing, but nothing alike the other 3 books. This book takes place after the war of course Feyre and her friends just “won”, trying to rebuild a new world, in an attempt to readjust and savor their victory despite the casualties and grieve. It does open a new thread added to the fact that the wall is gone and the love/hate relationship between Nesta and Cassian, so i’m waiting the next book.

Love it!: It’s so good and very graphic. Empowering women, Sarah did a great job with this book, where the protagonist is Nesta. The story clicks with the previous books, adding more plot and new relationships, but above everything all the factors a person must go through healing. It is amazing the way the author Sarah awakens emotions through written words. Either you like Nesta or you hate her, you’ll fall in love with her character.

Deromanticizing the battle of Little Bighorn: The tricky part about history is, there’s always two sides and pretty much we always learn or listen to one. The author in this book couldn’t be more accurate with that, I’m always up to some update in history which in many cases can be proved with technology or some archeological discovery; science has gone a long way updating knowledge. Nevertheless, when it comes to war we only rely on existent writings and the longer it goes the more difficult it is to get more information about it, so when a “refresh” of a battle comes, I’m all about it. This author not only focus his attention to praise what is already written and sets new hypothesis of what might, might not happened. He brings new testimony to deromanticize  this battle at Little Bighorn. I love how this author is so open about political agendas and culture. I can say my favorite part of this book is how rich in native American information is, the introduction might seem a little reluctant, but as it goes, it gets interesting and very informative. Moreover, the way he stripped everything about the tactics Cluster made, and all the mistakes that took him to the fate he was taken is something I really liked.

Go Back In Time To Jamestown, New York: What a great chance to follow Lucy and Desi back east to visit Ball's hometown. Jamestown, New York. Once Ball left Jamestown her return visits were fairly rare. In fact, this visit, in the mid-50s, would have been her last until a proposed return in the summer of 1989 which would have been after her death. Except for this, a combination business holiday, she would never return again. This book captures this visit in detail and gives you a look into what it was like to have a fairly plain and quiet city in Western New York turned upside down to honor one of their own.

Ball and Arnaz arrived in town via a local helicopter, which in those days was a pretty big deal. A cold, steady rain came down on the town to greet them, along with thousands of people. A parade thru the streets led off the visit. It was if Jamestown was getting a Royal Visit.

And for a few magic days, they were. And this book records that visit at a level fit for a Queen.

During their stay Ball & Arnaz made the rounds. The book details all of those with some great pictures and comments.

The famous couple arrived in town to promote their newest movie venture. It would debut in Jamestown, a first for sure. The picture turned out to be a dud, at the box office and critically. Yet, for one magic night it was the toast of the town and magic was in the air. It was a shame that didn't carry over to the public at large.

This is a great book to read if you're a fan of Lucy, Desi, their series or TV history. It takes us back to a place and time that will never be seen again. It has us breathing the same air and taking us back in time to Jamestown and a very special celebration. And you can join them too when you read this book.
Enthralling: The story pulled me in immediately and yanked me through to the end! Can hardly wait for book 2 to come out in January!
100 Days of Sunlight: This one instantly became a favorite.

Never Leave Me: I read the first book of the series a few months ago, and ever since, have been eagerly anticipating this one.
I found that Never Leave Me did not disappoint in the slightest! The time travel aspects were still there and we got to see characters from Come Back to Me.
The only complaint I have is a conversation at the end between Ellen and Harrison about children. It just seemed like they made the decision out of fear as opposed to believing that it was God's plan for them.
Unlike most Christian fiction, I only recommend this one to older teens and adults due to certain events in the story.
All that to say, I hope there is a book three, and I hope it comes out soon.

4 Stars

Content: some intense kissing

*I received a copy of this book from the publisher. All thoughts are my own and a positive review was not required.

The Sylvan and the Sand: First things first, I was seriously impressed with the interior of this book. The book is split into a few different sections and before each section was a gorgous piece of artwork that represented the coming chapters. This, my friends, is what Indie publishing can be.
Now, on to the story. I loved how much of a spitfire Yesenia was. She brought so much life to the story and handled her new environment very well. I also loved her influence on her husband. He was quite a pushover at the beginning of the story, but eventually stood up for himself and Yesenia.
Another aspect of the book that I liked was that the characters spoke with a bit of an accent, and that was portryated in the spelling of words. None of it was difficult to understand, and honestly, it was my favorite part.
As a fair warning, there are a lot of politics between the kingdoms in the beginning of the story. There were a lot of names and it was a lot to keep up with. I ended up having to skim that section, but it did not detract from the story at all.
I would recommend The Sylvan and the Sand for fans of Serpent & Dove.

Tropes: forced marriage, enemies to lovers

Content: there were some *ahem* married scenes (easy to skip), attempted r*pe (stopped), Yesenia's past love wanted a relationship with her even though they were both married (she said no), mentions of Yesenia's previous romantic relationships, made up and real cursing

Note: Technically this is listed as YA, however due to the subject matter and content, I would call it NA.

4 Stars

*I received a copy of this book from the author. All thoughts are my own and a positive review was not required.

A long-dead blackmailer still wreaks havoc on Sugarland: Angie Fox’s Give Up the Ghost explores the aftermath of opening the Sugarland time capsule. Verity Long, along with the rest of the town, is stunned when her sister Melody pulls Erma Sue Bryce’s burn book out of the time capsule. While Erma Sue’s long dead, her reputation as a blackmailer hasn’t faded from the town’s memory. Her daughter Twyla reclaims the book, and the town settles into a period of unease while everyone waits to see how Twyla uses her mother’s book. When Twyla is found murdered (with Virginia Wydell standing over her body) and the book is stolen, Verity gets pulled into yet another murder mystery. This mystery has much higher personal stakes for her though. Of course, she’s concerned for Ellis since his mother might be charged with murder. But while trying to track down Erma Sue’s ghost to see if she knows anything about her daughter’s murder, Verity learns that Erma Sue’s sister grounded her spirit but that Erma Sue figured out a way to unground herself and move freely again. Learning how Erma Sue managed to free herself could be the answer that Frankie and Verity have looking for to free Frankie. When Verity finally locates Erma Sue, she isn’t particularly cooperative and won’t agree to help Frankie unless Verity can return her burn book to her. Verity assumes the killer has the burn book so now she has twice the motivation to solve Twyla’s murder. But this case puts Verity in the path of both a killer and the vengeful ghost of Erma Sue....can she survive them both?

I enjoyed Give Up the Ghost, although I did feel like the plot was a little rushed at points. I thought Ms. Fox did a wonderful job exploring Verity and Virginia’s relationship. They obviously have a fraught history, but this book really digs into Virginia’s history and explains how Virginia ended up such a difficult person. Although there’s no excuse for her past behavior (and wow is there a lot of horrific past behavior to discuss!), I feel like Verity helps Virginia in this book and that Virginia’s hopefully starting to see the error of her ways. I look forward to seeing if Virginia can continue to redeem herself in future books. I believe that a reformed Virginia could provide some interesting future plot lines.

Of course, Frankie always brings a lot of humor to this series. In Give Up the Ghost, he decides to take up horse racing....as an owner, which means that Verity suddenly has a ghostly race horse living on her back porch. As the story progresses, Frankie adds a family of ghostly goats to Verity’s home. This thrills her little skunk Lucy to no end; Verity, however, is less than amused. I enjoyed the animal additions to this book. Lucy’s antics with the horse and goats made me laugh. And I thought that the care Frankie shows his new charges exposes an gentle element of his nature that normally only comes out when his girlfriend Molly is involved. I’m curious to see if Ms. Fox will continue to explore Frankie’s connections to the animals and if this will be a turning point for his character.

I recommend Give Up the Ghost, although I wouldn’t advise readers to start the series with this book. I received an ARC from the author, but that did not influence my review.

Really enjoyed it!: I have mixed feelings about this book.

First, just let me say that I really enjoyed it and am obviously going to finish this amazing series!

Really loved and enjoyed the characters and how their relationships grew with each other. Particularly Dash. I need more of him because, to put it simply: he's mysterious, loyal, and protective and that makes him even more attractive and shmexy. (Yes, I'm well aware he's fictional.)

But how some of the story progressed is bugging me and honestly, I'm still not entirely sure why. Maybe it's because it's not where I necessarily saw it going or how I thought some characters arcs would progress? Not sure...

Once I have my full thoughts ordered and organized, I'll give an updated review but in the meantime, still read this awesome book. Because it is and you'll be glad ya did.
OUCH!: This might be the worst, basically illiterate, first sentence I've ever read in a novel.  Did no one edit this book?  Scary.  Have we really fallen this far?  Please, tell me.
Gift for three year old: He loves it!

As titanically ingenious as the best Agatha Christie: Ruth Ware has created the creepiest of houses, a techie’s dream of a totally connected home but one with the darkest of hearts.. Very unsettling even as you know the heroine must escape her fate. Twist after twist, shock after shock. Unguessable ending to the cleverest plot.

Fantastic addition to the series!: I didn't love this as much as the previous 2. It took forever for me to get into. Once I did though I couldn't put it down.

Atticus and Jericho are the sweetest couple. Their dynamic is different from what I was expecting.

This book is a little steamier and a bit more dark than the others. We also get a bit of a look at what I hope are future couples. (I'm shipping Avi and Felix HARD!)

Dark, twisted, funny, and sweet: As with every Onley James book we have to remember the books are for fun. The plots are solved super fast. This book took place over a few days.

I didn't love this book as much as I have the previous ones. I adored the characters as always. I can't quite put my finger on why I didn't enjoy this quite as much.

3.5 bumped to 4: As always with this series I have to prepare myself for some happenings I don’t typically read.

I’ve been so looking forward to Felix and Avi’s story. I really liked most of it. I just felt like it was more spice than I was expecting. This isn't a bad thing. I just wanted a little more to their story.

My favorite parts of this book were when the entire Mulvaney clan was on page. I’d absolutely love a novella of the entire group set 5-10 years after Thomas and Aiden’s story.

Less Than Zero: Beyond disappointing. Stanley Tucci may be a great actor but he is not a writer. His stories in this book are banal and even his descriptions of food lack any pizazz. I rarely write negative reviews but I feel cheated by the hype for this so-called book.

Great look into world religions: I've bought several of these types of books (specifically for kids), and this is the best one I have found so far. Whereas other books aimed at kids sometimes seem to be missing semi important aspects of the religion or culture, as far as I could tell, this one is pretty accurate.
Very pleased with order: 10Stars✓
Very pleased with order: 10Stars✓

Beautiful art and story: This was such a sweet and heartwarming story about a bear who won’t give up on finding his missing friend. He goes around asking other animals if they have seen mouse and along the way we learn more about their friendship. Beverly’s illustrations are gorgeous and detailed and full of charm. I wish I could live in mouse and Humphrey’s forest.
Hilarious: My kids love this book and the made up words still manage to work their way into our conversations. “How about a nice yunch?” I have bought many copies as gifts.

Beautiful story and illustrations: This was such a beautifully illustrated, sweet and heartwarming story of a little girl’s relationship with her grandfather. I used to fish with my grandpa when I was young and the pages of this book brought back many happy memories.

Inspiring and uplifting: Why be the future when you can be today? This book is not only beautifully written and spectacularly illustrated — it’s also anthem that every kid needs. The main character isn’t satisfied with the idea that she has to wait to be an adult to make a difference. Matt’s lyrical words inspire us as the illustrations take us through her journey of rallying the community to protect sea creature friends. Also included is the most adorable origami turtle step by step. Please excuse me while I go buy one of these for every kid I know.

A Colorful and Culturally-Rich Bedtime Story: Crafted animals that come to life? Yes please. This is such a sweet story about a multigenerational family that celebrates Indian culture and a bond between two sisters. When parents are at their wit's end over trying to get the youngest daughter to sleep, the magic of a folk art craft and story brought by their grandmother saves the day (or more accurately, the night.) Along with writing this story, the author has also created handcrafted artwork such as the embroidery motifs, cultural elements, fabric patterns and the background which can be seen throughout the book. The illustrations are reminiscent of a bright and colorful Indian tapestry, making this a warm and inviting bedtime story.

Fun and Inspiring: Growth mindset was not something I had as a kid. I thought you were either born to do something or you were not. I love how this book not only presents kids with roles they can aspire to fill, but also reassures them that even if their goals don’t come easily, that’s ok. Even our smallest members of society can do hard and important things. The mirror at the end of the story ensures that every kid will truly be able to see themselves in this book. The colorful illustrations, cadence and the repetition make this a fun and engaging read.
