review: otherworldly at times. I felt that I was there.: This book is for people that like snow, isolation and beauty. Oh and evil. Or is it? Never a dull moment. A'yuh

Excellent read!: Great plot and moves quickly through lots of action. Tough to predict what will come next but keeps one anxious to find out and get to the next situation. If you like a tough guy who gets things done and is still believable, you will love reading this set. Enjoy!!

Fun but not enough: This is an enjoyable runthrough of Brooks's work but without
a lot of substance beyond his reminiscences of his
early years -- youth, army, live TV. The stories about his
films are amusing but superficial. Everyone he worked
with is talented and wonderful. No dark clouds ever appeared
on his horizon, even very much when he fought
the Nazis (or the "Narzis," as he recalled Churchill
calling them). I recommend Patrick McGilligan's thorough biography
for a more detailed, investigative, honest look into Brooks's actual life and work.

Best exposition of Brown v. Board of Education: Within this book is the best exposition of Brown v. Board of Education I have ever read. I was born not long after the decision and grew up in a still-largely-segregated southern state, so I saw some of the changes, often very slow changes, from this important decision after if happened. The context provided by the book provides great insight into getting things done in America. Beyond that I enjoyed the history of California politics from the point of view of the shaping of Earl Warren. Amazing to us today that he was a Republican. This is a truly excellent biography.

Beautiful book for a worthy cause!: Great, easy crochet patterns for kitty blankets to donate to shelter pets. Linda's story and cause are well worth anyone's time. A must have for any crafter and pet lover!
cute: A cute rhyming story.  This was a story/coloring book combo.  I read it to 3 kids and they thought it was fun though felt it was too short.  Lovely illustrations

Hilarious: This is such a wonderful rhyming story of a little boy that needs 2 minutes more and then another 2 and so on, exactly how most children are. It flows and moves quite nicely and you know that something is bound to happen, but I didn't expect that ending - it's hysterical.  Love it!

Another GREAT hit!: This is definitely another home run for this talented author!
The illustrations are just beautiful. The rhyming story will have kids giggling for hours.
Aside from being such a wonderfully written silly story, this is the perfect read for children to understand and see the inner beauty in everyone! With a little thought, persistence (not to mention some soap and a comb), and a lot of KINDNESS too, inner beauty is bound to shine through. Absolutely, without a doubt, I highly recommend this book. One of my new favorite authors and I can't wait for the next one.

Inspiring Story: This uplifting story is one of hope and friendship.  It reinforces the lesson of feeling grateful for not only what we have but whom we have in our lives.  The hand-drawn illustrations are wonderful and the underlying message is that things don't always go as planned and that we must learn to adapt to situations beyond our control such as the pandemic.  Perseverance and kindness win every time.  This book is however best suited for older children.

Great Story: An absolutely adorable story teaching about diversity, and the love of family and family bonding.
Imaginations run wild at Gramma's house when she helps the girls build a Princess Castle. Dress up, wear Royal jewels, and dance and twirl like real princesses. Nobody likes to stop having fun when told it's time to leave and excitement turns to sadness. Gramma reassures the girls of her love for them and that they will play again. Highly recommend this story.

A great resource: Captain Curriculum and Tracy Transition to the rescue! Many children have difficulties transitioning from one activity to the next.  In this wonderful story, the teacher has a hard time keeping the kids focused in circle time, that is until superheroes Captain C and Tracy T swoop in and save the day.  The illustrations are great.  The story is one that both children and teachers should read to ensure that they are all aware of the importance of following a schedule and moving from one activity to the next without havoc breaking out in the classroom.  I highly recommend this book.

We're not going back to March, 2020. This book shows you how to succeed going forward.: People Leaders - For 570+ days you've probably been leading your people virtually (or you were doing it long before then.) So let me ask you, how have you changed your expectations in engaging your team?

If you are like us, when COVID first hit we just shifted everything to Zoom but didn't really make changes to the structure or content. We quickly learned this was the WRONG approach.

I recently had the opportunity to do an early read of Dr. Betty Johnson's new book Making Virtual Work: How to Build Performance and Relationships and boy do I wish I'd have had it in March, 2020.

This fast read book is a great reference tool to sanity check how you are working with your teams. My favorite chapter is How to Do What Helps which provides you with the full recipe on how to structure your meetings to not only make them more productive but also less stressful to your team.

My favorite part is the focus on the meetings you SHOULDN'T have. Using tools like Slack to do asynchronous "Give me an update" interactions instead of having a meeting and going around the table can free your people to both focus on the tasks at hand and make the rest of your meetings more useful.

If your company is like ours, we aren't going back to life pre-COVID so your ability to be a successful people leader virtually will help you succeed and be a leader that people want to work for.

#makingvirtualwork

This is a good place to start your leadership learning: Note - I was provided an early edition of this book to review.

I was promoted into my first professional leadership role in 1988. Prior to that promotion, I had spent 3 years reading everything I could get my hands on regarding sales and leadership. I wish I had been given a book like this when I was going through that learning journey.

The authors admit right up front that this is not a comprehensive study on leadership. They use this book to introduce their concept of leadership with they term LEADERS. This stands for Leadership, Ethics, Alignment, Decision Making, Engagement, Resilience, and Stewardship. In each chapter, they dive down into the key points around that particular skill and then align it to their SIC which stands for Service, Inclusion, and Communication which defines the role that each takes in successfully executing this skill.

Throughout the book, the authors introduce concepts from a wide variety of thought leaders and authors. This makes this book function like a Syllabus for your continued learning about leadership. When you want to go deeper into a subject, the authors they quote will provide you with a great jumping-off point.

My only significant issue with this book is that the authors had previously written a leadership book which they constantly reference throughout this book. Sometimes up to half a page and rarely going more than 4-5 pages without mentioning it. I would have liked to have either seen them write a new edition of their previous book and incorporate the new info from this book into it or not reference their previous book at all.

So if you are starting a journey into leadership, I do recommend this as a useful jumping-off point.

Become that Wayfinder: Gartner has shared research recently that customers are only spending 17% of the time in their buying journey with the vendors they are considering. Think about that, if they are looking at you and 2 competitors, you are only getting about 5% of their ENTIRE buying journey to make an impact for your product and service.

So how are you going to differentiate?

I would recommend you dive into Anthony Iannarino's new book Elite Sales Strategies. This book focuses on the skills for being truly consultative and helping your customers move from a position of "One Down" to a position of "One Up". What is One Up and Down?

When you are One Up, you have insight that can help the person you are with effectively navigate their journey. Your mission is not to hold being One Up over their head, but to help them move from a position of One Down to One Up by sharing that insight.

In many sales situations, this may be the first time (or if you are lucky second) that your customer has made this specific purchase. You on the other hand, are helping people navigate this journey everyday so you have One Up insight that will benefit them in being as successful as possible.

Several years ago, Gartner started discussing the concept of Wayfinding. No they weren't giving a review of Disney's Moana, they were focused on Sales Pro's helping their clients navigate their own buying journey. In this book Anthony can arm to you be that Wayfinder.

Edge of seat, once again: OMG! How can Pamela Fagan Hutchins keep coming up with such intriguing story lines? Dr. Flint and his family are wrapped up in yet another murder. And once again I was at the edge of my seat, holding my breath at times. A fun mystery and easy read. Puts you right in the middle of all the action. If you've read the other Patrick Flint books, you won't want to miss this one.

Riviting, Well worth it.: If you've read the first 3 Patrink Flint books you will want to read these next 3. One adventure after another. The author writes putting you in the book. You see the landscape. You see the characters. You become the book. Truly amazing.

Not disappointed!: Wow! Pamela  Fagan Hutchins hit another homerun on Seeking Felicity. This book, like all her others, keep you reading wanting to know what will happen next. Will Katie find the killer? Will she and Jack ever get that long awaited honeymoon? Another action packed book. Don't miss it!

Thrilling!: And she does it again! A new series that is a riveting as the rest. Love how the Patrick Flynt kids have grown up in this 1st of the new Jennifer series. You can't go wrong reading this new book or any of Pamela's.
WOW!!: How does Pamela Fagan Hutchins keep doing this? Sitting Duck is one that you cannot put down from the beginning to the end. Love, love the Patrick Flint novels. You will never be disappointed.

Great for all levels of writers: The book walks you through beginning questions and activities, and continues through the phases of writing.

Each exercise can be returned to, or slightly tweaked.

Inventive and fun: The illustrations are, first and foremost, active and exciting. There are minimal words on the pages, but they are perfectly matched to the movement of the pages and invite readers to enjoy. It made for a fast and fun family read.

From the 8 yr old: I LOVE this book: I chose to write this review as my child dictated it, because from the first page of the book, she was hooked. She saw herself in Vanessa - - yearning to stand out and be special, but also hoping to be an accepted part of the group. She's even donned her fair share of tutus and hair bobbles and sparkly things to add pizzaz to her school look.

From the 8-year-old: I LOVE this book! When her mom said her name meaned "butterfly," I was so happy for her. Vanessa is like me because I love picking out outfits. I wanna be liked. I wanna make friends. I was happy when she [Vanessa] went to school again with her drawing.

A book about responsibility and teamwork: Sir Simon: Super Scarer

This new book is all about responsibility. Did you know that ghosts have quite a few chores?

What is an ambitious ghost who needs some free time in his schedule to do? Delegate, of course. And who better to delegate to than a kid in the home you're haunting?

Sir Simon is a funny new book from Cal Atkinson that is sure to be a fun favorite read.

My 9 year old repeats the mantra from this book!: Told in a well-constructed rhyme, this story shares with its readers the power in self-affirmation. Despite being scared, Lola continues on her trek home and along the way is reminded that her strength and courage is within.

My daughter especially appreciated the dedication to the real Lola, who bravely battled cancer. Having this at the beginning of the book sparked conversation.

A grim mystery with all the right twists.: Two days before I started reading A Different Dawn I had headed a discussion for my book club on mystery as a genre. During a tour of the different sub-genre's, we had discussed "hard boiled" fiction. The point had been made that there has been a paucity of women authors in that category, but things were getting better. With A Different Dawn, Isabella Maldonado takes over a big spot on that particular stage. She has a solid detective in Nina Guerrera, the story moves fast and hard, there is a nod to modern forensic science and a respect for the action we all expect from this type of mystery. The fact that the hero is female and Latina makes all of this newer, better and richer.
So why four instead of five stars? The coincidence that forms the heart of the story is a stretch even for someone who happily enters the realm of a "willing suspension of disbelief." I also wanted the book to be a bit longer. Maldonado needed to flesh out the bad guy a bit more. That being said, her description of a narcissistic psychopath struck so close to someone we all know that I gasped!
No question, I will be buying the prequel and the sequel to this book.

Great read!: This is an awesome book!  Reading about some of the obstacles our military people deal with upon their return is heartbreaking and yet so informative. Having their family to help them is so vital! I have known people who were involved in war and I don't know how they cope as well as some of them do. I recommend this book!

A Superb Book about A Superb (and ornery) Dog by a Superb Writer: I read everything that is written by Rick Bragg, I believe he is the best writer in this generation. And as a dog writer, I was predisposed to like this title. Speck, is an ornery, mangy mutt that has a host of bad habits and refuses to learn from his mistakes. Bragg is a consummate dog owner and joins Speck on his dangerous journeys, strolls around the property, and just sitting on the front porch. Throughout Speck’s time at the Bragg household, they navigate old age, many unknowns in the early Pandemic days, and family illness,  but through it all, Speck serves as a healing presence (although with occasional lapses into interesting and dangerous situations) for the family. Please read this book!

The best yet!: I have read all of the books in order, Matt has really developed as an author. All are excellent, Last Redemption is absolutely outstanding. I'm native to La Jolla, knowing all of the locations depicted in the book make it even better.

The only thing I don't like is having to wait until next year for the next book!

The gritty details of a glorious outcome: Conventional wisdom is that James Madison wrote the Constitution. This book is a five-month trip from conception to birth of a document second only to the Bible in its influence on the United States. That the document has been so seldom amended attests to wisdom and long-term perspective rarely seen in today's political processes.

compelling story: well crafted, an important read for all investors ...a great tale of rapture of the digital deep..the authors bring a direct and highly informed perspective ....important read for these days of halcyon valuations, memes, FOMO, story stocks and just tons of capital floating around

another good read: I have enjoyed every one of his books, good solid stories , very good writing. While I am a bit more pro RA, his books are all so far got me...I practically don't put them down.You don't have to be Irish to love McKinty...I'm starting The Chain tonight!
Excellent: I’m appreciated this book to getting education. Thank You.

A divine world!: I thoroughly enjoyed immersing myself in Sandra L Young’s Divine Vintage world! The characters are so well-written and appealing, the storyline is intriguing, and paranormal links between the past and present storylines were so engaging that I could hardly put the book down. Paranormal isn’t usually my  proverbial  cup of tea, but dual timelines and mysteries are, and I found myself enjoying all three aspects of Divine Vintage equally. Well done, Sandra - I’ll happily read whatever you write next! Thank you Wild Rose Press, Sandra L Young, and Net Galley for the ARC in exchange for an honest review.

Engaging and immersive: I thoroughly enjoyed Exiled South and protagonist Lizbeth Gordon’s quest to align what she knows of her cultural heritage and what she discovers when she delves deeper into her family’s history.
Many of the truths she uncovers are heartbreaking and poignant and others, such as the migration of Southerners to Brazil during Reconstruction, were fascinating and previously unknown to me. As a history buff, that last bit alone was a lagniappe to Lizbeth’s engaging and immersive story.
I highly recommend Exiled South, with Harriet Cannon' s wonderfully crafted storylines, characters, and locations, to historical fiction fans.
Fun Books: My daughter loves these books, she checked them out from her school library so :) it will be nice to see her reaction when she opens these up for Christmas, thank you :)

Good Book: I remember reading this book in high school, my best friend and I at the time enjoyed it, I happened to remember it while looking around at the library recently so I bought it.

Strong Female: Whenever I can find a book with a strong female heroine, I'm all in. But to also have that heroine introduce my students to the beautiful folklore of the Hmong, a culture many of them are unfamiliar with, so much the better. The story is engaging, action-packed, and the imagination level of the author, Lori M. Less, is off the charts fantastic. I found so many ways to integrate this wonderful story as part of a writing, activity, and creativity unit for my elementary students. I can hardly wait for the next book in the Pahua series to drop!

history: B0030MTPU6 B074ZNJQ8Y B06XBHBZ88 B0089EHWT6 B000RH0ESO B07THF6TX7 1658188764
review: Another wonderful series: I really enjoyed this introduction to her third series. The book was a quick fun read with the promise of rich character development as the series continues.  It will be interesting to see if sex becomes a major factor in the metaphysical part of this world.

Great mystery book: Clara is the main character in the story.  It seems that one day each year she has bad luck.  That day is coming soon, and she is dreading it.  She is almost destroyed, but she still puts one foot in front of the other.  It is a great story, and through many twists and turns, she finally solves the problem.  I would recommend reading this book.

Violence, Sex, Love, and Growth: This book is an emotional roller coaster.  You are going to need some tissues and a strong stomach to make it through. It is an amazing book, I highly recommend reading it if you don't have any triggers.  There is a lot of abrasive scenes played out through the whole book.  That aside the story line of this book is amazing.  It kept me turning the page and reading as fast as I could through the whole book.  I couldn't put it down, I had to know what happened next.  There is huge character development for the leading lady in this story. She is a bada$$ with an amazing will to survive the crap life has dealt her.  There are times you will want to smack her but seriously who makes the best decisions all the time.  Having a book be able to pull that type of emotion out of the reader is a true testament as to how well it is written.  I highly recommend this book as an escape from reality.

Incredibly different and very refreshing: First thing first, this is the 5th book in the series and if you haven't read the others in the series; you will be a little lost. I am not saying that you can't read this one and figure things out but it would be easier to understand if you read the whole series. This book reads beautifully. The words that are written seem to jump off the pages. This book has a little something for everyone. It has action, vampires, humans, danger, adventure, a huge political tone, tension, romance, and dystopia. You will be hooked after the first chapter. This book will take you on so many twists and turns that you won't want to stop reading. This book is not your typical vampire book either, which was a huge surprise to me. I felt while reading this that I haven't read anything quite like it before. It was a rush to be able to not know what was going to happen. After having read certain genres of books, I almost feel like at times I can somewhat predict what is going to happen or I have a few ideas as to what might happen. Well, whatever I thought was going to happen didn't. It was amazing and such a fresh look into a concept that I hadn't even dreamed of with paranormal writing. The growth of the characters throughout the book is sensational. Rowena one of the main characters goes through some difficult revelations but comes out better on the other side. I highly recommend this book to anyone. Especially, if you are looking for a different perspective in paranormal stories.

A woman's courage to overcome all sorts of tragedy.: This book is not in my normal wheel house, so I was a little apprehensive to start it. I was completely blown away with this book. The way it is written gives you all the feelings that you could ever dream of. It shows a very strong determined female lead. She goes through many trials and tribulations throughout this book trying to make sure that she actually does something with her life. This is completely unheard of during the WWII time frame and gives my inner feminist a pep rally so to speak. Knowing that this story is inspired by true events makes it even better. It is like a birds eye view as to how women were treated during the 1920's. It will make you realized how far women's rights have come and yet how far they need to go. The constant ups and downs that the main character goes through is gut wrenching and inspiring. I felt raw and vulnerable while reading this and I didn't want it to end. It was an amazing escape from my normal genre and I am so glad that I took the adventure. I highly recommend this book to anyone who just wants to see a woman thrive through what most would consider huge life decisions and tragedies.

A bet can destroy the trajectory of you life.: The Titans of Manhattan series does not disappoint with this 4th installment. This book is an easy read and a page turner. It takes you on a roller coaster of emotions. The main characters met in high school and a bet led to a series of events that unfolded both good and bad. 10 years later, they see each other again with a job on the line. Can they overcome what happened in high school that changed the trajectory of events for them? Can the hurt ever go away? When the female lead thought she had overcome everything that had transpired just to see the male lead and realize she wasn't as over things as she thought. This book is really well written and the angst, family issues, torture, secrets and love will have you reading all the way through the night. You want to see what will happen and you become physically and emotionally involved in the progress of the characters. Don't get me wrong there will be times that you are mad like spitting nails mad but it doesn't last that long.

Great Expanse if Walking: This book takes our most basic movement, walking, and makes it more. There are exercises and techniques. I received this book as an ARC and this is my honest and voluntary review.

Keeps you guessing!: Start with a battle, take a treacherous journey, find betrayal and incarceration, then add in a bit of magic, mayhem and mystery and you have an extremely enticing tale. Bennett once again reveals an amazing story that will captivate readers and keep them wanting more. Athgar, Natalia and friends are kept spinning as the family moves to control all. Don’t miss this one!
Made me cry: The emotional impact of this book killed me but I NEED book 2!
Den of Vipers lover's: If you loved den of Vipers then you will love the men and female lead as they are all a special kind of crazy!
Wild: This book was absolutely wild!!! I lived the take on shifters! Couldn't get enough of it. Thank you to the author of the book.

Beautiful Queer Love Story: This book made me cry no less than five times. A beautiful queer love story, found family, realistic conversations surrounding mental health... I cannot do it justice. Grace Porter is the protagonist I needed.
A Modern Twist on Jane Eyre - Fun Read!: A thrilling twist on Jane Eyre, such a great way to bring the story into the modern era and make it something fresh and unexpected.

Unique Fairytale Fusion: A wonderfully grim reimagining and fusion of different fairy tales that held my attention as I devoured the story. Gisela is a captivating protagonist, strong and clever, and Brahm stole my heart as he coveted Gisela's! Rosalyn Briar continues to impress!

The Poly Love Story I Needed: A beautifully original romance that intrigues and delights all the way through! Ingrid, Lilura, and Soren are such great protagonists and the way their relationships grow throughout the book is so enjoyable to read!

Captivating & Hauntingly Beautiful: It's been a while since I read a book within a day, and it was totally worth it! The language utilized is so visual and it gets under your skin in the best way possible. I was gripped by the building suspense all the way until it came to a head. Yet another brilliant book by Moreno-Garcia!

Wonderful Story in Wonderful Shape: I bought this book back in 1970 and was thoroughly enchanted and entertained. Now, 52 years later, I’ve gotten another near pristine copy that I can pass to my grandkids. Thank you!

Wow! Ryan Holiday lays out the first pillar of Stoicism: Ryan has outdone himself. He nailed what courage is and what it requires. The chapters are short and focused. He is truly a modern-day Stoic Master. I've learned so much for this young man this past year. Bravo!

Enthralling time travel romance: This was a highly anticipated book for me, and it did not disappoint! It has a great romance, lots of historical details that bring the past to life, and scientific explanations that make the time travel element feel possible and realistic. Five stars! I wish there were more books planned for this series.

Interesting look at a familiar story: Though there weren’t a ton of surprises about Joseph’s story, which is pretty well documented and described in Genesis, I really enjoyed reading Judah’s story. I thought the author did a good job of filling in the gaps to show what he might have been thinking and feeling to make the decisions he did.

Sweet, clean romance: I would say this book was fine. The story is unique with a twist I didn’t expect about 25% of the way in, but it’s not the best book I’ve read by Rachel Fordham. It seemed like she was a little off her game with this one, although I thought it wrapped nicely. If you want a super sweet romance with second chances and forgiveness then Where the Road Bends might be for you.

Not a standalone nor a cliff hanger: This book was almost perfect. I adored the main character and the love interest. I said WTF once while reading due to a plot twist. The only thing I wasn't super happy about was that this reads like a stand alone. There is an ending, but it's only the first story in the series. I feel like it may have been a little better if the book ended about 30 pages sooner and left it on a cliffhanger.
The ending....: The ending was rushed and unsatisfying. The rest of the book was really good and I enjoyed the progression until the last 50 pages.
Nothing spectacular here: I was disappointed with this book.  Thought it would be better.

Great book!: This book will walk you through the process of building a home with forms, checklists etc.  This book will give you confidence to build and manage your own build while saving lots of money.  I know how to build a home, yet this book gave me ideas and additional knowledge that I wasn’t thinking about.  If I were a beginner, I’d buy this book and read it twice before attempting to build your own home.  Think about this, the investment and time putting into this book will payoff huge amount of return on investment.  Follow the book and it’s worksheets.  There is a lot to read and absorb, but you can do this!  Time is your friend.  Put the work into this book and reap the rewards of the knowledge you obtain and apply to building your home.

Unimpressive…Most Unimpressive.: I had such high hopes, but unfortunately this book falls well short of cool. Let me start by saying anything set in a sci-fi version of feudal Japan, especially a Star Wars setting, has the potential for awesomeness. However, this book is not awesome, despite its cool setting. The cumbersome plot follows Ronin. A former Sith warrior on a quest for redemption (?). Along his journey he meets a colorful cast of characters much like every other SW story we’ve seen in the past few years. Since Disney bought out the SW franchise the novels have been mostly garbage. Sadly, this book is no different. I thought the Visions shorts were mostly cool, with the Kurosawa-esque Ronin by far the coolest. When I saw a novelization of this story I was stoked to read it and further explore this world. After the first few pages I realized my mistake in thinking this was going to be an exciting, quick read. The author’s writing style is very confusing and almost unreadable at times. Very little character development, unclear syntax, and disjointed chapters make it so you have to reread whole chapters multiple times to really get what’s going on (and sometimes that doesn’t even help). Halfway through the book I was still unclear as to what was going on with the main character. In addition to poor writing, the author further confuses us with some of the characters by giving them multiple names and with the “Traveler” character constantly refers to this figure as they or them…which is very confusing when describing actions of the group. I understand if you want to be PC, but find another way to display your open-mindedness. One that doesn’t confuse your readers, please.
Overall, this was a good attempt at doing something different with the SW franchise, but it falls well short of the mark due to horrible writing and a nonsensical plot—which I didn’t really touch on in this review. Just know that the plot is hard to follow and unclear.

You must read this if you hate spiders: I have nothing but praise for Leslie Brunetta and Catherine Craig for their collaboration.

They have not only communicated the science, but managed some surprising humor like their review of Spider-man's underwear on page 68.

Not only do they clearly present the evolution of spiders from their most ancient origin, but they make us respect their positive contribution to life today.
Good read: Classic dinosaur stories

Immersive, historical fiction, survival story: Kristin Harmel has become my go-to author for historical fiction. Kristin has created an immersive, emotional, achingly beautifully written story unlike anything I’ve read in the World War 2 time frame. The amount of research and time she spent getting the smallest details of the story right shines on each page of The Forest of Vanishing Stars. I felt Harmel’s heart on each page and have watched the emotion she shows talking about this story in interviews. As I was reading, I truly felt the cold of the forest in the dead of winter and the freshness of the locally foraged food. I heard the snap of a tree branch and stomping footprints in the snow. I felt like I was right there in the forest with Yona with my senses heightened, struggling to survive. The character of Yona will stay with me forever. The way Yona emerged from a sheltered childhood in the forest into a young woman who was deeply connected to nature of other’s needs and feelings was a beautiful story to read. People like Yona and the real life Bielski brothers, who’s story gave Harmel the idea for this book, are real life heroes, standing up to the atrocities and risking their own lives to save others. With tears streaming down my face and my breath held, I was both quickly turning the pages and anxious to see how Yona’s story unfolded at the end…

Yona, stolen at age two and raised solely in the forest by an elderly woman until her 20’s, faced a new reality after the woman’s death. Although she felt most at home in the forest, she was also drawn to the nearby villages. Quickly, Yona finds out what horrible things are happening to the Jews during World War 2 and bring Jewish refugees into the forest and helps them survive often putting herself at risk. Yona’s story largely takes place during the span of a couple years in the heart of World War 2. When a person from her past reemerges, Yona must decide what part of this war she wants to be on. Yona lived such a sheltered life and was let down by people she trusted and cared about, but still possessed the innate ability to be kind and caring towards each other. Human kindness and empathy shine throughout this story and is perhaps the biggest takeaway for me from The Forest of Vanishing Stars.
I can’t wait to read Harmel’s next story, however I don’t know how it can beat the world she created in The Forest of Vanishing Stars. An absolute must-read for any World War 2 historical fiction lovers.
Thank you NetGalley for my ARC of The Forest of Vanishing Stars.

check your books: Story is pretty good. However, I'm missing 49 pages toward the end of the book. I guess for any book purchased from Amazon, you need to count to see if all of the pages are actually there. I missed the return date by almost two months, although I didn't start reading the book until last week.

Lesson to be learned, don't trust Amazon to provide a good product. I certainly will review every book purchased from Amazon from now on to see if all of the pages are there.

Beautiful book about healing and strength: Lemon Drop Falls was a quick and emotional read that ended on a sweet note. Middle schooler Morgan takes her mother’s last words very seriously when she dies unexpectedly leaving behind a husband and three children. Morgan takes on a huge amount of responsibility caring for her siblings Janie and Budgie. She believes it is her duty to prevent her grieving Dad from feeling any more stress, even though she struggles with her own anxiety. She makes sacrifices in her social life such as giving up soccer and spending less time with her friends to take over duties at home.
The book was told in alternating chapters of before and after her mom’s death and the important backstory unfolds beautifully through this style. I made connections to several other books as I read such as The Canyon’s Edge and Ten Thousand Tries. Morgan is determined, giving, and responsible, but angry at the cards she has been dealt. Her risky adventure nearly turns tragic, but it is just what she needs on her journey of healing. I appreciated the realistic conversations amongst the characters such as struggling friendships, anxiety, crushes and puberty. This makes the book very relatable for my middle schoolers. I will be offering this as a book club choice for my next unit.

Recipe for success: So many students will connect to this book! Elliott has a lot going on in his life. His dad and stepmom are expecting a new baby very soon, he has a major group project at school that is a huge part of his grade, and he is struggling to deal with his ADHD. There is an “incident” that gets explained as the book progresses that affects his relationship with his dad and causes tension. Despite Elliott’s problems, he is kind, creative, notices so much about others, is a great listener, and a talented chef. He uses his gifts to pair with one of the most popular girls in school, who has celiac disease, on a group project. Elliott feels so out of control unless he is in the kitchen, and he learns you sometimes you can’t just throw things together. The author has the right recipe with just the right amount of humor, a dash of sadness as you feel for Elliott, and a taste of inspiration. This book will help students develop empathy and will entertain them as well.

A novel about shifting perspectives: This is Monica Ali’s most personal novel, about mothers and daughters, mothers and sons, about love, marriage and the assumptions we all make about the people we love.

Excited for the next in the series!: Thank you to NetGalley and Tor books for the ARC in exchange for my honest review.

I need the next book like right now! Ugh I'm sad I have to wait but it looks like it should be coming out soon (this year sometime) so that's good. Really interesting magic system/world, I love how different all the characters are and how they interact with each other. And oh man did things get interesting at the end!

Unique & Fun: If you’re a fan of diamond painting, you need this book! The symbols are a fun way to spice up the color by number experience with something many are already familiar with. I much prefer this to actual diamond painting because you get results much faster! The fun colored animals were a great choice to try this type of book on. Loved all the zodiac signs! It was so much fun hunting down all the symbols on the page. I also love the small circles! Curious to see if they will release more color by symbol books. I know I’ll definitely be buying them if they do!

review: Christmas Owl Cuteness: Fantastic book! Owls are cute enough as it is, but add some festive flair and you’ve got a cuteness overload! This would make a great gift for yourself or any owl enthusiast during the holiday season. The circles are so relaxing to color in and the superior paper is a dream to work with. The color palettes are always fun and well selected. A++

Epic adventure--definitely recommend!: This book blew me away. The worldbuilding is so rich and incredible, and I loved discovering all the different elements of the magical horses. The characters are amazing, and I loved watching the development of their arcs. That ending though...it was perfect for a book one--it wrapped up very well yet left me needing the next book way sooner than it's supposed to come out. This will definitely be a reread for me, and I'd recommend it 1000%!

Fantastic continuation of the series!: How can it end there...now I desperately need the next book! Ronie Kendig continues to surprise with allll the plot twists and ramp up the stakes in this epic saga. Loved this book, and can't wait to see where the story will go next!

Ultra Romantic with a Touch of Epic Adventure: Searching for a new and exciting couple? Meet Beth and Sheridan. (Except one of them does not have the same conviction that the other one is a perfect match.) The adventures are exciting, daring, and well written, but these two will keep the pages turning. Fall in love with them, even if they don't fall in love with each other!

There are a few pertinent events from The Nature of a Lady, book 1, that are key to understanding the magnitude of several parts of To Treasure an Heiress, but the character chatter and inspiration is easy enough to grasp. Instead of being a continuation of Oliver and Libby's story, these pages open with Beth, the missing Elizabeth from book 1, as she still struggles without adequate tangible proof of a pirate prince's treasure. The archeological world becomes a lot smaller over the period of a month and Beth has to decide who to trust with her heart and her knowledge.

Overall, a fabulous read and I highly suggest To Treasure an Heiress! I received a copy of this book from the publisher and was not required to write a review. The gush and excitement over this story is well deserved!

Excellent book!: This book marks the 20th anniversary of 9/11. It brings you back to that day through the eyes of Battalion Chief, Joseph Pfeifer. It is not only about the tragedy, but gives you insight into the lives of him, his family, his firefighter brother who died saving people in the towers, some of the other firefighters, and the filmmaker brothers who documented that history period in our history.
Very well written book: Excellent book I wish some of the lesser known actresses had more on there chapters still an all around excellent book for film lovers 5 stars!!
Great Gift!: My nephew received in seven days and loves it!

A Must Read: I have read dozens of books about Manson (don’t judge!) and I consider this book to be one of the best - In fact,  I would put it in my top three with Helter Skelter and Member of the Family. Vince Bugliosi (Prosecutor), Dianne Lake (Family member), and Ivor Davis (Reporter) were all deeply involved in the actual scene.

Great Read: Feehan never fails - her books keep
me up at night. Great read!

Ah, nostalgia...: Bright colors, horrifying monsters, damsels in distress. This was the art that sold the pulps way back when. And this book covers the who, what, when where and why of it all. Was surprising to know that Leyendecker illustrated images meant to place these outrageous tales into the hands of avid readers. Just like comic books, the images displayed on the cover were designed to capture the imagination, attention, and thus the dime of would-be readers. Even if you decide to forego the reading just to look at all the depictions of scantily-clad women, tied up and showing lots of cleavage, it's worth a look.

If you want a fun 'Day in the life' book, GET THIS ONE: Adam Ellis takes the reader on a fun ride via a series of incidents in his life. Things like The Chocolate Milk Incident (a lesson on morality...I think), World's Best Boss, Four Days Pretending to Be a Rabbit and Call of the Wild, all of them told in Adam's quirky yet delightfully appealing style. These are just a few of the adventures described in the book, the ones that appealed to me personally, but I'm sure just about anyone will find something in these pages that will make them chuckle. Good stuff.

We Must Remember: I’m a compulsive short story reader, from Eudora Welty and Marilynne Robinson to Margaret Atwood and Joyce Carol Oates. DC Diamondopolous doesn’t disappoint. I was engrossed from the first moment of interaction with each character in “Captured Up Close.” I followed their idiosyncratic stories, thinking how important it is that we give voice to lives that are harsh and unfair.

A hilarious middle grade about friendship and the future!: WELCOME TO DWEEB CLUB has it all—adventure, mystery, sci-fi, and laugh-out-loud humor! Readers will be sucked in instantly by the engaging characters and snappy dialogue. I HIGHLY recommend this hilarious middle-grade story about friendship and discovering who you want to be.
Must Read: Fans of THE LIST OF THINGS THAT WILL NOT CHANGE and WHERE WE USED TO ROAM are going to love this one!
Must Read MG: I adored this one! A fast paced story of friendship, bravery, and endless possibilities. It will help so many readers who have a family member struggling with addiction.

An Entertaining Crime Thriller: What I enjoyed is the slow pacing of the story. Every scene was described with great attention to detail, and each character was well-developed. It's not an action-packed story, because that's not what it needed to be; it's more of a character study.

There was some head hopping, and the grammar could have been better. Some character phrasing could have been more individualized and less American. Notwithstanding, it's still an entertaining crime thriller!

An Approachable Pride and Prejudice: Although the story of Jane Digby differs from that of Elizabelth Bennet, the tone and culture is similar, and it is easy to be transported to Jane Digby's adventures and travels. Where Pride and Prejudice is sometimes difficult to understand, Jane Digby's Diary is much more approachable and reader-friendly.

The descriptions that CR Hurst employs are very palpable and quite well-researched. As this is based on a real person, I can just imagine the joy of studying not only her life but all the historic details of exotic locales, cultural nuances of the time period, and contemporary concerns, and then incorporating them into the story with such mastery that it is easy to imagine the real life Jane DIgby.

I applaud the use of the diary technique, as it gives the reader an intimate portrayal of how she really feels in each stage of her life. So not only do we get a glimpse into her soul, but we relate to her, and we can experience that time period through her. I definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys historical fiction!

sorry, but i couldnt get into this one: the effort is there but the writing seems so scattered and disorganized. some of the rhymes feel awkward and dont flow well. maybe it just doesnt connect with me and i didnt care for the writing style

His best: I've read all FS Yousaf's books, and I thought Serenity was absolutely beautiful to experience. All in all, it's a really, really "pretty" read. I feel it had more substance and depth than Sincerely did, while taking on other topics besides romantic love. Well done!

returning: uninspiring, unoriginal, and seemed bland. nothing about the writing that stood out as amazing.
Gorgeous, emotional, thought-provoking poetry: I thought this book was excellent! The writing is affecting, resonant, and beautifully crafted.
